headline: Aubrey McClendon, Chesapeake Energy Ex-Chief, Dies Day After Indictment
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Authorities said Mr. McClendon, who built a fortune in shale gas across the country, was killed when his car drove into a bridge.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Aubrey McClendon was the face of the nation’s natural gas boom, a swashbuckling innovator who pioneered a shale revolution.

headline: Consult the Senate on a Court Nominee
abstract: A reader disagrees with The Times that President Obama is wasting his time consulting with the Senate leaders.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At Rochas, a ’60s Look With a Natural Glow
abstract: At the fall/winter 2016 show, models were given leftover mascara and “pillow effect” on their hair.
lead_paragraph: Though Rochas’s fall/winter 2016 collection heavily referenced the ’20s and ’30s, the hair and makeup both drew on later decades. “It’s a little bit ’60s, Bardot-inspired,” said the makeup artist Lynsey Alexander backstage. Skin was kept relatively bare and given a natural, well-moisturized glow. Alexander then applied Cle de Peau’s cream color eyeshadow in Pony, a delicate light beige, to eyelids, followed by a coat of mascara, which she promptly removed. The remaining hint of mascara at the lashes’ roots lent a deliberate “leftover” effect on the eyes, she said. But it was the salmon-peach lips that drew the most attention. Alexander swept on several layers of Cle de Peau’s Enriched Lip Lumizer in Peach Gelato, followed by a coat of translucent powder for a strong, matte finish.

headline: In Anna Sokolow’s Choreography, 1970s New York
abstract: Amid nostalgia for that time and place — found in HBO’s new series “Vinyl” and the novel “City on Fire” — Ms. Sokolow’s 1975 piece “Ride the Culture Loop” will be performed.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgia for 1970s New York is all the rage right now. HBO’s new series “Vinyl” and Garth Risk Hallberg’s acclaimed novel “City on Fire” frame the era through music. So what was dance seeing at the time? “Ride the Culture Loop,” a 1975 work by Anna Sokolow, captures the city’s vibrant diversity, restlessness and palpable tension through chaotic groupings and pounding fists.

headline: VW Says Old Memo Told Winterkorn of Emissions Irregularities
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: Volkswagen’s chief at the time received the information a year before the diesel scandal broke, but the company did not know if he read the memo.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen acknowledged on Wednesday that its former chief executive was given a memo in May 2014 that contained information about irregularities in the emissions of its diesel cars, well over a year before the company publicly admitted cheating on pollution tests.

headline: Julian Lage and His Sun-Dappled Americana
abstract: The celebrated guitarist and his trio will be performing at Rockwood Music Hall on Thursday, March 10.
lead_paragraph: The guitarist Julian Lage has been a celebrated talent for more than 20 years now, which is remarkable — mainly because he’s 28. Growing up in Northern California, he was hailed as a child prodigy, inspiring a documentary film titled “Jules at Eight.” Years later, he found a crucial mentor in the vibraphonist Gary Burton, who knew firsthand the pitfalls faced by a precocious soul making the leap into full artistry.

headline: Big Issues (and, Yes, Amour) Hit Rendez-Vous With French Cinema
abstract: Subjects at the Lincoln Center series include bereaved parents and the plight of immigrants in Europe, as well as the customary stormy love affairs.
lead_paragraph: No more stale pastries and flat Champagne. The persistence of sentimental nonsense that has tainted the Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series since its inception more than two decades ago is gone; in its place are hardheaded films on difficult subjects. Not an ooh-la-la is to be heard in this year’s series, which begins Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater.

headline: Letters: ‘Lit Up’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of David Denby’s “Lit Up,” Olga Grushin’s “Forty Rooms” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: It’s All in the Details
abstract: Updating: A runway look is more than the sum of its parts, as these fine points show. Some interesting details from the Paris shows.
lead_paragraph: Updating: A runway look is more than the sum of its parts, as these fine points show. Some interesting details from the Paris shows.

headline: A Swedish Girl, ISIS and a Cautionary Tale of Global Terrorism
abstract: The story of Marilyn Nevalainen stands out as a rare case in which a young European went unwittingly into the heart of jihadist territory and was freed.
lead_paragraph: MARK MUNICIPALITY, Sweden — It was a running-away-from-home nightmare for the age of global terrorism. Marilyn Nevalainen, a pregnant teenager, decided to follow her boyfriend last year when he set out to wage jihad, leaving the lakes and forests of southwest Sweden for life under the Islamic State in the desert heat of Iraq.

headline: At ‘Day of Drones,’ See What a Drone Sees
abstract: Top-notch drone filmmaking will be on display Sunday, March 6, at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: Despite concerns about the military (or mail-order) use of drones, there’s no denying that filmmakers can get some cool shots with them. On Sunday, March 6, top-notch drone filmmaking will be on display during an event called “Day of Drones” at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. There will be demonstrations by drone builders and pilots and an immersive experience with special goggles giving visitors a chance to see what a drone sees. The day will also include screenings of films from the second annual New York City Drone Film Festival, which takes place the day before. The films are diverse in style and subject, with a roster including “Lava Chaser” from National Geographic, “Sparked” from the performance troupe Cirque du Soleil and NBC News footage of the Nepal earthquake. As for live demonstrations, expect drone racing and a March Madness-style drone battle tournament. (Liberty State Park, lsc.org.)

headline: A Feast for Lovers of Classical Music
abstract: The delicacies include Spanish music by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and the soprano Karita Mattila and the pianist Martin Katz at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Thursday, March 10, will bring genuine conflict to a classical music lover’s life. These are just three of the concerts that evening, and each is a must hear.

headline: For the Cast of ‘She Loves Me,’ It’s the Sweet Smell of a Revival
abstract: Laura Benanti, Jane Krakowski, Zachary Levi and Gavin Creel talk about the return of a musical first presented on Broadway in 1963.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, audiences have found a tender affection — if not quite a burning infatuation — for “She Loves Me,” the musical that tells the story of two feuding perfume-shop employees, Georg and Amalia, who find epistolary romance as unknowing pen pals.

headline: Review: ‘The Circus’ Is Reality TV for a Reality-TV Presidential Race
abstract: Mark Halperin and John Heilemann digest the events on the presidential campaign trail, along with the local fried chicken, on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 election already has a reality-host front-runner and reality-TV trash-talking. It’s only fitting that it should also have its own reality show.

headline: Vaginal Delivery Tied to Higher Urinary Incontinence Risk
abstract: Having a child through vaginal delivery increases the risk for long-term urinary incontinence compared to having a cesarean delivery, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Having a child through vaginal delivery increases the risk for long-term urinary incontinence compared to having a cesarean delivery, researchers report.

headline: Saks Off 5th Set to Open in New York
abstract: Take in a film series with a French accent, jump into Paco Rabanne’s fall collection, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the designer outlet Saks Off 5th will open its first New York City location. It will include a Gilt shop-in-shop (after the acquisition of the luxury flash-sale site by Saks Fifth Avenue’s parent organization, Hudson Bay Company) that will feature weekly flash sales, starting with Zadig & Voltaire. Snag pieces like a faux-fur hooded jacket ($298, originally $650) for up to 70 percent off while you can. At 125 East 57th Street.

headline: Turkey Cracks Down on Insults to President Erdogan
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The justice minister revealed that 1,845 cases of insult crimes had been opened since August 2014, a reflection of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s authoritarian leadership style.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Since August 2014, 1,845 criminal cases have been opened against Turks for insulting their president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a crime that carries a penalty of up to four years in prison. Among the offenders are journalists, authors, politicians, a famous soccer star, even schoolchildren.

headline: It’s All in the Details at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Updating: A runway look is more than the sum of its parts, as these fine points show. Some interesting details from the Paris shows.
lead_paragraph: Updating: A runway look is more than the sum of its parts, as these fine points show. Some interesting details from the Paris shows.

headline: No Need for G.M.O. Labels
abstract: An official of a dairy association says G.M.O. products are safe and that any labeling rules should be national, not state by state.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Times Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, on racism in the Republican Party, John Kasich, profanity and John Oliver.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, on racism in the Republican Party, John Kasich, profanity and John Oliver.

headline: At Paris Fashion Week, All Eyes Will Be on Hedi Slimane
abstract: The designer’s next fashion show for Saint Laurent may also be his last.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hedi Slimane’s debut on Oct. 1, 2012, as the new creative and image director of Yves Saint Laurent, with a ready-to-wear collection he’d rebranded months before as, simply, Saint Laurent, was the news event of that Paris season.

headline: The Evolution of Hedi Slimane’s Saint Laurent
abstract: Select looks from the designer’s three years at the helm of the label.
lead_paragraph: Select looks from the designer’s three years at the helm of the label.

headline: Gov. Christie Looks Pensive and Perplexed in Donald Trump’s Shadow
abstract: Mr. Christie’s facial expression was a magnetic distraction from Mr. Trump’s Super Tuesday victory rant.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey proved mesmerizing on the presidential campaign trail Tuesday night merely by standing as silent and obedient as a man servant waiting behind his newly chosen political master, Donald Trump. Across long minutes, Mr. Christie’s facial expression proved a magnetic distraction for its pensiveness and perplexity as Mr. Trump delivered his Super Tuesday victory rant. Mr. Christie seemed preoccupied with wisps of might-have-beens or at least yet-to-be’s following his shocking embrace of the Trump machine.

headline: Beneath Hillary Clinton’s Super Tuesday Wins, Signs of Turnout Trouble
abstract: A drop in Democratic primary turnout has reached deeply into some of the core groups of voters Mrs. Clinton must not only win in November, but also draw in large numbers.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton set out 10 months ago to inspire and energize the Democratic Party, hoping to bring together the rising American electorate of black, brown, young and female voters into a durable presidential coalition. But buried beneath Mrs. Clinton’s wide-ranging and commanding victories on Tuesday night were troubling signs of a party that has not yet rallied to her call.

headline: Protecting Alberto Ginastera From Oblivion
abstract: Some works of the Argentine composer, who died in 1983, will be presented by Trinity Wall Street, whose music program has rebounded in recent years.
lead_paragraph: For an extravagant debut at its new home at Lincoln Center in 1966, the New York City Opera mounted the American premiere of Alberto Ginastera’s “Don Rodrigo.” With a youthful Plácido Domingo in the title role, the sexy and violent work required more than 200 musicians, the largest force of any City Opera production to date. According to The New York Times, Ginastera’s seething, atonal score was cheered by “an audience that contained seemingly everybody in New York music, philanthropy and society.” One critic proclaimed the opera a “12-tone ‘Otello’”; another called it “the ‘Wozzeck’ of the Western Hemisphere.”

headline: The Stephen Petronio Company Goes Into the Wild
abstract: Trisha Brown’s “Glacial Decoy” (1979), known for its stealthy critique of the proscenium, will be the centerpiece of Stephen Petronio Company’s annual Joyce Theater season.
lead_paragraph: When asked to “be nuttier,” the dancer Emily Stone hesitated. She was rehearsing a section of Trisha Brown’s 1979 “Glacial Decoy” with guidance from Stephen Petronio, who wanted to recapture the full abandon of the original, or at least his memory of the original.

headline: Super Tuesday Coverage Delivers Strong TV Ratings
keywords: ['Television', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'News and News Media', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Fox News broke a cable viewership record with its election coverage, and CNN achieved big gains over its numbers eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: The cable and broadcast networks have received more strong ratings for their coverage of Super Tuesday returns.

headline: Possible N.J. Transit Train Strike Raises Anxiety Among Commuters
abstract: The agency’s rail workers could walk off the job as early as March 13 if they do not reach a deal on pay and benefits.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the possibility of a rail strike starting next weekend, New Jersey commuters are increasingly worried about a shutdown that could paralyze the region and send them scrambling to find a way into New York City.

headline: In New York, Selling Movies as a Social Experience
abstract: Three new theaters say there are enough fans to support their screens, even though trends like streaming movies suggest otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Last month, when the Ziegfeld Theater, the ornate movie palace in Midtown Manhattan, was shuttered, its closing was yet another occasion for New Yorkers to bemoan a once-vital moviegoing culture now on the wane. But at least three multiscreen theaters opening in Manhattan and Brooklyn in the coming months still believe in cinema as a social experience.

headline: Man Accused of Gay-Bias Killing Says He Acted in Self-Defense
abstract: Elliot Morales admitted that he had gone to the West Village carrying a loaded revolver in 2013, and had gotten into a heated argument with two gay men.
lead_paragraph: A man charged with murdering a gay man in the West Village because of his sexual orientation testified on Wednesday that he had acted in self-defense because he believed he was about to be attacked. He denied that his motive had been a bigoted hatred toward gay people and said that he himself was bisexual.

headline: Stealing a Clear Look at an Elusive Star
abstract: Astronomers released a new image of rare O-type stars visible only using telescopes sensitive to certain wavelengths.
lead_paragraph: Gleaming through these crimson gas clouds are rarely seen, short-lived stars.

headline: A Victory for Transgender Rights in South Dakota
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'States (US)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gov. Dennis Daugaard’s veto of a misguided bill may have been informed by his meeting with young transgender South Dakotans.
lead_paragraph: It took courage for Gov. Dennis Daugaard of South Dakota to veto the misguided and harmful bill state lawmakers from his party passed last month in an effort to dictate which restrooms transgender students could use.

headline: Review: Daniel Lebhardt Shows Daring Command in a New York Debut
abstract: Mr. Lebhardt, only 23, impressed with his command during an adventurous program at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: Even before the 23-year-old Hungarian pianist Daniel Lebhardt began his New York debut recital on Tuesday night, I was impressed by the adventurous program he had chosen. For this performance at Merkin Concert Hall, Mr. Lebhardt, a winner of the Young Concert Artists International Auditions, played an overlooked Beethoven sonata, followed by the premiere of a substantive piece by Tonia Ko, ending with a cornerstone of the repertory (by a fellow Hungarian): Liszt’s daunting Sonata in B minor.

headline: Review: Esperanza Spalding’s Funk Enlightenment
abstract: There’s a bolt of reinvention in the songs on her new album, “Emily’s D+Evolution,” and Ms. Spalding sounds surer than ever of her footing.
lead_paragraph: “Emily’s D+Evolution”

headline: Rainbow Skirts, Bags to Break the Ice and More
abstract: Plus: Kitschy barrettes and fashion from Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Kitschy barrettes and fashion from Minneapolis.

headline: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Joseph Brodsky, in a Song of Exiled Russians
abstract: The dancer discusses the one-man show “Brodsky/Baryshnikov,” which layers poems by his late friend, the Russian poet Joseph Brodsky.
lead_paragraph: It may seem odd that the poet Joseph Brodsky, a man who had little time for ballet — “the art of better days,” he called it in a 1975 poem — should have counted among his closest friends the Russian dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov. (The poem, in fact, was dedicated to him.) Brodsky was eight years older than Mr. Baryshnikov, and in his friend’s dancing he saw something more than ballet, something, as he told the Russian musicologist Solomon Volkov, closer to metaphysics.

headline: The Last Word on Red Carpet Hair: Let It Be
abstract: Celebrities are turning their backs on the lacquered look in favor of an artfully undone alternative.
lead_paragraph: What’s a hun? For that bit of insider intelligence, you would have to turn to Alicia Vikander, who stepped up to claim her best supporting actress statuette at the Oscars on Sunday, her glossy hair tumbling fast and loose from a lazy half-bun at her crown.

headline: J.J. Abrams Takes Steps to Lift Diversity in Filmmaking
abstract: In a talk that was part of The New York Times’ New Work Summit, the director detailed a memo he sent to studies and agents announcing a new policy.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of #OscarsSoWhite, the director J. J. Abrams is the latest, and most prominent, Hollywood player taking steps to diversify the industry, from the start of production on up, as he explained in a conference presentation in Half Moon Bay, Calif., on Tuesday night.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Blacklisted in Iran, Gay Poet Seeks Asylum in Israel
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Payam Feili, a poet and novelist, fled to Tel Aviv after government loyalists accused him of immorality and collaborating with the enemy.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In his native Iran, leaders openly wish for Israel to be wiped off the map. Yet Payam Feili, a poet and novelist, developed what he called a “special relationship” with the place, imagining it in his stories, which are replete with gay themes and Jewish symbols.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Ben Carson, Chris Christie
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Paul Ryan Faces Tea Party Forces That He Helped Unleash
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House Republican leadership’s coalition with divisive elements in the Tea Party movement may have set up the current conflict with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul D. Ryan and his self-proclaimed “young guns” in the House Republican leadership traversed the country in 2010 harnessing the energy of the Tea Party movement that would sweep them to power that November. But in failing to confront the most divisive forces of the movement, they may have set their party up for its current crisis.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, on racism in the Republican Party, John Kasich, profanity and John Oliver.
lead_paragraph: “I’m mad today about the degree to which the racism in the Republican Party, which has been wriggling to the surface for a long time, and has accelerated during Obama, is now just right out there in the open” says The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, in this short podcast on the news: the good, the bad and the most maddening.

headline: Review: Heron Oblivion’s Debut Album Explores Opposites
abstract: This Bay Area rock quartet is loud and soft on a self-titled record that plays to each band member’s strengths.
lead_paragraph: “Heron Oblivion”

headline: Photos of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Ellen Page Explores L.G.B.T. Travel in New Documentary Series
keywords: ['Television', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The actress developed and produced the documentary series “Gaycation” with her friend Ian Daniel for the new Viceland channel.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Page, 29, best known for her Oscar-nominated role in “Juno” and recently starring in “Freeheld” with Julianne Moore, has become an advocate for L.G.B.T. rights after coming out as a lesbian in 2014. In the past year, Ms. Page developed and produced the documentary series “Gaycation” with her friend Ian Daniel. The series, created with Vice and the filmmaker Spike Jonze, the creative director of the new Viceland channel, follows Ms. Page and Mr. Daniel as they explore lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender groups around the world. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with her.

headline: March 2, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Israel, South Korea and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Israel, South Korea and the United States.

headline: Review: On the Debut Album by Mothers, Austere Honesty
abstract: Kristine Leschper’s band is part of a wavelet of stark and sincere music by women like Julien Baker, Soak and Waxahatchee.
lead_paragraph: “When You Walk a Long

headline: Review: In Sarah Bakewell’s ‘At the Existentialist Café,’ Nothingness Has a Certain Something
abstract: The author has tried to interweave the biographies and intellectual histories of philosophers including Sartre, de Beauvoir, Camus and Heidegger.
lead_paragraph: When she turned 16, Sarah Bakewell used some of her birthday money to buy a copy of Jean-Paul Sartre’s “Nausea” (1938). She fell in love with the book (cover blurb: “a novel of the alienation of personality and the mystery of being”) and soon realized she had stumbled across a philosophy called existentialism. It redefined concepts like being, existence and freedom. While still at entry level to this thinking, she went to a park in Reading, England, and stared protractedly at a tree, hoping to understand it more deeply.

headline: Santiago Calatrava’s Transit Hub Is a Soaring Symbol of a Boondoggle
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Transit Systems', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: The hub, opening Thursday, gives the city an Instagram-ready attraction and the most expensive train station ever.
lead_paragraph: For a dozen years, the World Trade Center Transportation Hub was a train wreck. Santiago Calatrava’s winged dove, beefed up to meet security demands, devolved into a dino carcass. The project’s cost soared toward a head-slapping, unconscionable $4 billion in public money for what, in effect, is the 18th-busiest subway stop in New York City, tucked inside a shopping mall, down the block from another shopping center.

headline: Review: ‘Adult Documentary’ Is Dense and Difficult, Including the Carpet
abstract: The choreographer Juliana F. May’s work is a duet of language and movement, telling stories both real and fictional.
lead_paragraph: During this age of reality television and its aggressive pursuit of chaos, it doesn’t seem a coincidence that the choreographer Juliana F. May has created “Adult Documentary,” a work constructed of real and fictional stories by its performers. Those stories serve as raw material, distorted over time and replayed on an incessant loop as Ms. May drains and fills in her choreographic terrain. That, by the way, is an expanse of sandy brown carpet — just thick enough that if you walked into a hotel room covered with it you’d think twice before taking off your socks.

headline: After Losses, Marco Rubio Skips the Donald Trump Jokes
abstract: Mr. Rubio was all business the day after a string of defeats in Super Tuesday contests, leaving aside the mean jokes about Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: SHELBY TOWNSHIP, Mich. – Gone were the petty torments about the size of Donald J. Trump’s hands and the orange hue of his skin. In fact, Senator Marco Rubio was all business on Wednesday, leaving aside the mean jokes about Mr. Trump.

headline: Texas’ Dangerous Abortion Law at the Supreme Court
abstract: In the biggest abortion case in years, the justices should not be fooled by Texas lawmakers’ phony claims about protecting women’s health.
lead_paragraph: States like Texas pass laws strictly regulating abortion clinics for one reason: to make it hard, if not impossible, for women to obtain a safe and legal abortion.

headline: Review: In ‘The Family,’ a Lost Son Might Be Back From Limbo
abstract: This new drama on ABC has secrets aplenty, including back-room deal-making, sibling guilt and lingering traumas.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a missing-child plot to get the pulse racing, but in “The Family,” ABC’s slick new drama, that’s only the foundational premise. For the clan in this twisting, turning show, it’s when the missing kid turns up again that things really become intriguing.

headline: Review: ‘Straight’ Glides Between Sexual Assumptions
abstract: The play, a bisexual romantic triangle at the Acorn Theater that takes on ambivalence, is written by Scott Elmegreen and Drew Fornarola.
lead_paragraph: In the bisexual romantic triangle “Straight,” now at the Acorn Theater, Charlie Corcoran’s set melds perfectly with Grant Yeager’s lighting: A tidy apartment is illuminated at times with cool pastel hues, in transitions punctuated by Will Van Dyke’s tidy synthesized musical accents. And all those elements converge seamlessly with this play — by Scott Elmegreen and Drew Fornarola, and directed with polished finesse by Andy Sandberg — that is supple and, yes, tidy.

headline: Eiko Invites You to Her Inner Land of Wraiths
abstract: She is performing for three weeks at seven East Village locations as part of a multidisciplinary program focused on her.
lead_paragraph: At 9 a.m. on Monday, if you had peeked through the storefront window of Dashwood Books on Bond Street in Manhattan, you would have seen a body on the floor, sleeping or possibly dead. Slowly, out of tattered Japanese robes emerged whitened feet, gnarled and aged and terribly exposed.

headline: Queens Man Sentenced to 55 Years to Life for Shooting Officer in Legs
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: John F. Thomas, 28, received the maximum sentence for shooting Sgt. Craig Bier as he was being pursued by the police in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A 28-year-old Queens man was sentenced on Wednesday to 55 years to life in prison for shooting a New York City police sergeant twice in the legs as he was being pursued by the police, prosecutors said.

headline: Texas Republicans Disavow Foul-Mouthed Election Winner
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Robert Morrow, the newly elected chairman of Travis County Republicans, is known for public behavior that might make Donald Trump look demure.
lead_paragraph: The Twitter account of the brash, outsider Republican is rife with conspiratorial accusations, declarations of dubious veracity and a stream of oftentimes crass language. Other party leaders say they wouldn’t be able to work with him.

headline: Greece Tries to House Migrants as Other Gates Close
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'International Relations']
abstract: Camps have been opening in Greece at the rate of nearly one a day to house thousands of migrants who cannot move forward, and cannot or will not go back.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Terminal E2 in Piraeus, the port city near Athens, is typically a cheerful holding spot for tourists waiting to board ferries for sunny Greek island vacations. But on a recent day, nearly 1,000 exhausted migrants who had just crossed the Aegean Sea from Turkey sprawled across the sweat-soaked floor and on the asphalt outside, waiting to hear if they could continue toward Germany.

headline: With Bet on Japan, Sharp Stumbles
abstract: The plight of the electronics company is a story of missteps by managers who failed to anticipate shifts in the global electronics industry.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When flat-screen televisions began replacing boxy analog sets in the world’s living rooms more than a decade ago, few companies bet bigger on the new technology than Sharp of Japan.

headline: Fraud Arrests May Be Turning Point for Polygamist Sect
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Money Laundering', 'Polygamy', 'Food Stamps', 'Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints', 'Embezzlement']
abstract: The prosecutions resemble the strategy used by the federal government to go after New York crime families, some experts say.
lead_paragraph: HILDALE, Utah. — Andrew Chatwin watched as federal agents and sheriff’s deputies swarmed this rural polygamist outpost last week, storming dairy and produce stores and a food distribution center in bulletproof vests, guns drawn, handcuffs dangling from their belts.

headline: Toxic Moss in Portland, Ore., Shakes City’s Green Ideals
abstract: When a study found toxic materials on tree trunks in residential neighborhoods of Portland, it produced an upheaval of surprise, anger and fear.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The 346 clumps of moss that science researchers from the United States Forest Service scraped from tree trunks and branches across this city looked as ordinary as moss gets — ancient, simple and common to the point of invisibility in the Pacific Northwest’s palette of green.

headline: Anti-Trump Republicans Call for a Third-Party Option
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For a growing group of conservative leaders, Donald Trump’s initial refusal to disavow an endorsement from a white supremacist was a breaking point.
lead_paragraph: Spurred by Donald J. Trump’s mounting victories, a small but influential — and growing — group of conservative leaders are calling for a third-party option to spare voters a wrenching general election choice between a Republican they consider completely unacceptable and Hillary Clinton.

headline: Spain’s Socialist Leader Fails in Effort to Become Prime Minister
abstract: The likelihood increases of new elections in June to help break the deadlock among the nation’s four main parties.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s Parliament on Wednesday handed a defeat to the leader of the Socialist party in the first round of his long-shot attempt to become the country’s next prime minister.

headline: Fox Moderators to Face Donald Trump in Thursday’s Debate
abstract: Megyn Kelly, Chris Wallace and Bret Baier talked about their preparations and how they see their roles.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our analysis of the 11th Republican debate.

headline: Miramax Is Bought by the Qatari beIN Media Group
abstract: The famed indie studio was bought for an undisclosed amount by beIN, a company formed in the spinoff of Al Jazeera’s sports unit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Miramax, one of Hollywood’s best-known independent film and television labels, was acquired by the beIN Media Group, a sports and media company headed by the Qatari executive Nasser Al-Khelaifi, the companies said on Wednesday.

headline: William H. Schaap, Radical Lawyer and Critic of C.I.A., Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Schaap counseled war resisters, exposed covert C.I.A. activities, and published Jim Garrison’s book on the John F. Kennedy assassination.
lead_paragraph: William H. Schaap, a radical lawyer, author and publisher who fought against investigative abuses by government agencies at home and abroad, died on Feb. 25 in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Defense Secretary Takes Position Against a Data ‘Back Door’
abstract: Secretary Ashton Carter spoke at a security conference about the F.B.I.-Apple dispute over access to an iPhone, but avoided taking sides.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter assured an audience of computer security experts Wednesday that he was not in favor of a “back door” that would give the government access to data that is protected by encryption.

headline: Toyota Adds 331,000 Vehicles to Takata Airbag Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Toyota is recalling 198,000 more vehicles because the airbag inflater produced by Takata could rupture.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling 331,000 more vehicles worldwide because the airbag inflater produced by Takata could rupture, sending metal shards into the passenger compartment, the automaker said on Wednesday. The new action covers the passenger-side airbag on the 2008 Corolla and Corolla Matrix as well as the 2008-10 Lexus SC 430. The company said it was not aware of any injuries associated with the new recall. In June, the automaker recalled earlier model years of those vehicles as part of an action covering almost 1.4 million vehicles. Toyota has now recalled about 15 million vehicles worldwide because of the Takata defect. Over all, 14 automakers have recalled about 24 million vehicles for the inflaters, which have been linked to 10 deaths and more than 100 injuries.

headline: New Doubts About ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks Rattle Foundation of Regulations
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: While a vast system of new rules governing bank behavior has arisen, some regulators wonder if enough has been done, and some analysts say the largest banks may shrink.
lead_paragraph: Governments around the world have built over the last few years a vast new system of rules that would allow banking giants to fail and shield taxpayers from bailouts.

headline: Goldman Executive Hired by TPG for Industrial Acquisitions
abstract: Jack Daly most recently oversaw industrial deals at a merchant banking division of Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm TPG Capital has hired a senior executive from Goldman Sachs to lead its industrial acquisitions, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: World Cup of Hockey Rosters
abstract: The eight teams competing in the World Cup of Hockey announced their first 16 players Thursday, with seven more to be added to each roster by June 1.
lead_paragraph: The eight teams competing in the World Cup of Hockey announced their first 16 players Thursday. Seven more players will be added to each roster by June 1. The World Cup, which was last held in 2004, will be played from Sept. 17 through Oct. 1 in Toronto.

headline: Without Naming Names, Hillary Clinton Focuses on Potential Rival
abstract: Riding high after big wins on Super Tuesday, Hillary Clinton shifted her attention to the Republican front-runner she could face in a general election: Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Riding high after big wins on Super Tuesday, Hillary Clinton returned to New York on Wednesday and shifted her attention to the Republican front-runner she could face in a general election: Donald J. Trump.

headline: As Campaign Unfolds, So Do Inquiries Into Hillary Clinton’s Emails
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The investigations into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private computer server as secretary of state could jar her campaign’s momentum in the months ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Hillary Clinton moves toward the Democratic presidential nomination, she faces legal hurdles from her use of a private computer server as secretary of state that could jar her campaign’s momentum in the months ahead.

headline: In Scandal at Puerto Rico Utility, Ex-Fuel Buyer Insists He Took No Bribes
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: William Clark led the fuel procurement office at the heart of accusations that the utility overpaid for cheap, dirty oil.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The mystery man at the heart of what is being called “a monumental fraud” in Puerto Rico broke his silence this week, answering questions under oath about whether conspirators at the island’s electric utility overcharged residents by hundreds of millions of dollars and worsened the island’s debt crisis.

headline: Egypt’s Parliament Expels Lawmaker Who Dined With Israel’s Ambassador
abstract: The lawmaker, Tawfik Okasha, had already been attacked with a shoe by a fellow lawmaker three days earlier over the same episode, which highlighted Egyptian sensitivity toward Israel.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s Parliament on Wednesday expelled a well-known television personality turned lawmaker over a dinner he had with the Israeli ambassador — a vote that exposed a raw nerve in the mostly tranquil relationship between the two countries.

headline: Memories of Last Season Stalk Knicks
abstract: The Knicks’ current season has begun to produce echoes of the last one: the same competitive despair, the same threat of irrelevance, the same undertones of nastiness.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony often says these days — with a smirk or smile — that he has blocked the Knicks’ 2014-15 season out of his mind. It is an undecipherable blur that he simply cannot remember.

headline: Yankees and Aroldis Chapman Accept the Inevitable
abstract: The Yankees gave up little to acquire one of baseball’s best relievers, and now he will be available to them after May 9.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When the Yankees traded for Aroldis Chapman in late December, they did so with minimal risk. Here was a four-time All-Star closer, the man with the hardest fastball in recorded history and the best strikeout ratio of any pitcher ever with at least 300 career innings. And he came cheap.

headline: F.B.I. Agent Testifies About Conversation With Suspect in ISIS Case
abstract: An undercover agent assigned to determine whether Tairod Pugh was trying to join the Islamic State spoke at Mr. Pugh’s trial in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Stripped of all context, it sounded like an ordinary request for directions.

headline: Melissa Harris-Perry Says MSNBC Show Deserved ‘Proper Burial’
abstract: A former host worries that the network will now lack coverage of social justice and race.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Harris-Perry is still frustrated with MSNBC.

headline: White Officer Is Arrested in Killing of Black Man
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Officer Aaron Smith was charged with murder in the death of Gregory Gunn, 58, in an early morning confrontation last week in Montgomery, Ala.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A white police officer in Montgomery, Ala., has been charged with murder in the shooting death last week of Gregory Gunn, a 58-year-old black man, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Donald Trump’s Son Calls Interview With White Nationalist Inadvertent
abstract: Donald J. Trump Jr. gave the interview to the Memphis radio host James Edwards, who has been promoting it on his website as a major exclusive that will air this weekend
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump Jr. said on Wednesday that he inadvertently gave an interview to a white nationalist radio host who has been promoting it on his website as a major exclusive that will air this weekend.

headline: Seeing Chris Christie With Donald Trump, New Jersey and Internet Cringe
abstract: Mr. Christie has faced ridicule since endorsing Mr. Trump for president and calls in New Jersey for him to resign.
lead_paragraph: What, you might ask, could be worse than a thoroughly failed presidential candidate returning home as a lame-duck governor to a $10 billion budget deficit and a recalcitrant legislature?

headline: Making a Fresh Start, World Cup of Hockey Unveils Its Preliminary Rosters
abstract: The World Cup could be a litmus test to determine whether it will be sufficient to replace N.H.L. participation in future Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist briefly mulled a question in jest as he removed his equipment after practice on Wednesday.

headline: Saudi Arabia Cuts Billions in Aid to Lebanon, Opening Door for Iran
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s tactic could allow Iran to increase its role in Lebanon through its ally, the militant group Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Even as Iran and Saudi Arabia supported opposite sides in a bitter and bloody proxy war in Syria, the two adversaries managed to preserve a tense calm just over the border in Lebanon, where they have long competed for influence.

headline: Cespedes Takes to the Links, and He Can Hit the Ball Far There, Too
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes had never held a golf club until four years ago. Now he aspires to join the PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: PALM CITY, Fla. — As Yoenis Cespedes and his agent, Brodie Van Wagenen, approached the par-3 eighth hole on Wednesday afternoon, Van Wagenen offered Cespedes a friendly wager he knew he couldn’t resist: closest to the pin, for $100.

headline: Massachusetts: U.S. Inquiry Begins at Boston Latin
abstract: Carmen M. Ortiz, the United States attorney for Massachusetts, announced an investigation on Wednesday into alleged civil rights violations at the prestigious Boston Latin School.
lead_paragraph: Carmen M. Ortiz, the United States attorney for Massachusetts, announced an investigation on Wednesday into alleged civil rights violations at the prestigious Boston Latin School. Earlier this year, two black students used social media to draw attention to what they described as simmering racial hostilities there, and an investigation by the district found administrators had violated internal policy in one of seven episodes related to race. Last week, a group of civil rights organizations urged Ms. Ortiz to investigate claims of racism and harassment at the school. Ms. Ortiz said that Mayor Martin J. Walsh and Tommy Chang, the superintendent of the city’s schools, were cooperating with the effort.

headline: Apple Gets Tech Industry Backing in iPhone Dispute, Despite Misgivings
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'iPhone', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act']
abstract: Silicon Valley appears to be siding with Apple in the San Bernardino iPhone case, overcoming worries about the consequences of an unfavorable ruling.
lead_paragraph: It is a remarkable moment for the technology industry, with many different companies and organizations rallying around a single company — Apple — in a major legal case against the United States government over privacy and security.

headline: Michigan: Head Start Aid Approved for Flint
abstract: Officials said Wednesday they had allotted $3.5 million to expand early childhood education in Flint, where contaminated drinking water has been linked to elevated levels of lead in children’s blood.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials said Wednesday that they had allotted $3.5 million in emergency funds to immediately expand an early childhood education program in Flint, where contaminated drinking water has been linked to elevated levels of lead in children’s blood. The one-time allotment will allow for three additional Head Start classrooms, serving 51 more children in neighborhoods hit hard by the lead contamination, through June 2017. The funds will increase health and nutrition services for 1,200 Flint children already enrolled in Head Start, the federally funded preschool program for low-income children, and Early Head Start, for children younger than 3. The money will also allow an additional 24 children to enroll in a home-based Head Start program. Officials said 800 Flint children remain on a waiting list for the program, and thousands more are most likely eligible.

headline: John Mayberry Jr., Symbol of Mets’ Troubles, Tries to Find New Life in Detroit
abstract: Mayberry, batting .170 at the time, started in the cleanup spot against Clayton Kershaw shortly before the Mets made trades to bolster their offense. Now he is with the Detroit Tigers.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — While it is all giggles and guffaws for the Mets now, wondering what outlandish craft Yoenis Cespedes might show up to work in tomorrow — a spaceship? a rowboat? — it was not that long ago that there was a different player who symbolized the Mets.

headline: Derick Brassard Proving to Be Key Figure for Rangers
abstract: Brassard has been a consistent force during the Rangers’ tumultuous season and is one of the team’s most valuable players as it prepares for a postseason run.
lead_paragraph: At the trading deadline three years ago, Derick Brassard was part of a deal that sent him to the Rangers from the Columbus Blue Jackets. In some reports, Brassard’s name was more or less ignored because Marian Gaborik’s departure from the Rangers was deemed more important. In other articles, Brassard was called an obscure player.

headline: Spieth, Day and McIlroy Stick With What (and Who) Works
abstract: As they have ascended to the top three spots in golf’s world rankings, Jordan Spieth, Jason Day and Rory McIlroy have kept the coaches who taught them while they were growing up.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — At the Honda Classic last week, Rory McIlroy could sense what was wrong in his putting stroke even if he could not fix it in time to salvage his second round and survive the cut.

headline: At Ted Cruz’s Speech, the Joke’s on Donald Trump
abstract: The senator’s take on Mr. Trump and immigration was typical stump speech fodder. Then a voter livened things up.
lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Ted Cruz walked into a joke about Donald J. Trump and a gentleman’s club.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | A Faithful Leap
abstract: The actress Amber Tamblyn reads an essay about a woman whose complicated relationship with her mother ends in a tragedy inspired by “Thelma & Louise.”
lead_paragraph: In the eighth episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Amber Tamblyn (“The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants,” “127 Hours”) reads “Ready to Take a Faithful Leap” by Kelly Thomas.

headline: One Added to the Staff
abstract: In which Andrew Zhou stumps me.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Here’s what can happen when your mother eagerly signs you up for music lessons when you’re a child and you don’t pay attention: You grow up to be a crossword puzzle blogger, responsible for explaining the puzzle to a large number of people, and then you wind up solving — or rather, not solving — a crossword that incorporates music notation theory as part of the theme. It’s like one of those stress dreams we all have, but this is for real.

headline: Russian Prosecutors Seek 23-Year Prison Term for Ukrainian Pilot
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Nadiya V. Savchenko, a helicopter pilot charged in connection with the deaths of two Russian journalists, has become a symbol in the Ukraine conflict.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prosecutors in southern Russia rested their case on Wednesday in the trial of a Ukrainian military pilot, asking for a lengthy sentence in the drawn out and highly publicized proceedings.

headline: Radio Upgrade to Link New York Officers in Subway and on Street
abstract: A move to improve communications for the police comes after decades of delays.
lead_paragraph: When New York City’s Transit Police Department merged with the New York Police Department in 1995, the city’s leaders signed an agreement. It said the officers — disconnected not only administratively but also by being above and below ground — would finally get a radio system that would allow them to talk to one another.

headline: Spooked Police Horse Throws Officer and Runs Loose in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: Frightened by a loud sound near Times Square, the animal, Gunny, dragged its rider for a while and ran loose for about 10 minutes.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police horse tossed an officer to the pavement and took off down a busy Midtown street on Wednesday after being spooked by a loud noise, the authorities said.

headline: Delmer Berg, Last of American Volunteers in Spanish Civil War, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Berg was one of nearly 3,000 Americans who, as the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, fought Franco’s fascist forces in the late 1930s.
lead_paragraph: Delmer Berg, the last known living veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, which vainly fought against Fascism’s advance into Spain in the late 1930s, died on Sunday at his home in Columbia, Calif. He was 100.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Shares Stage With Hillary Clinton in More Prominent Role
abstract: The mayor and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo drummed up enthusiasm for Mrs. Clinton before she appeared at a rally in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment several awkward months in the making: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who was notably slow to endorse Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential front-runner, would finally appear on stage with her on Wednesday, to introduce her at a rally at the Javits Convention Center.

headline: Jail Injury Claims Against New York City Surge
abstract: Personal injury complaints from correction employees and inmates rose by 27 percent, the city comptroller said, and most came from the Rikers Island complex.
lead_paragraph: The number of personal injury claims filed against New York City for episodes at the Rikers Island jail complex and other city correctional facilities surged last year in what the city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, called a troubling indication of a continuing plague of violence and mismanagement.

headline: World Cup of Hockey Rosters
abstract: The World Cup of Hockey, an eight-team international tournament featuring N.H.L. stars, begins Saturday in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup of Hockey, an eight-team international tournament featuring N.H.L. stars, begins Saturday in Toronto.

headline: Dick Bradsell, Bartender Who Helped Revive London Cocktail Scene, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Bradsell’s influence was felt throughout Britain and as far away as Australia thanks to bartenders trained by him or inspired by his creations.
lead_paragraph: Dick Bradsell, a career bartender who was considered the father of the cocktail revival that took root in London in the 1990s and continues to flourish today, died on Saturday at his home in London. He was 56.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | fawning
abstract: This word has appeared in 51 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: For Rutgers, Another Rout in a Season Full of Them
abstract: Facing the second-ranked Spartans, the Scarlet Knights had their Big Ten losing streak hit 31 consecutive games. They have also lost a program-record 17 straight over all.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — As Rutgers and Michigan State stationed themselves in their locker rooms during halftime Wednesday night at the Rutgers Athletic Center, the Scarlet Knights’ mascot walked over to the Spartans’ bench, grabbed Coach Tom Izzo’s clipboard and pretended to scribble a play.

abstract: Joan Allen plays the mother of a missing child in “The Family.” Viceland continues to roll out new series. And “The Fashion Fund” moves to Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Joan Allen, who plays the mother of an abducted teenager in “Room,” takes on a similar role in “The Family.” Viceland continues to roll out new series. And “The Fashion Fund” moves to Amazon for Season 3.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 3, 2016
lead_paragraph: “I hate to say this about the Republican establishment, but their view of civil rights is to tip the black waiter five bucks at the country club.”

headline: The Puerto Rican Lower East Side
abstract: In “Bacalaitos & Fireworks,” Arlene Gottfried chronicles the Lower East Side’s once-vibrant Puerto Rican community, rendering it with love, humor and warmth.
lead_paragraph: In “Bacalaitos & Fireworks,” Arlene Gottfried chronicles the Lower East Side’s once-vibrant Puerto Rican community, rendering it with love, humor and warmth.

headline: What to Expect at Paris Fashion Week: Day 3
abstract: The day’s highlights include Chloé, Rick Owens, Vetements and, for bling, the Balmain show, with its Insta-troupe of supermodels.
lead_paragraph: Rise and shine: The third day of Paris Fashion Week begins at the Grand Palais for the Chloé show at 10 a.m., followed by a quick Métro or Mercedes ride (depending where you fall in the pecking order) to Carven in the Jardin des Tuileries an hour later. Grab a coffee while you can — inside, of course, given the forecast is for yet more driving rain.

headline: The Puerto Rican Lower East Side
abstract: In “Bacalaitos & Fireworks,” Arlene Gottfried chronicles the Lower East Side’s once-vibrant Puerto Rican community, rendering it with love, humor and warmth.
lead_paragraph: When I first came across Arlene Gottfried’s vintage pictures of Puerto Rican New York, “Bacalaitos & Fireworks,” I chuckled. Her reference to the siren call of a Lower East Side street vendor hawking codfish fritters and firecrackers struck me as having all the ingredients for a Fourth of July party (just add Bacardi). My second reaction was nervousness — given the area’s devastation from poverty and drugs during the 1970s and 1980s, how would the photographer portray this world?

headline: Call Me Mister Trump
abstract: Back during “The Apprentice” and now when being introduced by a new sidekick, the gold-plated candidate has had no first name.
lead_paragraph: What do you think we should call Donald Trump?

headline: Donald Trump and Reconstruction-Era Politics
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Reconstruction Era', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: The leading Republican candidate is taking advantage of a backlash to racial progress, echoing events of the late 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s flirtation with the Ku Klux Klan should come as no surprise. He has functioned for years as a rallying point for “birthers,” conspiracy theorists, extremists and racists who are apoplectic about the fact that the country elected a black man president. These groups have driven the Republican Party steadily rightward, helping to create a national discourse that now permits a presidential candidate to court racist support without paying a political price.

headline: The Supreme Court’s New Era
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: With Justice Scalia’s seat empty, no one knows what will happen next.
lead_paragraph: So now we know what the post-Scalia Supreme Court sounds like. Thank you, Justice Thomas, for shaking up what had come to seem the natural order of things, as well as for your pithy observation from the bench that possession of a gun “at least as of now, is still a constitutional right.”

headline: Whose American Dream Flies?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Trump embodies showy wealth. Rubio talks about his struggle. Voters seem to like one version better than the other.
lead_paragraph: IN their campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination, both Donald J. Trump and Marco Rubio have said that the American dream is either dead or dying. But for the American people, the dream still holds sway. It’s a basic myth of our country: No matter where someone starts out, if he works hard enough he can climb to the top.

headline: A Stern Message to North Korea
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The U.N. Security Council — including China — has approved tough new economic sanctions on North Korea. The task now is to enforce them.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of dithering, mostly by China, the United Nations Security Council has finally delivered a serious response to North Korea’s dangerous expansion of its nuclear weapons program, unanimously approving the toughest sanctions yet. The penalties respond to the North’s fourth nuclear weapons test, which took place in January, and to the launch, a month later, of a type of missile that could one day hit the United States. They would ban the trade of all conventional weapons as well as luxury goods like Jet Skis and Rolex watches, which are enjoyed by the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and his generals.

headline: Demagogue for President
abstract: A nativist, sexist, arguably fascist and racist liar is the front-runner for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you have to simply step back from the hubbub and take stock, with cleareyed sobriety, at a moment in history to fully appreciate its epochal import. Now is such a time.

headline: What the Election Means for Reproductive Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'ABORTION']
abstract: The next president will have great influence over the future of women’s access to care.
lead_paragraph: The day after Justice Antonin Scalia’s death, Senator Ted Cruz released a campaign ad warning, “We’re just one Supreme Court justice away from losing” on abortion, among other issues. The ad showed Donald Trump, in a 1999 interview, saying he is “very pro-choice.”

headline: Bring Back the Autopsy
keywords: ['Autopsies', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Death and Dying', 'Hospitals']
abstract: To identify diagnostic errors, we need more post-mortem exams.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY attended an autopsy at the hospital where I work, in a room in the basement adjoining the morgue. The corpse, a newborn baby, was lying peacefully, as if napping, on a steel table with rusted wheels. He had succumbed to hypoxia, low oxygen levels in the blood, a few minutes after a full-term delivery. Did he have a heart defect? Had the umbilical cord been compressed? Had he breathed meconium, the first stool, into his lungs? The purpose of the autopsy was to find out.

headline: Debate Prep: Fact-Checking the G.O.P. Candidates on Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: All the candidates want to replace Obamacare but are thin on details.
lead_paragraph: The Republican debates have included very little discussion of health care policy. But the issue has roared back into the conversation, and is likely to come back again at the Detroit debate on Thursday.

headline: Tibetan Monk, 18, Dies After Self-Immolation to Protest Chinese Rule
abstract: It was the first known act of self-immolation in a Tibetan area of China since August.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A young Tibetan monk died this week after setting himself on fire in Sichuan Province to protest Chinese rule, according to a Tibet advocacy group. It was the first known act of self-immolation in a Tibetan area of China since August.

headline: News Q’s | Seattle Underbelly Exposed as Homeless Camp Violence Flares
abstract: What is the Jungle? What are conditions like there?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Seattle Underbelly Exposed as Homeless Camp Violence Flares.”

headline: An Unretired Hewitt Could Spoil Americans’ Davis Cup Bid
abstract: Playing captains are rare at the highest levels of Davis Cup, but Australia’s Lleyton Hewitt has replaced the ailing Nick Kyrgios.
lead_paragraph: Lleyton Hewitt’s retirement now looks more like an early-season break. After an emotional farewell at the Australian Open in January, Hewitt was supposed to make a transition into a role as Australia’s nonplaying Davis Cup captain.

headline: Germany to Continue Funding to Establish Provenance of Looted Art
abstract: The country’s culture minister, who is visiting the United States, said that the effort is “what we owe the victims.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany will pay for at least another year of research and hire extra people to establish the provenance of works owned by Cornelius Gurlitt, a reclusive Munich collector who sat on a trove of 1,500 artworks acquired by his father, a dealer for the Nazis, Germany’s culture minister said before her first official visit to the United States.

headline: Obama Says Enrollment in Affordable Care Act Reaches 20 Million
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: The president went to Milwaukee to highlight the success of health care coverage under the act.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — President Obama said on Thursday that enrollment in health coverage under the Affordable Care Act had reached a new high, 20 million, and he called the law an overwhelming success in this city and around the nation despite Republicans’ implacable opposition.

headline: Making the Journey From Menace to Neighbor, All on One Brooklyn Block
abstract: Living out of a Ford Explorer after losing his home, an unemployed chemist changes his own trajectory while stirring the altruistic impulses of some who were wary of him.
lead_paragraph: The time had come for Gene to leave the ground-floor apartment, as he knew it would. The owner who let him stay there rent-free had been dead for more than a year, and the estate wanted it back. With the marshal at the door, Gene delivered his cats to a neighbor, then bundled blankets, pillows and some clothes. Parked right outside was his next home: a 1996 Ford Explorer. He moved into the back seat. That was Feb. 27, 2015.

headline: The Moment We Knew Donald Trump Was Here to Stay
abstract: Times reporters recall when they first realized Mr. Trump could win the Republican nomination, a prospect that seemed unthinkable a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s dominant performance on Tuesday erased all doubt — if any remained — that he is in a strong position to be the Republican presidential nominee, a prospect that less than a year ago seemed inconceivable.

headline: At Republican Debate, a Field of Four on Fox News
abstract: With Ben Carson skipping the debate after suggesting an end to his campaign, a trimmed-down field will gather for the Fox News debate on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our analysis of the 11th Republican debate.

headline: In Saudi Arabia, a Kingdom to Myself
abstract: Untrammeled beaches, ancient sites and unfiltered local culture are all on offer in Saudi Arabia. Just don’t expect an easy trip.
lead_paragraph: I reached the port of Jizan in southwestern Saudi Arabia just in time to catch the speedboat. After buying my ticket and having my passport checked by a mustachioed police officer, I climbed into the small, closed cabin with a few other passengers, a box of vegetables, a green shag rug and a parakeet in a wire cage, and we set off for what I had been told was one of the most enchanting places in the kingdom.

headline: Deflategate: What’s Happened So Far, and What’s Next
abstract: More than a year later, the bizarre spectacle known as Deflategate is still not over. The latest chapter begins Thursday in federal court in New York.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 18, 2015, the New England Patriots hammered the Indianapolis Colts, 45-7, to advance to the Super Bowl.

headline: A Karaoke Night With Will Forte, Star of ‘Last Man on Earth’
abstract: In a private room in Los Angeles, the star and co-creator of “The Last Man on Earth” belts his way through “Mama Tried,” “Help Me” and “Superstar.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A reporter, a photographer and a TV star walked into Max Karaoke Studio on Sawtelle Boulevard. The place didn’t serve alcohol, and so the reporter, who had booked a private room for the evening, had a pint bottle of whiskey concealed in a jacket pocket.

headline: Xi Jinping’s Remedy for China’s Economic Gloom Has Echoes of Reaganomics
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']

headline: Jeff Daniels on the Terror of Returning to ‘Blackbird’
abstract: The actor writes about his role in a brutally unforgiving play: A man and a woman confront each other 15 years after their very illegal relationship — when he was 40 and she was all of 12.
lead_paragraph: The first time I visited the Grand Canyon, I froze. Try as I might, it was too much to take in. As I neared the canyon’s edge, my confident stroll quickly slowed. My fear of heights was yanking on my reins. I may have whinnied. I grabbed the protective railing and squeezed with both hands. I looked down, down, all the way down to the bottom of the canyon floor. I took a picture, acknowledged my insignificance and vowed never to do anything remotely foolish in the eyes of Mother Nature.

headline: Bipartisan Anti-Drug Bill Appears to Clear Final Hurdles
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Heroin', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: The bill, which directs federal resources to prevention, treatment and recovery programs with proven track records, is a boon to people like Senators Rob Portman of Ohio and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, Republicans who come from states with huge drug problems and who face tough re-election battles.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Senate Democrats have suggested that they might not vote for a bipartisan bill to address the prescription drug epidemic unless Congress spent more money to undergird the bill. But a measure to provide $600 million in funding for anti-heroin programs failed on Wednesday. And unlike an energy bill that Democrats have stalled because they are trying to get money for the water crisis in Flint, Mich., the drug bill still looks like a go.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Vanderpump Rules’
abstract: An outlier in the personal-growth-obsessed universe of reality TV.
lead_paragraph: American reality television has a near-pathological focus on success. It makes no difference whether a show documents an actual competition (‘‘Survivor’’) or a milestone refigured as a competition (‘‘The Bachelor’’), or offers some version, however far-fetched, of everyday life (‘‘Keeping Up With the Kardashians’’). The trajectory is the same: relentlessly upward.

headline: They May Be Next to Lead the Country, but Can They Play Ball?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Like many United States presidents, several of today’s hopefuls have notable sports backgrounds — even if they are no Gerald Ford.
lead_paragraph: The Duke of Wellington supposedly said that the Battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton. If you agree with the duke that leaders are forged in the crucible of sports, Ted Dobias has a story to tell you.

headline: Greenpoint’s Culinary Ghosts
abstract: Learning to make bigos, a meat-and-sauerkraut dish, in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to Brooklyn in 1999, I’d never heard of Greenpoint — a working-class Polish community out past Williamsburg with questionable subway access — before the apartment broker sold me on it. My landlords lived upstairs, among clear vinyl tablecloths and a shrine to Pope John Paul II. I ate bigos, a savory, tart stew cooked so long that its many meats fell to nearly spreadable shreds, and incredibly cheap pirogi in fluorescent restaurants, where I would laugh in amazement at how much pork and potatoes five bucks could get you. I walked around my new neighborhood, looking into shops filled with sacks and sacks of rye bread and hundreds of sausages dangling in the windows, wondering how long it would take me to learn all their names.

headline: Review: In ‘Zootopia,’ an Intrepid Bunny Chases Her Dreams
abstract: As the first rabbit police officer in Zootopia, Judy Hopps is stuck writing parking tickets, but the ambitious bunny pokes her nose into a missing-mammal epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Easter is still weeks away, but pet stores may find that the added demand for rabbits the holiday brings will come early this year thanks to the irresistible “Zootopia,” an animated movie with an intrepid bunny named Judy Hopps at its core. Her fox sidekick, Nick Wilde, is mighty enjoyable, too.

headline: Probiotics Are Common in Hospitals, but Evidence Is Lacking

lead_paragraph: Many hospitals give probiotics to patients, even though there is little evidence that these so-called “beneficial bacteria” are safe and effective.

headline: Death Toll in Ukraine Conflict Hits 9,160, U.N. Says
abstract: The number of casualties from fighting has fallen in recent months, a senior official said, but killings, abductions and torture are still being reported.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations said on Thursday that 236 civilians were killed in conflict-related violence in Ukraine in the 12-month period to mid-February, and it estimated that at least 9,160 had died since the conflict started in April 2014.

headline: Conservative Lawmakers Push New Legal Protections for Opponents of Gay Rights
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: After controversy over religious freedom bills last year, conservative lawmakers are pushing more specific legislation but running into similar opposition.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Less than a year after the Supreme Court recognized a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, conservative lawmakers across the country are pushing for a new round of legal protections for opponents of gay rights. But the proposals are meeting the kind of resistance from business interests and gay rights groups that similarly motivated, but less specific, legislation faced last year in Arkansas and Indiana.

headline: My Father, the Editor, Under Fire
abstract: When the Bangladeshi government pursues a vendetta against a newspaper, its real target is press freedom.
lead_paragraph: I scrolled through a series of videos and images. The first one was titled “Confession,” and featured a newspaper editor being harangued by a talk-show host. Further down, I saw a photograph of a crowd burning an effigy of this man. There was another, a Photoshopped image of the man with devil’s horns affixed to his head. Then there were the news stories, the tally of lawsuits against him rising to 30, 40, 70 cases. Finally, there was a statement from the prime minister of Bangladesh: The editor should resign and face trial.

headline: Divide Grows in Southeast Over Offshore Drilling Plan
abstract: Many coastal residents, fearing a repeat of the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill, see potential disaster, while those inland speak of economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: KURE BEACH, N.C. — On a recent frigid night, anxious residents, many in “Protect Our Coast” sweatshirts, packed the town hall here, spilled onto the lawn, and then erupted in cheers as their town government gaveled in a resolution urging President Obama to block oil drilling off their shoreline. “Some things are just too precious to risk,” Mayor Emilie Swearingen said.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Hurting All Over
abstract: Can you figure out what is wrong with a 36-year-old man who has had body aches for 20 years?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you figure out what is wrong with a 36-year-old man who has had body aches for many years?

headline: The English Lose Their Cool
abstract: Britain’s debate over leaving the European Union isn’t the first time it has shown its emotional side.
lead_paragraph: Milan — THE British have a reputation for being calm under pressure. It’s a stereotype, sure, but it’s something I noticed time and again in the decades I spent working in and reporting on the country, from my interactions on the street to the goings-on in Parliament. It’s written into their literature and their language, all of which seems intended to remind the world of a simple fact: They will not overreact. Rudyard Kipling’s famous lines — “If you can keep your head when all about you/Are losing theirs and blaming it on you” — are not just words from a poem. Together, they express Britain’s creed.

headline: 1916: Village a Rock Amid War
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Douaumont makes a stand against Germans in 1916.
lead_paragraph: The village of Douaumont continues to be the storm centre of the Verdun battle and the rock against which the German tide has been repeatedly broken. The Germans, after the inevitable heavy bombardment, resumed their infantry attacks late on Thursday evening.

headline: Trump’s Rise Highlights Need to Reinvent the Republican Party

lead_paragraph: The emergence of a presumptive presidential nominee typically begins a process of closure in American politics. The 2016 Republican campaign is producing the opposite.
