headline: Where China Goes to Chill
abstract: A trip to the ancient city of Chengdu, where the pace is slow, the food is spicy and there’s always time for a good gossip over a cup of tea.
lead_paragraph: It may only be the seventh-largest city in China (with an estimated 11 million people), but it’s perhaps no surprise that Chengdu, about a three-hour flight west from both Beijing and Shanghai, has emerged as an urban-getaway destination for the country’s food and shopping obsessed. The 2,300-year-old city — which is the capital of Sichuan Province in the nation’s southwest, an area long renowned for its bright, spicy cuisine — was once a hub for silk brocade and satin, and is also celebrated for being home to the country’s first distillery, as well as the onetime residence of the Tang Dynasty poet Du Fu (China’s equivalent of Horace).

headline: Indonesia’s Tsunami Sensors Were Down During Quake
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The country relied on other nations’ systems because its own sea-based buoys had not been operable since last year.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia was compelled to rely on tsunami warnings from other nations’ buoys in the Indian Ocean this week after a huge earthquake off the west coast of Sumatra because its detection system was disabled, a senior disaster agency official said on Thursday.

headline: Is It Worth Stopping Trump?
abstract: Why a contested convention might be the worst option — except for all the others.
lead_paragraph: My column after Super Tuesday made the case, increasingly the conventional wisdom among “it won’t be Trump” diehards in the commentariat, that Tuesday night’s results do not show the Donald running away with the nomination, which means that given the joint weakness and remarkable parity of his main rivals, a contested convention is now the most likely endgame for the party.

headline: Donald Trump Calls David Duke a ‘Bad Person’ and Mentions a Third-Party Run
abstract: “David Duke is a bad person, who I disavowed on numerous occasions over the years,” Donald J. Trump said in an interview on MSNBC. On the possibility of an independent run, if Mr. Trump ever decided to bolt from the Republicans, he said his supporters are “all coming with me.”
lead_paragraph: After five days of controversy, Donald J. Trump called the former Ku Klux Klan sympathizer David Duke a “bad person,” as he condemned Mitt Romney’s planned speech about the real estate developer’s rise in the Republican Party.

headline: Goldman Sachs Expands Philanthropic Fund to Younger Workers
abstract: Some millennials have still been having a hard time finding a sense of purpose underneath their pitch books and spreadsheets.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has recently seen its share of young analysts leave their six-figure salary jobs to join the scrappier worlds of start-ups, nonprofits and even food trucks. To retain them, banks increased their compensation, gave them more time off and even did away with some of their more menial work.

headline: Charles Grassley Faces Formidable Challenger in Iowa Senate Race
abstract: Patty Judge, a former Iowa lieutenant governor and state agriculture secretary, will seek the Democratic nomination to challenge the senator, who is seeking a seventh term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats on Thursday unleashed a furious assault on Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican and Judiciary Committee chairman who has become the face of his party’s refusal to hold a hearing on President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court.

headline: ‘Madonnaland,’ by Alina Simone
abstract: A book about Madonna looks at everyday people on the margins of her fame.
lead_paragraph: When Alina Simone is commissioned to write a book about Madonna, she approaches the assignment at first “with enthusiasm, even bluster.” After all, doesn’t Simone — like many of us who have grown up alongside the force of nature that has been Madonna’s career for the past three decades — know so much, have so many opinions to share, about the most iconic of icons? Soon, however, she realizes that her project differs from the sort that biographers and writers of cultural histories are often tasked with: There is no dearth of material about Madonna, but an overwhelming excess. “I maintained hope of finding some tiny stone left unturned in the giant gravel pit of Madonna studies,” Simone recalls, chastened. What could be written about Madonna that hasn’t already been written a million times over?

abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.

headline: 1941: Nazis Gather on Greek Frontier
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German troops gather in Bulgaria in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA — While Bulgarians flew flags and paraded today [March 3] in celebration of the sixty-third anniversary of the nation’s liberation from the Turks, their country was being efficiently occupied and prepared for use as a base for future operations by German forces. Already there were more than enough Nazi soldiers in Bulgaria to keep peace in the Balkans. Reports that the Germans had arrived at the Greek and Turkish frontiers could not be confirmed, but undoubtedly they were very near those lines. — New York Herald Tribune, March 4, 1941

headline: Three’s a Trend: Big, Voluminous Sleeves
abstract: Jacquemus, Marni and Y Project exaggerated typical silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: From ’80s shoulders and baggy knits to bubble skirts, the fall/winter 2016 season has been big on volume. A handful of designers, in particular, have experimented with exaggerated, ballooning sleeves. At Jacquemus (left), the designer Simon Porte Jacquemus showed a muscular navy jacket, while at Marni (center), a Harlequin-checked blouse had a Victorian feel. And at Y Project (right), most of the sleeves were long and cinched at the wrist — but we particularly loved the silhouette rendered, unexpectedly, in sweatshirt fabric.

headline: In Ukraine Towns Ravaged by War, Evangelical Missionaries Find Fertile Ground

lead_paragraph: MARYINKA, Ukraine — On a recent frosty morning, a group of evangelical missionaries piled out of a Volkswagen minivan to meet elderly and poor people who had gathered on a roadside here. They handed out loaves of bread and Bibles, declaring, “Jesus wants peace!”

headline: A Gay Couple’s Exclusion Is an Occasion to Talk
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Also, etiquette for store grazers; previewing a daughter’s birthday plans; and walking back a tasteless comment.
lead_paragraph: My best friend of 60 years, whose son is to be married, called to tell me that my same-sex partner of two years would not be included on my invitation. He said that our joint presence would deflect attention from the young  couple. I am hurt and disappointed. My friend and I have shared many joyous and sad occasions over the years, including the death of my wife of 30 years, as well as happy times in the lives of our children. What would you do?

headline: In the Studio With Fashion’s Great Hair Iconoclast
abstract: Julien D’ys — the man behind Linda Evangelista’s famous ’90s bob and every Comme des Garçons runway show — lets T into his eclectic world.
lead_paragraph: Island’ys, as it is known, the four-room workspace of the Parisian hair master Julien D’ys, is more artist’s-lair-meets-cabinet-of-curiosities than it is a hair studio. Save for a cluster of wigs on mannequins in the center of the main salon, the space is crammed with notebooks, photographs and vibrant, large-scale oil paintings by D’ys himself. The latter are portraits of models he has worked with, for the most part: Karlie Kloss as studied from a Patrick Demarchelier photo, sits front and center, and is flanked by Kate Moss and Linda Evangelista, imagined as a bright blue angel.

headline: Fleeing Trump (or Clinton): Look Out, Canada, Here They Come
abstract: A surge in Twitter outbursts, Google searches and helpful how-to guides on how to emigrate north mark another U.S. election cycle.
lead_paragraph: The online outbursts have become customary during presidential election cycles: “I’m moving to Canada!” And this week saw plenty of them, as Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump collected victories on Super Tuesday.

headline: Balmain: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Olivier Rousteing shows his fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Rousteing shows his fall collection.

headline: In the Studio With Julien D’ys
abstract: The eccentric hairstylist and painter brings T into his workspace-meets-cabinet-of-curiosities.
lead_paragraph: The eccentric hairstylist and painter brings T into his workspace-meets-cabinet-of-curiosities.

headline: Tricked Into Cheating and Sentenced to Death
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The story of how Iranian agents caught my husband with another woman, threatened to stone him to death and then forced him to denounce me.
lead_paragraph: IN August 2009, I was betrayed by both my husband and my country.

headline: Opera and Punk Come Together in Conversation Series
abstract: Marina Abramovic, Laurie Anderson and Meredith Monk are among the artists who will appear as part of National Sawdust+.
lead_paragraph: The opera diva Waltraud Meier will appear at National Sawdust, the abandoned sawdust factory turned concert hall in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on April 17 for a conversation with the proto-punk singer, poet, artist and memoirist Patti Smith — who happens to be a fan of Ms. Meier’s renowned portrayal of Wagner’s Isolde.

headline: Flint Is in the News, but Lead Poisoning Is Even Worse in Cleveland
keywords: ['Lead', 'Paint', 'Children and Childhood', 'Urban Areas', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Water']
abstract: Four decades ago, political leaders declared war on lead, citing evidence of its pernicious impact on young brains. But the crusade remains unfinished.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — One hundred fifty miles northwest of here, the residents of Flint, Mich., are still reeling from the drinking water debacle that more than doubled the share of children with elevated levels of lead in their blood — to a peak, in mid-2014, of 7 percent of all children tested.

headline: G.O.P. Foreign Policy Figures Denounce Donald Trump’s Worldview
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In an open letter, prominent figures in both Bush administrations warned that Mr. Trump’s vision of U.S. power was “wildly inconsistent” and lacking in principle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not that it will bother him much, but Donald J. Trump has lost much of the Republican foreign policy establishment.

headline: Transcript of Mitt Romney’s Speech on Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: The following is a transcript of Mitt Romney’s remarks addressing the candidacy of Donald J. Trump, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our analysis of the 11th Republican debate.

headline: The Great Balmain Model-Mane Switcheroo
abstract: At the Balmain runway show in Paris, Kendall Jenner, Gigi Hadid and others showed off new hair colors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Forget a velvet rope: The Balmain show has become such a magnet for fans and paparazzi that French police put up cordons and blockades on Thursday afternoon to control the chaos outside the Hôtel Potocki, a former nobleman’s palace a stone’s throw from the Champs-Élysées.

abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: Paperback books of particular interest.

lead_paragraph: Fashion connoisseurs show off their best street-style looks during fashion week.

abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

headline: 11th Republican Debate: Analysis
abstract: Four Republican candidates met in Detroit, Mich., after Donald J. Trump’s victories on Super Tuesday and some of the Republican establishment’s denouncement of him on Thursday. Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport provided analysis in real time.

headline: ‘Every Song Ever,’ by Ben Ratliff
abstract: In a world of expanded access, a music critic wades through the wealth of listening options.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff, the longtime popular-music critic for The New York Times, is very much an enthusiast, which is in no way remarkable among those who write about popular music — that near-oceanic category that includes jazz, world, country, folk, hip-hop, reggae, punk, goth, heavy metal, nearly everything except classical. Why bother to write about it if you don’t like it, unless you’re taking issue with a disappointing live performance? What is remarkable about Ratliff, who has written an appreciative, at times passionate book about the artistry of John Coltrane, is his musical intelligence and his almost singular breadth of knowledge and sympathy for all kinds of music. He also writes very well, a quality not at all common among those who write about music in general, a famously tricky subject, as its appeal, whether visceral or ethereal, verges on the ineffable.

headline: How to Watch the Republican Debate
abstract: There will be only four Republican candidates debating Thursday night after Ben Carson said he would not participate in light of the Super Tuesday results.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our analysis of the 11th Republican debate.

headline: Ambac Financial Gets Pressed to Make a Move
abstract: Buying up claims can help the company, but doing so too quickly could hinder the bond insurer’s ability to meet other liabilities.
lead_paragraph: The Ambac Financial Group is getting the right pressure but from the wrong place.

headline: In Praise of Pioneering Women
abstract: Olivier Rousteing name-checks supermodels at Balmain, while Chloé celebrates independence and Paco Rabanne fires up.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Given the current uneasy state of things in France — the controversial dismantling of the migrant camp near Calais, the scanning of bags at Paris Fashion Week and, depending on the show, guests; the organizers’ announcement that they would not disclose locations publicly because of safety concerns — it takes a certain amount of gumption for a designer to claim as a muse the first woman to ride a motorcycle solo across the Middle East (and then around the world).

headline: A Critic’s Education
abstract: Ben Ratliff, a music critic at The Times, on the books that “helped teach me how to hear and how to write.”
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff has been a music critic at The Times since 1996, writing about everything from the saxophonist Ornette Coleman to the experimental metal band Sunn O))). This week, August Kleinzahler reviews Ratliff’s new book, “Every Song Ever: Twenty Ways to Listen in an Age of Musical Plenty.”

headline: ‘The Wave’ and the Disaster Movie Formula
abstract: “The Wave” — can you guess what it’s about? — exemplifies the disaster-movie playbook. Here’s a look at the film and others that share its D.N.A.
lead_paragraph: “The Wave” — can you guess what it’s about? — exemplifies the disaster-movie playbook. Here’s a look at the film and others that share its D.N.A.

lead_paragraph: Fashion connoisseurs show off their best street-style looks during fashion week.

headline: If Bernie Sanders Loses
abstract: If you support Bernie Sanders and he is not the Democratic nominee, would you vote for Hillary Clinton? Let us know.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Elliott Discloses Stake in Qlik Technologies
abstract: The hedge fund said in a regulatory filing that it had begun talks with Qlik’s management about strategic moves, including a potential sale.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Elliott Management, the hedge fund that has become a specialist in shaking up technology companies, has found its new target.

headline: Steps We Can Take to Prevent Opioid Abuse
abstract: Readers discuss how school, family and community programs and better drug packaging can deter drug use.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Wounded Marco Rubio Falls Back to Florida
abstract: The Florida senator’s campaign has apparently given up on Ohio, and some suggest that his best hope may lie in a convention battle, however implausible.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Confident just two weeks ago that he could win Ohio and cement his path to the Republican nomination, Marco Rubio now plans to spend almost no time or money there at all. He is resigned to hunting for smaller prizes like Puerto Rico, where he will campaign this weekend.

headline: Study Finds Surprising Benefit of Viral DNA: Fighting Other Viruses
abstract: A report in the journal Science reveals how evolution harnessed viral DNA to rewire humans’ own genetic circuitry and strengthen the immune system.
lead_paragraph: What could be more alien than a virus? It’s a nanobiological weapon — a microscopic protein shell holding a few genes that hijack a cell’s internal machinery, forcing it to make new viruses. The battles we fight with these alien enemies brings malaise, scars and even death.

headline: Barbara Cook to Appear in One-Woman Show at New World Stages
abstract: “Barbara Cook: Then and Now,” inspired by a coming book of the same name, begins performances on April 13.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Cook, a Tony and Grammy winner and longtime Broadway fixture, will appear in a one-woman Off Broadway show inspired by her coming memoir.

headline: Donald Trump’s Talk on Health Care Is Not Matched by His Plan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The proposal would wipe out protections for those with pre-existing conditions and end coverage for the poor in many states.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump talks about health care, he sounds as if he wants to do something different from the rest of the Republican field. But his health care plan, released Wednesday night, looks a lot like what his competitors have already presented.

headline: College Lecturer Accuses New York Police of Racial Bias After Encounter on His Roof
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Search and Seizure', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Damion Scott, an adjunct lecturer at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said two officers unlawfully handcuffed and searched him after he was locked out of his apartment building.
lead_paragraph: A man who has taught a course in law and ethics at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice is criticizing two New York City police officers, saying they unlawfully handcuffed and searched him after he was locked out on the roof of his building in Hamilton Heights.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Mr. Owen’s fall 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Owen’s fall 2016 show.

headline: VW Scandal Clouds Prospects for Other Diesel Makers at Geneva Motor Show
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution', 'Geneva International Motor Show', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: Automakers’ plans to use diesel to meet Europe’s tough carbon dioxide limits have been upended by Volkswagen’s admission that it cheated on emissions tests.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Thanks a lot, Volkswagen.

headline: Jobs for Minorities
abstract: The head of an employment and training agency writes that “policy makers must resist the temptation to claim ‘Mission Accomplished’ in tackling unemployment.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Republican Turmoil Has Historians Straining for Parallels
abstract: Mitt Romney’s political assault on Donald J. Trump on Thursday was so savage that historians strained to recall any precedent in American politics, with a major party’s former nominee blistering his party’s leading presidential candidate in such a personal and sweeping fashion.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s political assault on Donald J. Trump on Thursday was so savage that historians strained to recall any precedent in American politics, with a major party’s former nominee blistering his party’s leading presidential candidate in such a personal and sweeping fashion.

headline: New Critique Sees Flaws in Landmark Analysis of Psychology Studies
abstract: The new scrutiny of a report that placed doubt on many psychological studies because they could not be replicated noted problems with the retesting.
lead_paragraph: A landmark 2015 report that cast doubt on the results of dozens of published psychology studies has exposed deep divisions in the field, serving as a reality check for many working researchers but as an affront to others who continue to insist the original research was sound.

headline: Romney Versus Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why Romney’s broadside was the right thing to do.
lead_paragraph: The sophisticated take on Mitt Romney’s remarkable broadside against Donald Trump’s policy positions, business acumen and personal morals this morning is that it was an unforced blunder that probably only helps Trump. After all, who more than Romney embodies the establishment that Trump’s followers so despise? Who more than Romney, who lost to Obama in a race most Republicans expected to win, embodies the lack of “winning” that Trump has so skillfully attacked? How can Romney of all people, a scion of wealth and a frequent flip-flopper, be the right person to press the case that Trump is an unprincipled silver-spooner? And didn’t Romney accept Trump’s endorsement just four short years ago?

headline: Facts & Figures: A Drop in Marijuana Smuggling
abstract: A decrease in the amount of marijuana confiscated at the border with Mexico may be due to legalization efforts in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Agents at the United States border with Mexico confiscated about 1.5 million pounds of marijuana last year. That’s the smallest amount in at least 10 years, The Washington Post’s Wonkblog reports, and the drop may be due to increased production in states where marijuana is legal.

headline: Republicans Have a Stake in Making a Deal on a Supreme Court Justice
abstract: Given recent poll numbers and the chance that they may lose the Senate, Republicans might want to consider an Obama nominee for the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republican leaders have insisted they won’t consider an Obama nominee to the Supreme Court, leaving that choice to the next president. But they may want to reconsider after this week — especially if they care about protecting the pro-business rulings that are among the late Justice Antonin Scalia’s most important legacies.

headline: Step-by-Step Fitness History on an iPhone
abstract: Apple’s Health app can store a comprehensive record of your fitness activity.
lead_paragraph: Q. I can see my step count for the day, week, month or year on the graph in the iPhone 6 health program, but does it store the amount of past recorded steps by specific day?

headline: John Kasich’s Plan: Win Ohio on March 15, Then Fight at the Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: The Ohio governor said that winning his home state’s primary would stop Mr. Trump from clinching the nomination before the party’s convention in July.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on Thursday echoed calls to derail Donald J. Trump, and he predicted that if he won his home state, the Republican nomination would be decided at the party’s convention in July.

headline: P.K. Subban’s Bare-Bones Gym Routine
abstract: A rising star of the National Hockey League has a simple workout regimen that contrasts with his flashy style of play.
lead_paragraph: P. K. Subban, a star defenseman for the Montreal Canadiens, is known as much for his flashy style of play as for his wicked slap shot. “I grew up in the inner city,” said Mr. Subban, who is from Toronto. “I went to school with kids that didn’t know anything about hockey. Most of the guys I played with went to private school or lived in predominantly white neighborhoods.”

headline: Readers React: Pet Allergies and Air Travel
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'ALLERGIES', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Pets']
abstract: A boy who was asked to leave a flight after he had an allergic reaction to a dog prompted criticism and commentary about animals on planes.
lead_paragraph: Last week In Transit posted an article about a boy and his parents who were asked to leave their Allegiant Air flight after the boy developed an allergic reaction to a dog, a service animal. More than 350 readers posted comments about the incident — and about animals, service and otherwise, on planes. Here is a sampling.

headline: How to Build an Art Fair
abstract: A time-lapsed video shows Spring Studios’ transformation from an airy, empty space to the fully installed Independent fair, previewing tonight.
lead_paragraph: During their vernissages, or preview nights, art fairs look as polished as their V.I.P.s — but it takes months of planning and several construction days to erect the necessary infrastructure. This week, the Independent art fair raised walls on four floors of Spring Studios, its airy new home in TriBeCa (also the site, just last month, of several big New York Fashion Week shows). With BBM Development, Independent’s construction crew, leading the charge, here’s a time-lapsed look at the fair and its exhibitors getting ready for tonight’s big reveal.

headline: Four Handsomely Sporty Stopwatches for Men
abstract: Elegant, black-on-black chronographs that are as functional as they are attractive.
lead_paragraph: Elegant, black-on-black chronographs that are as functional as they are attractive.

headline: Talk to North Korea
abstract: A Korea expert writes that “only diplomacy and upfront discussion” will settle the conflict.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Two Eerie Armory Installations, From One Buzzy Artist
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: Kapwani Kiwanga, the recipient of the show’s Artist Commission, will show both sisal-based sculptures and a video work.
lead_paragraph: The research-based artist Kapwani Kiwanga, best known for the ongoing series she started in 2011 of cut-flower arrangements symbolic of African independence, is having a big Armory week. She’s represented in the fair twice, both as the recipient of its Artist Commission, headlining the fair’s “Focus: African Perspectives” spotlight section, and in a joint booth operated by her representation Galerie Jerome Poggi, Paris, and Galerie Tanja Wagner, Berlin. So she’s created two separate Armory projects — one plant-derived and the other stemming from an eerie photograph.

headline: You Married Them Once, but What About Twice?
abstract: Some couples are discovering marriage may not always be forever, but neither is divorce.
lead_paragraph: After 22 years, the divorce didn’t work out for Sagan Lewis and Tom Fontana.

headline: Americans Are Speaking. Republicans Aren’t Listening.
abstract: Senate Republicans say the people’s voice should be heard on Supreme Court nominees. They should take a look at the polls.
lead_paragraph: As Washington gears up for a brutal Supreme Court nomination battle, the Senate Republicans continue to insist preposterously that their obstructionism is meant to heed the people’s voice.

headline: Spain Seizes 20,000 Military Uniforms Bound for ISIS
abstract: The uniforms were part of a shipment declared as “secondhand clothing” and were hidden inside three shipping containers intercepted in the ports of Valencia and Algeciras.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish authorities on Thursday announced the seizure of about 20,000 military uniforms that were being shipped from Spanish ports to fighters with the Islamic State and other Islamist groups, according to the Interior Ministry.

headline: Donald Trump Dismisses Mitt Romney as a ‘Lightweight’ and a ‘Failed Candidate’
abstract: Mr. Trump struck back against Mr. Romney, deriding the 2012 Republican presidential nominee as “a choke artist” who should keep his nose out of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump struck back against Mitt Romney on Thursday afternoon, deriding him as a “lightweight” and “a failed candidate” who should keep his nose out of the 2016 presidential race.

headline: Romney Denounces Trump, and Trump Responds
abstract: Mitt Romney pleaded with Republicans to support a presidential candidate other than Donald Trump, and Mr. Trump swiftly responded.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney pleaded with Republicans to support a presidential candidate other than Donald Trump, and Mr. Trump swiftly responded.

headline: Debating Zoe Saldana, Nina Simone and the Spectrum of Black Skin
abstract: With the unveiling of a poster and a trailer for the movie “Nina” came new questions about whether Ms. Saldana was the right choice for the title role.
lead_paragraph: A debate over whether Zoe Saldana is the right actress to star in a biopic of Nina Simone, the black singer, pianist and civil rights activist, has been reignited after a poster and trailer of the movie were unveiled  online this week and a message from a Twitter account belonging to representatives of Ms. Simone’s estate attacked the actress.

headline: As the Wild Campaign Rolls On
abstract: Readers discuss the political scene, including Republican leaders’ efforts to derail Donald Trump’s candidacy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With Clear Vision, Two Americans Brace for Rio’s Polluted Waters
abstract: Winning a medal and taking medical precautions are priorities for Helena Scutt and Paris Henken, who will compete in an event that puts sailors in close contact with ocean spray.
lead_paragraph: If a broken spine, two fractured ribs and a lacerated kidney did not put an end to Helena Scutt’s Olympic dreaming, it should come as no surprise that she and her crewmate, Paris Henken, are not prepared to let the health risks in Rio de Janeiro dissuade them from taking part in their first Games.

headline: ‘Look at the Data.’ Each Number Is a Child. Notes From the Lead Beat.
abstract: The reporter Michael Wines describes the tip that led to his article about millions of children at risk for lead poisoning.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that some children in a lot of cities, mostly in poorer areas, have elevated levels of lead. It is not even a secret that many cities have a greater share of such children than beleaguered Flint, Mich.; in the wake of the Flint debacle, local newspapers across the East wrote that story about their own children, again and again.

headline: Well Family: A New Name and New Home for Motherlode
abstract: The Times is introducing Well Family, a new online report with expanded coverage of parenting, childhood health and relationships to help every family live well.
lead_paragraph: When The New York Times started Motherlode in 2008, the name was a play on words that marked our entry into the world of parenting blogs. But like many readers, I questioned the name of a parenting report that, by definition, seemed to exclude half of all parents.

headline: Another ‘Cloverfield’ Comes Out of Nowhere
abstract: J.J. Abrams, who surprised moviegoers in 2008 with the release of “Cloverfield,” drops a pseudo-sequel, “10 Cloverfield Lane.”
lead_paragraph: J.J. Abrams was explaining recently how he is no great fan of what he called “jump scares”: Those moments in horror films that rely purely on surprise, and what is just out of view, to make you leap out of your seat.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist, Hockey’s Fashion Leader
abstract: A talk with the New York Rangers goalie about his five favorite things.
lead_paragraph: The New York Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, 34, joined the team for the 2005-6 season at age 23. Back then, the native of Are, Sweden, was teased for his skinny jeans, skinny ties and European flair. He stuck with his look and is now known as perhaps the most stylish guy in the National Hockey League.

headline: Terrence Malick’s ‘Knight of Cups’ Is an Insider’s Tale
abstract: This new experimental drama stars Christian Bale as a screenwriter and offers up a glimpse at Hollywood’s corridors of power.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to his cultivated mystique, Terrence Malick has long enjoyed a reputation as Hollywood’s man who wasn’t there. He’s the visionary auteur who dropped off the movie radar for two decades after writing and directing the 1978 drama “Days of Heaven,” only to roar back into public consciousness with the war epic “The Thin Red Line,” which landed seven Oscar nominations, including best picture and director, in 1999.

headline: Europe, Reeling From Strain, Tells Economic Migrants: Don’t Bother
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Remarks by Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, signaled Europe’s determined turn away from Germany’s approach to absorbing migrants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As Europe’s migrant crisis spiraled toward yet another humanitarian catastrophe, a European Union leader issued a stark warning Thursday to millions in search of economic opportunity: Stay away.

headline: Why Barnes & Noble Isn’t Going Away Yet
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Company Reports']
abstract: A look at how the struggling bookstore chain is surviving in a challenging environment as it reports its quarterly earnings.
lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble had another not-so-bad quarter, which these days counts as good for the struggling bookstore chain. When the company reported its earnings on Thursday for the third fiscal quarter of 2016, there were signs that the steep losses that have plagued it in recent years may finally be leveling off.

headline: Green Beret Who Hit Afghan Child Rapist Should Be Reinstated, Lawmakers Say
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Assaults']
abstract: Sgt. First Class Charles Martland faces discharge after he helped to beat up an Afghan militia commander who kept a boy chained to his bed as a sex slave.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers are calling on the Pentagon to fully reinstate a decorated United States Army sergeant whose career status is under review after he hit an American-backed Afghan militia officer for raping a boy.

headline: Ex-Homelessness Chief Is Appointed as New York Family Court Judge
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Family Courts']
abstract: Gilbert Taylor, who resigned in December amid near-record levels of homelessness, began his career as a litigator for the Administration for Children’s Services.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after Gilbert Taylor resigned as the commissioner of homeless services amid record levels of homelessness in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio has named him a judge in Family Court.

headline: Twilight in the House of Ghibli, as ‘The Boy and the Beast’ Roars
keywords: ['Movies', 'ANIMATED FILMS', "New York International Children's Film Festival"]
abstract: While the giants Hayao Miyazaki (“Spirited Away”) and Isao Takahata (“Grave of the Fireflies”) near retirement, anime offers emerging creators.
lead_paragraph: To much of the world, Studio Ghibli has defined Japanese animation since the 1990s, producing classics like Hayao Miyazaki’s “Princess Mononoke” and Isao Takahata’s “Grave of the Fireflies.” But those titans of the genre haven’t made a film in three years. Mr. Miyazaki, 75, announced his retirement from features in 2013, and while Mr. Takahata, 80, is a producer of the coming Ghibli release “The Red Turtle,” he has announced no definite plans to direct more films. And Ghibli itself has not released a film in nearly two years.

headline: Apology Puts Carmelo Anthony at Odds With the Knicks
abstract: Anthony made it clear on Thursday that he did not think a heckler at Tuesday night’s Knicks game deserved Wednesday’s apology.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The shelf life of Carmelo Anthony’s brief interaction with a heckler during the Knicks’ loss Tuesday night to the Portland Trail Blazers has proved to be amazingly long. On Wednesday, the team issued a statement on Anthony’s “behalf” in which he expressed regret for his actions. On Thursday, Anthony apologized for nothing.

headline: ‘Triumph of the Will’: Fascist Rants and the Hollywood Response
abstract: Leni Riefenstahl’s largely staged “documentary” about the 1934 Nazi Party Congress inspired American filmmakers to address its imagery.
lead_paragraph: Brilliant, tedious and irredeemably evil, Leni Riefenstahl’s “Triumph of the Will” (1935) is one of the great conundrums of cinema history.

headline: Is Worry Worthwhile in Confronting Climate Change?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'News and News Media', 'Stroke', 'Sustainable Living', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: Andrew Revkin discusses a tough assignment — digging in on what he’s learned, and unlearned, in three decades of reporting on climate change and explaining why worry is not the first feeling that emerges.
lead_paragraph: Is worry worthwhile in confronting a challenge as complex and sprawling — in time and geography — as greenhouse-driven climate change?

headline: Review: Memoirs From Two Eras Testify to Prison’s Corrosive Effect
abstract: “The Life and the Adventures of a Haunted Convict” and “Writing My Wrongs” paint harrowing portraits of incarceration in America.
lead_paragraph: Two newly published prison memoirs — one contemporary, the other written in the late 1850s — provide harrowing portraits of life behind bars. They also speak to the personal consequences of what is today an epidemic of mass incarceration: America has the largest prison population in the world, and one in 35 African-American men are in prison.

headline: Apple Is Rolling Up Backers in iPhone Privacy Fight Against F.B.I.
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Security', 'iPhone', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.
lead_paragraph: Google, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and a parade of other technology companies filed a barrage of court briefs on Thursday, aiming to puncture the United States government’s legal arguments against Apple in a case that will test the limits of the authorities’ access to personal data.

headline: Tech Companies’ Court Brief
abstract: A group of Internet companies submitted this court brief supporting Apple in the case in which the government is seeking Apple’s help to break into an iPhone used by a gunman in the San Bernardino terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: A group of Internet companies submitted this court brief supporting Apple in the case in which the government is seeking Apple’s help to break into an iPhone used by a gunman in the San Bernardino terrorist attack.

headline: Donald Trump Held Briefing With Richard Haass, Head of Council on Foreign Relations
abstract: Mr. Trump held a private briefing last August with Richard N. Haass, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, a spokeswoman for Mr. Haass said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who again declined on Thursday morning to say whom he talks to about foreign affairs, held a private briefing last summer with Richard N. Haass, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, a spokeswoman for Mr. Haass said Thursday.

headline: Gov. Rick Scott Says No Endorsement Before Florida Primary
abstract: Amid speculation that he would back Donald J. Trump over Senator Marco Rubio, Mr. Scott said he would not endorse anyone before the state’s presidential primary on March 15.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, a Republican who won a 2010 primary as an insurgent businessman running against a veteran politician, said on Thursday that he would not make an endorsement before the presidential primary in his state on March 15.

headline: Law Firm’s First Latina Partner, With Boost From N.Y.U. Program
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Law Schools', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The AnBryce program aims to give students from disadvantaged backgrounds the financial and networking support needed to succeed in school and beyond.
lead_paragraph: As a young girl helping her parents run their Brooklyn bodega, Damaris Hernández would not have dared to dream that she would one day become a lawyer, let alone a partner in one of world’s most rarefied legal firms.

headline: Security Logs of Hillary Clinton’s Email Server Are Said to Show No Evidence of Hacking
abstract: The records bolster her assertion that her use of a personal account as secretary of state did not give secrets to hackers or foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former aide to Hillary Clinton has turned over to the F.B.I. computer security logs from Mrs. Clinton’s private server, records that showed no evidence of foreign hacking, according to people close to a federal investigation into Mrs. Clinton’s emails.

headline: Unearthed Works by Abbott Handerson Thayer to Be Exhibited
abstract: Mr. Thayer developed ideas for concealing troops, battlefield equipment, battleships and submarines. Also, the Jewish Museum explores fake heirlooms.
lead_paragraph: The painter Abbott Handerson Thayer ran an impractical household. In the early 1900s, he and his dutiful second wife, Emma, raised his three children in ramshackle buildings in Dublin, N.H. Fervent believers in the benefits of fresh air, they let snow drift into their sleeping cabins. Pets and wildlife, including monkeys and porcupines, roamed their rooms. Mr. Thayer was prone to mood swings, and he sometimes destroyed his canvases or stowed them under a kitchen sink. Wealthy devotees like the art collector Charles Lang Freer assisted the family financially, while Mr. Thayer spent time portraying angels and pondering how to adapt animal camouflage patterns for military use.

headline: Justice Thomas Talks; People Listen: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Justice Clarence Thomas breaks his 10-year silence. A Times reporter misses the moment but gets the story — and its significance.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas breaks his 10-year silence. A Times reporter misses the moment but gets the story — and its significance.

lead_paragraph: Results for fingerprints discovered at the scene where Garrett was killed.

abstract: Photos from Turkey, Russia, China and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Russia, China and India.

headline: Review: In ‘Emelie,’ Don’t Tell Mom the Babysitter’s Deadly
abstract: In this horror film directed by Michael Thelin, a girl hired to mind the children in a household turns out to be a dire threat to them.
lead_paragraph: Like some other contemporary shockers that bridge the art house and the grindhouse, the low-key horror movie “Emelie” opens with a scene straight out of the auteur Michael Haneke’s playbook. In long shot, a teenage girl walking on a tree-canopied street in Anywhere, U.S.A., is suddenly snatched and hustled into a car. It’s a disquieting overture, partly because it takes place in daylight. Mostly, though, it’s because there are no close-ups of the assault, no cutaways to the presumably terrified victim or views of her two abductors, a man and a woman who materialize as if out of nowhere. This is terror at an artful remove.

headline: In Senate Brawl Over Court Nominee, Knuckles Will Be Bare
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Let the battle begin: President Obama intends to nominate a replacement for Justice Antonin Scalia, and the Republicans plan to ignore it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top Senate Democrats yearn for video of President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee being ignored outside Senator Mitch McConnell’s suite just off the Senate floor, perhaps snacking on the Hershey’s chocolate kisses the Kentucky Republican keeps in small bowls in his outer office.

headline: Review: Alessandra Ferri, Herman Cornejo and Piano Makes Three
abstract: Two dancers who discovered their chemistry only after they were no longer with the same company are together in TRIO ConcertDance at the Joyce.
lead_paragraph: Who knows when a dance partnership will blossom? Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo were members of American Ballet Theater at the same time, but didn’t discover their chemistry until they were cast as the leads in “Chéri,” Martha Clarke’s 2013 production about an older woman and her young lover. Ms. Ferri was 50 and Mr. Cornejo was 32.

headline: Mickalene Thomas and Derrick Adams’s Fair Trade Dance Party
abstract: The artist and curator, old friends from college, celebrated the beginning of Armory Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The artist and curator, old friends from college, celebrated the beginning of Armory Week in New York.

headline: An Art Party, With Dancing (Really!)
abstract: The artists Derrick Adams and Mickalene Thomas hosted the Fair Trade celebration in a Chinatown basement last night.
lead_paragraph: Each year, the artists Derrick Adams and Mickalene Thomas, who met as undergraduate students at Pratt in the ’90s, celebrate their January 28 birthday together. “He’s been a friend and is an inspiration — he’s like a brother to me,” Thomas said last night, when they — unofficially, belatedly — marked this year’s occasion with the Fair Trade dance party in the basement of the Wyndham Garden Chinatown. (They also had a proper, timelier dinner at the Beatrice Inn in January.)

headline: ‘You Could Look It Up,’ by Jack Lynch
abstract: A professor examines the history of putting words and concepts in accessible order.
lead_paragraph: From the days of Copernicus to our own time, scientists have tried to teach us humility: that our minuscule species is only a speck on a tiny planet in one of the least important galaxies of the seemingly incommensurable universe. And yet, with stubborn pride, we see ourselves at the center of everything known and unknown, decreeing what things are, under what label they might be permitted to exist and what place they should be allotted on our library shelves. In the Judeo-Christian tradition, even God submits to our chutzpah and brings to the brand-new Adam all the creatures he has made to see how Adam would define them. “And whatsoever Adam called every living creature,” Genesis tells us, “that was the name thereof.” In the beginning was a dictionary.

headline: ‘Movie Freak,’ by Owen Gleiberman
abstract: A longtime film critic mixes memoir and thoughts about the job.
lead_paragraph: Soon after becoming a second-string movie critic at The Boston Phoenix early in his career, Owen Gleiberman drew a rebuke from a friend and former college professor, who chided him for being too negative about a certain film. “You looked at the glass and fixated on the part that was empty,” the professor said. “The way you wrote that review, it’s as if you were punishing the film for not being a masterpiece. It’s a good movie. And that’s all it has to be.”

headline: ‘Master of Ceremonies: A Memoir,’ by Joel Grey
abstract: Joel Grey’s memoir recounts his conflicts and struggles.
lead_paragraph: Every actor both craves and fears “the role of a lifetime”: that warm mantle of fame, fulfillment and maybe even financial security that like the red shoes of lore can never be completely removed. Rather than try, Joel Grey has chosen to burrow down into his R.O.A.L., examine every ­fiber — even though it was a leering creep, the rouged M.C. of the Kit Kat Klub in Hal Prince’s “Cabaret” and the utter antithesis of his own nice-guy persona.

headline: War Nurse, Now 100, Saw It All
abstract: Mimi Greeley, 100, lives on her own in Manhattan but spends a lot of time on the phone with a fellow World War II Army nurse, who’s only 99.
lead_paragraph: “I hope you brought your sense of humor,” said Mimi Greeley, greeting a visitor on Wednesday to her apartment, where she was accessorized with a walker, a hot pink feather boa and a tiara on her head.

headline: Review: ‘Rimbaud in New York’ Splices the Genes of the Original Outlaw Artist
abstract: This collage tribute piece celebrates the French poet Arthur Rimbaud as the man who invented downtown as a state of mind.
lead_paragraph: It is the consensus of the seriously cool that nobody was ever cooler than Arthur Rimbaud. More than a century after his death, this French poet still blazes as the unwashed apotheosis of the outlaw artist, a beautiful, sexually fluid renegade genius who, as one of his early biographers put it, “lived in three years the literary evolution of modern times.”

headline: Judges Seem Skeptical of Tom Brady’s Deflategate Claims
abstract: The judges appeared unsympathetic on Thursday to the player’s defense, perhaps signaling that he would again face a four-game suspension.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court panel indicated Thursday that it was not sympathetic to Patriots quarterback Tom Brady’s defense in what is known as the Deflategate case, perhaps signaling that it will overturn the district court’s ruling against the N.F.L.

headline: Vijay Iyer and Mark Turner Help Open the Met Breuer
abstract: Mr. Iyer, the 2015-16 artist in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, began his residency in the Breuer’s lobby.
lead_paragraph: Vijay Iyer exchanged a look with his duet partner, Mark Turner, just after noon on Tuesday, half an hour into the inaugural performance in the Met Breuer’s lobby gallery. They had just wove through an uninterrupted chain of jazz standards — Mr. Iyer at a Steinway piano and Mr. Turner on his tenor saxophone — as part of a press preview for the museum, and the kickoff of “Relation,” a residency that will keep Mr. Iyer very busy through the end of this month.

headline: Melvin Sokolsky’s “Paris Pictures”
abstract: The photographer’s fantastical, pre-Photoshop images depict couture-clad women flying around Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s fantastical, pre-Photoshop images depict couture-clad women flying around Paris.

headline: Fantastical, Impossible (and Entirely Photoshop-Free) Vintage Fashion Photos
abstract: Melvin Sokolsky’s magical “Paris Pictures” depict couture-clad women flying around town.
lead_paragraph: The sublime magic and fun captured in Melvin Sokolsky’s “The Paris Pictures,” on view at Staley-Wise Gallery, are eye-catching — even all these years (and Photoshop fakeries) later. Melvin Sokolsky was a self-taught 21-year-old when he started his career at Harper’s Bazaar in 1959; he was a pioneer of the experimental and playful fashion photography of the 1960s. Inspired by surrealism and futurism, he created fantastical images of couture-clad women flying in and around Paris and New York — truly a feat in a pre-digital age.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey,’ the Good, the Bad and the Forgotten
abstract: You enjoyed the Crawleys when they were the hot new thing, then you drifted. But with end times approaching, here’s a crash course in Downtonology.
lead_paragraph: YOU didn’t stay the course.

headline: Review: In ‘Whiskey Tango Foxtrot,’ Tina Fey as a Wisecracking War Reporter
abstract: Based on Kim Barker’s memoir, “The Taliban Shuffle,” the comedy depicts the battle-tested experience of a journalist in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Based on Kim Barker’s memoir, “The Taliban Shuffle,” “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot” contains the fondly, proudly recalled details of battle-tested experience. Kim — last name “Baker” in the film — goes from typing TV news in an office to a tour of duty as a journalist in war-ravaged Afghanistan. She dashes into a shootout to get video, parries the clumsy advances of an Afghan government official and frequents the hormone-addled expat party scene.

headline: Berta Cáceres, Indigenous Activist, Is Killed in Honduras
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Indigenous People', 'Land Use Policies', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Levees and Dams']
abstract: Ms. Cáceres, a winner of the Goldman Environmental Prize, had led a decade-long fight against a proposal to build the Agua Zarca Dam.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — An indigenous activist in Honduras who won a prestigious international environmental prize for fighting a dam project despite continued threats was assassinated on Thursday in her hometown, officials said.

headline: Review: In ‘Knight of Cups,’ a Writer’s Flesh Is Willing but His Spirit Is Weak
abstract: Starring Christian Bale, Terrence Malick’s film addresses the existential, and erotic, issues of a screenwriter in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The last word uttered in Terrence Malick’s “Knight of Cups” — whispered in voice-over, like most of the other speech in the movie — is “begin.” Curiously enough, that is also the penultimate word of “Portnoy’s Complaint.”

headline: Joe Biden: The Senate’s Duty on a Supreme Court Nominee
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It would be an astonishing act of obstruction for Senate Republicans to not consider Obama’s nominee to succeed Justice Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: IN my 36-year tenure in the United States Senate — nearly half of it as chairman or ranking Democrat on the Judiciary Committee — I presided or helped preside over nine nominees to the Supreme Court, from both Republican and Democratic presidents. That’s more than anyone else alive today.

headline: Spare Times for March 4-10
abstract: ‘Heart of Hearts’ (through Sunday) This public art exhibit is sure to be selfie central in its final days. The display of 12 reflective gold hearts featuring 6 internal “kissing booths” allows visitors a space that straddles the border between private affection and public performance. Designed by Collective-LOK, the piece was this year’s winner for the Times Square Alliance Valentine Heart Design competition. It is where Broadway and Seventh Avenue intersect at 46th Street. Father Duffy Square, Times Square, timessquarenyc.org; free.

headline: Review: ‘The Wave’ Is a Disaster Movie Making a Big Splash
abstract: Roar Uthaug’s disaster movie follows a family and others in a Norwegian village confronting a crumbling mountain and the cataclysm that follows.
lead_paragraph: The flashy number in “The Wave” rolls in like a star. You know it’s coming, just not when. (Fanning the crowd’s anxiety is crucial to making a great entrance.) Once it arrives, the crowd gawks and freezes, mesmerized by the spectacle of so much ferocious power. And, like all stars, the wave waits for no one. A palpably convincing digital creation, this churning gray inundation powers straight into the little people, who panic and scatter, creating a regular day-of-the-locust free-for-all that separates children from parents, the survivors from the newly dead.

headline: Review: Russian National Orchestra Plays Borodin and Prokofiev
abstract: The orchestra, conducted by Mikhail Pletnev at Carnegie Hall, included the “Firebird” Suite and a Violin concerto featuring Stefan Jackiw.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers could be forgiven for wondering in recent weeks whether the great line of Russian maestros had been reduced to a lone survivor, as Valery Gergiev oversaw The Mariinsky at BAM, a 12-day festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, then led the Vienna Philharmonic in a weekend at Carnegie Hall. Carnegie provided an answer on Wednesday evening, presenting the Russian National Orchestra under Mikhail Pletnev, a conductor of a different stripe.

headline: Friday File: A Look at the Golden Age for Oscar-Nominated Newspaper Movies
abstract: In the 1930s reporters were the heroes, but not exactly exemplars of the Fourth Estate.
lead_paragraph: Journalists are still cheering, objectivity be darned, for “Spotlight,” awarded the Oscar for best picture on Sunday.

headline: Florida Revamps Death Penalty, Making It Harder to Sentence Someone to Die
abstract: The new legislation grew out a Supreme Court order saying jurors did not have enough say in whether someone was put to death for committing a crime.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With Florida’s capital punishment system at a standstill, the state Senate passed a compromise bill on Thursday that would overhaul Florida’s death sentencing law, allowing the state to resume death penalty prosecutions by making it harder for juries to send someone to death row.

headline: Review: ‘Trapped,’ a Documentary, Looks at Abortion Clinics in the South
abstract: Dawn Porter’s film offers an examination of clinics facing the so-called TRAP laws, or the targeted regulation of abortion providers.
lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court’s hearing of  a challenge to a 2013 Texas law imposing stringent requirements on abortion providers comes Dawn Porter’s “Trapped,” the winner of the Sundance Film Festival’s Special Jury Award for Social Impact Filmmaking and an urgent, vital examination of Southern abortion clinics. The film’s subjects face so-called TRAP laws (the letters stand for targeted regulation of abortion providers), whose critics say aim to close clinics or reduce their number by placing unaffordable or unfeasible demands on them.

headline: Review: ‘Colliding Dreams’ Explores Varying Viewpoints on Zionism
abstract: This documentary covers a movement’s development over more than a century, from the pogroms that drove Jews from Europe in the 1880s to the 1995 assassination of Yitzhak Rabin.
lead_paragraph: The history of Zionism — and the movement’s changes before and after the establishment of Israel — is a topic that could easily fill multiple libraries. “Colliding Dreams” takes on the unwieldy task of condensing it into a feature documentary that presents several points of view.

headline: Review: ‘White Lies,’ the Stately Weight of the Past
abstract: A quiet tale of cultural oppression, in Maori and English, set in the New Zealand of more than 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Quiet, graceful, stately and infused with slow tension, Dana Rotberg’s “White Lies” unfolds with inexorable weight. Set in rural New Zealand, the movie begins in the late 19th century, with the death of the father of Paraiti, a Maori girl, at the hands of white settlers, in a conflict that leaves her permanently scarred on her cheek. You might assume that a story of vengeance awaits, but it does not, at least how you would expect.

headline: Clip: ‘Cemetery of Splendour’
abstract: A scene from Apichatpong Weerasethakul’s film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Apichatpong Weerasethakul’s film.

keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The deal comes a few days after Perseus sold its publishing business to the Hachette Book Group.
lead_paragraph: The Perseus Books Group reached an agreement to sell its distribution business to the Ingram Content Group, a large book printer and distributor, the companies announced on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘Cemetery of Splendour,’ a Nod to Dream Logic
abstract: A muted dreamscape from the Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul, who is best known for his “Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives.”
lead_paragraph: In the final quarter of “Cemetery of Splendour,” the latest feature from the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul, there’s an unusual exchange among the three main characters.

headline: Mount Vernon, N.Y., Police Found Not Responsible for Woman’s Death in Holding Cell
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman said the inquiry into Raynette Turner’s death also showed that there was “no good reason” for the delay in her arraignment on theft charges.
lead_paragraph: The police in Mount Vernon, N.Y., were not responsible for the death last year of a woman in their custody after she was arrested on suspicion of stealing crab legs from a wholesale food store, according to an investigation by the state attorney general released on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.
