abstract: Gucci’s graffiti turn, simple, elegant suits — and, of course, lots of good food.
lead_paragraph: 1. The Graffiti at Gucci

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for March 4-10
abstract: “Try it!” many parents cajole, urging children to taste a new food. But while that approach ultimately worked for the title dish in Dr. Seuss’s “Green Eggs and Ham,” it often proves less effective for broccoli or beets. So Cricket Azima has a different message: “Make it!”
lead_paragraph: “Try it!” many parents cajole, urging children to taste a new food. But while that approach ultimately worked for the title dish in Dr. Seuss’s “Green Eggs and Ham,” it often proves less effective for broccoli or beets. So Cricket Azima has a different message: “Make it!”

headline: Review: In ‘London Has Fallen,’ the President Must Be Saved From Terrorists
abstract: Aaron Eckhart plays American’s leader visiting London, and Gerard Butler is his Secret Service protector when bloody chaos erupts.
lead_paragraph: President Benjamin Asher needs two things: better security personnel and better scriptwriters.

headline: Review: In ‘The Boy and the Beast,’ Learning From Anime Animals
abstract: Mamoru Hosoda’s fantasy tells of a runaway transported to a world whose mammals include a bear that trains him for a warrior’s life.
lead_paragraph: Mamoru Hosoda’s anime fantasy “The Boy and the Beast” is a curious hybrid with a foot in two realms. It begins vividly, in a gritty and monochromatic rendering of the Shibuya district in Tokyo, where a 9-year-old runaway, Ren, scrapes by.

headline: What Not to Miss at the Art Show at the Armory
abstract: There is a strong African-American presence this year, many historical shows and a number of concept exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: The Art Show, organized by the Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA) at the Park Avenue Armory, has the fair theme down to a science. Rather than fatigue-inducing roundups of mixed artists, most galleries here are devoting their booths to solo presentations. There is a strong African-American presence this year, many historical shows and a number of concept exhibitions. Alongside these are what might be called the post-retrospective reminder: a gathering of works that follow on the heels of an important museum show. Here are highlights from the 72 exhibitors.

headline: What Not to Miss at the Armory Show at the Piers
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: There’s a relative dearth of the sort of aesthetic, conceptual or political extremism that might have shocked casual art fans a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: With 205 international dealers in modern and contemporary art, down from approximately 275 in 2011, this year’s Armory Show is more spacious and easier to navigate than in the past. It’s also comparatively mild. There’s a relative dearth of the sort of aesthetic, conceptual or political extremism that might have shocked casual art fans a few years ago. Whether this reflects the fair’s leadership under its new director, Benjamin Genocchio; competition from the numerous art fairs also going on around Manhattan; or a creative energy lull in art in general is hard to say. Nevertheless, it’s still a great way to catch up on what’s happening in art, from the cleverly inane to the soulfully poetic.

headline: Review: Troye Sivan Sings, and His Fans Swoon
abstract: Mr. Sivan bantered easily with his young audience as he performed songs from his album, “Blue Neighborhood,” in a concert at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: A half-hour after Troye Sivan left the Webster Hall stage Tuesday night, the scrum of people at the merchandise table was still three deep. One of the two beleaguered clerks jumped up on the table and issued a desperate plea: “I need you to take two steps back!”

headline: Review: In ‘Road Games,’ a French Hitch Turns South
abstract: Abner Pastoll’s thriller focuses on two hitchhikers and the eccentric motorist who picks them up.
lead_paragraph: Getting into a stranger’s car has been ill-advised in movies at least since Ida Lupino’s 1953 pressure-cooker-on-wheels “The Hitch-Hiker.” That doesn’t stop the two hitchers in Abner Pastoll’s “Road Games” from getting into the wrong Peugeot. But their predicament comes to feel less chilling than mildly confusing, and a little disappointing, as Mr. Pastoll’s halting thriller goes through its paces.

headline: Review: In ‘Ava’s Possessions,’ Fallout From a Lost Month of Demonic Activity
abstract: There is a mysterious bloodstain beneath Ava’s rug, and there are criminal charges for assault and indecent exposure to be faced.
lead_paragraph: A goofy horror movie with little to say and not a lot to see, “Ava’s Possessions” sacrifices scares in favor of a rambling addiction metaphor that never finds an emotional rhythm.

headline: Review: ‘They Will Have to Kill Us First’ Documents Malian Music in Exile
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Music']
abstract: Johanna Schwartz’s film follows musicians in exile after Islamic jihadists banned music in their home country.
lead_paragraph: Filmed partly in refugee camps and on the war-ravaged streets of Timbuktu and Gao, Johanna Schwartz’s miraculously hopeful documentary, “They Will Have to Kill Us First: Malian Music in Exile,” delivers a vibrant testimony of resilience under oppression.

headline: Michigan: Medicaid Is Extended to 15,000 Exposed to Lead in Flint
abstract: The Obama administration approved Michigan’s request to extend Medicaid coverage to about 15,000 more children and pregnant women in Flint, where the water supply has been contaminated with lead.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration approved Michigan’s request to extend Medicaid coverage to about 15,000 more children and pregnant women in Flint, where the water supply has been contaminated with lead. Children and pregnant women who were exposed to Flint water in their homes, workplaces, schools or day care facilities will be eligible for free health care if their household incomes do not exceed 400 percent of the poverty level, or about $97,000 for a family of four. The federal government will pay 65 percent of the costs for pregnant women, and up to 99 percent for children; the state will cover the rest. In addition, about 30,000 current Medicaid beneficiaries in Flint will be eligible for expanded services under the five-year agreement.

headline: Fox News to Host Live Event With Bernie Sanders
abstract: A day before the Michigan primary on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders has agreed to appear on the cable news network in a live one-hour, town-hall-style event in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: A day before the Michigan primary on Tuesday, Senator Bernie Sanders will be the focus of a live one-hour, prime-time event in Detroit.

headline: Biblical Nomads Will Return to the Holy Land, Thanks to a Canadian Farm
abstract: A flock of Jacob sheep being raised by a British Columbia couple will be sent to their ancestral homeland in Israel this year.
lead_paragraph: Over thousands of years, they wandered from their homeland in the Middle East to Europe and finally traveled to North America, bound by a shared history and rigid dietary restrictions.

headline: Mitt Romney Aims at Donald Trump, Hits G.O.P.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: It took the Trump victories on Super Tuesday to force a reckoning by Republicans. Now they should look in the mirror.
lead_paragraph: Holy Mitt, what a meltdown.

headline: Samsonite to Buy Tumi for $1.8 Billion
abstract: Under the deal, Samsonite will pay $26.75 a share in cash, 32 percent higher than the closing price of Tumi’s stock on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Samsonite agreed on Thursday to buy one of its most prominent competitors in the luggage industry, Tumi Holdings, for about $1.8 billion in a deal that unites two of the biggest companies to cater to business travelers.

headline: Spieth, Day and McIlroy Play Together, but It’s Not Obvious From Gallery
abstract: Jordan Spieth, Jason Day and Rory McIlroy slipped a bit toward the end of the first round of the World Golf Championships-Cadillac Championship in Doral, Fla.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Jordan Spieth, Jason Day and Rory McIlroy shared a grouping on Thursday, which was the brightest constellation of stars to illuminate the Miami area sports landscape since LeBron James, Chris Bosh and Dwyane Wade shared the ball with the Heat. Spieth, Day and McIlroy have passed the world No. 1 ranking back and forth, spending a combined 122 weeks at the top.

headline: Brazil Opens Investigation Into McDonald’s
abstract: The company and its master franchise owner in Latin America are under scrutiny for possible violations of labor, tax and franchise laws.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor in Brazil on Thursday opened a criminal investigation into McDonald’s and its Latin American master franchise owner, Arcos Dorados Holdings, saying that they and related entities may have engaged in “fiscal and economic crimes.”

headline: New York’s Sidewalks, Unsung Moneymakers
abstract: As revenue from use permits rises, some property owners are unhappy with the city’s permit-renewal rules.
lead_paragraph: The squat, vermilion, steel-clad No. 9 was installed in front of 9 West 57th Street decades ago not just to identify the address of the distinctive ski slope-shaped tower, but to distract from the bare walls of adjacent buildings in Midtown Manhattan. For the privilege of parking the three-ton, nine-foot-tall numeral on the sidewalk, the property owner pays the city $12,000 a year.

headline: Daughter Will Keep the Obamas in Washington
abstract: President Obama said during a visit to Milwaukee that “we’re going to have to stay” in the capital until his younger daughter, Sasha, finishes high school.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — After years of speculation, President Obama confirmed on Thursday that he and his wife, Michelle, intend to remain in Washington for “a couple of years” after his term ends.

headline: Aubrey McClendon, Restless and Reckless Wildcatter, Was Deal-Making to the End
abstract: Mr. McClendon, who died in a car crash a day after being indicted on bid-rigging charges, was trying to expand globally the shale boom he pioneered.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the days leading up to Aubrey McClendon’s death in a car crash on Wednesday, the pressure on him had become unrelenting.

headline: Pension Benefit Cuts Planned at T.V.A., Breaking a Federal Firewall
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Organized Labor', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Workers and retirees at the Tennessee Valley Authority may see their benefits cut even as executives spare their own supplemental pension plan.
lead_paragraph: Politicians in states around the country have moved in recent years to rein in the pensions of government employees, which in many cases had become more generous and less risky than those of their private sector counterparts.

headline: Edward Lammer, Doctor Who Linked Acne Drug to Birth Defects, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Lammer was among the first to establish a link between the acne medicine Accutane and human birth defects, and who became an advocate for the families of affected children.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Edward Lammer, who was among the first researchers to establish a link between the acne medicine Accutane and human birth defects, and who became an advocate for the families of affected children, died on Feb. 20 in San Francisco. He was 62.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: As members of the Republican Party’s establishment denounced Donald J. Trump, the four candidates gathered in Detroit for yet another face-off.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the Republican debate, and fact checked it.

headline: AMC Deal for Carmike Would Create Biggest U.S. Theater Chain
abstract: AMC Entertainment agreed to buy Carmike Cinemas in a deal that is valued at about $1.1 billion, including debt.
lead_paragraph: In a significant consolidation of movie theater holdings, AMC Entertainment will acquire Carmike Cinemas for about $737 million in cash, forming the country’s largest chain with more than 600 theaters, the companies said on Thursday.

headline: Threatened With Rail Strike, N.J. Transit Warns of Disruptions
abstract: The agency warned that under its contingency plans it would be able to transport fewer than half its regular commuters to New York City.
lead_paragraph: SECAUCUS, N.J. — New Jersey Transit warned riders on Thursday that under its contingency plans for a rail strike it would be able to transport fewer than half its regular commuters to New York City.

headline: Daniel Murphy Faces Mets, and Lingering Queries
abstract: In the Mets’ first exhibition game, they faced Murphy, their biggest star in the 2015 postseason.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — The Washington Nationals’ batting practice was coming to a close on Thursday morning, and Mets players and coaches began wandering onto the field. Daniel Murphy started hugging them, one by one. Most had not seen Murphy since the World Series, or since the Mets had let him sign with the Nationals in free agency.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Has Impressive Start, Soothing the Yankees and Himself, for Now
abstract: The Yankees’ designated hitter hits a home run in his first swing of the exhibition season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — On his first swing of the exhibition season, Alex Rodriguez launched a drive down the left-field line that was so deep and majestic he felt compelled to hold his follow-through for a moment, pausing to admire it.

headline: Iran Invites Boeing for Talks, a Stride Toward Business Ties With the U.S.
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Iranians want to modernize their commercial aircraft fleet, and the invitation could be a precursor to the biggest business arrangement with an American company after decades of estrangement.
lead_paragraph: Boeing has been invited to talks with Iranian officials about modernizing Iran’s aged commercial aircraft fleet, the country’s transport minister said Thursday, in what could be a precursor to the biggest business arrangement with an American company after more than three decades of estrangement.

headline: Head of a Group Backing Trump Is Among 14 Charged in a Nevada Standoff
abstract: Gerald A. DeLemus, who served as a chairman of a group supporting Donald J. Trump in New Hampshire, was charged in connection to a standoff in 2014 over illegal grazing on federal lands.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A conservative activist who served as a chairman of a “Veterans for Trump” coalition in New Hampshire was one of 14 people charged on Thursday by the Justice Department in connection with the armed showdown over federal control of grazing lands led by the Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy.

headline: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Teenagers in Brooklyn Rape Case
abstract: The five suspects were cleared after inconsistencies began to emerge in their accuser’s statements to investigators about an encounter on Jan. 7.
lead_paragraph: After a brief hearing, a judge on Thursday formally dismissed charges against five teenagers accused of raping an 18-year-old woman at a Brooklyn playground in a case that fell apart as inconsistencies emerged in her statements to investigators and she became increasingly reluctant to cooperate with prosecutors.

headline: Activists Recall Fight to Allow Gays in St. Patrick’s Day Parade
abstract: “Perhaps our hearts will be dancing all the way,” said a leader of the Lavender and Green Alliance, a group that will represent gay Irish-Americans in the parade.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment that some feared might never come, after so many years of viewing the St. Patrick’s Day Parade from the outside, politically and personally.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If you experience that small trauma of being exposed and shamed, it is very unlikely you will break the same rule twice.”

headline: ‘Hughie,’ Starring Forest Whitaker, Will Close Early
abstract: The play, which had been scheduled to run through June 12, will now close on March 27.
lead_paragraph: “Hughie,” a Eugene O’Neill one-act play starring Forest Whitaker in his Broadway debut, is closing unexpectedly early because of weak ticket sales.

headline: Donald Trump Defends His Hands
abstract: At Thursday’s debate, Mr. Trump assured the American people that Marco Rubio’s attacks on his hand size were unfounded.
lead_paragraph: The metaphorical finally became literal at the Republican Party’s latest debate in Detroit.

headline: Review: In ‘Red Speedo,’ a Swimmer Faces a Moral Quandary
abstract: This Lucas Hnath drama features a competitive swimmer who makes a surprising revelation.
lead_paragraph: A bright slip of a swimsuit seems a small garment on which to hang a knotty morality play, but the ingenious Lucas Hnath engineers this remarkable feat with “Red Speedo,” a taut, incisive drama at New York Theater Workshop about a swimmer with high Olympic hopes and a waterlogged ethical compass.

headline: Review: ‘Familiar,’ a Comic Clash of Assimilation on the Path to a Wedding
abstract: In Danai Gurira’s fiercely funny new play, impending nuptials expose a culture clash and deep fissures within a Zimbabwean-American family in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: A wedding almost always involves some kind of culture clash. Church ceremony or civil? To bridesmaid or not to bridesmaid? But the impending nuptials in Danai Gurira’s fiercely funny new play, “Familiar,” about a Zimbabwean-American family in Minnesota, make even the most fraught weddings seem comparatively placid affairs. By the end of this engrossing comedy-drama, which opened on Thursday at Playwrights Horizons, deep fissures within the family have been exposed, fresh wounds are rubbed raw and long-buried secrets are unearthed.

headline: Dandy Headpieces
abstract: Friday themeless fun by Evans Clinchy, and why you should try solving a late-week puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When you don’t have a theme to cling to and the clues are ramped up to weekend-level, it can be difficult to conquer a crossword puzzle. If you are just dipping a toe into the late week, themeless puzzles, there are only two things you will need to be successful, and they are 1) patience and 2) more patience.

headline: Brazil’s President Rousseff, Facing Impeachment Effort, Is Deluged by More Bad News
abstract: With Brazil’s economy tumbling and her campaign strategist jailed, President Dilma Rousseff now confronts a report that a senator from her party will accuse her in a plea deal.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just when it seems things cannot get any worse for Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, they do.

headline: Civil War Plays Out in Republican Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A slimmed down field of four candidates sparred as Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and John Kasich tried to grab the mantle from Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Tonight’s debate offered a window into the civil war in the Republican party. It featured a whittled down field of four candidates. Here’s my analysis in the form of collected tweets: journalism on the fly!

headline: North Korea’s Kim Jong-un Tells Military to Have Nuclear Warheads on Standby
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The North Korean leader’s comments were reported a day after the United Nations Security Council approved tougher sanctions aimed at curtailing his country’s nuclear and ballistic-missile programs.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has urged his military to have its nuclear warheads deployed and ready to be fired at any moment, the country’s state-run news agency reported Friday.

headline: John Chilton, Jazz Musician and Historian, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Chilton, a trumpet-playing fixture on the British jazz scene, wrote a survey of Billie Holiday’s career, definitive biographies and a memoir.
lead_paragraph: John Chilton, an acclaimed jazz historian and one of the few jazz writers to have a successful parallel career as a musician, died on Feb. 25 in London. He was 83.

headline: In Republican Debate, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Wage Urgent Attacks on Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz relentlessly demeaned and denounced Mr. Trump at Thursday’s debate, all but pleading with Republicans to reconsider nominating him.
lead_paragraph: Get live updates about the Florida primary.

headline: Five Big Questions After a Vulgar Republican Debate
abstract: It was a night of truth, consequences and puerile boasting for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Does the size of Donald Trump’s penis matter?

abstract: This word has appeared in 51 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: defection • \di-ˈfek-shən\ • noun

abstract: Following is a transcript of the 11th G.O.P. debate, prepared by the Federal News Service. Just four candidates were on the stage for the event.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

abstract: The Times reporter Nick Corasaniti discusses key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Detroit, as the field of candidates narrowed to a four-man race.
lead_paragraph: The Times reporter Nick Corasaniti discusses key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Detroit, as the field of candidates narrowed to a four-man race.

headline: Joe Biden's 1992 Senate Speech
abstract: As a senator more than two decades ago, the vice president argued that President George Bush should delay filling a Supreme Court vacancy.
lead_paragraph: As a senator more than two decades ago, the vice president argued that President George Bush should delay filling a Supreme Court vacancy.

headline: China Military Budget to Rise Less Than 8%, Slower Than Usual
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations']
abstract: The People’s Liberation Army’s budget will increase by 7.6 percent this year, the smallest rise in six years.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As China’s economy slows, its military budget will rise by 7.6 percent this year, the lowest increase in six years and less than the double-digit increases that have been the norm for years, the government said Saturday at the opening of the country’s annual legislative meeting.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: The Underwoods fight to the death in “House of Cards.” And former brothers-in-law cruise Iceland in “Land Ho!”
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought politics couldn’t get any more torrid, along come the Underwoods in the new season of “House of Cards.” Former brothers-in-law cruise Iceland on a journey of old-age self-discovery in “Land Ho!” And “American Masters” bows down to the Queen of Country, Loretta Lynn.

headline: ‘Pandemic,’ by Sonia Shah
abstract: A science journalist looks at re-emerging old diseases like cholera and new ones like SARS.
lead_paragraph: Over Christmas, headlines across Britain screamed that Victorian-era diseases had returned. The past five years had apparently witnessed a 136 percent increase in scarlet fever cases, a remarkable 300 percent rise in the confirmed ­cases of cholera along with reported occurrences of other once-vanquished diseases like tuberculosis, measles and whooping cough.

headline: ‘The Fever of 1721,’ by Stephen Coss
abstract: A pivotal year in colonial Boston, when an outbreak put faith, science and leadership to the test.
lead_paragraph: In 1721, Boston was a dangerous place. The Massachusetts colonial government barely maintained order, though it ­needed to. Abenaki Indians were threatening colonists on land while pirates were ­marauding at sea. Alternative sources of authority were scarce. Fallout from the Salem witch trials of 1692 had ­discredited the colony’s Congregationalist ministers. It didn’t help that a young firebrand named Franklin began to print a newspaper that mocked both the government and the ministers. Perhaps most dangerously, smallpox had spread from an infected ship to people ashore. The resulting ­epidemic is the “fever” Stephen Coss places at the center of his first book, “The Fever of 1721,” though his title bundles up all of the city’s hot troubles into one big crisis.

headline: ‘The First Congress,’ by Fergus M. Bordewich
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An account of the First Federal Congress maintains that it completed the work of the Revolution.
lead_paragraph: America’s federal era has been enjoying a welcome, if surprising, popularity in recent years. Best-selling biographies, an impressive array of scholarly books and articles, even a hit Broadway show, attest to its new status. This popularity has been sparked, in part, by a growing recognition that the American Revolution was a beginning, not an ending, in the story of our nation-building. But the interest can also be explained by the publication online of the correspondence of most of the major players of the era, along with the debates and proceedings of the early Congressional sessions. Easy access to such sources whets the appetite of the scholar and popular historian alike.

headline: ‘Cities I’ve Never Lived In,’ by Sara Majka
abstract: Linked stories on breakups, displacement and missing children.
lead_paragraph: The first story in Sara Majka’s first book begins, “Maybe 10 or 11 years ago, when I was in the middle of a divorce from a man I still loved, I took the train into the city.” There the narrator visits an art exhibit — the story is called “Reverón’s Dolls,” after the Venezuelan artist — and stays in an apartment owned by an artist friend, filled with light and canvases. Unjustly, I assumed right away that I knew exactly what kind of book this would be: a book about arty people with complicated personal lives, who use the word “lover” and contemplate wintry landscapes from lonely trains.

headline: ‘Free Men,’ by Katy Simpson Smith
abstract: A white man, an Indian and an escaped slave team up in this novel.
lead_paragraph: I have long believed that the joy of reading novels set in the past is the thrill of time travel, but reading “Free Men,” by Katy Simpson Smith, it occurred to me that the best of such novels make us feel not merely in another time but of it. This is the distinction between books dismissed (fairly or no) as historical fiction and literature that happens to be set in the past, which immerses the reader beyond period verisimilitude and sensory detail, taking her deep into the collective psyche of another era.

headline: ‘A Friend of Mr. Lincoln,’ by Stephen Harrigan
abstract: Historical fiction, not always flattering, about Lincoln’s early adult years on the Illinois frontier.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Harrigan’s new novel, “A Friend of Mr. Lincoln,” begins with a famous ending: We are introduced to the invented protagonist of this tale of deep, fraught friendship as he stands anonymously in line to pay his coffin-side respects to the murdered 16th president. “Forgotten, fat, one-armed” Micajah Weatherby hasn’t exchanged words with his old friend Lincoln in years, and as Micajah (or Cage) makes his way toward the coffin, and afterward wanders the streets of once-familiar Springfield, Ill., Harrigan skillfully inscribes his loss of friend and president in the context of national ­devastation.

headline: First Novels
abstract: New books by Kate Hamer, A. Igoni Barrett, Matthew Griffin, Natasha Stagg and Sari Wilson.
lead_paragraph: THE GIRL IN THE RED COATBy Kate Hamer324 pp. Melville House, $25.95.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Debbie Macomber, now a regular best seller, struggled early in her career: “I got rejected so fast, my manuscripts would hit me in the back of the head on my way back from the post office.”
lead_paragraph: Step by Step: In her latest novel, “A Girl’s Guide to Moving On” — new at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list — Debbie Macomber tells the story of a woman inspired to leave her own unhappy marriage when her daughter-in-law files for divorce; as they fumble toward independence, the two lean on each other for support and grow closer than they ever were as actual relatives. “A lot of my books have to do with forgiveness,” Macomber has said. “I don’t know why that’s so important to me, but it seems to be a common theme.” Macomber is a regular on the fiction list, often for series novels about knitting or Christmas or new beginnings (as this one is, although the only knitting in it involves the tangling of human limbs). But the work didn’t always come easy. “When I started out 35 years ago,” she told a newspaper in Savannah, Ga., recently, “I saw a quote from Phyllis Whitney: ‘There has never been an easy time to sell a book.’ I wanted this more than I ever wanted anything in my life. I got rejected so fast, my manuscripts would hit me in the back of the head on my way back from the post office.” But Macomber never gave up. “It has a lot to do with stubbornness and desire,” she said, adding that she similarly trained herself to run despite a lack of athletic ability. In both cases, “It was making myself stick to it until I could do it. It got to the point where it didn’t hurt anymore.”

headline: Jo Nesbo’s ‘Midnight Sun,’ and More
abstract: Jo Nesbo’s latest is about a Norwegian hit man who flees Oslo to escape the wrath of his boss, a mobster known as the Fisherman.
lead_paragraph: The Finnmark Plateau is known as a beautiful spot. “Isn’t that just the sort of thing people say about inhospitable places?” reflects the antihero of MIDNIGHT SUN (Knopf, $23.95), Jo Nesbo’s character study of a fugitive Norwegian hit man. Jon Hansen has fled Oslo for this desolate land above the Arctic Circle, trying to escape the wrath of his boss, a mobster known as the Fisherman. Working as his debt collector and fixer was an easy job — until Hansen botched a murder and found himself in the Fisherman’s cross hairs.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘All the Single Ladies’
abstract: This week, Rebecca Traister talks about “All the Single Ladies”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ben Ratliff discusses “Every Song Ever”; Richard Armitage discusses his audiobook recording of “David Copperfield”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Rebecca Traister talks about “All the Single Ladies”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ben Ratliff discusses “Every Song Ever”; Richard Armitage discusses his audiobook recording of “David Copperfield”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. abstract: With tides rising from climate change and with money tight, villagers on an Alaskan barrier island are unsure how, or when, they will relocate.
lead_paragraph: With tides rising from climate change and with money tight, villagers on an Alaskan barrier island are unsure how, or when, they will relocate.

headline: Corrections: March 4, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, March 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Who Won the Debate? Maybe No One, Analysts Say
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many wondered whether Thursday’s Republican debate — notable for insults, interruptions and genitalia jokes — would make much difference in the race.
lead_paragraph: There were insults, genitalia jokes and even some discussion of foreign policy on Thursday night in the 11th Republican presidential debate. Commentators and pundits thought that Donald J. Trump weathered attacks from both sides, that Senator Ted Cruz delivered a crisp performance, that Senator Marco Rubio had some of the best zingers and that Gov. John Kasich stuck to playing the grown-up in the room. At the close, many wondered if the face-off would make much difference. And some said that, in the end, there were no winners.

headline: Nowhere to Go Amid Alaska’s Melting Ice
abstract: With tides rising from climate change and with money tight, villagers on an Alaskan barrier island are unsure how, or when, they will relocate.
lead_paragraph: Alaska’s Chukchi Sea was only just starting to freeze when Nima Taradji arrived at the Inupiat village of Shishmaref last December. Situated on a narrow barrier island, Shishmaref was founded over 400 years ago as a seasonal fishing settlement. Cold weather and natural ice barriers used to protect the shore, but now the municipal village, home to some 600 residents, faces the immediate threat of inundation.

headline: Republican Debate Takeaways: Taking On Donald Trump, at Their Own Peril
abstract: Time and again, anxious Republican leaders have urged candidates to take on Donald J. Trump. Thursday’s debate showed why that almost never works.
lead_paragraph: At a critical and last-chance moment for the contenders, Thursday’s Republican debate in Michigan offered voters the clearest view yet of their options going into November. There was John R. Kasich, the last results-focused governor standing. There was Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who combines conservative economic orthodoxy with the foreign policy views of The Weekly Standard. There was Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, the slightly more populist, Wall Street-phobic version of a contemporary conservative. And then there was Donald J. Trump, who is — well, let’s just leave that to him.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Day 4
abstract: The crowds will mass at Dior for the first ready-to-wear collection without Raf Simons, and at Undercover for bonkers theatrics.
lead_paragraph: Beauty sleep is for the weak. Fashion week starts earlier than usual today, with Loewe kicking off the day at Maison Unesco in the Seventh Arrondissement at 9:30 a.m. Jonathan Anderson has made the place his Loewe home-away-from-home, and the concrete back garden where he has shown his last two collections is lovely (assuming the rain abates).

headline: Clash of Republican Con Artists
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Donald Trump isn’t the only fraud running for the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: So Republicans are going to nominate a candidate who talks complete nonsense on domestic policy; who believes that foreign policy can be conducted via bullying and belligerence; who cynically exploits racial and ethnic hatred for political gain.

headline: Donald Trump, the Great Betrayer
abstract: Republican officials have a responsibility to their country to spread the nasty truths about Trump.
lead_paragraph: Now, at long last, the big guns are being brought to bear. Now, at long last, some major Republicans like Mitt Romney are speaking up to lay waste to Donald Trump.

headline: The Beast Is Us
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Trump’s supporters know what he stands for: hatred of immigrants, racial superiority, a sneering disregard of the basic civility that binds a society.
lead_paragraph: You heard the word “scary” used a lot this week, that and much more. Not from the usual scolds. Or Democrats. The loudest alarms came from desperate, panicked Republicans, warning of the man who is destroying the Party of Lincoln before our eyes.

headline: Chris Christie’s Day Job
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Endorsements', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: He’ s been rejected nationally and he’s reviled at home, with editorials demanding he quit. Maybe Chris Christie could actually address his state’s problems for a change.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie pretty much gave up on New Jersey when he decided to run for president. Little wonder that New Jersey has given up on him.

headline: Australia Turns Its Back on Climate Science
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Research', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: A shift by a government-financed science agency away from basic research makes no sense for the island continent or the planet as a whole.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Australia has run the most advanced and comprehensive atmosphere and ocean monitoring programs in the Southern Hemisphere, providing critical information not only for a nation that is already the driest on earth and fast getting drier, but also for a world in urgent need of such data to search for ways to cope with climate change.

headline: Five Black Teenagers, Innocent, Face a Lifetime of Guilt

headline: Morning Agenda: AMC to Buy Carmike Cinemas in $1.1 Billion Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Legal Profession', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Minorities', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shale', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Shale Pioneer Doubled Down on Deals to the End | Samsonite to Buy Tumi for $1.8 Billion | A Law School Opens Doors to a Rarefied Realm
lead_paragraph: AMC TO BUY CARMIKE CINEMAS IN $1.1 BILLION DEAL | AMC Entertainment would create the largest movie theater chain in the United States with its purchase of Carmike Cinemas,  Michael J. de la Merced and Michael Cieply write in DealBook. AMC, whose controlling investor is Wang Jianlin of China’s Dalian Wanda Group, said Thursday that it will pay $737 million in cash, or $30 a share, up 19 percent from Carmike’s closing price on Thursday. Including the assumption of Carmike’s debt, the transaction is valued at about $1.1 billion, which is the biggest deal by AMC since it returned to the public markets in a 2013 stock sale, Mr. de la Merced and Mr. Cieply report.

headline: How to Tell Someone You’re Terminally Ill
abstract: Give people a chance to help. Sometimes a text is O.K.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘I say, ‘The doctors told me there is nothing they can do, it is inoperable and incurable,’ ’’ says Wanda N., who is 50 and in hospice care at home in New York with metastasized colon cancer. ‘‘When I tell people, I use the same words the doctors used to tell me.’’ You might not have time or energy to formulate the exact right phrasing — but you are not obliged to be the town crier, spreading the news of a terminal diagnosis. ‘‘Don’t feel the need to announce your situation over and over again,’’ says Wanda, who has told only a handful of people, including her father, a cousin and a few women from her Army veterans’ group. Some she told in person, others by phone or text.

But when I was 15, the government banned the commemoration.

headline: How Much More Can the Labor Force Grow?

But there’s some great news beneath the surface: Americans are returning to the work force in the largest numbers in many years.

headline: A Spirited Bar Crawl in Belfast
abstract: Celebrating the Northern Ireland city’s distinctive and varied pub culture.
lead_paragraph: Belfast pubs pop up from time to time in the work of Ciaran Carson, one of the city’s greatest writers and chroniclers. In the taut, tense poem “Last Orders,” from his remarkable 1989 collection “Belfast Confetti,” Carson writes about a bar where “you never know for sure who’s who, or what/You’re walking into,” and “how simple it would be for someone/Like ourselves to walk in and blow the whole place, and ourselves, to Kingdom Come.” It’s a chilling expression of the uncertainty and fear endured by the people of Belfast during the worst of times.

headline: At M.I.T., Science Embraces a New Chaos Theory: Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Science and Technology', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment']
abstract: More than 30 artists have been invited to embed in the labs since the creation of the school’s Center for Art, Science & Technology in 2012.
lead_paragraph: As a graduate student at the respected M.I.T. Media Lab, Marcelo Coelho collaborated with the artist Vik Muniz to help him achieve a poetic and technical feat that teases the imagination: drawing a picture of a castle on a single grain of sand. After two years of failed experiments with various lasers, they finally began getting images of beautiful complexity using an electron microscope with a focused ion beam to etch superfine lines—when it didn’t pulverize the grains altogether. The tiny etchings could then be scanned and printed large scale.

abstract: In a rare victory, about 1,350 retirees will be paid in full for pensions that were cut when the Renco subsidiary they worked for went bankrupt in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A group of retirees whose pensions were cut three years ago have won a lengthy battle with the multibillionaire Ira Rennert, a mining industrialist, onetime junkbond king and owner of a Hamptons mega-mansion.

headline: Krishna Devotees Look to Provide for This Life
abstract: Some members of a movement founded in the 1960s and based on Hindu teachings have started an organization to care for themselves and others.
lead_paragraph: For Roger Siegel, the last half-century has been the proverbial long, strange trip. It started in New York, where, as an idealistic college dropout in the early 1960s, he tutored Harlem schoolchildren. It included civil rights marches in Alabama and peyote hikes in the Nevada hills.

headline: 3 Men Charged With Hate Crimes in Attack on Hispanics in California
abstract: The defendants verbally abused and then physically attacked five Hispanic men playing soccer in a Los Angeles County park, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three white men accused of attacking a group of Hispanics in a Los Angeles County park on Sunday were charged with hate crimes this week, the authorities said.

headline: Joshua Reeves of Gusto: Directing Without Dictating
abstract: Mr. Reeves, co-founder and chief executive of Gusto, says effective leadership is about building and guiding a well-balanced team.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Joshua Reeves, C.E.O. and co-founder of Gusto, an online payroll, benefits and workers’ compensation firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: 1966: Ghana Cuts Ties With Guinea
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Ghana broke diplomatic relations with Guinea in 1961.
lead_paragraph: ACCRA — The new military government of Ghana today [March 4] broke diplomatic relations with Guinea, whose president has proclaimed deposed Ghanaian President Kwame Nkrumah his equal. The break came as the new regime of Gen. Joseph Ankrah gained the formal recognition of the United States, Britain and several African nations.

headline: Investigation Opened Into Ford F-150 After Brake Failure Reports
keywords: ['Brakes', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had received 33 consumer complaints about the pickups from the 2013-14 model years.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are investigating reports of brake failure that may affect about 420,000 Ford F-150 pickup trucks.

headline: Quantifying Aspirin’s Reduction in Cancer Risk
abstract: The drug’s population-wide benefits may be even greater than previously believed.
lead_paragraph: Many people take a daily low-dose aspirin to lower the risk of heart disease, and several studies have shown that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for some cancers. Now a long-term analysis has found that its population-wide benefits against cancer may be even greater than previously believed.

headline: Paper Bank Statements May Surpass Digital for Some Customers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Personal Finances', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Older, less educated and lower-income consumers who may lack fast Internet connections at home may benefit from paper statements, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE a push by financial institutions to switch customers to digital statements from paper, the traditional hard-copy version may work better for some people, a new report finds.

headline: 1941: Mrs. Roosevelt’s Request
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Mrs. Roosevelt urges Jewish workers to cooperate with groups outside their own in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt revealed yesterday that her mail at the White House has averaged 800 letters a day during the last winter. Most of these contain appeals for help or advice from persons in trouble of one kind or another, Mrs. Roosevelt told 3,000 members of the women’s division of the United New York Appeal for Joint Distribution Committee and National Refugee Service, at the opening rally of their annual drive yesterday morning at the Hotel Commodore.

headline: In Fledgling Exchange-Traded Fund, Striking a Blow for Women
abstract: With a new E.T.F., State Street hopes to achieve market-rate returns by investing in firms that are leaders in gender diversity.
lead_paragraph: State Street Global Advisors will introduce its 159th exchange-traded fund on Tuesday, the SPDR Gender Diversity Index E.T.F. Fortunately, the fund’s ticker symbol is catchier: SHE.

headline: 36 Hours in Austin, Texas
abstract: Beyond the SXSW festival, there’s classic barbecue, contemporary art and even a beer garden on a working ranch.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the SXSW festival, there’s classic barbecue, contemporary art and even a beer garden on a working ranch.

headline: Conor McGregor and Holly Holm Matched With Second Choices

lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship has two of its biggest new stars in action on Saturday in Las Vegas. Unfortunately, neither will be in the fights everyone was hoping for.

headline: Syrian Protesters Take to Streets as Airstrikes Ease
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: “The Revolution Continues” was the slogan as demonstrators, taking advantage of a partial truce, came out in their largest numbers in years.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Street protests erupted across insurgent-held areas of Syria on Friday, as demonstrators took advantage of the relative lull in airstrikes during a partial truce, coming out in the largest numbers in years to declare that even after five punishing years of war they still wanted political change.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: The ultimate guide to frosting a cake and delicious ideas for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: As Economy Slows, Experts Call on China to Drop Growth Target
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Falsification of Data']
abstract: A growing number of analysts say China’s practice of setting an annual target for growth actually hurts the economy and encourages officials to falsify data.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Every March, China releases a closely watched growth target for the year, a number that looms large for the world’s economists, executives and policy makers. But a growing number of those experts are now calling for China to stop setting that goal, saying the target actually harms the economy and encourages officials to falsify data.

headline: Serbia Dissolves Parliament and Calls Early Elections
abstract: The government said it needed a new mandate to pursue the economic changes that it deems essential for the country to join the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Serbia’s president dissolved Parliament and called early elections on Friday, after the government said it needed a new mandate to pursue the difficult economic changes that it deems essential for the country to join the European Union.

headline: Two Studies Strengthen Links Between the Zika Virus and Serious Birth Defects
abstract: In one small study, many fetuses of infected pregnant women in Brazil either died or experienced serious birth defects. A possible mechanism is suggested in a second report.
lead_paragraph: The Zika virus damages many fetuses carried by infected and symptomatic mothers, regardless of when in pregnancy the infection occurs, according to a small but frightening study released on Friday by Brazilian and American researchers.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Larry Kramer
abstract: The playwright and activist shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the playwright, author and activist Larry Kramer, who shares his list exclusively with T. (One Grand currently has an installation at the Shinola store in Palo Alto featuring the recommendations of Alice Waters, Bret Easton Ellis, Lena Dunham and Gia Coppola.)

headline: Tax Tips for Those Who Make Money in the Gig Economy
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The gig economy is reshaping the work world for many Americans. It is also reshaping tax season. Here is what the newly self-employed need to know.
lead_paragraph: Since losing her job in advertising during the financial crisis, Dina Scherer has spent her days helping women cultivate their own personal styles — finding flattering color palettes, editing closets and taking customers on shopping excursions.

headline: Snapshot of Brazil’s Web of Scandal
abstract: A raid at the home of the former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was the latest development in the country’s political and economic turmoil.
lead_paragraph: The former president of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, was taken into custody by the Brazilian police on Friday for questioning as part of an investigation into a colossal graft scheme. The raid on Mr. da Silva’s house was the latest development in the expanding political and economic turmoil in Brazil.

headline: A Touch of Europe on 14th Street
abstract: A developer taps the Parisian architect Jacques Garcia to help bring a sumptuous French style to a boutique apartment building downtown.
lead_paragraph: To find design inspiration for his new condominium building, d’Orsay, the developer Matthew Adell didn’t have to look far. His office is just steps from the NoMad Hotel, designed by the Parisian architect Jacques Garcia, which he found enchanting.

headline: Quite a Garage Sale: 11 Highlights From the Bob Dylan Archive
abstract: There are more than 6,000 items in Mr. Dylan’s personal collection, including mysterious notebooks, doodles and rare recordings.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Bob Dylan has offered up glimpses of himself with the “Bootleg” series of outtakes and demos. But until now, nobody knew exactly what the Bob Dylan Archive held: more than 6,000 items from Mr. Dylan’s personal collection, almost none of which have been seen publicly before. The material, which is still being sorted through by specialists, is being transferred to Tulsa, Okla., where it will be cataloged, digitized and displayed. The New York Times previewed the collection and identified some of the items Dylanologists will find most exciting and illuminating:

headline: Silicon Valley Has Not Saved Us From a Productivity Slowdown
keywords: ['Productivity', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: New research questions the notion, popular in tech circles, that the benefits of technology are making up for mediocre gains in productivity and wages.
lead_paragraph: American middle class wages haven’t been rising as rapidly as they once were, and a slowdown in productivity growth is probably an important cause.

headline: Police Test Knife Reportedly Found on Property Once Owned by O.J. Simpson
abstract: The knife had been kept since the late 1990s by a retired officer who claimed it was found at the home where Mr. Simpson lived at the time of the murders.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Mezzaluna restaurant where Nicole Brown Simpson had her last meal is now a Peet’s Coffee & Tea. The condo complex where she and her friend Ronald L. Goldman were slashed to death has been remodeled. The Brentwood mansion where O. J. Simpson lived — and where the police chased him down in his white Bronco in 1994 as the public watched on television — has been demolished.

headline: ‘Bernie Baby’ Died of SIDS, Family Says
abstract: The boy, Oliver Jack Carter Lomas-Davis, who rose to fame for being dressed up as the Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders, was 4 months old.
lead_paragraph: An infant who rose to fame on social media as the Bernie Baby after his mother took him to a Bernie Sanders rally dressed up as the Democratic candidate, complete with oversize glasses and a wild white wig, died on Feb. 25 at 4 months, his family said.

headline: Wangy Transforms at Dior
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.

headline: Accara Offers a Taste of Senegal in Fried Form
abstract: The West African street-food snack can be piled into a sandwich with a spicy bite.
lead_paragraph: Not far from the Place des Vosges in Paris, on a side street called the Rue Elzévir, there is a restaurant called Le Petit Dakar. It’s where I first tasted thieboudienne, the soul-warming national dish of Senegal, a rich, spicy and deeply flavored mix of rice, vegetables and fish. I loved the complexity of the dish and the atmosphere of the place. It made me want to hop the next plane to Dakar.

headline: Iditarod Sled Dog Race Lacks Snow, So Alaska Ships Some In
keywords: ['Dog Sledding', 'Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Snow filling several train cars had to be shipped from Fairbanks to Anchorage this week to ensure a snowy start for the famous sled dog race.
lead_paragraph: As mushers and their dogs prepare for the Iditarod sled dog race, the fabled trek through Alaska’s wilderness, a warm winter has once again robbed the starting line of an important ingredient: snow.

headline: Rick Owens on Fast Fashion, His Physical Connection to Clothes — and More
abstract: T caught up with the designer backstage at his fall/winter 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: The designer Rick Owens is no stranger to iconoclastic fashion shows, but his fall/winter 2016 collection, presented yesterday in Paris, made one of his biggest, most personal statements to date. For this collection, entitled “Mastodon,” Owens was thinking a lot about the bigger picture, specifically evolution, uneasiness with regards to the changing environment, even our own extinction — and coming to terms with it all. He spoke with T backstage before the show.

headline: Rick Owens Designs for the End of Days; Dior and Lanvin Soldier On
abstract: Among the collections, Jonathan Anderson finds a new voice for Loewe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was sheer coincidence that Rick Owens, an American in Paris, staged his “Mastodon” show, named for an extinct species, the same night as the Republican debate in Detroit, where Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz were characterized by this newspaper as “fighting for their political lives.” It was a fluke of timing that Mr. Owens subtitled the show after a Salvador Dalí painting (“Swans Reflecting Elephants”) at a moment when most observers, including those at the side of the runway, feel they are living through a surreal time. And it was just happenstance that he was looking at embracing “the inevitable end of a cycle” just as issues of the decline of the republic were on everyone’s minds.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Circling Each Other in Michigan
abstract: The presidential race began to shift in earnest to the industrial Midwest on Friday, offering a preview of what the general election might look like.
lead_paragraph: The presidential race began to shift in earnest to the industrial Midwest on Friday, with pivotal contests looming in Michigan, Ohio and Illinois, and Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton crossing each other’s paths in a preview of what the general election could hold.

headline: Russell Simmons Backs Hillary Clinton for President

headline: A Plan Worth Its Salt
abstract: A worthy public-health initiative — informing some diners, eating in chain restaurants with more than 15 outlets, of an item’s salt content — is met with cries of unfairness, and resistance.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago the Los Angeles County Health Department, in conjunction with a separate initiative taken by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, issued a series of videos warning of the stealth capacities of salt, which can lurk in seemingly innocuous foods and do harm. One of the “Salt Shocker” videos, as they were called, examined the problem using cottage cheese, a mere half-cup of which contains 450 milligrams of sodium. What if you ate a cup of cottage cheese for breakfast? You would be consuming about 40 percent of your prescribed allotment of sodium for the day — most dietary guidelines recommend no more than 2,300 milligrams — forcing you to conduct a rigorous cost-benefit analysis of the ham sandwich you brought for lunch.

abstract: College basketball upsets can lead to a joyous rush, and sometimes injury.

headline: Turkey Seizes Newspaper, Zaman, as Press Crackdown Continues

headline: Public Editor Margaret Sullivan on the State of Journalism; Mark Thompson on Digital Publishing
abstract: A weekly recap of the television and radio appearances of New York Times journalists.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters, columnists and executives participated in interviews about their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

headline: For Older Borrowers, Being Thrifty Can Tarnish a Credit Score
abstract: Older people may still need credit, but their financial histories — and even their stability — can trip them up in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: John M. George, 63, the retired owner of a small oil-field service company, never had much need for credit. With assets now worth $4 million, he paid cash for his cars; bought his successive houses with small loans from relatives, the seller or a local bank; and had just one credit card, which he used for occasional airplane tickets or business needs and always paid off promptly. He paid off his most recent home loan in 2003.

headline: President Erdogan’s Thin Skin
abstract: The Turkish president is known for his tough talk, but he apparently cannot abide criticism.
lead_paragraph: Like other authoritarian leaders, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has made it a point to show his people who’s boss. He has waged war on the Kurdish separatists, imprisoned critics, taken control of much of the media, cowed the military and convinced a preponderance of his people that he is indispensable.

headline: Donald Trump on Why He Defended the Size of His Hands (and More)
abstract: Speaking to a crowd in Warren, Mich., the morning after the latest Republican debate, Donald J. Trump recounted how he had been mocked for having small hands. He went on to say that his supporters love how he stands up for himself, even if it isn’t always typical presidential behavior, so he did.
lead_paragraph: So, just why did Donald J. Trump decide to delve into the matter of his anatomy on the debate stage Thursday night?

headline: On Eve of Retirement, Savings for Medical Costs Can Fall Short
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Retirement', 'Savings', 'Elderly', 'Medicare', 'Long-Term Care Insurance']
abstract: Longer lives, rising costs and the limits of Medicare coverage have increased the amount people must save to pay for health care in retirement.
lead_paragraph: William Seavey, 69, does not fret about paying future medical expenses. He and his wife, Eleanor, are healthy. And they both have Medicare and Medigap policies, which can help pay many health costs. So they have not put any money aside in a medical savings account.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Suits With Sexy Underpinnings
abstract: Y/Project, Anthony Vaccarello and Paco Rabanne have all offered risqué complements to classic jackets for fall/winter 2016.
lead_paragraph: New plays on classic suiting have been popping up all over the runways this season, in a variety of forms: Designers have patchworked different fabrics into single garments; played with volume and silhouette; and styled the items with unexpected, provocative underpinnings. Glenn Martens at Y/Project (right) sent down an oversize, men’s wear-inspired tweed coat over a matching tweed cutout bustier. At center, Anthony Vaccarello’s version of the trend was a roomy suit sexed up with a boudoir corset. And yesterday at Paco Rabanne (left), Julien Dossena showed a bra-baring silk top that draped around the torso under a tailored jacket.

headline: Visit the Scene of the Shooting
abstract: Watch the virtual-reality film about the killing of a Mexican teenager by a U.S. agent firing through the border fence by downloading NYT VR, The Times’s virtual-reality app for iPhone and Android.
lead_paragraph: Watch the virtual-reality film about the killing of a Mexican teenager by a U.S. agent firing through the border fence by downloading NYT VR, The Times’s virtual-reality app for iPhone and Android.

headline: ‘Battle of Versailles’ Relives 1973 Win for American Fashion
abstract: Joining other fashion documentaries like “The September Issue” and “Dior & I” comes a film about the Battle of Versailles. The result is shiny and new, if not wholly original.
lead_paragraph: The Battle of Versailles, the 1973 showdown between five French design houses (Yves Saint Laurent, Hubert de Givenchy, Emanuel Ungaro, Pierre Cardin and Christian Dior) and their American counterparts (Halston, Oscar de la Renta, Bill Blass, Stephen Burrows and Anne Klein), which is credited with putting American fashion on the international map, has long been a topic of fascination for the style world.

headline: Review: Tennessee Williams’s Late-Career Curiosities
abstract: Playhouse Creatures Theater Company presents two of the playwright’s one-acts from 1982, the year before he died.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee Williams had been in precarious shape for years by the time he died in February 1983: drinking too much, abusing prescription drugs, alienating those who loved him most. His career was correspondingly unwell. But he hadn’t stopped writing. And since his death, at 71, every last scrap has been potential fodder for the stage. A certain skepticism might be apt, then, at news of a double bill of Williams one-acts written in 1982.

headline: Davis Cup Matches on Grass Should Have Been on Hardcourts
abstract: Apparently, an agreement between the U.S. and Australia from 1999, the last time the two Davis Cup powers met, was lost and forgotten.
lead_paragraph: As the Australians and the Americans continued their first-round Davis Cup match on grass at historic Kooyong Stadium in Melbourne, tennis officials confirmed Friday that the matches should have been played on a hardcourt surface.

headline: Why Trading in Retirement Is a Bad Idea
abstract: The danger for investors in retirement is a punishing stock market downturn that reduces not only their income stream but also their total wealth.
lead_paragraph: You have a significant retirement portfolio, it’s yours to manage and you have time on your hands. You’re a smart person and you’re sure you can beat the market — or at least do better than a boring basket of mutual funds and income investments.

You should ask tenants why they will be renting, who will live in your home, whether they have pets and what they do for a living. Here are some of the lessons for homeowners based on our experiences as landlords and tenants.

headline: ‘NCIS’ at 300: The 5 Most Compelling Episodes
abstract: The CBS crime procedural is to air its 300th episode on March 15; here are some of the best episodes in its 13 years.
lead_paragraph: On March 15, the CBS crime procedural “NCIS” will air its 300th episode. As I write in my look back at 13 years of the series, reaching that number is a rare feat, and it’s usually a fairly circumspect type of show that does it. But while it might be easy to think of “NCIS” as comfort food, it is deeper and more ambitious than most people realize. Here are my nominations as the five most compelling “NCIS” episodes — ones that went unexpected places or showed especially deft writing and acting. (You can watch them all on CBS’s subscription streaming service, CBS All Access; the show’s first 12 seasons are also currently on Netflix.) Agree? Disagree? What episodes really got your attention? Offer up your choices in the comments section.

headline: ‘NCIS’: Meat and Potatoes TV, but Still Popular
abstract: The CBS drama, TV’s most-watched scripted show, is about to air its 300th episode, a rare achievement.
lead_paragraph: For a prime-time, scripted American television series to reach 300 episodes is a towering achievement. Fewer than 20 have done it. Yet attaining that milestone also practically guarantees a certain amount of disdain from the type of TV watcher who wants to project coolness. “Lassie.” “Bonanza.” “Law & Order.” “My Three Sons.” Square shows all, each in the 300 club.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Evidence is accumulating that food allergies in children might be prevented by feeding peanuts and other allergenic food to infants in their first year of life, researchers reported here Friday.

headline: Bud Collins, Who Covered Tennis With Authority and Flash, Dies at 86

lead_paragraph: Bud Collins, the passionate, often irreverent face of tennis for nearly half a century in his Wimbledon broadcasts and his newspaper and magazine columns, died on Friday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 86.

headline: A Sandal’s Name Has Dolce & Gabbana Under Fire Again
abstract: The front row mulls the context of $2,395 shoes that some on social media see as glorifying slavery.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Italian designers of Dolce & Gabbana are no strangers to scandal. After inflammatory comments about gay adoption and accusations of racial stereotyping on the runway last year, the latest apparent misstep by the duo came this week, after the brand listed a pair of $2,395 shoes on its website as “slave sandals with pompoms” and set in motion a social media firestorm.

headline: At Dior, Dramatic Lips and Clumpy Mascara
abstract: The house’s makeup director Peter Philips called the look “intense, almost dangerous.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s all about contradictions,” said Dior’s makeup director, Peter Philips, about the look he created for the house’s fall/winter 2016 show today. This season’s collection mixed prints with patterns — so Philips said he wanted the makeup to reflect a similar attitude. The look he had in mind, he said, was “really sophisticated, with intense, almost dangerous lips on this beautiful, even, alabaster skin, and rebellious clumpy lashes.”

lead_paragraph: IF your employer offered you $550 to lose weight, an amount that would be deducted from your health insurance premiums next year, would that provide the motivation to help you finally shed those pounds?

headline: Woolly Mullein: The City Cactus
abstract: A flowering plant found in poor soils is a prolific producer of seeds and the source of numerous tall tales involving Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: The seed-packed woody stalk of the common or woolly mullein stands out this time of year like an urban saguaro. Once covered with pale green leaves and flowers as yellow as summer, it is now leafless, coarse and bleached, anchored in the poor soil it prefers.

headline: 2 Who Helped Expose Flint Water Crisis Win PEN Awards
abstract: In May, PEN America will honor LeeAnne Walters and Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, who sounded early alarms about the quality of the water in Flint, Mich.
lead_paragraph: Two women who sounded early and persistent alarms about the quality of the water in Flint, Mich., will receive the Freedom of Expression Courage Award from PEN America, the group announced on Friday.

headline: T Toasts Marie-Amélie Sauvé With a Dinner in Paris
abstract: Charlotte Rampling, Alber Elbaz and more celebrated our new fashion director last night at Le Grand Véfour.
lead_paragraph: There were plenty of reasons to celebrate last night in Paris: We’re nearing the end of a fashion month that’s seen lots of excitement; our spring men’s style issue hits newsstands inside The Times this Sunday, March 6; and two weeks ago, T announced the appointment of Marie-Amélie Sauvé as our new fashion director. Last night, T’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, hosted a dinner to welcome and honor her at Le Grand Véfour, the storied Beaux-Arts establishment — and oldest continually operating restaurant in Paris — where Napoleon and Josephine used to rendezvous. Friends and supporters including Charlotte Rampling, Alber Elbaz, Christian Louboutin, Shayne Oliver, Nicolas Ghesquière, Liya Kebede and many others enjoyed lobster, Champagne and conversation — well into the Parisian night.

headline: T Celebrates Marie-Amélie Sauvé

lead_paragraph: Editor in chief Deborah Needleman hosted a dinner last night at Le Grand Véfour in Paris to honor our new fashion director.

headline: The Return of Joe Bataan, the Boogaloo King
abstract: A documentary film, “We Like It Like That,” has brought new attention to Mr. Bataan, a pioneer of boogaloo, the fusion of Latin rhythm and soul.
lead_paragraph: Joe Bataan was bouncing around behind his keyboard onstage at the B. B. King Blues Club in Times Square, turning to cue his 14-piece band and clearly enjoying himself. It was a good crowd for a Wednesday night, and the dancers were getting after it, so he was mixing in a dose of mambo with his signature doo-wop-tinged Latin soul songs like “Subway Joe” and “Ordinary Guy.” Between numbers he pointed out friends in the crowd, including a man he introduced as “Lindy from the Dragons,” a comrade from Mr. Bataan’s wild days running with New York street gangs in the 1950s.

lead_paragraph: Jason Servis watched with pride when John, his brother and fellow thoroughbred trainer, sent Smarty Jones to victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in 2004. But his joy turned to sadness when the long-shot Birdstone upset Smarty Jones’s Triple Crown bid by one length in the Belmont Stakes. Sadness turned to dismay when the colt never ran again.

Each year, teams assign salaries to players who have not played in the major leagues long enough to be eligible for arbitration; most of the time, the player and the team reach an agreement on salary, but in some instances, they do not.

headline: The Future of Grizzly Bears
keywords: ['Bald Eagles', 'Bears', 'Condors', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'States (US)', 'Wolves']
abstract: What will happen to grizzlies in the Yellowstone area if they’re taken off the endangered species list?
lead_paragraph: The 1973 Endangered Species Act, a landmark environmental measure much detested by developers and other commercial interests, is credited with saving the bald eagle, the peregrine falcon, the American alligator and the gray wolf, among other species. If the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has its way, the grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem will soon join that company of once-close-to-extinction creatures that no longer needed the act’s protection. On Thursday, the service proposed to remove grizzlies in the Yellowstone region — meaning the national park, and the states of Idaho, Montana and Wyoming — from the endangered species list, whose protections the bears have enjoyed since 1975.

headline: Man Convicted of Killing 3 Brooklyn Merchants Gets 75 Years in Prison
abstract: Salvatore Perrone, 67, was found guilty in February of a series of murders in 2012 that left shopkeepers on edge for months.
lead_paragraph: A traveling clothing salesman was sentenced on Friday to 75 years to life in prison for killing three merchants in Brooklyn in a series of attacks that had shopkeepers on alert for months, prosecutors said.

headline: The Way Things Work
abstract: Fashion is more democratic than ever before, and yet the industry’s problems can be summed up simply: You can’t buy a heavy coat in winter.
lead_paragraph: ANY MAN-MADE SYSTEM risks becoming so insular it is rendered nonsensical for those outside it. The complexities, anachronisms and demands of the current fashion system almost read like a cautionary tale. Fashion is more democratic and more popular than ever before, and yet the industry’s problems can be summed up by the simple fact that you can’t buy a swimsuit in summer or a heavy coat in winter.

headline: Mets’ Longtime Drill Sergeant Keeps Everything in Line at Camp
abstract: Guy Conti, 73, the team’s spring training czar, has sweat the details for five Mets managers.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As another spring training workout day came to a close, a group of Mets pitchers gathered on a remote field for one last round of pitchers’ fielding practice, or P.F.P.s, as they are called. The players knelt in a semicircle on the infield as instructed, and a coach began hitting hard, chopping ground balls toward their chests.

headline: Review: La Otra Orilla and Its Flamenco Bizarro
abstract: This Montreal troupe presents its experimental work as part of the World Music Institute’s Festival Ay! Más Flamenco.
lead_paragraph: Forget about a dress with an enchantingly long ruffle. How about a flamenco dancer who looks like she stepped out of a J. Crew catalog in a blue striped top and slim navy pants? That, apparently, signals innovation. (Or, as you may be thinking, the exact opposite.)

headline: 3 Top Officials Leaving Coney Island Hospital After Patient’s Death
abstract: Gisele Soto, who died a month ago at the hospital, was treated as though she were emotionally disturbed rather than severely ill, relatives said.

headline: Supreme Court Blocks Louisiana Abortion Law
abstract: Opponents say the 2014 law would leave the state with only one clinic, while Louisiana officials say things are not that dire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday temporarily blocked a Louisiana law that its opponents say would leave the state with only one abortion clinic. The court gave no reasons, though it did say that its order was “consistent with” one last June that blocked part of a Texas abortion law.
