lead_paragraph: For Dr. Paul Frank, the director of the Fifth Avenue Dermatology Surgery & Laser Center at 86th Street in Manhattan, weekends mean meditation, fitness and plenty of family time.

headline: How Paul Jarrod Frank, a Cosmetic Dermatologist, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Dr. Frank, director of the Fifth Avenue Dermatology Surgery & Laser Center, meditates with his wife, goes to Central Park with his kids and sometimes indulges at a guilty-pleasure spot for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul Jarrod Frank is the director of the Fifth Avenue Dermatology Surgery & Laser Center at 86th Street in Manhattan. Each year he performs over 300 surgeries, including liposuction, and over 1,000 noninvasive procedures, making him somewhat of a celebrity among certain sculpted New Yorkers. Dr. Frank, a 46-year-old dermatologist, grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and attended the Horace Mann School. In his youth, his favorite place to hang out on Friday nights was the steps of the Met. “It’s where I had my first kiss and my first drink,” he said. Dr. Frank lives on East 102nd Street with his wife, Diana, 44, a photographer, and their two children, Aidan, 10, and Avery, 8. Both attend his alma mater. ALIX STRAUSS

headline: Undercover: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Jun Takahashi’s latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Jun Takahashi’s latest designs.

headline: California Gas Leak Threatens Jerry Brown’s Image as a Climate Change Hero
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas', 'Methane', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The record gas leak in Porter Ranch prompted complaints that Governor Brown failed to prevent it and has snarled the state’s climate efforts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In his final term as California’s governor, Jerry Brown has made the battle against climate change a signature issue: He is fighting to vastly reduce the state’s emissions of greenhouse gases, to accelerate the move to electric cars and to rewire the state’s electrical grid. In December, he had a star turn with world leaders at the United Nations climate change conference in Paris.

headline: Noted Pianist Piotr Anderszewski Takes a Break From His Career
abstract: Mr. Anderszewski, 46, offered a diverse, dramatic performance at Alice Tully Hall before taking a surprise sabbatical from concertizing.
lead_paragraph: The superb Polish pianist Piotr Anderszewski does not want to become a “200-concert-per-year performing machine,” as he said in a recent interview with the website Humans of New York. The constant pressure and high expectations make it difficult for an artist to have fun, experiment and “stay in your dreams,” he explained.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Diantha Parker, Lynda Richardson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Pictures of the Day: Brazil and Elsewhere
abstract: Brazil and More — Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: Brazil and More — Photos of the Day

headline: March 4, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Brazil, Greece, Syria and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Brazil, Greece, Syria and France.

headline: Review: At Kishuya, Some Noodles to Go With That Drink
abstract: Kishuya, in Hartsdale, has a long counter, great for a quick drink and a snack, or working your way up to a heartier meal.
lead_paragraph: Some noodle places try to be distinctive by including sushi, tempura or yakitori selections with the featured item. Kishuya in Hartsdale has added a happy hour, with a banner in its window proclaiming ramen and izakaya, which is sort of a Japanese version of a small tavern.

headline: Here’s Hoping Earth Imagery Isn’t Too Routine to Inspire
abstract: Has the power of imagery of Earth from space faded since the days of “Earthrise”?
lead_paragraph: Much has been written about the remarkable achievements of NASA astronaut Scott Kelly and his Russian counterpart, cosmonaut Mikhail Kornienko, during their (340-day) Year in Space mission aboard the International Space Station. Daniel Victor had a fine overview on Tuesday and make sure to revisit Kenneth Chang’s fascinating package on Kelly and the long mission, in which, as he notes, Kelly and Kornienko experienced 10,880 sunrises* and sunsets in those 340 days.

headline: Review: At INC, a Menu of Conversation Starters
abstract: A young restaurateur hopes his restaurant gets guests talking, with friendly service and a bevy of small plates designed to be shared.
lead_paragraph: After our first visit to INC American Bar & Kitchen in New Brunswick, my wife asked whether I had noticed that we had not received any bread while waiting for our appetizers.

headline: Review: At Fish on Main, a World of Difference
abstract: Ayhan Hassan’s newest restaurant, billed as an American seafood grill, is a departure from his other successful places in Nassau County.
lead_paragraph: Ayhan Hassan has gone upscale with his newest venture, Fish on Main. In 1980, Mr. Hassan opened his first restaurant, Ayhan’s Shish-Kebab, in Port Washington. He now owns five Shish-Kebabs in Nassau County.

headline: The Road Not Taken to Better Jobs and Higher Pay
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: More Americans might be getting ahead if not for Republicans’ obstructionist strategies.
lead_paragraph: There is less to the February employment report than meets the eye.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Dusty Trails
abstract: We’s be lost without our own advice.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been getting ever more attention; on Colbert earlier this week. But this was the video I was waiting for: a lovely, acoustic version of this song. Goosebumps at 2:45:

headline: U.S. Pays to Feed and Shelter Cuban Migrants Stranded in Costa Rica
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The aid to Cuban migrants has raised questions about their special status compared with Washington’s efforts to bar Central American migrants.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The United States government has been paying to feed and shelter thousands of Cubans trying to migrate to the United States, in what critics consider another sign of the lopsided treatment provided to Cubans under American law.

headline: A Dress That Moves — With a Life of Its Own
abstract: The designer Hussein Chalayan created a “possessed dress” for a new show about technology and fashion opening this weekend.
lead_paragraph: For the designer Hussein Chalayan, technology is an essential part of designing a collection. It’s evident in the way he carefully describes his ideas for his performative runway shows — but also in the way he explains his process.”For me, it always starts with the idea and the piece I’m making. The way it’s presented comes after,” he says. (Today, Chalayan showed his fall/winter 2016 collection in Paris, which was full of dresses and blouses printed with technical drawings.)

headline: Review: At Vespa, Italian Authenticity With a Contemporary Vroom
abstract: Vespa, in Westport, has options like the spaghetti carbonara and the spicy lumache; its desserts bring drama and creativity to the plate.
lead_paragraph: Vespa in Italian means wasp or hornet, both of which suggest a “buzz.” Certainly a buzz exists at the newish Vespa restaurant in Westport, with its stylish décor, farm-to-table cuisine and genial atmosphere. And, at least when I visited, there wasn’t a single Vespa, an Italian motor scooter, parked outside.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Mr. Yamamoto, who just opened a retrospective in New York, debuts his fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Yamamoto, who just opened a retrospective in New York, debuts his fall collection.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Looks (and Listens) for Authenticity in Its Tunes
abstract: The television series has brought in old experts and new musicians to create songs with an authentic 1970s punk feel.
lead_paragraph: On the most recent episode of the new HBO drama “Vinyl” — a “Mad Men” for the 1970s record industry created by Terence Winter, Martin Scorsese, Mick Jagger and Rich Cohen — the fictional proto-punk band Nasty Bits gets its big break in front of label executives eager to find a fresh sound.

headline: Paris Fashion Week’s Best-Kept Secret
abstract: The juice bar Maisie Café officially opens in May, but it’s delivering in the capital as part of a trial run through March 9.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Paris had been devoid of food delivery services, much less gluten-free and dairy-free options. But the luxury sector executive Isabella Capece Galeota has introduced a solution — which coincides with the French capital’s fashion week. She and her husband, Xavier Barroux, decided to soft-launch their Maisie Café ahead of its official May opening near Place Vendôme to bring healthy snack alternatives to the show-going masses. The menu includes fresh coconut-water-based, cold-pressed juices; three types of shakes (banana, avocado and espresso); a cucumber detox; and chocolate or fruit granolas. By Capece Galeota’s count, they’ve already distributed several hundred M/M-branded bottles, which bodes well for such an endeavor in a gastronomic epicenter. “Here, people will not eat or drink something because it’s good for them — you have the added pressure of making it taste good, as well,” she says. “This is the capital of gourmet food, so you have to make gourmet juices.”

headline: Ben Carson's Path to the Exit
abstract: Ben Carson formally announced on Friday that he was ending his Republican presidential campaign. Here are some of the most emblematic moments of his bid, from debate mishaps and interview gaffes to campaign shake-ups.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson formally announced on Friday that he was ending his Republican presidential campaign. Here are some of the most emblematic moments of his bid, from debate mishaps and interview gaffes to campaign shake-ups.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Art Rules
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: Young artists challenged the status quo with their installations in the defunct post office at Moynihan Station, and the New York art establishment mingled at the Armory Show on the Hudson Piers.
lead_paragraph: Young artists challenged the status quo with their installations in the defunct post office at Moynihan Station, and the New York art establishment mingled at the Armory Show on the Hudson Piers.

headline: It’s Not a Reading, It’s Literary Cabaret
abstract: House of SpeakEasy wanted to take a break from the typical bookstore reading format. Now its “Seriously Entertaining” series is coming to Joe’s Pub.
lead_paragraph: When Amanda Foreman and Lucas Wittmann founded House of SpeakEasy, the organization behind their literary cabaret series, “Seriously Entertaining,” they wanted to break from the format of typical bookstore readings and hark back to the performative styles of authors like Dickens and Twain.

headline: Migrant Crisis Alters E.U. Calculations for Greece as Its Debt Struggle Continues
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Eight months after Greece agreed to more austerity measures as part of a bailout, it has largely been left to fend for itself on asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — When Greece’s debt crisis threatened to sink the European Union’s single currency last summer, the rest of Europe, led by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, ganged up to deliver the Greek government a stern message: Overcome your domestic political problems and do what is necessary to hold the Continent together.

headline: Restoring a Music Room’s Grandeur at the Rosen House
abstract: A new, improved Rosen House at the Caramoor Center for the Arts is on display for a March 13 concert.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 16, 1946, about 60 people witnessed the first concert with tickets at what would become the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah. They did so in comfort befitting the ornate setting, seated in plush velvet chairs facing the stage in the grandly appointed music room of the treasure-filled home now known as the Rosen House.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Dives Into Brahms’s ‘German Requiem’
abstract: The program — a single hourlong choral work— could hardly be simpler or more moving.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s program this week could hardly be simpler or more moving. It consists of a single hourlong choral work by Brahms, “Ein Deutsches Requiem” (“A German Requiem”), exquisitely prepared and performed.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, O.J. Simpson, Syria
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Ropes,’ a High-Wire Act of Brotherly Bonding
abstract: The play, by Bárbara Colio, focuses on three men bound uneasily together by their distant ties to their father, a tightrope walker who abandoned them as boys.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Cain and Abel, many stories have been told about brothers who do not get along. A variation on this eternal theme is currently being presented by the Two River Theater in Red Bank in the United States premiere of “Ropes.”

headline: Embracing Art to Escape the Holocaust’s Shadow
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Ruth Jacobsen, 83, a collage artist, and Judith Leiber, 95, a handbag designer, built creative careers after enduring Nazi repression.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Jacobsen, 83, a collage artist, and Judith Leiber, 95, a handbag designer, built creative careers after enduring Nazi repression.

headline: 2 Holocaust Survivors Turn to Art to Reclaim Lost Lives
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Art']
abstract: Ruth Jacobsen, 83, a collage artist, and Judith Leiber, 95, a handbag designer, built creative careers after enduring Nazi repression.
lead_paragraph: The collage artist Ruth Jacobsen, 83, and the handbag designer Judith Leiber, 95, both Holocaust survivors, have relied on the creative process and a strong-willed entrepreneurial spirit to reclaim their lives and break glass ceilings for women in the United States.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Art Rules
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: Young artists challenged the status quo with their installations in the defunct post office at Moynihan Station, and the New York art establishment mingled at the Armory Show on the Hudson Piers.
lead_paragraph: March 1: While the political world had everyone in a tizzy, the New York art world exploded last week with fairs, exhibitions and a new museum. One fair was the Spring/Break Art Show in the main post office on Eighth Avenue and 31st Street. The art installations had a youthful exuberance. More than 7,000 attended the opening festivities.

headline: Review: 2 Sisters Navigate 100 Years of Black History in ‘Having Our Say’
abstract: Emily Mann’s play, at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, offers a portrait of disparate personalities and a chronicle of the century they lived through.
lead_paragraph: Don’t call them old maids. Don’t call them African-Americans. Sadie and Bessie Delany, holding forth at Long Wharf Theater in Emily Mann’s Tony-nominated 1995 play, “Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters’ First 100 Years,” are very particular about things, whether the exact placement of a spotlessly white cutwork tablecloth, the precise thickness of an orange slice for ambrosia, or the careful arrangement of sparkling goblets and candlesticks. And when you have lived past the century mark, you are entitled to have things just as you want them. And husbands were not among the things they wanted. They were “too smart, too independent for most men,” Bessie says.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s Evening Hours
abstract: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.

headline: Review: The Minnesota Orchestra’s White Light and White Heat
abstract: Finally arriving at Carnegie Hall, after a bitter lockout, the orchestra and Osmo Vanska present their urgent take on the vision of Sibelius.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Osmo Vanska and his Minnesota Orchestra experienced a bitter inversion of the old maxim. How do you not get to Carnegie Hall? Lockout, lockout, lockout.

headline: Review: ‘Neal Brennan 3 MICS’ Comes at Comedy From Several Directions
abstract: A solo show from a writing partner of Dave Chappelle, mixes one-liners, stand-up and the confessional.
lead_paragraph: Neal Brennan’s three-cornered show at the Lynn Redgrave Theater doesn’t quite add up to a play; it’s more like listening to a decent comedy album while eavesdropping on someone’s therapy sessions. Think of it as an effort to present in stage form the dichotomy that many comics have written or talked about over the years: that humor is how they deal with personal pain.

headline: Regina King Has So Many Stories to Tell
abstract: The actress, who won an Emmy for her role in “American Crime,” has found success in playing a wide range of characters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Regina King’s house has a cozy seat at the foot of a hill in a section of the Los Feliz neighborhood here. The house isn’t far from the street but fosters an aura of secluded serenity anyway: A grapefruit tree guards the property. Off the rear patio is a small room with a vintage Pac-Man console and a signed LP of Prince’s “Controversy” on the wall.

headline: Your Evening Briefing.
abstract: Your Evening Briefing.
lead_paragraph: Your Evening Briefing.

headline: Donald Trump Is Spending Nearly $2 Million on TV Ads
abstract: Mr. Trump is spending close to $1 million apiece in Ohio and Florida for television ads, two people tracking media spending said, in a signal that the advertising assault against him is taking a toll.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is dropping close to $1 million apiece in Ohio and Florida for television ads, two people tracking media spending said, in a signal that the sustained advertising assault against him is taking a toll.

headline: Art Gone to Hell: A Boschian Bestiary
abstract: Most of Hieronymus Bosch’s surviving paintings are now on display in his hometown. Here’s a guide to a few of them.
lead_paragraph: Most of Hieronymus Bosch’s surviving paintings are now on display in his hometown. Here’s a guide to a few of them.

headline: For Hieronymus Bosch, One Helluva Homecoming
abstract: Two major retrospectives, one in the Dutch artist’s hometown in the Netherlands, bring together his scattered masterpieces.
lead_paragraph: ’S-HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands — Hieronymus Bosch died 500 years ago, his soul dispatched to parts unknown — perhaps oblivion, perhaps heavenly peace, perhaps a hellscape of his own invention. His reputation, however, resides in earthly paradise, with two blockbuster exhibitions this year, drawing tens of thousands to admire his slavering, fluttering, waddling abominations.

headline: As Olympics Near and Zika Spreads, No Talk of a Plan B
abstract: Olympic officials continue to express confidence that the Games will go on as planned, but health questions persist.
lead_paragraph: How confident is Scott Blackmun, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, that the Zika virus will not ruin the Rio Summer Olympics or render them unsafe for athletes, workers and spectators?

headline: Your Back Pages: Readers Share Dylan Memories
abstract: Generations of fans offered recollections and images from their personal Bob Dylan archives: vinyl records, his mother’s autograph, a backstage bottle of bourbon.
lead_paragraph: This week, we published an article about the new Bob Dylan Archive in Tulsa, Okla. The lyrics, letters, photographs and other ephemera among the more than 6,000 items in the archive represent decades of American history. Arguably just as important as Mr. Dylan’s items are the memories carried by generations of fans. So we asked readers to share something from their own personal Dylan archives: the vinyl copy of “Blonde on Blonde” that survived moves, marriages and children; the ticket stub that conjures mental images of an inspiring performance; the bootlegged recording from the show.

headline: She Wanted to Do Her Research. He Wanted to Talk ‘Feelings.’
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: For women in science, part of the job can mean dealing with unwanted sexual attention.
lead_paragraph: Honolulu — OVER the past two decades as a professor, I’ve grown thousands of plants, studying how their biology shifts in response to our changing environment. Soon I’ll begin to design and build my fourth laboratory; I’ll teach classes and take on more staff members, as I do every year. Like all professors, I also do a lot of extra jobs for which I was never trained, such as advising former students as they navigate the wider world. Last year, after one of my most talented students left to start her next adventure, she would text me now and then: “This is such a great place,” “I am learning so much here” and “I know this is where I am supposed to be.”

headline: Bravo Zulu: On (Representative) Ryan Zinke
abstract: Zinke’s two Twitter accounts — separate, but basically identical — try to divide the personal and the political.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

headline: Email Regarding Tom Donilon
abstract: This email, released by the State Department, was sent to Hillary Clinton's private server, which she used while she was secretary of state. The correspondence is full of tongue-in-cheek remarks concerning the overlapping trips to Israel of national security adviser, Thomas E. Donilon, and Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: This email, released by the State Department, was sent to Hillary Clinton's private server, which she used while she was secretary of state. The correspondence is full of tongue-in-cheek remarks concerning the overlapping trips to Israel of national security adviser, Thomas E. Donilon, and Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Agency Rivalries and Satire Show Up in Latest of Hillary Clinton’s Emails
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A series of tongue-in-cheek messages from Mrs. Clinton’s spokesman were initially viewed as serious when White House lawyers reviewed them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reviewing Hillary Clinton’s emails for public release has strained the State Department’s lawyers, set off bitter turf battles between the department and other agencies, and ignited a contentious debate over the nature and handling of classified information.

headline: Steven Ballmer, Clippers’ Top Fan, Is Really Invested in Them (for Billions)
abstract: Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive, is a creative owner and a screaming, trampoline-bouncing presence at the team’s games.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — During the first timeout, a few minutes into Wednesday’s game between the Los Angeles Clippers and the Oklahoma City Thunder at Staples Center here, Steven A. Ballmer looked up from his courtside seat at the fans still filtering in. “There are still some empty seats,” he said.

headline: Rikers Island Cases Are Focus for New Bronx District Attorney
abstract: New York City’s main jail complex lies within Darcel D. Clark’s jurisdiction and is at the top of her priority list.
lead_paragraph: The new Bronx district attorney, Darcel D. Clark, oversees the prosecution of crime in a dozen police precincts and scores of neighborhoods.

headline: Fed Proposes New Rule Capping Business Between Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The cap says that eight systemically important banks cannot have loans or trades or other business with another large bank that exceed 15 percent of their capital.
lead_paragraph: One of the problems with big Wall Street banks in 2008 was that they had too many of their financial eggs in one basket.

headline: William & Mary Seeks an Elusive Berth
abstract: William & Mary is one of five charter Division I members that have never participated in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: Russell Turner was a part of not one but two teams that became the first in their programs’ histories to make an N.C.A.A. tournament. As a player, he was a freshman on the Hampden-Sydney team that made its first Division III tournament in 1989. Now, as the coach of U.C. Irvine, he hopes to lead the Anteaters to a second consecutive berth in the Division I tournament after last season’s team earned the first invitation in program history.

headline: Connecticut Rock Pile Known as Negro Heads May Get a New Name
abstract: It may be dwarfed by Denali, the 20,308-foot peak in Alaska long known as Mount McKinley, but the mussel-covered formation in the Long Island Sound is at the center of a naming debate of its own.
lead_paragraph: BRANFORD, Conn. — It may be dwarfed by Denali, the 20,308-foot peak in Alaska long known as Mount McKinley. But the mussel-covered pile of rocks about a mile off shore from this briny town on the Long Island Sound is at the center of a naming debate of its own, one fueled by what many consider the ugliness of the label it carries: Negro Heads.

headline: Obstacles for Global Talent in National Women’s Hockey League
abstract: The N.W.H.L.’s first year has required sacrifices from its 72 players to grow the game of women’s hockey. These costs are magnified for the league’s 21 international players
lead_paragraph: During a trip to Junior’s restaurant in early February, Nana Fujimoto sat against a wall decorated with Brooklyn Dodgers memorabilia, savoring a slice of cheesecake while discussing her journey from Sapporo, Japan, to the National Women’s Hockey League.

headline: At RSA Conference, Unlikely Allies Address Value of Digital Security
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Given Apple’s dispute with the F.B.I., what surprised many at the world’s largest gathering of security experts was the nuanced tone of former government officials.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To Amit Yoran, a digital security veteran, the fight between Apple and the F.B.I. over access to an iPhone can be viewed in black-and-white terms: What law enforcement authorities want is “so misguided, they simply boggle the mind.”

headline: Rev. Robert Palladino, Scribe Who Shaped Apple’s Fonts, Dies at 83
abstract: Father Palladino was a world-renowned master of calligraphy who taught Steve Jobs the importance — and aesthetics — of scripts.
lead_paragraph: Because of a Trappist monk, Apple computer displays look the way they do today.

headline: Distant, Tropical Isle Is Home Court for the French in a Davis Cup Match
abstract: Its first-round matchup against Canada is the first in France’s illustrious but tumultuous Davis Cup history to be played overseas in the Caribbean island of Guadeloupe.
lead_paragraph: BAIE-MAHAULT, Guadeloupe — It seems fantastic that four of the world’s best tennis players would descend upon a small Caribbean island more than 4,000 miles from home to take the first step toward their elusive Davis Cup.

headline: Harvard Law to Abandon Crest Linked to Slavery
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Heraldry', 'Law Schools']
abstract: The school has decided to stop using an 80-year-old shield based on the crest of an 18th-century slaveholding family who helped endow the institution.
lead_paragraph: Harvard Law School is poised to abandon an 80-year-old shield based on the crest of a slaveholding family that helped endow the institution, as campuses across the country debate the use of historic names and symbols that some consider offensive.

headline: Trump’s Softened Stance on Visas Alarms Some Immigration Critics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The word quickly spread after Donald J. Trump said during Thursday night’s debate that he wanted to expand the number of visas available for highly skilled immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Amid the sparring and free-flying insults of Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate, Donald J. Trump said he wanted to expand the number of visas available for highly skilled immigrants.

headline: Toxic Passaic River to Get $1.38 Billion Cleanup Over 10 Years
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Superfund', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Chemicals']
abstract: The project announced by the Environmental Protection Agency will be among the most ambitious yet in the 35-year history of the Superfund program.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Passaic River was once the backbone of an industrial corridor, snaking through this stretch of northern New Jersey and sustaining the factories and plants that cropped up alongside it. But now, the river’s banks are dotted by deserted manufacturing sites while the waterway remains scarred after decades as a dumping ground for industrial pollutants that linger in the water and have seeped into the soil.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “They need food. They need to eat. They’re stealing everything.”

headline: Ted Cruz Promoted Himself and Conservative Causes as Texas’ Solicitor General
abstract: Mr. Cruz turned the solicitor’s office into a defender of the right wing and he made crucial friends in Texas — though he once angered Bush family allies.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — From its start in 1999, the office of the solicitor general of Texas was run by a plain-spoken Mormon, a by-the-books lawyer known for mentoring young attorneys and defending the state, whatever the political consequences.

headline: Spain’s Socialist Leader Loses Another Vote to Become Prime Minister
abstract: The second defeat for Pedro Sánchez makes it more likely that the country will hold new elections in June.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The leader of the Socialist party, Pedro Sánchez, on Friday lost another parliamentary vote in his bid to become prime minister, prolonging the deadlock in Spanish politics.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Join Bernie Sanders at Fox News Town Hall on Monday
abstract: After initially saying she couldn’t make it, Hillary Clinton’s campaign agreed to participate in a Fox News town hall event in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton will join Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont at a town hall event hosted by Fox News on Monday night in Detroit, the network announced.

headline: Clinton Offers Economic Plan Focused on Jobs
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Corporate Taxes', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Hillary Clinton, campaigning in Michigan before the Tuesday primary, also offered proposals to strip tax benefits from companies that move jobs overseas.
lead_paragraph: In an election year defined by angry populism, Hillary Clinton made an optimistic economic pitch on Friday, presenting a wide-ranging plan for job growth that would provide incentives for corporations that invest in employees and strip tax benefits from companies that move jobs overseas.

headline: Review: Independent Fair Is More Conventional, but Still Eye-Catching
abstract: Now in its seventh year, this art fair has moved from Chelsea to TriBeCa, with 45 galleries exhibiting.
lead_paragraph: The Independent art fair, which runs through Sunday, began as a more provocative alternative to the bigger art fairs. Now in its seventh year, it isn’t quite so independent anymore. There are two iterations in New York — one in November and the one now in TriBeCa — as well as one in Brussels, which opens next month.

headline: Rank and File Republicans Tell Party Elites: We’re Sticking With Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The appeal from Mitt Romney and the furious reaction to it captured the essence of the party’s schism.
lead_paragraph: From Michigan to Louisiana to California on Friday, rank-and-file Republicans expressed mystification, dismissal and contempt over the instructions that their party’s most high-profile leaders were urgently handing down to them: Reject and defeat Donald J. Trump.

headline: Stream of Protesters Turns Donald Trump Rally Into ‘Wild Evening’
abstract: “Get ’em out of here” was Mr. Trump’s go-to line as a series of protesters disrupted his New Orleans rally.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — An almost constant stream of protesters interrupted Donald J. Trump’s nighttime rally here Friday, often resisting removal and dropping to the ground as security personnel tried to hustle them from the event.

headline: The Right to Sue the Gun Industry
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Firearms', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The gun industry shield law that Congress foolishly passed in 2005 could derail a lawsuit filed by Sandy Hook Elementary School parents.
lead_paragraph: The world recoiled in horror in 2012 when 20 Connecticut schoolchildren and six adults were killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School by a deranged teenager using a military-style assault rifle to fire 154 rounds in less than five minutes. The weapon was a Bushmaster AR-15 semiautomatic rifle adapted from its original role as a battlefield weapon. The AR-15, which is designed to inflict maximum casualties with rapid bursts, should never have been available for purchase by civilians.

headline: Breuer Building Expands the Imagination, and the Budget, of the Met
abstract: The new Met Breuer museum will cost $17 million each year to run. The Met also spent millions upgrading and rebranding the building.
lead_paragraph: Taking on the Breuer building is a big deal even for a behemoth like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with an annual operating budget of $370 million.

headline: A $15 Minimum Wage for New York
abstract: Republicans in the State Senate would be smart to stop playing politics and support the sensible budget provision.
lead_paragraph: The lowest-wage workers in New York could soon get a much-needed raise — if the stingy Republicans who control the State Senate don’t block it.

headline: Three More Judges Said to Be Vetted for Supreme Court
abstract: Two federal appellate judges, Merrick B. Garland and Sri Srinivasan, and a trial judge, Ketanji Brown Jackson, help flesh out the slate of President Obama’s potential nominees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is vetting Merrick B. Garland and Sri Srinivasan, federal appellate judges who have enjoyed substantial support from Republicans in the past, as potential nominees for a Supreme Court vacancy that has set off a brutal election-year fight.

headline: Syria’s Shaky Respite
abstract: The cease-fire shows some promise, but if the Syrian and the Russian presidents exploit it, the United States will have to consider alternatives.
lead_paragraph: Syrians desperate for normalcy after nearly five blood-soaked years of war have slowly begun testing the cease-fire that took effect a week ago. They are planting potatoes in the garden, going to the market and playing in the street, resuming cherished everyday routines that have been cruelly disrupted.

headline: Scott Kelly Says a Year in Orbit Felt Like ‘Forever’
abstract: The astronaut Scott Kelly, back on Earth after 340 days in space, said he was feeling fatigue, soreness and a sensation “almost like a burning feeling” on his skin.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year in space, Scott Kelly, the NASA astronaut who returned to Earth this week, is clear on one thing: It was a long trip.

headline: Phil Mickelson Loses Grip on His Game, and Then the Lead
abstract: Mickelson dropped to five shots behind the leader of the Cadillac Championship, Adam Scott, who feasted amid soft conditions and benign breezes.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Phil Mickelson was his vintage self on Friday, a thrill ride filled with imagination and anticipation that anything was still possible. At 45, he is the oldest player in the Cadillac Championship field. He was leading by two strokes at midround when he inexplicably lost his momentum and golf’s next generation of stars blew past him like a rogue wind.

headline: Ralph Baruch, Who Shaped Viacom’s Rise, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Baruch, the first president and chief executive of Viacom, transformed it from a small cable and syndication company into a communications and entertainment giant.
lead_paragraph: Ralph M. Baruch, a refugee from Nazi Germany who turned Viacom, a small cable and syndication company that CBS spun off in 1971, into a communications and entertainment giant, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Pale Yellow
abstract: Roland Huget describes the evolution of his Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Roland Huget is back, and he says below that he might have filled his puzzle differently these days, compared with how he filled it when it was submitted. That’s reasonable. We all evolve over time. And at least Mr. Huget can claim to be the guy who first introduced BARE IT ALL in The New York Times crossword.

headline: Judge Reduces Man’s Wrongful Conviction Award to $12 Million
abstract: A man who was imprisoned for more than 20 years was first awarded $18.5 million, but a judge has ordered that amount reduced by more than $6 million.
lead_paragraph: A judge who had previously thrown out a jury’s award to a New York City man who was wrongly convicted of rape and imprisoned for over 20 years ruled on Friday that the judgment should be reduced by more than $6 million.

headline: Blame HUD for America’s Lead Epidemic
keywords: ['Lead', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Inadequate federal regulations are egregious contributors to lead poisoning cases in public and low-income housing.
lead_paragraph: Chicago — SINCE news first emerged last year about dangerously high levels of lead in the drinking water in Flint, Mich., it has become shockingly clear that that city is far from alone. Reports of lead poisoning are on the rise across the country, from New York to Ohio and Iowa, particularly among low-income and minority children.

headline: Chinese Premier’s Annual Work Report
abstract: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China delivered his government's annual work report to the National People’s Congress, the national legislature, on Saturday. Here is a transcript of his speech.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China delivered his government's annual work report to the National People’s Congress, the national legislature, on Saturday. Here is a transcript of his speech.

headline: Abortion Witch Hunt
abstract: House Republicans are abusing their subpoena power.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, Representative Marsha Blackburn, Republican of Tennessee, in her capacity as chairwoman of the newly created House Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives, issued subpoenas to three organizations: StemExpress, a company that supplies biological specimens for research; the University of New Mexico, where scientists conduct medical research using fetal tissue; and Southwestern Women’s Options, an abortion clinic in Albuquerque.

headline: How Iran’s Reformists Found Their Center
abstract: Last week’s election was a victory for pragmatism. Is that what the country needs in order to reform?
lead_paragraph: FOR decades, Iran’s politics have centered on a contest of visions that pitted democratic reformists against hard-line theocrats. Under President Hassan Rouhani, that binary has begun to give way. Last week’s elections showcased a coordinated movement toward the center of Iran’s political spectrum.

headline: China’s National People’s Congress: Key Points
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Air Pollution', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A look at the nation’s priorities for this year, and for the rest of the decade, shows an emphasis on economic pain and environmental troubles.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government laid out its priorities for the year on Saturday, when Prime Minister Li Keqiang gave his annual state-of-the-nation report to the legislature, the National People’s Congress. Here are highlights from that report and other government documents released at the legislative meeting in the Great Hall of the People.

headline: Judge Seals Harper Lee’s Will From Public’s Scrutiny
abstract: Considerable curiosity has surrounded the value of the beloved author’s estate, and the ultimate distribution of her assets and papers.
lead_paragraph: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — In death, as in life, Harper Lee appears to have opted for privacy, as a lawyer for the estate of the “To Kill a Mockingbird” author asked this week that her will be sealed from the public.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Misses, and a Bad Week Continues for Knicks
abstract: Anthony’s week began with an exchange of words with a heckler and on Friday he missed a potential game-winning shot at the buzzer.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Carmelo Anthony was already having a difficult week before he showed up Friday at TD Garden with the rest of the Knicks. Where to begin?

headline: Pat Conroy, Author of ‘The Prince of Tides’ and ‘The Great Santini,’ Dies at 70
abstract: The writer’s troubled relationship with his father, as well as the lush coastal landscapes of the South, were perennial subjects of his fiction and memoirs.
lead_paragraph: Pat Conroy, who used his tortured family life and the scenic marshlands of coastal South Carolina as unending sources of inspiration for his fiction, notably the novels “The Great Santini,” “The Lords of Discipline” and “The Prince of Tides,” died on Friday. He was 70.

headline: Tom Knight, Brooklyn’s Baseball Sage, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Knight was the first and only official baseball historian of Brooklyn, and though it was not certain that he had any official duties, his qualifications were indisputable.
lead_paragraph: As decades pass, fans of the Brooklyn Dodgers, perhaps the most fervidly nostalgic partisans in the history of sports, are growing fewer and fewer. The 2016 baseball season, now getting underway, is the 59th since the team decamped to Los Angeles, leaving Brooklyn’s baseball die-hards with pangs of heartsickness for the loss of Gil Hodges, Duke Snider and Pee Wee Reese and venomous animosity for the never-to-be-forgiven betrayal of the team owner, Walter O’Malley, who took them away.

headline: Tony Dyson, Who Brought R2-D2 to Rolling, Beeping Life, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Dyson originally built eight models of the robot for the first “Star Wars” film, some operated by remote control and two fitted with a seat inside for the actor Kenny Baker.
lead_paragraph: Tony Dyson, the special-effects designer who built R2-D2, the squat robot sidekick that beeped and whirred its way through seven Star Wars films, died on Friday at his home on the Maltese island of Gozo. He was 68.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Melissa McCarthy plays a funny Miss Moneypenny in “Spy.” Amy Adams is an unheralded painter in “Big Eyes.” And Jonah Hill hosts “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: Need a laugh? Melissa McCarthy spoofs Miss Moneypenny in “Spy” and Jonah Hill hosts “Saturday Night Live.” Feel like a cry? Amy Adams portrays Margaret Keane, the unheralded artist behind those popular 1960s waifs with sad faces and enormous peepers, in “Big Eyes.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: The Weekend
abstract: Talk on the front rows will be centering on the debut of Demna Gvasalia at Balenciaga and Phoebe Philo’s future at Celine.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Rise and shine, fashion week folk: The weekend begins with the Japanese designer Junya Watanabe, a former protégé of Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garçons, who shows (mercifully, with coffee) at 9:30 at La Cantine, on the far side of the Seine.

headline: Corrections: March 5, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: ‘No Grace in Defeat’: Our Best Comments of the Week
abstract: Readers sound off about Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump, as well as lead poisoning, the testing of children’s emotional skills and more.
lead_paragraph: In this new feature, we list the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Networking in the ‘Girls’ Lounge’
abstract: Shelley Zalis, who is leading an effort to advance corporate women, says businesswomen should band together and pour on the pink.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Serious, successful businesswomen banding together as “girlie girls” to help end gender inequality in the workplace?

headline: After the Broadway Show, a Trip to Hamilton’s Grave
abstract: Fans of the Broadway musical “Hamilton,” eager to connect, are flocking to a founding father’s final resting place.
lead_paragraph: The tranquil graveyard at Trinity Church is tucked into an otherwise bustling commercial corner of Lower Manhattan. Inside its gates, weatherworn headstones — some dating from the 1680s — stand in the shadows of skyscrapers.

headline: Millennial Reporters Grab the Campaign-Trail Spotlight
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Millennial Generation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Youth']
abstract: Young reporters from BuzzFeed, CNN, The Washington Post and other news outlets have become the media stars of the topsy-turvy 2016 race.
lead_paragraph: When the last presidential race was in its early stages, Katie Glueck was a senior at Northwestern University. Now covering the Ted Cruz campaign for Politico, Ms. Glueck, 26, belongs to a select group of millennial reporters who have a front-row seat to the greatest political show on earth.

headline: Causes of Blindness Vary for Older Adults
abstract: Studies have found striking differences by age and by racial and socioeconomic groups.
lead_paragraph: Q. What’s the No. 1 cause of blindness in older adults in the United States?

headline: A One-Man Quest for Answers in Malaysian Jet’s Disappearance
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Blaine Alan Gibson, who found debris that officials say could be from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, says he is “intrigued by mysteries that need to be solved.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The search for the Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished almost two years ago has involved ships scanning thousands of square miles of the Indian Ocean seabed. But what could be the most promising development in months was the result of a lone man’s search, one that took him to an uninhabited sandbank along the coast of Mozambique.

headline: The Intrexon Menagerie
abstract: Randal Kirk’s ventures range from gene therapies and cancer research, to a collection of genetically engineered animals, fruits and insects.
lead_paragraph: Randal Kirk’s ventures range from gene therapies and cancer research, to a collection of genetically engineered animals, fruits and insects.

headline: A Biotech Evangelist Seeks a Zika Dividend
keywords: ['Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Mosquitoes', 'Zika Virus', 'Genetic Engineering', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Synthetic Biology']
abstract: A diverse biotechnology company hopes its genetically engineered mosquitoes can help stop the spread of a devastating virus. But that’s just a start.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — In the expanding realm ruled by Randal J. Kirk, sliced apples don’t brown. Salmon grow twice as fast without swimming upriver to spawn. Beloved cats are reborn.

headline: In New Economic Plan, China Bets That Hard Choices Can Be Avoided
abstract: China’s leaders are wagering that they can spur growth while deferring the pain of restructuring the economy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As economic growth has fallen while debts and excess industrial output have risen, Chinese leaders have faced growing questions about whether they will carry out the painful policy surgery many experts say is needed to cut away the financial dead weight on the economy.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2016
abstract: The Colombian designer, Mr. Ackermann, debuts his fall collection.
lead_paragraph: The Colombian designer, Mr. Ackermann, debuts his fall collection.

abstract: Mr. Watanabe presents his fall looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Watanabe presents his fall looks.

lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the Academy Awards to Cadaqués, Spain.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Run 5-Minute Documentary Ad on Univision to Court Hispanics
abstract: In an effort to reach millions of Hispanic voters, Bernie Sanders’s campaign is running a five-minute Spanish-language ad on Univision that calls attention to the plight of a female farm worker in Florida.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to reach millions of Hispanic voters, Bernie Sanders’s campaign is running a five-minute Spanish-language ad on Univision that calls attention to the plight of a female farm worker in Florida.

headline: Tensions Simmer as a Small Town Seeks Answers in a Boy’s Killing
abstract: The case against a soccer coach charged with murdering a former girlfriend’s 12-year-old son in upstate New York raises questions of racial bias and overreaching.
lead_paragraph: POTSDAM, N.Y. — At the southern edge of this village near the Canadian border, a small billboard slowly comes into focus. On the left is a black-and-white photo of a boy, reminiscent of so many missing-children posters; to the right are the words “Unsolved Murder.”

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: Discuss your solving experience of the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: The Daily Shoe: Loewe
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Anderson’s pointed Loewe heels are art for the feet — and as covetable as the clothes.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Dior
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The edge at the Dior show came out not in the clothes but in the jewelry, as seen in this fistful of rings dangling charms and beads.

headline: The Daily Bag: Loewe
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The hobo bag gets an update courtesy of Loewe: The soft, laid-back shape was complete with braided straps and gold hardware, making for one of the best bags we’ve seen this week.

headline: Farhad and Joe Examine Silicon Valley’s Pull in Washington
abstract: The chat goes from new talking devices, a drone that sees things, goggles (really) and the Apple cliffhanger. (Where’s Mike, anyway?)
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Isaac is out this week, so Joe Plambeck, deputy technology editor, is filling in.

headline: Ad Calls Trump a Fraud, and Unfit for the White House
abstract: In the political ad world, it was a week of accusations, cuss words, emojis and the blues.
lead_paragraph: For 60 seconds, the accusations fly: “Massive Scam.” “Operating a phony university.” “Habitual liar.” Seizing on one of his more questionable business ventures, this ad – helpfully titled “Scam” — assaults Donald J. Trump’s character and fitness for the presidency. The commercial was produced by Our Principles PAC, a group that is not aligned with any of his rivals but that sees Mr. Trump as calamitous to the Republican Party if he becomes its nominee.

headline: Buying a Co-op with ‘Dummy Money’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Pets', 'Water', 'Mortgages', 'Dogs']
abstract: Co-op liquidity requirements, running out of hot water, and circumventing a no-pet policy.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: If It’s March, It Must Be Miami: When Home Changes With the Season
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Urban Areas', 'Seasons and Months']
abstract: Today’s ultrawealthy often maintain residences in a number of hot spots, and they’re spending less time in each one.
lead_paragraph: Oren Alexander, the Miami-based real estate agent to the rich, no longer thinks of his clients as second-home buyers. Today’s ultrawealthy, he says, are often looking for “the four-pack” — a pied-à-terre in New York, a beach house in the Hamptons, a ski villa in Aspen and a winter condo in Miami.

headline: Ted Cruz Keeps Up Pressure on Donald Trump; Bernie Sanders Takes 2 on ‘Super Saturday’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The hunt for delegates resumed Saturday with Republican contests in Kansas, Louisiana, Maine and Kentucky, and Democratic ones in Kansas, Louisiana and Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz scored decisive wins in the Kansas and Maine caucuses on Saturday, demonstrating his enduring appeal among conservatives as he tried to reel in Donald J. Trump’s significant lead in the Republican presidential race.

headline: The Kasich Con
abstract: Nonsense Uber alles.
lead_paragraph: At this point, according to Predictwise, John Kasich has the fourth-best chance of getting the Republican nomination. It’s not a big chance — 5 percent — but you can imagine a scenario in which the stop Trump forces produce a hung convention, and Kasich emerges as the supposedly reasonable candidate. So an advance warning: he’s a con artist too.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Dior, Loewe and Olympia Le-Tan in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.

headline: At Haider Ackermann, an Otherworldly Beauty — With Sculptural Hair
abstract: For the fall/winter 2016 collection, makeup was restrained with pale, ethereal skin and bleached brows.
lead_paragraph: “It’s an otherworldly beauty. It’s about very blank faces with beautiful skin,” the makeup artist Lynsey Alexander said of the beauty look at the Haider Ackermann show earlier today. To achieve it, she smoothed and illuminated models’ faces with MAC’s Face and Body Foundation — and mixed it with Face and Body White and Silver Strobe Cream to give a slight iridescent finish to the skin.

abstract: Sometimes art imitates life. Sometimes life imitates art.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes art imitates life. Sometimes life imitates art. And sometimes, life imitates art before that art has even shown up on Netflix.

headline: Variety: A Beautiful Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon help us find our way.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — For me, maps are all about possibilities. Looking at the highways and byways, the cities and towns, the land masses, all I can think of is the possibility of seeing places I’ve never visited and how I will get there. Maps are about adventure.

headline: Red Bulls’ Bradley Wright-Phillips Wins Greater Regard by Scoring Less
abstract: Wright-Phillips tied the M.L.S. record for goals in a season in 2014, but then his production dropped. Yet he has become a better all-around player as a result.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — It is hard to argue with the results, even if the cold, spare statistics of soccer suggest otherwise. Bradley Wright-Phillips and his teammates insist that Wright-Phillips, their high-scoring, heel-clicking striker, has been a more efficient player, and the Red Bulls a better team, since he avoided the net-bending feats he accomplished in 2014.

headline: New York Governor Race Analysis and Trump
abstract: An October 2013 memo sent to senior New York State Republicans urged them to consider Donald J. Trump as the party's nominee for governor.
lead_paragraph: An October 2013 memo sent to senior New York State Republicans urged them to consider Donald J. Trump as the party's nominee for governor.

headline: 'Springboards to the Presidency' Memo
abstract: A memo sent to Donald J. Trump in December 2013 detailed how he could increase his chances of winning the White House if he first ran for governor of New York.
lead_paragraph: A memo sent to Donald J. Trump in December 2013 detailed how he could increase his chances of winning the White House if he first ran for governor of New York.

headline: Donald Trump Considered Path to Presidency Starting at Governor’s Mansion in New York
abstract: In late 2013 and early 2014, Mr. Trump held meetings with Republican leaders in New York about a possible race for governor, discussing themes that are now central to his presidential race.
lead_paragraph: In late December 2013, after Donald J. Trump had met with a number of Republicans to discuss a possible run for governor of New York, he received a memo from an attendee, a freshman assemblyman from upstate.

headline: After Heartbreak, Twins Slugger Miguel Sano Looks Ahead
abstract: Sano has slowly come to terms with the death of his infant daughter, and now he is channeling his energy into learning the intricacies of right field.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The memorial stretches nearly from the wrist to the elbow on the right forearm of the major leagues’ next slugging star. Miguel Sano, the Minnesota Twins’ 22-year-old power hitter, is never far from his daughter.

headline: Italian Cuisine Worth Going to Prison For
abstract: InGalera, a restaurant that opened recently to rave reviews, is inside the Bollate Penitentiary on the outskirts of the city.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The waiters glided through the crowded dining room of InGalera, a restaurant that opened recently to rave reviews. Dinner reservations are almost fully booked for March, and the Milanese elite have taken note. A former bank president came a few weeks ago. So did a former Miss Italy. Families come on weekends.

headline: Airbnb Pits Neighbor Against Neighbor in Tourist-Friendly New Orleans
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Bed-and-Breakfast Lodgings', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']

headline: New Yankee Had a Sweet Swing as a Child, but in Golf

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Aaron Hicks was 10, already busy collecting golf trophies on some of the same courses that Tiger Woods had grown up on, his friends asked him to play Little League with them. So Hicks asked his father for permission.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The intensifying legal battle over encryption between Apple and the Justice Department has all but obscured another more subtle division, the one inside the Obama administration itself.

headline: Canadiens’ Fast Start Gives Way to Long Skid
abstract: Following a 9-0-0 start, optimism was washed away by a succession of injuries, including one to the star goalie Carey Price, and a struggling offense.
lead_paragraph: On the day the Montreal Canadiens completed a winless three-game trip through California, the biggest news for the franchise came almost 3,000 miles away. Hours before the Canadiens lost, 3-2, to the Los Angeles Kings on Thursday, their star goaltender Carey Price, the reigning Hart Trophy winner as the N.H.L.’s most valuable player, spoke at the team’s practice complex in Montreal.

headline: Money Given to Kenya, Since Stolen, Puts Nike in Spotlight
abstract: According to email exchanges, letters, bank records and invoices, Nike’s attempt to maintain sponsorship of Kenya’s runners has precipitated a scandal.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When a Chinese clothing company swooped in and offered to sponsor Kenya’s famed runners, Nike panicked, Kenyan officials say.

headline: When the Tide of Islamophobia Reached My Hometown Mosque
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Americans', 'Mosques', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vandalism', 'Hate Crimes', 'Pigs']
abstract: Despite vicious rhetoric in politics and a rash of anti-Muslim crimes across the country, I felt safe. Until now.
lead_paragraph: THE Islamic Society of North America’s headquarters sit atop a grassy hill overlooking Plainfield, Ind. The complex includes a prayer hall, a space for community events and a field house with a basketball court and playground. It is surrounded by cornfields. As the largest mosque in the Indianapolis area, it draws hundreds of families, especially during Ramadan and on holidays.

headline: Waiter, Where’s Our (Political) Spinach?
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A look at Times political coverage finds a lot of attention to the “horse race,” and a lot less to the issues.
lead_paragraph: ASKED what we prefer to eat for dinner, many of us will virtuously claim a diet of salads and whole grains, never mentioning lifeboat-size portions of penne alla vodka or our addiction to flourless chocolate cake. Asked what we serve the kids, we will nod dutifully to lean proteins and green vegetables, while double-cheese pizza and tater tots will go unmentioned.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Judge’s Message to the Xenophobes
abstract: A ruling in Indiana involving Syrian refugees is the first to address substantively the attempt by some governors to exploit the terrorism issue.
lead_paragraph: More than two dozen Republican governors were in a virtual stampede last fall to be first to bar the resettlement of federally approved Syrian refugees in their states. The shameless display of jingoism was prompted by the Paris shooting massacre in November and fears — wildly driven by the Republican presidential rivals — that terrorists could infiltrate the United States as refugees despite a resettlement process that is one of the strictest in the world.

headline: Chickens, Home to Roost
abstract: Mixed emotions on Donald Trump: why he’s wicked fun and just plain wicked at the same time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — HERE’S why the Trump campaign is wicked fun:

headline: Raise the Legal Age for Cigarette Sales to 21
abstract: Limiting young people’s access to tobacco would significantly improve public health.
lead_paragraph: California could soon raise the legal age for buying cigarettes and other tobacco products to 21, from 18. That change could help prevent many young people from becoming addicted and reduce premature deaths from lung cancer and other tobacco-related diseases.

headline: Hidden Gold in College Applications
abstract: To diversify campuses, smart admissions offices look closely at candidates.
lead_paragraph: IF the gatekeepers at Davidson College had judged the teenager by her ACT score, she probably wouldn’t have gotten in. It was 25 out of a possible 36, and more than three-quarters of the students at Davidson, a liberal-arts school in North Carolina with about 1,800 undergraduates and an acceptance rate of just over 20 percent, do better than that.

headline: An All-American Family Portrait, in White
abstract: In a single composition, Vincent Valdez has captured a selfie for 21st-century America.
lead_paragraph: I walked through the door of Vincent Valdez’s studio, in a renovated firehouse near downtown San Antonio, the other day. I stopped dead, my eyes widened, my mouth made a silent O.

headline: Two-Man Race for Top Rookie Should Be a Rout
abstract: The Knicks’ Kristaps Porzingis and the Timberwolves’ Karl-Anthony Towns are having fine seasons, but by some metrics Towns is the clear choice for rookie of the year.
lead_paragraph: One rookie-of-the-year contender was called a unicorn by Kevin Durant, has two nicknames that incorporate the word “god” and has single-handedly given hope to New York basketball fans. The other, known simply by his initials, has been honing his game far more quietly in Minnesota.

headline: Pencil Pushes Way Into Daytona Lore
abstract: The inaugural race in 1959 lacked the technology of today, and a narrow finish resulted in a dispute that has never been settled.
lead_paragraph: When two cars flashed across the finish line together at the Daytona 500 two weeks ago, modern camera technology captured the moment, leaving no doubt that Denny Hamlin had won by a nose.

headline: How Marco Rubio's Grandfather Was Nearly Deported
abstract: Excerpts from an immigration hearing in 1962 where Marco Rubio's grandfather, Pedro Garcia, discussed his expired green card and pleaded his case to stay in the U.S. as a permanent resident.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from an immigration hearing in 1962 where Marco Rubio's grandfather, Pedro Garcia, discussed his expired green card and pleaded his case to stay in the U.S. as a permanent resident.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Policies Might Shut the Door to People Like His Grandfather
abstract: Under the stricter screening Senator Marco Rubio now supports, his grandfather would most likely have been deported, depriving him of knowing the man he has called his mentor and closest boyhood friend.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Marco Rubio’s grandfather was a man without a country.

headline: Donald Trump Broke Debate Rule About Huddling With Staff, Rivals Say
abstract: After Donald J. Trump met with his campaign manager during a commercial break on Thursday night, a violation of debate rules, Fox News let his opponents do the same.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump flouted a rule set by Fox News during Thursday night’s debate by conversing with his campaign manager during a commercial break, according to two rival campaign officials.

abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio made the literary reference while speaking to reporters on Saturday in Traverse City, Mich.
lead_paragraph: — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, speaking to reporters on Saturday in Traverse City, Mich.

keywords: ['Population', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Youth', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: They may put pressure on the global economy, sow political unrest and spur mass migration.
lead_paragraph: AT no point in recorded history has our world been so demographically lopsided, with old people concentrated in rich countries and the young in not-so-rich countries.

lead_paragraph: Guillaume Henry presents his latest fall looks.

headline: Taliban Say They Won’t Attend Peace Talks, but Officials Aren’t Convinced
abstract: Afghan and Pakistani government officials expect negotiations to continue, but pushed the start date back to sometime later this month.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban said on Saturday that they would not participate in international peace talks, citing what they claimed were increased American airstrikes and Afghan government military operations.

headline: The Return of the D.I.Y. Abortion
abstract: Fewer clinics, more Google searches for alternative methods.
lead_paragraph: DURING oral arguments last week before the Supreme Court in Whole Woman’s Health v. Hellerstedt, Justice Elena Kagan noted that she was struck by the clear relationship between abortion restrictions in Texas and the closing of abortion clinics. “It’s almost like the perfect controlled experiment as to the effect of the law, isn’t it?” she said. “It’s like you put the law into effect, 12 clinics closed. You take the law out of effect, they reopen.”

headline: The Eviction Economy
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Poverty', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Poverty is not just a product of joblessness and low wages. It’s also a product of exploitation.
lead_paragraph: I FIRST met Larraine when we both lived in a trailer park on the far South Side of Milwaukee. Fifty-four, with silvering brown hair, Larraine loved mystery novels, “So You Think You Can Dance” and doting on her grandson. Even though she lived in a mobile home park with so many code violations that city inspectors called it an “environmental biohazard,” she kept a tidy trailer and used a hand steamer on the curtains. But Larraine spent more than 70 percent of her income on housing — just as one in four of all renting families who live below the poverty line do. After paying the rent, she was left with $5 a day.

headline: The Rise of Antipolitics
abstract: Readers discuss a David Brooks column about trends leading to Donald Trump’s candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a David Brooks column about trends leading to Donald Trump’s candidacy.

headline: Can Nicotine Be Good for You?
keywords: ['Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Nicotine', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: It was possible that my patient’s addiction was more helpful than harmful.
lead_paragraph: THERE was something odd about my new patient. She was elegantly dressed and self-possessed, and yet she was slowly, rhythmically chewing gum, something I rarely see in my psychiatry sessions. Was she trying to cover up anxiety about this first encounter, I wondered, or was she perhaps hoping to project a kind of cool, laid-back style?

headline: The Art of Failing Upward
abstract: Don’t believe the hype. Not everyone can fail successfully.
lead_paragraph: IN the start-up world, failure is in. No sooner has an entrepreneur failed at a venture in Silicon Valley than he takes to the web — frequently to blogging sites like Medium, which hosts a continuous stream of essays on the topic — or to the stage at industry conferences like FailCon to narrate the failure and the growth he experienced as a result.

headline: In Character
abstract: David J. Kahn offers us a special kind of tribute.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — April of this year marks the 400th anniversary of the death of William Shakespeare, and David J. Kahn is back with a puzzle about some of the Bard’s characters.

abstract: Voters turned out for primaries and caucuses in Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Kentucky and Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: Voters turned out for primaries and caucuses in Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Kentucky and Nebraska.

headline: South Korea Government Accused of Using Defamation Laws to Silence Critics
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Such laws carry penalties of up to seven years in prison — even for comments that are true, if they are deemed not to be in the public interest.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In late 2014, months after 304 people died in the sinking of a South Korean ferry, a leaflet began circulating with a scurrilous rumor about President Park Geun-hye: that she had failed to respond swiftly to the disaster that day because she was having a romantic encounter with a former aide.

headline: Maryland House Race a ‘Caldron of Power Couples and Washington, D.C., Politics’

lead_paragraph: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — What happens when a coveted House seat opens up a quick subway ride from the Capitol? A hugely expensive free-for-all, studded with celebrities (or what passes for celebrities in Washington) — with a whiff of dirty tricks.

headline: Crosswords Seemingly Copied From The New York Times Questioned
abstract: A database suggests that crosswords that have appeared in USA Today and Universal Crossword, a syndicated service, were plagiarized from New York Times puzzles.
lead_paragraph: In the world of crossword enthusiasts, a new puzzle presents a fresh challenge each day. But what if the puzzle was plagiarized from one that appeared years ago?

headline: Dr. Myron G. Schultz, Who Helped Identify AIDS Crisis, Dies at 81
abstract: Dr. Schultz, an infectious disease epidemiologist, detected a cluster of pneumonia cases that proved “the opening salvo for the AIDS epidemic,” he later recalled.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Myron G. Schultz, whose detection of a cluster of pneumonia cases in the early 1980s helped public health officials identify the AIDS epidemic, died on Feb. 19 in Atlanta. He was 81.

headline: Britain’s Exclusive Schools Try to Be a Little Less So
keywords: ['Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities']
abstract: Few institutions better symbolize social stratification and privilege in Britain than its top independent schools. Some of them are trying to remedy that.
lead_paragraph: RUGBY, England — Patrick Derham remembers the moment in October 1973 when, age 14, from a troubled home and planning to join the navy, he saw the course of his life changed, rather miraculously, for the better.

headline: Alumni of Britain’s Elite Schools
abstract: A sampling of some of the alumni — in common parlance, “old boys” and “old girls” (but mostly boys) — who have made names for themselves.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Graduates of Britain’s famous private schools are still overrepresented in the upper tiers of British life, from government to the arts.

headline: Donald Trump Again Alters Course on Torture
abstract: After saying he would stay within laws on tactics that are considered torture, Donald J. Trump told a rally that he would seek to “broaden” those laws.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said he would seek to “broaden” laws regarding the torture of terrorism suspects, a day after he said that as president he would be “bound by laws and treaties” that he would not order the military to violate.

headline: Forging a 3-Shot Lead, McIlroy Can See Augusta From Doral
abstract: McIlroy overcame a two-stroke lead by his playing partner Adam Scott and distanced himself from the field with a four-under-par 68 heading into Sunday.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Rory McIlroy has captured three of golf’s four major championships, and with his game kicking into another gear as he methodically took apart the Blue Monster course at Trump National Resort on Saturday, talk will soon shift to the major title he covets most.

headline: With Porzingis Out on Short Notice, Knicks Unite for a Victory

He called out for Derrick Williams, who could not hear his name over the music pumping through his headphones.

headline: Yale Finally Has an Ivy Title to Call Its Own

lead_paragraph: After Yale’s players had celebrated with bearhugs and a scrum at center court, the Ivy League’s executive director, Robin Harris, told them, “I want to congratulate you on being outright champion.”

headline: ‘Don’t Write Us Off,’ Bernie Sanders Says After Caucus Wins on Saturday
abstract: In a telephone interview from Detroit, Bernie Sanders acknowledged having work to do with minority voters but said wins in Nebraska and Kansas gave him momentum.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, energized by victories Saturday in Kansas and Nebraska, declared that people should not “write off” his campaign and that the caucus wins show that he has the momentum to gain the Democratic presidential nomination.

abstract: John Kasich released partial tax returns Saturday, leaving Donald J. Trump as the only Republican candidate who has not released any returns.
lead_paragraph: BIRCH RUN, Mich. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio released partial tax returns on Saturday showing that he and his wife earned more than $5 million from 2008 through 2014.

headline: It’s Discounted, but Is It a Deal? How List Prices Lost Their Meaning
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Discount Selling', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: When the same skillet costs $200 at a dozen web stores, the bargain isn’t so obvious to consumers, and scrutiny of this practice is growing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As traditional retailing falters, shutting stores and shedding workers, online merchants are reaping the rewards. People like the convenience of e-commerce, and they love the feeling that they are getting a deal.

headline: As Aid Floods Into Flint, a Fix Remains Far Off
abstract: Five months after state authorities announced that it was unsafe to drink unfiltered water, the water is still unsafe, with no promise of when it will be.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — For months, almost no one would listen to residents’ fears about their odd-looking drinking water. Now, it seems, everyone is listening — and sending truckloads of bottled water, water filters and baby wipes, and cash donations and television news crews that set up along Saginaw Street downtown.

headline: Lewis Hamilton at Vivienne Westwood
abstract: Lewis Hamilton, the reigning Formula One world champion, is becoming a seasoned fashion week circuit fixture.
lead_paragraph: The crowd that assembles at the Vivienne Westwood show during Paris Fashion Week is typically an eclectic bunch. So it was something of a surprise on Saturday afternoon to see Lewis Hamilton, the clean-cut reigning Formula One world champion, speeding through the drag queens, goth rockers and the more avant garde of the fashion elite on his way to his spot on the front row. But Mr. Hamilton, who became an official ambassador for British men’s fashion in June, is becoming a seasoned circuit fixture. In Paris for the weekend before the 2016 championship season kicksoff in Melbourne, Australia on March 20, he took five minutes to talkto Styles after the show was over.

headline: Philippines Will Impound Ship Linked to North Korea
abstract: A cargo vessel linked to North Korea was seized under United Nations sanctions intended to punish it for recent nuclear and rocket tests.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippines will become the first country to enforce tough new United Nations sanctions on North Korea when it begins formal procedures on Monday to impound a cargo vessel linked to the reclusive nation, a government spokesman said on Sunday.
