headline: The Family Footsteps We Follow
abstract: The glory of a close family is that you never lack for cheerleaders, enveloping you in support. The flip side is that you never lack for judges, weighing you down with expectations.
lead_paragraph: My father is one of three brothers who thrived in their respective professions, lifting themselves above the economic station of their Italian-immigrant parents. They’re archetypal American success stories. Buoyed by their good fortune, my siblings, my cousins and I racked up athletic trophies, won scholarships, gained admission to competitive schools, built enviable careers.

headline: Balenciaga’s New Balance
abstract: Demna Gvasalia’s debut collection was a highly controlled reboot of the brand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The most anticipated debut of Paris Fashion Week took place in a white box of a padded sound stage in the far reaches of the 15th Arrondissement as a cold wind blew in from the Seine. Guests trooped down a staircase covered in industrial gray carpet against the soundtrack of air raid sirens, to see Demna Gvasalia, the Georgian fox in the iconoclastic Vetements henhouse of fashion, unveil his Balenciaga. A hush of expectation settled over the crowd.

headline: 1966: Russia Says Venus Probes Failed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Moscow acknowledges that the Venus flights, though technological achievements, were scientific failures, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union acknowledged last night [March 5] that though the group flight of Venus-2 and Venus-3 was a great technological achievement, it was a scientific failure. Neither of the two spaceships — each weighing more than a ton — returned any information about the cloud-covered planet.

headline: A Food Order Ends in a Flurry of Fists, Hurled Sodas and Flying White Sauce
abstract: The police said a man in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, ordered a lamb gyro from a late-night food truck and then left the truck in shambles and attacked the cook.
lead_paragraph: What turned out to be the last order of the night — before an attack left a police officer with injuries, a suspect in custody and a Halal Paradise food truck in shambles — came from a man with $4 in his hand and a $5 lamb gyro on his brain.

abstract: Keeping buttermilk on hand and a delicious itinerary for the week ahead.

headline: Nancy Reagan, an Influential and Protective First Lady, Dies at 94
abstract: Mrs. Reagan was a fierce guardian of her husband’s image, sometimes at the expense of her own, and a trusted adviser to Ronald Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Reagan, the influential and stylish wife of the 40th president of the United States who unabashedly put Ronald Reagan at the center of her life but became a political figure in her own right, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: In Sunset Park, a Call for ‘Innovation’ Leads to Fears of Gentrification
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Gentrification', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: An advocacy group in the Brooklyn neighborhood worries that its hard-fought achievements will be usurped by newly interested developers.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the industrial waterfront of Sunset Park, on the western edge of Brooklyn, was an urban flyover country of sorts, as commuters heading to Manhattan or Staten Island zipped past on the elevated Gowanus Expressway, catching glimpses of auto repair shops, huge warehouses and billboards.

headline: Club for Growth to Spend $2 Million on Anti-Trump Ads

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 4: Well That Was Surprising
abstract: Just when this episode threatens to get bogged down in political strategy, Lucas Goodwin wades in.
lead_paragraph: Just when this episode threatens to get bogged down in political strategy — Claire and Frank’s continued quid pro quo, the execution of Operation Intimidate Russian President Petrov — Frank Underwood gets shot. The effect is a little like bringing a gun to a chess match. It immediately adds a sense of urgency and danger to this initially dull episode. The way the incident is initially telegraphed, with Claire put on lockdown by the Secret Service in a way that suggests Frank is again attempting to assert his dominance, works quite effectively. Narratively, though, the introduction of an assassination attempt also feels a little desperate and, potentially, like a bad omen for anyone waiting to witness the fall of Frank Underwood.

headline: Review: Carnegie Hall’s ‘West Side Story’ at the Knockdown Center
abstract: This production, a culmination of the Somewhere Project, a citywide exploration of that classic musical, mixes professional actors with high-school-aged apprentices.
lead_paragraph: The headlong energy of youth was on ample — no, make that spectacular — display over the weekend in Maspeth, Queens, at the Knockdown Center, a former factory where a wonderfully energized, energizing production of “West Side Story” was presented for just three performances, under the auspices of Carnegie Hall and the Weill Music Institute.

headline: A Call for College Students to Help Shape Their States’ Clean Power Plans
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'State Legislatures', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Youth']
abstract: Students across the country are preparing to meet state officials on April 4 to state their views on how to meet emissions targets set in the Obama administration’s Clean Power Plan.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, Eban Goodstein, the director of the Bard College Center for Environmental Policy, distributed an invitation to college students and faculty across the United States to participate in “Power Dialog,” an exciting effort to mesh learning and civic engagement around the nation’s efforts to curtail power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, the main human-generated gas contributing to global warming.*

headline: Republicans and Trade Wars
abstract: The pot calls the kettle protectionist.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure whether anyone but me cares about the Romney-Trump spat over trade policy; it’s much more interesting, for normal human beings anyway, to talk about the size of Trump’s, er, hands. For that matter, even Romney’s past relationship with Trump is notable mainly because racism and birtherism didn’t bother him back in the good old days. Still, the trade dispute is a revealing fight, on both sides.

headline: Nancy Reagan Dies
abstract: Mrs. Reagan died at 94 on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Reagan died at 94 on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles.

headline: A Big Night for Ted Cruz and Bernie Sanders
abstract: The two made strong showings in Saturday’s primary contests, while Marco Rubio faltered.
lead_paragraph: The most interesting developments in Saturday’s primary contests centered on Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Bernie Sanders, in that order.

headline: Billie Jean King Campaigns for Women's Soccer
abstract: The tennis trailblazer says that expanding the women's soccer game and increasing women's influence on the game should be a big part of the future of global soccer.
lead_paragraph: Forty-three years after its creation, the Women’s Tennis Association still bills itself as “the global leader in women’s professional sport.”

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Style
abstract: Some memorable looks from the former first lady.
lead_paragraph: Some memorable looks from the former first lady.

headline: In a Note, Bob Dylan Told Barbra Streisand, ‘You Are My Favorite Star’
abstract: In a statement, Ms. Streisand provided the back story to a 1978 card she wrote to Bob Dylan, which has surfaced in the Bob Dylan Archive.
lead_paragraph: Of the thousands of lyrics, tapes and correspondence in the Bob Dylan Archive, one of the more intriguing items is a handwritten card from Barbra Streisand, postmarked November 1978, in which she thanks Mr. Dylan for sending flowers and suggests that they make a record together.

headline: Candidates React to Nancy Reagan’s Death
abstract: The presidential candidates reacted quickly to the death Sunday of Nancy Reagan, who died at age 94.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidates reacted quickly to the death Sunday of Nancy Reagan, who died at age 94.

headline: Mets Revamp Sign System After Daniel Murphy’s Departure
abstract: Tim Teufel, the third-base coach, will use a new set of hand signals, partly from a concern that Murphy, a former Met, could decode the old signs for his new teammates.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At some point near the end of spring training, Tim Teufel, the Mets’ third-base coach, will gather the team for a meeting to demonstrate and decode the hand signs they will use this season. One sequence of signs may tell a batter to bunt, or tell a runner to steal, or tell them both that the hit-and-run is on. Teufel has about 10 signs, and he uses his own elaborate system to relay them, just to make the enterprise that much harder for an opponent to pick up on.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
abstract: The debate between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders in Flint, Mich., will be aired on CNN on Sunday night, and followed on other platforms.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the Democratic debate.

headline: ‘Zootopia’ Tops the Box Office
abstract: The Disney film about an all-animal city took in $73.7 million at North American theaters.
lead_paragraph: “Zootopia,” which delighted critics with its low-high approach to topics like racism (err, speciesism), drew moviegoer hooves in droves over the weekend. But Tina Fey’s war dramedy “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot” was a dud, taking in roughly 25 percent less than even the weakest of prerelease analyst projections.

headline: Akris: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Albert Kriemler presents his latest looks.
lead_paragraph: Albert Kriemler presents his latest looks.

headline: Louis C.K. Condemns Trump in Email
abstract: The comedian compared the Republican front-runner Donald J. Trump to Hitler in an email blast to his fans.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Louis C.K. condemned the Republican presidential front-runner, Donald J. Trump, in an email to his fans on Saturday. “The guy is Hitler. And by that I mean that we are being Germany in the 30s,” he writes. “Hitler was just some hilarious and refreshing dude with a weird comb over who would say anything at all.”

headline: Nikolaus Harnoncourt, Conductor and Early-Music Specialist, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Harnoncourt, who was also a cellist, founded the period-instrument ensemble Concentus Musicus Wien and worked regularly with many of Europe’s major orchestras.
lead_paragraph: Nikolaus Harnoncourt, a pioneering and influential early-music specialist and respected mainstream maestro, died on Saturday in the village of St. Georgen im Attergau, east of Salzburg, Austria. He was 86.

headline: BET Honors Pay Tribute to Patti LaBelle, Lee Daniels, Eric Holder and Others
abstract: The annual event will be broadcast on Black Entertainment Television on March 14.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Black excellence,” the running theme of the BET Honors, was on full display Saturday evening at the Warner Theater here, where the network filmed its annual homage to African-American luminaries in art, music, theater, technology and business.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Haider Ackermann
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Velvet is proving to be a big trend for fall. Haider Ackermann put his best foot forward with these high-heeled boots in a palette of jewel-tone colors.

headline: Joe Biden Jokingly Suggests Ted Cruz for Supreme Court Pick
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: “Before you know it, you’ll have eight vacancies,” the vice president said at the annual Gridiron Dinner.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had some tongue-in-cheek advice for President Obama on Saturday about whom he should nominate to fill the Supreme Court vacancy that has preoccupied the White House and incited an election-year fight.

headline: Not Everyone Says Headgear Is Right Fit for Girls’ Lacrosse
keywords: ['Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Lacrosse', 'Women and Girls', 'Helmets', 'Sports Injuries', 'Interscholastic Athletics']
abstract: Regulated headgear will soon be available for girls’ teams, but some say wearing it will alter the sport.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most popular, fastest-growing girls’ sports is nearing a move that might seem obvious to outsiders but has instead engendered rigorous debate: offering players protective headgear.

headline: Nuance Was Never the Plan
abstract: The Veterans Room at the Park Avenue Armory, restored to all its Gilded Age swagger, opens on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Veterans Room at the Park Avenue Armory, restored to all its Gilded Age swagger, opens on Monday.

headline: Law Graduate Gets Her Day in Court, Suing Law School
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Law Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Legal Profession', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: For the first time, a law school will stand trial on charges that it inflated the employment data for its graduates to lure prospective students.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade has passed since an aspiring young lawyer in California, Anna Alaburda, graduated in the top tier of her class, passed the state bar exam and set out to use the law degree she had spent about $150,000 to acquire.

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Endorses John Kasich
abstract: “He was an action hero when he went to Washington,” Mr. Schwarzenegger said of Mr. Kasich’s time in Congress.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Arnold Schwarzenegger endorsed Gov. John Kasich on Sunday as Mr. Kasich rallied voters in his home state of Ohio, whose primary has emerged as a critical moment in the Republican race.

headline: Review: ‘Don Pasquale’ Returns to the Met, With a Bravura Aria and More
abstract: It briefly seemed as though Javier Camarena might sing an encore in this revival, which stars the compelling Ambrogio Maestri as a crotchety uncle.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago at the Metropolitan Opera, the Mexican tenor Javier Camarena absolutely nailed a bravura aria in Rossini’s “La Cenerentola,” setting off an ovation that would not stop until he repeated its flashy final section — a rare occurrence of an aria encore at the Met.

headline: Review: Elisa Monte Dance Moves On, but Aesthetic Doesn’t Stray
abstract: Elisa Monte stepped down after 35 years at the helm of her company. Tiffany Rea-Fisher is the new artistic director.
lead_paragraph: After 35 years at the helm of her company, the choreographer Elisa Monte, who began her career as a dancer with Agnes de Mille and Martha Graham, is stepping down. Her troupe’s season at Aaron Davis Hall, which closed on Saturday, warmly ushered in a new artistic director, Tiffany Rea-Fisher, who joined Elisa Monte Dance in 2004.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Riccardo Tisci is back in Paris to present his fall designs.
lead_paragraph: Riccardo Tisci is back in Paris to present his fall designs.

headline: The Gilded Age Glows Again at the Park Avenue Armory’s Veterans Room
abstract: The opulence of the room was concealed beneath bad repairs, inadequate lighting and a patina of cigar smoke. It reopens on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In his story “The Secret Room,” the French novelist Alain Robbe-Grillet describes an interior so ornate as to defy description, whose very dimensions are shadowy but “whose considerable space must in reality extend all around, right and left, as it does toward the faraway browns and blues among the columns standing in line, in every direction.”

headline: Marco Rubio Wins Puerto Rico Primary; Bernie Sanders Takes Maine Caucuses
abstract: Senator Rubio’s much-needed victory came a day after he was shut out of four Republican nominating contests.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida won the Puerto Rico primary on Sunday, giving him a much-needed victory after a string of losses that threatened to push the Republican presidential nomination further out of his reach.

headline: Egypt Says Muslim Brotherhood, Backed by Hamas, Killed Top Prosecutor
abstract: The assassination of Hisham Barakat in June prompted Cairo to introduce a sweeping antiterrorism law that expanded government powers and restricted civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt said Sunday that members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood, trained by the Palestinian militant group Hamas, carried out the bombing in Cairo that killed Egypt’s top prosecutor last summer.

headline: Michigan Primary Puts Donald Trump’s Rust Belt Strategy to a Test
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Mr. Trump, who attracts blue-collar voters by promising a 35 percent tariff, has pledged to be the Republican presidential candidate who brings industrial states back into the Republican fold.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — Neil Mortensen remembers how neighbors lost factory jobs in this suburb north of Detroit, and then, inexorably and sadly, their homes.

headline: Review: Adam Cohen’s ‘Imbeciles’, on the Supreme Court and Justice Not for All
abstract: The court’s 1927 decision in Buck v. Bell upheld a statute that enabled the State of Virginia to sterilize “mental defectives,” amid a mania for eugenics in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Of all the disgraceful rulings the Supreme Court has made in its 227-year history — and the lowlight reel is fairly lengthy — the decision in Buck v. Bell still stands out as one of the ugliest. The case may not be as well known as, for instance, Dred Scott v. Sandford, which denied African-Americans citizenship. But in just five paragraphs, the court upheld a statute that enabled the State of Virginia to sterilize “mental defectives” — specifically one Carrie Buck, a young resident of the Virginia Colony for Epileptics and Feeble-Minded.

headline: For a Young Donald J. Trump, Broadway Held Sway
abstract: Mr. Trump helped finance “Paris Is Out!,” which began performances on Broadway in 1970 and was a flop whose closing brought an end to his career as a Broadway producer.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway producer David Black was sitting in his office, above the Palace Theater, when a young Donald J. Trump walked in, unannounced, and asked him to lunch.

headline: Snowboarding, Once a High-Flying Sport, Crashes to Earth
keywords: ['Snowboarding', 'X Games', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Olympic Games', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: Its elite athletes are paying the price of waning participation, falling equipment sales and warmer weather as sponsors slash their rosters.
lead_paragraph: As the Swiss snowboarder Iouri Podladtchikov twisted, flipped and spun above the halfpipe at X Games Oslo last week on his way to a silver medal, the bottom of his board — one of the more valuable pieces of advertising real estate in the sport — displayed no corporate logo. Instead, it was adorned with an artistic design he had created for a college class assignment.

headline: Review: In ‘Damien,’ a Photojournalist Resists His More Devilish Side
abstract: In this new series on A&E, Bradley James plays a role made famous in the “Omen” horror-movie franchise.
lead_paragraph: Damien Thorn, the title character of A&E’s new horror series “Damien,” is subject to a particularly onerous punishment. Throughout the early episodes, whenever he has flashbacks to his childhood, he sees clips from “The Omen.” Talk about hell on earth!

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Style
abstract: Some memorable looks from the former First Lady Nancy Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Some memorable looks from the former First Lady Nancy Reagan.

headline: Kendrick Lamar and Lil Wayne Each Sidestep the Traditional Album Cycle
abstract: Mr. Lamar, on “untitled unmastered.,” shows a more casual side than on “To Pimp a Butterfly,” while Lil Wayne, on 2 Chainz’s “Collegrove,” gets his groove back.
lead_paragraph: Back in the mid-late 2000s, when Lil Wayne used to refer to himself as the “greatest rapper alive,” music flowed forth from him like a geyser. Each year brought several dozen new songs, a sign of an artist obsessed with sound, and also with his own freedom to create.

headline: Emitt Rhodes, a New Album Out, Emerges From His Slumber
abstract: Mr. Rhodes’s singing career stalled after a promising start. Now fans in the music industry are backing him as he releases his first album since 1973.
lead_paragraph: When the Bangles formed in the 1980s, the band sought out an ace melodist to produce its music: Emitt Rhodes.

headline: G.O.P. Goes Astray on Guantánamo. So Does Obama.
abstract: Many claims on both sides of the debate over the future of the prison in Cuba collapse under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even by the standards of an epically polarized Washington, the political talk about President Obama’s effort to close the Guantá namo Bay prison is starkly divorced from facts. On both sides of the debate, many claims collapse under scrutiny.

headline: Review: ‘Hungry’ Portrays a Mourning Clan in Election Year 2016
abstract: In Richard Nelson’s play at the Public Theater, the characters’ bereavement is laced with a sense that the world as they know it is coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: As befits a work with the title “Hungry,” food is prepared — ardently and aromatically — in the wonderful new play written and directed by Richard Nelson, which opened on Friday night at the Public Theater. Yet it is unlikely that the ratatouille and apple crumble on offer will satisfy the appetites of the five women and one man assembled in a snug kitchen in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

headline: Back in The Day
abstract: Damon Gulczynski reminds us of a fresher era.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The main challenge I faced while solving this nicely symmetrical Monday puzzle was swallowing the emotions that surfaced, a tasty mix of fondness and revulsion for the cute little decade sandwiched between the Awesome ’80s and the terrifying era we live in now. I’m Generation X, though. Eating our feelings is one of our specialties.

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Love of Fashion Recalled at Givenchy Show
abstract: She is remembered as a champion of American designers of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Apart from Jackie Kennedy, Michelle Obama and I guess Dolley Madison, Mrs. Reagan was the only president’s wife who had an interest in American fashion,” said Valerie Steele, the director of the Museum at FIT, on Sunday night at the Givenchy show here, “and was actually good at it.”

headline: N.J. Transit Plans Park-and-Ride Locations
abstract: In the event of a strike, the agency said it would add five park-and-ride locations throughout New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In the event of a strike, the agency said it would add five park-and-ride locations throughout New Jersey.

headline: Robert Del Tufo, Former New Jersey Attorney General, Dies at 82
abstract: As a United States attorney for New Jersey, Mr. Del Tufo challenged the federal Abscam investigation, arguing that the F.B.I. had entrapped a senator.
lead_paragraph: Robert J. Del Tufo, a former New Jersey attorney general and federal prosecutor who offered a lonely dissent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s corruption investigation known as Abscam, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 7
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Greta Varlese Transforms at Givenchy
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.

headline: Europe’s Antitrust Enforcer on Google, Apple and the Year Ahead
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In an interview, Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s competition commissioner, discusses the issues underpinning her current investigations and whether she unfairly targets American companies.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Margrethe Vestager is already having a busy 2016.

headline: Queens Man in Custody After Stabbings and Burn Attacks, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Assaults']
abstract: James Patrick Dillon is accused of slashing a woman in the face, fatally stabbing a man and badly burning another in the Astoria neighborhood. Two officers were also injured.
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old man slashed a woman in the face on Sunday morning in Queens, the police said, before fatally stabbing a shopkeeper and setting another man on fire several hours later at a nearby liquor store, leading to a wild manhunt that ended with officers shooting the suspect as he threw a chemical at them.

headline: Leaving the E.U. Would Hurt Britain’s Economy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Trade with member nations and the rest of the world would become more difficult, as new agreements and regulations would be needed.
lead_paragraph: Would Britain be better off economically outside the European Union? The answer is most likely no, which is why Britons need to weigh the evidence carefully when they go to the polls in June to vote on leaving the E.U.

headline: Iraq Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens at Checkpoint Near Babylonian Ruins
abstract: More than 100 people were injured when a driver detonated a fuel truck in the city of Hilla.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At least 33 people were killed and 115 wounded in the Iraqi city of Hilla on Sunday when a fuel truck driven by a suicide bomber exploded at a checkpoint not far from the ruins of ancient Babylon.

headline: Toronto’s Counterattack Breaks Down the Red Bulls
abstract: The Red Bulls reached the conference finals last year with a high-press offense, but Toronto slowed things down and left with a shutout.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Before a disheartening home opener Sunday, Red Bulls Coach Jesse Marsch had spoken about a possible Plan B for this season, if opponents adjusted too effectively to his club’s high-press tactics.

headline: New York Legislators Plan to Introduce Measure on Carried Interest Tax
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Taxation', 'Hedge Funds', 'Law and Legislation', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: The measure is part of a state-level drive by progressive groups to change how carried interest, a percentage of the profits made by funds, is taxed.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of progressive groups is starting a state-level campaign to close the so-called carried interest loophole, which allows fund managers to pay a substantially reduced federal tax rate on much of their income.

headline: Nancy Reagan Dies at 94
abstract: Mrs. Reagan was a trusted adviser to her husband, President Ronald Reagan, and a fierce guardian of his image. She championed efforts to fight drug abuse and Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Reagan was a trusted adviser to her husband, President Ronald Reagan, and a fierce guardian of his image. She championed efforts to fight drug abuse and Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Migrants Remain Stranded in Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: More than 10,000 migrants have been waiting in Idomeni, Greece, to cross the border into Macedonia.
lead_paragraph: More than 10,000 migrants have been waiting in Idomeni, Greece, to cross the border into Macedonia.

headline: NATO to Expand Patrols in Aegean Sea to Stop Human Traffickers
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Smuggling', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The day before a European conference on the migrant crisis, NATO announced it would strengthen its presence in the territorial waters of Turkey and Greece.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The day before a European conference designed to persuade Turkey to curb the uncontrolled flow of migrants making perilous journeys across the Aegean Sea, NATO announced on Sunday that it would expand its maritime efforts to stop the smugglers who make many of those journeys possible.

headline: Democratic Debate in Flint, Mich.: Analysis
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders debated in Flint, Mich. Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport provided analysis in real time.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders faced off in Flint, Mich., in a state where voters head to the polls on Tuesday that will prove a crucial test for both candidates.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the Democratic debate.

headline: New Proposal to Divide Jerusalem Unites People Against It
abstract: A plan promoted by a group of liberal Israeli Jews would fence off most of the Palestinian neighborhoods and transfer responsibility for their residents to the Palestinian Authority.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A new plan on how to divide Jerusalem’s Jewish and Arab neighborhoods has had the peculiar distinction of uniting people against it.

headline: As Alaska Warms, the Iditarod Adapts
keywords: ['Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)', 'Dog Sledding', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Seasons and Months', 'Weather', 'Winter (Season)']
abstract: The dogs, the mushers and the sleds were ready for the beginning of the annual race from Anchorage to Nome, but there was one thing missing: the snow.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — The Iditarod dog-sled race has gripped the imagination here for a long time, partly because it captures the idea, cherished by Alaskans, that a true-north wildness lies just over the horizon, and anyone getting there must first face a harsh gantlet of ice and cold.

headline: White House and Cuba Maneuver Over Obama’s Visit
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: An elaborate behind-the-scenes effort aims to ensure that the president’s historic visit yields both powerful symbolism and concrete policy progress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Major League Baseball completed a deal with the Cuban government last week to hold an exhibition game in Havana during President Obama’s planned visit this month, White House officials quietly rejoiced that a pivotal piece of their plan had fallen into place after weeks of intensive negotiations.

headline: Health Law Insurance Plans to be Rated by Network Size
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Under new rules to be published on Tuesday, insurers will still be allowed to sell health plans with narrow networks of providers, but consumers will know in advance what they are getting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, responding to consumer complaints, says it will begin rating health insurance plans based on how many doctors and hospitals they include in their networks.

headline: Tech Companies, New and Old, Clamor to Entice Cloud Computing Experts
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Employee Fringe Benefits']
abstract: As some tech sectors show signs of slowing, cloud services have created remarkable demand for highly educated engineers and mathematicians. And they are being compensated very well.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon Web Services, a globe-spanning cloud computing network that is part of the online retailing giant Amazon, has rapidly become one of the most powerful forces in technology. It has also become a target for poachers.

headline: Tripoli, a Tense and Listless City With Gunmen and a Well-Stocked Hugo Boss Outlet
abstract: As conflict rages elsewhere in Libya, a precarious order holds in the capital, as heavily armed militias and politicians, nominally allied, vie for control.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Cracking open the giant church door, the Nigerian watchman cast a wary eye over the deserted street.

headline: Women Try to Make Italy’s Shoe-Shining as Chic as Its Shoes
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Two women in Italy have gained notice for moving into the unfashionable trade of shining shoes, once exclusively a men’s job, and even making it hip.
lead_paragraph: VERONA, Italy — In a country famed for its fine leather products and fashion sense, shining shoes was never a particularly exalted profession.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Returns to Mound for Yankees After Off-Season Surgery
abstract: Tanaka pitched two innings in his spring training debut for the Yankees, who also saw some promising signs from Rob Refsnyder, auditioning for a reserve infielder role.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — On Sunday, for the first time since the wild-card playoff game against the Houston Astros, Masahiro Tanaka pitched in a game.

headline: Heroin Epidemic Increasingly Seeps Into Public View
keywords: ['Heroin', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As heroin use soars, people are routinely being found unconscious in public places like the bathrooms of fast-food restaurants, libraries and churches.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In Philadelphia last spring, a man riding a city bus at rush hour injected heroin into his hand, in full view of other passengers, including one who captured the scene on video.

headline: Suspension of Chase Utley Is Rescinded, Reports Say
abstract: The Dodgers’ Chase Utley broke the leg of Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada while trying to break up a double play in a National League division series last season, leading to a rule change addressing so-called rolling slides.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Los Angeles Dodgers’ Chase Utley, who was barred for two games after his aggressive slide in a playoff game last year broke the leg of Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada, had his suspension lifted by Major League Baseball, according to multiple news media reports.

headline: Wary of Digital Guests, Brooklyn House Tour Closes Its Doors
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Photography', 'Privacy', 'Social Media']
abstract: After three decades of providing glimpses into impressive homes, a Brooklyn Heights group canceled its house tour amid concerns about online exposure.
lead_paragraph: Strolling past the brownstones of Brooklyn Heights is an exercise in envy suppression. What homey perfection hides behind each cornice and gable, bay window and ornate lintel? How much more resplendent are the lives inside those buildings than in our own apartments? For 31 years the Brooklyn Heights Association has provided some answers by offering a tour of private residences in the neighborhood that, for one day, allowed the curious up the stoops and into the living rooms that are often every bit as palatial as imagined.

headline: Earnings From Urban Outfitters and Square, and an E.C.B. Meeting
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The clothing retailer and the mobile payments company are expected to report earnings, and the European Central Bank’s Governing Council is set to discuss stimulus measures.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to look for this week:

headline: U.S. Conferred With Iran Before Iraq Invasion, Book Says
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Books and Literature', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Securing a promise that the Iranian military would not fire at United States warplanes that strayed into Iranian airspace, a Bush-era official writes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior American officials held confidential talks with Iran about Iraq’s future in advance of the United States-led invasion to topple Saddam Hussein, and secured a promise that the Iranian military would not fire at United States warplanes that strayed into Iranian airspace, according to a new book by a ranking Bush administration official.

headline: Being Paid to Play Basketball, Pat Connaughton Is Dreaming of Diamonds
abstract: Connaughton, a rookie with the Portland Trail Blazers, also wants to pitch in the major leagues, and one baseball official said Connaughton “has the talent to be a top-of-the-rotation guy.”
lead_paragraph: Downtime for N.B.A. players is a study in relaxation techniques. After a practice or before a game, many indulge in video games, a movie, a book or the ever-popular nap. A day off might include all of the above.

headline: 36小时玩转巴黎左岸
abstract: 从拉丁区的小巷子到圣日耳曼德佩区的宽敞大道，巴黎左岸的经典魅力在咖啡馆、博物馆和商店里一览无遗。
lead_paragraph: 从拉丁区的小巷子到圣日耳曼德佩区的宽敞大道，巴黎左岸的经典魅力在咖啡馆、博物馆和商店里一览无遗。

headline: Obama Pays Tribute to Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the ‘Peanuts’ Gang
abstract: President Obama wrote the foreword for the penultimate volume of “The Complete Peanuts,” a series published over 12 years.
lead_paragraph: “Like millions of Americans, I grew up with ‘Peanuts.’ But I never outgrew it.”

headline: Trial of Veteran Accused of Trying to Join ISIS May Hinge on Unsent Letter
abstract: A former Air Force mechanic’s trial in Brooklyn on terrorism charges has centered on a drafted letter in which he pledged to defend the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The most conclusive piece of evidence against Tairod Pugh, a 48-year old U.S. Air Force veteran accused of trying to join the Islamic State, is the letter he addressed to his wife. In it, Mr. Pugh, wrote of his plan to become a martyr.

headline: To Reinvigorate Sales, Mondelez Reimagines the Snack
abstract: With a new line of crackers made from unconventional ingredients, Mondelez is going after a larger slice of the $6.2 billion snack business.
lead_paragraph: Mondelez International, the large snacks and confections business that used to be part of Kraft, is introducing its first new product line in years.

headline: As Stephen Curry and Kobe Bryant Converge, Basketball Universe Tilts on Its Side
abstract: Curry and Bryant, at opposite ends of the spectrum in their brilliant careers, were among those who witnessed a rarity on Sunday: powerful Golden State falling to lowly Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The nature of the spectacle on Sunday afternoon at Staples Center changed drastically about halfway through the second quarter of the game.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 7: What Makes a Bad Partnership?
abstract: Sunday’s episode attempted to puzzle out the mysteries of the show’s power couples.
lead_paragraph: Chuck and Wendy retire to the bedroom after a long night. It’s the first time they’ve seen each other since earlier that morning, and they’re dutifully exchanging “What’s up?” questions. Chuck casually lies about how he spent his evening; Wendy casually lies about how she spent her evening. At this point in their marriage, the lies are as routine as slipping on their pajamas — so routine that it isn’t immediately obvious to the viewer that they’re lying to each other at all. There’s no hitch in their voices or calculated hitch in their strides. They’re keeping secrets from each other— betraying each other, in fact — but there’s no indication this is an uncommon night. This is their marriage.

headline: Philosophy’s True Home
abstract: It has influenced Einstein’s physics, Turing’s computation and human flourishing, all from its place in the university.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all heard the argument that philosophy is isolated, an “ivory tower” discipline cut off from virtually every other progress-making pursuit of knowledge, including math and the sciences, as well as from the actual concerns of daily life. The reasons given for this are many. In a widely read essay in this series, “When Philosophy Lost Its Way,” Robert Frodeman and Adam Briggle claim that it was philosophy’s institutionalization in the university in the late 19th century that separated it from the study of humanity and nature, now the province of social and natural sciences.

headline: ‘The Ancient Minstrel,’ by Jim Harrison
abstract: Jim Harrison’s obsessions include rural roughneck mores, the writing life and male lust.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Anne Porter argued (or at least asserted) that “novella” is “a slack, boneless, affected word that we do not need to describe anything”; her stern yet vague taxonomy recognized only “short stories, long stories, short novels, novels.” But writers who work in that Venn diagrammatic long story/short novel zone can find reassurance, if not absolute definitional clarity, in this term for something that’s neither a malnourished novel nor an overstuffed story: a genre of its own, distinguished less by length, perhaps, than by the scope or complexity of the narrative. (I’d call Melville’s 14,000-plus-word “Bartleby” a novella — he called it a “tale” — and Joyce’s “The Dead,” some 1,500 words longer, a story.) Certainly Jim Harrison isn’t sniffy about the word — in fact, Jim Harrison isn’t sniffy about much — and since his first collection of novellas, the 1979 “Legends of the Fall,” he has done as much as any living writer to demonstrate the validity and vitality of the form.

lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Sixteen people were killed Monday morning, including two police officers, when a bomber detonated his suicide vest after shooting his way into a court compound about 20 miles north of Peshawar, a senior police official said.

headline: Tunisian Clash Spreads Fear That Libyan War Is Spilling Over
abstract: At least 54 people were killed on Monday as militants stormed a Tunisian town near the border.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Fear engulfed Tunisia on Monday that Islamic State mayhem was spilling over from neighboring Libya, as dozens of militants stormed a Tunisian town near the border, assaulting police and military posts in what the president called an unprecedented attack.

headline: Ex-Times Reporter Remembers Interview With Nancy Reagan, ‘Peewee Powerhouse’
abstract: In an interview aboard Air Force One in 1981, Mrs. Reagan was eager to make it clear that she helped President Ronald Reagan renovate their ranch in California, including wrestling with dead trees.
lead_paragraph: The most memorable interview I did with Nancy and Ronald Reagan was just before Thanksgiving 1981. We sat down aboard Air Force One on the way to California to talk about their routine at the ranch.

headline: Morning Agenda: Court to Hear Law Graduate’s Suit Against Her School
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Interest Rates', 'Law Schools', 'Legal Profession', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Proponent of Energy Transfer-Williams Deal Is Said to Oppose It | The Upside-Down World of Negative Rates
lead_paragraph: COURT TO HEAR LAW GRADUATE’S SUIT AGAINST HER SCHOOL | Five years after suing the Thomas Jefferson School of Law in San Diego over the accuracy of its employment data, Anna Alaburda, one of the school’s former students, will get her day in court,  Elizabeth Olson writes in DealBook. This is not the first time a disgruntled student has sued a law school over publicly listed alumni employment rates, claiming that law schools were counting part-time waitress and other full-time jobs outside the legal field as employment. Those cases often were dismissed because judges contended that law school students should have known that a job as a lawyer was not guaranteed. Only Ms. Alaburda has been successful in getting her case to a trial, thanks to California’s strong consumer protection laws.

headline: Stella McCartney: Fall 2016 RTW

lead_paragraph: Ms. McCartney presents the latest looks for her eco-conscious brand.

headline: The Always Hungry Teenage Boy
abstract: Why are young men told to eat less meat? It really means they need to eat their vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the adolescent male appetite. Those always hungry growing boys who eat standing up, drain the quart containers of milk or juice, and are fully capable of finishing off as an after-school snack the whole lasagna or pot of stew or cold roast beef that was supposed to serve as dinner for the family. I have come home to this myself: the teenager who greets his parents in the evening with an empty refrigerator, a sink full of dirty dishes, and the hopeful question, “What’s for dinner?”

headline: ScienceTake | Surfing Beetles
abstract: The lily pad beetle moves across the surface of the water in a kind of self-powered windsurfing.

headline: We’re Losing the Race Against Antibiotic Resistance, but There’s Also Reason for Hope
abstract: Preventing infections through vaccination or public health measures is the outcome to aim for.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, the top three causes of death were infectious diseases. More than half of all people dying in the United States died because of germs. Today, they account for a few percent of deaths at most.

headline: Senators Cite Nancy Reagan’s ‘Just Say No’ Efforts in Call to Complete Bipartisan Antidrug Bill
abstract: With the deepening acrimony over the Supreme Court vacancy continuing to threaten legislation to combat the nation’s widening opioid epidemic, two senators on Sunday invoked the memory of Nancy Reagan.
lead_paragraph: The Senate returns on Monday to resume work on legislation to combat the nation’s growing opioid epidemic, but there are continued signs that the bipartisan bill is getting caught in the increasing nastiness surrounding the Supreme Court fight.

headline: 1916: Enver Pasha Badly Wounded
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Enver Pasha is wounded in an attempt on his life in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Delayed despatches from Athens state that Enver Pasha, the leader of the Young Turks and the Ottoman Minister of War, has been seriously wounded in an attempt upon his life, organized by the friends of the late Prince Yussuf Izzeddin, the Ottoman Heir Apparent.

lead_paragraph: GAIOLE IN CHIANTI, Italy — Fences are rising. There is talk of a brutal and destructive insurgency, invasions and a slaughter that could include hundreds of thousands in the years ahead.

lead_paragraph: Even as much of the tech industry is shifting into a less frothy period, one thing hasn’t changed: the fierce competition for top technical talent.

headline: Counting Characters in Twitter
abstract: There is a reason Twitter allows 20 fewer characters in a post than a standard SMS text message.
lead_paragraph: Q. SMS text messages have a character limit of 160 characters, so why does Twitter allow only 140 characters in a tweet?

keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Efforts by Myanmar’s democracy leader to negotiate her way to the top post this year have failed, associates of hers confirmed on Monday.
lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Efforts by Myanmar’s democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to negotiate her way to the presidency this year have failed, associates of hers confirmed on Monday, highlighting the challenges her party faces as it prepares to take power on April 1.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel to Host 2016 Emmys in September
abstract: The awards, recognizing television’s best, will be broadcast on ABC on Sept. 18.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 Emmy Awards will be hosted this year by ABC’s Jimmy Kimmel on Sept. 18, the late night host announced on Twitter.

headline: Ringleader of British Jewelry Theft Is in Failing Health, Lawyer Says
abstract: Brian Reader, 77, who had been hospitalized after suffering a stroke in prison, was described as a “very sick and old man” at a sentencing hearing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The white-haired ringleader behind an audacious $20 million jewelry theft at a safe deposit company in central London is in critical condition, a court heard at a sentencing on Monday.

headline: Year After Detentions, Chinese Feminists Mark Setbacks and Progress
abstract: China’s first law against domestic violence took effect almost a year after five women were detained, causing an international uproar.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Dressed as Rosie the Riveter, the icon of American women’s empowerment during World War II, Li Tingting’s raised fist in a photograph posted on Facebook on Monday signaled defiance — one year after the authorities detained her and four other Chinese feminists on the eve of International Women’s Day, causing an international uproar.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Director Michael Engler on the Emotional Final Episode
abstract: The longtime TV director talks about the final episode and the last day of shooting.
lead_paragraph: Over six seasons, 14 directors have worked behind the scenes of “Downton Abbey,” which ended its run on Sunday. As with many series, a house visual style was established early on, with specific guidelines on what Michael Engler — who directed the series finale — described as “tonal sensibilities.” Mr. Engler, who has worked on “Sex and the City,” “The West Wing” “Six Feet Under” and “30 Rock,” spoke about working on the final season in an interview in May at Highclere Castle, where much of “Downton Abbey” was shot, then more recently on the phone. These are edited excerpts from the conversations.

headline: Ty Cobb Baseball Card Trove Reignites Dreams of Shoebox Jackpots
abstract: A find of rare memorabilia from the early 20th century excited a collectors’ industry suffering from an oversupply of cheap trading cards.
lead_paragraph: The unattended bag found while cleaning out a great-grandparent’s home looked like trash, and it was nearly discarded. But someone decided to root through the pile of postcards and paper products, and was rewarded by finding seven baseball cards from 1909 to 1911 featuring the Hall of Fame player Ty Cobb.

The 94-year-old New Yorker is the subject of “Iris in Paris,” a fashion exhibition and pop-up shop at Le Bon Marché Rive Gauche department store that celebrates her famous, forthright style. And rightly so.

abstract: After 15 years of performing as his alter ego Hunx, Seth Bogart has released a debut album under his own name.
lead_paragraph: “I’m bored of just being in a band and touring,” says Seth Bogart, who, after 15 years on stage as slimy-shiny gay pop-punk act Hunx, recently released his debut album under his own name. “I realized that the best place to present my next album would be inside a world I made for it.”

Trump claimed in September that hedge fund managers were “getting away with murder” by avoiding taxes, while Senator Bernie Sanders argues that “it is time to break up the largest financial institutions in the country.”

lead_paragraph: DENVER — Donald J. Trump’s harsh campaign language against Mexican immigrants has helped him win a substantial delegate lead in the Republican primaries, but it is also mobilizing a different set of likely voters — six in the family of Hortensia Villegas alone.

When all else fails, travel! In your mind, if not in actuality. Surf the globe (or the Internet) for inspiration and see what comes up.

lead_paragraph: Staten Island is not a borough known for its skyline, but along the eastern shore, a jagged silhouette now caps the horizon of New Dorp Beach: up, down, up, down, down, down, up — empty.

headline: Review: In ‘Rising,’ One Dancer’s Interpretation of Four Solos by Four Choreographers
abstract: The program, at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, showcased Aakash Odedra’s background in Indian dance, and his departures from it.
lead_paragraph: The British dancer Aakash Odedra first presented “Rising,” a suite of four solos by four choreographers (including himself), in 2011. Though he had shown parts of it in New York, the full production did not arrive here until Friday, when it came to the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts for one night.

headline: Studies Offer Hope for Malnourished Children
abstract: Research on mice indicates that the gut bacteria of healthy children can fix that of starving children, and that breast milk can be improved.
lead_paragraph: Starving children have gut bacterial colonies that are “immature” compared with those of healthy children, and their mothers’ breast milk may lack sugars that can nourish the right bacteria, researchers have found. Those children may not grow even when they are fed nutritious food.

headline: The Costumes That Obscure Doctor and Patient
abstract: The traditional doctor’s white coat and patient’s gown can work against good health care, and against better mutual understanding.
lead_paragraph: Is it time for new costumes in the long-running improv act featuring doctor and patient? The white coat and the cotton gown are tattered, under continual assault for their practical deficiencies and outmoded symbolism.

headline: Ali Baba’s Cave
abstract: Ali Baba has discovered a cave full of gold and diamonds. How can he maximize the value of what he carries out?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Kenneth Kong, a TV personality in Singapore. Kenneth had a moment of global fame about a year ago after sharing the Cheryl’s Birthday problem, a simple challenge that went wildly viral (covered in Numberplay here). The problem generated quite a storm on Twitter, including suggestions for more puzzles. I asked Kenneth if he had a favorite, and he pointed to a suggestion by Igor Diev, who introduces his puzzle this way: “Frankly speaking, the task of #cherylsbirthday you’ve showed the world is rather easy and it’s a shame to be unable to solve it. Let me give you a task that Russian 14-year-old students solve. That’s what should really blow your mind.”

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']

keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Wireless Communications', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: The penalty, $1.35 million, was small, but the action drew wide attention from the telecom industry as a glimpse of the F.C.C.’s ambitions into privacy regulation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said Monday that it had reached a settlement with Verizon Wireless for its use of hidden tracking technology known as “supercookies,” which were used for targeted advertising without customers’ permission.

headline: Ten Celebrated Chefs’ Contributions to a Brand-New Kitchen
abstract: Chef Timothy Hollingsworth solicited pots and pans for his restaurant, Otium — and received vessels from Thomas Keller, René Redzepi, David Chang and more.
lead_paragraph: When chef Timothy Hollingsworth was conceptualizing Otium, the new restaurant that is part of the Broad Museum in downtown Los Angeles, the former chef de cuisine of French Laundry made a request of colleagues and friends who have been influential in his career — “in order to create a sense of soul and bring my past into Otium,” as he puts it. He sent out a letter before the restaurant opened last fall: “I would like you to send in any pots or pans, a serving vessel of sorts, to Otium for display and possibly use,” it read.

headline: N.R.A. Praises Bernie Sanders for Debate Comments on Gunmakers
abstract: The approval for Bernie Sanders from the National Rifle Association, after his latest presidential debate against Hillary Clinton, puts the Vermont senator in an awkward position of having the backing of a group that many Democrats loathe.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders received praise for his views on gun control on Monday from a group that he would probably like some distance from: the National Rifle Association.

headline: Veterans Take On Donald Trump in 2 New Ads
abstract: In one of a pair of ads by the nonprofit American Future Fund, a veteran says Mr. Trump “would not have survived a P.O.W. experience.”

headline: Raymond Tomlinson, Who Put the @ Sign in Email, Is Dead at 74
abstract: The computer programmer chose the “at” sign to separate a user name from a destination address in his new messaging program.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Tomlinson, the computer programmer who in 1971 invented email as it is known today and in the process transformed the “at” sign — @ — from a sparely used price symbol to a permanent fixture in the lives of millions of computer users around the world, died on Saturday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 74.

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Example
abstract: A reader writes that her death “is a reminder of what unconditional love, unwavering support and faith are all about.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Screenwriter Turned Songwriter Flips His Own Script
abstract: Ben Abraham tried film school and hospital work before finding his voice as a singer.
lead_paragraph: The story of Ben Abraham’s burgeoning music career sounds like something out of a movie. The singer-songwriter, 30, was born in Melbourne to an Indonesian father and an Australian mother with a thinly veiled family secret: They had been Indonesian pop stars. “I knew they were singers, but they’ve always been a bit cagey about it,” says Abraham, whose debut album, “Sirens,” was released in the U.S. last week. It wasn’t until he was watching TV on a family trip to Indonesia in 2004, however, when a contestant on the show “Indonesian Idol” sang one of his parents’ songs that he learned that just how famous his parents had been. “I was like, ‘Hang on a second — how big were you guys?’” Despite growing up in what he describes as “a very musical household,” Abraham eschewed the family business as an 18-year-old in favor of five years of film school, turning to music only after a professor (“a scary, kind of crotchety stalwart of the Australian writing scene”) offered a particularly stinging critique of his work. “He went through my script scene by scene, and at the end he sort of looked at me and went, ‘It’s just not very interesting, is it?’”

headline: Marco Rubio’s Campaign Echoes ’07 Tax Revolt: A Big Plan With Little Payoff
abstract: In his biggest gamble as Florida House speaker, Marco Rubio tried to end residential property taxes, displaying tactical weaknesses but a disregard for entrenched systems.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It began with the audacity and promise of a rising political star. Marco Rubio, a young state lawmaker, was going to do what nobody had tried for decades: rewrite the bedeviling tax code in Florida and elevate his stature in the process.

headline: Michigan Poll Shows John Kasich Gaining Ground on Donald Trump

headline: Emory Acquires W.E.B. DuBois’s Copy of Rare Early Abolitionist Appeal
abstract: Published in Boston in 1829, “Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World” was the first sustained attack on slavery and racism written by a black person in the United States.
lead_paragraph: David Walker’s “Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World,” published in Boston in 1829, was the first sustained attack on slavery and racism written by a black person in the United States. It’s also a notably rare item today, with only a half-dozen early copies, and two first editions, listed in library catalogs.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 5: The Ghosts of Frank’s Past
abstract: Frank Underwood is sidelined, in an episode full of the past.
lead_paragraph: This episode of “House of Cards” opens with a slow pan into an M.R.I. machine, one where perpendicular red laser lines make President Frank Underwood appear to be caught in the cross hairs. While Frank clings to life in what may be the only hospital in America where fluorescent lights have been replaced with a moody blue glow, the information Lucas Goodwin was so desperate to share has become public knowledge. Lucas’s suicide note has been seized as evidence, and to get ahead of a potential leak, Claire Underwood acknowledges and debunks the “outrageous” claims it makes about the president, including that he murdered both Congressman Peter Russo and the Slugline reporter Zoe Barnes. In more ways than one, this episode evokes thoughts of Metro stations.

headline: Unplanned Pregnancies Hit Lowest Level in 30 Years
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Of 6.1 million pregnancies for those 15 to 44 in the United States in 2011, only 2.8 million were unintended, representing the lowest level in three decades.
lead_paragraph: The rate of unintended pregnancy in the United States has declined to its lowest level in the last three decades.

headline: This Dessert Fits In on St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: Also, pandan-glazed doughnuts filled with a coconut jam; a smoky tequila; Jonathan Gold, the star Los Angeles restaurant critic; and more.
lead_paragraph: A creamy matcha custard pie that’s about as verdant as you can get for St. Patrick’s Day is the work of Melissa and Emily Elsen, the owners of Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Brooklyn. The matcha, or powdered green tea, is from Ippodo Tea in Murray Hill and is culinary grade so it’s less bitter. To make the tart, heat the oven to 325 degrees. Whisk together ⅔ cup granulated sugar, 1½ tablespoons flour, ¼ teaspoon salt and 2 teaspoons matcha powder. Stir in ½ cup melted unsalted butter, then beat in 3 eggs and 1 egg yolk one at a time. Beat a couple of minutes more, stir in 2 cups heavy cream and ½ teaspoon vanilla, and strain into a par-baked 10-inch pie shell. Bake about 50 minutes, rotating it 180 degrees after 35 minutes, until the pie is set around the edges but still wobbly in the center. Let cool, then adorn with whipped cream: Matcha Custard Pie, $40 at Four & Twenty Blackbirds, 439 Third Avenue (Eighth Street), Brooklyn, 718-499-2917, birdsblack.com.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Loses Finra Arbitration Over Firing
abstract: The bank botched the firing of a former executive so badly that a Finra arbitration panel ordered it to pay $2.05 million in damages.
lead_paragraph: When a Wall Street executive is fired, it is usually done quietly.

headline: U.S. Strikes in Somalia Kill 150 Shabab Fighters
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The strikes hit a camp where officials said fighters with the Shabab militant group were preparing an attack against American troops and their allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American aircraft on Saturday struck a training camp in Somalia belonging to the Islamist militant group the Shabab, the Pentagon said, killing about 150 fighters who were assembled for what American officials believe was a graduation ceremony and prelude to an imminent attack against American troops and their allies in East Africa.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Turkey surprised European Union leaders on Monday by hitting them with a new set of demands if it is to help stem the flow of refugees from Syria and Iraq and other migrants seeking to enter Europe.

headline: The 2016 Primary Campaign Has a Cold. Pass the Tissues.
abstract: Marco Rubio sounded hoarse. Ted Cruz took a break. The long slog is lowering the volume, even the volume of insults, on the campaign trail.

lead_paragraph: Peyton Manning’s retirement leaves a hole in the Denver Broncos’ roster. It also leaves one in the N.F.L., among players who match talent on the field with TV-ready appeal.

keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: While pundits differed on who scored what points in Sunday’s Democratic debate, all agree that the discourse was substantive and policy-focused, a refreshing change from Republican exchanges, which lately have focused more on insults about “hand” size than about ideas.

headline: Retrial in Etan Patz Murder Case Is Delayed

lead_paragraph: The retrial of a New Jersey man accused of strangling Etan Patz was postponed for six months on Monday because the lead defense lawyer has injured his back.

headline: Penguins Make a Bid for the Playoffs by Bouncing Back Again and Again

headline: Fasting Diets Are Gaining Acceptance
abstract: The health benefits of skipping meals are growing more apparent, though critics argue that the idea is still impractical for most people.
lead_paragraph: Mark Mattson, a neuroscientist at the National Institute on Aging in Maryland, has not had breakfast in 35 years. Most days he practices a form of fasting — skipping lunch, taking a midafternoon run, and then eating all of his daily calories (about 2,000) in a six-hour window starting in the afternoon.

keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Regulators asked well operators in a large patch of the state to reduce by 40 percent the oil and gas wastes they are injecting deep into the earth.
lead_paragraph: Facing a six-year barrage of increasingly large earthquakes, Oklahoma regulators are effectively ordering the state’s powerful oil-and-gas industry to substantially cut back the underground disposal of industry wastes that have caused the tremors across the state.

headline: Hulk Hogan Takes Stand in His Sex-Tape Lawsuit Against Gawker
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The trial is the latest prominent legal battle highlighting the somewhat murky line between the right to privacy and the right to free speech.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Taking the stand as the first witness in his $100 million invasion-of-privacy lawsuit against the website Gawker, the former wrestling champion Hulk Hogan told a jury on Monday that he had been “completely humiliated” by the public release of a video that showed him having sex with his now-former best friend’s wife.

headline: Miles of Moroccan Tiles in the Marais
abstract: Caitlin and Samuel Dowe-Sandes of Popham Design have filled a new Paris space with hand-painted cement squares in shades of blue — and more.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that top French designers and architects had to leave the country for an up-close look at Popham Design’s Moroccan-made tiles. Now, Caitlin and Samuel Dowe-Sandes, Americans who have lived in Marrakesh for 10 years, have opened a storefront in the Marais. Even with most surfaces covered in cement squares, hand-painted in various patterns and shades of blue, the 375-square-foot space looks and feels more like a chic living room than a shop. ‘‘This way we can show tiles the way we want people to live with them,’’ Caitlin says. An enormous brass table and bronze lighting fixtures that Samuel designed for the space are also for sale, prototypes for a new line.

headline: Wall Street Bonuses Fell in 2015, and 2016 Isn’t Looking Rosy
abstract: The average bonus fell 9 percent last year, and recent cutbacks prompted New York State to cut its forecast for this year’s bonus pool.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses are down for the second straight year, and recent market volatility and cutbacks suggest that 2016 is shaping up to be a difficult year, according to the New York State comptroller.

headline: Review: ‘Burning Down the House,’ a Novel Wallowing in Money and Misery
abstract: Jane Mendelsohn, who wrote “I Was Amelia Earhart,” returns with an overstuffed melodrama.
lead_paragraph: The references in and influences behind Jane Mendelsohn’s preposterous new novel, “Burning Down the House,” are beyond eclectic: “The Great Gatsby,” “The Sound and the Fury,” “East of Eden,” “Buddenbrooks,” “Atonement,” the plays of Aeschylus, the movies “Sabrina” and “Heaven Can Wait,” the TV series “Dallas” and “Dynasty,” and countless daytime soaps. It’s no surprise that the resulting novel is a melodramatic mess: suspenseful, even moving at times, but atrociously overwritten and overstuffed with implausible plot twists, stereotyped characters and scenes oozing sweat and tears.

lead_paragraph: After the outbreak of World War I in 1914, coverage of fashion in the Herald became noticeably absent for several months. But by the autumn of 1915, Parisian life had returned to relative normality and reports of the latest trends reappeared in the pages. Below are excerpts on the success and influence of Maison Chanel in the spring of 1916:

headline: Screening for Alzheimer’s Gene Tests the Desire to Know
abstract: Two brothers in Denver came to different conclusions, one deciding it wasn’t worth it, the other choosing to find out whether he had the gene.
lead_paragraph: Marty and Matt Reiswig, two brothers in Denver, knew that Alzheimer’s disease ran in their family, but neither of them understood why. Then a cousin, Gary Reiswig, whom they barely knew, wrote a book about their family, “The Thousand Mile Stare.”

headline: Thanat Khoman, Thai Statesman and Co-Founder of Asian Alliance, Dies at 101
abstract: Mr. Thanat helped the United States gain military bases in Thailand during the Vietnam War and helped start the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thanat Khoman, a Thai diplomat and statesman who paved the way for United States military bases in Thailand during the Vietnam War and helped found the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, died on Thursday in Bangkok. He was 101.

headline: Yayoi Kusama Debuts Vivid, Whimsical Work in Hawaii
abstract: “Footprints of Life,” a 15-piece installation of blob sculptures, is a prelude to the artist’s new commission for next year’s inaugural Honolulu Biennial.
lead_paragraph: In anticipation of next spring’s Honolulu Biennial — which will feature local and Indo-Pacific contemporary art — the Honolulu Biennial Foundation will present Yayoi Kusama’s first Hawaiian exhibition starting this week. The Tokyo-based artist’s “Footprints of Life,” a 15-piece installation of giant blob sculptures — previously exhibited in the 2011 Aichi Triennial and Taiwan’s 2011 Taoyan Land Art Festival — can be interpreted as islands, or as a nod to Kahuli tree snails, endemic only to Oahu, which were nearly picked into extinction to decorate leis in the mid-20th century. According to Isabella Ellaheh Hughes, a co-founder of the foundation, Kusama’s piece “particularly resonates with Hawaii, because innately, this is a place where we are most attuned to our relationship with our delicate ecosystem.”

headline: Dow-DuPont Deal Seems Impermeable to a Bid by BASF
abstract: Tax benefits make the planned union of Dow and DuPont seem ironclad were BASF, the German chemical giant, to make a counterbid.
lead_paragraph: DuPont’s planned union with Dow Chemical, both American companies, looks like a tough nut for interlopers to crack. The German chemical giant BASF is considering a counterbid for DuPont, its rival, according to Bloomberg. But tax benefits alone make the American conglomerates’ merger and expected breakup pretty close to ironclad.

headline: At Giambattista Valli, Eyes Get a Silver Streak
abstract: For fall/winter 2016, models got a metallic accent.
lead_paragraph: Giambattista Valli’s fall/winter 2016 collection, which showed today in Paris, featured predominantly black and white pieces punctuated by flashes of silver. Taking a cue from the clothes, the makeup artist Val Garland created two variations of a silver liner: one across the lash line, the other under the brow, by mixing MAC’s Pigment powder in Silver with MAC’s Reflect Pearl glitter and swiping it on in a semi-cat-eye shape. She finished by dotting the corner of the eyes with a creamy highlighter. “It’s an embellished eye,” she said.

headline: Retail Health Clinics Result in Higher Spending, Survey Finds
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugstores', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Researchers said the frequency of use outweighed the savings when people went to a cheaper clinic instead of to the doctor or emergency room.
lead_paragraph: Insurers and employers are eager to have workers explore new ways of getting care, like visiting a clinic at a drugstore when they have a sore throat. The care they receive not only is more convenient, but also costs much less than a visit to the emergency room or a doctor’s office.

headline: Mexico’s President Says Donald Trump Sounds Like Hitler and Mussolini
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto vowed that Mexico would never pay for Mr. Trump’s proposed border wall and warned that the Republican candidate’s language was reminiscent of Hitler and Mussolini.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s repeated threats against Mexico drew a forceful response on Monday from President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico, who vowed that his country would never pay for the Republican candidate’s much-ballyhooed border wall and warned that his language was reminiscent of Hitler and Mussolini.

lead_paragraph: It’s “Game of Thrones” with less scheming and fantasy. It’s “Spartacus” with half the gratuitous violence and considerably less sex. It’s “The Bible” without much Bible.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)']

lead_paragraph: When the European Central Bank meets on Thursday, policymakers are expected to push its deposit rate deeper into negative territory, to minus 0.4 percent. The stated aim is to head off deflation.

Trump.

headline: Donald Trump Laces Into Japan With a Trade Tirade From the ’80s

abstract: In an attack reminiscent of another era, Mr. Trump has chastised Japan as a country where “we are getting absolutely crushed on trade.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Donald J. Trump has often aimed his raucous brand of disparagement at foreign countries during his presidential run. There is China, “ripping off” the United States on trade and stealing its jobs. And Mexico, closing its eyes to a flood of migrants and drugs across the border.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’: Lessons Learned After Six Seasons
abstract: This show, with its six seasons and immense popularity, has taught us about our television viewing habits.
lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” has poured its last cup of tea, strapped its last traveling case to the car, dispatched its last awkward reaction shot to a mildly witty bon mot. The lesson of Sunday’s series finale was that every complicated melodrama requires a multiplicity of happy endings, no matter how hurriedly achieved. The lesson of the show’s longevity and immense popularity was that even in the age of Very Serious television, our strongest appetite is for sheer escapism, and once we’re hooked we don’t really notice if what we’re being served becomes progressively less savory.

headline: Strike by West Bank Teachers Gains Momentum, Challenging Government
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Strikes', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Palestinians', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: A dispute that began with demands for a pay raise has turned into a broad challenge to the Palestinian Authority.
lead_paragraph: BEITIN, West Bank — Children are watching television all night and lolling in pajamas until late afternoon. Parents are scraping together savings to hire tutors. Day care centers have extended their hours. Laith Zeidan, 17, is spending his days working in his uncle’s carwash because, as he put it, “my dad said I had to stay off the streets.”

headline: An Expansive Show of Undersung (Don’t Call them ‘Outsider’) Artists
abstract: Now at the Kunsthal in Rotterdam, the Museum of Everything is a traveling installation of work by self-taught, undiscovered and unintentional creators.
lead_paragraph: When crates and boxes holding more than 1,000 artworks landed on the doorstep of the Kunsthal in Rotterdam, museum director Emily Ansenk was worried that they might not all fit inside. She soon figured out all she could do was trust James Brett, the mastermind behind the Museum of Everything, a traveling installation with art by self-taught, undiscovered and unintentional creators.

headline: Wells Fargo Charged With Fraud in Video Game Start-Up Case
abstract: Wells Fargo underwrote a $75 million bond deal for 38 Studios, a video game company led by Curt Schilling that went bankrupt, leaving taxpayers on the hook for the debt.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has been accused of fraud over its role in underwriting a $75 million municipal bond deal for a video game company in Rhode Island that eventually went bankrupt, leaving taxpayers on the hook for the debt.

headline: Review: Andreas Staier on the Harpsichord, Coaxing Gravity and Gloom
abstract: Mr. Staier’s concert at the Frick Collection included Froberger’s “Plainte Faite à Londres Pour Passer la Mélancolie” and two memorials.
lead_paragraph: Andreas Staier’s harpsichord recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday evening was easy to respect but sometimes hard to love. Mr. Staier is an excellent and thoughtful performer on early keyboard instruments — the fortepiano as well as the harpsichord — but somewhat dour in mien, and his program here was almost unrelievedly gloomy.

headline: Review: Tonia Ko’s ‘Strange Sounds and Explosions Worldwide’
abstract: The New York Youth Symphony, which champions new music, presented a premiere of the composer’s work at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: A listener might assume that a new symphony called “Strange Sounds and Explosions Worldwide” would depict perilous global situations. But the title of Tonia Ko’s new symphony alludes to fireworks and other joyful events, as well as natural ones like erupting volcanoes.
