headline: ‘Alice Isn’t Dead,’ a Dark New Fictional Podcast in a Booming Market
abstract: The show, from the team behind the popular “Welcome to Night Vale,” promises a novelistic story in a serialized form, with dark plot turns.
lead_paragraph: The new fictional podcast “Alice Isn’t Dead” starts with a declaration from the narrator: “This is not a story. It’s a road trip.” The aim, she continues, homing in on a mostly universal aspiration for both, is to “end up somewhere else” and to travel “a long way from where we started.”

headline: Mac ‘Ransomware’ Attack Exposes Vulnerability of Apple Users
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Mac OS (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The infected software affected a relatively small number of people over the weekend, but it pierces an image of safety long enjoyed by fans of the brand.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, security experts say, a dangerous form of software called “ransomware” has successfully targeted a Mac operating system, piercing an image of safety that Apple customers had long enjoyed.

headline: U.S. Restricts Sales to ZTE, Saying It Breached Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Chinese phone maker will be blocked from buying American technology without a special license for violating sanctions against Iran.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — ZTE is one of China’s few truly international electronics firms. Yet American companies will now need special permission to sell to it.

headline: Mitch McConnell Bets That Impasse on Court Now Helps G.O.P. Later
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: To the anti-abortion and pro-gun movements, there is no bigger issue than control of the Supreme Court. The Senate majority leader may be gambling on that.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell has long antagonized Democrats with his tactics. Now he just has them perplexed, wondering why he would unilaterally block a Supreme Court nominee and potentially put vulnerable Republicans at risk with control of the Senate at stake in November.

headline: The Cosby Case: Where Things Stand
abstract: A criminal case against Bill Cosby is on hold pending a review by a higher court. He’s also embroiled in five civil suits.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby had once been due in a Pennsylvania court on Tuesday for a hearing in the only criminal case that has been brought out of the many sexual assault accusations leveled at the once-beloved entertainer. A judicial ruling last week, though, suspended those proceedings, perhaps for many months. Below are questions and answers to help untangle the complexities of that case and five civil suits in which Mr. Cosby is also embroiled.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 6: Is Pollyhop a Sillier Name Than Slugline?
abstract: Claire gets tough with Petrov, and Frank’s back in business.
lead_paragraph: Frank Underwood is back in business. After a successful liver transplant, he recovers, leaves the hospital and, by episode’s end, reclaims his job from Donald Blythe.

headline: Erin Andrews Awarded $55 Million in Lawsuit Over Nude Video at Hotel
abstract: The Fox sportscaster had sued for $75 million for negligence after a stalker secretly filmed her naked through a peephole at the Nashville Marriott.
lead_paragraph: A jury awarded the Fox sportscaster Erin Andrews $55 million in her lawsuit against a Nashville hotel and a stalker after she was secretly videotaped naked several times in 2008, according to reports.

headline: Rumors Fill the Air at Hedi Slimane’s Saint Laurent Show
abstract: The possibility of his impending departure and an intimate crowd create one of fashion week’s hottest tickets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The most urgent gossip this Paris Fashion Week has centered on Hedi Slimane, the press-averse designer of Saint Laurent, whom the rumor mill has decreed is imminently leaving Saint Laurent.

headline: For Chris Christie and Donald Trump, Ties Go Back Years
abstract: Starting with a dinner in 2002 that Mr. Trump’s sister set up, he and the New Jersey governor established a relationship that led to an endorsement.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie says he first met Donald J. Trump 14 years ago as a courtesy to Judge Maryanne Trump Barry, after she told him, “My little brother really wants to meet you.”

headline: Group Backing Ted Cruz Accuses Marco Rubio of ‘Cronyism’
abstract: The advertising in Florida attacks Mr. Rubio’s support for subsidizing sugar growers in his state, aiming to drive him from the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to drive Senator Marco Rubio from the presidential race, a “super PAC” supporting Senator Ted Cruz is spending heavily against Mr. Rubio in Florida, his home state. The five new ads that the group, Keep the Promise I, have released attack Mr. Rubio’s attendance record in the Senate, his stand on immigration, his tax plan and his relationship with Florida’s sugar producers.

headline: Diplo and Major Lazer Headline in Havana
abstract: The first concert in Cuba by a major U.S. pop act since the reinstatement of diplomatic relations between the countries drew an estimated 450,000 people.
lead_paragraph: The first concert in Cuba by a major U.S. pop act since the reinstatement of diplomatic relations between the countries drew an estimated 450,000 people.

headline: Diplo and Major Lazer Bring Their Brand of Music to Cuba
abstract: A crowd estimated at almost a half-million roared to amped-up electronic dance music at the José Martí Anti-Imperialist Platform in Havana.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — “I know you’ve been waiting a long time for a party like this,” the D.J. and producer Diplo called out to a sea of pulsating young Cubans here on Sunday evening, during a free concert by his Caribbean-influenced electronic group, Major Lazer.

headline: Julie Kent to Lead Washington Ballet
abstract: Ms. Kent, a beloved ballerina who danced her final performance with American Ballet Theater last June, will succeed Septime Webre as artistic director in July.
lead_paragraph: Julie Kent, a beloved ballerina who danced her final performance with American Ballet Theater last June after spending nearly three decades with the company, will be the next artistic director of the Washington Ballet, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Justice Dept. Appeals Ruling in Apple iPhone Case in Brooklyn
abstract: The Justice Department said a federal judge had erred in not ordering Apple to unlock a drug dealer’s iPhone, in a case being watched by lawyers and experts on both sides of the encryption debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the latest volley in its high-profile fight with Apple, the Justice Department said on Monday that a federal judge in Brooklyn had erred last week in refusing to order the company to unlock a drug dealer’s iPhone.

headline: Nancy Reagan, the Happiest First Lady
abstract: Many ambitious women have filled the role of presidential spouse, and found it limiting. Not Nancy Reagan.
lead_paragraph: FOR more than two hours, Nancy Reagan sat behind the artist Everett Raymond Kinstler as he painted her husband’s portrait in his New York City studio shortly after the Reagans left the White House. Mr. Kinstler, who had done several portraits of President Gerald Ford, was unnerved by Mrs. Reagan’s intensity. “It was terribly distracting,” he recalled. When he asked if she would wait in the living room, Mrs. Reagan replied, unmoved, “No, I really would like to stay here while you work.”

headline: Towns Run by Polygamist Sect Violated Rights of Others, Jury Finds
keywords: ['Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Towns in Arizona and Utah run by the sect controlled by Warren Jeffs discriminated against outsiders in housing permits, policing and utility hookups.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Two towns run by the polygamist sect controlled by Warren Jeffs routinely violated the civil rights of nonbelievers by discriminating against them in housing permits, policing and utilities hookups, a Federal District Court jury here found Monday.

headline: Democracy’s Disintegration in Turkey
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The takeover of the country’s largest newspaper is the latest of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s increasingly authoritarian moves.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt about why the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan seized the newspaper Zaman last week, consider this: Within 48 hours after the takeover, the paper began publishing pro-Erdogan propaganda.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Elderly', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to pay $130,000 in legal fees and damages to 10 older or disabled residents who said they were unfairly removed from the Rent Freeze Program after their spouses or parents died.

headline: Jacob deGrom Grumbles, and It Fails to Resonate With Mets
abstract: DeGrom, a star pitcher, has no recourse to increase his $607,000 salary. But baseball economics remains a delicate and potentially divisive issue for the Mets.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Brown hair flowing from beneath his blue-and-orange cap, Jacob deGrom moved not a strand when asked about that little old contract deal.

headline: Return of Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist and Rick Nash Draws Near
abstract: Lundqvist, a goaltender dealing with neck spasms, and Nash, a wing who has been out with a bone bruise in his leg since Jan. 22, said they were making progress.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist and Rick Nash will miss Tuesday’s game at Buffalo, but they appear closer to returning to the Rangers’ lineup.

headline: Oil Prices Perk Up, Suggesting a Rebound Has Taken Hold
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Production']
abstract: The price of crude is up more than 40 percent since last month. But the stockpiles that drove prices down remain at 80-year highs.
lead_paragraph: After a prolonged slide that took oil prices within sight of the $20-a-barrel threshold last month, sentiment in commodity markets seems to have turned, raising the question of whether oil prices have finally bottomed out.

headline: Elizabeth Garrett, First Female President of Cornell, Dies at 52
abstract: Ms. Garrett, who started the position last summer, announced a month ago that she had learned she had colon cancer.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Garrett, a lawyer and scholar who was the first woman to be president of Cornell University, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan, only eight months after starting the post. She was 52.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Hillary Clinton, Not Himself, in North Carolina
abstract: Mr. Clinton, whose policies were criticized by Bernie Sanders in a debate on Sunday, kept the focus largely on his wife as he campaigned for her ahead of next week’s primary.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — If Bill Clinton felt raked over the coals during the Democratic debate on Sunday night, he didn’t seem sore about it on his three-city swing through North Carolina on Monday.

headline: Lurid Suit Over Hate Mail Embroils Isaac Perlmutter, Marvel Chief
abstract: Isaac Perlmutter, the enigmatic head of the Marvel Entertainment unit of Disney, is accused of orchestrating a slander campaign that called a neighbor a murderer and child molester.

headline: Astoria Residents Say Suspect in Fatal Spree Was a Troubled Local Fixture
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The suspect, James Patrick Dillon, 23, congregated with a group of men who were viewed more as lost than as a menace. Some who knew him said he had been deteriorating.
lead_paragraph: They are as much a fixture on the streets of Astoria, Queens, as the souvlaki shops and markets selling lamb and feta straight from Greece: a group of about a dozen men, of varying ages, who share the same bleary eyes and frequently unsteady gaits when their indulgences — in marijuana and liquor — catch up to them. Well known to shop owners and local residents, the men stand out from the increasingly hip and well-heeled new arrivals to the neighborhood — ruffians, but benign, viewed more as lost than as a menace.

headline: Mitt Romney Records Phone Message for Marco Rubio’s Campaign
abstract: Mr. Romney has recorded get-out-the-vote calls for Mr. Rubio’s presidential campaign that are being sent to voters in the four states voting Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Offering Senator Marco Rubio of Florida a much-needed boost, if not an outright endorsement, Mitt Romney has recorded get-out-the-vote calls for Mr. Rubio’s presidential campaign that are being sent to voters in the four states voting on Tuesday.

headline: In This Crowd, It’s O.K. to Stare
abstract: Giant printed heads seem to pop up everywhere: Nascar tracks, beauty pageants, even political rallies. But few places have embraced them quite like college basketball.
lead_paragraph: With college basketball’s postseason in full swing, casual television viewers soon will see famous faces popping up at games across the country: Kim Kardashian. Donald Trump. Miss Universe. Not their actual faces, but rather their attention-grabbing likenesses: oversized cutouts of their heads, waved around by fans looking to draw the eye of both opposing shooters and network cameras.

headline: Netanyahu Calls Off Obama Visit, and Fingers Point
abstract: The Israeli prime minister abruptly canceled a trip to Washington that was to include a visit with President Obama, prompting speculation that a rift between two leaders lingers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to the strained relationship between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, even a single missed meeting is cause for grievance and accusations.

headline: Peyton Manning: Epitome of a Golden Age Goes Out on Top
abstract: The retiring Peyton Manning is distinguished by his prolific passing, his diligent preparation and the way he managed to maintain a pristine image.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Peyton Manning is the pillar of an enduring, golden era of professional quarterbacks, which will end over the next few years when we see the retirements of Tom Brady, Drew Brees and Philip Rivers.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The night after a testy Democratic debate, Senator Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton had the chance to confront another adversary: Fox News.

headline: Review: ‘The Royale’ Harks Back to the Fighter Jack Johnson
abstract: This Marco Ramirez play, which takes place in the early 20th century, is set amid the sport of boxing and recreates the racism of the day.
lead_paragraph: Jay Jackson has found the zone, a place where all he hears is the upbeat percussion of his own thoughts and the drumming of flesh hitting flesh. A declaration of satisfaction purrs out of this perfectly proportioned giant, delivered both to himself and to the young opponent who has surprised him by giving almost as good as he gets: “We’re making music, boy.”

headline: Warm Fuzzies
abstract: David Steinberg conceals some cuteness.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This was a straightforward circled-answer puzzle with a good number of long clues for early in the week – potentially slow going for a new solver, but the corners used crossword standards like ASSUAGE, THANE and UPROOT that you will encounter again. Odd little semi-words like AHH, URL and SLR contributed to the challenge here.

headline: Several More Ex-Guantánamo Detainees Suspected of Militancy, Report Says
abstract: Of the 144 detainees transferred under the Obama administration, seven are known to have engaged in militant acts, the report said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence analysts now believe that an additional former Guantánamo Bay detainee has engaged in terrorist activity after his release, while seven more have been added to a roster of those who might be causing problems, according to data disclosed on Monday.

headline: F.C.C. Fine-Tunes Plan to Subsidize Internet Access

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — People who do not have regular access to the Internet can fall behind in school, at work and in other everyday tasks. The Federal Communications Commission is close to what it hopes will be a solution to address that gap: $9.25 a month.

lead_paragraph: A loose-knit band of young vagabonds seeks peace, love and community going state to state hitchhiking and hopping freight trains.

headline: Methane Has Never Looked So Beautiful
abstract: What looks like a page ripped from an alien’s dream journal, is actually a frozen lake containing methane bubbles trapped in icy cells in Alberta, Canada.
lead_paragraph: What looks like a page ripped from an alien’s dream journal is actually a frozen lake containing methane bubbles trapped in icy cells in Alberta, Canada. In January and February when the lake has frozen over and abrasive winter winds have polished the ice, visitors can peer through a window into one of Earth’s most mesmerizing natural prisons.

headline: Hopping Freight Trains With the Dirty Kids
abstract: A loose-knit band of young vagabonds seeks peace, love and community going state to state hitchhiking and hopping freight trains.
lead_paragraph: If you combine the tinge of loneliness in Jimmie Rodgers’s “Waiting for a Train” with the outcast mentality of Bob Dylan’s “I Am a Lonesome Hobo,” you might understand the millennial hippiedom of a group called Dirty Kids. They’re not a band, but a self-proclaimed set of countercultural vagabonds: a new wave of nomadic, homeless youth traveling state to state hitchhiking, sleeping in cars and hopping on freight trains.

headline: It’s Not Too Late!
abstract: Republicans still have time to reject Donald Trump, avoid Ted Cruz and pick a nominee who allows them to maintain their standards.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2 a.m. The bar is closing. Republicans have had a series of strong and nasty Trump cocktails. Suddenly Ted Cruz is beginning to look kind of attractive. At least he’s sort of predictable, and he doesn’t talk about his sexual organs in presidential debates!

headline: Reducing Drug Waste Could Save Billions of Dollars
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Cancer', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: The distribution of lifesaving cancer drugs needs to be done in a more efficient way.
lead_paragraph: Given how expensive many cancer drugs are, it is alarming that the government, private insurers and patients spend an estimated $3 billion a year on cancer medicines that are thrown out because they are packaged in unnecessarily large quantities. The Food and Drug Administration ought to figure out ways to reduce this costly waste.

headline: The Presidential Plot Thickens
abstract: Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins on the rise of Cruz, the fall of Rubio, the persistence of Trump and the triumph of Don Rickles.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. What a week, right? No huge surprises on Super Tuesday, as Trump increased his plurality with wins in a majority of states. Thursday’s Republican debate was yet another dumpster fire of insults and name-calling.

keywords: ['Editorials', 'Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Children who fled to the United States from Central America must have fair hearings before deportation.
lead_paragraph: In this time of political absurdity, can it be any surprise that a federal immigration judge insists that toddlers can represent themselves in immigration court?

headline: Limit the Next President’s Power to Wage Drone Warfare
abstract: Obama greatly expanded the power to wage drone warfare. Before he leaves office, he must establish policies restricting that power.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Barack Obama took office as the reluctant heir to George W. Bush’s “war on terror,” he renounced some of his predecessor’s most extreme policies. There is one Bush-era policy, though, that President Obama made emphatically his own: the summary killing of suspected militants and terrorists, usually by drone.

headline: Pentagon Has Plan to Cripple ISIS in Libya With Air Barrage
abstract: But the plan is not being actively considered, at least for now, as the U.S. presses ahead with diplomatic efforts inside Libya.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has presented the White House with the most detailed set of military options yet for attacking the growing Islamic State threat in Libya, including a range of potential airstrikes against training camps, command centers, munitions depots and other militant targets.

headline: Student Question | How Do You Celebrate Your Birthday?
abstract: Is celebrating our birthdays after we outgrow childhood a fun way to bring our community of family and friends together? Or is it a narcissistic exercise?
lead_paragraph: Birthdays can often be a huge deal for children: themed parties, elaborate cakes, lots of presents, even goody bags. But at some point, do we outgrow celebrating our birthday? Or is it still fun to celebrate ourselves once a year with friends and family?

headline: ‘The Profiteers,’ by Sally Denton
abstract: The famously secretive Bechtel Corporation, of Hoover Dam fame, and its decades of extraordinary influence in Washington.
lead_paragraph: When James Madison discussed the relationship between corporations and government, he sounded as if he were knocking on doors for Bernie Sanders. “The stockjobbers,” he wrote, “will become the pretorian band of the Government, at once its tool and its tyrant.” But stop right there. You might recognize Madison’s worry about corporations being government’s “tyrant,” but “its tool”?

headline: ‘Because of Sex,’ by Gillian Thomas
abstract: A last-minute amendment to the 1964 Civil Rights Act would have far-reaching effects on equality in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, Congress passed two bills that changed the working world for women — although, at the time, their impact was far from clear. The aim of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was certainly not focused on women’s concerns; nor was the vote in 1968 to remove the draft exemption for law school students. But the effects were far-reaching: Law school seats suddenly opened up for women, and as the A.C.L.U. attorney Gillian Thomas suggests in her new book, many of those women went on to fight discrimination in the workplace.

headline: Seeing Slim Chance of Accord, Senate Republicans Table Budget Discussions
abstract: With the budget stalled in the House, Senator Michael B. Enzi, the Wyoming Republican who leads the Budget Committee, announced on Monday that his panel would be putting off any action on a budget for at least this month and probably beyond.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans pounded Democrats for years for not producing a budget, but they are now finding out that it’s not that easy to do in a charged political environment.

headline: Whatever Happens in Michigan, John Kasich Says, ‘I’m Going to Ohio, O.K.?’
abstract: Amid promising signs in Michigan, Mr. Kasich, who three weeks ago said he would “roll up the carpets and go back” if he did not perform well in the state, is now stopping short of describing Tuesday’s contest in such momentous terms.
lead_paragraph: TROY, Mich. — Three weeks ago, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio came to Michigan and emphasized the importance of its coming primary. “We have to do really, really well in this state,” he said, “or I have to roll up the carpets and go back.”

headline: Don’t Post About Me on Social Media, Children Say
abstract: The first babies of Facebook are now preteens, and they are not happy with the digital record of their lives created by their parents.
lead_paragraph: Recently, university researchers asked children and parents to describe the rules they thought families should follow related to technology.

headline: Fox News Forum May Signal Thaw With Democrats
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders appeared together on the channel, which has not hosted a presidential campaign event with all the Democratic candidates since 2004.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Rebuffed yet again in coaxing Hillary Clinton onto Fox News, executives at the network had an outside-the-box idea last month that would have made primary debate history: a face-off between Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and the equally fiery candidate on the Republican side, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Donald Trump Doesn’t Understand Common Core (and Neither Do His Rivals)
abstract: He is promising to solve a problem that doesn’t exist by using power the president doesn’t have.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s presidential campaign has not been driven by detailed policy papers. But on one issue at least, his position is clear: He hates the Common Core State Standards. They are, he says, a “total disaster,” and he promises to abolish them upon assuming the presidency, because education “has to be at a local level.”

headline: Mr. Darcy’s Shirt Is Coming to America
abstract: A proposal to display the garment wet was deemed “curatorially unsound.”
lead_paragraph: It’s official: The shirt that turned the actor Colin Firth into a heartthrob — and helped fuel the continuing global Jane Austen pandemonium — is coming to the United States.

headline: Ad Watch: Under Armour Trains With Michael Phelps
abstract: The Phelps ad promotes Under Armour’s training apparel while serving as a reminder that success does not come easy.
lead_paragraph: For 90 seconds, Michael Phelps’s training regimen is on display: He swims, lifts weights, eats. At one point, he undergoes cupping therapy (seriously, just Google it).

headline: Michigan Leads Three Other States Into the Fray
abstract: It’s another primary day. For Democrats, it’s another opportunity for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to forge a path against Hillary Clinton. For Republicans, it’s a chance to try to blunt the front-runner, Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: It’s another primary day, with nominating contests from Mississippi to Hawaii. For the Democrats, it’s another opportunity for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to forge a path forward against Hillary Clinton. For the Republicans, it’s another chance to try to blunt the front-runner, Donald J. Trump, or a chance for the New York real-estate developer to further lock up delegates.

headline: Deep Rifts Among Israeli Jews Are Found in Religion Survey
abstract: The Pew Research Center found that religious and social divisions in Israel are reflected in “starkly contrasting positions on many public policy questions.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Most Israeli Jews marry within their own religious or secular subgroups and inhabit largely separate social worlds, according to the findings of a new survey exposing the deep gulfs over the role of religion in Israeli politics and society.

headline: A Young, Beloved Label Introduces Shoes
abstract: Ellery debuts its first full foray into footwear in its fall/winter show in Paris today.
lead_paragraph: Aside from the fall/winter season being her favorite collection to work on, the designer Kym Ellery has another reason to look forward to her namesake label’s presentation at the Palais de Tokyo in Paris today: This season marks the launch of Ellery’s first-ever shoe collection.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 1-7, 2016
abstract: Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Iranian Unit Tests Missiles, Accusing U.S. of Threats
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Accounts on state television did not specify whether the military had fired any weapons capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, which would violate a U.N. resolution.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran staged nationwide ballistic missile tests on Tuesday, Iranian state television reported, though the accounts did not specify whether the military had fired any ballistic missiles capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, which would violate a United Nations resolution.

headline: Too Soon Gone – Gary Braasch, Visual Chronicler of Climate Change
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Photography', 'Polar Bears', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A photographer roaming the globe to chronicle global warming dies exploring an imperiled reef.
lead_paragraph: Gary Braasch was a gifted photographer passionately devoted to chronicling climate change. I only met him a handful of times, and always, regrettably, in passing. On Monday, word rapidly spread through environmental circles that he had died at age 70 while snorkeling with a companion near Lizard Island on Australia’s Great Barrier Reef.

headline: Philippine Court Clears Way for Senator Grace Poe to Run for President
abstract: Senator Grace Poe, the adopted daughter of a movie star, had been disqualified over citizenship and residency rules.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Supreme Court of the Philippines on Tuesday ruled that a popular senator, seen by some as likely to carry forward the policies of President Benigno S. Aquino III, is eligible to run for the presidency.

headline: Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Despotic Zeal
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A brazen takeover of my newspaper is just the latest power grab by Turkey’s president.
lead_paragraph: Istanbul — THE virtual control he already has of a majority of Turkey’s newspapers and TV stations apparently isn’t enough for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. On Friday, with the zeal of its despotic leader, his government seized my paper, Today’s Zaman, and its parent, the Turkish-language Zaman, which is the highest-circulating daily in the country. Together, these titles were two of the few remaining independent voices inside Turkey — and Today’s Zaman, in particular, was a reliable English-language news source for diplomats, academics and expatriates.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Sacai
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The heeled rubber boots that Pierre Hardy designed for Sacai are the definition of sporty chic.

headline: Ugly Disagreements
abstract: We should all be able to agree that singular subjects need singular verbs and plural subjects need plural verbs. Upholding that rule on deadline, however, continues to be a challenge. Here is the latest sampling of singular/plural tribulations.
lead_paragraph: Writers and editors may debate whether a colloquial expression is effective, how well a metaphor works, or whether a complex sentence is elegant or just impenetrable.

headline: Chanel: Fall 2016
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld presents his latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld presents his latest designs.

headline: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim (and Their Families), Out for Dinner in Paris
abstract: Over a steaming hot pot, the designers discuss their fall/winter 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: Over a steaming hot pot, the designers discuss their fall/winter 2016 collection.

headline: On an Italian Island, How He Met My Mother
abstract: A visit to an abandoned family home on the tiny island of Ponza brings a woman, and her new husband, close to her roots, and each other.
lead_paragraph: When you pull into the port of Ponza, a tiny Italian island between Rome and Naples, you can see my grandfather’s childhood home. Position yourself outward from the terra-cotta wall of the harbor, which is shaped like a crescent. Glance across the ombré Tyrrhenian Sea and up the western hillside specked with pastel doll houses. Look closely and you can spot one outlier, an eroding whitewashed facade haunting the cheery amphitheater like a holy ghost. There it is.

headline: A Project Reclaims an Abandoned Stretch of New Jersey Coast
abstract: Groundbreaking is expected soon on former industrial land in Sayreville, for a development that is to include retail space, housing and hotels.
lead_paragraph: SAYREVILLE, N.J. — A bleak expanse of coastal New Jersey, polluted by paint pigments and abandoned for decades, is undergoing a makeover that will bring a major development of housing, retail space and office space a half-hour’s drive from Lower Manhattan.

headline: Family Travel Unplugged: More Options for Teenagers
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Spas']
abstract: Responding to parents’ concerns, hotels and resorts are adding programs to encourage children to become involved in real-world interactions.
lead_paragraph: It’s annoying enough to police your children’s digital excesses at home. But precious vacation time being wasted as they socialize virtually instead of engaging in the moment is the bane of 21st-century parenting. Heeding parents’ frustrations, hotels and resorts have responded with adolescent-savvy programming that encourages real-world interaction.

headline: In Portland, Oregon, a Warm Embrace of Tango
abstract: Tango has expanded beyond the ballroom into anywhere with a suitable dance surface, including a local bakery.
lead_paragraph: On a gray Wednesday afternoon in Southeast Portland, Ore., someone flicked on the lights in Tango Berretín, a dance studio devoted entirely to Argentine tango. Alex Krebs, the owner, teacher and acclaimed dancer, pressed play on traditional music from the 1930s and 1940s, as students drifted in, tossing aside street shoes for strappy stilettos. Against a backdrop of tango sheet music on the walls, the dancers didn’t wait for a formal invitation to the timeworn hardwood floor. One look with sustained eye contact (“cabeceo”) was a mutual agreement to dance. Within moments of arrival, dancers were locked in a cheek-to-cheek embrace, gliding to the music.

headline: In Paris, a Kenzo Family Dinner
abstract: Just days before their fall/winter 2016 show, the designers Carol Lim and Humberto Leon went out for a big, festive meal with their mothers.
lead_paragraph: “When you eat a meal, you’re in the present,” says the designer Carol Lim. She and Humberto Leon, the duo behind Opening Ceremony and Kenzo, along with their families, were seated around a long table at Han Shi Fang, a lively hot pot restaurant near the Place de la République in Paris. “Normally you’re working on something for the future or you might be reminiscing about the past, but food is one of the few things that you can just enjoy in the moment.”

headline: New York Nerve Wins Again
abstract: A commuter and her backpack pushed themselves onto a train at Pennsylvania Station after she had reached her limit.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Volkswagen Inquiry Expands to 17 Suspects
abstract: German prosecutors said that they had widened the inquiry into illegal manipulation of tailpipe emissions and that they had not ruled out involvement by top management.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — German prosecutors said on Tuesday that they had expanded their investigation into the illegal manipulation of tailpipe emissions by Volkswagen, raising the number of suspects to 17, from six.

headline: The Geometry of Progressive Trumpism
abstract: Hard to get the right shade of orange.
lead_paragraph: Should progressives fear a Trump nomination or cheer it on? The basic answer is, of course, who cares? While Ted Cruz may insist that the liberal media are conspiring to choose Trump so they can blow him up later — it’s all tinfoil hats over there, folks — the truth is that Republican primary voters don’t watch John Oliver, and an endorsement from the NY Times is probably the kiss of death. Still, it’s something people think about, and I found myself trying to clarify things with a silly diagram.

headline: New Poll Shows Republican Attacks Are Slowing Donald Trump
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: The ABC News/Washington Post survey finds that Donald J. Trump lags in one-on-one matchups with both Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio. And Mr. Trump trails his two leading Republican opponents with female voters and on questions of honesty, empathy and temperament to be president.
lead_paragraph: Weeks of attacks from his opponents and “super PACs” are taking a toll on Donald J. Trump’s popularity, according to a new ABC News/Washington Post poll that shows his Republican rivals slowly gaining on him.

headline: Faces in the Chanel Crowd: Wendi Deng and Pharrell Williams
abstract: Ms. Deng was at Céline and Givenchy, then Saint Laurent and Valli, before a stop at Tuesday’s Chanel show. Mr. Williams was there, too.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Around the time Rupert Murdoch married wife No. 4, the former model Jerry Hall, Wendi Deng (wife No. 3) was a near-ubiquitous presence at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Hedge Funds Escalating Attacks on United Continental
abstract: The former chief executive of Continental Airlines is one of six director candidates put forward by two activist hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: After years of seeing United Continental struggle, two hedge funds have begun an insurrection against the airline’s board — and have turned to a well-regarded figure from the company’s past to lead the charge.

headline: Penny Pritzker on the Privacy Shield Pact With Europe
abstract: Ms. Pritzker, the commerce secretary, discussed the difficulties in reconciling differing privacy protections in Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: The E.U.-U.S. Privacy Shield may, at first blush, sound like a pretty boring group of superhero characters. But the agreement, whose details were released late last month, will have a major impact on how companies collect, manage and use digital data transferred from Europe to the United States.

headline: ‘It’s Time for Some Disruption’: Readers on Donald Trump’s Appeal
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A number of readers offered political and economic explanations for Donald Trump’s success in the primaries.
lead_paragraph: A number of readers offered straightforward political and economic explanations for Donald Trump’s success in the primaries, even as many decried what they saw as his appeals to racism and xenophobia.

headline: South China Sea Buildup Brings Beijing Closer to Realizing Control
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The swift military expansion and island-building efforts have raised tensions while advancing China’s goal of a security buffer far from its coast.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the aircraft carrier John C. Stennis and four other American warships sailed into the South China Sea last week for what were described as routine exercises, the message was clear: The United States is the dominant military power in the region and plans to keep it that way.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 14: Sliding Doors
abstract: How cruel was that fake-out opening?
lead_paragraph: How cruel was that fake-out opening?

headline: The End of the Road for Picasa
abstract: Google is retiring the free photo-editing program and urging its users to give the newer Google Photos software a try.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is Google ever going to update the Picasa program again?

headline: A Proposal to Bridge the Digital Divide
abstract: The F.C.C. is poised to approve a broadband subsidy of $9.25 a month for low-income households.
lead_paragraph: The details of how to help close the digital divide are coming into focus.

headline: A Bid for Burberry Would Come With Challenges
abstract: The stock is not cheap, costs are already lean and it’s not clear that a new owner could do much to halt slowing sales.
lead_paragraph: A bid for Burberry does not check out financially.

headline: Tom Hayes Denied Latest Bid to Appeal Libor Conviction
abstract: Mr. Hayes had sought to have his conviction on charges of manipulating a global benchmark interest rate reviewed by the Supreme Court of Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An appeals court on Tuesday denied a request by Tom Hayes, a former trader at Citigroup and UBS, to ask Britain’s highest court to review his conviction in August for conspiring to manipulate a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: Haute Expectations at Saint Laurent and Chanel
abstract: The shows offered a contrast: one evoked the now omnipresent ’80s in a way that felt like a re-creation; the other used the past to point in a new direction.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It didn’t feel like a wake — though it was, essentially, one long paean to the past. In fact, Hedi Slimane’s maybe-possibly-but-no-one-knows-could-be last show for Saint Laurent resembled nothing so much as historically accurate immersive theater: a 1980s Helmut Newton photograph come to life.

headline: 1941: Patriots Pledge Fight to End
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Freed patriots pledge to fight for freedom for Norway in 1941.
lead_paragraph: More than 300 Norwegian patriots, who were brought to England by British and Norwegian forces which raided the Nazi-held Lofoten Islands on Tuesday, pledged themselves today to fight to the last for Norway and the common cause of freedom. The patriots took their vow in a London hotel, where they were greeted by King Haakon VII and Johan Nygaardsvold, Premier of the Norwegian government in exile. The 300 men and eight women cheered the King when, speaking with emotion, he told them they had shown the spirit of their countrymen in breaking away from Nazi tyranny. — New York Herald Tribune, March 9, 1941

headline: Warhol and Avedon Form an Unlikely Tandem in London
abstract: Works by Andy Warhol and Richard Avedon, arranged thematically, are on display at the Gagosian Gallery in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If his diaries are any indication, Andy Warhol had little affection for Richard Avedon. In an entry from December 1976, Warhol recalled running into a woman they both knew at a dinner party in New York.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 7: Rock Star Candidate
abstract: We finally meet Will Conway.
lead_paragraph: We’ve heard Will Conway’s name a few times and images of the Republican presidential candidate have flashed by in TV commercials over the course of the season. But in this episode, the New York governor (Joel Kinnaman) and his family finally come into full view.

headline: Donald Trump Avoids Tax Talk, and Calls Comparisons to Nazi Pledge ‘Ridiculous’
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Philanthropy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Taxation']
abstract: Donald J. Trump, in a series of morning television program interviews, declined to say what his effective tax rate was in 2014, and called comparisons of his “pledge” request that people at his rallies raise their hands and vow to support him to Nazi rallies “ridiculous.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Tuesday declined to say what his effective tax rate was in 2014, and called comparisons of his “pledge” request that people at his rallies raise their hands and vow to support him to Nazi rallies “ridiculous.”

headline: Vale May Take Stake in Fortescue, an Australian Rival
abstract: Both companies are struggling with volatile iron ore prices driven by expectations over China’s economic growth and subsequent steel demand.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Vale of Brazil, the world’s largest iron ore mining company, said on Tuesday that it could take a stake of as much as 15 percent, worth $965 million, in its erstwhile Australian rival Fortescue Metals Group, as both companies seek to carve out more market share in China.

headline: A Charity-Minded Lemonade Stand Meets Silicon Valley Churn
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Venture Capital', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Philanthropy', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Ambitions that began with a drink stand and led to a lemonade business, now on hiatus, have shifted to a struggling crowdfunding app, called Stand.
lead_paragraph: If you think starting a social network business is hard, try selling lemonade.

headline: Cameron’s Moment of Truth
abstract: As Britain heads toward a crucial referendum on membership in the European Union, the prime minister is already losing allies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Less than a year after his unexpected general election victory, Prime Minister David Cameron has undertaken an even greater challenge. Staking his future on the outcome, he is holding a referendum on June 23 to decide whether Britain should stay in the European Union, or leave.

headline: Derailed California Train Plunged Into Creek, Injuring at Least Nine
abstract: Passengers and emergency services shared images of the accident in which a commuter train car plunged into a creek in Northern California late Monday.
lead_paragraph: The lead car of a commuter train derailed and plunged into a creek in Northern California late Monday, injuring nine passengers, officials said. Passengers shared images on social media of the rescue operation as emergency workers battled currents throughout the night to pull people from the car.

headline: High Street on Hudson
abstract: Breads and breakfasts lead the way at the chef Eli Kulp’s West Village restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Breads and breakfasts lead the way at the chef Eli Kulp’s West Village restaurant.

headline: At High Street on Hudson, Prime Time Starts Early in the West Village
abstract: The chef Eli Kulp’s restaurant leads with its breads and breakfasts.
lead_paragraph: High Street on Hudson is an adventurous and often exciting restaurant trying extremely hard to pass for an ordinary West Village cafe. “Philly spinoff providing house-made breads & pastries, elevated sandwiches, coffee & cocktails,” is Google’s capsule summary. The description is factual to the last ampersand, yet it doesn’t go past the camouflage this place wrapped around itself when it sidled into town in December.

headline: As the Taliban Menace Afghanistan, the Helmand River Offers Solace
abstract: The resilience of Lashkar Gah, a city known as Little America, is reflected on the riverbank, a gathering place that has inspired at least one poem.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — The banks of the placid Helmand River have always been the social center of Lashkar Gah, the southern Afghan provincial capital sometimes called Little America during the decades of modernization efforts here.

headline: 1966: Nelson’s Pillar Destroyed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nelson’s Pillar in Dublin is destroyed by a bomb in 1966.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A time bomb today [March 8] wrecked the Nelson Pillar — a central landmark and controversial relic of Britain’s former rule of Ireland. The 157-year-old column stands 134 feet high, including the 20-foot-high statue of the British naval hero Lord Nelson on top. The statue itself and about 20 feet of the pillar were blown to bits. Scores of detectives and uniformed police immediately raided homes of people suspected of links with the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Six men were arrested and many more arrests were expected. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1966

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Stella McCartney and Sacai in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Monday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Monday.

abstract: The auction will include 200 lots in a live sale on June 22 and about 80 lots in an online auction June 16–23.
lead_paragraph: “Can we talk?”

headline: The Daily Bag: Hermès
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Hermès showed an oxblood crocodile clutch with a jeweled closure — the ultimate luxury accessory.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Stella McCartney
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The one-earring trend has popped up again all over the Paris runways — and Stella McCartney’s sculptural drop is one of the best we’ve seen yet.

headline: U.N.C. Football Player Who Ended Up Homeless Had C.T.E.
abstract: Ryan Hoffman, who fought depression and short-term memory loss before his death at age 41, was found to have the degenerative brain disease.
lead_paragraph: For so long, Ryan Hoffman, a former college football player I wrote about last year, had the same explanation for his inability to get his life on track.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rides a Wave of Caution in Uncertain Seas
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s constrained campaign style may not inspire voters the way her challenger’s bold promises do, but it may prove a winning strategy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Hillary Clinton has a clearer path to the Democratic presidential nomination than she ever had in 2008. But she is marching toward November facing the likelihood of an unpredictable opponent — and constrained by well-defined characteristics that have always limited her ability to inspire.

headline: Valentino: Fall 2016
abstract: Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli present their latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli present their latest collection.

headline: Terence Blanchard’s Opera, ‘Champion,’ Is Among Kennedy Center Season Highlights
abstract: “Champion,” a jazz-inflected opera by Terence Blanchard, will be performed by the Washington National Opera during the Kennedy Center season.
lead_paragraph: Terence Blanchard’s jazz-inflected opera, “Champion,” based on the true story of a boxer who threw a fatal punch after being taunted about his sexuality by a rival, and Jake Heggie’s “Dead Man Walking,” based on Sister Helen Prejean’s memoir about working on death row, will be staged next season at Washington National Opera, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Mothers of Slain Black Teenagers Assail Bernie Sanders for ‘Ghetto’ Comments
abstract: Hillary Clinton, seeking to cement her lead among black voters, released statements from the mothers of Trayvon Martin and Jordan Davis criticizing Senator Bernie Sanders for saying white people “don’t know what it’s like to be living in a ghetto.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, seeking to cement her lead among black voters, released statements from the mothers of Trayvon Martin and Jordan Davis on Tuesday criticizing Bernie Sanders for saying white people “don’t know what it’s like to be living in a ghetto.”

headline: Officer Charged in Freddie Gray Case Ordered to Testify Against Colleagues
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The Maryland Court of Appeals ruled that Officer William G. Porter must testify against five fellow Baltimore police officers, clearing the way for long-stalled prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maryland’s highest court on Tuesday ordered a Baltimore police officer who is charged in the death of Freddie Gray to testify for the prosecution in the trials of his fellow officers. The ruling clears the way for the state to move ahead with long-stalled prosecutions in a case that has become a touchstone in the emotional national debate over race and policing.

headline: Calvin Johnson, Quiet and Classy, Retires the Way He Played
abstract: Johnson, 30, who had 88 catches last season while playing through lingering injuries, retires with 731 career receptions and 83 touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: It was a study in contrasts. Peyton Manning, fresh off a Super Bowl victory that came almost in spite of him rather than because of him, held a televised news conference to make the retirement announcement everyone knew was coming. A day later, Calvin Johnson, still seemingly in the prime of his career and one of the best receivers in football, issued a simple statement through the Detroit Lions to confirm the surprising news that he was walking away from the game after just nine seasons.

headline: Hillary Clinton Ad in Michigan Derides Companies Moving Overseas
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Political Advertising', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tax Shelters', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Many American companies have moved their headquaters overseas to reap tax savings, a maneuver Mrs. Clinton says she will tax.
lead_paragraph: Appealing to voters in Michigan, Hillary Clinton released “Bam,” an ad attacking American companies that move their headquarters to foreign countries to reap enormous tax savings.

headline: Frank Zappa’s House Can Be Yours for $9 Million
abstract: The filmmaker Alex Winter is introducing a Kickstarter campaign to help finance a Zappa movie and preserve his archive. The home sale is part of the plan.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Gail Zappa, the widow of the iconoclastic rock musician Frank Zappa, was known as a fierce guardian of her husband’s business empire. But before she died last year at 70, Mrs. Zappa granted the filmmaker Alex Winter rare access to her husband’s “vault,” the enormous media archive kept in the basement of the Zappa family home in Los Angeles, as part of Mr. Winter’s latest project: a documentary about Zappa’s life and music.

headline: Iris Van Herpen: Fall 2016
abstract: Ms. Herpen presents her latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Herpen presents her latest designs.

headline: Radiohead Tribute Coming to Café Carlyle From Lena Hall and Michael C. Hall
abstract: Lena Hall and Michael C. Hall, who performed in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” will present “Radiohead: Obsessed” at Café Carlyle in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” reunion of sorts will arrive at Café Carlyle this month, set to the music of … Radiohead.

headline: In San Francisco and Rooting for a Tech Comeuppance
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Start-ups', 'Commuting', 'Evictions', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: The city is bulging, the rents soaring, and residents are growing more vocal about wishing Silicon Valley would cool off, or at least pay up.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — These are anxious days in the land of start-ups. Another few months of tight money and the entrepreneurs and venture capitalists will be feeling real pain.

headline: Seven Ways of Seeing Beauty in Design
abstract: This year’s design triennial at the Cooper Hewitt offers seven categories of beauty. Here are striking examples of each.
lead_paragraph: This year’s design triennial at the Cooper Hewitt offers seven categories of beauty. Here are striking examples of each.

headline: Coming Home to Pot Roast
abstract: The favorite dish of Gavin Kaysen, a former Café Boulud chef and native Minnesotan, owes to his culinary skill — and his grandmother.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Pot roast was one of the first dishes the chef Gavin Kaysen learned to cook, if you can call it cooking. The recipe he used as a teenager growing up in Bloomington, Minn., a Twin Cities suburb, required no culinary training.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Campaign Is Accused of Spreading Rumors of Marco Rubio’s Withdrawal
abstract: Ahead of Tuesday’s Republican caucuses in Hawaii, Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign is accusing Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign of “dirty tricks” similar to what happened in Iowa. This time, false rumors are said to have been spread via emails that Mr. Rubio is dropping out of the race.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz is under fire from Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign, which accuses him and his campaign of employing more “dirty tricks” ahead of the Republican caucuses in Hawaii on Tuesday and spreading false rumors that Mr. Rubio is dropping out of the race.

headline: How Three Hollywood Stars Became Music Legends
abstract: With new music biopics, Tom Hiddleston, Don Cheadle and Ethan Hawke prove that practice makes perfect.
lead_paragraph: There’s only one way to truly embody a musical genius: practice, practice, practice. In preparation for his role as Hank Williams in ‘‘I Saw the Light’’ (March 25), the English actor Tom Hiddleston spent five weeks mastering the country legend’s trademark yodel in Nashville. While making his directorial debut, ‘‘Miles Ahead’’ (April 1), in which he also stars as Miles Davis, Don Cheadle played the trumpet every day, continuing even after shooting had finished. And Ethan Hawke reveled in the singing lessons he took in order to play Chet Baker in ‘‘Born to Be Blue’’ (March 25), despite a rather tragic hitch: After a marathon studio session in which he nailed the standard ‘‘I’ve Never Been in Love Before,’’ the actor learned that none of the day’s work had been properly recorded. It’s a long and lonely road to the top.

headline: The Lofty Rise of the Lowly Comic
abstract: The prestigious publishing house New York Review Books launches a special imprint for overlooked comics. Not graphic novels — comics.
lead_paragraph: Before it was accepted as literature, the humble ‘‘comic’’ was euphemistically rebranded as the ‘‘graphic novel.’’ Now, a new imprint from New York Review Books is reclaiming the word. New York Review Comics will release six titles this year, with a focus on ‘‘things that have fallen through the cracks,’’ says co-editor Gabriel Winslow-Yost, from longer narratives to collections of gag cartoons. The first, with a foreword from Colson Whitehead, is Mark Beyer’s ‘‘Agony,’’ a dark, pen-and-ink sitcom of urban ennui that possesses the same universal appeal as the best of the Sunday funnies: long-suffering protagonists who show up week after week to do it all over again.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Your Wisconsin Supreme Court!
abstract: A judge supported by Gov. Scott Walker once had some pretty nasty things to say about gay people, Bill Clinton and nearly half of the American electorate.
lead_paragraph: Stipulated: College students make mistakes. But there are mistakes like drinking too much or growing a goatee, and there are mistakes like what Rebecca Bradley wrote for her student newspaper.

headline: Serena Williams Says Sharapova’s Announcement Surprised Her
abstract: Williams on Tuesday was sympathetic toward Maria Sharapova, who said that she had tested positive for a banned substance.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams may soon become the richest endorser in women’s tennis, if only by default.

headline: Trump and Christie’s Evolving Roles
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has known Donald J. Trump for 14 years. The pair’s relationship has changed over the past several months during the Republican race for the party nomination.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has known Donald J. Trump for 14 years. The pair’s relationship has changed over the past several months during the Republican race for the party nomination.

headline: E.U. Woos Turkey for Refugee Help, Ignoring Rights Crackdown
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: To win help with the migrant crisis, Europe seems prepared to overlook what critics say is President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march toward authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The contrast was jarring: Just days after the police broke into the offices of an opposition newspaper using tear gas and water cannons, Turkey’s prime minister was greeted in Brussels with offers of billions in aid, visa-free travel for Turks in Europe and renewed prospects for joining the European Union.

headline: Pakistani Politician’s Son, Abducted 5 Years Ago, Is Found Alive
abstract: The Pakistani police and intelligence agencies found Shahbaz Ali Taseer, the son of a former governor who was assassinated eight months before the kidnapping.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials said Tuesday that the police and security forces had found Shahbaz Ali Taseer, the son of a prominent former governor, alive in southwestern Pakistan five years after militants kidnapped him in a mystery that had riveted Pakistan for years.

headline: Review: In ‘Scary Old Sex,’ Arlene Heyman Mines the Details
abstract: This short-story collection includes taboos and all kinds of attention to late-life lovemaking.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if no one writes about sex among the senior set. Novels and poems increasingly bring us news from this front. John Betjeman’s poem “Late-Flowering Lust,” written many decades ago, began with a man presenting himself this way: “My head is bald, my breath is bad/Unshaven is my chin.”

headline: Mitt Romney Records Another Anti-Trump Message, This Time for John Kasich
abstract: Mr. Romney, who spoke out against Donald J. Trump’s candidacy last week, made a similar get-out-the-vote call to Republicans supporting Marco Rubio.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — As voters in Michigan go to the polls on Tuesday, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is getting some help from Mitt Romney, who recorded a get-out-the-vote call for Mr. Kasich’s campaign.

headline: Chinese Collector Joins Public Art Fund
abstract: Adrian Cheng, 36, a prominent Chinese collector and the scion of a multibillion-dollar retailing empire, is to join the board.
lead_paragraph: The Public Art Fund, which in recent years has looked far outside its New York City base for artists and projects, announced Tuesday that it had enlisted Adrian Cheng, a prominent Chinese collector and the scion of a multibillion-dollar retailing empire, to join its board.

headline: John Oliver Sells Out of ‘Make Donald Drumpf Again’ Caps
abstract: A section of “Last Week Tonight” focuses on the candidate’s so-called “original” family name, complete with a hashtag and offer to sell caps.
lead_paragraph: Last month, John Oliver said that the latest season of his HBO show, “Last Week Tonight” wasn’t going to cover the election the way other late night shows would. He said he wasn’t that interested in providing in-depth looks at the candidates. Each week, Mr. Oliver dedicates about 20 minutes of his half-hour show to what he calls the “main story,” but he blanched when I asked him if he would ever spend 20 minutes on Donald J. Trump.

headline: Finalists for PEN/Faulkner Award Named
abstract: James Hannaham, Julie Iromuanya, Viet Thanh Nguyen, Elizabeth Tallent and Luis Alberto Urrea are the finalists.
lead_paragraph: The judges for the 2016 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction have announced the five finalists for the prize: James Hannaham for “Delicious Foods”; Julie Iromuanya for “Mr. and Mrs. Doctor”; Viet Thanh Nguyen for “The Sympathizer”; Elizabeth Tallent for “Mendocino Fire”: and Luis Alberto Urrea for “The Water Museum.”

headline: Why Donald Trump Has Done Worse in Mostly White States
abstract: An appeal to white identity tends to work better in areas where that identity is felt to be under threat, like the racially polarized South.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has tended to fare worst in states that are mostly white.

headline: Afghan Court Confirms Reduced Sentences in Mob Killing of Farkhunda
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', "Women's Rights", 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Men sentenced to death in the brutal killing of Farkhunda, a young woman who was an Islamic scholar, had their sentences cut to as little as 10 years.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — One defendant was the custodian of a holy shrine who trafficked in Viagra, condoms and pagan amulets, and who, when exposed, falsely accused a young woman named Farkhunda of burning a Quran. Another was an employee from an optician’s shop who joined a growing mob at the shrine and pummeled Farkhunda with a rock the size of a watermelon.

headline: From Pinup to Muse: Pamela Anderson’s Next Chapter
abstract: There is more to the actress than her inflated-doll image and tangled relationships with bad boys would suggest.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a sun-soaked Southern California morning in the Hollywood Hills, the perennial pinup Pamela Anderson considered whether or not she had been afraid when she got breast implants. “I didn’t even have time to think about it,” she said in her breathy girlish voice. “It was done within a week, and that was that.”

headline: In Politics as in Investments, a Long-Term Outlook Can Soothe
abstract: Take a step back from what’s happening right now and remember that the political system is remarkably resilient, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: “What’s the deal with American politics right now?”

headline: Le Coq Rico Captures Essence of a Parisian Poultry Palace
abstract: Also, Josh Mazza and Steve Laycock opens Belle Shoals; Barneys in Chelsea gains a restaurant; German comfort food at Studio Kraut, and more.
lead_paragraph: Le Coq Rico Antoine Westermann, the Alsatian chef who once had three Michelin stars, has created a New York incarnation of his Parisian poultry palace. It occupies two storefronts, one with a long bar and the other a stretch of counter with a battalion of rotisseries and some seating, joined by a spacious rear dining room. Mr. Westermann has had some practice operating a restaurant in the United States. He ran the Café du Parc in Washington and became familiar with local farmers. He is a fan of our heritage chickens from small farms; his menu even lists how many days it took to raise each one (the longer the better). “In France, it’s poulet de Bresse,” he said, referring to the chickens with blue feet, “but here there are other breeds that can replicate the taste of Paris.” There are also guinea fowl, Cornish hens, ducks and squab, as well as poultry livers, egg dishes and a traditional Alsatian baeckeoffe casserole: (Opens Thursday): 30 East 20th Street, 212-267-7426, lecoqriconyc.com.

headline: Hitting Brings Don Mattingly and Barry Bonds Together on Marlins Staff
abstract: Mattingly and Bonds didn’t cross paths much as players, but now they are working together, as manager and hitting coach.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The earliest memory Don Mattingly could summon on the subject of Barry Bonds as a hitter not unlike himself, one genuinely blessed with a pureness of swing, was a late 1980s conversation with a former Bonds teammate in Pittsburgh, Sid Bream.

headline: How Europe’s Deal With Turkey Aims to Resolve the Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A look at the tentative accord reached Tuesday to help address the migration crisis that has roiled the Continent.
lead_paragraph: European Union leaders and Turkey reached a tentative deal early Tuesday morning to help resolve the migration crisis that has roiled the Continent. But human rights advocates have raised concerns about the accord.

headline: Hulk Hogan Exudes Calm in Second Day of Sex Tape Trial Against Gawker
abstract: The retired wrestler, legally Terry Bollea, was subdued during testimony in his suit against Gawker over its posting of a secretly recorded video.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — On the witness stand for a second day, Hulk Hogan was far from the chest-thumping, T-shirt-tearing champion wrestler admired for years by his fans for his braggadocio and his swagger.

headline: ‘Elvis & Nixon’ Will Debut at Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The film about a meeting between Elvis Presley and Richard M. Nixon is the centerpiece of the festival.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, Elvis will be in the building.

headline: Netflix Finds a Home With Younger and Wealthier Households
abstract: A researcher breaks down the key findings of an analysis of the streaming service’s effect on traditional television.
lead_paragraph: When a veteran industry analyst released a report last week stating that Netflix was to blame for half the decline in traditional TV viewing last year, he included a number of interesting assessments of how Netflix has changed the way we watch television.

headline: A Flying Baseball Bat, a Dad’s Instinct and a Photograph
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Photography', 'Sports Injuries', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Social Media']
abstract: In a split second, a father’s instinct takes over, and a risky moment becomes a picture that dazzles the Internet.
lead_paragraph: A father stops a flying baseball bat that was inches away from hitting his son’s face. A photographer captures the moment. You can guess what happens next.

abstract: A politics professor writes about a foray into files at the State Department.

abstract: With subtle touches and elegant lines, the late designer built his own legacy of modern Italian design.
lead_paragraph: With subtle touches and elegant lines, the late designer built his own legacy of modern Italian design.

abstract: Starring the stand-up comic Jerrod Carmichael, this NBC comedy has a lot to say about subjects from guns to race to Bill Cosby.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s “The Carmichael Show” has a simple message: America, we need to talk.

headline: FIFA Match Agent Pleads Guilty in U.S. Corruption Case
abstract: Miguel Trujillo, a Colombian citizen working in Florida, admitted he bribed top soccer officials. He is the 42nd defendant in the case, and the 15th to plead guilty.
lead_paragraph: The United States Justice Department announced a new defendant in its corruption case focused on world soccer on Tuesday: Miguel Trujillo, a Colombian citizen working in Florida as a soccer consultant and agent licensed by FIFA, the sport’s global governing body, to arrange matches between national associations.

headline: The Internet Haves and Have Nots
abstract: A modest and necessary plan to help narrow the digital divide between those who can afford high-speed Internet access and those who cannot.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission will vote later this month on a plan that could help narrow the digital divide between those who can afford high-speed Internet access and those who cannot. This is a good thing.

headline: Police Shooting of Oregon Occupier Declared Justified, but F.B.I. Faces Inquiry
abstract: Investigators said questions had been raised as to why F.B.I. agents did not disclose that they had fired shots when LaVoy Finicum, an occupier at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, was confronted.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Investigators said Tuesday that Oregon state officers had acted properly when they shot and killed LaVoy Finicum, one of the activists who occupied a wildlife refuge in Oregon this year, but federal officials have opened an inquiry into the actions of F.B.I. agents for not disclosing that they also fired shots during the confrontation.

headline: Better Business Bureau Contests Claim That Trump University’s Rating Improved
abstract: Donald J. Trump has been boasting that his contentious Trump University educational program earned an “A” rating from the Better Business Bureau, but the bureau says it has no rating.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has been boasting that his contentious Trump University educational program earned an “A” rating from the Better Business Bureau, but the bureau says it has no rating at all.

headline: Officer in Ramarley Graham Shooting Won’t Face U.S. Charges
abstract: Mr. Graham’s family had hoped that prosecutors would bring a civil rights case against the officer who killed the unarmed teenager in the bathroom of his family’s Bronx home in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A family’s four-year quest to hold a white New York City police officer criminally accountable for  the fatal shooting an unarmed black teenager in the bathroom of his Bronx home ended on Tuesday, when federal prosecutors said there was not enough evidence to pursue criminal charges.

headline: How Trump Loses, Revisited
abstract: Auditing my “it won’t be Trump” prognostication.
lead_paragraph: As we wait for the returns to come in from Michigan and other points of interest, I thought I might conduct a provisional pundit audit, revisit the most detailed of my various “it won’t be Trump” predictions, and compare what I foresaw to what’s actually transpired. Here, from early January, was my description of Trump’s likely path to defeat if he didn’t collapse early (as, obviously, he hasn’t):

abstract: The gallery acquired a former flour mill, and all the original street art that came with it. Then they commissioned some more.
lead_paragraph: The gallery acquired a former flour mill, and all the original street art that came with it. Then they commissioned some more.

headline: Preserving Old Graffiti at a New L.A. Gallery
abstract: Hauser Wirth & Schimmel acquired a former flour mill, and all the original street art that came with it. Then they commissioned some more.
lead_paragraph: When Hauser Wirth & Schimmel acquired its new space, a former flour mill in L.A.’s Arts District, it was already remarkably painted — with graffiti. “There are a lot of places that people would consider dodgy, but where people have created work that requires craft and commitment, even though they know they’re going to put it up and it’ll be gone,” says Steve Grody, the street art historian who worked with Hauser Wirth & Schimmel to identify the works. But the murals painted on the building’s walls aren’t going anywhere — in fact, the gallery commissioned the artist Kim West to expand upon her dreamlike mural on the old warehouse’s exterior.

lead_paragraph: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Carl Levin, a producer of the show, cited “the loss of a major investor” in announcing the step, in the musical about Bill Gates and Steve Jobs.
lead_paragraph: “Nerds,” a musical about the rivalry between Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, has abruptly canceled its Broadway debut just weeks before it was scheduled to begin performances, citing financial troubles.

abstract: A six-pack of boutique fitness studios is opening in New York this spring, promising better bodies for a price.
