headline: Reviving the Working Class Without Building Walls
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Minimum Wage', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: On the wrong side of globalization, workers supporting Donald Trump have embraced his proposals. But there are better ways to make things better.
lead_paragraph: Can the government help Donald Trump’s supporters?

headline: A Future Without Jobs? Two Views of the Changing Work Force
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: The Business Day columnists Eduardo Porter and Farhad Manjoo discuss the concept of a universal basic income and the trajectory of our economy.
lead_paragraph: In the utopian (dystopian?) future projected by technological visionaries, few people would have to work. Wealth would be generated by millions upon millions of sophisticated machines. But how would people earn a living?

headline: David Barton Reinvents His Gym Empire
abstract: The muscle-bound man who pioneered the gym-as-nightclub aesthetic is set to open a new fitness center, TMPL, in Hell’s Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: “I’m dressed for a construction site, so pardon my casual presentation,” David Barton said one recent Friday afternoon in Hell’s Kitchen. But his appearance was classic Barton: ripped jeans, mesh hoodie that exposed his “George of the Jungle” pecs, camouflage robe, hair spiking every which way.

headline: American Graduate Student Killed in Stabbing Rampage Near Tel Aviv
abstract: Taylor Force, an Army combat veteran and Vanderbilt graduate student, was killed by a Palestinian man who attacked groups of people in Jaffa.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian on a stabbing rampage on Tuesday along a coastal promenade near Tel Aviv killed an American combat veteran who was a graduate student at Vanderbilt University.

headline: When Is Hulk Hogan Not Hulk Hogan?
abstract: The wrestler’s case against the news site Gawker raises a question of identity.
lead_paragraph: One of the more surreal First Amendment trials in American history started this week in Florida. The wrestler Hulk Hogan, whose real name is Terry Bollea, is demanding a $100 million settlement from Gawker, the news website, over an excerpt from a video it published, of Mr. Bollea having sex with the wife of a friend, a radio shock jock known as Bubba the Love Sponge.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Prospects Ascendant, Though Perhaps Not With Senate Peers
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements']
abstract: Mr. Cruz has been gaining on Mr. Trump, but he is one of the least popular senators, in large part because he masterminded the 2013 government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas hopes his presidential fortunes are rising as he approaches a cluster of Republican primaries. But his prospects seem pretty flat among his party colleagues.

headline: March 8, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, France, Norway and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, France, Norway and the United States.

headline: Revamped United Airlines Board Could Be a Winning Compromise
abstract: A week before Oscar Munoz returns as C.E.O., the hedge funds PAR and Altimeter say they are aiming to install six new directors at United Continental.
lead_paragraph: It’s not the fresh start Oscar Munoz, United Airline’s chief executive would have wanted.

headline: Review: ‘Here Come the Videofreex,’ Revolution via the Portapak
abstract: This concise and informative documentary follows the early adopters of a lightweight record-playback model by Sony in 1968.
lead_paragraph: The 1968 introduction of a record-playback model of the Sony Portapak, which yoked a video camera to a video recorder in a lightweight format, was without a doubt seminal in media history. For various counterculture idealists, the relatively affordable, low-resolution devices had utopian truth-telling potential. “Here Come the Videofreex,” a concise and informative documentary directed by Jon Nealon and Jenny Raskin, tells the story of one such collective.

headline: W.H.O. Advises Pregnant Women to Avoid Areas Where Zika Is Spreading
abstract: The committee said that they were not recommending that pregnant women avoid whole countries, but that they avoid only “areas” where mosquitoes are transmitting the virus.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization advised pregnant women on Tuesday to avoid travel to areas where the Zika virus is spreading.

headline: For an Author in the Audience, the Thrill of Hearing Your Book Invoked
abstract: Attending “Our Mother’s Brief Affair,” a writer is surprised to learn that his account of World War II spying helped inspire the play.
lead_paragraph: Just as Act I of Richard Greenberg’s play “Our Mother’s Brief Affair” is about to end, Anna Cantor’s secret paramour confesses that the name she knows him by, Phil Weintraub, is actually a pseudonym.

headline: Sarah Paulson on Playing the Bruising Role of Marcia Clark
keywords: ['Television', 'Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Ms. Paulson, who performs the role of the prosecutor in “The People v. O.J. Simpson,” discusses the sixth episode, which addresses the withering scrutiny Ms. Clark faced.
lead_paragraph: The FX show “The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story” has explored issues of race, celebrity and the 24-hour news cycle. On Tuesday night, in the sixth episode, “Marcia, Marcia, Marcia,” the series examines gender discrimination, and the withering scrutiny that the prosecutor Marcia Clark faced during the trial.

headline: Charlie Sheen, 9/11 and the Mystery Production Company
abstract: A would-be comeback vehicle for a star better known lately for his drug abuse looks dicey on closer inspection.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s a juicy headline: Charlie Sheen, whose struggles with drug abuse have eclipsed his acting career, will star in a movie about people trapped inside a World Trade Center elevator during the 9/11 terrorist attacks. The film, “Nine Eleven,” would be Mr. Sheen’s first project since announcing in November that he is H.I.V.-positive.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Joins Yankees’ Trip and Flashes Some Spark
abstract: Sabathia, 35, who left the Yankees last year to be treated for alcohol abuse, threw 25 pitches against the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia had never been to Roger Dean Stadium, the shared home of the Miami Marlins and the St. Louis Cardinals, until he stepped off a four-hour bus ride on Tuesday morning.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Andrew Ross Sorkin, Eugene Wang and others.

headline: Call of the Track Too Hard to Ignore for Racing’s Mad Genius
abstract: Michael Dickinson, who developed a synthetic surface now used throughout the world, decided to return to training thoroughbreds at age 66 after an eight-year absence.
lead_paragraph: NORTH EAST, Md. — Michael Dickinson has an eternal twinkle in his eye. It is there on winter weekends when he participates in fox chases: on foot and alongside 70 horses. It was there a decade ago when he decided thoroughbred racing needed safer racetracks and, after years of experimenting, came up with a synthetic surface now used throughout the world.

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Presents Messiaen in a Broader Context
abstract: “The Messiaen Connection,” at National Sawdust, included works by three composers who influenced that French modernist master.
lead_paragraph: Though Alan Gilbert did not take part in the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! program at National Sawdust in Brooklyn on Monday night, almost every aspect of this exciting concert was because of his vision as music director.

headline: Will Shortz: Everything You Want To Know About Crossword Puzzles
abstract: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described “puzzlehead,” Will Shortz answers readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described “puzzlehead,” Will Shortz answers readers’ questions.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Giambattista Valli, Hermès and Sonia Rykiel
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Monday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Monday.

headline: Review: Jason Moran at the Park Avenue Armory
abstract: This pianist has programmed a series of performances, mostly collaborations, in the restored Veterans Room at the armory.
lead_paragraph: The Veterans Room at the Park Avenue Armory, opened in 1881, was designed by Louis C. Tiffany & Company, Associated Artists. It’s a sensory riot: the refined enthusiasms of the American Aesthetic movement, stuffed into 1,850 square feet, including a small balcony. The room has Moorish, Persian and Japanese details, colored glass, latticework in wood and metal, circles within squares within grids.

headline: In ‘Iolanta/The Nutcracker,’ a Director Unites Two Tchaikovsky Works
abstract: Dmitri Tcherniakov discusses his complicated, and ambitious double bill for the Paris Opera that reunites works by Tchaikovsky.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dmitri Tcherniakov had not slept all night. It was the day after the dress rehearsal of his double bill of Tchaikovsky’s opera “Iolanta” and his ballet “The Nutcracker” for the Paris Opera here, and he was still feeling overwrought. “So much is going on in my head,” he said, gesturing expansively. “This is so big and complicated.”

headline: Announcing the Times Insider Book Club: Joe Nocera’s ‘Indentured’
abstract: Should college athletes be paid? Join Joe Nocera, Times columnist and author of “Indentured,” in an online chat.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider is hosting an online book club with the Times columnist Joe Nocera — and you’re invited!

headline: Three’s a Trend: A Modern Warrior
abstract: At Valentino, Loewe and Mugler, looks with a gladiator edge.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, a handful of designers have showed looks with a distinctly gladiatorial feel. At Loewe (right), the designer Jonathan Anderson paired a sexy leather bustier over a neutral skirt, while at Mugler (center), David Koma designed a tough cocktail number edged in fringe. And at Valentino (left), a petite leather dress with allover metal panels nicely offset a tulle skirt and ballet-inspired underpinnings.

headline: How to Watch the Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: Skywatchers across Southeast Asia and the western Pacific can witness a solar eclipse. Here’s how to observe it from other places, too.
lead_paragraph: With protective glasses at the ready, skywatchers across Southeast Asia and the western Pacific are preparing to witness a total solar eclipse. But you don’t have to live in those parts of the world to observe it. With only a few hours before the cosmic spectacle starts, here are answers to some questions you might have.

headline: Eating Leaves, and Other Ways Besieged Syrians Try to Survive
keywords: ['Malnutrition', 'Children and Childhood', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The report detailed how civilians in 18 areas across the country are forced to scrounge to survive.
lead_paragraph: Medical workers in parts of Syria have been forced to let the wounded bleed to death for lack of bandages, and have opted to use catheter bags meant for urine to administer intravenous fluids to newborns because proper drip bags are gone.

headline: Bernie Sanders Wins Michigan Primary; Donald Trump Takes 3 States
abstract: Mr. Sanders’s upset in Michigan threatened to prolong the Democratic campaign. Mr. Trump’s victories demonstrated his popularity in the Midwest and South.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump easily dispatched his Republican rivals in the Michigan and Mississippi presidential primaries Tuesday and won the Hawaii caucuses, regaining momentum in the face of intensifying resistance to his campaign among party leaders.

headline: Police Officer Shot and Wounded in Brooklyn
abstract: Two people are in custody and police are searching for a third after a shooting in the Bushwick neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A plainclothes New York City police detective was shot on Tuesday, apparently in a crossfire with a sergeant, as they sought to make a drug arrest in Brooklyn and the suspects tried to flee in a car, the police said.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul Stays With Giants on One-Year Deal
abstract: Pierre-Paul was without a contract for next season and had attracted interest from several teams, most notably the ascending Arizona Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: Late last summer, a month after a Fourth of July fireworks accident had seriously damaged his right hand, defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul and the Giants were at a strained standoff. With scant information about the condition of his hand and with no sense of what Pierre-Paul’s football future held because he would not contact the Giants, the team’s leaders routinely shook their heads in exasperation when asked about Pierre-Paul, the linchpin player of their defense.

Others intend to pay for one of the more expensive private buses that service their suburbs. Still others said they would wake up at the crack of dawn and shoulder their way into the exasperated crowds jamming onto PATH trains in Hoboken, Jersey City and Newark.

The mayor spoke during a conference call with reporters.

headline: Yemen: Houthi Rebels Enter Peace Talks With Saudi Arabia
abstract: A delegation from the Houthi rebel movement is conducting peace talks directly with Saudi Arabia for the first time since Yemen’s civil war began nearly a year ago.
lead_paragraph: A delegation from Yemen’s Houthi rebel movement is conducting peace talks directly with Saudi Arabia for the first time since Yemen’s civil war began nearly a year ago, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A Saudi-led military coalition started fighting in Yemen last year after the Houthis seized Sana, the capital, and drove Yemen’s government from power. The United Nations has sponsored several failed attempts to halt the fighting, which has killed more than 3,000 civilians and left most of the country in need of humanitarian aid. Representatives of the Houthis traveled to Saudi Arabia this week to discuss prisoner exchanges and a de-escalation of fighting along the Saudi-Yemeni border. It was hoped that the talks would lead to a broader agreement to end the war, according to the people briefed on the negotiations, which have not been publicly announced.

headline: Record Number of Tourists Visited New York City in 2015, and More Are Expected This Year
abstract: The city’s tourism-marketing agency plans to announce a forecast of 59.7 million visitors this year, an increase from last year’s record of 58.3 million.
lead_paragraph: It has been a decade since former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg decided to ramp up New York City’s efforts to attract more tourists, and city officials say there is no end to the influx on the horizon.

headline: Canada: Government Raises Its Target for Admitting Political Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The government said Tuesday that Canada would bring in a total of 55,800 political refugees this year, many of them fleeing the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: After achieving its initial target of admitting 25,000 refugees from Syria late last month, the government said Tuesday that Canada would bring in a total of 55,800 political refugees this year, many of them fleeing the Syrian civil war. Despite the Liberal government’s push to admit Syrian refugees, many private groups that have raised money to sponsor refugee families still find themselves without anyone to host. John McCallum, the immigration minister, said that the government would triple the annual limit for privately sponsored refugees to 18,000 people this year. The new limits are part of an overall goal of admitting 305,000 immigrants, a portion of whom are political refugees, as permanent residents this year, compared with 285,000 last year. Mr. McCallum said the rules would be changed to make it easier for previous immigrants to bring family members to the country.

headline: Kathryn Popper, Last Surviving Actor in ‘Citizen Kane,’ Dies at 100
abstract: Mrs. Popper was Orson Welles’s assistant and played a photographer in the 1941 film who asked, “What’s Rosebud?”
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Trosper Popper, who was a 25-year-old personal assistant to Orson Welles when he cast her as a photographer in the closing scene of “Citizen Kane” and fed her the immortal line, “What’s Rosebud?,” died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 100 and believed to be the last surviving actor to have appeared in the film, which was released in 1941.

But while the talk got loopy on Tuesday in the Missouri State Senate, the cause was serious on the second day of a filibuster against a bill giving new legal protection to opponents of same-sex marriage.

headline: Brazil: Former C.E.O. Is Sentenced to 19 Years in Corruption Inquiry
abstract: Marcelo Odebrecht, the former chief executive of Brazil’s largest construction company, was convicted of corruption and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: Marcelo Odebrecht, the former chief executive of Brazil’s largest construction company, was convicted of corruption and money laundering on Tuesday. He was sentenced to more than 19 years in prison by the Brazilian judge who is leading the wide-ranging investigation into corruption at the state-owned oil company, Petrobras. Testimony in the overall inquiry has shown that executives at Petrobras accepted large bribes from companies and channeled some of that money to political figures and the governing Workers Party. Judge Sergio Moro, in a 234-page decision, said that Mr. Odebrecht had paid about $30 million in bribes to officials at Petrobras and had used overseas accounts and secret offshore accounts to make many of the illicit payments. His family’s company, Odebrecht SA, works in 27 countries and employs more than 250,000 people worldwide. It won contracts to work on many of the stadiums built for the 2014 World Cup and for the Olympics to be held in Brazil this year.

headline: Only Trump Can Trump Trump
abstract: Donald Trump’s opponents foolishly think they can break his bond with voters by giving them facts, but his supporters are following their gut.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a walking political science course. His meteoric rise is lesson No. 1 on leadership: Most voters do not listen through their ears. They listen through their stomachs. If a leader can connect with them on a gut level, their response is: “Don’t bother me with the details. I trust your instincts.” If a leader can’t connect on a gut level, he or she can’t show them enough particulars. They’ll just keep asking, “Can you show me the details one more time?”

lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Sometime around Christmas, Chicago White Sox General Manager Rick Hahn called his new catcher, Alex Avila, to ask about a player Hahn was interested in signing.

headline: Florida, Famed for Political Spectacles, Braces for Another as Primary Nears
abstract: The dizzying race descends on the delegate-rich state over the next week, as one of its senators, Marco Rubio, looks to make a stand against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Get live updates about the Florida primary.

headline: 500 Years of Jewish Life in Venice
abstract: A journey into one of the world’s oldest Jewish ghettos, where this year a long, rich history is commemorated.
lead_paragraph: Though you can still see the recesses in the walls where the hinges of the portals once hung, the Venice ghetto has not been a prison since Napoleon seized the city and tore down the gates in 1797. Today, no barrier or signpost marks where Venice ends and its ghetto begins. Cross a canal on an arched bridge, duck through a sottoportego (an alley tunneling through a building), disappear down a vent in the urban fabric — you come and go just like everywhere else in the maze of this island city.

headline: Beloved Anachronisms, Times Square Mosaics of the City May Be Preserved
abstract: The giant, detailed maps of New York, frozen in 1957, are on two sides of the Times Square police substation, which is about to be modernized.
lead_paragraph: Chances are, you have passed by them dozens of times. Chances are, you have never noticed.

headline: Living in Westwood, N.J.
abstract: The borough of Westwood offers an expansive downtown and tight-knit residential neighborhoods, along with plenty of ponds, brooks and parks.
lead_paragraph: The borough of Westwood offers an expansive downtown and tight-knit residential neighborhoods, along with plenty of ponds, brooks and parks.

headline: Westwood, N.J., Busy Hub, With Ponds and Parks
abstract: The borough of Westwood offers a busy commercial district and tight-knit residential neighborhoods, along with plenty of ponds, brooks and parks.
lead_paragraph: Kate McDermott was just a week shy of giving birth to her first child when she and her husband, Steve, moved from Hoboken, N.J., to Westwood, N.J., in 2008. Six years, three more children and another house later, the McDermotts still find Westwood delivering on the qualities they originally sought.

headline: The Echo From Amazon Brims With Groundbreaking Promise
abstract: The voice-controlled computer has the potential to become a dominant force in the most intimate of environments: our homes.
lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s largest technology companies have spent the last five years searching in vain for the holy grail, a machine to succeed the smartphone as the next must-have gadget.

headline: For Serious Training, Hold the Carbs at Dinnertime
abstract: A “sleep-low” sports diet, in which an athlete skips carbohydrates at dinner, led to notable improvements in performance.
lead_paragraph: Strategically skipping bread, pasta and other carbohydrates at dinner might improve subsequent athletic performance, provided those low-carb meals are combined with the right types of workouts, according to a new sports nutrition study. Its findings undercut some entrenched ideas about how athletes should eat in preparation for spring marathons and other endurance races.

headline: As Paris Fashion Week Winds Down, the Parties Rev Up
abstract: Valentino celebrated a milestone, L’Oreal drew some buzz and Kenzo toasted a Disney collaboration.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Paris Fashion Week went out with a bang on Tuesday, thanks to a scattering of glittering parties held on the penultimate night of the calendar. Hordes of high-heeled — if weary — industry revelers prepared their Instagram filters, determined to document the end of the season in style.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:01 a.m.

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Leading Bernie Sanders in Florida and Ohio, Polls Show
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Losses in Ohio, where Hillary Clinton has a modest lead, and in Florida, where it is more significant, could deal a blow to Senator Bernie Sanders’s campaign and increase pressure on him to consider dropping out of the race.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is leading Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in Florida and Ohio, according to polls released on Wednesday that show him looking vulnerable going into next week’s primary contests.

headline: Two Shows, Four Eventful Days for Balenciaga’s Hot New Designer
abstract: Demna Gvasalia talks about his work, his Paris shows and the reaction to his first designs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If the appointment of Demna Gvasalia, 34, the upstart designer of Vetements, as artistic director of Balenciaga was the surprise of the last Paris fashion season, it has been the toast of this most recent one. His debut collection for the landmark French label was met with raves from nearly every corner. (The all-white cast of models received harsher reviews, especially online. Asked about the matter, Mr. Gvasalia declined to address it directly, saying, in part, “What does attitude look like? Is it in the body, the clothes, the mind?”)

headline: Despite Initial Congressional Objections, Obama’s Trip to Cuba Will Feature Full Flight
abstract: At least 20 lawmakers will accompany President Obama on his trip to to Cuba this month, and many more asked for a seat aboard Air Force One.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t so long ago that a small congressional delegation’s trip to Cuba was a less-than-popular outing. But at least 20 lawmakers will accompany President Obama on his trip to Cuba this month, and many more asked for a seat aboard Air Force One. The group is bipartisan, demonstrating that some Republicans are coming around to the idea of ending a decades-old trade embargo, a policy Mr. Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba have pursued.

headline: Letting Happiness Flourish in the Classroom
abstract: Joy can be a rare beast in our classrooms, but we can create and protect learning conditions in which it can flourish, the author Emma Seppala says.
lead_paragraph: When I look out into my classroom, and take the emotional temperature of my students, I’m usually checking for engagement. I want to make sure they feel supported, are interested in the lesson at hand, and that the lesson is relevant to each student.

headline: What Chinese Media Mustn’t Cover at the ‘2 Sessions’
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Propaganda', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A list of forbidden news topics reportedly issued by China’s propaganda authorities offers a picture of their anxieties.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Tastes differ. Some people may enjoy salacious stories about philandering abbots, or hair-raising ones about violence between doctors and patients.

headline: Court Orders One of Japan’s Two Operating Nuclear Plants to Shut Down
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Radiation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A court in Japan ordered one of only two nuclear power plants operating in the country to shut down on Wednesday, citing insufficient safety measures put in place after meltdowns at a facility in Fukushima five years ago.

keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s two-day visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories was expected to be one of public pleasantries and private talks on regional energy and a new military aid package for Israel. Instead, he stepped into a bloody maelstrom.

They are coming to Los Angeles from out of state and from overseas. They are skipping work and sacrificing vacation days.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service on Tuesday night arrested a man suspected of shooting a pastor in Idaho after the man traveled here and threw unidentified objects over the White House fence, a spokesman for the Secret Service said in a statement.

headline: Q. and A. With Neve Campbell: Fiction Eclipsed by Truth
abstract: The actress talks politics, her character on “House of Cards” and roles for women over 40.
lead_paragraph: Every politician needs a henchperson. In Netflix’s “House of Cards,” President Francis Underwood, who is running for re-election in the now-streaming Season 4, has Douglas Stamper. So it’s only fitting that the equally Machiavellian first lady has her own: Leann Harvey, a take-no-prisoners campaign strategist played by Neve Campbell. Confronted by Stamper in her office, she pulls a gun and lets him know that she’d use it.

abstract: Valeant said it had named three new directors to its board, including an executive from a major shareholder, Pershing Square Capital Management.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has been under scrutiny for its drug-pricing practices, said on Wednesday that it was adding three new members to its board, including one from Pershing Square Capital Management, a major company shareholder.

keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Museums', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Palaces and Castles', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: The Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, is backing two big projects, for both economic and political reasons, to restore key buildings to their pre-World War II glory.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Augustus boasted of finding Rome a city of brick and leaving it a city of marble. Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, seems to be trying for something similar.

headline: At Carnegie Hall, Concerts of Handel and Max Reger
abstract: The English Concert is scheduled to perform Handel’s “Orlando”; the American Symphony Orchestra will play a program honoring Reger.
lead_paragraph: No one who attended the remarkable 2014 Carnegie Hall concert performance of Handel’s “Alcina” by the English Concert, the acclaimed period instrument orchestra, is likely to forget it. The ensemble, with its director Harry Bicket again conducting, returns to Carnegie to perform Handel’s “Orlando,” featuring the superb countertenor Iestyn Davies in the title role. The enticing cast includes Erin Morley, Sasha Cooke, Carolyn Sampson and Kyle Ketelsen. (2 p.m., Sunday, March 13.)

headline: Of Guitars and ‘Ghosts’: Jimi Hendrix and Lucinda Williams
abstract: The Experience Hendrix tour pays tribute to the guitar pioneer, and Ms. Williams digs into her latest album.
lead_paragraph: For Jimi Hendrix, the guitar was a blues transmitter, a thruster, a twang maker, a horn section replacement, a wordless yet urgent voice and a wild electronic noise generator. Hendrix carried all those roles to pioneering extremes, and the Experience Hendrix tour pays tribute with a guitar onslaught. It features Buddy Guy — a wily master of suspense, subtlety and flashy aggression — and other guitarists, including Zakk Wylde. (Friday, March 18, at 8 p.m., Kings Theater, Brooklyn; 718-856-5464, kingstheatre.com.)

headline: The Strange Beauty of Superlative Eyelashes
abstract: This season, eyes take the feminine ideal to bizarre (and alluring) extremes.
lead_paragraph: This season, eyes take the feminine ideal to bizarre (and alluring) extremes.

headline: ‘There Might Be Others,’ a Work of Spontaneous Sound and Movement
abstract: The choreographer Rebecca Lazier and her musical collaborator, Dan Trueman, will stage an open-ended performance at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: When 14 dancers step onstage for Rebecca Lazier’s “There Might Be Others,” they won’t know what’s going to happen. That might be true of any live performance, but Ms. Lazier, a choreographer drawn to volatile group dynamics, and her musical collaborator, Dan Trueman, are especially interested in composing on the spot. Inspired by Terry Riley’s indeterminate musical score “In C,” they’ve developed sound and movement modules to be arranged and manipulated spontaneously by the performers. It’s a work about the art of making decisions, wherever they may lead.

headline: ‘The Effect,’ by Lucy Prebble, Comes to the Barrow Street Theater
abstract: When two test subjects taking a new antidepressant fall for each other, is their passion fueled by the drug, or is it from the heart? David Cromer’s play investigates.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult these days to read a newspaper or magazine or watch a television show without seeing an advertisement for some sort of prescription medication (usually with a long and disconcerting list of possible side effects). But can a pill really change a person? The British playwright Lucy Prebble (“Enron”) raises the question in “The Effect,” her play about a clinical drug trial that had its premiere in London in 2012. When two test subjects taking a new antidepressant fall for each other, is their passion fueled by the drug, or is it from the heart?

headline: ‘Fatima’ Captures the Immigrant Experience in France
abstract: The surprise winner of this year’s Cesar (the French Oscar) for best film will screen on the final day of the Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: In Philippe Faucon’s “Fatima,” the surprise winner of this year’s César (the French Oscar for best film), Soria Zeroual plays the title character, a divorced Algerian woman bringing up her two teenage daughters in Lyon. She works tirelessly as a cleaning woman to pay for their education. The oldest, the 18-year-old Nesrine (Zita Hanrot), is struggling through her first year of medical school, and Souad (Kenza-Noah Aïche), 15, is a rebel who treats her mother with such contempt that Fatima begins to question her humiliating self-sacrifice. The hostility of Arab neighbors adds to Fatima’s woes, and she develops physical symptoms that make walking difficult.

headline: 1916: Gen. Villa Raids U.S. Town
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: “Pancho” Villa raids the town of Columbus and kills many in 1916.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — At the head of 500 troopers, General ‘‘Pancho’’ Villa, bandit leader of the Mexican rebels, dashed across the New Mexican border at daybreak this morning [March 9] and raided the town of Columbus, sixty miles west of El Paso, Tex.

headline: Setting Hourly Alarms on Apple Devices
abstract: If you need an hourly reminder to do something, you can get a third-party app or just use software included with your Apple device.
lead_paragraph: Q. I am an 84-year-old sedentary person and I need some kind of alarm program that reminds me to get up every hour. I could set the alarm on my iPad/iPod every hour, but that is a pain.

abstract: Some residents are rooting for a tech downturn, in the latest sign that San Francisco has become an example of what-not-to-follow.
lead_paragraph: First came the rise. Now comes the it’s-time-to-fall.

headline: 2 Baltimore School Officers Arrested in Assault on Teenager
abstract: A video shows one of the officers slapping and kicking a young man at a school as the other officer stands by.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two school police officers in Baltimore were charged with assault and misconduct on Wednesday in connection with a cellphone video that shows one of them slapping and kicking a teenage student while the other officer looks on.

headline: No Mystery Bidder for Burberry; Shares Down Nearly 6 Percent
abstract: Market speculation that Burberry might be the subject of a takeover bid sent the luxury fashion brand’s shares higher on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Market speculation on Tuesday that Burberry might receive a potential takeover offer from a mystery bidder turned out to be nothing more than speculation, according to people with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Palace Files Complaint Over Report That Queen Elizabeth II Favors E.U. Exit
abstract: The Sun, citing anonymous sources, reported that the queen had made her skepticism known during a lunch at Windsor Castle and at a palace reception.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Buckingham Palace said on Wednesday that it had filed a formal complaint against The Sun, Britain’s biggest tabloid, after the newspaper reported that Queen Elizabeth II supported the country’s departure from the European Union.

headline: New Polls Offer Promising Outlook for Donald Trump in Florida and Ohio

abstract: Surveys from CNN/ORC show Donald J. Trump with solid leads, potentially dealing serious blows to the campaigns of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio in their home states when voters cast primary ballots next Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Florida and Ohio are looking like friendly states for Donald J. Trump ahead of their primary elections next Tuesday, according to two new polls.

headline: Director Chosen for Harvard Art Museums
abstract: Drew Gilpin Faust said that Martha Tedeschi’s experience would serve the museums well as the university seeks to integrate its collections “more fully into Harvard’s intellectual life.”
lead_paragraph: The Harvard Art Museums, which have been without a director since last July, announced Wednesday that they had chosen Martha Tedeschi, a longtime curator and administrator at the Art Institute of Chicago, to lead the institutions.

headline: Ireland Waits to See if 2 Parties Can Reach Pact After Indecisive Vote
abstract: Its chances of forming a stable coalition government depend on whether two center-right parties can set aside deacdes of enmity and come together.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Nearly two weeks after an inconclusive general election, Ireland’s chances of forming a stable coalition government revolve around a single question: Can the two center-right parties that have long dominated Irish politics put aside nearly a century of enmity and find a way to run the country together?

headline: ISIS Detainee’s Information Led to 2 U.S. Airstrikes, Officials Say
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The prisoner is an Iraqi chemical weapons specialist who provided details about the Islamic State’s cache to military interrogators, Pentagon officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top specialist in chemical weapons for the Islamic State who is in American custody in northern Iraq has given military interrogators detailed information that resulted in two allied airstrikes in the last week against the group’s illicit weapons sites, Defense Department officials said Wednesday.

headline: A Trail of Zika-Borne Anguish
abstract: Once called a mystery disease, everyone in Brazil is aware of the Zika virus, which appears to cause microcephaly, or abnormally small heads, in babies.
lead_paragraph: Once called a mystery disease, everyone in Brazil is aware of the Zika virus, which appears to cause microcephaly, or abnormally small heads, in babies.

headline: Europe’s Illiberal Democracies
abstract: The E.U.’s post-Communist eastern states are rebelling against what Brussels considers political norms.
lead_paragraph: Paris — Twenty-five years ago, in February 1991, the leaders of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary met in Visegrad, a Hungarian town overlooking the Danube. Those three countries had recently broken free of the Soviet bloc; their newly elected leaders, Lech Walesa, Vaclav Havel and Jozsef Antall, had taken an active part in the liberation. Two, Mr. Havel and Mr. Walesa, had been jailed for their activities.

headline: Six Men Are Sentenced in Record Jewelry Theft in London
abstract: Three ringleaders were each sentenced to seven years for stealing $20 million in gems, gold and cash. Three other men also received terms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They have been called the Diamond Geezers and the Bad Grandpas: four thieves in their 60s and 70s who used diamond-tipped drills to break into a safe deposit company in London and make off with plastic garbage bins stuffed with $20 million in gems, gold and cash.

abstract: Carly Fiorina endorsed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, supplying his campaign with a high-profile supporter and an eager critic of Donald J. Trump. “The truth is that Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are two sides of the same coin,” Mrs. Fiorina said at a Cruz campaign rally in Miami.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Carly Fiorina endorsed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas on Wednesday, supplying his campaign with a high-profile supporter and an eager critic of Donald J. Trump.

headline: 1941: Women Called to War Plants
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 100,000 women are called to volunteer in British war factories in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, appealed today for 100,000 women from all walks of life to volunteer within two weeks for war service in British factories. He also called on 50,000 skilled shipbuilding workers who have left the industry in the last fifteen years to return to their old jobs, and urged businessmen and others not engaged in defense occupations to take over the thousands of unskilled jobs waiting in British shipyards. The triple-barreled appeal was made in a speech at Newcastle. — New York Herald Tribune, March 10, 1941

headline: Pollution Tied to Premature Births, Especially in Women With Asthma
abstract: A new study suggests that women with asthma exposed to air pollution, even before conception, significantly increase their risk of delivering a premature baby.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that women with asthma exposed to air pollution, even before conception, significantly increase their risk of delivering a premature baby.

headline: A Lumber Executive Loses His Voice and Finds Balance
abstract: Kevin Hancock, chief executive of a lumber company in Maine, found his life changed when a vocal cord disorder cost him his normal speaking voice.
lead_paragraph: CASCO, Me. — Kevin Hancock, chief executive of his family’s lumber company, thought things could not possibly get worse: The housing market was sputtering, hundreds of lumberyards had shut down and his company had to resort to painful cuts, hiring freezes and layoffs at its sawmills and retail stores.

headline: Pot Roast and Other Edibles
abstract: A love letter to pot roast, and a no-recipe, one-pan chicken thigh recipe.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Beer Bottles, Graffiti and Puccini: The LoftOpera Formula
abstract: Equal parts keg party, tech start-up and opera troupe, LoftOpera is performing “Tosca” in an old bus depot in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In an old bus depot in an industrial stretch of Bushwick, Brooklyn, whose architectural ornamentation consists of concertina wire and graffiti, young singers and musicians — some wearing knit hats and parkas against the cold — were rehearsing Puccini’s “Tosca.”

headline: ‘Apostle,’ by Tom Bissell
abstract: Part investigation, part travelogue, a book asks what Christians actually know about Jesus’ disciples.
lead_paragraph: Nietzsche believed that if only a Dostoyevsky had been among the apostles who followed Jesus, someone who understood the environment in which “the scum of society, nervous maladies and ‘childish’ idiocy keep a tryst,” we might have been spared centuries of ovine idiocy. One genius could have given us a work of ennobling art. Instead, we got 12 bleating sheep and one filthy religion.

headline: At Louis Vuitton and Valentino, Mapping the Season’s Genome
abstract: Miu Miu, Iris van Herpen and Moncler Gamme Rouge complete the fall 2016 women’s shows.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A long, strange season it has been. One filled with ambiguity, rumor and infighting (Show now, sell now! Over my dead body!), that aside from some discernible trends — an elongated silhouette; leopard; the continuing popularity of lingerie dresses; the haute puffa jacket — has left most questions as yet unresolved.

headline: Out of Shape at 18, at Risk for Future Diabetes
abstract: Being out of shape at age 18 may increase your risk for eventually developing Type 2 diabetes, regardless of your weight and family history.
lead_paragraph: Being out of shape at age 18 may increase your risk for eventually developing Type 2 diabetes, regardless of your weight and family history, a new study says.

headline: Priyanka Chopra of ‘Quantico’ Shares Her Beauty Tricks
abstract: The actress, who stars in the new ABC drama, follows a beauty regimen that’s a mix of Indian D.I.Y. and favorite Western products.
lead_paragraph: The actress Priyanka Chopra, 33, made a career in Bollywood before becoming the first South Asian woman to lead an American network series — that is, the ABC drama “Quantico.” Though she is currently filming in Montreal for the show, which has been renewed for a second season, she is more often “based on a plane,” she said. Ms. Chopra was born in Jamshedpur, India, but was also raised in Newton, Mass., and Queens. Her beauty regimen is a hybrid of Indian D.I.Y. and Western favorites.

headline: Orsay Museum President Is Reappointed, but to a Shortened Term
abstract: The French Culture Ministry announced that Guy Cogeval, the president of the Musée d’Orsay, would be reappointed to his post – but for only one year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Culture Ministry announced on Wednesday that Guy Cogeval, the president of the Musée d’Orsay in Paris since 2008, would be reappointed to his post – but for only one year rather than the expected three.

headline: Republican Delegate Math Favors Donald Trump After Latest Wins
abstract: After winning Michigan, Mississippi and Hawaii, Mr. Trump needs about 54 percent of outstanding delegates; Ted Cruz needs 62 percent.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump drew closer to grasping the Republican presidential nomination with his victories in three states Tuesday night, and the chances of party leaders’ wresting it from his hands at a contested convention were a bit more remote on Wednesday.

headline: Tammy Duckworth and Backers Denounce G.O.P. Tweet as Insensitive
abstract: A Republican committee deleted its post that said the Iraq veteran — and double amputee — has a “sad record of not standing up for our veterans.”
lead_paragraph: The tweet, sent by a branch of the Republican Party, had even jaded social-media users gasping.

headline: Missouri Senate Approves Bill Protecting Foes of Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Republicans broke a filibuster by Democrats, passing a bill that would shield religious groups and businesses from having to facilitate same-sex weddings.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — A bill to give some of the nation’s broadest legal protections to opponents of same-sex marriage took a crucial step forward in Missouri on Wednesday, winning approval in the State Senate after Republicans used a rare procedural move to break a 39-hour filibuster by Democrats.

headline: For Fall, Chanel Brings Out the Classics
abstract: At Paris Fashion Week, Karl Lagerfeld presented layers of tweed, piles of pearls, ladylike gloves, prim handbags and delightful bags.
lead_paragraph: At Paris Fashion Week, Karl Lagerfeld presented layers of tweed, piles of pearls, ladylike gloves, prim handbags and delightful bags.

headline: Anxious Dramas for the Age of Trump and Sanders
abstract: This year’s fractious, frightening election cycle — and the surprising rise of Donald J. Trump and Senator Bernie Sanders — is a referendum of sorts on the shrinking of the American middle class. Behind the anger, though, is pain — and a number of recent plays are mining that vein.
lead_paragraph: One by one, they make their confused, anxious, sometimes mysterious departures. Husband and wife, their two daughters and one daughter’s boyfriend, a grandmother suffering from dementia, rolled off in her wheelchair, until the stage before us is a darkened void.

headline: ‘The Secret Life of the American Musical,’ by Jack Viertel
abstract: A longtime theater professional explains what makes musicals work..
lead_paragraph: Anyone for whom touring ancient ruins on the Greek island of Delos summons images of Nathan Lane in a toga singing “Everybody Ought to Have a Maid” from “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum” is my kind of die-hard musical theater fan.

headline: Bookshelf: Women Making History
abstract: New picture books introduce children to the nation’s first woman detective, an aviation pioneer, a groundbreaking photographer and more.
lead_paragraph: New picture books introduce children to the nation’s first woman detective, an aviation pioneer, a groundbreaking photographer and more.

headline: Killer Whale From ‘Blackfish’ Film Is Ailing, SeaWorld Says
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The prognosis is poor for the 35-year-old orca, Tilikum, who has been involved in the deaths of three people, drawing criticism of the whale shows.
lead_paragraph: Tilikum, the orca whose killing of a trainer at a SeaWorld park in Orlando became the focus of the documentary “Blackfish,” has been found to have a respiratory disease that could likely end in death, his caretakers said.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders’s upset victory over Hillary Clinton in Michigan has added intrigue to the Democratic debate in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders will convene in Miami for the second Democratic presidential debate of the week on Wednesday night, ahead of big primaries in Florida and Ohio next Tuesday. Their previous encounter was a testy affair, as the candidates clashed over the economy, guns and campaign finance. While Mr. Sanders won in an upset over Mrs. Clinton in the Michigan primary on Tuesday, her delegate lead still widened because of her victory in Mississippi.

headline: The Hydra Gets a New Mouth With Every Meal
abstract: Every time a hydra wants to eat, it rips a hole through the center of its body’s outer layer. After dinner, it closes back up.
lead_paragraph: This week’s GIF science lesson might give you a newfound appreciation for how simple it is for most humans to consume a shrimp cocktail.

headline: The Dangers of Being a Female Sportscaster
abstract: Erin Andrews’s ordeal with a stalker was only one example of how frightening obsessed fans can be for female sportscasters.
lead_paragraph: Even before revelations that the reporter Erin Andrews was secretly videotaped naked by a stalker in a hotel room in 2008, female sportscasters understood how frightening obsessed fans can be.

headline: In Design, Now Is the Time for All Materials to be Treated Equally
abstract: It’s never been more clear that authenticity in decorating is a fallacy, writes the interior designer Nicky Haslam.
lead_paragraph: It’s never been more clear that authenticity in decorating is a fallacy, writes the interior designer Nicky Haslam.

headline: Analyzing the Elements of Art | Five Ways to Think About Color
abstract: The fourth piece in our Seven Elements of Art series, which helps students make connections between formal art instruction and our daily visual culture.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fourth piece in our Seven Elements of Art series, in which Kristin Farr of KQED Art School helps students make connections between formal art instruction and our daily visual culture.

headline: Mobile Games to Make Time Fly
abstract: Here are some of the best games to take the boredom out of unexpected lulls in your day.
lead_paragraph: WHAT are the best mobile games to play these days? I decided to find out recently when a train I was riding came to an unexpected stop between two stations and there was no cellphone signal. That meant no Internet for distraction, no Twitter or Spotify to while away the time.

headline: Gelsey Kirkland, Ever Fierce and Surging Forward
abstract: The dancer’s ballet academy keeps growing, and its small studio company will be performing its first original, evening-length work, “Stealing Time.”
lead_paragraph: Given that there are some dozen ballet schools in New York, it’s striking how quickly the Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet has found its niche.

headline: Unappetizing Experiment Explores Tools’ Role in Humans’ Bigger Brains
abstract: Scientists at Harvard concluded that stone tools that broke down food could have helped early human relatives conserve energy, aiding in their evolution.
lead_paragraph: Scientists recently turned Harvard’s Skeletal Biology Laboratory into a pop-up restaurant. It would have fared very badly on Yelp.

headline: Reflective Spring Fashion Shines Bright
abstract: Head-to-toe looks in everything from lamé to leather aren’t merely metallic — they’re marvels of light and texture.
lead_paragraph: Head-to-toe looks in everything from lamé to leather aren’t merely metallic — they’re marvels of light and texture.

headline: Hans Abrahamsen: Fame and Snow Falling on a Composer
abstract: A Danish composer comes into his own at 63 with ethereal Minimalist works, some that use pieces of paper for percussion.
lead_paragraph: In the final moments of Hans Abrahamsen’s song cycle “let me tell you,” a key instrument emerges: a single piece of paper. After the soprano’s ethereal voice has faded and as the rich orchestration dissipates, a percussionist slowly rubs it in circular motions on the surface of a bass drum. Mr. Abrahamsen writes in the score that the effect should sound “like walking in the snow.”

headline: Growth of Financial Tech Industry Requires Unified Regulation
abstract: American regulators have not kept pace with the explosion of “fintech” firms, partly because of an outdated patchwork of state rules.
lead_paragraph: America’s financial technology industry has exploded in recent years, but regulators have not kept pace.

headline: A Brief Visit With My Inner Diesel
abstract: A new flagship remains committed to its war on denim.
lead_paragraph: In the back of the new Diesel flagship on Madison Avenue, near the jeans bar, which breaks down the company’s offerings into various cuts (Slim? Sure. Tapered? Fine. Carrot? Ummmmmm.), there is a small museumlike display paying homage to the brand’s long-running wrestling match with denim.

lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collection that was presented Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Switzerland’s Office of the Attorney General announced on Wednesday that it had enlisted the help of French authorities in its continuing criminal investigation of Sepp Blatter, the former president of FIFA, world soccer’s ruling body.

headline: Views of the Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: Thousands across the world watched the eclipse on Wednesday, with many capturing captivating images.
lead_paragraph: Crowds across Southeast Asia and the west Pacific gathered on Wednesday to witness the total solar eclipse. Thousands more from around the world tuned in to livestreams and watched as the distant daytime skies darkened.

headline: Introducing Matthew Zapruder, the Magazine’s New Poetry Editor
abstract: He succeeds Natasha Trethewey in this annually rotating position.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Zapruder is the new poetry editor for the magazine, succeeding Natasha Trethewey in this annually rotating position. His first selection, “You Throw a Stone” by Juan Felipe Herrera, appeared in the March 6 issue.

headline: Germany’s Embrace of Migrants Spawns Rise of Far-Right Leader
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Elections']

lead_paragraph: MANNHEIM, Germany — In the current tussle for the future of Germany, Frauke Petry is what you might call the anti-Angela Merkel.

abstract: The commando attack occurred at a village 40 miles west of Mogadishu on Tuesday night, with the help of American military advisers and helicopters.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Only days after American aircraft struck a Shabab training camp in Somalia, American Special Operations forces and Somali troops carried out a raid against Shabab fighters, officials said Wednesday, in a sign of heightened pressure against the militant group.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The route that more than one million migrants have used to traverse southeastern Europe was effectively shut down Wednesday, when four Balkan nations stopped waving the migrants through on their journey northward.

abstract: When a computer beats the champion of the world's most complex game, does it mean machines are gaining the upper hand on humans?

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida who ended his presidential bid after a string of disappointing finishes, is planning to meet with three of the remaining Republican candidates while they’re in Miami for the Republican debate on Thursday night.

keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Seniority Systems']
abstract: Thousands marched in Paris on Wednesday to protest proposals that would make it easier to fire workers, but that the government says could mean more jobs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Firing an employee in France often means a court date, months of hearings and hefty payouts under the country’s 3,400-page labor code. Employers hate the thick book.

abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders faced off in a debate for the second time this week. Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport provided real-time analysis.

headline: One Young Artist’s 21st-Century Baroque
abstract: Jesse Mockrin’s new paintings seize on elements of work by masters like Fragonard and Boucher — and yet feel entirely new.
lead_paragraph: The work in the Los Angeles-based artist Jesse Mockrin’s upcoming solo show at Night Gallery, “The Progress of Love,” looks pointedly familiar — and yet entirely new. Her saturated oil paintings involve a healthy dose of pastiche, borrowing from late-Baroque masters, including Jean-Honoré Fragonard and Francois Boucher.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Mr. Morales, who shot Mark Carson, a gay man, nearly three years ago, had claimed that he acted in self-defense.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex Crimes', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'New Year']
abstract: A 26-year-old Algerian and a 31-year-old Iraqi were detained in the investigation into hundreds of sex attacks and robberies on Dec. 31 in the German city.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A day after publishing the first photos from chaotic New Year’s Eve celebrations that descended into mass sexual attacks and robberies, the police in Cologne on Wednesday announced the detention of two men suspected of committing some of more than 1,000 assaults reported from that night.

headline: Padma Lakshmi Opens Up About Rushdie in Memoir
abstract: The host of “Top Chef” gets deeply personal about her marriage to Salman Rushdie, motherhood and being Indian.
lead_paragraph: Padma Lakshmi, the cookbook author and reality television star, has a signature repertoire as host of “Top Chef” on Bravo. It plays out at key moments in the competition, when anxious chefs stand opposite her as she tastes their dishes, their faces scrutinizing hers for some clue about what she is thinking.

headline: Tairod Pugh, Ex-U.S. Serviceman, Is Found Guilty of Trying to Aid ISIS
abstract: Mr. Pugh, on trial in Brooklyn, was convicted of seeking to support a foreign terrorist organization after trying to travel to Syria.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury on Wednesday found a former United States serviceman guilty of trying to travel to Syria to join the Islamic State, the first such case involving the terrorist group to reach a verdict in a United States courtroom.

headline: Review: In ‘The Violet Hour,’ Great Writers Facing the Inevitable
abstract: This Katie Roiphe book becomes a nifty twofer, a meditation on how five authors experienced death both in vivo, so to speak, and in their art.
lead_paragraph: In a 2004 television interview, Bill Moyers told his guest, Maurice Sendak, that he’d cheated death, thanks to his sublime body of work. “Most of us will live only as long as our grandchildren remember us,” Mr. Moyers said. “But you will never die.”

headline: Awash in Empty Homes, China Asks Migrant Workers to Settle Down
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Beijing hopes to turns the country’s hundreds of millions of itinerant laborers into homeowners as the slumping property market drags on the economy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Migrant workers are the unsung heroes of China’s economic miracle. Numbering more than 270 million, they abandon their impoverished farms and villages to move to the cities, where they run the factories and build the highways and high-rises that have made China’s growth the envy of the world.

headline: If Jack Dorsey Has a Problem Child Among His 2 Companies, It Isn’t Square

lead_paragraph: For months, a prime question facing Jack Dorsey has been how he will juggle being the chief executive of two complicated companies he helped found — Square, the recently public mobile-payments company, and Twitter, the ailing social network in search of new users.

headline: Polish Court Strikes Down Law Limiting Its Powers, Inflaming a Crisis
abstract: The right-wing government of Poland said it would ignore a ruling by the Constitutional Tribunal, the only court empowered to review national laws.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — A political crisis in Poland entered a new and dangerous phase on Wednesday, as the country’s Constitutional Tribunal struck down a new law limiting its powers. The nation’s right-wing government, which adopted the law in December, said it would ignore the court’s ruling.

headline: Head of VW’s U.S. Unit Is Out, and Dealers Are Alarmed
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling']

lead_paragraph: The head of Volkswagen’s American operations, a central figure in the carmaker’s effort to repair relations with dealers and customers after an emissions scandal, unexpectedly stepped down on Wednesday.

headline: New Procedure Allows Kidney Transplants From Any Donor
abstract: The procedure, reported in The New England Journal of Medicine, involves a reboot of a patient’s immune system and could also work for lung and liver transplants.
lead_paragraph: In the anguishing wait for a new kidney, tens of thousands of patients on waiting lists may never find a match because their immune systems will reject almost any transplanted organ. Now, in a large national study that experts are calling revolutionary, researchers have found a way to get them the desperately needed procedure.

headline: Fall Looks to Order From Jonathan Simkhai and Phelan
abstract: Smythson celebrates with an exhibition of artifacts, Paul & Joe teams with Cosabella, and more.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a study in contrasts: On Thursday and Friday, the private shopping salon Suite 1521 will host an event with sweet fall looks from the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner Jonathan Simkhai, like a lace appliqué bustier dress ($795) styled over lace hem culottes ($465) for preorder, alongside distressed Golden Goose Super Star sneakers ($590). Membership information at suite1521.com. At 980 Madison Avenue, third floor.

headline: Meldonium Ban Hits Russian Athletes Hard
abstract: In the two days since Maria Sharapova’s announcement, seven Russian athletes have confirmed testing positive for meldonium.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The fallout from Maria Sharapova’s failed drug test has ensnared her native Russia as it becomes clear that the banned substance found in her system is creating wider problems for Russian sports.

headline: What It Takes for This Actor to Wear That ‘Red Speedo’
abstract: Alex Breaux, formerly a Harvard wide receiver who opted for an acting career, plays a smarter-than-he-looks swimmer in Lucas Hnath’s play.
lead_paragraph: Alex Breaux faced a twofold challenge in portraying Ray, a champion swimmer in the dark and twisty “Red Speedo” at New York Theater Workshop. He had to look convincing as an aspiring Olympian who spends the whole show in the swimsuit of the title. And he needed to, well, play dumb — at least outside the water, where his character is caught up in a doping scandal that could derail a lucrative future.

headline: How George Martin Changed Pop Music Production
abstract: Notable producers discuss Mr. Martin, who helped define a pop music producer’s role as equal parts technical master and creative enabler.
lead_paragraph: For the legions of musicians, producers and music executives who carefully followed everything the Beatles did, one name on the band’s records mattered perhaps just as much as those of the Fab Four themselves: George Martin.

headline: Airline Fees Are Out of Hand, a Bill From Senators Says
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Transportation', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Legislators have introduced a bill that would limit airline fees for checked bags, ticket changes and cancellations.
lead_paragraph: What once was free on airlines now often translates to fees.

headline: George Martin and the Beatles: A Producer’s Impact, in Five Songs
abstract: The contributions that Mr. Martin, who died Tuesday at 90, made to the Beatles’ recorded catalog were crucial. A look at a few of his musical fingerprints.
lead_paragraph: When we hear a great recording, we tend to think of the music as having sprung fully developed from the imagination of the musician or band that cut the tracks. But that ignores the role of the producer, who translates the musician’s vision into the sound we experience.

headline: The Smollett Family Business: Acting and Activism
abstract: Jussie Smollett, of “Empire,” and Jurnee Smollett-Bell, in “Underground,” a new WGN show about runaway slaves, have four other siblings —and at one point they were all in the same ABC sitcom.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Jussie Smollett and Jurnee Smollett-Bell were growing up, bouncing with their parents and four siblings between New York and Los Angeles, as the kids pursued careers in modeling, acting and music, their downtime was just another chance for performance and togetherness.

headline: Listen to 19 Songs, Straight From the Fall/Winter 2016 Runways
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Music', 'New York Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Our favorite tracks from the New York, London, Milan and Paris fashion weeks.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Month comes to an end today in Paris, and we’ve seen plenty of trends on the runways: from extra-warm shearling and new plays on puffer coats to reimagined check and leopard patterns, plus deliciously goth black velvet and lace.

headline: Create YouTube-Worthy Videos With a Few Simple Tools
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Cameras', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Expensive equipment isn’t necessary to make videos that attract million of views. Gadgets starting at less than $50 will do just fine.
lead_paragraph: To be the next big YouTube star, you need the right tools. But before you break the bank on expensive video equipment, start with these simple devices. You can always upgrade later when you become famous.

headline: Second Wachowski Sibling Comes Out as Transgender Woman
abstract: Lilly Wachowski — who with her sister, Lana, are the first major Hollywood directors to make the transition public — says she was pressured by The Daily Mail.
lead_paragraph: A second sibling from the film-directing duo that created “The Matrix” series came out as a transgender woman on Tuesday after a reporter from The Daily Mail appeared on her front porch to ask questions about her gender identity.

headline: Marco Rubio Says His Children Were ‘Embarrassed’ By His Taunts of Donald Trump
abstract: Though he stood by his criticism of Mr. Trump’s business record, Mr. Rubio said he had come to regret ridiculing Mr. Trump as small-handed, orange-faced and wimpy.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said he had come to regret what became one of the most sensational moments of his campaign: his schoolyard taunting of Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘Plastic,’ at MoMA, Is on the Floor and the Stairs
abstract: This live installation by Maria Hassabi features performers in poses that attract the curious and even gives security guards a role of sorts.
lead_paragraph: “Is she real? Is she alive? Does she need help? Call 911. Is she breathing? Is she a sculpture? Is this art?”

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump, Solar Eclipse
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: China’s Harsh Child Discipline, Through the Lens of Domestic Violence
abstract: The continued use of corporal punishment by Chinese parents has stoked new debate in light of a recent law against abuse within the family.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Trying to be helpful, a Chinese father at our sons’ elementary school advised me to slap my child’s face if he was being recalcitrant. He made a slicing hand gesture. “This is what I do,” he said.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 9: Convention Time
abstract: This was ‘House of Cards’ at its most fast-paced and entertaining.
lead_paragraph: President Frank Underwood said he wanted an open Democratic National Convention that gave people a show. In this episode, that’s exactly what he and we get: 45 minutes of “House of Cards” at its most fast-paced and entertaining.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
