headline: Review: Nathan Lane, You’ve Got a Part (This Time) in ‘White Rabbit Red Rabbit’
abstract: The play, which is performed just once a week, features a new actor who doesn’t know the script.
lead_paragraph: For all I know, as I write these words, Nathan Lane is lying dead on a chaise longue on the stage of the Westside Theater.

headline: Review: ‘Flaked’ Features Will Arnett as a Dude of a Certain Age
abstract: Laughs in this new Netflix series come from the self-regard of two characters in Los Angeles who fancy themselves irresistible to young women.
lead_paragraph: Will Arnett is a man of many hats, but the one he’s trying to wear in his new Netflix series, “Flaked,” would be a better fit on a 20-something college dropout.

headline: John Kasich Sees Three-Way Race Without Marco Rubio
abstract: The Ohio governor suggested that the Republican contest was now a three-man race among Donald J. Trump and Ted Cruz and himself, casting aside Marco Rubio.
lead_paragraph: PALATINE, Ill. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio suggested on Wednesday that the Republican contest was now a three-man race among Donald J. Trump, Ted Cruz and himself, casting aside Marco Rubio as he talked about his competition.

headline: Review: ‘Bosch’ Returns a Detective to the Force
abstract: Drawn from Michael Connelly’s California noir novels, the second season of this Amazon series starts by having the protagonist come off a suspension.
lead_paragraph: Season 2 of Amazon’s “Bosch” begins the way Season 1 did — with a car gliding down a Los Angeles hillside, the lights of the city twinkling in the background and a violent death just around the corner. No other current series is as conversant with the images, the moods and, sometimes, the clichés of Southern California noir.

headline: Mutual Funds Oppose S.E.C.’s Plan for a Bigger Cash Cushion
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: David W. Grim, who leads the agency’s asset management division, is pushing to increase funds’ liquidity cushions so investors can sell out quickly.
lead_paragraph: At an industry conference last week, the lead regulator for the Securities and Exchange Commission’s asset management division came under fire.

headline: Sanders Surprises
abstract: Michigan strengthened the candidate’s argument that he is a very real and viable alternative to Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Jaws dropped Tuesday night as Bernie Sanders defied the embarrassingly incorrect polls and shocked election watchers with a narrow but important upset of Hillary Clinton in Michigan.

headline: Pop Warner Settles Lawsuit Over Player Who Had C.T.E.
abstract: The case could have broad implications on youth sports if it prompts other families to accuse leagues and organizations of not doing enough to protect their children.
lead_paragraph: Pop Warner, the nation’s largest youth football league, has settled a lawsuit with a family whose son played in the league and later committed suicide and was found to have a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated hits to the head.

headline: A Cozy Bar to Call Home in Ridgewood, Queens
abstract: Filled with books, a fireplace and comfy couches, the Bad Old Days evokes a Midwestern family’s lake house.
lead_paragraph: Bars that seem like communal living rooms play an important role in this often inhospitable city. For settlers in up-and-coming Ridgewood, Queens, the Bad Old Days is becoming such a homey hangout. One night it looked like a house party. “This place is cozy,” said the leader of a foursome. Sonja Lutnicki, one of the bar’s young owners, said, “We get that a lot.”

headline: Jets Add Running Back Matt Forte
abstract: The team moved swiftly to find a new starting running back after losing Chris Ivory to the Jaguars by agreeing to a contract with Forte, who spent the previous eight seasons with the Bears.
lead_paragraph: The Jets moved swiftly to find a new starting running back, agreeing to a contract with Matt Forte, who spent the last eight seasons with Chicago. Forte ranks among the league’s most durable and versatile backs, and both attributes appealed to the Jets, who snagged him after losing Chris Ivory to Jacksonville.

headline: Howl Gallery Resurrects the Punk-Era East Village
abstract: The pre-gentrification spirit of the neighborhood is the subject of a new gallery named after Allen Ginsberg’s epic Beat poem.
lead_paragraph: Downtown survivors who are mourning the bohemian spirit of the old East Village will be delighted to know of a gallery devoted to preserving its memory, gender-bending warts and all.

headline: Ted Cruz Plays Up Cuban Heritage Before Florida Primary
abstract: Campaigning in Miami, he sounded a lot like the other Republican Cuban-American from the Senate whose presidential campaign he is looking to end.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ted Cruz bounded onstage to a seldom-heard introduction — “the first Hispanic president of the United States” — and spoke later of his “abuelo and abuela” in Cuba.

headline: Gawker Editor’s Testimony Stuns Courtroom in Hulk Hogan Trial
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Celebrities', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Privacy']
abstract: Albert J. Daulerio suggested in a deposition that celebrity sex tapes featuring children over 4 could be newsworthy. Gawker later said his comment was sarcastic.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — A palpable sense of shock rippled through a courtroom here Wednesday morning when the former editor in chief of Gawker.com was shown in a videotaped deposition suggesting that almost anything goes when it comes to the newsworthiness of celebrities’ sex videos.

headline: Rodarte’s Collaboration With & Other Stories, Lace Pants and More
abstract: Plus: big jewelry and British footwear.
lead_paragraph: Plus: big jewelry and British footwear.

headline: After Michigan Loss, Hillary Clinton Sharpens Message on Jobs and Trade
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s surprising victory came after he contended that he was the only candidate who had opposed free trade agreements that led to U.S. job losses.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — From the start of her presidential campaign 11 months ago, Hillary Clinton has presented an upbeat assessment of an improving economy, saying Wall Street and corporations would be held accountable, but must be part of the solution for all Americans to benefit from the country’s prosperity.

headline: Nasdaq to Buy International Securities Exchange
abstract: Nasdaq’s $1.1 billion deal with Deutsche Börse for an options exchange operator comes as even bigger takeovers loom.
lead_paragraph: Nasdaq agreed on Wednesday to buy the International Securities Exchange for $1.1 billion from Deutsche Börse of Germany, in yet another deal among exchange operators as even bigger takeovers loom.

headline: A Lesson in Hillary Clinton’s Loss in Michigan
abstract: If she hopes to unify Democrats as the party nominee, trying to tarnish Bernie Sanders is not the way to go.
lead_paragraph: The split decisions in Tuesday’s primaries make it clear that the nominating contests in both parties could last for months.

headline: Brooklyn Man Who Posed as Immigration Lawyer Gets 2 to 4 Years
abstract: Howard Seidler, who was caught by an undercover investigator, is the first to be convicted of immigrant-services fraud, a felony charge created by the state last year.
lead_paragraph: He posted ads around his neighborhood in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, billing himself as a lawyer specializing in immigration cases. To burnish his credentials, on ads and business cards, Howard Seidler appended an alphabet of suffixes to his name: Esq., J.D. and Ph.D.

headline: Berkeley Law School Dean Was Harasser, a Suit Says
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Law Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Many universities, including Berkeley, have adopted strict policies about sexual misconduct and taken steps to train everyone from staff to students in how to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: The dean of the law school of the University of California, Berkeley, sexually harassed his executive assistant over a period of several months, and then was allowed to stay on the job out of concern for his career after an internal investigation found her sexual harassment complaints to be justified, according to a lawsuit announced Wednesday.

headline: At Yale, Basketball Success Collides With Sexual Misconduct Case
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The Bulldogs ended a long N.C.A.A. tournament drought, but many students are upset over the university’s support for a player who was dismissed last month without a public explanation.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — This should be the Yale Bulldogs’ crowning moment — after a 54-year wait, the men’s basketball team brought an unshared Ivy League title home and with it an invitation to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Democrats Target Trump U. in Digital Ads Aimed at March 15 Voters
abstract: A Democratic National Committee ad aimed at Facebook users in Ohio, Florida and North Carolina is the first in a series against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Negative advertising has been raining down on Donald J. Trump from his opponents, from super PACs, from issue groups. Now, through a digital ad campaign, the Democratic National Committee is joining the fray.

headline: Martha Wright, Who Played Leading Roles in Beloved Musicals, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. Wright replaced Mary Martin in “South Pacific” and “The Sound of Music,” logging more than 1,200 performances, yet not becoming a household name.
lead_paragraph: Martha Wright, who played well over 1,200 performances in leading musical roles on Broadway, nearly all of them as a replacement for Mary Martin, died on March 1 in Newburyport, Mass. She was 92.

headline: N.J. Transit and New York Businesses Make Strike Contingency Plans
abstract: As a deadline approaches, the transportation agency is increasing its warnings to commuters and city businesses are preparing for the worst.
lead_paragraph: The worst-case situations are sounding dire.

headline: North Korea Fires Test Missiles, Defying U.N. Ban
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The two projectiles, believed to be Scud-C missiles, flew about 310 miles and crashed into the sea off North Korea’s east coast, a South Korean statement said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea flouted United Nations resolutions on Thursday by launching two ballistic missiles toward the sea between the Korean Peninsula and Japan, the South Korean military said in a statement.

headline: New York Assemblywoman Is Punished After Sexual Relationship With Aide
abstract: Angela M. Wozniak, a first-term Republican from western New York, succeeded a Democrat who resigned after being accused of unwanted sexual advances.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A state assemblywoman from suburban Buffalo was punished on Wednesday after an ethics investigation found that she had had a sexual relationship with a staff member in her office, then retaliated against him when he complained about her behavior.

headline: Series of Errors Allowed Shooting Suspect, in U.S. Illegally, to Remain
abstract: Pablo A. Serrano-Vitorino, a Mexican man accused of killing five people, should have been jailed or deported last year, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — A Mexican man who stands accused of murdering five people and was captured Wednesday was in the country illegally and should have been jailed or deported last year, federal immigration officials said, but three times in less than a year, he was arrested and allowed to go free because of procedural errors.

headline: Chris Mullin, the Red Storm’s Savior, Instead Finds There Is a Lot of Work to Do
abstract: Chris Mullin, an all-American at St. John’s 30 years ago, returned to his alma mater and had a difficult first season as coach.
lead_paragraph: When St. John’s lost by 32 points in a preseason exhibition game to St. Thomas Aquinas, a Division II team, some saw it as a teachable moment for the team’s new coach, Chris Mullin, a stumble he could turn into a springboard.

headline: Holding Their Noses, Louisiana Officials Act to Narrow State Budget Gaps
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republican-controlled Legislature approved tax increases and budget cuts during a special session called by John Bel Edwards, a Democrat in his first year as governor.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Facing the threat of layoffs, cancellation of university classes and a suspension of health care services, state lawmakers avoided more than $900 million in budget cuts by passing a package of tax increases and spending reductions Wednesday in the closing moments of a special session.

headline: Groups Scrutinize White House Plan to Cut Drug Costs in Medicare
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration touched off a tempest with its plan to test new ways of paying for prescription drugs under Medicare.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration touched off a tempest on Wednesday with its plan to test new ways of paying for prescription drugs under Medicare, widely seen as the administration’s first serious attempt to rein in drug spending.

headline: Big 12 Emerges As the Mightiest of Them All
abstract: The conference’s teams went 28-15 this season against opponents from the other five power conferences.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — College basketball’s instant classic moment this season came relatively early, when Oklahoma played Kansas on Jan. 4 at the historic Allen Fieldhouse in Lawrence, Kan.

headline: John Gutfreund, 86, Dies; Ran Wall Street Investment Firm at Its Apex
abstract: Mr. Gutfreund transformed Salomon Brothers into one of the world’s largest securities traders, but left the industry in disgrace.
lead_paragraph: John H. Gutfreund, whose aggressive leadership of Salomon Brothers and extravagant lifestyle personified the meteoric rise and fall of Wall Street moguls in the heady 1980s, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Auction Official Pleads Guilty in Scheme to Smuggle Wildlife Products Worth $1 Million
abstract: Prosecutors said that Joseph Chait, who works in California, falsely claimed on customs forms that items made of rhinoceros horn or elephant ivory were made of bone, wood or plastic.
lead_paragraph: An auction house official from Beverly Hills, Calif., pleaded guilty in a New York City court for his part in a scheme to traffic items made of rhinoceros horn, elephant ivory and coral worth at least $1 million, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Continues to Deport Central American Migrants
abstract: The Obama administration is moving ahead with deportations of migrants fleeing from three violence-racked countries in Central America, despite a furor among refugee advocates.
lead_paragraph: Since late January, the immigration authorities have arrested 336 migrants from Central America for deportation, part of a continuing operation to toughen border enforcement, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said Wednesday.

headline: As Mets Rise, Curtis Granderson Has Even More Reason to Be Upbeat
abstract: After four years as a Yankee, Granderson, who turns 35 next week, is savoring his time with defending National League champions.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The four older gentlemen, fans with field passes, were standing by the Mets’ dugout Wednesday morning when Curtis Granderson, bat in hand, bounded down the steps after taking swings in the batting cage for his spring training debut.

headline: Ex-President of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Faces Charges
abstract: The specific charges filed on Wednesday were unclear, but they were connected to claims of money laundering and misrepresentation of assets involving a luxury apartment.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prosecutors filed charges on Wednesday against former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, one of Brazil’s most prominent political figures, shaking the country’s already anxious political establishment.

headline: Tate Modern Announces Show of Photographs From Elton John Collection
abstract: The musician has collected photographs for 25 years, including vintage prints by Man Ray, Berenice Abbott and André Kertész.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rare vintage prints by Man Ray, Berenice Abbott, André Kertész, Alexandr Rodchenko and Edward Steichen will be part of a major exhibition drawn from Elton John’s collection of photography, the Tate Modern announced on Wednesday. The exhibition, “The Radical Eye: Modernist Photography from the Sir Elton John Collection,” will run Nov. 10 through May 7, 2017, and will show around 150 works created between the 1920s and the 1950s.

headline: Shopping Spree Shores Up Defense, but Giants Have Plenty of Holes to Fill
abstract: In a 24-hour period, Giants General Manager Jerry Reese committed about $204 million in contracts for defensive players, with $114 million of that sum guaranteed to be paid out.
lead_paragraph: In January, days after a third successive Giants season ended with another losing record, John Mara, a Giants co-owner, said his team’s defensive roster lacked talent. Then Mara pointedly said it was General Manager Jerry Reese’s responsibility to fix the disaster the defense had become.

headline: P.S.G. Beats Chelsea in Champions League, and Its Brash Attitude Is Rewarded
abstract: In one of soccer’s best rivalries, Paris St.-Germain ousted Chelsea from the Champions League.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — About 30 minutes before kickoff at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday, the band of visiting Paris St.-Germain fans in the far end of the stadium sang out in unison. “On est chez nous,” they crooned in French, bragging to the Chelsea fans, “We are at home.”

headline: Queens Man Accused of Amassing ‘Arsenal of Deadly Weapons’
abstract: A search of Lee Bergman’s apartment in the Rockaways uncovered a stockpile that included multiple revolvers, rifles and shotguns, an AK-47 and an AR-15, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: In a large safe at his apartment near the boardwalk in the Rockaways, Queens, the authorities said on Wednesday, Lee Bergman had amassed a stockpile of weapons.

headline: In Mets’ Starting Rotation, Yankees See Where They Strive to Be
abstract: Assembling the Mets’ low-cost, high-powered staff required patience, and while the Yankees do not have that luxury, they are excited about the hard-throwing prospect James Kaprielian.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — There are few general managers in baseball who would not readily trade their starting rotations for the Mets’ low-cost, high-powered staff.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Seesawing Libidos
abstract: The actor Stephen Bogardus reads an essay about a medication that leads to a hypersexualized wife, and a husband struggling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: In the ninth episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actor Stephen Bogardus (currently co-starring in Steve Martin and Edie Brickell’s musical “Bright Star” on Broadway) reads Marc Jaffe’s essay “Finding Equilibrium in Seesawing Libidos,” about a medication that leads to a hypersexualized wife, and a husband puffing to keep up. In time, the mismatch subsides, leaving them partners in a bigger way. Look for the “play” button below.

headline: “Do You Spell Your Name With a V, Herr Wagner?”
abstract: Ed Sessa uses words of vim and vigor.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE —This was a textbook Thursday wordplay grid. As is often the case, I think that if you got it, you got it fast, but it was possible to work around the trickery until it made itself evident. I became wise to it on the southwest corner, knowing A PRIORI, LOW TIDE, SHARI and AGASSI – the cross had to be REVVING UP at that point. You might have found it easier on the diagonal corner with ADULATE, RENEWER and TECH SAVVY. Either way, once I had my eye out for the VV/W swap things went pretty well.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I hung up, called downstairs and said: ‘I got a really threatening call. Can you trace it?’ They said it was coming from inside the hotel. Then he called back — it was so chilling and terrifying.”

headline: Clinton and Sanders Joust in Democratic Debate
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Deportation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders sparred over immigration and the auto bailout.
lead_paragraph: After Bernie Sanders’s surprise victory in Michigan, he and Hillary Clinton sparred tonight in a Democratic presidential debate. I’m sparing you an analysis, but here are my tweets as the debate progressed: the first rough, rough draft of history!

headline: Legislators Seek to Promote Diversity at Elite Public High Schools
abstract: A $5 million initiative in Albany would help prepare black and Hispanic students for the admissions test for Brooklyn Tech and similar New York City high schools.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to increase the number of black and Hispanic students at New York City’s elite public high schools, a group of Democratic state legislators has proposed a $5 million package of initiatives aimed at preparing those students for the eighth-grade admissions test.

headline: Zika Vaccine Still Years Away, W.H.O. Says
abstract: Despite efforts to speed up development, a vaccine to combat the virus may come too late for the current outbreak in Latin America and the Caribbean, health experts said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — More than 60 research institutes and companies are working on products to combat the spread of the Zika virus, the World Health Organization said Wednesday, but a vaccine is likely to take years to develop and may come too late for the outbreak now sweeping across Latin America and the Caribbean.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders attacked each other’s records and argued over who would better represent Hispanic voters’ interests.

headline: Brazil Adjusts Guidelines for Diagnosing Defect Linked to Zika
abstract: Officials adopted stricter guidelines to determine when babies have been born with abnormally small heads, a step expected to reduce the number of false positives for microcephaly.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazilian officials said on Wednesday that they had tightened the guidelines used to determine when babies have been born with abnormally small heads, a step taken in part to reduce the number of false positives for microcephaly, a condition that can lead to brain damage.

headline: Hillary! Bernie! Debate!
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: We’ve gone from complaining that the Democrats wouldn’t meet enough times to wondering when the talking will stop.
lead_paragraph: Let’s give a hand to Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. After all we’ve been through with the Republicans, it’s nice to hear presidential candidates go at each other’s throat while they’re talking about where they stood on immigration issues in 2007.

headline: Driver Charged in Confrontation That Led to New York Officer’s Shooting
abstract: An 11-year Police Department veteran was shot by a fellow officer in Brooklyn when a driver began to move his vehicle while the detective was partly inside it.
lead_paragraph: The New York City police have charged the driver of a vehicle that crashed into a police car during a drug investigation in Brooklyn on Tuesday, a confrontation in which a plainclothes detective was shot in the shoulder by another officer.

headline: E.C.B.’s Bold Stimulus Takes Aim at Eurozone Economy
abstract: The European Central Bank announced a set of unexpected measures that will include, in effect, paying commercial banks to lend money to businesses and consumers.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Faced with a eurozone economy stubbornly resistant to revival, the European Central Bank on Thursday went where no central bank — at least no major one — had gone before.

headline: What to Watch Thursday

headline: Christian McBride, Newport Jazz Festival Star, Becomes a Backstage Player
abstract: The Grammy-winning jazz bassist, who has played on Newport’s stage many times, is poised to succeed George Wein as the festival’s artistic director.
lead_paragraph: Christian McBride made his first appearance at the Newport Jazz Festival in 1991, as the bassist in Jazz Futures, a youthful hard-bop wrecking crew. He was 19 then and has returned to the Newport stage many times since. Now, in a significant move, he is poised to become the festival’s new artistic director, taking the reins from the impresario George Wein.

headline: Migrants Working Far Away in European Fields
abstract: The workers’ lives is the subject of “Working Far Away,” which seeks to dispel myths that they “steal” jobs by showing the realities of their nonstop — and underpaid — labors.
lead_paragraph: The workers’ lives is the subject of “Working Far Away,” which seeks to dispel myths that they “steal” jobs by showing the realities of their nonstop — and underpaid — labors.

headline: Shooting That Killed 5 at Party Near Pittsburgh Was Planned, Police Say
abstract: The police said they were looking for two gunmen who attacked a party in Wilkinsburg, Pa. In addition to the dead, three people were wounded.
lead_paragraph: WILKINSBURG, Pa. — A shooting at a backyard party that killed five and wounded three — many of them related — in this suburb of Pittsburgh was planned and calculated, a prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Soros and Other Liberal Donors to Fund Bid to Spur Latino Voters
abstract: Strategists involved said the new spending would be the largest Democratic voter-turnout effort ever devoted exclusively to Latino and immigrant voters.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire George Soros and other liberal donors will bankroll a new $15 million campaign to mobilize Latinos and other immigrants this fall, hoping to channel outrage at the political rhetoric of Donald J. Trump and other Republicans into a surge of votes for Democratic candidates in November.

headline: Migrants Working Far Away in European Fields
abstract: The lives of migrant workers in Europe is the subject of “Working Far Away,” which seeks to dispel myths that they “steal” jobs by showing the realities of their nonstop — and underpaid — labors.
lead_paragraph: The sun showed no mercy, yet the asparagus workers kept bending, squatting and digging as if their lives depended on it.

headline: When Welfare Cuts Hit Sheppie the Guide Dog
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Welfare (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Food', 'Editorial Notebook']
abstract: Slashing benefit programs for the needy can lead to unexpected consequences.
lead_paragraph: For as long as poverty endures, there will be political candidates working to snag voters’ attention with vows of a “crackdown” on welfare abuses supposedly traceable to great throngs of people living high on the hog with taxpayer support. This year, Republicans in the New York State Legislature are proposing tighter controls on what the poor can buy with their Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) payment cards. “Luxury items” would be banned, including steak and lobster.

headline: How to Reduce Medicare Drug Costs
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Medicare', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Getting a handle on rising prices will require some experimentation.
lead_paragraph: Prescription drug spending in Medicare has been rising fast, but it is not completely clear what policies are driving the increases. The Obama administration hopes to find ways to control costs by testing different approaches to paying for the drugs.

headline: Stalling on Fuel Efficiency

abstract: The Obama administration’s fuel efficiency standards are in jeopardy as automakers build more gas-guzzling light trucks, S.U.V.s and minivans.

headline: ‘Crime Stories: Photography and Foul Play’ Is a Rogues’ Gallery
abstract: An exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art examines the role of photography in crime investigation.
lead_paragraph: There’s not a single uninteresting picture in “Crime Stories: Photography and Foul Play” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but as a whole exhibition it’s confused and confusing. Drawn from the museum’s collections, it includes scores of 19th- and 20th-century mug shots; pictures of crime scenes by photojournalists; photographs by modern artists like Walker Evans, Diane Arbus, William Klein and Larry Clark; and a variety of old publications and ephemera.

headline: Review: Tastes of Los Angeles in ‘City of Gold’
abstract: Laura Gabbert’s documentary follows the food critic Jonathan Gold in his pursuit of excellence, which can lead to a taco truck or a high-end restaurant.
lead_paragraph: “Criticism is criticism,” says Jonathan Gold, who writes about food for The Los Angeles Times. “An aria is like a well-cooked potato.” To which I can only say: Amen. Creative inspiration can be found in a great variety of human pursuits, and criticism is the name we give to the act of identifying and sharing it. A painting is, in that respect, like a poem. A well-written book is like a well-built shelf. A newspaper column is like a documentary film.

headline: New Zealand: One Nation Under a Beach Towel?
abstract: Prime Minister John Key has spent millions trying to change a flag that Kiwis want to keep.
lead_paragraph: TE ATATU, New Zealand — New Zealand is as beautiful as it is isolated. We live a long way from anyone and anything, and we like it that way. We have almost four and a half million people and more than five million dairy cows. We have snow-capped mountains and deep dark woods where hobbits roam, as directed by Peter Jackson in his interminable “Lord of the Rings” movies. We sing (Lorde) and act (Russell Crowe) and throw stuff (rugby balls).

headline: 1941: Nazi Troops Flood Rumania
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazis send fresh divisions into Rumania in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — With more than half of the Nazi forces which were in Rumania two weeks ago massing along the Greek and Turkish borders of Bulgaria, the German high command has begun to send fresh divisions into Rumania to take the place of those which have crossed the Danube, it was learned today [March 10] from a reliable source at Bucharest. There is good reason to believe that the number of German troops in Rumania once more will be raised to twenty-five or thirty divisions — a figure far higher than anything that would be necessary for maintaining law and order and dealing with any possible British air attacks. — New York Herald Tribune, March 11, 1941

headline: New Ways of Being
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The literature of immigration is not as fashionable as it once was,but readers are still interested. Two new novels about migrants tell a dark story.
lead_paragraph: The migrant is the “defining figure of the 20th century,” Salman Rushdie wrote 20 years ago in the literary magazine Granta. In “this century of wandering,” of refugees and writers in exile carrying “cities in their bedrolls,” migrants taught us what it was to be human, he said, because they’d lost those very things that gave shape to their humanity — roots, culture, social knowledge — and were forced to devise new ways of being. And the migrant writer hatched a new language along the way. “To conquer English may be to complete the process of making ourselves free,” Rushdie wrote in his 1991 essay collection, “Imaginary Homelands.” Shoals of people still move across the world today, but the idea of a literature of migration seems to have fallen out of fashion — not with readers but with writers, some of whom chafe at being narrowly categorized, consigned to an ethnic beat, their work treated as sociology instead of art.

headline: 1966: No NATO, No Atomic Rockets
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. will take back atomic warheads from French hands if France leaves NATO in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The United States will take back its atomic warheads now in French hands as soon as France withdraws its forces from NATO command, it was learned today [March 10]. President Charles de Gaulle, meanwhile, has asked West Germany for bilateral negotiations on maintaining the French forces stationed on German soil once they are removed from NATO. It is these French forces which are equipped with U.S. warheads under the ‘‘two-key’’ system giving both Washington and Paris a veto over their use. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 11, 1966

headline: Boko Haram and Mass Starvation
abstract: Violence and killing has destroyed villages and crops, setting the stage for famine in Northern Africa.
lead_paragraph: Boko Haram’s continuing raids of terror have turned a swath of territory in the Sahel region in northern Africa into a virtual wasteland, barren of crops and livestock, pocked by ghost villages lying in ruin. Add to this desolation an early “lean season” — the precarious time between harvests when temperatures soar, rainfall is scant, and hunger, even in good years, is a threat to the area’s subsistence farmers and herdsmen — and the stage is set for starvation on a mass scale.

headline: Review: ‘Eye in the Sky,’ Drone Precision vs. Human Failings
abstract: Gavin Hood’s movie is a riveting thriller — and often a grim, suspenseful farce — about drone warfare and its perils.
lead_paragraph: An alternative title to “Eye in the Sky,” a riveting thriller about drone warfare and its perils, might be “Passing the Buck.” When urgent life-or-death decisions are required in a race against time to kill terrorists preparing a suicide attack, officials, wary of being held responsible for civilian casualties, repeatedly “refer up” to higher authorities for final approval.

headline: Video Review: The BMW 750i xDrive, Tranquillity With a Touch of Vegas
abstract: A powerful V8 and adaptive suspension give this luxury ride serenity, but the mesmerizing cabin lighting seems to take a cue from the Las Vegas Strip.
lead_paragraph: A case could be made that modern automobiles are the most impressive consumer products created. Sophisticated cars contain more than 100 million lines of computer code (apparently all of Facebook comes in at about 60 million), and you probably don’t leave your laptop outside in the rain, snow or blistering heat for days on end. If you do, please write and tell me why.

headline: Fukushima Keeps Fighting Radioactive Tide 5 Years After Disaster
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Radiation', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Wastes']
abstract: A full cleanup of the site is expected to take at least 40 years, according to the government’s timetable, and a century by other estimates.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Of the thousands of workers who have answered the help-wanted ads at Fukushima Daiichi, the ruined and radioactive nuclear power plant in northeastern Japan, Kazuto Tatsuta, a part-time lettuce farmer and occasional comic-book artist, must be among the least likely.

keywords: ['Movies', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Two movies — one a drama, the other a documentary — examine the ethical quandaries behind military drones, which can kill without the pilots ever leaving home.
lead_paragraph: In “Eye in the Sky,” a thriller about a secret drone operation against terrorists in Kenya, it doesn’t take long for the characters to land in a moral minefield.

headline: What’s Snaky, Easy to Wear and Scaled With Diamonds?
abstract: A sinuous Tiffany & Company design takes all the stiffness out of fine jewelry.
lead_paragraph: While the haute jewelry world continues to revel in chunky collars adorned with oversize gems, Tiffany & Company’s design director, Francesca Amfitheatrof, has instead gone for a radically casual take on the oft-interpreted diamond-encrusted necklace. Evoking a snaky, sinuous form, this 27-inch piece swings insouciantly against the body, accommodating itself to the wearer’s mobility rather than limiting it. Crafted from more than 100 carats of marquise-cut diamonds in subtly graduating sizes and affixed to an almost-invisible platinum armature, it’s the ultimate in throw-it-on luxury.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton, Miu Miu and Moncler

headline: John Legend and Aldis Hodge Discuss ‘Underground’
abstract: WGN America’s new series about a group of slaves trying to escape from a Georgia plantation debuted on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to drum up excitement for a show that tackles a subject as upsetting as slavery. Even putting “slavery” and “excitement” together in a sentence can feel problematic. But the two words are not mutually exclusive on “Underground,” WGN America’s new series about a group of enslaved men and women who embark on a harrowing escape from a Georgia plantation via the Underground Railroad.

headline: More Than 60 Athletes Have Tested Positive for Meldonium
abstract: Maria Sharapova, Olympic medalists and world champions are among those who have tested positive for meldonium since it was added to the banned list in January.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 athletes, including Olympic medalists and world champions, have tested positive this year for meldonium, the performance-enhancing drug that Maria Sharapova admitted to using, according to antidoping officials.

headline: Eli Zabar’s Wine Cellar: It’s Not Chopped Liver
abstract: The famed food retailer collects and sells Burgundy — his way, as always.
lead_paragraph: Many New Yorkers know at least something about Eli Zabar. They can probably guess that his family opened the Upper West Side emporium that stands for classic New York eating. They may know that he left that business decades ago to open his own store on the Upper East Side, E.A.T., followed by Eli’s at the Vinegar Factory, and that his markets and takeout shops now dominate the neighborhood above 79th Street.

headline: Mario Draghi Throws the Kitchen Sink at Europe’s Economic Distress. Again.
abstract: The last seven years have upended what we thought we knew about how central banks can and should operate; today’s actions offer another example.
lead_paragraph: One hopes that at the very least, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, is able to buy kitchen sinks in bulk at a discount from some plumbing supply shop in Frankfurt.

abstract: The United States and 11 other countries on the Human Rights Council expressed alarm at the sweeping arrests of activists and lawyers and the treatment of several Hong Kong residents who vanished.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States and 11 other countries scolded China on Thursday over its crackdown on lawyers and human rights activists, saying that China had violated its own laws and international commitments.

abstract: Why do older women buy ugly shoes? For the same reason they go out with unsuitable men: availability.
lead_paragraph: I know I am going to take a lot of heat for what I am about to tell you, but I just spent almost $1,000 for a pair of custom shoes.

headline: Sophie Grégoire Trudeau: A Very Canadian ‘First Lady’
abstract: As the Obamas welcome the Trudeaus to the White House, Canadians like me are watching eagerly, even if we don’t want to admit it.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, arrived at the White House for a state dinner on Thursday, the first given for a Canadian in two decades, it was on a wave of international attention not accorded a Canadian politician in, well, maybe ever.

headline: To Stop the Missiles, Stop North Korea, Inc.
abstract: The United Nations’ new sanctions won’t curb the North’s weapons programs as long as a sophisticated business network remains in place.
lead_paragraph: American diplomats should be proud of the new sanctions on North Korea that the United Nations Security Council passed last week. In response to a nuclear test in January and missile launch in February, the Council, at the United States’ urging, agreed to a ban on North Korean imports of jet fuel and to mandate inspections of all cargo coming into or out of North Korea. These are the toughest sanctions the North has ever faced.

headline: Thomas Adès  Joins Boston Symphony as Artistic Partner

lead_paragraph: The Boston Symphony Orchestra announced Thursday that it had named the highly acclaimed British composer Thomas Adès to the newly created position of artistic partner, a three-year post that will showcase his work as a composer, conductor, pianist and teacher.

abstract: Being tall is associated with higher income for men; being overweight is associated with lower income for women.
lead_paragraph: Being tall is associated with higher income for men and being overweight is associated with lower income for women. A new study shows that height and weight may have a direct cause-and-effect relationship with pay.

keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'States (US)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Opium']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Responding to a drug crisis that has contributed to more American deaths than car crashes, the Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly passed a broad drug treatment and prevention bill, the largest of its kind since a law in 2008 that mandated insurance coverage for addiction treatment.

lead_paragraph: After years as the lone holdout among Division I conferences in not holding a postseason basketball tournament, the Ivy League announced on Thursday that starting next season its automatic bids to the men’s and women’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments would be decided by a season-ending playoff.

headline: Review: ‘Hello, My Name Is Doris,’ About an Older Woman’s Love for a Much Younger Man
abstract: A frumpy, lower-middle-class woman in her 60s suddenly finds herself desired, which leads to a ferocious awakening.
lead_paragraph: The first time that the heroine in the disarming comedy “Hello, My Name Is Doris” sees the kid, they’re in a crowded office elevator. He’s not a child at all, but somewhere in his mid-30s, which can seem light-years away for a woman who has been of a certain age for decades. So when he jostles Doris (Sally Field), she braces for the usual morning-elevator scrum. Instead, he straightens her lopsided eyeglasses. With this one small, human kindness he does something that astonishes Doris, something that doesn’t often happen to the world’s invisible women: He sees her.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Thursday proposed a set of privacy rules for Internet service providers that would significantly curb the ability of companies like Comcast and Verizon to share data about their customers’ online activities with advertisers without permission from users.

headline: No Need for a Dust-Up Over Accommodations
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Bullies', 'Children and Childhood', 'Names, Personal', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Also, forgetting a name; the neighborhood bully; and loud-talking travelers.
lead_paragraph: We visit my family in California every year. I have a difficult relationship with them, but I want them to be part of my child’s life. My mother has ample room for us, but her house is cluttered and not very clean. My husband has severe allergies, but we all end up sneezing. Last year, we rented a house; my mother was insulted. This year, my daughter wants to spend more time with her, and I would like to avoid the expense of renting. My husband thinks I should offer to pay for a cleaning service before our visit. But there would need to be decluttering, too. Thoughts?

headline: Ted Cruz Receives First Senate Endorsement, From Mike Lee of Utah
abstract: Ted Cruz received his first endorsement from a Senate colleague, Mike Lee of Utah, who is admired by the party’s conservative base.

keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Questions and answers on Iran’s recent missile tests and how its actions apply to the parameters of the nuclear agreement that took effect in January.
lead_paragraph: Iran has infuriated American critics over the past few weeks with missile tests that skeptics say violate a United Nations Security Council resolution and call into question Iran’s commitment to the landmark nuclear agreement that took effect in January.

headline: When a Jeweler Designs a Faucet
abstract: Jill Platner’s sumptuous all-brass design took nearly two years to get right.
lead_paragraph: When Waterworks decided to expand beyond its sleek updates on classic fixtures, the company called upon the cult New York City-based jewelry designer and sculptor Jill Platner. Her Isla faucet takes the very notion of free flow in a pared-down, organic direction: The prototype, initially sculpted in wax and later cast in solid brass, took nearly two years to get right. Like a golden-hued fountain bubbling up through boulders at a natural hot spring, the piece evokes a mountain spa.

headline: Finra’s Help Sought in Fight Between Credit Suisse and Brokers
abstract: Lawyers for dozens of former Credit Suisse brokers are seeking to have their claims heard in arbitration overseen by the regulator.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for dozens of former Credit Suisse brokers have appealed to the brokerage industry’s main regulator to step into a fight over millions of dollars of accumulated bonus payments the brokers say the bank owes them.

lead_paragraph: Could a young boy donning blue swimming goggles be a savior? Could a spirited couple at a Los Angeles dinner party have the solution for spiritual malaise? Could a charismatic young blond woman in a basement be the answer to life’s problems? Or could they all just lead to more questions?

headline: Locked Away for 24 Years, an Exonerated Man Still Feels Imprisoned
abstract: Han Tak Lee, 81, who was wrongfully convicted of killing his daughter in a fire, spends most of his time now in his Queens apartment, getting by thanks to people who have sympathized with his plight.
lead_paragraph: Han Tak Lee, 81, spends much of his time alone in a small room in Queens. It is a ground-floor studio apartment with a kitchenette and a bathroom, right beside train tracks used by the Long Island Rail Road. Commuter trains roar by every so often, though the double-glazing of his windows reduces the noise to a gentle whoosh.

headline: Draghi’s Plan Lifts Markets, but Clouds Loom on the Horizon
abstract: Mario Draghi unveiled an aggressive package of stimulus measures, but he may be encouraging more risk-taking without being able to increase inflation.

headline: How an Amateur Meteorite Hunter Tracked Down a Fireball
abstract: Since last October, citizen scientists have uncovered fragments from three different fireball sightings using online reports.
lead_paragraph: When a fireball whizzed over Florida on Jan. 24, more than a hundred witnesses reported spotting the flare on the American Meteor Society’s website. Within a week, Mike Hankey, an amateur meteorite hunter based nearly a thousand miles away near Baltimore, was holding a muddy chunk of the space rock he found near a swamp.

headline: Parole for Killer of Chris Hani, Apartheid Opponent, Elicits an Outcry
abstract: Some South Africans expressed outrage over the release of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the 1993 assassination.
lead_paragraph: A South African judge granted parole on Thursday to the killer of Chris Hani, a leading anti-apartheid activist who was assassinated in 1993. The decision to release the killer, Janusz Walus, provoked immediate criticism and revived painful memories of a murder aimed at derailing the country’s transition to black-majority rule.

headline: Trey Edward Shults Narrates a Scene From ‘Krisha’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence that he shot in his family’s home.
lead_paragraph: With “Krisha,” the writer and director Trey Edward Shults made a family drama using his actual family.

headline: Simon & Schuster to Publish Writings of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: The Georgetown Law professors Mary Hartnett and Wendy W. Williams will select the writings compiled in “My Own Words,” which will have an introduction written by Justice Ginsburg.
lead_paragraph: “My Own Words,” a collection of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s writings, will be published by Simon & Schuster in January. The book will include her writing and speeches on a variety of subjects, like her Jewish identity, gender equality, interpreting the Constitution, and the way lawyers and the law are depicted in opera. It will have an introduction by Justice Ginsburg, who was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1993.

headline: With ‘Krisha,’ a Director Finds a Cast He Can Relate To
abstract: Trey Edward Shults put himself, his mother and aunts in a film about addiction, estrangement and family ties.
lead_paragraph: “We felt like a family” is a sentiment often voiced by actors about smooth productions. But when the filmmaker Trey Edward Shults says the same about “Krisha,” his debut feature film, he’s just stating facts. His mother, aunts and even grandmother all star in the film — as does he.

headline: The Value of Autopsies for Doctors and D.A.s

headline: In Israel, an Arab Chooses Baskets Over Goals
abstract: Karam Mashour is the only player of Arab heritage in the Israeli basketball league, though he says he does not see himself as a pioneer.
lead_paragraph: NAZARETH, Israel — Long before he was a professional basketball player in Israel’s most prestigious league, Karam Mashour honed his game on one of the only courts in this city: the tiny alleyway between his parents’ house and his grandmother’s. The narrow sliver of concrete and its portable hoop came with specific challenges — duck low if you want to dribble to the right but avoid a collision with the electrical box jutting out from the window, for example — yet Mashour never dwelled on the setting.

The latest effort came on Thursday, with Warner Bros. saying it would start an incubator “to provide access and voice to new and underrepresented talent.”

headline: Fundamentals, Polls, and the Primary
abstract: What if the polls are all wrong?
lead_paragraph: The huge polling miss in Michigan was a cautionary tale: for all its excellence, FiveThirtyEight is only as good as the polls, which at least this time were way, way off. It’s too soon to dismiss them, but not too soon to explore other approaches, which is what Alan Abramowitz has just done. Using data for the Dem contests so far, he estimates a simple relationship based on just two factors — nonwhite share of the population, and north versus south — that accounts for the results quite well — and Michigan is not an outlier.

lead_paragraph: Christopher Plummer puts on a master class in acting, and his director, Atom Egoyan, delivers one in audience manipulation in “Remember,” a psychological thriller featuring that most blood-boiling of plot devices: a Nazi who escaped justice.

headline: Great Gray Owl Female Contact Call
abstract: Biologists in Yosemite play back recorded owl vocalizations like this one to encourage responses that can determine presence and provide hints about breeding status. This recording is of a common “whoop” call, often heard when a female owl contacts a male.
lead_paragraph: Biologists in Yosemite play back recorded owl vocalizations like this one to encourage responses that can determine presence and provide hints about breeding status. This recording is of a common “whoop” call, often heard when a female owl contacts a male.

headline: Great Gray Owl Begging Fledgling Call
abstract: This call, typical of young owls requesting food, is useful as evidence for biologists attempting to home in on the location of nests. As a recording, it can also be used to elicit responses from other owls.
lead_paragraph: This call, typical of young owls requesting food, is useful as evidence for biologists attempting to home in on the location of nests. As a recording, it can also be used to elicit responses from other owls.

headline: Living With Cancer: Being Erased
abstract: The experiences of minorities remain strikingly marginal in cancer literature.
lead_paragraph: While I recover from a fractured pelvis, I have time to remember the day after a less ruinous fall two years ago. No bones broken then, but I quickly developed a shiner and then slowly an insight into the color of cancer.

headline: Review: ‘Rise of the Legend,’ a Kung Fu Period Film
abstract: In 19th-century Guangzhou, two friends who have trained together, and pine for the same woman, are on opposite sides of a battle.
lead_paragraph: The blending of vast sets and digital effects is not quite seamless in Chow Hin Yeung’s kung fu period extravaganza “Rise of the Legend,” but it’s close. Revisiting the story of Wong Fei Hung, a martial arts master whose life has passed into Chinese folklore, “Legend” takes place in 19th-century Guangzhou, where two crime factions vie for control of the docks. This movie’s Guangzhou is a marvel: sprawling, detailed, abounding in narrow alleys and vivid street scenes.

headline: In Trudeau and Obama, the Internet Sees a Budding Bromance
abstract: The crowd went wild as friendly scenes from the Canadian prime minister’s first official visit to the White House unfolded.
lead_paragraph: It was, as President Obama put it in the most American of jokes, “aboot time, eh?”

headline: Review: ‘Hyena Road’ Follows a Sniper Team in Afghanistan
abstract: Paul Gross’s Canadian war film begins with the killing of a Taliban rebel by coalition forces.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan has been a combat zone for so long that it’s become a film genre unto itself, with documentaries like “Restrepo,” features like “Lone Survivor,” even comedies like “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.” Now a Canadian movie, “Hyena Road,” adds another perspective.

headline: A Trip Through Amazon’s First Physical Store
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Two reporters discuss and marvel at what is and isn’t in Amazon’s sole brick-and-mortar store as it plans to expand its physical locations.
lead_paragraph: This week, Amazon revealed the location of its second brick-and-mortar bookstore, which will open in a few months in Southern California, at a mall near the University of California, San Diego. The online retailer seems to have big ambitions for its physical stores.

headline: Review: ‘10 Cloverfield Lane’ Houses a Survivalist, His Captive and Jolts
abstract: J.J. Abrams produced but did not direct this thriller, which is only slightly connected to his “Cloverfield” (2008) and stars Mary Elizabeth Winstead.
lead_paragraph: “10 Cloverfield Lane” demands to be seen before reading a single review. So I plan to divulge even less than its makers, whose hype-by-omission campaign — which included a late title change to summon fans of J. J. Abrams’s hurtling thriller “Cloverfield” (2008) — seems unnecessarily manipulative.

headline: Ad Watch: Offering Salvation for Americans Fleeing Politics
abstract: Critical Mass, a Canadian advertising agency, has created an online campaign that takes advantage of the American presidential election.
lead_paragraph: During presidential election years, Americans of varying political persuasions often contemplate moving to Canada. Google queries for Canada spike. Conversations between friends turn to preferred Canadian destinations.

headline: IndyCar Chief Looks to Build Interest Beyond the 100th Indianapolis 500
abstract: Mark Miles says the IndyCar Series, which opens its season on Sunday, has the venues and events to attract ticket-buyers and viewers beyond its milestone main event.
lead_paragraph: Mark Miles often has lunch at a restaurant not far from his office at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He says he is often stopped by race fans who tell him what the Indianapolis 500 means to them. The race, for many, is still a deeply cherished tradition.

headline: Review: ‘The Brothers Grimsby’: From Sacha, With Love
abstract: Sacha Baron Cohen returns with a movie about two brothers — a sleek superspy and a bumbling fool — who battle a global crime syndicate.
lead_paragraph: A Freudian might be able to make something of Sacha Baron Cohen’s emphasis on bodily orifices and protrusions in “The Brothers Grimsby.” I prefer a more obvious explanation: At some point during the making of this 1-hour-18-minute burlesque, Mr. Cohen became bored. Given the production budget, the pitch was obviously good enough for someone to write a check and hire an action director, Louis Leterrier, who could give the material the requisite spit-shine: After years of separation, two drastically different brothers — a sleek superspy and a bumbling fool — reunite and, in between guffaws, heal old wounds, zip around the world and fight a global crime syndicate.

headline: 3 ‘Survivor’ Contestants Collapse in Cambodian Heat, and One Is Evacuated
abstract: One participant, Caleb, was rushed to a hospital in the incident, which was broadcast on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of the 16 years it has been on the air, “Survivor” hasn’t really been about actually surviving.

headline: In Rivette’s ‘Out 1: Noli Me Tangere,’ Paris Is a Stage
abstract: The director, who died in January, has two works now on disc: his debut, “Paris Belongs to Us,” and the sprawling, multipart “Out 1.”
lead_paragraph: Jacques Rivette, who died in January  at 87, was in some ways the most classical of French New Wave directors (adapting Denis Diderot and Balzac, celebrating Joan of Arc), and in others the most experimental. His more radical movies were extended meta-dramas that conflated narrative with conspiracy, and actors were typically cast in the role of actors.

headline: Review: In ‘About Scout,’ a Young Woman Searches for Her Sister
abstract: Scout recruits a traveling companion from a psychiatric care center to search for her younger sister, who has been taken by their absentee father.
lead_paragraph: “About Scout” is another entry in the “charming road movie” genre, one that banks a little too heavily on charm and not enough on story. The two young leads pair engagingly, though, and the screenwriter and director, Laurie Weltz, surrounds them with name actors in small roles, a sweet reversal of the usual casting structure.

headline: 8 Compelling Mini-Documentaries to Teach Close Reading and Critical Thinking Skills
abstract: Short documentary films can stir up ideas in the classroom to get students discussing, debating, thinking and writing. And, they can serve as a refreshing break from print media to help students explore curriculum themes and practice important literacy skills.
lead_paragraph: From the days when instructional films like these were shown via projector, students have enjoyed watching movies in class. Teachers have too. But it’s often hard to justify watching a two-hour film when there’s so much else that has to be done.

headline: Review: ‘Boom Bust Boom,’ a Pythonesque Look at Financial Crashes
abstract: This film by Terry Jones, formerly of Monty Python, explores the 2008 financial collapse and the possibility of more crashes through animation, puppetry and interviews with economists.
lead_paragraph: “This film is about the Achilles’ heel of capitalism,” Terry Jones says at the opening of “Boom Bust Boom.” “How human nature drives the economy to crisis after crisis, time and time again.”

headline: Review: In Julie Delpy’s ‘Lolo,’ a Teenager Tries to Sabotage His Mother’s Romance
abstract: Ms. Delpy plays an indulgent divorced parent whose chance at happiness is threatened by her spoiled and scheming son.
lead_paragraph: With “Lolo,” Julie Delpy (“2 Days in New York”) makes a much simpler addition to her prickly, idiosyncratic comedies, which have doubled as a frank running commentary on life (as with her roles in Richard Linklater’s films). In Ms. Delpy’s broadest effort yet — which she directs, and wrote with Eugénie Grandval — she plays a Paris fashionista who dotes on a snooty son and finds their clingy bond getting in the way of a rejuvenating romance.

headline: Apple and U.S. Bitterly Turn Up Volume in iPhone Privacy Fight
abstract: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration argued on Thursday that “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law by refusing to help the F.B.I. unlock the iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, March 12 Through 27
abstract: The R&B musician Aaron Neville will perform on March 17 at Club Helsinki Hudson.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Reporter Says Donald Trump’s Campaign Manager ‘Yanked’ Her Arm
abstract: Michelle Fields of Breitbart News said Mr. Trump’s campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, got physical with her after a news conference. A Washington Post reporter corroborated her account, but a campaign spokeswoman denied it.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump often excoriates the news media, calling reporters dishonest or disgusting.

headline: Top 10 Moments From Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Balenciaga’s new chapter, Iris Apfel’s whirlwind week and more highlights from the fall/winter 2016 shows.
lead_paragraph: Balenciaga’s new chapter, Iris Apfel’s whirlwind week and more highlights from the fall/winter 2016 shows.

headline: Review: ‘Mabel Madness,’ a Singer’s 20th-Century Journey
abstract: A one-woman show written and performed by Trezana Beverley tells the story of the singer Mabel Mercer, who even influenced Sinatra.
lead_paragraph: In 1900, in a riverside town near Birmingham, England, a 14-year-old white girl who worked in vaudeville had a baby fathered by a fellow vaudevillian, a black American. And so the story behind “Mabel Madness,” Trezana Beverley’s consistently beguiling solo show at Urban Stages, began.

headline: “Mexican Crime Photographs / from the archive of Stefan Ruiz”
abstract: The photographer Stefan Ruiz’s new book collects mug shots and crime-scene photos — made all the more striking for their lack of context.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Stefan Ruiz’s new book collects mug shots and crime-scene photos — made all the more striking for their lack of context.

headline: Haunting Found Images From Mexico City’s Police Archives
abstract: The photographer Stefan Ruiz’s new book collects mug shots and crime-scene photos — made all the more striking for their lack of context.
lead_paragraph: While visiting La Lagunilla, a public market in Mexico City, in 2010, the photographer Stefan Ruiz came upon a collection of the city’s police archives of crime photographs. Intrigued, he spent the next six months buying hundreds of them, which he has now collected into a new book, “Mexican Crime Photographs / from the archive of Stefan Ruiz.” Fascinated by the pasts of these unknown men and women, Ruiz continued his search and uncovered more photographs — both images of crimes taking place, such as a dramatic armed bank robbery, and many mug shots of recently arrested suspects. The impact of these photos is all the more powerful for their lack of context: As viewers, we can only imagine their stories, and reckon with realities that might sharply differ from our stereotypical understanding of Mexico’s tragically crime-ridden history.

headline: For China Banks, Swapping Stock for Debt Is a Stopgap With Pitfalls
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Using shares to pay overdue loans could help banks temporarily shore up their balance sheets. But it could cause greater difficulties down the road.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A new approach to managing China’s corporate debt burden may offer temporary relief for banks but spell further difficulties for the country’s economy: having deeply troubled companies use stock to pay overdue loans.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: California Water District Fined by S.E.C. Over ‘Enron Accounting’
abstract: The Westlands Water District had been accused of hiding financial problems from investors who bought municipal bonds.
lead_paragraph: When the overseers of the nation’s largest and most powerful agricultural water district approved a bookkeeping change at their July 2010 board meeting, the district’s general manager called it “a little Enron accounting.”

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, March 12 Through 27
abstract: “Godspell,” a musical by John-Michael Tebelak and Stephen Schwartz, is playing at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Mystery Deepens Over Death of Former Putin Ally Mikhail Lesin
abstract: A medical examiner’s report, which found that Mr. Lesin had died of blunt force injuries in a Washington hotel, conflicted with Russian news reports that he had died of a heart attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mikhail Y. Lesin once occupied the upper stratosphere of Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia, an advertising executive turned cabinet minister who helped carry out the state takeover of the country’s independent media and later created the Kremlin’s global English-language television network.

headline: Sketches From a P.O.W. Camp That Held African-Americans and Others
abstract: An album of drawings made for a Manhattan-born schoolboy who was interned with other foreign nationals during World War II is yielding insights at the Museum of Jewish Heritage.
lead_paragraph: During World War II, the Nazis imprisoned African-American athletes and jazz musicians and European Jews with passports from the United States and Latin America at Tittmoning Castle in Bavaria. The black detainees had been working overseas, partly to escape racism at home, and some had European wives and children who were also taken to interment centers.

headline: Bernie Sanders Draws Thousands at Rallies Across Florida
abstract: Bernie Sanders spent Thursday talking to thousands of people in rallies across Florida in an effort to garner support before the state’s primary next week.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

headline: Review: Renée Fleming, a Voice With Wardrobe Changes
abstract: Ms. Fleming, accompanied by the pianist Olga Kern, performed songs by Rachmaninoff, Debussy and Patricia Barber, among others, at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Renée Fleming’s song recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, with the pianist Olga Kern, promised to be a big event, in ways both good and possibly less good. Ms. Fleming recently made known that she intends to phase out her operatic career, but her voice is still in excellent shape, and this program could indicate that she will invest more heavily in the song repertory.

headline: How a Rembrandt Masterpiece Evolved
abstract: “Judas Returning the Thirty Pieces of Silver,” coming to the Morgan Library & Museum, includes sketch drawings of the painting.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t just that Rembrandt’s “Judas Returning the Thirty Pieces of Silver” is recognized as the artist’s first masterpiece. Or that it hasn’t been seen in the United States before. What makes the Morgan Library & Museum’s coming exhibition noteworthy is that it will include three preparatory drawings of the painting, making it one of Rembrandt’s only works for which such sketches survive.

headline: The Obama-Trudeau Climate Pledge Contains Overdue Steps to Fix Natural Gas Leaks
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: President Obama includes an overdue domestic push to cut leaks in America’s vast natural gas system in a joint announcement with his Canadian counterpart.
lead_paragraph: Today’s “Joint Statement on Climate, Energy, and Arctic Leadership” by President Obama and Canada’s new prime minister, Justin Trudeau, contained lots of welcome environmental commitments, particularly on curbing emissions of methane leaking from existing oil and gas infrastructure. They pledged to cut such emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2012 levels by 2025 from the oil and gas sector.

headline: Review: ‘The Hospital’: 3 Nurses, No Patients, Dark Ritual
abstract: This Jo Stromgren Kompani show, making its New York debut at the Abrons Arts Center, has a sad underlying story that is played for laughs.
lead_paragraph: The three nurses in the Norwegian Jo Stromgren Kompani’s “The Hospital” look bored to death. Now and then, they hear a helicopter fly over their outpost but no one lands. And so the nurses take turns disappearing behind one of the set’s dirty walls. There’s a whack and a howl and then a nurse returns bloodied: Finally, a patient!

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, March 12 Through 27
abstract: “Beets” (2015), a photograph by Dan Lenore, is on view in the group show “Visions” in Fairfield.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Creative Control,’ a Satire of Gadget-Driven Reality
abstract: Benjamin Dickinson’s sophomore feature stars Mr. Dickinson as a stressed-out adman, an unprepossessing antihero with no control at all.
lead_paragraph: Concocted with heaps of style but only a smattering of substance, Benjamin Dickinson’s sophomore feature, “Creative Control,” is as brittle and unwelcoming as its characters’ surroundings. Those would be Brooklyn, some time in the near future when everyone enjoys panoramic city views from habitats bristling with glass and chrome. Tactile surfaces, like emotional satisfaction, are in short supply.

headline: One Model, 40 Beauty Looks
abstract: From a fresh face at Jason Wu to slicked-back tresses at Miu Miu, a month’s worth of Frederikke Sofie’s hair and makeup, in pictures.
lead_paragraph: From a fresh face at Jason Wu to slicked-back tresses at Miu Miu, a month’s worth of Frederikke Sofie’s hair and makeup, in pictures.

headline: Review: ‘Marguerite,’ a Screeching Diva Clinging to Her Operatic Dream
abstract: Xavier Giannoli’s comedy, inspired by the life of the talentless American socialite Florence Foster Jenkins, stars Catherine Frot as an aspiring singer.
lead_paragraph: “The self-deception that believes the lie.” That phrase from the Rodgers and Hart song “I Wish I Were in Love again” distills the theme of “Marguerite,” Xavier Giannoli’s satirical comedy about a tone-deaf would-be opera diva who thinks she can sing.

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for March 11-17
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Review: Molly Poerstel Challenges Structure at Gibney Dance
abstract: “Are We a Fossil, and of Facings” is a dance in which hearing is as integral as seeing, and the visible isn’t favored over the invisible.
lead_paragraph: A row of pillars runs down the center of the studio-theater at Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center. Any choreographer presenting work there has to solve this architectural problem, and while it sometimes proves cumbersome, Molly Poerstel has made it work to her advantage.

headline: Review: In ‘Me Him Her,’ Late-20-Somethings Emerge From Life’s Confusion
abstract: A loose indie comedy, this feature debut from Max Landis shows the mark of the 1985 cult classic “Into the Night,” made by his father, John Landis.
lead_paragraph: The screenwriter and director Max Landis — he wrote the recent action-comedy-horror-thriller mash-ups “American Ultra” and “Victor Frankenstein” — is the son of John Landis. You can see the elder Landis’s touch in Max Landis’s first feature as a director, “Me Him Her.” But it’s not “Animal House” that shows up.

headline: Mourning Nancy Reagan, and Looking Back at the Class and Dignity of an Era
abstract: Several thousand people traveled to the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library to pay respects and celebrate the romance of the Reagans, who were married more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — In death, Nancy Reagan is drawing the kind of public warmth and adulation that her husband received for much of his life.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, March 12 Through 27
abstract: “Grounded Construct” (2014), oil on canvas by Elaine Shor, is on view in “SWART: Artwork by N.J. Social Workers and Art Therapists” in Westfield.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Van Dyck at the Frick, Documenting Aristocracy
abstract: See how van Dyck’s exceptional gifts elevated the art of portrait at the Frick Collection.
lead_paragraph: The synchronization of art, talent, money and power is a constant that was especially clear-cut in the 17th and 18th centuries, when kings were still considered semi-divine and the camera was not yet invented. This gave skilled portrait painters a signal importance. They produced likenesses — generally flattering — that affirmed the status of rulers and nobles for one another, their constituencies and posterity.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Draw Distinctions on Immigration Policy
abstract: In their debate on Wednesday, the two Democrats showed differences on deportation and criticized each other on their votes on immigration legislation.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

abstract: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.
lead_paragraph: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? headline: Highlights From Asia Week
abstract: The 10-day parade of exhibitions includes arts, crafts and ancient jade artifacts, as well as 17th-century portraits and contemporary ceramics.
lead_paragraph: Asia Week, the 10-day parade of exhibitions that arrives each spring from every corner of that continent, can seem like a parallel universe to the art world most often written about here.

headline: Review: Joan Osborne Delivers No-Nonsense Dylan
abstract: Ms. Osborne’s rock-blues voice clarifies Bob Dylan lyrics and brings out the strength of his blunt tunes without sweetened emotions at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: “Well, it may be the Devil or it may be the Lord/But you’re gonna have to serve somebody.”

headline: For St. Patrick’s Day Parade 1855, Snow on the Clover
abstract: First snow and then a pitiless pelting rain disrupted a proud parade in Manhattan 161 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Who marches, and who doesn’t. That is the perennial talk of the latter-day St. Patrick’s Day Parade in New York. Mayor Bill de Blasio will march this year. As will a group representing gay Irish-Americans.

headline: Review: Brian Fallon Strikes Out on His Own With the Same Raspy Zeal for Yesteryear
abstract: Mr. Fallon, a nostalgist whose lyrics evoke a non-idyllic past, mixes in songs from “Painkillers,” his first true solo album, at Irving Plaza.
lead_paragraph: With Brian Fallon’s voice, the decay is the thing. Pockmarked and abraded but still firm, it’s a vehicle for beautiful distress, for committed uncertainty. Over the last decade, primarily as the frontman for the Gaslight Anthem, he’s become a vessel for preserving some of the best bits of American rock, especially from the 1950s and 1970s, and also a singular nostalgist with a gift for lyrics that evoke a non-idyllic past without living in it.
