headline: Ben Carson to Endorse Donald Trump
abstract: Ben Carson, the retired pediatric neurosurgeon who ended his presidential bid last week, plans to endorse Donald J. Trump Friday morning, three people familiar with the discussions said.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 10: The Sympathy Vote
abstract: The specter of death seeps into every story line in this chapter of “House of Cards.”
lead_paragraph: The specter of death seeps into every story line in this chapter of “House of Cards.” Claire’s mother, Elizabeth Hale, passes away. Frank makes a confession to Cathy Durant that for a moment feels as shocking as the final scene of “The Jinx.” Yet as sad and macabre as things get, everything still works out for the Underwoods. Frank is officially chosen as the Democratic presidential candidate, and Claire — who picks up some sympathy votes in the wake of her recent loss — is officially named her husband’s running mate. It seemed as if it couldn’t be done, mainly because it still doesn’t make much sense. But apparently, all a first lady needs to shatter political conventions and logic is a little help from the Grim Reaper.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 11, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Brothers Grimsby,” “Eye in the Sky” and “10 Cloverfield Lane.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Brothers Grimsby,” “Eye in the Sky” and “10 Cloverfield Lane.”

headline: Nefertiti 3-D Scanning Project in Germany Raises Doubts
abstract: Some technology experts say two artists are overselling their prowess regarding the digital swiping of a bust of the queen at a Berlin museum.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Experts have raised questions about assertions by two German artists that they used a concealed mobile device to scan the bust of Queen Nefertiti at the Neues Museum in Berlin, and then released the resulting data online in a project meant to question museum policies and notions of cultural ownership.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Weird at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Relive the ups, the downs and the plateaus of the final stretch of shows in Europe.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Paris Fashion Week was an unusual one: two major houses, Dior and Lanvin, were without creative directors; rumors swirled about Phoebe Philo’s departure from Céline; a new designer debuted at the storied Balenciaga; and Hedi Slimane, who many suspect will soon leave Saint Laurent, presented a show entirely different from his past ready-to-wear collections for the label. Against this backdrop, there were the expected shenanigans: Rei Kawakubo imagined an 18th-century punk; Kendall Jenner and Gigi Hadid switched hair colors; and Kanye West tried to blend in while wearing a pearl-covered jacket.

headline: Brazil Prosecutors Seek Arrest of ‘Lula,’ Former President, in Graft Case
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: The former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is by far the biggest figure to be ensnared in sweeping investigations that have rattled almost every level of government.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prosecutors in Brazil are seeking the arrest of the country’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, by far the biggest figure to be ensnared by the sweeping corruption investigations that have upended the nation and rattled almost every level of government.

headline: Health Officials Urge Congress to Fund Zika Research
abstract: President Obama’s request for $1.8 billion has stalled, and concern was raised that Puerto Rico was “facing an uphill battle” with the virus.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top health officials said Thursday that “urgent action” was needed to contain the Zika virus and appealed to Congress to allocate money to fighting the outbreak.

headline: ‘New York’s Yiddish Theater’ Explores a Fractious Heritage of Melodrama and Musicals
abstract: This show at the Museum of the City of New York traces a road from the shtetls of Eastern Europe to the Lower East Side to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: A DEFINITE if wobbly line connects the Yiddish theater of 19th-century Eastern Europe and the Lower East Side to the giants of modern American entertainment. It traces a long road from the ghettos and shtetls to Broadway and Hollywood and the likes of Marlon Brando and Barbra Streisand.

headline: PMK-BNC Absorbs the Boutique Publicity Agency Prime
keywords: ['Public Relations and Publicity', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Cindi Berger, PMK-BNC’s chief, said the publicists Joy Fehily and Michael Donkis, who ran Prime since 2009, would fold operations into her company.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood publicity and marketing agency PMK-BNC absorbed the clients and principals of a smaller competitor on Thursday, sending a ripple through a corner of moviedom that has been relatively quiet of late.

headline: 7 Democrats in Congress Say Clinton Email Inquiry Is ‘Too Politicized’
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The three representatives and four senators criticized the government’s review of Hillary Clinton’s use of private email while she was secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Democrats in Congress have accused the inspectors general of the State Department and the nation’s intelligence agencies of politicizing their review of Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.

headline: Republican Threats and the Supreme Court
abstract: They now admit that they don’t care about the “people’s voice,” only about getting a conservative to replace Justice Scalia.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, John Cornyn, the senior Republican senator from Texas, warned President Obama that if he dares to name a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, the nominee “will bear some resemblance to a piñata.”

headline: Bill Gadsby, N.H.L. Star With Scars to Prove It, Dies at 88
abstract: The Hall of Fame defenseman played in the rough and tough Original Six era of the N.H.L., when skaters went without helmets and goalies shunned masks.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gadsby was 12 years old and crossing the Atlantic with his mother on the British ocean liner Athenia at the outset of World War II when it was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine. They spent several hours in a lifeboat before being rescued.

headline: Effects of Meldonium on Athletes Are Hazy
abstract: The drug has been sold in Russia and former states of the Soviet Union, but evidence for any health benefit or improvement in athletic performance is scant.
lead_paragraph: The drug that caused Maria Sharapova’s failed doping test sounds almost like a miracle potion.

headline: 12th Republican Debate: Analysis
abstract: The Republican candidates debated at the University of Miami on Thursday, the last one before Florida votes on Tuesday. Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport provided real-time analysis.

headline: In Tsunami’s Wake, a Japanese Family Drifts Apart
abstract: In the five years after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Hiroko Masuike has followed the Sato family, whose members drifted apart as they struggled to recover and rebuild.
lead_paragraph: After the tsunami’s dark waves receded from the Japanese city of Kesen, leaving destruction in their wake, the Satos huddled together on what remained of their family plot. Naoshi and Teruko Sato’s son, Shoichi, a firefighter who had raced toward the sea to rescue the stranded, was missing. Shoichi’s wife, Mio Sato, was sick with worry.

headline: The Speech Yang Jisheng, Barred From Going to U.S., Planned to Give at Harvard
abstract: The Chinese journalist and author was forbidden from traveling to receive an award at the university. Here are excerpts from the talk he was to give Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: In China, as in other countries ruled by authoritarian regimes, journalists and authors intent on exposing wrongdoing and telling the truth inevitably find themselves at odds with the government. Such is the case with Yang Jisheng, a longtime reporter for the state news agency Xinhua who, after he retired, published a landmark book, “Tombstone,” documenting the deaths of 36 million people during the 1958-62 famine, one of the worst man-made disasters in history.

headline: Officer in Fatal Shooting of Ramarley Graham Faces Police Dept. Charges
abstract: An internal case against Officer Richard Haste will proceed now that federal prosecutors have declined to charge him in the death of Mr. Graham, who was 18 when he was killed in his Bronx apartment.
lead_paragraph: After federal prosecutors declined this week to file criminal charges against a white New York City police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in the Bronx four years ago, the Police Department’s long-delayed internal case against him will proceed.

headline: In Tsunami’s Wake, a Japanese Family Drifts Apart
abstract: In the five years after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Hiroko Masuike has followed the Sato family, whose members drifted apart as they struggled to recover and rebuild.
lead_paragraph: In the five years after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Hiroko Masuike has followed the Sato family, whose members drifted apart as they struggled to recover and rebuild.

headline: For Hedge Funds, Start of 2016 Offers Little Relief From 2015
abstract: The first two months of this year have favored very, very few hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund titan Larry Robbins did something out of character last year. He apologized to investors for losing their money and pledged to “right the ship as quickly as possible.” Then he solicited more money from them, raising $1 billion for a new fund and promised to waive the fees.

headline: Long Island Teenager Pleads Guilty in Deadly Drag-Racing Crash
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Cory Gloe, 19, who was indicted on 17 counts stemming from a 2014 collision that left five people dead, is likely to be sentenced to six months in jail.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island teenager pleaded guilty on Thursday to more than a dozen criminal charges stemming from a 2014 street-racing crash that left five other teenagers dead, prosecutors said. He is likely to be sentenced to six months in jail under an agreement.

headline: Sharapova Is Not the Only Player Paying Little Attention to Antidoping Emails
abstract: Many players say they rely on their staffs to decipher WADA’s latest pronouncements.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Explaining on Monday how she tested positive for the recently banned substance meldonium, Maria Sharapova admitted that she received an email from the World Anti-Doping Agency in December that contained changes in its prohibited list. The list included meldonium.

headline: Muslims Sue Over Denial of Bid to Build Mosque in New Jersey Suburb
keywords: ['Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: The Islamic Society of Basking Ridge, led by former Mayor Mohammad Ali Chaudry, was subjected to 39 hearings over four years.
lead_paragraph: In a prosperous New Jersey suburb about an hour west of Manhattan, a retired AT&T executive decided with some friends to open a mosque in the town where he has lived for nearly 40 years, been on the board of education, led a task force to create the town’s community center and even served as mayor.

headline: Complaint in Basking Ridge Mosque Case
abstract: The Islamic Society of Basking Ridge argues that the Township of Bernards, N.J., and others have blocked the construction of a mosque by raising unreasonable objections and devising a "Kafkaesque" approval process.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic Society of Basking Ridge argues that the Township of Bernards, N.J., and others have blocked the construction of a mosque by raising unreasonable objections and devising a "Kafkaesque" approval process.

headline: At Pepe’s Place, a Chef With a Flavorful Past Creates Soul Food
abstract: Pepe Manigault draws inspiration from his years in other kitchens to create the menu at his restaurant, a largely takeout cafe in New Rochelle that specializes in seafood.
lead_paragraph: Pepe Manigault said there were two reasons he decided to showcase seafood at Pepe’s Place, his small cafe in New Rochelle.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: The four candidates still battling for the Republican presidential nomination gathered at the University of Miami for the party’s 12th debate, hosted by CNN.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the Republican debate.

headline: Review: Taino Smokehouse and Its Hodgepodge of Barbecue
abstract: The owner of the Middletown restaurant left a career as a software engineer to devote himself to the art of smoked meats.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago Chris Szewczyk quit a successful career as a software engineer, abandoning his office cubicle to follow the lure of barbecue. The restaurant he and his wife, Jenny, opened in 2012, Taino Smokehouse in Middletown, adjoining the Ace Hardware store, isn’t much bigger than a cubicle. Its tiny kitchen barely holds the restaurant’s Ole Hickory Pits smoker, and its cozy dining area has just seven tables. The walls are painted a reddish brown, between black wainscoting below and black ceiling above, so the room itself looks, vaguely, suitably charred; a big overhead fan lazily pushing smoky air around adds to the effect.

headline: Jets Build Running Corps, but Still Lack a Quarterback
abstract: The Jets have secured their top three running backs for next season, but Ryan Fitzpatrick is still a free agent.
lead_paragraph: In the first two days of free agency, the Jets secured their top three running backs for next season — Matt Forte, Bilal Powell and Khiry Robinson. They had yet to determine by Thursday who would be handing the ball off to them.

headline: Review: At Industry Standard, Pub Fare That Gets a Little Adventurous
abstract: The restaurant, which opened in November, offers pub classics along with a few pan-Asian dishes that are almost always outstanding.
lead_paragraph: The formula for the contemporary gastro pub is pretty basic: Offer an alternative to chains like T.G.I. Friday’s by being distinct and idiosyncratic. This includes décor that reflects a personality or a region, a beer and wine selection that embraces local artisans whenever possible, and simple but good food that does not arrive in microwaveable bags trucked in from central headquarters.

headline: Review: Vital, in Montclair, Whisks Diners to the Caribbean
abstract: Led by the chef, Kwame Williams, the restaurant’s creative cuisine and colorful dining room offer the allure of the islands.
lead_paragraph: I’m not partial to Caribbean food but after several visits to Vital in Montclair, I fell in love with it. And I’m not alone. Everyone I brought into the bright and festive restaurant on a busy stretch of Bloomfield Avenue was also smitten. The laid-back atmosphere is one reason; the large, colorful room accented with green walls and turquoise cloth napkins radiates that incongruous mix of luxury and insouciance that distinguishes the best Caribbean resorts. It’s funky in the nicest possible way.

headline: Documenting Violence Against Women, Even if It’s Hard to Look
keywords: ['Art', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A new exhibit at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County explores the brutal treatment of women around the world.
lead_paragraph: The doors to a small but powerful new exhibition at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County in Glen Cove are usually kept closed.

headline: Clyde Lovellette, Hall of Famer Who Brought Size and Skill to Basketball, Dies at 86
abstract: One of the game’s early big men, Lovellette was the first player to win N.C.A.A., Olympic and N.B.A. titles.
lead_paragraph: Clyde Lovellette, a bruising Hall of Famer who was one of the first big men in basketball and the first player to win an N.C.A.A. championship, an Olympic gold medal and an N.B.A. title, died on Wednesday at his home in North Manchester, Ind. He was 86.

headline: White House Welcomes Canada’s First Family
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made the first official visit to the White House by a Canadian leader in 19 years.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made the first official visit to the White House by a Canadian leader in 19 years.

headline: Amid Conflict, Rutgers Acquires a Noted Filmmaker
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Movies', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: The digital filmmaking department created a bachelor’s program, with the filmmaker Nicolás Pereda at the helm. But many students were upset by the departure of a popular director.
lead_paragraph: Aspiring artists who enroll at Rutgers University do not lack for accomplished role models.

headline: Poets Give Voice to Art in ‘Sound and Sense’ at Wadsworth Museum
abstract: An exhibition in Hartford juxtaposes verse with about 50 works of visual, sculptural and decorative arts from the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Go ahead and recite the verses that accompany the artwork in “Sound and Sense: Poetic Musings in American Art,” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art. Feel the pulsing rhythms, like soldiers marching or the relentless ticking of a clock. Listen to the passion: the exuberance of love, the wonderment of nature, the sorrow of loss. Delight in the play of words: “Goosey goosey gander / Whither shall I wander? / Upstairs and downstairs / And in my lady’s chamber.”

headline: At the Jay Heritage Center in Rye: Young Americans
abstract: The 23-acre property is a homage of sorts to a founding father, and to the many important figures who visited the estate.
lead_paragraph: If you like a sprawling, multifaceted plotline when it comes to cultural experiences, incorporating watershed moments in United States history, architecture, landscape design and the abolitionist movement, put the Jay Heritage Center in Rye on your list of destinations.

headline: N.J. Transit Labor Talks Resume, but No Deal Is Reached
abstract: The rail unions were angered by a warning from the agency that health benefits would be suspended in a strike, which could begin in two days.
lead_paragraph: With two days left before New Jersey Transit rail workers could go on strike, negotiators from the agency and its rail unions met again on Thursday but did not reach an agreement.

headline: Wounded Warrior Project’s Board Fires Top Two Executives
abstract: The chief executive, Steven Nardizzi, and chief operating officer, Al Giordano, faced accusations of lavish spending and financial irregularities.
lead_paragraph: The Wounded Warrior Project ousted its top two executives Thursday after accusations of lavish spending and financial irregularities by the charity.

headline: Justin Trudeau’s White House Dinner Has the Air of a Family Reunion
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The state dinner for Canada’s prime minister included celebrity guests born in his country, such as Ryan Reynolds, Sandra Oh, Michael J. Fox and Mike Myers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada mounted the carpeted steps of the White House’s North Portico on Thursday night for one of this city’s most glamorous rituals, a state dinner, he followed in his father’s footsteps — but only so far.

headline: At Garden, Top Big East Seeds Try Out Knicks’ Quarters
abstract: For the top-seeded teams in matchups during the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden, one reward is the opportunity to use the locker room of the arena’s N.B.A. team, the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: When he popped into the training room adjacent to the Knicks’ locker room before Villanova’s quarterfinal game Thursday against Georgetown, Wildcats guard Josh Hart could hardly believe his eyes.

headline: Michael White, Colorful Impresario With a Taste for the Outlandish, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. White could depart from the mainstream to produce “The Rocky Horror Show,” “Oh! Calcutta!” and “Monty Python and the Holy Grail.”
lead_paragraph: Michael White, a Scottish-born theater and movie producer whose catholic but often risqué taste and devil-may-care attitude helped bring to life “The Rocky Horror Show,” “Oh! Calcutta!” and “Monty Python and the Holy Grail,” died on Monday. He was 80.

headline: ‘This Is a Hockey School’: Quinnipiac Students and Polls Agree
abstract: The players do not discuss it much, but the men’s team (25-2-7) and the women’s team (30-2-5) are good enough to win national titles this year.
lead_paragraph: HAMDEN, Conn. — Goaltender Michael Garteig knows it takes 66 hours to drive the 3,000-plus miles to the Quinnipiac University campus from his hometown, Prince George, British Columbia, because he has taken that long journey all by himself.

headline: Riskiest Political Act of 2016? Protesting at Rallies for Donald Trump
abstract: As Mr. Trump has unleashed the pent-up fury of economically displaced Americans, a much smaller but equally fervent protest movement has materialized.
lead_paragraph: When Kashiya Nwanguma learned that Donald J. Trump would campaign in Louisville, Ky., where she is a student, she walked into a FedEx store and printed two colorful signs she had found online, depicting his head on a pig’s body.

headline: Suspended Aroldis Chapman Confident Despite Shaky Debut
abstract: Chapman’s first outing in spring training for the Yankees was entirely forgettable.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Sometime this season, when Aroldis Chapman, baseball’s hardest thrower, confronts the heart of the Toronto Blue Jays’ fearsome batting order, the atmosphere will be different from that of Thursday, when a few thousand fans enjoyed a trifling spring training game.

headline: Chile Halts Inquiry on American Who Disappeared 31 Years Ago
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'Statutes of Limitations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A judge closed a case against retired police and military officers accused of abducting Boris Weisfeiler, who vanished in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship, a mystery that may never be solved.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Boris Weisfeiler, a mathematics professor at Penn State, liked to hike alone. A naturalized American citizen who immigrated from the Soviet Union in 1975, he had explored remote parts of Siberia, Alaska, Canada and Peru. On Dec. 24, 1984, Mr. Weisfeiler embarked on a hiking tour of southern Chile while the country was under military rule.

headline: Brooklyn Man Is Exonerated After 25 Years in Prison for Murder
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Andre Hatchett, 49, is the 19th person to be cleared since the Brooklyn district attorney bolstered efforts to review questionable convictions.
lead_paragraph: When police officers came upon the body of Neda Mae Carter in a park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, 25 years ago, her face and neck were battered, her arms splayed and her legs straight, in the pose of a crucifixion.

headline: ‘Architecture of the Plain’
abstract: Martin Ashwood-Smith builds us a fancy set of steps.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I suppose the Friday puzzle, compared to Thursday, is a bit like pure vs. applied science.

headline: Review: In ‘Boy,’ a Man Deals With Gender Cards He’s Given (Not Born With)
abstract: In Anna Ziegler’s play, Bobby Steggert plays a character — based on an actual person — who was born male but raised female after a botched circumcision.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Steggert is a good little girl. Let me clarify: In the title role of “Boy,” the diligent new play by Anna Ziegler that opened on Thursday night at the Clurman Theater at Theater Row, Mr. Steggert is very good at portraying a little girl who wants to be good but is thwarted by the discomfort that comes from being born a boy, a fact of which she (he) is unaware.

headline: Review: ‘Blackbird’: The Past Returns, Taunting
abstract: David Harrower’s disturbing drama of criminal love returns in a Broadway staging starring Jeff Daniels and Michelle Williams.
lead_paragraph: They make an alarming entrance, these two, setting off instant worry and wonder. They walk as if welded together, though whether in support, restraint or combat is unclear. Her eyes are wild and her bare legs wobbly, and he leads their stuttering steps with an angry, obdurate chin.

headline: In Republican Debate, Candidates Lower Volume as 5 Key Primaries Near
abstract: Neither Donald J. Trump nor his opponents showed much of an appetite for blood in their final debate before next week’s votes in Florida, Ohio and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Get live updates about voting in the Florida primary.

lead_paragraph: Nick Corasaniti of The Times points out key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Coral Gables, Fla., where candidates discussed Cuba, immigration and climate change.

headline: Two Shots at a Title
abstract: Quinnipiac’s highly ranked men’s and women’s hockey teams, whose programs are not that old, both have a chance to win national championships.
lead_paragraph: Quinnipiac’s highly ranked men’s and women’s hockey teams, whose programs are not that old, both have a chance to win national championships.

abstract: Democrats and Republicans sometimes seem to be living in two different Americas. We analyzed the past seven debates on each side to show which topics are most discussed within each party.
lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans sometimes seem to be living in two different Americas. We analyzed the past seven debates on each side to show which topics are most discussed within each party.

headline: Iran Executions at Highest Level Since ’89
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: At least 966 people were put to death in Iran last year, according to a special investigator’s report to the United Nations Human Rights Council.
lead_paragraph: Executions in Iran surged to nearly 1,000 in 2015, a United Nations investigator said on Thursday, the highest level in more than a quarter-century.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The work’s not hard, if you don’t think about radiation.”

headline: Judge Declines to Reopen Case Against Ex-President Kirchner of Argentina
abstract: A complaint filed by a prosecutor who later died in mysterious circumstances accused the former president of derailing an inquiry into a 1994 bombing.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — A federal judge on Thursday refused to reopen a criminal complaint against former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner first brought by a prosecutor who died in mysterious circumstances last year, according to Télam, the state news agency.

headline: Charles Granby, Who Coached Future N.B.A. Players in Queens, Dies at 81
abstract: At Campus Magnet High School in Queens, Granby coached generations of players, including future N.B.A. stars like Chris Mullin, with a combination of brashness and fatherly love.
lead_paragraph: Charles Granby, a renowned New York City basketball coach who amassed 722 victories over 45 years at the same Queens high school, coached a number of future N.B.A. players and served as a father figure for hundreds of young men, died on March 1 in Queens. He was 81.

abstract: Following is a transcript of the Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: “Pixels,” a nostalgic comedy from last summer, is on Starz. And “Bosch” returns for a second season of old-fashioned California noir.
lead_paragraph: “Pixels,” a nostalgia-fueled comedy starring Adam Sandler, is on Starz. ABC News tells the stories of families struggling with heroin addiction. And “Bosch” returns to Amazon for a second season of old-fashioned California noir.

headline: Fact Check: Florida Republican Debate
abstract: The New York Times checks assertions made by the Republican presidential candidates during Thursday's debate in Coral Gables, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times checks assertions made by the Republican presidential candidates during Thursday's debate in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Substance Over Theater
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: There was little sparring and only a few barbs as the Republican presidential candidates largely stuck to talk of trade, terrorism and immigration.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates turned to substance over theatrics on Thursday night in a final effort to court voters before they go to the polls in Florida, Ohio and three other states next week, in what could be a decisive Primary Day. There was little sparring and only a few barbs as the contenders largely stuck to talk of trade, terrorism and immigration. Commentators and critics thought a “low-energy” Donald J. Trump seemed to be running out the clock, while Senator Marco Rubio delivered a sharp performance that probably came too late.

headline: North Korea: New Nuclear Threat
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his country to conduct more nuclear tests, its state media reported on Friday.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his country to conduct more nuclear tests, its state media reported on Friday, while a senior United States military commander, Adm. William E. Gortney, warned during a Congressional hearing that the North had the ability to launch an intercontinental ballistic missile to the United States. The United States and South Korea began large-scale annual joint military exercises this week. Such drills typically prompt the North to issue bellicose warnings.

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, March 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Dogs, Cats and Leadership
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Maybe we should ask candidates questions that would reveal qualities we associate with pets.
lead_paragraph: When he was in the middle of his Syrian peace deal negotiations, Secretary of State John Kerry would go to President Obama with a request: Could the U.S. quietly send a few cruise missiles to hit Assad regime targets, just to send a message and maybe move the Syrian president toward a deal.

headline: Trade and Tribulation
keywords: ['Protectionism (Trade)', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: Donald Trump’s popularity and Bernie Sanders’s Michigan upset prompt the question: Are we in a protectionist moment?
lead_paragraph: Why did Bernie Sanders win a narrow victory in Michigan, when polls showed Hillary Clinton with a huge lead? Nobody really knows, but there’s a lot of speculation that Mr. Sanders may have gained traction by hammering on the evils of trade agreements. Meanwhile, Donald Trump, while directing most of his fire against immigrants, has also been bashing the supposedly unfair trading practices of China and other nations.

headline: Irish Spring
abstract: Emerging triumphant after centuries of sadness.
lead_paragraph: Between the Guinness and the leprechauns, the rivers of green and the buckets of blarney, we’re going to experience a lot of paddywhackery over the next week. Patrick’s high holiday, honoring the Roman British outcast who never drove the snakes from Ireland, may generate more than the usual excess of Celtic pride.

headline: Fill In the Foreign Policy Blanks
abstract: Few of the candidates running for president have given American voters much of a sense of how they would take on issues like Syria and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: The next president will have to set the direction of the fight against terrorism, define America’s role in the Syrian war, which has created a refugee crisis that is destabilizing Europe, and address the tensions between China and its neighbors that could turn into military conflict.

headline: What Are Trump Fans Really ‘Afraid’ to Say?
abstract: Glance at your worst relative’s Facebook page. No one really holds back.
lead_paragraph: RHINESTONES twinkling around the perimeter of her shades, cornsilk curls undaunted by the Pensacola sun, Elizabeth Kemper, a supporter of Donald J. Trump, is all certainty. She is fed up. “You know, this country is so dang political correct,” she tells a CNN reporter. “I’m afraid to say what I really feel, you know?”

headline: New York Challenges a Tax Privilege of the Rich
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Income Tax', 'Private Equity', 'Hedge Funds', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'State Legislatures', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Closing the “carried interest” loophole would be a step toward a fairer taxation system.
lead_paragraph: Two Democratic members of the New York State Assembly, Jeffrion Aubry and Sean Ryan, introduced a bill this week to close the “carried interest” loophole, which lets partners at private equity firms and hedge funds pay a greatly reduced federal tax rate on much of their income.

headline: What Liberals Can Learn From the N.R.A.
abstract: Lessons from the most effective civil rights group in the country.
lead_paragraph: VILIFYING the National Rifle Association’s tactics has long been standard practice among liberals. In October, Hillary Clinton compared dealing with the N.R.A. to “negotiating with the Iranians or the Communists.” In January, President Obama accused the gun lobby of “holding Congress hostage.” The New York Daily News recently called Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A.’s chief executive, a “terrorist.”

headline: A Global Barbie Moment

headline: Donald Trump Criticized After Calling Tiananmen Protests a ‘Riot’
abstract: Mr. Trump said earlier comments to Playboy were not endorsing the crackdown, but critics said his response matched Beijing’s description of the events.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — During the Republican presidential debate on Thursday, Donald J. Trump was forced to defend his earlier comments about the Chinese government’s 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen protests in Beijing. He said that he did not endorse the crackdown, which he called “horrible.” But critics pointed out that in his comments on Thursday he called the protests a “riot,” which matches the Chinese government’s description of the events.

headline: That Family Party Everyone Hated? It Was Mine.
abstract: Every year my holiday party would bring together ex-spouses’ new spouses and step-grandparents in my effort to manufacture closeness.
lead_paragraph: For years my husband and I threw a Christmas Eve party that was completely out of control: Friends brought their friends, and those friends brought their entire families. I never knew who was coming or how many of them there would be. Every year the house was packed with people I’d never seen before. I found them sitting on the couch in my study with the door closed. I found them in the basement. Finally I changed the rules: Only family was invited.

You unwrap a chocolate bar amid breathtaking views of mountain and desert and then you notice movement below.

headline: Maria Sharapova and the Pharmaceutical Quest for an Edge
abstract: A surprising number of healthy people use drugs intended for ill people because they think — often mistakenly — that it will give them an advantage.
lead_paragraph: It’s understandable that athletes at the highest end of the performance spectrum might look for any gain, any edge at all, that might help propel them to the top. Ego, fame and unbelievable amounts of money are at stake. But people all over the athletic spectrum are convinced that one supplement or another will make them healthier, faster or stronger, while other people seek a different sort of edge with drugs they hope will improve cognition.

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Signs Lend-Lease Bill
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Roosevelt signs the lend-lease bill to aid Great Britain in 1941.
lead_paragraph: President Roosevelt, at 3:50 o’clock this afternoon, signed into law his historic lend-lease bill to aid Great Britain by turning the United States into an ‘‘arsenal for democracy.’’ Five minutes later, acting under the broad powers granted to him by the unprecedented peace-time legislation, the President signed orders for the immediate transfer to Britain of an undisclosed amount of Army and Navy equipment — warships, warplanes and general military supplies. Embattled Greece received lesser assistance, and struggling China is to be aided soon.

headline: China Wrestles With Draft Law on Nongovernmental Organizations
abstract: Some wonder if the government worries that the legislation could crimp international cooperation in areas it cares about.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It has been more than two years since the Chinese government proposed tighter controls on foreign nongovernmental organizations, prompting fears for the future of a wide range of groups active in China, like medical charities, branches of foreign universities and business chambers. Among their concerns are the prospect of requirements to obtain government sponsors and police approval of projects and restrictions on fund-raising.

headline: Once Hopeful for Harmony, a Philosopher Voices Discord in France
abstract: Alain Finkielkraut, arguably the country’s most visible public intellectual, believes that much of Islam is incompatible with French society.

Alain Finkielkraut’s mere presence in a television studio raises temperatures and sends accusations of racism flying.

headline: ‘Janet King,’ a Legal Drama Down Under
abstract: Marta Dusseldorp stars in the title role, an Australian prosecutor just back from maternity leave, in this series from the streaming service Acorn TV.
lead_paragraph: If weeknights have become an endless game of “Name That ‘S.V.U.’ Episode,” “Janet King” may be your salvation. The Australian legal drama (beginning Monday, March 14, on the streaming service Acorn TV) stars Marta Dusseldorp in the title role, a senior crown prosecutor with a lacerating tongue and even sharper investigative skills who, on her first day back from maternity leave, is hurled into court to try a sexual predator. That case, though, is just the tip of a very deep iceberg exposed when a high-ranking police officer is charged with euthanizing his ailing wife, and Janet suspects murder. What follows as she connects the dots threatens to tear her relationship with her companion and their twins asunder — and possibly end her own life.  Ms. Dusseldorp has said that her role model was Helen Mirren’s detective in “Prime Suspect,” for whom justice trumped likability. Bonus points: Ms. Dusseldorp’s aquiline profile and formidable stature are killer in the required court attire of wig, jabot and silk robe.

headline: 1966: Verdict in Malcolm X’s Killing
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: All three defendants in the killing of Malcolm X are convicted in 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — All three defendants in the Malcolm X murder trial — two of them Black Muslims — were convicted of murder in the first degree early today [March 11]. Convicted were Talmadge Hayer, 24, also known as Thomas Hagan, of Paterson, N.J.; Norman 3X Butler, 27, and Thomas 15X Johnson, 30, both of the Bronx. Black nationalist leader Malcolm X, 39, was slain in a Manhattan ballroom, Feb. 21, 1965, before 400 of his followers.

headline: ‘For a Little While,’ by Rick Bass
abstract: Rick Bass writes to save our wild places, but also to save what’s wild and humane within us.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say we’ve entered a new geological age, one they propose calling the Anthropocene owing to humanity’s outsize effect on the environment. There’s little doubt to any observant person that we’re making a mess of things. Driving up Route 93 south of Florence, Mont., you can see the damage. Although the loggers quit clearcutting the mountains in the 1980s, the rest of us didn’t stop superheating the planet. Now pine beetles, which flourish in our era of abbreviated winters, have left acres of dead ponderosa and lodgepole pines.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Seven Brief Lessons on Physics,” No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list, outsold “Fifty Shades of Grey” in its author Carlo Rovelli’s native Italy.
lead_paragraph: Let’s Get Physical: If you believe Einstein, time as we usually understand it is “nothing more than a persistent, stubborn illusion.” That may be. But timing is still everything — and the timing could hardly be better for the theoretical physicist Carlo Rovelli’s latest book, “Seven Brief Lessons on Physics,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. Originally published two years ago in Rovelli’s native Italy (where it outsold “Fifty Shades of Grey”), the book arrives in America less than a month after scientists announced the first direct evidence of gravitational waves, confirming Einstein’s theory of general relativity and reigniting the public’s occasional love affair with what may be the hardest of the hard sciences. (Over the years, other theoretical physicists to hit the list have included Stephen Hawking, Brian Greene, Lisa Randall and Lawrence Krauss.) Rovelli, as it happens, is an expert on gravity: He’s a founder of the loop quantum gravity theory, the chief competitor to string theory among efforts to unite the macro world of relativity with the micro world of quantum mechanics. So he was giddy at the news that gravitational waves had been detected. “For physicists this is an ecstatic moment,” he wrote on Slate. “If a benign nature wanted to honor the centenary of Einstein’s idea, she has found the most elegant way. It’s hard to imagine a more vivid indication of the power of scientific reason: From indirect evidence and clarity of thought, reason sees so far that it takes another century before our eyes and our hands can follow up.”

headline: ‘Anna and the Swallow Man,’ by Gavriel Savit
abstract: Orphaned by the Nazis, a young girl survives by wandering the countryside with a mysterious, possibly magical stranger.
lead_paragraph: There are two questions about Gavriel Savit’s splendid debut novel that are sure to be asked repeatedly: Is it an allegory, and at whom is it aimed? The first I believe Savit answers clearly. “The world understands stories,” he has one of his main characters come to realize, “not as absolute, irrevocably factual truths that simply don’t exist, but as flaccid allegories or metaphors.” You may read the novel as allegory; go ahead. All stories are allegory. This one makes use of stock figures from European folklore (the fool, the golem, the trickster, the demon, animal shape-changers). It’s also tempting to expand on ways in which the novel’s characters represent aspects of the Polish people during World War II. Even the winsome chapter-heading designs created by the illustrator Laura Carlin can be interpreted in more than one way. But Anna and the Swallow Man, and the very human people they meet in the course of the novel, also have their own plausible existence within the rules of the world we know. Indeed, they learn to question and distrust allegory as the tale progresses. For every apparent piece of magic performed in the text, there is a scientific explanation. When the Swallow Man gives Anna a fantastical description of the medicine he takes, for example, there is a literal interpretation as well. This is masterly storytelling.

headline: ‘The Girl in the Well Is Me,’ by Karen Rivers
abstract: Trapped by a freakish accident, a girl reconsiders her priorities and her family’s travails.
lead_paragraph: Anyone of a certain age remembers the little girl who fell into a well in Texas in the late 1980s. Workers spent three days trying to free her. It was the stuff of parent nightmares. Coming at the dawn of the 24-hour news cycle, the story was covered night and day, causing our child imaginations to go wild: Was she going to die? How did she go to the bathroom? The event was, of course, soon turned into a TV movie.

headline: ‘Forest of Wonders,’ by Linda Sue Park
abstract: An apothecary’s cure for an injured bat also gives it the ability to speak.
lead_paragraph: It all seems innocent enough. The White Rabbit fretting about the time. Charlotte writing in her web. Pooh spouting his ­honey-sweet wisdom. The world of children’s literature is a veritable petting zoo, full of adorable talking animals ready to snuggle us to sleep.

headline: Five Up and Coming Irish Designers to Know Right Now
abstract: The London furniture store Heal’s is currently hosting Design Ireland, a pop-up market showcasing some of the country’s hottest creative talent.
lead_paragraph: Ireland is a country still best known for Waterford crystal, Belfast linen and Donegal tweed. But these days, talented designers there are working across all disciplines — from glass and ceramics to wood and textiles. Now, thanks to a concerted push by the Design & Crafts Council of Ireland, the wider world is catching on. This month the council is collaborating with Heal’s, a British furniture and furnishing brand with a flagship store on London’s Tottenham Court Road, to host Design Ireland, a pop-up market showcasing some of the hottest creative talent working in the Emerald Isle. Each maker combines traditional crafting techniques and skills with the highest-quality materials and fresh ideas, pushing the boundaries to produce contemporary, relevant objects for the home. There will also be a series of in-store demonstrations offering visitors an insight into the processes behind the craft. Here, we introduce five Irish makers to look out for.

headline: Kafka’s Odds and Ends
abstract: A new book collects pieces of trivia and ephemera by and about Kafka.
lead_paragraph: Kafka really didn’t like mice. “What a horrible silent noisy people they are,” he wrote to a friend. “My feeling toward the mice is flat-out fear,” he explained to another. “It has to do with the unexpected, unbidden, unavoidable, virtually silent, persistent, ulteriorly motivated appearance of these animals.”

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Five options for cheesecake, recipes for the outdoors and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Bookshelf: Bedtime Adventures
abstract: New picture books include “Shhh! I'm Sleeping” and “Blanche Hates the Night.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Shhh! I'm Sleeping” and “Blanche Hates the Night.”

headline: ‘Innocents and Others,’ by Dana Spiotta
abstract: In Dana Spiotta’s novel, two women who grew up together remain in each other’s lives and art.
lead_paragraph: The literature of friendship, like friendship itself, tends to unfold episodically — with none of the narrative determination of the Marriage Plot, in which young women accrue interest like a mutual fund until they mature into the expected climax: not orgasm but matrimony. There is no such thing as the Friendship Plot, because while friendship, like marriage, is at least presumably a voluntary estate, it has no official consummation, no church- or state-sanctioned vows. It would seem, then, that the literary form most suited to its pick-up-where-we-left-off, drop-me-when-you-couple-up-and-have-kids ebb and flow might be the story cycle, or serial tale — just ask Quixote and Sancho, or Huck and Tom, or the four dudes of “The Three Musketeers.”

headline: Political Cloud Relegates Marco Rubio’s Onetime Insider to the Outside
abstract: David Rivera, once Mr. Rubio’s closest ally, is in political exile, trying to resuscitate a career tarnished by accusations of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When Marco Rubio struggled to choose an engagement ring for his wife, his closest friend and unwavering political ally, David Rivera, was by his side. When all four of Mr. Rubio’s children were born, Mr. Rivera kept vigil in the waiting room.

headline: ‘Sudden Death,’ by Álvaro Enrigue
abstract: Caravaggio plays tennis and Cortés conquers Mexico in Álvaro Enrigue’s far-ranging novel.
lead_paragraph: Álvaro Enrigue, a Mexican author who lives in New York, must be having some fun when people ask what his latest novel is about. In no particular order, “Sudden Death” concerns: the tale of four tennis balls made from the hair of a beheaded Anne Boleyn; a fictional tennis match between the Italian painter Caravaggio and the Spanish poet Francisco de Quevedo; Cortés’s conquest of Mexico; and the history of various ball games. It also includes a few emails purporting to be an exchange between the author and an editor in Spain, as well as references to Thomas More’s “Utopia,” Galileo and the Aztec emperor Cuauhtémoc. And there’s a dialogue featuring Pope Pius IV. What isn’t Enrigue’s novel about?

headline: ‘The Night Gardener,’ ‘Tokyo Digs a Garden’ and ‘Stories From Bug Garden’
abstract: In three new picture books, you never know what might crop up in the natural world.
lead_paragraph: Spring is (almost) here. It’s time to be thinking about your garden, if you have one. Even if you don’t, thinking about gardens — renewal, growth, wildness, creativity — has its own reward. As three new picture books with dramatically varied styles of illustration show, a garden is an idea that can be approached from starkly different directions.

headline: Drawing Inspiration
abstract: For some artists the melding of writing and drawing is integral to their process — and a perfect solution to creative difficulties.
lead_paragraph: William Makepeace Thackeray may not be thought of as an artist, but he was a very fine one. He longed to illustrate Dickens, but when he was turned down he wrote his own novel, “Vanity Fair,” partly so he could illustrate it himself.

headline: How Wage Insurance Could Ease Economic Inequality
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'Income Inequality', 'Insurance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Providing wage protection to those who lose their jobs could be expanded through the government and in the private sector.
lead_paragraph: Wage insurance may not be on your radar, but it should be. It helps people who have lost their jobs and cannot find new ones that pay as well. That assistance can reduce economic inequality while providing incentives for unemployed people to go back to work quickly.

lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, The Netherlands — The European Fine Art Fair, held on the outskirts of this historic Dutch city, has for almost three decades been the world’s pre-eminent commercial event devoted to pre-21st-century art and objects.

headline: At a London Restaurant, More Than a French Accent
abstract: In a city with too many tables courting expense-account extravagance, Piquet stands out by offering beautifully sourced and cooked food at reasonable prices.
lead_paragraph: Britain and France may have a historically complicated relationship, but this has never stood in the way of their longstanding connection through fine dining. In this culinary minuet, France has always led by bestowing its food and wines on an island it deems gastronomically benighted, and Britain has shown its gratitude by revering French cooking more than any European country aside from Belgium and maybe Switzerland.

lead_paragraph: Last week, FX announced that it had picked up “Trust,” a new limited series from Danny Boyle, the acclaimed director of “Slumdog Millionaire” and “Steve Jobs.” The 10-episode season will be about the kidnapping of the oil fortune heir John Paul Getty III.

headline: Bernie Sanders Hones Anti-Trade Message for Illinois and Ohio
abstract: After his upset win in Michigan, the candidate’s new ad for two states voting on Tuesday highlights job losses in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Bernie Sanders campaign is bringing the anti-trade message that helped score an upset win in Michigan to the airwaves in two crucial states in the industrial Midwest that vote on Tuesday.

headline: The Rams Can Go Home Again, to the 93-Year-Old Los Angeles Coliseum
abstract: The Rams played in the classic stadium from 1946 to 1979, but it lacks many comforts of a modern N.F.L. pleasure palace.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a hazy afternoon last week at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, the grass was being mowed, as it is every two or three days. A location scout was studying the long staircases for use in a commercial. A guide led a tour along the tunnel that Olympians, Rams, Chargers, Raiders, Dodgers, U.C.L.A. Bruins and U.S.C. Trojans have passed through to enter the field.

headline: Marco Rubio Aide Urges Supporters to Back John Kasich in Ohio
abstract: A top aide to Senator Marco Rubio urged his supporters in Ohio to support Gov. John Kasich in that state’s primary, giving fresh momentum to efforts to stop Donald J. Trump a day after a debate in which his rivals declined to take a swing at the leading Republican presidential candidate.

John Kasich in that state’s primary on Tuesday, giving fresh momentum to efforts to stop Donald J. Trump a day after a debate in which his rivals declined to take a swing at the leading Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Tom Sachs’s Workshop: Willy Wonka Would Approve
abstract: The sculptor and his helpers build an untraditional Japanese garden from whatever materials are available.
lead_paragraph: A visitor entering the Tom Sachs Studio is asked to pose for an instant photo, which is then laminated into a fake Swiss passport. The ritual is only one reason a newcomer feels he has entered a foreign country — or a teenage boy’s clubhouse.

headline: Shari Redstone Prepares for Battle to Control a Media Empire
abstract: Ms. Redstone says she has patched up her relationship with her media mogul father as a legal battle looms over money and power in the family business.
lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone pulls her iPhone out of her purse to show off “just one” picture of her grandchildren. She laughs then apologizes when she sees that the back of the phone is covered with heart-shaped stickers — the result of a craft session with the two youngsters.

headline: Test of Zika-Fighting Genetically Engineered Mosquitoes Gets Tentative F.D.A. Approval
abstract: A trial in the Florida Keys has been tentatively approved, but public comment must be assessed first by the agency.
lead_paragraph: The federal government on Friday moved to clear the way for the release of genetically engineered mosquitoes into the wild for the first time in the United States, tentatively approving a field test that might help slow the spread of the Zika virus.

headline: Starving Public Education
abstract: Why attack the American dream in action?
lead_paragraph: While most of us are focused on presidential politics — with good reason, to be sure — much of the work of government, for good and for ill, is done at the state and local level. In most cases, these days, that means Republican politicians are calling the shots; but there are some big states where Democrats still hold sway, and it’s really important for progressive values that these Democrats set a positive example about what good government can do.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Miranda July
abstract: The writer shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer and T contributor Miranda July, who shares her list exclusively with T.

abstract: We’re springing forward again. But why? Common beliefs about the shift aren’t grounded in fact.
lead_paragraph: (This article has been updated.)

headline: Inside Charles Finch’s BAFTA Party
abstract: The British businessman throws an annual star-studded dinner. Now, he’s compiled highlights into a new book, out this month.
lead_paragraph: The British businessman throws an annual star-studded dinner. Now, he’s compiled highlights into a new book, out this month.

headline: How to Throw a Party You Won’t Want to Leave
abstract: The British businessman Charles Finch, who’s held a famous dinner to celebrate the BAFTAs for years, on how he hosts.
lead_paragraph: When the businessman Charles Finch threw his first BAFTA party at Lola’s in Greater London in 1999, people showed up, he recalls, because “nobody really had anywhere else to go.” But in the years since, his annual dinner — now held at Annabel’s on the eve of the BAFTAs, with a crew of regulars that includes Cate Blanchett, Harvey Weinstein and Mick Jagger — has come to be regarded as one of the most intimate, cozy and fun parties of the year.

headline: A Smaller Down Payment, and No Mortgage Insurance Required
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Homeowners Insurance', 'Personal Finances', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Insurance']
abstract: Traditionally, home buyers needed a 20 percent down payment to avoid the added cost of mortgage insurance. Now there are ways to get around that.
lead_paragraph: It was a year of firsts: In 2015, Kristian and Michele Klein welcomed their first child, a daughter, and bought their first home — a freshly renovated four-bedroom Cape Cod in Glen Head, N.Y.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Profiteers’
abstract: This week, Sally Denton talks about “The Profiteers”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jack Viertel discusses “The Secret Life of the American Musical”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Sally Denton talks about “The Profiteers”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jack Viertel discusses “The Secret Life of the American Musical”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: South by Southwest, by the Numbers
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Music']
abstract: As the music festival kicks off on Friday, we look back at the bands, brands and barbecue that have helped shape it — and Austin.
lead_paragraph: Since its humble beginnings as a showcase for local musicians in 1987, South by Southwest (or “South by,” to its attendees) has exploded into a multigenre behemoth, encompassing not only music performances but film screenings and technology panels. For 10 days each March, hundreds of thousands of pass-holders descend upon downtown Austin, hoping to share patio space with their favorite indie rockers or drink third wave coffee with Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. In the process, they’ve transformed the capital of Texas from a quirky college town into a tech mecca with soaring property values and an eye on the future. (Naturally, as the festival has ballooned in size and prominence, the experience can skew a little corporate.) As SXSW kicks off its 29th incarnation this Friday, we look back at the bands, brands and barbecue that have helped shape America’s biggest networking spectacle.

headline: ‘Two Donald Trumps’ Emerge, the Public One and the Private One
abstract: His public version, Donald J. Trump said, “seems to have worked over my lifetime.” But, he added: “I’m a big thinker. And I have my ideas and they’re strong, and typically they worked out.” He went on to say: “I don’t think there are two Donald Trumps. I think there’s one Donald Trump.”
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — “I think there are two Donald Trumps,” said the first version of Donald J. Trump, addressing reporters at a news conference at Mar-a-Lago, his club where he was endorsed by his former Republican presidential rival Ben Carson on Friday.

lead_paragraph: Two years after drafting him in the first round, the Cleveland Browns cut Johnny Manziel on Friday, in the wake of his many problems both on and off the field.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The Republic of South Sudan is not even five years old, but already 50,000 people have been killed in an ethnically driven civil war.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Diu Tut glanced up at the gates of the displaced persons camp where he lives and shook his head.

headline: Condos on a West Village Triangle
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Condominiums']

headline: On Selection Day, There Are Metrics, and Then There Are Advanced Metrics
abstract: The panel that makes the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball bracket has come to rely on more than the Rating Percentage Index to guide its decision-making.
lead_paragraph: The Rating Percentage Index, an official N.C.A.A. statistic, is the most prominent metric that the men’s basketball selection committee uses to fill out the annual N.C.A.A. tournament bracket, which will be released Sunday. Entering the weekend, Wichita State was a lukewarm 46th in the index.

headline: Is It Really A.D.H.D. or Just Immaturity?
abstract: New research shows that the youngest students in a classroom are more likely to be given diagnoses of attention disorders than the oldest.
lead_paragraph: New research shows that the youngest students in a classroom are more likely to be given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder than the oldest. The findings raise questions about how we regard those wiggly children who just can’t seem to sit still – and who also happen to be the youngest in their class.

headline: With Black Ops Laser Tag, Going to War (and Off the iPad)
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Health Clubs', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: The game, as in an 8-year-old’s birthday party at Indoor Extreme Sports in Queens, gets players off the couch and on to a bloodless battlefield.
lead_paragraph: Years had passed since Edgard El Chaar’s retirement from the United States Army, but on a recent Sunday the former major, now a dentist, found himself back on the battlefield. Sweat trickled down his brow as Dr. El Chaar, 46, wove through barrels of radioactive waste and into enemy territory. Then, sensing his combatant’s vulnerability, he raised his firearm and pulled the trigger.

abstract: A crowded cult dedicated to erecting an ever-higher pedestal to the aesthete, photographer, Bright Young Thing, diarist, painter and designer.
lead_paragraph: Among defunct tastemakers, few rival Cecil Beaton, who died in 1980 at 76, as a continuing commercial franchise.

headline: Obama, at South by Southwest, Calls for Law Enforcement Access in Encryption Fight
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Privacy', 'Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: President Obama told an audience of technology enthusiasts he supported efforts to gain protected information from electronic devices, opposing the stance taken by Apple.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — President Obama said Friday that law enforcement must be legally able to collect information from smartphones and other electronic devices, making clear, despite disagreement within his administration, that he opposes the stance on encryption taken by technology companies like Apple.

headline: Murdered for Activism in Honduras
abstract: In a country known to be deadly for rights advocates, my aunt stood up for the environment and her indigenous kin.
lead_paragraph: Oakland, Calif. — It was always a relief to see my aunt Berta, whom we affectionately called Bertita. Not just because of the constant threats to her life, but because she was a “rayo de luna” — a ray of moonlight — in any situation.

headline: When Gene Tests for Breast Cancer Reveal Grim Data but No Guidance
abstract: The results from genetic tests can leave patients with frightening information but no clear guidance to fight the disease.
lead_paragraph: At a time when genetic testing and genetically personalized treatments for cancer are proliferating, buoyed by new resources like President Obama’s $215 million personalized medicine initiative, women with breast cancer are facing a frustrating reality: The genetic data is there, but in many cases, doctors do not know what to do with it.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 11: An Odd Threesome
abstract: After two energetic chapters, this episode of ‘House of Cards’ treads water.
lead_paragraph: After the energetic, momentous back-to-back episodes that focused on the intrigue of the Democratic National Convention, this chapter of “House of Cards” feels as if its treading water. Without the “will Claire get the vice-presidential nomination or won’t she?” suspense that has fueled much of the season, things suddenly feel less focused. During a conversation with Cathy Durant and the Joint Chiefs in this episode, Frank refers to the advance of the terrorist group ICO as a serpent’s path, which is an apt description for the plots and subplots in this episode.

headline: Donald Trump’s Greatest Hits Against Ben Carson
abstract: A collection of some of Donald J. Trump’s best public criticisms of Ben Carson, the mild-mannered retired brain surgeon who now supports him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson “buried the hatchet” on Friday as Mr. Carson endorsed the Manhattan businessman, proclaiming him the best person to be America’s next president. Mr. Trump said that the tough attacks he once leveled at Mr. Carson were just politics, and Mr. Carson agreed that forgiveness was the way forward.

headline: At Nancy Reagan’s Funeral, Honoring the Queen of a Republican Camelot
abstract: Mourners pay tribute to the former first lady and guardian of President Ronald Reagan, and say goodbye to an era, at her funeral in California.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Nancy Reagan was celebrated at her funeral at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library on Friday, closing a chapter of history revered by conservatives as the Republican Camelot.

headline: Inventgenuity Festival: A Design and Engineering Fair for Children
abstract: This Brooklyn fair for children 7 and older will investigate natural machinery, and its largest venture will explore some of the greatest exemplars of that theme: birds.
lead_paragraph: No matter how creative or powerful the technology, nature can often get the better of it. That happened about two months ago, when the Jan. 23 blizzard forced the cancellation of the Inventgenuity Festival, the seventh annual Brooklyn design and engineering fair for artistic and tech-minded children 7 and older.

headline: An Upper East Side Penthouse for $31 Million
abstract: A triplex penthouse atop a new condominium conversion on the Upper East Side was the top sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A triplex penthouse atop a new condominium conversion on the Upper East Side, just a block from Central Park, with three terraces and a private roof deck, sold for $31,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: BP to End Sponsorship of Tate Museums
abstract: A BP spokesman said the “commercial decision” was prompted by the collapse in oil prices and the decline in the company’s profit since mid-2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BP has decided to end its 26-year sponsorship of the Tate group of art museums, one of Britain’s most high-profile cultural institutions, the energy giant and Tate said on Friday.

headline: A Ted Cruz-Carly Fiorina Ticket? Not So Fast …
abstract: At Mrs. Fiorina’s first campaign stop since endorsing Mr. Cruz, she said she did not intend to be an inconspicuous surrogate but rather would be a prominent critic of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — How would Ted Cruz feel about Vice President Carly Fiorina?

headline: Death in Texas: An Officer’s Odyssey
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Until David Hofer died this month, shot in a park by a 22-year-old with a long criminal record, a police officer hadn’t been killed in Euless, Tex., in 34 years.
lead_paragraph: Euless, Tex., a suburb of Fort Worth, is a town of about 54,000 people, with a low rate of poverty, an average home-to-work travel time of 23 minutes, Italian restaurants and Thai restaurants and 18 parks. A few years ago it attracted the interest of David Hofer, a young police officer in Manhattan’s Ninth Precinct, in the East Village, who was researching places where he might live and begin a family that weren’t quite as noisy as New York, or as expensive, or as alienated from the natural world. Early in 2014, he joined the Euless Police Department; his girlfriend moved to Texas with him. They got engaged and bought a house.

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Abiding Role in her Husband’s Career
abstract: Ronald Reagan credited his wife with saving his soul, and she shrewdly guided him at crucial points in his professional life.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, it seems clear that Ronald and Nancy Reagan were not only one of the great married couples of American history, but also one of its great career partnerships. By the time she became first lady, Nancy Reagan had grown immensely from the new wife of March 1952 who was trying to help her 41-year-old bridegroom onto his feet as he reeled from professional setbacks.

headline: China’s Censors Denounced in Online Attack
abstract: A letter described as written by an employee of Xinhua, the main state-run news agency, spread quickly on the Internet. Then it was taken down.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s formidable propaganda apparatus came under renewed attack on Friday, when a denunciation spread online in the name of an employee of Xinhua, the main state-run news agency. The letter accused censors of using tactics reminiscent of Maoist times to silence and smear critics.

headline: A Dance Project With Fashion, Literary and Indie-Rock Cred
abstract: Boomerang’s new work, “Repercussion,” was created with the designers threeASFOUR, the writer Lewis Hyde and the Deerhoof drummer Greg Saunier.
lead_paragraph: Forget whirling and twirling — there’s nothing dainty about “Repercussion,” the first full-length dance work by Boomerang, a burgeoning dance and performance project that since its inception in 2012 has garnered attention from all corners of the industry. “Repercussion” was developed by Boomerang’s co-directors Kora Radella and Matty Davis in a slew of residencies, and final tweaks took place at the Watermill Center this past summer; its celebrated director, Robert Wilson, called the piece “brilliant” and “exceptionally strong.”

headline: A Push for Less Expensive Hearing Aids
abstract: Many older people need hearing aids, but they can cost $2,500 or more. Medicare doesn’t pay for them, which makes them less likely to be used.
lead_paragraph: I know my television is too loud.

headline: A Powerful Collective Rooting for You: On Vin Diesel’s Facebook
abstract: Vin Diesel’s hugely popular Facebook page is a community for inspiration and fellowship.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

headline: A Student of History, Jerry Dipoto Hopes to Make Some of His Own in Seattle
abstract: General Manager Jerry Dipoto, hired in September, has begun his overhaul of the Mariners, who have the longest playoff drought in baseball.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — When Jerry Dipoto pitched in the major leagues, as a reliever for three teams from 1993 to 2000, he was widely known among players for his vast memorabilia collection.

headline: Possible Gas Pipeline Deal Could Spur Others
abstract: The TransCanada Corporation is said to be in talks with the Columbia Pipeline Group, suggesting that similar deals could be possible.
lead_paragraph: A possible deal with a gas pipeline company is signaling a thaw in mergers and acquisitions in the energy market.

headline: Bernie Sanders Sees Michigan Win as a Springboard to the Nomination
abstract: As he did in Michigan, Mr. Sanders plans to use Hillary Clinton’s stance on trade as one weapon to win over independent, black, white and young voters.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Convinced that his surprising victory in Michigan represented a turning point, Senator Bernie Sanders and his advisers are maneuvering and spending aggressively to pull off a huge upset on Tuesday — a victory in the Ohio primary — by focusing on Hillary Clinton’s past support for trade deals that are deeply unpopular in the Midwest and other key states in his updated battle plans.

headline: Met Opera’s Credit Rating Left Unchanged by Moody’s
abstract: Moody’s, in maintaining its credit rating for the Metropolitan Opera, notes box-office “softness” but also unusual donor support.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera is seeing “some softness in box office revenue” this year compared to what it had budgeted, but continues to benefit from “uncommonly high donor support,” Moody’s Investors Service said in a report issued Friday.

headline: At Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Quiet Before the Hum
abstract: Emon Hassan, a photographer, was accompanied by a security escort through some largely undisturbed corners of the old shipyard, which promises wider public access in the near future.
lead_paragraph: In an article about the Brooklyn Navy Yard last fall, Chris Terrell, a wine importer, described what it was like to run a business inside the 300-acre walled industrial park. “It’s literally like working in a federal prison,” he said, referring to the security checkpoints. If that’s your fetish, get there quickly, because the rusted old shipyard, which New York City bought from the federal government in 1966, is rapidly going the way of the rest of Brooklyn, with a small-batch distillery and rooftop farm already in place and a cavernous food hall featuring an outpost of Russ & Daughters, a purveyor of smoked fish and Jewish delicacies, on the way. The yard, which has long been closed to everyone but employees and their guests, is in the process of opening up, with more than 300 industrial tenants currently humming and promises of wider public access in the near future. If you hand-slice Nova, they will come.

headline: Jack Gibbs Shines Brightly in Stephen Curry’s Shadow
abstract: Gibbs is a high-scoring Davidson guard. That means comparisons to Curry, who played for the school.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jack Gibbs engaged in a heated argument with his teammates about the propercolor of fire hydrants. Gibbs, a junior guard at Davidson, was so certain of his stance that he posted a poll on Twitter. In a near landslide, voters sided with him.

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

lead_paragraph: Q. I’d like to do something more the week of St. Patrick’s Day than watch a parade. Would you know of any Manhattan tour focusing on Irish-American history?

abstract: Researchers asked Siri a series of questions to see how it responded.
lead_paragraph: Researchers asked Siri a series of questions to see how it responded.

lead_paragraph: A Broadway actress has taken the rare step of publicly challenging the tone of anonymous online comment boards where theater lovers exchange news, gossip and opinions, often with a heavy dose of snark.
