headline: For the Expat or the Local
abstract: Books, manga and Japanese ephemera abound at Kinokuniya.
lead_paragraph: Books, manga and Japanese ephemera abound at Kinokuniya.

headline: Turning Japanese at Kinokuniya in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: The New York branch of Japan’s largest bookstore chain offers an array of texts in English and Japanese: fiction, manga and, of course, booklets on dog haircuts.
lead_paragraph: Cleo Fleming was spending her lunch hour on a recent Tuesday browsing the fiction section at Kinokuniya, a bookstore opposite Bryant Park. You can find the latest in American pop culture on its display tables: Lena Dunham’s “Not That Kind of Girl,” Aziz Ansari’s “Modern Romance,” Allie Brosh’s “Hyperbole and a Half.” But while Kinokuniya has the bright design of a chic New York bookstore, it also feels very much apart from Midtown Manhattan.

headline: How Barry Rohrssen, a Basketball Coach, Spends His Sundays
abstract: For Mr. Rohrssen, the associate head coach for men’s basketball at St. John’s University in Queens, Sundays include sports, church and Frosted Mini-Wheats.
lead_paragraph: If Barry Rohrssen, 55, the associate head coach for men’s basketball at St. John’s University in Queens, seems a bit preoccupied this weekend, it’s probably because he’s following the news of who will be invited to “the big dance,” as the N.C.A.A. tournament is called. (St. John’s will be sitting this one out.) You might also spot him at church or grocery shopping in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where he lives with his fiancée, Kerry Parker, 33. Mr. Rohrssen, who is nicknamed Slice, had a minor acting role in the 1992 film “Glengarry Glen Ross.” He said New York “is one of the few towns where you can do something like that; where else do you have opportunities to be a coach and be in a film?”

headline: General Motors to Buy Cruise Automation in Push for Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Industry analysts said the G.M. deal underscores how competitive the race toward autonomous vehicles has become.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors on Friday said that it was acquiring the software firm Cruise Automation as part of its larger effort to develop fully autonomous vehicles.

headline: For Donald Trump, Friends in Few Places
abstract: Who are Mr. Trump’s real friends? Those who know him say there aren’t many.
lead_paragraph: Last month Donald J. Trump  told a crowd in New Hampshire that he would happily annoy his wealthy friends if it meant getting big money out of politics. “I have no friends, as far as I’m concerned,” he said. “You know who my friends are? You’re my friends.”

headline: The Superior Social Skills of Bilinguals
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Language and Languages', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Yet another benefit to speaking multiple languages.
lead_paragraph: BEING bilingual has some obvious advantages. Learning more than one language enables new conversations and new experiences. But in recent years, psychology researchers have demonstrated some less obvious advantages of bilingualism, too. For instance, bilingual children may enjoy certain cognitive benefits, such as improved executive function — which is critical for problem solving and other mentally demanding activities.

headline: David M. Gates Dies at 94; Sounded Early Alarm on Environmental Perils
abstract: Dr. Gates was in the vanguard of scientists who warned early on that fossil fuels, fertilizers and pesticides posed a dire threat to the environment.
lead_paragraph: David M. Gates, an ecologist who sounded early warnings that fossil fuels, fertilizers and pesticides posed a potentially fatal threat to the global environment, died on March 4 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 94.

headline: How Toothless Regulation Makes Raising Secret Campaign Money Easier
abstract: Two supposed watchdog agencies recently showed how feeble their oversight has become.
lead_paragraph: Considering the torrent of political money flowing through Washington, fundraisers from both parties must be rejoicing as the campaign finance industry feasts on the presidential contests. Particularly since two supposed watchdog agencies, the Federal Election Commission and Internal Revenue Service, have just presented fresh evidence of how feeble their oversight has become.

headline: ‘War Horse’ Closes in Britain, but Its Influence Gallops On
abstract: The show, which has played for seven years on the West End, has changed the National Theater and perhaps the industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After seven years in the West End here, “War Horse” is onto its final furlong. Just after 10 p.m. on Saturday, its equine star, Joey — that magnificent puppet – will gallop offstage at the New London Theater for the last time. Some 2.7 million people will have cheered him on there, but “War Horse” has been a global success, seen by nearly seven million worldwide. It has changed the National Theater, which opened it in 2007 — and arguably British theater as a whole — dramatically.

headline: Sterling Ruby’s Clothing (Yes, Clothing) Designs Go on Display
abstract: “Work Wear: Garment and Textile Archive 2008-2016,” opening today at Sprüth Magers London, gathers the artist’s handmade ponchos, coats and pants.
lead_paragraph: Though some may think that Sterling Ruby’s relationship to clothing design hinges entirely on Raf Simons, his ongoing collaborator, it actually all began when the L.A.-based multidisciplinary artist (whose output spans painting, ceramics and video) was just 12 or 13 — when his mother gave him a sewing machine. “I remember her being upset with me because I kept bending her bobbin and needle clamp,” Ruby says. “I was always trying to run thick upholstery-like material through her machine.” He liked to deconstruct clothes, “cutting off the sleeves and collars, patching them back together, then adding hand-painted and stenciled materials,” and pulled inspiration from the punk scene. (Although Ruby grew up on a farm in Pennsylvania, his parents allowed him to slip off to Baltimore and Washington, D.C. for concerts, as long as he made it to school in the mornings.) He mentions seeing H.R. from Bad Brains in denim and Black Flag’s Greg Ginn, who favored Oxford shirts, and Henry Rollins, in only his running shorts. Ruby says he was “really just a kid, thinking that there was power in the way people dressed.”

headline: Angolan President, in Power Nearly Four Decades, Says He’ll Step Down
abstract: José Eduardo dos Santos, a former guerrilla who came to power in 1979, has been criticized for human rights violations and rampant inequality in Angola.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The president of Angola, José Eduardo dos Santos, one of Africa’s longest-ruling leaders, announced on Friday that he would step down from office in 2018.

headline: Review: Philharmonic Takes on the ‘Turangalîla-Symphonie’
abstract: Messiaen’s vast 10-movement symphony is such a formidable undertaking that every performance is an event.
lead_paragraph: Before conducting the New York Philharmonic in Messiaen’s “Turangalîla-Symphonie” on Thursday night, Esa-Pekka Salonen assured the audience that he did not want to tell anyone how to listen to this “sprawling, ecstatic madness,” as he described this stunning piece, completed in 1948. Instead, he just wanted to explain how he heard it. Then later, he added, “We can compare notes.”

headline: The Times on the Air: Brazil, Trump, Ad Blockers and More
abstract: A weekly recap of the television and radio appearances of New York Times journalists.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters, columnists and executives participated in interviews about their coverage and other top news stories. Below are some radio highlights.

headline: Review: Echoes of Flamenco From Orchestra of St. Luke’s
abstract: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s Carnegie Hall concert saw its Granada-born conductor interpret the work of an Andalusian composer.
lead_paragraph: The Andalusian composer Manuel de Falla was inspired by Gypsy music when he wrote his ballet “El Amor Brujo” (“The Bewitched Love”), although today the flamenco vocal line is usually rendered by a classically-trained mezzo-soprano. Pablo Heras-Casado, principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, also from Spain’s Andalusian region, prefers hewing to the composer’s original vision, and so, in a concert on Thursday at Carnegie Hall, he paired the gritty voice of the flamenco singer Marina Heredia  with the polished, smoothly-sensual sound of the orchestra.

headline: Review: In ‘Brodsky/Baryshnikov,’ One Friend Recalls Another
abstract: In this piece presented by the Baryshnikov Arts Center, Mikhail Baryshnikov recites poetry by Joseph Brodsky, the Nobel laureate who died in 1996.
lead_paragraph: I have never felt a particular desire to learn Russian, wonderful though it would be to read, say, Chekhov in the original language. But I’m sure it would have enhanced my enjoyment of “Brodsky/Baryshnikov,” a theater piece that, as the title makes clear, features the former ballet star Mikhail Baryshnikov reciting, in Russian, selections from the poetry of Joseph Brodsky.

headline: Ben H. Bagdikian, Reporter of Broad Range and Conscience, Dies at 96
abstract: He covered stories from the Suez crisis to segregation, then trained his sharp eye on journalism itself, and its increasingly corporate character.
lead_paragraph: Ben H. Bagdikian, a journalist and news media critic who became a celebrated voice of conscience for his profession, calling for tougher standards of integrity and public service in an era of changing tastes and technology, died on Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Review: New Order, Still a Clockworks of Suppressed Emotion
abstract: The British band, sustained by a mixture of electronic beats and intricate musical patterns, played to a sold-out Radio City Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: New Order got started in 1980 amid personal and political turmoil, reacting thoroughly against both.

headline: Review: Farruquito, Flamenco From a Soaring Eagle
abstract: The dancer returns to New York, after an absence of 13 years, as part of Flamenco Festival 2016.
lead_paragraph: The flamenco dancer Farruquito returned to New York on Thursday, after an absence of 13 years, like a king reclaiming his realm. Within moments, he proved that he is one of today’s superlative dance artists. He’s slender, handsome, taut; he transfixed attention just by standing, walking, raising an arm. In simple passages, he demonstrated stunning effects of contrast. Taking the City Center stage three times during a 90-minute program shared with the guest dancer Gema Moneo and seven musicians, he built each solo to peaks of rich rhythmic brilliance.

headline: The Ensembles of Miles Davis Epitomized Cool
abstract: As a new movie from Don Cheadle makes clear, Miles Davis’s look was as stylish as his sound.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “Miles Ahead,” the soon-to-be-released movie about Miles Davis, directed by and starring Don Cheadle, the famously irascible musician tells a freelance writer (played by Ewan McGregor) in a dowdy corduroy blazer, “You’re not driving me around looking like that no more.”

headline: My Father’s Killer’s Funeral
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Tens of thousands turned out in the streets of Pakistan to mourn the radical Islamist who assassinated my father.
lead_paragraph: ON Feb. 29 — a bad day for anniversaries — Pakistan executed my father’s killer.

headline: Review: ‘And Then There Were None,’ a Classic Murder Case Revived
abstract: Agatha Christie’s mystery goes beyond its roots as a whodunit into new psychological territory in this BBC production being shown on Lifetime.
lead_paragraph: “And Then There Were None” — the alternate name of the 1939 Agatha Christie novel “Ten Little _____” — stands out among her work for more than its startlingly racist original title. It’s a mystery without a detective, no Hercule Poirot or Miss Marple to make sense of things — just 10 people trapped on an island, being murdered one by one per the instructions of a macabre nursery rhyme.

headline: Autodesk Chooses Peace With Activist Investors
abstract: Autodesk’s chief recently compared activist investors to callers on sports-talk radio. Now, some will join its board.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While activist battles at other technology companies appear to be heating up, what looked like a potential fight brewing at Autodesk has instead ended quietly.

headline: Jenrry Mejia’s Lawyer and M.L.B. Trade Charges Over Doping Ban
abstract: Major League Baseball was accused of using unscrupulous tactics in its handling of Jenrry Mejia’s doping offenses, an accusation baseball rejected.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer representing Jenrry Mejia, the Mets pitcher who was permanently barred from Major League Baseball for failing three drug tests, said Friday that baseball used unscrupulous tactics in its handling of his doping offenses.

headline: Unearthing an Old Reptilian Relative of Dinosaurs
abstract: Called Teyujagua paradoxa, or “fierce lizard,” the species was recently discovered in Rio Grande do Sul, in southern Brazil.
lead_paragraph: A quarter of a billion years ago nearly all life on Earth vanished in a cataclysmic event known today as “the Great Dying.”

abstract: The actress, movie producer and singer-songwriter has a new album, “Rita Wilson,” which she is performing on a 20-city tour.
lead_paragraph: Rita Wilson walked into Bleecker Street Records and headed for the counter.

headline: Jets, Lacking Fitzpatrick, Meet With Robert Griffin III
abstract: With negotiations with Ryan Fitzpatrick at an impasse, New York hosted Griffin, the former No. 2 overall pick whose promising career in Washington foundered.
lead_paragraph: The Jets want to re-sign Ryan Fitzpatrick, who has said he wants to re-sign with them. But with negotiations at an impasse, the Jets are not waiting around for him.

headline: Antique Dealers Protest New 1stdibs Rules
abstract: The online antiques marketplace has instituted new policies some say are ‘Orwellian.’
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, a sign was placed in the window of Lost City Arts, a high-end vintage design store in Lower Manhattan, saying the shop was closing early. Inside, 30 of the city’s top antiques dealers had gathered for a tense, hastily arranged meeting. Other dealers dialed in from Texas and California to hear the proceedings.

headline: Review: In ‘The Perfect Match,’ Weddings, Babies and One Bachelor Holdout
abstract: Bille Woodruff’s circle-of-friends romantic comedy puts a commitment-phobic Los Angeles talent agent in the path of a ravishing mystery woman.
lead_paragraph: While its title suggests a narrower focus, “The Perfect Match” is largely an ensemble rom-com, and a pretty enjoyable one. Set in a youngish, upscale circle of Los Angeles, the movie sees five old friends negotiating standard life and lifestyle challenges. The scenarios and their attendant psychologies are utterly conventional, but the characters and cast are appealing in equal measure.

headline: Hillary Clinton Lauds Reagans on AIDS. A Backlash Erupts.
abstract: Attending Nancy Reagan’s funeral on Friday, Mrs. Clinton praised her record on H.I.V. and AIDS. After an avalanche of criticism, she quickly apologized, saying she “misspoke.”
lead_paragraph: In the days since her death on Sunday, Nancy Reagan has been praised for her work on a range of causes, from preventing drug abuse to supporting research into Alzheimer’s.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Artists Grapple With America’s Prison System
abstract: The penal system in the United States moves beyond politics and into museums.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks in February and March, the Whitney Museum’s fifth-floor gallery has been drenched in the slamming of gates, the rattling of keys and the bellowing of prisoners and guards. The artist Andrea Fraser recorded the sounds at Sing Sing, the infamous prison 34 miles up the Hudson River, then fed them into a gallery that’s roughly the same size as the prison’s A Block.

headline: As Americans Take Up Populism, the Supreme Court Embraces Business
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court vacancy created by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia highlights a growing rift between the country and the nation’s highest court on questions of economic power and support for big business.

headline: Europe Tries to Shut Down Routes as Migrant Flow Intensifies
abstract: European leaders announced an agreement this week aimed at stopping the flow of migrants trying to reach Europe through the Balkans. In January and February, more than 123,000 migrants landed in Greece, compared with about 4,600 in the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: European leaders announced an agreement this week aimed at stopping the flow of migrants trying to reach Europe through the Balkans. In January and February, more than 123,000 migrants landed in Greece, compared with about 4,600 in the same period last year.

headline: Federal Agents Raid Christie’s, Seizing 2 Ancient Sculptures
abstract: The artworks were to be included in a sale on Tuesday called “The Lahiri Collection: Indian and Himalayan Art, Ancient and Modern.”
lead_paragraph: The calendar for Asia Week in New York City, an observance dedicated to art from the region, included events on Friday at the Japan Society, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Tibet House. But one unscheduled incident occurred in the morning: Federal agents raided Christie’s to seize what they said were stolen antiquities that were to have been sold as part of the festivities.

headline: Stalin, Russia’s New Hero
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The gulag is a distant memory. In today’s Russia, people pine for an era of order and superpower status.
lead_paragraph: Penza, Russia — AT School No. 58 in Penza, a regional capital that is an eight and a half hour drive southeast of Moscow, the jury is still out on Joseph Stalin.

headline: Emoji Feminism
keywords: ['Emojis and Emoticons', 'Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: When women succeed against all odds, don’t just text them an image of airborne confetti.
lead_paragraph: RECENTLY, upon notice that she’d received tenure, I texted a close friend to offer my congratulations. Later, I knew, we’d meet for drinks and celebration, but the day was early and I was thrilled, imagining her pleasure in her hard-won achievement.

headline: N.J. Transit Reaches Tentative Deal With Rail Workers, Averting a Strike
abstract: The last-minute deal came just over a day before workers could have gone on strike, which officials said could have crippled commuting into New York City.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — New Jersey Transit reached a tentative agreement with its rail workers on Friday night to avoid a strike that could have paralyzed commuting into New York City, officials said.

headline: Naná Vasconcelos, Daring Brazilian Percussionist, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Vasconcelos was an award-winning talent, collaborating with artists as varied as the Talking Heads and Pat Metheny.
lead_paragraph: Naná Vasconcelos, a Brazilian percussionist whose stylistic daring and freewheeling experimentalism made him a sought-after collaborator with artists as varied as the Argentine jazz saxophonist Gato Barbieri and the Talking Heads, died on Wednesday in Recife, Brazil. He was 71.

headline: Bernie Sanders Praises Ruling Allowing 17-Year-Olds to Vote in Ohio
abstract: A group of 17-year-olds in Ohio have successfully persuaded a state judge to allow them to vote in the state’s primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A group of 17-year-olds in Ohio has successfully persuaded a state judge to allow them to vote in the state’s primary on Tuesday.

headline: Mass Market Edition of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ to End
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Education (K-12)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: An edition of Harper Lee’s classic that is popular in classrooms will not be sold after April 25, although more expensive editions will be available.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird” has been a staple in schools across the country, sparking countless classroom discussions about complex issues like race and social justice. But its long legacy in classrooms could be threatened by a recent decision to discontinue a popular paperback edition.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Cure for the Cold
abstract: Women and men came out of their winter cocoons like butterflies in light, colorful clothes. Legs were bared.
lead_paragraph: New York City experienced the magic of a drastic weather change last week. From Monday to Thursday, New Yorkers had their first break from winter’s grip as the city took on a springlike appearance. By the fourth day, it was more like summer. Women and men came out of their winter cocoons like butterflies in light, colorful clothes. Legs were bared. Some men were nattily dressed, but the majority just stripped down to open-neck shirts. The parks were a magnet for lunchtime throngs.

headline: Evening Hours | A Flower Show and Fundraisers
abstract: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.

headline: U.S. Finds More Possible Victims in Hacking of Celebrities’ Email Accounts
keywords: ['Identity Theft', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'E-Mail', 'Celebrities']
abstract: A federal prosecutor in Manhattan said other possible victims have emerged in the case of Alonzo Knowles, who is accused of breaking into email accounts to acquire personal information about famous people.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor in Manhattan said on Friday that investigators were continuing to learn of possible new victims in the case of a Bahamian man accused of hacking into the email accounts of celebrities and others to obtain and sell stolen scripts of unreleased movies, sexually explicit videos and personal information like passport and Social Security numbers.

headline: Are as Many Civilians Dying in South Sudan as in Syria?
abstract: Uncounted thousands are dying from South Sudan’s civil war, not so much from bullets as from malnutrition and disease, and the conflict isn’t getting the attention it merits.
lead_paragraph: The answer is we don’t know, because the data aren’t reliable, especially for South Sudan. But as I write in my column, it’s possible — and that’s staggering considering how little attention South Sudan has received. The Tyndall Report says that television network evening news programs provided zero coverage of South Sudan’s civil war in 2015.

headline: U.S. Rebukes Iran Over Missile Tests, Calling Them Provocative
abstract: The United States ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, scheduled a Security Council meeting on Monday to address what she called “these dangerous launches.”
lead_paragraph: The United States rebuked Iran on Friday over a series of “provocative and destabilizing” ballistic missile tests this week and all but accused the Iranians of having violated a United Nations Security Council resolution that calls on them to refrain from such acts.

headline: Donald Trump’s Rally in Chicago Canceled After Violent Scuffles
abstract: Protesters and supporters of Donald J. Trump confronted each other, screaming and shoving, at a campaign event Friday that was called off over security concerns.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With thousands of people already packed into stands and music blaring to warm up the crowd, Donald J. Trump’s campaign abruptly canceled his rally here on Friday night over security concerns as protesters clashed with his supporters inside an arena where he was to speak.

headline: States Move to Control How Painkillers Are Prescribed
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'States (US)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Heroin']
abstract: A national heroin crisis may be forcing change in how doctors use narcotic painkillers, the most widely prescribed class of drugs in the nation.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of states, alarmed by the rising death toll from prescription painkillers and frustrated by a lack of federal action, are moving to limit how these drugs are prescribed.

headline: ‘In It to Win It,’ Says Phil Jackson, Vowing Knicks Revival
abstract: Jackson, the team president, discussed Carmelo Anthony, Kurt Rambis and free-agent possibilities in a rare news conference.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As questions about the direction of the struggling Knicks continued to hound the organization, Phil Jackson, the team’s president, held a rare discussion with the news media on Friday morning to address a host of festering concerns.

headline: Man Accused in Anti-Islam Cartoon Attack Awaits Verdict
abstract: A Muslim convert in Arizona was accused of financing, training and motivating the two men who attacked an anti-Islam cartoon exhibit last year in Texas.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Jurors on Friday began deliberating the fate of a Muslim convert accused of financing, training and motivating the two men who tried to attack an exhibit of anti-Islam cartoons last year in Texas. The assault was thwarted, leaving the gunmen dead after a shootout with the police.

headline: Peace Event Hosts Wives of South Sudan Leaders Tied to Rape
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The spouses of two South Sudanese rivals accused by the United Nations of using sexual violence as a war tactic are participating in a United Nations panel.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Two rivals for power in South Sudan are accused by the United Nations of not only drawing their people into one of the world’s most gruesome wars, but also subjecting the country’s women and girls to unspeakable horrors.

headline: After Diatribe by Goose Gossage, He and Yankees Clear the Air
abstract: One day after an expletive-peppered interview with ESPN.com, Gossage, a training-camp instructor, received a talking-to from Yankees management.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Goose Gossage still wears his fearsome mustache — it is just white now — and carries himself around the Yankees’ clubhouse during spring training with the same body language that made him one of baseball’s more intimidating presences during the late 1970s and early ’80s.

headline: White House Backs Off From Obama’s Critique of Cameron
abstract: President Obama unloaded on a number of American allies: Britain, France, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and other Persian Gulf countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his much-discussed interview with The Atlantic magazine, President Obama unloaded on a number of American allies: Britain, France, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and other Persian Gulf countries. On Friday, a White House official walked back Mr. Obama’s comments about the closest of the allies, Britain, and its prime minister, David Cameron.

headline: Newark School Officials Knew of Lead Risks, 2014 Memo Shows
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Lead', 'Water Pollution', 'Water', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The document, sent that summer, urged principals and custodians to have everyone run the water in fountains before drinking in an effort “to reduce the risk of possible lead contamination.”
lead_paragraph: In August 2014, as 35,000 students prepared to return to Newark’s public schools, Keith Barton, the managing director of operations for the district, sent a memo with an urgent message to all principals, custodians and building managers: Before anyone drank from the water fountains, they should run the water for at least 30 seconds.

headline: A Reluctant Barkeep, Mourned on the Brooklyn Streets That Called Him Home
abstract: Sunny Balzano, a fixture at his family’s quirky bar, Sunny’s Bar, in Red Hook, died on Thursday at 81.
lead_paragraph: The thing about Sunny Balzano was you couldn’t stop him from talking, but you didn’t ever want to. He just had stories to tell and stories to tell and stories to tell. And you listened, mesmerized, chuckling along while quaffing your second or third or 13th drink in his bar, Sunny’s Bar, wedged in at the foot of the harbor in Red Hook, Brooklyn. It was a motley joint, decorated with just about everything, but so what, you felt good there.

headline: Asdrubal Cabrera May Not Be Healed in Time for Opening Day
abstract: After straining a tendon in his left knee on Thursday, Cabrera was to undergo plasma therapy, and the Mets were looking at their options at shortstop.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Asdrubal Cabrera walked without a limp on Friday but had mixed feelings as he headed from the Mets clubhouse to his car.

headline: After Complaints on Wounded Warrior Project, Pressure From Donors
abstract: By the time the Wounded Warrior Project’s board met on Thursday, it had concluded that with contributions down and a damning report in, top leadership had to go.
lead_paragraph: When the Wounded Warrior Project was hit in January with multiple accusations in the news media of lavish spending on travel, conferences and public relations, and a toxic corporate culture, Fred Kane, one of its major fund-raisers, was stunned by the organization’s response.

headline: Alex Carpenter’s Last Chance to Add a National Title to Her Résumé
abstract: Carpenter, an Olympic medalist whose father, Bobby Carpenter, played 18 N.H.L. seasons, continues her quest for Boston College’s first Frozen Four championship.
lead_paragraph: Boston College center Alex Carpenter is at the pinnacle of women’s hockey.

headline: Trump Clarifies, and It’s Worse
abstract: If you want to fix the system, hire someone who already exploits it.
lead_paragraph: Admit it, people, you miss the Republicans screaming at one another.

headline: I’m Not Evil. I’m a Landlord.
abstract: I think I’m better at providing affordable housing than the government.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland Heights, Ohio — MATTHEW DESMOND, a Harvard sociology professor, moved into poor Milwaukee neighborhoods and wrote this year’s hottest ethnographic tome about it: “Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City.” While working on the book, he kept a journal. He wrote, “I feel dirty, collecting these stories and hardships like so many trophies.”

headline: Gary Jeter, 61, Giants Draftee Who Starred as Rams Lineman
abstract: A promising rookie who did not immediately live up to expectations, Jeter later thrived, particularly after a trade to the Rams.
lead_paragraph: Gary Jeter, a former defensive lineman and a highly touted draft pick by the Giants whose best playing years came after he was traded to the Los Angeles Rams in 1983, died on Wednesday at his home in Plainsboro, N.J. He was 61.

headline: Supreme Court Contenders and Their Views on Big Business
abstract: Here are the leading contenders, with a snapshot of what we know about their views on business-related legal issues.
lead_paragraph: Here are the leading contenders, with a snapshot of what we know about their views on business-related legal issues.

headline: Saving a Mixed-Income New York
abstract: The city should pursue a strategy of enlarging the permanently affordable cityscape.
lead_paragraph: Could it be that the fate of New York City is being decided right now? Mayor Bill de Blasio thinks so.

headline: Protecting the Privacy of Internet Users
abstract: The rules proposed this week by the F.C.C. chairman are needed to give consumers control over their personal information.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission proposed common-sense privacy rules this week that would limit what broadband companies are allowed to do with the Internet browsing history and other personal information of consumers.

headline: When the College Degree Is Useless and the Debt Is Due
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Student Loans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'For-Profit Schools']
abstract: A court ruling and a proposed federal rule should help to rein in predatory education companies and provide relief to their students.
lead_paragraph: For-profit colleges that saddle students with crushing debt and useless degrees — while getting as much as 90 percent of their revenue from the federal student aid program — represent an especially destructive form of corporate welfare. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit recognized exactly that on Tuesday when it upheld Obama administration rules that would deny federal aid to career training programs that bury students in debt that is beyond their capacity to repay.

headline: Hague Appeals Panel Voids Conviction of Lebanese TV Executive
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Karma al-Khayat had been fined 10,000 euros for defying a court order to remove information about confidential witnesses from her TV station’s website.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Appeals judges at an international tribunal in The Hague have overturned the conviction of a Lebanese television executive and cleared her and her station of charges of contempt of court.

headline: Get Down
abstract: Josh Knapp is cool with us.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —I didn’t struggle mightily with this Josh Knapp production, but that could be because I’m a hipster. I mean, I liked the Roots from way back when, yo – long before QUESTLOVE sold out to big television. And did I visit the world’s largest IKEA when I took my ironic vacation to Seoul? You betcha – THAT’S WHAT’S UP. I can’t stop saying that phrase now. It works in every situation.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 12, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If, technologically, it is possible to make an impenetrable device or system, where the encryption is so strong that there is no key, there is no door at all, then how do we apprehend the child pornographer? How do we disrupt a terrorist plot?”

headline: Keith Emerson, ’70s Rock Showman With a Taste for Spectacle, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Emerson was also an early innovator who incorporated the Moog synthesizer into his work in Emerson, Lake & Palmer.
lead_paragraph: Keith Emerson, the keyboardist of the English supergroup Emerson, Lake & Palmer and one of the key figures of the progressive-rock era in the 1970s, was found dead on Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 71.

headline: World’s Oldest Man, a Confectioner From Poland, Survived Auschwitz
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Longevity', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Israel Kristal, 112, lost his family in the Holocaust and weighed 81 pounds when the Allies freed him from a labor camp. Now, he has been declared the world’s oldest man.
lead_paragraph: Israel Kristal lived through the tumult of two world wars, lost his family in the Holocaust and escaped death in the Auschwitz concentration camp. He then built a new life in Israel. On Friday, at the age of 112 years and 178 days, he was declared the oldest man in the world.

headline: Donald Trump Urges Party to Unite, but Resistance Remains
abstract: “We’ve had enough debates,” Mr. Trump said on Friday. Those looking to halt his march toward the Republican nomination had other ideas.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Donald J. Trump sought to move past the primary fight and toward the Republican nomination on Friday, saying that there had been enough debates and that the party needed to come together behind him. But as he cast his eye forward, he raised fresh questions about his porous understanding of intricate policy matters that all presidents face.

headline: Venus Williams Returns to Indian Wells, in the Form of a Shooting Star
abstract: After boycotting the tournament for 14 years after not feeling welcome, Williams fell in a second-round match to the 89th-ranked Kurumi Nara in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — For a change, it was the trailblazing Venus Williams’s turn to follow her younger sister Serena’s lead.

headline: Ted Cruz Says Donald Trump Is to Blame for Violence at His Rallies
abstract: Speaking to reporters at a local Republican dinner outside Chicago, where Donald J. Trump had just canceled a rally amid fierce confrontations, Senator Ted Cruz said “responsibility starts at the top.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas said on Friday that Donald J. Trump bore responsibility for “creating an environment” that encourages violence at his events.

headline: Ben Simmons, a Top Big Man, May Find an N.C.A.A. Berth Is Out of Reach
abstract: Simmons, a dynamic freshman forward, and L.S.U. need the automatic berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament that comes with winning the Southeastern Conference tournament.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — College basketball’s most talented player stood near the free-throw line with his mouthguard sticking out. He appeared listless as his Louisiana State teammates passed the ball around the perimeter. Then, in a single fluid motion, he shoved the mouthpiece into position and rolled off his defender to the basket and soared for a powerful alley-oop dunk.

headline: Thomas Greiss Calmly Comes to the Islanders’ Rescue
abstract: Greiss, signed as a free agent last summer to back up the now-injured Jaroslav Halak, could be a key for the Islanders as they make a playoff push.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — Islanders goaltender Thomas Greiss and his wife, Brittney, were running errands in his enormous truck during a late January snowstorm that ultimately canceled the team’s home game that night against Philadelphia.

headline: State Assembly Plan Would Limit New York Lawmakers’ Outside Income
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'State Legislatures', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The proposal, from a Democrat-controlled Assembly still reeling from corruption scandals, far exceeds a pay ceiling for part-time legislators suggested by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — An ethics proposal from the Democrat-dominated New York State Assembly would set a much higher limit on outside income than one suggested by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, allowing the state’s part-time legislators to earn tens of thousands of dollars in addition to their $79,500 base salary.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: F. Gary Gray charts the story of N.W.A in “Straight Outta Compton.” Audra McDonald channels Billie Holiday, and Ariana Grande is on “S.N.L.”
lead_paragraph: F. Gary Gray chronicles the rise of the gangster rappers N.W.A in “Straight Outta Compton.” Audra McDonald channels Billie Holiday in “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.” And Ariana Grande hosts and performs on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Corrections: March 12, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 12 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Raise the Smoking Age to 21?
abstract: Raising the legal age will save many lives, readers say. But others question treating 18-year-olds as adults in most other ways except smoking.
lead_paragraph: Proponents raise health arguments, while opponents discuss the age of adulthood.

headline: Stephen Curry vs. Damian Lillard Has the Makings of an Epic Rivalry
abstract: Lillard returned to Oakland with the Trail Blazers to confront the Warriors and Stephen Curry, potentially one of the best matchups for years to come.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Damian Lillard tried to insulate himself from any potential distractions before the Portland Trail Blazers faced the Golden State Warriors on Friday night. Lillard, who grew up in Oakland, remained with his teammates in San Francisco before they made the trip over the bridge for the game.

headline: Our Best Comments of the Week
abstract: “It’s not a woman’s responsibility to control the sexual urges of men by dressing more conservatively.” Readers react to the Erin Andrews case and more.
lead_paragraph: In this new feature, we list the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: After Rockets Fired From Gaza, Israelis Strike Hamas Bases
abstract: Israel targeted Hamas bases after militants fired rockets toward Israeli border communities late Friday. Shrapnel from Israeli attack kills 2 children.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Israel struck at Hamas military bases in the Gaza Strip overnight, killing a 10-year-old boy and his 6-year-old sister, a Palestinian official said on Saturday. The airstrikes came after Palestinian militants fired rockets toward Israeli border communities late Friday.

headline: ‘Valley of the Dolls,’ Pitched to a New Generation
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Women and Girls', 'Millennial Generation']
abstract: Celebrating its 50th anniversary, Jacqueline Susann’s book (and the film that followed) inspired many brands. Now her estate is getting involved.
lead_paragraph: “It is very Tumblr-friendly,” said Whitney Robinson of “Valley of the Dolls,” the novel by his stepgrandmother Jacqueline Susann that celebrates its 50th anniversary this year.

headline: A Certain Word Is Really Getting on My Nerves
abstract: There’s been a meteoric rise in the word “super” being used as a synonym for “very” or “extremely.” Some people are blaming technology.
lead_paragraph: A specific adverb has become superpopular in the last few decades, its spoken and written use rising at such a superfast clip that, if you’re inclined to verbal curmudgeonliness, it can be superirritating.

headline: How Did You Manage Your Breakup on Facebook?
abstract: We asked our readers to share their experiences dealing with a breakup on the social network. Here are 10 of their stories.
lead_paragraph: We asked our readers to share their experiences dealing with a breakup on the social network. Here are 10 of their stories.

headline: The Facebook Breakup
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Empathy']
abstract: The social network’s “Compassion Team” has made calling it quits online a little easier.
lead_paragraph: For Kate Sokoloff, a brand strategist in Portland, Ore., the Facebook mirror of her breakup with her boyfriend of three years was like “an emotional sucker punch,” she said. “Not 15 minutes after we broke up four years ago, and probably while he was still parked outside of my house, he changed his status to ‘single.’”

headline: A Texas Candidate Pushes the Boundary of the Far Right
abstract: Mary Lou Bruner, who is running for a Texas Board of Education seat, posted on Facebook that “a reliable source” had told her President Obama was once a prostitute.
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, Tex. — On Super Tuesday, Dale Clark voted for a local Republican who claimed on social media that President Obama had worked as a gay prostitute in his youth, that the United States should ban Islam, that the Democratic Party had John F. Kennedy killed and that the United Nations had hatched a plot to depopulate the world.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our Instagram followers from the White House to a concert in Havana.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our Instagram followers from the White House to a concert in Havana.

headline: The Geography of Trumpism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Census', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Unemployment', 'Population', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A look at the counties that have a high level of support for Donald Trump shows the factors that predict his popularity.
lead_paragraph: When the Census Bureau asks Americans about their ancestors, some respondents don’t give a standard answer like “English” or “German.” Instead, they simply answer “American.”

headline: China Weighs Letting Banks Sell Bad Debt to Investors
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The tentative proposal, which officials said on Saturday would be modest in scale, is meant to help alleviate one of the major drags on China’s economy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is exploring a new way to grapple with its mounting pile of bad corporate debt, though its top central banker sought on Saturday to dispel worries that the plan would simply shift the burden to other parts of the country’s vast economy.

headline: To Maintain Supply of Sex Slaves, ISIS Pushes Birth Control
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Series', 'Human Trafficking', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'ABORTION', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Modern methods allow the Islamic State to keep up its systematic rape of captives under medieval codes.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Locked inside a room where the only furniture was a bed, the 16-year-old learned to fear the sunset, because nightfall started the countdown to her next rape.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: Discuss your solving experience of the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad and Mike Discuss the Apple Case and a Go-Playing Computer Program
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: John Markoff, a tech reporter, helps Farhad and Mike understand AlphaGo, the Go-playing program, and what it means for artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, they needed extra help and roped in veteran tech reporter John Markoff.

headline: When an Apartment Contains Lead Paint
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Air Conditioning', 'Lead', 'Cooperatives', 'Paint', 'Children and Childhood', 'Landlords']
abstract: Protection from the hazards of lead paint; illegal sublets; and air conditioner charges are addressed this week.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: 'House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 12: White House and Chill
abstract: The Underwoods invite a family into their inner sanctum.
lead_paragraph: Episode 12 is not a bottle episode. But having the Conways and the Underwoods cohabitate, briefly, under the White House roof makes this chapter of “House of Cards” occasionally feel like one.

headline: One Dead and Two Missing After Tugboat Hits Barge Near Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: Rescuers were searching for two people after a tugboat struck a barge early Saturday in the Hudson River and sank.
lead_paragraph: A tugboat with three crew members aboard struck a construction barge moored beneath the Tappan Zee Bridge and sank into the Hudson River before dawn on Saturday, killing one crew member and leaving the other two missing, officials said.

headline: A Monkey With a Typewriter
abstract: Tom McCoy builds his brand.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE —Please tell me this has happened to you – I solved this whole puzzle, cogitated, doodled, napped, did yoga and otherwise digested it, and never got the theme. I dare say I would never have gotten it – I needed professional help – even though it makes perfect sense and is in no way obscure, cheap, overly intellectual or otherwise flawed. For whatever reason, the commonality in the answers was just squarely in my blind spot, and now I don’t understand how I missed it — the title also should have helped.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Posthumously, Rosalie Moscovitch mixes us up with a cryptic.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I love a good cryptic, and this one did not disappoint. I have binged on this type of puzzle over the years, mainly solving from Harper’s and Atlantic Monthly (those were magnificent puzzles, for years, by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon). Rosalie Moscovitch, who passed away last November, constructed four other excellent cryptics for the Sunday Magazine, and this one was also a treat.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Ivy League Makes Tradition the Servant of Commerce

headline: WhatsApp Encryption Said to Stymie Wiretap Order
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Instant Messaging', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: A fight with WhatsApp, the world’s largest mobile messaging service, would open a new front in the Obama administration’s dispute with Silicon Valley over encryption, security and privacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the Justice Department wages a public fight with Apple over access to a locked iPhone, government officials are privately debating how to resolve a prolonged standoff with another technology company, WhatsApp, over access to its popular instant messaging application, officials and others involved in the case said.

headline: John Kasich Says Donald Trump Has ‘Created a Toxic Environment’
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio faulted Donald J. Trump for the tension and violence at his rallies and suggested Saturday that he might not support him if he wins the nomination.
lead_paragraph: SHARONVILLE, Ohio — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, drawing a contrast between the tone of Donald J. Trump’s campaign and his own, chastised Mr. Trump on Saturday for having “created a toxic environment.”

headline: Remote Utah Enclave Becomes New Battleground Over Reach of U.S. Control
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Federal Lands', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Native Americans', 'Navajo Indians', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: Conservation groups say a new monument here in the red-rock deserts would protect 1.9 million acres of culturally significant land from new mining and drilling.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN COUNTY, Utah — The juniper mesas and sunset-red canyons in this corner of southern Utah are so remote that even the governor says he has probably only seen them from the window of a plane. They are a paradise for hikers and campers, a revered retreat where generations of American Indian tribes have hunted, gathered ceremonial herbs and carved their stories onto the sandstone walls.

headline: Off the Mound, Sean Doolittle Brings Relief to the Ostracized
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Philanthropy', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The Oakland Athletics reliever and his girlfriend have endorsed social causes that are not always closely embraced by professional athletes.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — Sean Doolittle, the ace reliever for the Oakland Athletics, would rather not be known that way. He has a charming impulse to ridicule anything that sounds absurd and self-righteous, even if it is accurate. His Twitter handle — @whatwouldDOOdo — is a pun and a question, a vessel for jokes, but also for good will.

headline: Marco Rubio, Nearing Reckoning in Florida Primary, Likens Donald Trump to ‘Third-World Strongmen’
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio criticized Donald J. Trump for his rhetoric and said he was not completely sure he could back him in a general election.
lead_paragraph: LARGO, Fla. – Senator Marco Rubio, in his strongest and most emotional condemnation yet of Donald J. Trump’s incendiary brand of politics, likened Mr. Trump to a third-world dictator who was leading the country dangerously close to a boiling point. Events include the Refill Roulette, which is the Haggler’s term for the niggling gas question — do you want to bring the vehicle back full, or near empty and buy from the company? The role was Jessie, daughter of Dan Aykroyd’s character and stepdaughter of Kim Basinger’s. Jessie begins to suspect that her stepmother is an alien after she sees her drink battery juice from a Honda, a definite tell.

headline: The Party Still Decides
abstract: The intricacies of the convention process can be turned against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: POLITICAL parties are mentioned nowhere in the Constitution, and the party nominating process offers few of the protections associated with the ideal of “one man one vote.” Voters in early states have far more influence than voters in later ones. Votes in hard-to-attend caucuses effectively count more than votes in high-turnout primaries. Some primaries are open to party loyalists; others to all comers. The rules that assign convention delegates are byzantine, the delegate selection process is various, and a few states rely on conventions and cut the voters out entirely.

headline: Congress Needs to Throw Puerto Rico a Lifeline

abstract: Lawmakers must act soon because the island’s financial situation is deteriorating rapidly.

headline: The Neuroscientist Who Lost Her Mind
abstract: My brain scan showed new tumors and swelling, terrifying everyone but me.
lead_paragraph: AS the director of the human brain bank at the National Institute of Mental Health, I am surrounded by brains, some floating in jars of formalin and others icebound in freezers. As part of my work, I cut these brains into tiny pieces and study their molecular and genetic structure. My specialty is schizophrenia, a devastating disease that often makes it difficult for the patient to discern what is real and what is not. I examine the brains of people with schizophrenia whose suffering was so acute that they committed suicide. I had always done my work with great passion, but I don’t think I really understood what was at stake until my own brain stopped working.

headline: How Saudi Arabia Turned Its Greatest Weapon on Itself

headline: The Global Solution to Extinction
abstract: It is not too late to halt the alarming loss of species and biodiversity threatening the planet.
lead_paragraph: DURING the summer of 1940, I was an 11-year-old living with my family in a low-income apartment in Washington, D.C. We were within easy walking distance of the National Zoo and an adjacent strip of woodland in Rock Creek Park. I lived most of my days there, visiting exotic animals and collecting butterflies and other insects with a net that I had fashioned from a broom handle, coat hanger and cheesecloth. I read nature books, field guides and past volumes of National Geographic. I had already conceived then of a world of life awaiting me, bottomless in variety.

While she didn’t reveal state secrets, she took a stand for the public’s right to know by providing free online access to just about every scientific paper ever published, on topics ranging from acoustics to zymology.
