Heckroth of Des Moines. Rabbi Jessica Minnen officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

headline: Lisa Manley, Christina Mitchell
abstract: The couple met in June 2000 through a women’s golf group in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Elisabeth Manley and Christina Hartford Mitchell were married March 11 at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Pamela L. Werntz, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Karli Provost, Eric Goldstein
abstract: The bride is a third-year resident physician in obstetrics and gynecology. The groom is a creative director for an advertising agency.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Karli Anne Provost and Eric Michael Goldstein were married March 12 in the library of the Brooklyn Historical Society. Harris Bloom, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Valerie Garagiola, Benjamin Redmond
abstract: The couple met when both were attending George Washington University.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Francesca Garagiola, a daughter of Noel Mikita Garagiola and Joseph H. Garagiola Jr. of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married March 11 to Benjamin Michael Redmond, a son of Heather A. Redmond and Calvin D. Redmond of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Richard Sunwoo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Mission Basilica Catholic Church in San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

headline: Corrections: March 13, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: My Dinosaur’s Jet Lag Helps Explain Why a Time Change Is Hard
abstract: Glow-in-the dark dinoflagellates illuminate why Daylight Saving Time causes you to spill coffee and fumble through conversations.
lead_paragraph: Update: Since this article was published in 2016, the company that made the dinosaur has gone out of business.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Donald Trump, Nancy Reagan, Daylight Saving Time
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Politics Invades Hollywood
abstract: In an election year, the only real “October surprise” from Hollywood would be a complete political blackout. But don’t worry. It won’t happen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a presidential election year, the only real “October surprise” from Hollywood would be a complete absence of films with political tinges. But don’t worry. It won’t happen. Already, release schedules for the months preceding Nov. 8, Election Day, are peppered with movies that have partisan potential, whether overt or covert.

headline: 1891: The Death of a Poet
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The French poet Théodore de Banville dies of apoplexy in 1891.
lead_paragraph: The well-known poet, Théodore de Banville, who since the death of Victor Hugo has been regarded as heading the list of contemporary French poets, died suddenly of apoplexy shortly before midnight on Thursday [March 12].

headline: England Avenges World Cup Loss to Wales With Six Nations Win
abstract: A victory over France would complete a perfect first season for England's new coach, the Australian Eddie Jones, and close a Six Nations sweep.
lead_paragraph: England is the 2016 European Six Nations champion, but must win again in Paris next Saturday to take the biggest prize: the Grand Slam.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Setback for Angela Merkel as Far Right Makes Gains in Germany
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Elections']
abstract: As three states voted, the ascendance of the Alternative for Germany pointed to strains from the chancellor’s policy of accepting refugees.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A far-right party fiercely opposed to Chancellor Angela Merkel’s welcome for refugees made startling gains in three state elections in Germany on Sunday, dealing the chancellor a blow as she tries to seal a deal with Turkey to reduce the influx of migrants.

headline: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
keywords: ['Coal', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mines and Mining', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Protests by angry workers at a vast failing state coal mine in the rust belt of northeastern China have forced a senior official to admit that he understated their problems, and signaled how President Xi Jinping’s plans to shake up slumping state-owned industries could run into resistance.

headline: 1941: Justice Would Put Communists in Camps
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Justice Lloyd Church proposes Communists be placed in special camps and prisons in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Justice Lloyd Church proposed yesterday in Supreme Court that Communists be placed in special camps and prisons so that their designs to overthrow the existing government could be thwarted. He referred scathingly to a Communist as ‘‘the lowest form of animal life, the dog which bites the hand which feeds him.’’

headline: Riding With Bill Cunningham
abstract: A bicyclist couldn’t help preening when he thought he had come across the legendary photographer of fashion on the street.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Donald Trump Says He May Pay Legal Fees of Accused Attacker From Rally
abstract: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he would look into paying the legal fees of a supporter who sucker punched a protester at one of his rallies last week, directly contradicting his claim that he does not condone violence by his backers.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he would look into paying the legal fees of a man who was accused of sucker-punching a protester at one of Mr. Trump’s rallies last week, directly contradicting his claim that he does not condone violence by his backers.

headline: No Smoke After Bank’s Fire Alarm Sounds, but Signs of a Heist in Progress
abstract: Firefighters responding to an alarm in Manhattan last week arrived at a bank to find a hole cut in an interior wall: the makings, it seemed, of a burglary.
lead_paragraph: The fire engine arrived 10 minutes after 10 p.m. that Sunday in Chinatown, stopping outside a building containing offices and a branch of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. A fire alarm had sounded five minutes earlier. The bank, like many in the Manhattan neighborhood, is open for business on Sunday, but on that day, March 6, it had been closed for hours.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Planning out meals for the week, preparing to interview Michael Pollan and Alex Gibney, and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Samantha Sault, Matthew Lauer
abstract: The couple met in 2007 in Washington at a party celebrating the 12th anniversary of The Weekly Standard magazine.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Kay Sault, the daughter of Kathy D. Sault and William J. Sault of Rockville, Md., was married March 11 to Matthew Jay Lauer, a son of Maribeth M. Lauer and Charles E. Lauer of Mount Pleasant, S.C. Deborah Braize, a civil officer for the Canton of Geneva, officiated at city hall in Geneva.

headline: John Boehner Endorses Fellow Ohioan John Kasich
abstract: In one of his few public appearances since he resigned from Congress under pressure last year, Mr. Boehner endorsed Gov. John Kasich in Ohio’s Republican primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WEST CHESTER, Ohio – On Saturday afternoon, John Boehner, the former speaker of the House, posted an image of himself on Instagram pushing a lawnmower and boasting, “My first cut of the year. My grass is perfect!!!!”

headline: A Cast of Children for York Theater’s ‘Charlie Brown’
abstract: The York Theater Company plans to cast children in all of the roles for its coming show, “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown.”
lead_paragraph: The York Theater Company has a new(ish) philosophy for “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown”: Cast it with children.

headline: Resolving the Nagging, if Minor, Mysteries of New York City
abstract: Among the questions: Is it the March Hare or the White Rabbit that is on the “Alice in Wonderland” statue in Central Park? And why are there different dates on the souvenir New York City baseball caps?
lead_paragraph: “We live among mysteries and riddles.” It’s a line from a novel published more than 250 years ago, but it can apply to the way we live now, to daily life in New York. Will the C train ever come? Some mornings you might as well ask a nonsense question, like one from a certain song from the 1960s: “Who Put the Bomp (In the Bomp Ba Bomp Ba Bomp)?”

headline: Wave of Positive Tests for Meldonium Adds to Doping Crisis
abstract: At least 99 athletes have tested positive for the drug, according to the World Anti-Doping Agency, startling officials over its widespread use.
lead_paragraph: Larry Bowers, the chief science officer for the United States Anti-Doping Agency, gave a presentation on Oct. 4, 2014, at the organization’s Symposium on Anti-Doping Science.

headline: G.O.P. Effort to Block Trump May Lead to a Morass
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: It’s hard to imagine giving the nomination to someone who finished second or a distant third. There seem to be no good alternatives.
lead_paragraph: The anti-Donald J. Trump brigade is banking on defeating him this week in Ohio, and possibly Florida, paving the way for an open convention that would deny him the Republican presidential nomination and avoid what it believes would be a general election debacle.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: Agatha Christie’s “And Then There Were None” comes to television. And “The Wave,” a Norwegian take on the disaster movie genre, is on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect beloved characters like Hercule Poirot or Miss Marple in a new adaptation of Agatha Christie’s macabre novel “And Then There Were None.” And “The Wave,” a Norwegian take on the disaster-movie genre, makes a splash on iTunes.

headline: Nonprofit Ads Tap ‘Game of Thrones’ to Highlight Real-World Conflict
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: A new campaign for the International Rescue Committee features actors from the hugely popular HBO fantasy series and gives donors a chance to win prizes related to the show.
lead_paragraph: The actors in “Game of Thrones,” the epic fantasy series featuring story lines about civil war and banishment, are using the enormous popularity of their HBO series to raise money for real-life victims of conflict and exile.

headline: Valeant, Woes Rising, Backs Away From Boldness to Calm Investors
abstract: The drug maker, which made big profits by raising the price of old drugs, is now talking about investing in research and paying down debt as its stock price slumps.
lead_paragraph: Back when its stock soared and investors fawned — just six months ago — Valeant Pharmaceuticals billed itself as a new kind of drug company. It thrived on acquiring new drugs rather than inventing them, and generating big profits from raising prices on old, undervalued treatments.

headline: 16 Killed in Terrorist Attack on Resort Hotels in Ivory Coast
abstract: The assault in Grand-Bassam, a popular seaside resort, pierced the national calm that has prevailed in recent years. Six terrorists were also reported dead.
lead_paragraph: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — Gunmen opened fire on picnickers and swimmers enjoying a perfect day at three beach resort hotels near the Ivory Coast’s largest city on Sunday, killing 16 people and leaving bodies strewn across the bloodstained sand. It was the third major attack in West Africa since November, and verified fears that the spread of terrorism across the region was far from over.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’: What to Watch Next Now That It’s Over
abstract: Feeling an acute sense of Dowager Countess withdrawal? Several shows (some British and some not) could help fill the void for “Downton” fans.
lead_paragraph: The final episode of “Downton Abbey” ran last Sunday and some viewers may already be feeling an acute sense of Dowager Countess withdrawal. Luckily, there are several shows (some British and some not) that could fill the void left by the show’s absence in the weeks and months ahead. Here are just a few:

headline: Chinese Owner of Waldorf Astoria Bets Big on More U.S. Hotels
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: China’s Anbang, an ambitious insurer, will purchase properties from Blackstone Group just six months after the private equity firm bought them.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese owner of the Waldorf Astoria is placing a bigger bet on high-end lodging in the United States.

headline: Germanwings Crash Inquiry Urges Stricter Oversight of Pilots’ Mental Health
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: French aviation officials called for guidelines that could require doctors to report pilots whose psychological condition might imperil public safety.
lead_paragraph: LE BOURGET, France — French aviation officials on Sunday called for stricter international monitoring of the mental health of pilots and for guidelines that could require doctors to report pilots whose psychological condition might imperil public safety.

headline: ‘Zootopia’ Rules, While ‘Brothers Grimsby’ Bombs
abstract: The Disney film, which had a writing team that included Phil Johnston, who co-wrote ‘Grimsby,” took in $50 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The audience has spoken, Sacha Baron Cohen: It’s over.

headline: Donald Trump Returns to Illinois and Gets a Friendlier Welcome
abstract: Donald J. Trump returned to Illinois Sunday morning less than 48 hours after protesters and security concerns prompted him to call off a rally in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMINGTON, Ill. — Donald J. Trump returned to Illinois on Sunday morning less than 48 hours after protesters and security concerns prompted him to call off a rally in Chicago.

headline: SXSW Addresses Online Harassment of Women in Gaming
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Computer and Video Games', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: At a daylong meeting at the South by Southwest conference, panelists in the gaming industry discussed attacks against them, including death threats.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Brianna Wu, a prominent video game developer, is no stranger to threats against her life.

headline: Custody Battle Over Picasso Bust Intensifies
abstract: New legal complaints charge that the artist’s daughter canceled a first sale of the work and then rushed in secret to close a better deal by transferring ownership to another buyer.
lead_paragraph: The battle over a rare Picasso sculpture, first reported by The New York Times in January, has intensified with new legal complaints that the artist’s daughter canceled a first sale of the work for about $42 million to agents of the royal family of Qatar and then rushed in secret to close a better deal for $106 million by transferring ownership to another buyer.

headline: Explosion in Ankara Kills at Least 34, Turkish Officials Say
abstract: The blast in Turkey’s capital, less than a month after a bombing on a military convoy in the city, was believed to have been caused by a car bomb.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A car filled with explosives blew up in a public square in the heart of Ankara, the Turkish capital, on Sunday evening, killing more than 30 people in the latest of a string of terrorist attacks that have destabilized the country.

headline: Key and Peele Film Gets a Sneak Peek at SXSW
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The new comedy featuring Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele was the subject of a work-in-progress showing at the festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — One way to guarantee a strong reaction to the opening scene of your action comedy? Feature a slow-motion kitten.

headline: Rangers Take Their Shots, but the Penguins Make Theirs Count
abstract: Pittsburgh’s Matt Cullen scored the decisive goal midway through the third period after the Rangers had rallied to tie the score three times.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Penguins played their first game Sunday in what will probably be a six-to-eight-week stretch without the injured Evgeni Malkin, but they put together a second period that alarmed Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault so much that he used only three forward lines.

headline: Review: In ‘Nómada,’ Manuel Liñán Revels in Flamenco Energy
abstract: This choreographer and his troupe displayed a mix of extravagance, skill and aggression in a show at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of “Nómada,” a show by the Spanish flamenco troupe Compañía Manuel Liñán, a line of three singers parts to reveal a large shawl, pink and fringed, with someone hidden inside it. The shawl drops like a curtain, unveiling a dancer in one of the long-trained skirts that women in flamenco traditionally whip around themselves. This skirt is held up by suspenders over a sleeveless T-shirt and above that — surprise! — is the stubbled face of the production’s choreographer and star, Mr. Liñán.

headline: With Hamas Watching, Singer Creates a (Modest) Sensation
abstract: An easing of some decade-old cultural restrictions, including singing by women in front of men, has given Rawan Okasha an opportunity to start “achieving what is in my soul.”
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Rawan Okasha pushed aside the black curtains, her large kohl-lined eyes scanning the two-story theater packed with people. Then she did something no other woman has done in public in Gaza for nearly a decade: She began to sing.

headline: At LoftOpera’s ‘Tosca,’ Go for the Arias, Not the Express to Albany
abstract: An opera troupe stages Puccini’s classic in an old Brooklyn bus depot.
lead_paragraph: Empty seats are an all-too-familiar sight at major opera houses these days, but LoftOpera had the opposite problem on Saturday night during its performance of “Tosca.” Daniel Ellis-Ferris, one of the company’s founders, urged the crowd of some 500 people who had assembled in an old bus depot in Bushwick, Brooklyn, to sit closer together on the benches arrayed in a section of the vast space. Other listeners sat on rugs on the floor just inches from the performers or stood against the back walls.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Celtics at Raptors
abstract: Toronto is still trying to prove that it is first in line in the East to dethrone the Cavaliers. Boston, which has excelled at home, is trying to stay in the top half of the conference.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Fed’s Plans to Raise Interest Rates Are Delayed, Not Derailed
abstract: The challenge is to forge consensus among Federal Reserve officials about when to resume the march begun in December, when the central bank raised rates for the first time since the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials will gather in Washington on Tuesday and Wednesday to debate whether a bumpy start to the year is now in the rearview mirror, clearing the way for higher interest rates.

headline: Sketch Comedy’s New Faces on TV
abstract: In shows like ‘The Characters’ on Netflix and ‘Night Class’ on the History channel, the genre is enlivening usually drab corners.
lead_paragraph: Endless supply of young, funny people; endless need for small-screen content: Yeah, it makes perfect sense that sketch comedy is suddenly turning up across the TV landscape. Some of it is kind of lazy, like Fox’s new “Party Over Here.” But some of it is enlivening usually drab corners, like “Night Class” on — what? — the History channel. And, best of all, some of it is brashly experimental.

headline: Review: Karita Mattila, and Her Quirks, in Concert
abstract: Ms. Mattila’s artistry was intact during a recital at Alice Tully Hall, but her vocal luster was missing.
lead_paragraph: Call it an off night, and hope that it was nothing more.

headline: Selection Sunday 2016: Kansas, North Carolina, Virginia and Oregon Are Top Seeds
abstract: The Jayhawks are the overall No. 1 seed, but in contrast with past seasons, there are several teams capable of winning it all this year.
lead_paragraph: Kansas, the Big 12 tournament champion, was the top-ranked team over all in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament field announced Sunday night. The other three top seeds in the 68-team bracket were the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament winner, North Carolina; the Pacific-12 tournament champion, Oregon; and the A.C.C. runner-up, Virginia.

headline: To Defray Legal Costs in Defamation Suits, Bill Cosby Turns to His Insurance
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Homeowners Insurance', 'Insurance', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As Mr. Cosby faces lawsuits from women, he has turned to his insurer, American International Group, which has challenged his claims.
lead_paragraph: In defending himself against lawsuits from women who say he sexually assaulted and then defamed them, Bill Cosby is facing mountainous legal expenses.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4 Finale: We Make the Terror
abstract: The season ends on a chilling moment.
lead_paragraph: In the final moment of the tonally inconsistent but nevertheless intriguing fourth season of “House of Cards,” Frank Underwood looks into the camera and speaks these words: “We don’t submit to terror. We make the terror.” Talking directly to the audience is nothing new for Frank, but there’s something different in the way it’s handled this time. He’s not breaking the fourth wall alone.

headline: Review: ‘Iolanta’ and ‘The Nutcracker,’ Reunited Naturalistically at the Paris Opera
abstract: Dmitri Tcherniakov’s production reconstructs these two tales of a female heroine’s awakening, while stripping “The Nutcracker” of its sugarplum sweetness.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — They’ve removed the Christmas tree from “The Nutcracker” at the Paris Opera. Literally. At the end of “Iolanta,” the opera that precedes it on a double bill that opened here on Friday, footmen carry off the spangled tree that’s been a symbol of warmth and prosperity onstage from the start.

headline: Beautiful, Maxwell!
abstract: Lynn Lempel names names.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE —This was a lovely, breezy solve for me, but very rewarding for an early week puzzle, and after a full day of running last names through my mind I’m much impressed by Lynn Lempel’s construction. In my opinion, she took a clever enough theme for a Thursday or Sunday and presented it for a Monday solver to sink their teeth into, a nice service to beginners and post-time-change befuddled minds alike.

headline: Who Is Elena Ferrante? An Educated Guess Causes a Stir
abstract: An article in an Italian newspaper suggested that a professor in Naples is the author of the popular novels, who writes under a pseudonym. She denied the report.
lead_paragraph: As her following grows, so does the mystery surrounding the pseudonymous Italian writer Elena Ferrante, whose Neapolitan novels on the lifelong friendship of two women have become a global phenomenon.

headline: Film Academy Governors Take On Race and Ratings
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science governing board will wrestle with a lack of diversity in its ranks and with poor ratings for the Feb. 28 Oscars telecast.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next marquee event at Hollywood’s film academy: “Identity Crisis — Part 2.”

headline: Protesters Across Brazil Call for President Dilma Rousseff’s Ouster
abstract: It was the fifth time in the past year that groups had mobilized large numbers for demonstrations in the streets against the governing leftist Workers’ Party.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Protesters in cities across Brazil called for the ouster of President Dilma Rousseff on Sunday, reflecting rising anger in the country over huge corruption scandals and a deepening economic crisis.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 14
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘The Young Messiah’ Depicts Jesus as a Boy Discovering His Powers
abstract: Cyrus Nowrasteh’s film hits some New Testament basics as it depicts the flight of Joseph, Mary and their son from Alexandria, Egypt, to Nazareth and eventually to Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Limping into theaters this weekend was yet another entry in the current avalanche of religious-themed movies: Cyrus Nowrasteh’s “The Young Messiah,” which imagines the life of Jesus at age 7.

headline: Review: Jonathan Lee’s ‘High Dive’ Revisits a Plot to Kill Margaret Thatcher
abstract: The novel, Mr. Lee’s first to be published in the United States, has its broad outlines in a 1984 I.R.A. bombing at a hotel in Brighton, England.
lead_paragraph: Terrorism may involve dramatic, unspeakable acts, but its logistics can be positively banal. In “High Dive,” the vibrantly cinematic new novel by Jonathan Lee, a 24-year-old Irish Republican Army volunteer named Dan checks in under a pseudonym at the Grand Hotel in Brighton, England, with the express intention of helping a colleague plant a bomb to kill Margaret Thatcher.

headline: Bouncer Dies After Trying to Break Up a Fight in Queens
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Two men were charged with manslaughter and gang assault in the death of Elsworth Reid, 43, who was beaten at Johnny’s Restaurant & Bar in Ozone Park.
lead_paragraph: A bouncer at a Queens restaurant died after he was beaten by two men who turned on him when he tried to break up a brawl, the police said.

headline: Baby’s Killing Tests India’s Protection of an Aboriginal Culture
abstract: India has a “hands-off” policy toward hunter-gatherer tribes like the Jarawas. But what happens when a murder inquiry brings the police into an isolated society?
lead_paragraph: OGRABRAJ, India — The police on South Andaman Island know what to do when members of the isolated Jarawa tribe venture into the villages that surround them, hoping to snatch rice and other prized goods, like cookies, bananas or, for some reason, red garments.

headline: Quiet Support for Saudis Entangles U.S. in Yemen
keywords: ['Series', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Obama administration has quietly supported the Saudi-led war in Yemen, even as American officials see a bloody quagmire there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Adel al-Jubeir, Saudi Arabia’s urbane, well-connected ambassador to Washington, arrived at the White House last March with the urgent hope of getting President Obama’s support for a new war in the Middle East.

headline: For Harry Reid, the Supreme Court Vacancy Offers One Last Fight
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Supporters of the senator, who is retiring this year, say he is prepared for an intense fight with Republicans over a new member of the court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there were any doubt, Senator Harry Reid clearly has one last, good fight in him.

headline: Momentum to Remove Confederate Symbols Slows or Stops
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Symbols']
abstract: Less than nine months after the massacre of black churchgoers in South Carolina, the pendulum swings back in favor of the battle flag and other icons of Southern history.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — After a white supremacist was accused of killing nine black churchgoers in South Carolina last summer, Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama acted decisively: Within a week, and without public debate, he ordered the removal of four Confederate flags outside the State Capitol here.

headline: Snowmobile Driver Apologizes for Hitting Iditarod Teams
keywords: ['Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)', 'Snowmobiles', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Dog Sledding']
abstract: Alaska State Troopers arrested Arnold Demoski in connection with the accident, and he said in interviews that he had been drinking.
lead_paragraph: A snowmobile driver accused of colliding with two teams of mushers in the Iditarod dog-sled race in Alaska over the weekend has apologized, saying that he had been drinking before the episode.

headline: Hillary Clinton Stops Apologizing and Starts to Sprint
abstract: Mrs. Clinton stressed her resilience at a church near Cleveland on Sunday by sharing a favorite saying of Eleanor Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND HILLS, Ohio — Hillary Clinton began the final sprint to Tuesday’s nominating contests in five states with a visit to church here on Sunday. She had spent the previous few days apologizing for wrongly saying that Nancy Reagan had “started a national conversation” about HIV/AIDS during the administration of her husband, President Ronald Reagan.

headline: Football Drags on UConn’s Power 5 Ambitions
abstract: Connecticut’s curse is to be a great basketball university in a football-centric world, where the major conferences earn big money on lucrative TV contracts.
lead_paragraph: It was very good week for the University of Connecticut. First, the undefeated UConn women’s basketball team polished off a solid University of South Florida team, 77-51, Monday night in its conference tournament. Then came the men. On Friday afternoon, the Huskies won a thrilling four-overtime game against Cincinnati in a quarterfinal tournament game that included a remarkable three-quarter-length buzzer beater by Jalen Adams to send the game into the fourth overtime. They followed that game with victories over Temple and Memphis to win the tournament. A bubble team coming into its conference tournament, the UConn men landed a ninth seed for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: 2016 Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket
abstract: Kansas, North Carolina, Virginia and Oregon are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: Kansas, North Carolina, Virginia and Oregon are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Modeled After Ants, Teams of Tiny Robots Can Move 2-Ton Car
abstract: Researchers are exploring the limits of friction in the design of tiny robots that can pull thousands of times their weight, wander like gecko lizards on vertical surfaces or mimic bats.
lead_paragraph: Archimedes pointed out that with a lever he could move the world.

headline: Obama Often Depends on Mail to Tell His Story
keywords: ['Letters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Around the White House, they’re known as the 10 LADs — the 10 letters a day President Obama insists on reading, and sometimes using to make a point.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brent Brown used to call Barack Obama a liar who had betrayed America. Then one day last year, while in the throes of a painful flare-up of his ulcerative colitis, he sat down and wrote Mr. Obama a letter thanking the president for saving his life.

headline: Tyler Ulis, Kentucky’s 5-9 Star, Takes Charge
abstract: Ulis, the smallest player of the year in Southeastern Conference history, has an ability to control games on both ends of the floor that could help the Wildcats reach their third straight Final Four.
lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, 5-foot-9 guards would struggle to start for Trump University, much less the vaunted Kentucky Wildcats. But Tyler Ulis, the smallest man to be named the Southeastern Conference player of the year, is special.

headline: Perry Ellis Spurs Kansas by Talking Up a Storm
abstract: On defense, Ellis, a senior forward, is like a catcher in baseball, telling guards where their men are and yelling out warnings of coming screens.
lead_paragraph: Perry Ellis speaks loudest on the basketball court. Not in the sense of how well he plays, although Ellis, a Kansas senior, is one of the country’s best players and the leading scorer on the top team. But in the sense of how much — and how loudly — he literally talks when on the court.

headline: In the Apple Case, a Debate Over Data Hits Home
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Terrorism', 'Smartphones', 'iPhone', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: The debate that began three years ago after revelations about government surveillance has become more personal, now that smartphones are involved.

That’s when Viacom shareholders will vote on whether to re-elect the company’s 11 directors. Despite the turmoil at Viacom, it is a foregone conclusion that all the directors will keep their jobs. And if last year’s meeting is any indication, the meeting will be short: Last year’s lasted only about 15 minutes. —Emily Steel

headline: Labor Protests Multiply in China as Economy Slows, Worrying Leaders

But last month, the 31-year-old welder stood outside the plant with hundreds of co-workers, picketing against pay cuts and singing patriotic battle hymns.

headline: 1941: Yugoslavs May Delay Nazi Tie
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Yugoslav statesmen delay their trip to the Reich, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — Discussions between Yugoslavia and Germany have broken down, and a trip to the Reich by Yugoslav statesmen has been postponed, well informed sources said. Although official reticence is still veiled, the sources said the talks had had no positive results. It is considered likely that Yugoslavia will make no commitments toward the Axis in the immediate future. In this rumor-ridden city, where nine-tenths of all information is issued with a purpose and by some interested party, it is impossible to put complete faith in any source. — New York Herald Tribune, March 15, 1941

headline: Reasonable-Seeming but WRONG Approximations of π
abstract: Happy Pi Day! Pi, math’s most famous constant, equals 3.14…, but there’s a proof that pi equals 4. Can you find the error in this proof?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge is a pi-approximation paradox proposed by our friends at Brilliant.org, the online community for students and professionals looking for tantalizing problems, like-minded peers and mentorship. And the final paradox was inspired by a problem originally posted to Brilliant by Pranshu Gaba, a student in Mumbai, India. Our discussion will be moderated by Brilliant’s Zandra Vinegar.

headline: Simple Syrups for Cocktails and Desserts

Use them sparingly in cocktails and iced tea, or drizzle them over ice cream or pancakes. Black pepper is dark and viscous with sweet heat; bird’s-eye chile ignites; mahogany-hued vanilla is mellow; and palm sugar has a caramelized richness: Blank Slate Kitchen Rich Simple Syrups, $11.99 to $14.99, blankslatekitchen.com and amazon.com.

headline: When Fashion Meets Technology, You Can Wear Your Tweets

abstract: Garments as gadgets (and how they got that way) at the Costume Institute, the High Museum in Atlanta and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch fashion designer Iris van Herpen, in her 2010 collection “Crystallization,” was the first person to send a 3-D-printed haute couture garment down the runway. keywords: ['Eating Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'ANOREXIA NERVOSA', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Move beyond the inviting photographs on websites and choose based on priorities and statistics.
lead_paragraph: Choosing a residential treatment program for eating disorders can be challenging. Websites may show scenic landscapes and comfortable interiors, but there is an absence of industry standards and research indicating which types of programs are effective.

headline: Centers to Treat Eating Disorders Are Growing, and Raising Concerns
keywords: ['Eating Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'ANOREXIA NERVOSA', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: A proliferation of residential centers has some experts questioning their marketing and wondering if quality is at times sacrificed for profit.
lead_paragraph: Their websites show peaceful scenes — young women relaxing by the ocean or caring for horses in emerald pastures — and boast of their chefs and other amenities.

headline: The Mysterious House That Inspired an L.A. Artist’s New Show
abstract: John Divola’s “Theodore Street” series documents a home in Moreno Valley with a complicated visual — and political — identity.
lead_paragraph: “If you were to look up ‘superficial’ in the dictionary, it should say ‘like a photograph,’” offers the artist John Divola, who’s something of an expert on the subject. Divola, born in 1949, began his photography career in the Los Angeles area in the early ’70s, when the actual usage of a camera was deemed passé by the academy and artists alike, including his UCLA professor Robert Heinecken, who stitched together ready-printed cultural iconography. But Divola didn’t care so much about conceptual trends — and frankly still doesn’t. “My work is still very indexical,” he says. “My work is still about: time, place, and circumstance. I make these literal imprints of what’s in front of me, and then I bring them back and they’re my artifacts of my actual engagement with the world.”

headline: Life in the Slow Lane, Still a Draw for Heritage Fans
abstract: Institutions continue to come up with compelling “living history” showcases that demonstrate how Americans spent their days in earlier eras.
lead_paragraph: Though a stalwart of the industrial age, Henry Ford was always looking back to what he felt was a kinder and simpler time. In the early 1910s, already one of the wealthiest men in the United States, he started collecting what today are viewed as artifacts — from early washing machines to locomotives to wagons to blacksmithing tools.

headline: Rediscovering Daubigny, an Unsung Influence on the Impressionists
abstract: “Daubigny, Monet, Van Gogh: Impressions of Landscape,” at the Taft Museum of Art in Cincinnati, illuminates one painter’s role in the evolution of art.
lead_paragraph: If, on the night of Feb. 20, Lynne Ambrosini had emptied a champagne flute a few times and then triumphantly thrown it into a fire, anyone who knows her would have understood.

headline: Bernie Sanders Rallies in Four States to Spur Voter Turnout
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders, campaigning at a feverish pace, made last-minute pitches to supporters on the eve of crucial primaries being held Tuesday. “We’ll have a good vote tomorrow,” he said at one rally. “If people come out, we are going to win Ohio.”
lead_paragraph: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — Bernie Sanders, campaigning at a feverish pace on Monday, made last-minute pitches to supporters on the eve of crucial primaries, holding five rallies in four states as he seized on his anti-trade message to rally people to turn out to vote on Tuesday.

headline: A Bangladesh Editor’s Mistake
abstract: The Bangladesh ambassador discusses the publication of uncorroborated newspaper articles that led to the arrest of the woman who is now prime minister.

headline: In San Diego, a Comics Confab That Never Ends
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Art', 'Museums', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: A gallery founded by the comics publisher IDW gives visitors a sense of the artist’s creative process, from thumbnail sketch to the published page.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Comic books and San Diego are nearly synonymous because of the annual Comic-Con International held each July. But IDW Publishing, a hometown company that exhibits at the convention, has given comic-book fans a reason to visit anytime by opening its San Diego Comic Art Gallery.

headline: Putin Orders Start of Syria Withdrawal, Saying Goals Are Achieved
abstract: The order from the Kremlin came as the United Nations was trying to revive peace talks to stop the conflict, which has created a humanitarian catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday ordered the withdrawal of the “main part” of Russian forces in Syria, a surprise move that reflected what he called the Kremlin’s achievement of nearly all its objectives in the war-torn country.

headline: A Nationwide Guide to Art Exhibitions This Spring
abstract: A selection of promising museum shows on everything from Asian megacities to Robert Mapplethorpe.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK “Pergamon and the Hellenistic Kingdoms of the Ancient World.” This international loan exhibition reveals the profound legacy of Greek civilization through the display of more than 265 objects, from bronze, marble and terra-cotta sculptures to gold jewelry, made between the death of Alexander the Great in 323 B.C. and the birth of the Roman Empire in the first century B.C. Above, a second-century B.C. “Colossal Head of a Youth.” April 18 through July 17. Metropolitan Museum of Art; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.

abstract: Danielle Greco is not only a buyer for the trendy SoHo boutique, but she is also its budding video star.

abstract: North Bennington joined a list of communities, including nearby Hoosick Falls, N.Y., that face water-supply problems after private wells near a closed plant tested positive for a chemical, PFOA.
lead_paragraph: NORTH BENNINGTON, Vt. — Above the Walloomsac River, where ramshackle farmhouses sit just downhill from tidy homes with organic gardens out back, the old ChemFab plant was, for many, a respected local employer from the days when this village’s prosperity depended on industry.

abstract: The blaze destroyed a house on High Street, where a relative said 10 people lived.
lead_paragraph: ORANGE, N.J. — A father and his two sons were killed and several others injured in a fire that destroyed a house here on Monday, a relative said.

headline: Anbang Insurance’s Hotel Shopping Spree Could Be Costly
abstract: In its latest quest, the Chinese insurer is leading a consortium that is offering $76 a share in cash, about 10 times book equity for Starwood.
lead_paragraph: Anbang Insurance Group is in what may be an expensive hurry.

headline: Syrian Asylum Seeker Linked to Mass Killing Is Arrested in Sweden
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A man who sought asylum in Sweden is believed to be among a group of Syrian rebels who were recorded executing seven soldiers in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish authorities have filed criminal charges against a Syrian man who is suspected of having participated in the mass killing of captured Syrian soldiers in 2012.

headline: Ex-Gawker Editor Backs Off Testimony in Hulk Hogan Case
abstract: Albert Daulerio, former editor of the Gawker website, said he was being sarcastic when he said children over 4 were fair game for online sex tapes.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The former editor in chief of the website Gawker testified on Monday that he was not being sincere when he said in a videotaped deposition that children over the age of 4 were fair game for sex tapes to be published online.

headline: The Unfolding of Polio
abstract: In The Times, it began with an 1857 article on graduation at New-York Medical College. The prize for best thesis went to one on infantile paralysis.
lead_paragraph: On March 6, 1857, The New-York Times described the commencement exercises at New-York Medical College. The first prize for the best thesis went to Nehemiah Nickerson “for his thesis on Infantile Paralysis.” It was the first time the newspaper mentioned what would come to be known as polio.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Buy Honest Dollar, a Small Plan Start-Up
abstract: Honest Dollar is part of a group of investment companies vying for small-business employees who do not have access to traditional employer-sponsored savings plans.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is adding a little robo to its investment management business, buying Honest Dollar, a digital retirement savings tool aimed at millions of small-business employees who do not have access to traditional employer-sponsored savings plans.

abstract: The Oakland Education Association takes issue with a billionaire’s project.

lead_paragraph: The key to winning your N.C.A.A. tournament pool is picking the right teams to knock off higher-seeded opponents. Here are a few teams worth considering as you fill out your brackets.

keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: A fired Volkswagen employee in Michigan contends that employees erased electronic files as U.S. officials were investigating its emissions cheating.
lead_paragraph: A former Volkswagen employee has filed a whistle-blower lawsuit in Michigan, asserting that co-workers illegally deleted electronic data shortly after the United States government accused the carmaker of cheating on emissions tests.

abstract: Readers discuss the protests at rallies for Donald Trump and efforts to deny him the nomination.

headline: A Note on Globalization and Labor
abstract: Consider Canada.
lead_paragraph: This is mainly a data note to myself. But with trade becoming an issue in the election, I thought it might be useful to take on one myth: the supposedly necessary relationship between globalization and the decline of organized labor.

headline: Fossil Hints T. Rex Got Smart Before It Got Big
abstract: An older relative of Tyrannosaurus rex had a brain and ears like the well-known dinosaur, but not the stature or heft.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the dinosaur age, Tyrannosaurus rex was a behemoth killer animal, up to 40 feet long and weighing several tons — the top carnivore in the food chain.

headline: Holding Prosecutors Responsible in an Insider Trading Investigation
abstract: Prosecutors have broad discretion in how they obtain evidence, but the targets of an investigation have few tools to combat misuse of that authority.
lead_paragraph: The Roman poet Juvenal posed the question “quis custodiet ipsos custodes?” or “who will guard the guards themselves?” That issue surfaced last week as part of a lawsuit filed by a hedge fund owner against a number of F.B.I. agents and federal prosecutors in Manhattan, including the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, accusing them of making deliberate misrepresentations in an affidavit used to obtain a search warrant in an insider trading case that ended up putting the hedge fund out of business.

headline: Fox News to Host a Republican Debate Next Week, but Will the Candidates Come?
abstract: The next Republican debate will be in Salt Lake City on March 21, but the results of primaries in five states on Tuesday could determine who shows up on stage.
lead_paragraph: Fox News announced Monday that it would host the next Republican debate, but who will be on stage remains an open question.

headline: Study Calls a Malaria Preventive for Pregnant Women Into Question
abstract: The World Health Organization’s recommended method was found to not be as effective as a newer solution.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women and their unborn children are particularly vulnerable to malaria: the women because they may develop lethal anemia, and the babies because infected red blood cells tend to clump in the placenta, robbing the fetus of nutrients.

headline: An End to a Chess Grandmaster’s Eviction Battle Could Be Near
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Evictions', 'Chess']
abstract: After a long fight to stay in his home in Stuyvesant Town, William J. Lombardy, 78, one of America’s greatest chess players, may be giving up.
lead_paragraph: William J. Lombardy was in the midst of explaining the virtue of the Philidor Defense when a knock came at the door of his sixth-floor apartment in Stuyvesant Town on May 27, 2014. A grandmaster and a mentor to Bobby Fischer, Mr. Lombardy excused himself to answer the door.

headline: Women Who Brought Zika Fears Home With Them
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Defects', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Microcephaly', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: U.S. women who traveled to Central and South American countries and are pregnant deal with the worry of a virus that is linked to birth defects.
lead_paragraph: In December, Ami Levy and her husband, Jason, left frigid Washington, D.C., for a two-week vacation in Argentina. Once there, they headed north to the Brazilian border for a couple of days, lured by Igauzu Falls.

headline: New Zika Notice Says Higher-Altitude Areas Can Be Safe for Pregnant Women
abstract: Federal health officials say places like Mexico City and Bogotá, Colombia, can be safe for travel because mosquitoes that transmit the virus are not normally found above 6,500 feet.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials last week modified their travel notices related to the Zika virus to say that pregnant women can safely travel to areas at altitudes above 6,500 feet.

headline: The Value of Surprise? For Some Artists, It’s a Springboard to No. 1
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Kendrick Lamar’s latest album, which arrived with no advance notice, jumped to the top of Billboard’s chart.
lead_paragraph: Releasing a new album by surprise can be a smart marketing strategy — if you are already a big star.

headline: Review: ‘Crowded’ Disrupts Life in an Empty Nest
abstract: A middle-aged couple’s two adult daughters move back home in this comedy series, created by Suzanne Martin, on NBC.
lead_paragraph: No one absorbs a punch line better than Patrick Warburton, and he is certainly pummeled with them in “Crowded,” which starts on Tuesday on NBC. He’s the best thing about this stand-and-deliver-jokes comedy, playing half of a middle-aged couple who are just beginning to enjoy being empty nesters when their two adult daughters move back in.

headline: Something Is Missing in High School Hazing Stories: Adults
abstract: The district attorney investigating the latest hazing case in high school sports says all coaches need to be present and proactive in fighting these brutal sports rituals.
lead_paragraph: BERWYN, Pa. — On my way to Conestoga High School last week to learn about accusations of brutal hazing by the football team, I felt as if I’d been to this place before.

headline: Train Jam: Strangers on a Train, Creating Video Games
abstract: Heading for the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco, the 190 participants in this effort — some from as far away as Zambia — spent 52 hours immersed in virtual worlds.
lead_paragraph: Disheveled, eyes bruised with fatigue, and feeling grungy after two days of showerless toil, 190 video game designers, artists and programmers disembarked on Saturday afternoon from the rain-slicked California Zephyr at the Emeryville, Calif., Amtrak station. The travelers — some of whom had come from as far away as Zambia and Pakistan — had taken part in Train Jam, which uses the trip from Chicago to this city just north of Oakland as both an opportunity and a time frame for strangers to come together and, amid laptops, headphones and virtual-reality headsets, create video games.

headline: In Late Antiquity Textiles, a Long-Lasting Fashion Show
abstract: On display in New York, fabrics that somehow survived time’s decay reflect the wealth and social standing of the elite in the late Roman Empire.
lead_paragraph: Archaeology is about more than rock-hard ruins of palaces and temples, royal mummies in remote tombs and obscure writing on clay tablets. Less durable remains, like fabrics of garments and home decorations that somehow survive time’s decay, can also be telling artifacts of early cultures.

headline: Defying E.U., Hundreds of Migrants Enter Macedonia From Greece
abstract: Migrants formed a human chain to cross a river; at least three drowned. It was unclear whether they will be sent back to Greece.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Hundreds of migrants braved a fast-moving river to cross from Greece into Macedonia on Monday, defying efforts by European officials to stop people fleeing war and desperation from traveling through the Balkans to Germany and other destinations.

headline: Matchmaking and Other Guilty Passions: Notes From Nancy Reagan’s Funeral
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For the reporter Alessandra Stanley, Mrs. Reagan’s funeral was like a trip back in time.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Alessandra Stanley — who covered the Reagan White House for Time magazine — describes how reporting on Mrs. Reagan’s funeral was like a trip back in time.

headline: Mitt Romney Campaigns With John Kasich, Telling Ohioans ‘America’s Counting on You’
abstract: Mr. Romney, trying to stop Donald J. Trump, told voters in Ohio that Mr. Kasich’s experience in Congress and as governor was “the kind of record that you want in Washington.”
lead_paragraph: GREEN, Ohio — Mitt Romney, in his latest attempt to help stop Donald J. Trump, joined Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on the campaign trail on Monday as Mr. Kasich tries to pull out a victory in his home state.

headline: Peter Maxwell Davies, Contrarian British Composer, Dies at 81
abstract: Although Mr. Davies was anti-establishment, anti-monarchist and avant-garde, he was named Queen Elizabeth II’s official Master of Music.
lead_paragraph: Sir Peter Maxwell Davies, the prolific English composer long known as an anti-establishment anti-monarchist avant-gardist enfant terrible — but whose work was so renowned that he was named Queen Elizabeth II’s official music master anyway — died on Monday at his home in the Orkney Islands of Scotland. He was 81.

headline: Mets’ David Wright Takes First Swings but Holds Back a Bit
abstract: A big question for the Mets is how much Wright, who has spinal stenosis, will be able to contribute over 162 games this year.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Almost precisely at 1 p.m. Monday, Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, pulled his golf cart up to one of the practice fields here behind Tradition Field.

headline: Review: Apollo’s Fire Enhances ‘St. John Passion’
abstract: There is confrontation and many moving parts in this period ensemble’s performance of this Bach work.
lead_paragraph: The ghost of Bach seems to inhabit St. Paul’s Chapel on lower Broadway. The musical forces of the parent church, Trinity Wall Street, directed by Julian Wachner, have presented no end of thrilling Bach performances there in recent years.

headline: Review: ‘Bride & Prejudice’ Shows Three Engaged Couples Facing Family Opposition
abstract: This FYI reality show puts bigotry — from race to religion to sexual orientation — front and center in depicting couples headed to the altar.
lead_paragraph: Reality television is far from a utopian space, but it has been an accepting one for many years — if you want to see the grand diversity of American life, scripted television doesn’t hold a candle to reality, which moves with a sure-footed combination of empathy and voyeurism that allows room for almost anyone to be a compelling protagonist.

headline: A Word With: Isaac Mizrahi, Dramaturge of the Runway
abstract: The fashion designer discusses a new survey of his work at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-born fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi is seldom at rest. On Monday nights, he hosts “Isaac Mizrahi Live!” on QVC, presenting his ready-to-wear designs. He is a judge for the fifth season of Lifetime’s “Project Runway All Stars.” He is also working on a memoir and trying to pull together a theatrical show based on Ingmar Bergman’s 1960 comic fantasy film, “The Devil’s Eye.”

headline: 9 Key Designs From ‘Isaac Mizrahi: An Unruly History’
abstract: An exhibition at the Jewish Museum covers three decades of work, with original sketches and finished garments.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition at the Jewish Museum covers three decades of work, with original sketches and finished garments.

headline: European Union Suspends Aid to Burundi Over Political Crisis
abstract: Officials announced a halt in financial support over a political crisis that has claimed hundreds of lives, but said humanitarian aid would continue.
lead_paragraph: The European Union on Monday suspended aid to Burundi’s government, citing a political crisis that has claimed more than 400 lives and forced more than 240,000 people to flee to neighboring countries.

headline: Review: Lydia Johnson Dance Keeps Everything in Control
abstract: In the four works Ms. Johnson presents at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, including one premiere, what feels exciting at first grows less so.
lead_paragraph: Nice, good, attractive, pleasant, fine: Those words come to mind when watching the work of Lydia Johnson, whose company returned to the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Thursday. Ms. Johnson makes unadorned, soundly structured, musically adept ballets for a lovely, unpretentious group of dancers. She seems to know exactly what she’s doing; nothing is out of her control.

headline: Donald Trump Jokes — Awkwardly — About Todd Palin
abstract: Donald Trump joked about how Todd Palin would have handled the San Bernardino terror attacks – just as he was being treated in the hospital for injuries suffered in an accident.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The joke was, it seemed, a little awkward.

headline: Moneyball for Book Publishers: A Detailed Look at How We Read
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A reader analytics company in London wants to use data on our reading habits to transform how publishers acquire, edit and market books.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Rhomberg wants to be the Billy Beane of the book world.

headline: Review: The English Concert Performs Handel’s ‘Orlando’ at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Sunday’s concert performance featured the British countertenor Iestyn Davies in the title role, with Harry Bicket conducting.
lead_paragraph: The premiere run of Handel’s “Orlando” in 1733 lasted only 10 performances. For the final few, audiences were thin, and the opera was never revived in its composer’s lifetime. He died in 1759 assuming that “Orlando,” like most of his Italian works, would languish, and he wasn’t wrong: It was not until the 1950s that the Handel revival really got going.

headline: Review: Five Young Winners, and Others, at National Council Auditions
abstract: At the Metropolitan Opera House, top prizes went to Sol Jin, Yelena Dyachek, Jakub Jozef Orlinski, Emily D’Angelo and Sean Michael Plumb.
lead_paragraph: The finals of the National Council Auditions that the Metropolitan Opera hosts each year must be daunting for the young contestants who vie for one of five top prizes. It’s not just one of the most reliably career-accelerating competitions in opera. It’s also held in the largest opera house, with an auditorium that can dwarf even experienced voices.

headline: Review: In ‘Widowers’ Houses,’ Loving a Slumlord’s Daughter
abstract: George Bernard Shaw’s first play, highlighting the social ills of slums, is reframed as an individual’s moral struggle in this adaptation at Beckett Theater.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of this play, and at the end, the young Dr. Harry Trench stands alone in shadowy light, while disembodied voices speak of money or call his name. The effect of these bookends is cinematic, and their aim is clear enough: to frame George Bernard Shaw’s “Widowers’ Houses” as the story of one man’s moral struggle.

headline: Review: ‘And Then All Hell Broke Loose,’ Richard Engel’s Memoir of Reporting From the Middle East
abstract: Mr. Engel, a veteran war correspondent, explains the chaos and complexity of the region in a fast-paced account.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Engel was 13, traveling abroad with his parents, he dreamed of becoming a reporter. He imagined working at the old International Herald Tribune and living in an apartment in Paris, overlooking the Champs-Élysées. He saw himself wearing white suits and brandishing a bone cigarette holder, and “writing dispatches about intrigues and politics and spies and damsels and all the rest.”

headline: Review: In ‘Fly,’ Tuskegee Airmen Are Deployed to Defend Freedoms They Don’t Fully Share
abstract: This play at the New Victory Theater, set during World War II, shows the heroism of these black Army pilots and the discrimination they faced back home.
lead_paragraph: In 1943, a group of officer candidates, debonair in their khakis and caps, approach a bar just off their Alabama base, in search of some music and beers.

headline: German State Elections Point to Vulnerability for Angela Merkel
abstract: In giving a far-right party up to a quarter of the vote, Germans let their chancellor know they are not happy with how the refugee crisis is being handled.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The results of German state elections, in which an insurgent far-right party garnered up to 25 percent of the vote, have signaled a rare turn toward political vulnerability for Chancellor Angela Merkel, as well as potential instability for her country and perhaps paralysis for Europe as a whole.

headline: What a Hand Model Knows About Skin Care
abstract: Adele Uddo is one of the most successful models you’ve never heard of, even though her job is to stay mostly out of the picture.
lead_paragraph: Adele Uddo is a model whose job is to stay mostly out of the picture. On a cover shoot for Town & Country, for example, Hugh Jackman perched on apple crates while Ms. Uddo stood beneath him, arm raised, so the only part of her in the frame was her hand cupping his face, her slender fingers tousling his hair. David Yurman bracelets were taped to her forearm so they’d hang artfully (and not catch Mr. Jackman’s beard).

headline: A Crucial Day for Candidates Trying to Stop Donald Trump
abstract: Tuesday’s results could turn out any number of ways, but many of them look promising for Mr. Trump’s path to an uncontested nomination. Here’s a look.
lead_paragraph: There are 367 Republican delegates at stake Tuesday, far fewer than the 595 two weeks ago on Super Tuesday. But Tuesday nonetheless has the potential to decide whether Donald Trump has a clear path to the nomination.

headline: American Airlines Doesn’t Care for Its Gogo Wi-Fi, Either
abstract: With passengers expecting more from in-flight connectivity, the carrier recently filed a legal action against its Wi-Fi provider, Gogo.
lead_paragraph: Passengers aren’t the only ones frustrated by airplane Wi-Fi’s high cost, slow speed and balky connections.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Angela Merkel, Syria
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Matt Forte Undeterred by Jets’ Questions at Quarterback
abstract: Forte, a running back who signed a three-year deal with the Jets last week, said he hoped that quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick would return to the team.
lead_paragraph: Given the teams that expressed interest in Matt Forte, he could have played with some of the N.F.L.’s best quarterbacks: Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers or Tony Romo.

headline: The Trump Campaign Gives License to Violence
abstract: Amid rage and violence at his rallies, Donald Trump’s concerns are only for himself.
lead_paragraph: After a weekend of violence at his rallies, Donald Trump arrived in Florida for a rally in Boca Raton on Sunday night, crowing at “how well we handled” those confrontations, because “nobody got hurt,” apparently meaning nobody got killed. Standing in an open-air amphitheater filled with thousands of supporters and surrounded by scores of police officers, this season’s version of George Wallace coyly asked, “Do we have a protester, anyone?” and “Is there a disrupter in the house?”

headline: Primary Stages Season to Include Adaptation of Rankine’s ‘Citizen’
abstract: The season will also include a revival of Horton Foote’s “The Roads to Home.”
lead_paragraph: A new adaptation of Claudia Rankine’s poetry collection “Citizen” will headline the Primary Stages 2016-7 season. Ms. Rankine has updated her best-selling work for the stage along with Stephen Sachs, and the production will arrive next January.

lead_paragraph: Greece and More — Photos of the Day

abstract: Photos from Greece, Turkey, Ivory Coast and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Turkey, Ivory Coast and Ukraine.

headline: Joe Berlinger Discusses His Feel-Good Tony Robbins Film
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The director says his film about seminars led by Mr. Robbins, a popular life coach, sprang from a transformative experience he had in attending one.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The documentary filmmaker Joe Berlinger is known for investigative films that explore cracks in the criminal justice system (“Brother’s Keeper,” “Paradise Lost”) or corporations’ involvement in environmental disasters (“Crude”). His latest film is a departure.

headline: Gunman Intended to Die in Maryland Attack, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The gunman, identified as Michael Ford, planned the confrontation with two brothers, who watched and recorded the episode, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A police officer who was killed in a gun battle in a Washington suburb after a man opened fire outside a police station was probably shot in the confusion by a fellow officer, the police chief of Prince George’s County, Md., said on Monday.

headline: As CBS Dawdles, Fans Are First to Be Upset in This Tournament
abstract: CBS expanded its selection show to two hours to draw out the suspense over who would play where, and fans reacted with disdain.
lead_paragraph: They gave us a fattened N.C.A.A. tournament selection show, starting at 5:30 p.m. Eastern on Sunday and ending at 7:30. Who asked for it? Are two-hour studio shows worth watching, especially if all you want to know is who’s playing whom and where?

headline: A Supreme Court Seat Sits Empty, and Calls to Fill It Dog Republicans
abstract: At home and in Washington, members of the Judiciary Committee are hearing chants of “Do Your Job” as they try to delay confirmation hearings past the election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah addressed the conservative Federalist Society luncheon on Friday at a Chinatown restaurant, young protesters from the liberal group Generation Progress suddenly broke into loud chants of “Do your job,” disrupting the staid legal discussion.

headline: Owen Labrie’s Interview May Lead to His Bail Being Revoked
abstract: The former student at an elite New Hampshire prep school, who was convicted of a sex offense last year, may have violated his curfew, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: When a reporter on a train in Boston spotted a former student of an elite New Hampshire prep school who was free on bail after a high-profile rape trial last year, she couldn’t resist peppering him with questions.

headline: Ted Cruz to Protester: ‘Very Charming’

lead_paragraph: Strings McCrane, a country music and movie star, talks way too much, and half the time he doesn’t even know what he’s saying. As embodied by an entertainingly irritating Timothy Olyphant in “Hold On to Me Darling,” which opened on Monday night at the Linda Gross Theater of the Atlantic Theater Company, Strings is a walking, whining confirmation of our suspicions that the rich and famous really are different from you and me: They’re a lot more shallow and needy.

This was a good debut, I thought, with some original clues for standard words (I liked “inspiring part of the body?” for LUNG, and although it was a little juvenile, ANITA bath seems to be another first for The New York Times puzzle).

headline: France: A Restaurant Begins Again
abstract: Le Petit Cambodge, one of the Paris sites attacked by terrorists last November, reopened on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Le Petit Cambodge, a Paris restaurant that was the site of one of the Islamic State attacks that killed 130 people last November, reopened on Monday night, almost four months to the day since the assaults that terrorized the city. The floor-to-ceiling windows, shattered by bullets, have been replaced. And though the restaurant — in the 10th Arrondissement — has been entirely refurbished, it seemed almost indistinguishable from before, with long wooden benches and stools with minimalist décor to match. The only addition is a small mosaic placed on the back wall in memory of the victims. Within an hour, Le Petit Cambodge was full.

headline: Illinois: 3 Chicago Police Officers Are Wounded in a Shooting
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Three Chicago police officers were wounded Monday night in a shooting on the city’s West Side, a spokesman for the Police Department said.
lead_paragraph: Three Chicago police officers were wounded Monday night in a shooting on the city’s West Side, a spokesman for the Police Department said. All three officers were expected to survive, said the spokesman, Officer Hector Alfaro. The shooting happened about 9:40 p.m. in the Homan Square neighborhood, Officer Alfaro said. He had no information Monday night about a possible suspect, saying that the information was “very preliminary” and that the situation was “still unfolding.” The shootings come at a time of intense scrutiny of the Chicago police, a force of about 12,000 officers that is being investigated by the Justice Department. Violent crime here has spiked this year, a search is underway for a permanent superintendent, and leaders of the local police union have said officer morale is low. According to the Officer Down Memorial Page, 23 American law enforcement officers have died in the line of duty this year. No Chicago police officer has died on duty since 2011, according to that website.

headline: Putin’s Syria Surprise

abstract: A military pullback announced by Russia’s leader could be a signal that he is serious about a lasting peace.

The announcement could turn out to be a constructive move toward a more lasting peace settlement. It could also be a practical necessity, reflecting a desire not to get bogged down in the Syrian morass indefinitely. As the United States has found, it is easier to get into wars than to get out of them.

abstract: It used to mean someone who liked drinking beer and hanging out with other guys. Now it’s an accusation of political cluelessness — or worse.
lead_paragraph: Are you a young or youngish man who prefers the company of other men? Platonically, platonically. (For the most part.) Are you currently wearing — or have you ever worn — baggy shorts? A baseball cap? A polo shirt? White sneakers? Sunglasses on your head? All at the same time? Are you white? And these other men whose company you enjoy, do you guys drink and watch sports together? Are they white, too? Have you been to see Mumford and Sons with them? What about Diplo? Or A$AP Rocky? If the New England Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski announced that he was having a three-day party on a cruise ship, would you go?

headline: Want Xavier’s Plays? Sure, Just Ask
abstract: While most top college teams play things close to the vest, the Musketeers share their plays and more in a newsletter emailed to 30,000 coaches across 17 countries.
lead_paragraph: College basketball coaches are often guarded about details concerning their programs. Practices are typically closed to the public. Coded keywords communicate plays to the players on the court. Many teams now go as far as to move their players off the bench and onto the court — and away from possibly nosy fans — before offering instructions during timeouts.

headline: On Small Ship, Ocean Life (and Other Passengers) Are Up Close
abstract: On a vessel this small, you can’t help but be immersed in the people and workings of the boat that’s taking you places.
lead_paragraph: Most of the boat is asleep when we pass through Ballard Locks in Seattle shortly before midnight. Blotchy, heavy clouds are stacked like anvils above a purple horizon. Stars wink here and there, a promise of a clearer night. Salmon still run freely between the fresh water of Lake Washington and the salt water of Puget Sound, through a fish ladder integrated within the locks.

headline: Al Qaeda’s Branch in Africa Makes a Lethal Comeback
abstract: Only a few years after French troops scattered its fighters, Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has regrouped and extended its reach in three nations.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Only a few years after French troops broke up its desert stronghold and scattered its fighters into the dunes, Al Qaeda’s branch in West Africa has regrouped and extended its reach, storming into new territory across three nations.

headline: A King in His Castle: How Donald Trump Lives, From His Longtime Butler

The sun glinted off the pool and the black Secret Service S.U.V.s in the circular driveway. Palm trees rustled in a warm breeze, croquet balls clicked and a security guard stood at the entrance to Donald J. Trump’s private living quarters.

headline: Q. and A.: Lau Ming-wai on Why Disaffected Hong Kong Youth Should Vote, Not Riot
abstract: The chairman of the government’s Commission on Youth discusses the sources of, and possible remedies for, young people’s political alienation in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong politics has not traditionally been an arena for teenagers. But in 2012, students as young as 15 turned out to protest a plan for a “national education” curriculum, calling it an attempt at brainwashing by Beijing in the semiautonomous Chinese territory. Then, in 2014, student-led demonstrators occupied large parts of central Hong Kong to press for greater popular participation in the election of the territory’s leader. This year, teenagers as young as 14 were among those detained when a protest against what they said was the authorities’ crackdown on street hawkers — seen as emblematic of local culture — escalated into the worst rioting in Hong Kong in half a century.

headline: 1941: British Arrive in the Balkans
keywords: ['BALKAN STATES', 'GERMANY', 'GREAT BRITAIN', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: British troops arrive in the Balkans and prepare for imminent battle in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — British and German troops are rapidly taking up positions in preparation for the Battle of the Balkans, which may begin in a few hours or a few days. In Greece nearly 100,000 British Empire troops already have landed, and double that number will follow as rapidly as they can be brought there, organized and sent to their posts. This correspondent talked tonight [March 15] with a diplomat who had just arrived here from Athens. He described how ships from Alexandria and Haifa were arriving daily in Greek ports. The vessels are filled with men and all kinds of war materials. — New York Herald Tribune, March 16, 1941

headline: Anders Behring Breivik, Killer in 2011 Norway Massacre, Says Prison Conditions Violate His Rights
abstract: Mr. Breivik, who killed 77 people in a gun and bomb rampage, claims that solitary confinement in a three-room prison suite amounts to torture.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — He lives in a three-room suite with windows, about 340 square feet, that includes a treadmill, a fridge, a DVD player, a Sony PlayStation and a desk with a typewriter. He has been taking distance-learning courses at his country’s main university. He has access to television, radio and newspapers. He prepares his own food, and he entered the Christmas gingerbread-house baking contest at his prison.

headline: 1966: U.S. to Hatch Tadpoles in Space
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. plans to hatch tadpoles in space aboard Gemini-8 in 1966.
lead_paragraph: COCOA BEACH, FLA. — Frogs, which normally spawn their young in bucolic ponds, now will get a chance to try it out in space. Some 400 fertilized eggs of the leopard frog — a small spotted creature — will take to the skies this week, along with two human astronauts, if Gemini-8 gets off the ground. Scientists designed the experiment to test the effects of zero gravity on the development of the frogs. At the end of the flight, the scientists believe, some of the live tadpoles may come down out of orbit with two heads. The astronauts, it is known, survive space flight with one. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 16, 1941

headline: The Segregation of India
abstract: In the building where I grew up, Hindus and Muslims lived side by side.
lead_paragraph: Each time I visit Mumbai, I make a pilgrimage to an old five-story building with crumbling balconies on Nepean Sea Road. It’s where I lived during the ’60s and ’70s — the first two decades of my life. I went back a few weeks ago. Standing outside, I thought about the diverse, cosmopolitan city I knew, and how it has changed.

headline: Angela Merkel, Down but not Out
abstract: Recent elections in Germany show the far right is on the rise. But the chancellor still has a chance to pull her country back to the center.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — ON Sunday, roughly nine million Germans cast their votes in three state elections. On the surface, the far right did well: The populist Alternative for Germany Party, the most outspoken opponent of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s course in the refugee and migration crisis, made significant gains in all three states. In Saxony-Anhalt, in the East, the party came in second, just 5 percentage points behind Ms. Merkel’s Christian Democrats and 14 points ahead of her coalition partner, the Social Democrats. Even in the West, traditionally more immune to all things that reek of radicalism, the party came in third.
