headline: Where is the E.U.’s Moral and Political Courage?
abstract: If the Greeks — bankrupt and tired, with a state that is dysfunctional at the best of times — can try their best, the union can try harder.
lead_paragraph: PIRAEUS, Greece — Greece pulsates with people fleeing war and poverty, from the docks of this port to the muddy fields of Idomeni, where their great migration runs into the barbed wire fences of Europe’s confusion and fear. Already drained by overwhelming debt, austerity and recession, the country is rushing to provide shelter and care for a surging number of stranded refugees and migrants who want nothing more than to keep moving, indifferent to the fact that their pursuit of freedom, stability and prosperity has thrown the European Union into its greatest crisis since its founding.

What was going on?

headline: Guadalajara, Mexico’s Party City
abstract: Thanks to a new arts and crafts movement, the galleries there are as cutting-edge as the food.
lead_paragraph: A former 16th-century trade outpost some 285 miles northwest of Mexico City in Jalisco state, Guadalajara is one of Mexico’s most traditional cities, a place where leafy boulevards are patchworked with French Baroque colonial mansions. Until recently, the art in Guadalajara has tended toward the folkloric: The town is primarily known for earthen ceramics, as well as for mariachi bands (the genre originated in the region). ‘‘It used to be that creative people got out of here as soon as possible,’’ says the artist Eduardo Sarabia, who moved to Guadalajara from Los Angeles and co-founded an art ‘‘laboratory’’ called PAOS that hosts residencies and exhibits in the stark studio that once belonged to the great Modernist muralist José Clemente Orozco. ‘‘But that’s changed.’’ Sarabia is part of a wave of young artists and gallerists who’re remaking the town into a sort of mellow, sunny-skies utopia. He’s joined by the young Spaniards Silvia Ortiz and Inés López-Quesada, who opened a branch of their Madrid gallery, Travesía Cuatro, in the upscale Colonia Lafayette neighborhood a few years ago in order to be closer to some of their key artists — local talent who have seen their stars rise on the contemporary scene, including Jose Dávila, Gonzalo Lebrija and Jorge Méndez Blake.

headline: ‘The Americans’: In Season 4, the Wars Grow Colder and More Dangerous
abstract: When “The Americans” returns to FX this week, Paige grapples with her parents’ story and the consequences of confiding in a friend.
lead_paragraph: In the season premiere of “The Americans,” Elizabeth Jennings (Keri Russell) has a chat with her teenage daughter about the family business: Paige (Holly Taylor) recently learned her parents are Soviet spies. “Is it dangerous?” Paige asks.

headline: Brussels Raid Linked to Paris Attacks Erupts in Fatal Shootout

lead_paragraph: PARIS — A police counterterrorism raid in Brussels linked to the Paris attacks turned into a chaotic shootout on Tuesday, leaving one suspect dead clutching an assault rifle, at least one other on the run, four officers wounded and an entire neighborhood in a traumatized lockdown.

headline: Teisui Gives ­Yakitori Top Billing in NoMad
abstract: Also, a Caprese addition to Little Italy, Tim and Nancy Cushman are opening a second restaurant in the Park South Hotel, and more.
lead_paragraph: Teisui Yakitori, or chicken grilled on skewers, has yet to attract the kind of following that other types of Japanese cooking, like ramen and sushi, have acquired in New York. But at this handsome new restaurant, it is given top billing and an elegance rarely associated with what in Japan is usually a quick meal of grilled chicken bits. “Yakitori is changing in Japan,” said Yuko Hagiwara, the manager of the restaurant, which is owned by a Japanese company. “It’s becoming more high-end because chicken is very expensive.” Here, several yakitori dishes, made with chicken from Bo Bo Poultry in Brooklyn, include chicken breast with beets and chicken tenders with mushrooms. They are part of a $150 10-course kaiseki menu served at a U-shaped stone counter facing the open kitchen and at tables around the room. The chef is Nobutaka Watanabe, working alongside Yuichiro Yoshimura, a yakitori expert. The room is designed to suggest the ryokan, a type of traditional country inn, that the parent company owns in northern Japan. Layers of wavy maple meant to resemble the sea cover one wall. (Opens Friday): 246 Fifth Avenue (entrance on 28th Street), 917-388-3596, teisui.nyc.

The beach was close enough that waves could be heard crashing onto the sand. Sugarloaf, the bullet-shape mountain with a cable car to the top, familiar from Rio postcards, loomed overhead.

headline: A Bygone Time Captured Through the Lens of Walker Evans
abstract: The High Museum of Art in Atlanta will offer a comprehensive show of the photographer’s work, beginning in June.
lead_paragraph: The most comprehensive show of work by the photographer Walker Evans since the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s retrospective in 2000 will open at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta in June. While the photographer’s work has been exhibited widely and often, the South has not “been exposed to an Evans show of this scope and caliber,” said Brett Abbott, the High’s curator of photography. The High will be the show’s only stop in the United States — something of a coup for a regional museum.

headline: Riches on Paper for the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston

A vast trove of imagery, it included everything from publicity snapshots of Russian czars in rowboats to promotional pieces that Bauhaus artists designed to advertise a 1923 exhibition.

headline: The Pacific Standard Time Initiative Seeks to Rescue Fugitive Art
abstract: The second iteration of the Getty Trust’s landmark Latin American art program in Southern California involves a tricky balancing act for curators.

She was researching the performance history of an experimental 1967 text by Ferrari, who died in 2013, called “Palabras Ajenas” (“The Words of Others”).

headline: A Marriage of Tastes — and of Two Furniture-Designing Artists
abstract: The fantastical yet functional furniture line of Hannes Van Severen and Fien Muller represents their distinct sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: It was a literal lightbulb moment that inspired the husband-and-wife Belgian artists Hannes Van Severen and Fien Muller to start making furniture. In 2010, the couple moved into an old house in a village outside Ghent and, unable to find electric wiring in the ceiling, decided to build a metal-framed table with a long-necked lamp growing from one of its legs. The result became the prototype for their first collection; soon they were working on more pieces, like a conjoined steel-and-leather chair and a white lacquered rack with colorful marble shelves.

headline: The Most Magical Moments of Texas’s Remotest Music Festival
abstract: Scenes from the dreamy, site-specific performances at Marfa Myths, which took place over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: It’s a blustery Saturday afternoon in Marfa, Texas, and hundreds are gathered inside a former Army hangar, much of the crowd lying prone on the red gravel floor or sitting cross-legged with their eyes closed. A few people stand, some staring dreamily up at a high row of windows that split the sky into perfect squares of indigo blue. The experimental music artist William Basinski is at the center of the hangar, his mirrored sunglasses focused on a table topped with computers, volume knobs, a thick knot of electrical cords. From the speakers flanking him comes a sweet, synthesized drone — complex tones that fill the massive space, lulling the audience into a kind of midday trance. Wind blasts at the cavernous arch of corrugated steel roofing, creating an aching, eerie, metallic rhythm, creaks and pops that seem somehow syncopated to Basinki’s improvised soundscape.

lead_paragraph: Three former leaders of a Franciscan religious order in Pennsylvania were charged with felonies on Tuesday for allowing a friar who was a known sexual predator to repeatedly work with children, including as a high school athletic trainer who massaged students naked, and pull some out of class for what a grand jury report called “private physical therapy sessions.”

headline: House Panel Denounces E.P.A. Actions in Flint Crisis
abstract: A congressional panel accused Susan Hedman of not responding forcefully enough when she learned the city was not adding an anti-corrosion chemical to the water supply.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of a congressional oversight committee excoriated a former Environmental Protection Agency official on Tuesday for not responding more forcefully when she learned last year that Flint, Mich., was not adding a chemical to its new water supply that would have prevented the city’s pipes from corroding and leaching lead.

headline: Mariah Carey to Star in a Series for E!
abstract: “Mariah’s World,” produced by the company behind “Keeping Up With the Kardashians,” will chronicle the singer’s new concert tour and her planned wedding.
lead_paragraph: The Kardashians, Caitlyn Jenner and the female wrestlers of “Total Divas” will welcome a new neighbor to the E! lineup later this year: the singer Mariah Carey.

headline: CBS Looks to Exit Radio Business
abstract: CBS is examining various options as traditional radio tries to compete with online services like Pandora and Spotify.
lead_paragraph: CBS Corporation announced on Tuesday that it was putting its radio business on the block, as the media company aims to streamline its business to focus on its broadcast network, the premium channel Showtime and digital.

headline: N.F.L. Shifts on Concussions, and Game May Never Be the Same
abstract: An N.F.L. executive’s acknowledgment of a link between football and degenerative brain disorders could have ripple effects throughout the sport.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no one will remember the setting, a hearing room for the House Energy and Commerce Committee, or the person who asked the question, a member of the House of Representatives from Illinois. But seven words spoken in the Rayburn House Office Building in Washington on Monday could profoundly affect the country’s most popular sport.

headline: Even if You Can’t Afford Designer Clothes, Your Bitmoji Can
abstract: Michael Kors, Zac Posen, Alexander McQueen, Calvin Klein and Diane von Furstenberg have all created looks for the popular avatar app. More to come.
lead_paragraph: You wonder how fashion designers keep up: fall, spring, resort, cruise, couture, pre-fall. All this while trying to navigate the shifting sands of the industry. Soon designers may be tasked with creating yet another collection — for Bitmoji. Some already are.

headline: Video Shows Texas Police Officer Pepper-Spraying, Motorcycle Riders Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: The officer, who had pulled over a truck on the side of a highway, was put on administrative leave while the Fort Worth department investigated the episode.
lead_paragraph: A Texas police officer was removed from his patrol duties and officials were investigating a video that appears to show him pepper-spraying motorcycle riders as they passed his parked cruiser on a highway last weekend.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jim Dwyer, David M. Halbfinger and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Bangladesh Bank Chief Resigns After Cyber Theft of $81 Million
abstract: The banking official quit and three subordinates were fired after an electronic theft from Bangladesh’s account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
lead_paragraph: A spreading scandal over the mysterious electronic theft of $81 million from Bangladesh’s official account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York prompted the governor of that country’s central bank to resign Tuesday, and three of his subordinates were fired.

headline: Review: In ‘The Travelers,’ Danger at Every Destination
abstract: In Chris Pavone’s new novel, a travel writer is on the run through countless efforts to recruit, frame, trick and kill him.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of spy-hopping in “The Travelers,” Chris Pavone’s third and most furiously peripatetic novel. The first is what an inquisitive whale does when it shoots its head above water. The second is what this espionage novel does when it jumps from Paris to London; the Gulf of Maine to Husavik, Iceland, in the space of three pages; then back to Paris, Husavik and New York City shortly thereafter. Mr. Pavone keeps his readers’ heads spinning and his main character, the travel writer Will Rhodes, on the run.

headline: Dr. Barbara Almond, Who Examined Maternal Ambivalence, Dies at 77
abstract: Dr. Almond was a psychiatrist whose 2010 book looked at women’s difficult, and sometimes guilty, feelings about childbearing and motherhood.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Barbara Almond, a psychiatrist who lifted the veil on the ambivalence some women feel about childbearing and on society’s expectations about motherhood, died on March 6 in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 77.

headline: Instagram May Change Your Feed, Personalizing It With an Algorithm
abstract: As our online networks of friends have grown and the social media companies have matured, feeds are evolving, too.
lead_paragraph: For years, we have been trained to view web postings from our friends in a certain order. Refresh the top of your various “feeds” — the running column of content on some versions of Facebook, Twitter and Instagram — and you will see the latest news at the top. The further back you scroll, the older the material gets.

headline: Chappatte on Putin’s Syria Withdrawal
abstract: Mission accomplished?
lead_paragraph: Mission accomplished?

headline: Review: In ‘Elijah Green,’ Archetypes in Search of Meaning
abstract: Andrew Ondrejcak’s play at the Kitchen examines characters inspired by Strindberg and Breugel.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of an hour, a woman sits at a cutting board at the edge of the audience, gutting fish. Far upstage, a man in what looks like bunny ears paints a fluted column white. One woman dances, wearing a tunic made of net; another does little but iron.

headline: Review: Los Angeles Philharmonic Makes the Familiar Feel Fresh
abstract: The orchestra, led by Gustavo Dudamel, juxtaposed Copland with works by Ginastera and Andrew Norman at David Geffen Hall.
lead_paragraph: It is possible to hear even a chestnut like the “Appalachian Spring” Suite with fresh ears. Sometimes context alone can do it. Played by the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Monday evening, during the second of a two-concert stand at David Geffen Hall, this Copland piece of soaring, stirring Americana was preceded by a 1961 piano concerto by Alberto Ginastera and a 2013 symphonic detonation by Andrew Norman.

headline: In ‘Happy Valley,’ the Bodies Pile Up
abstract: The second season of this British police series includes prostitutes being targeted by a serial killer, adding to a sergeant’s troubles.
lead_paragraph: The excellent British cop show “Happy Valley” built toward a grim and brutally violent resolution in its first season, and as Season 2 opens — the six episodes will be available on Netflix on Wednesday — the mood is reassuring, almost comic. Sgt. Catherine Cawood (Sarah Lancashire) is 18 months removed from her battle to near death with the murderous Tommy Lee Royce (James Norton) and finds herself chasing a band of young, stoned sheep rustlers. It’s just the latest reminder of her humble status as a uniformed police officer.

headline: Review: ‘Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders’ Tracks Gruesome Assaults on Traveling Americans
abstract: In this CBS spinoff, an F.B.I. team led by Gary Sinise jets across the globe trying to take down murderous psychos.
lead_paragraph: Like some presidential campaigns, the “Criminal Minds” television franchise is built on fear. In the original show (now in its 11th season), murderous psychos are everywhere in America, waiting to turn your home into an abattoir or torture chamber. In the new spinoff, “Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders” (starting on Wednesday on CBS), murderous psychos are everywhere Americans travel around the world, waiting to sell them into slavery or steal their kidneys.

headline: Dozens Killed in Airstrikes on Market in Yemen
abstract: The Saudi-led coalition fighting the Houthi rebel group was blamed for the attack that killed civilians at a market and a restaurant.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Dozens of people were killed when warplanes from a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia bombed a restaurant and crowded market in northern Yemen shortly before noon on Tuesday, medical workers said.

headline: Karen Hall Alters ‘Dark Debts’ in a New Edition
abstract: Ms. Hall’s obsessiveness was the driving force behind the decision to revisit her 1996 breakthrough novel.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Hall published her debut novel, “Dark Debts,” 20 years ago, it seemed like the start of a blockbuster literary career. Ms. Hall, a veteran TV writer who had worked on hits like “M*A*S*H” and “Hill Street Blues,” had the commercial storytelling chops. She spent five years working on the novel, a pulpy theological thriller about a Roman Catholic priest who becomes mixed up with demonic forces.

headline: S.E.C. Opens Door to Investment Banking for Steven Rattner, Barred Financier
abstract: Mr. Rattner, who led the Obama administration’s auto industry overhaul, was barred from certain Wall Street jobs in 2010.
lead_paragraph: If Steven Rattner wants to return to investment banking, the Securities and Exchange Commission has cleared the way for him.

headline: Seton Hall’s Big-Time Player
abstract: Guard Isaiah Whitehead chose Seton Hall because it was close to home, and the Pirates are glad he did.
lead_paragraph: Guard Isaiah Whitehead chose Seton Hall because it was close to home, and the Pirates are glad he did.

headline: In Seton Hall’s Late Run, Praise for a Most Valuable Parent
abstract: Guard Isaiah Whitehead chose Seton Hall because of his mother, who also played a role in the basketball career of one of his teammates.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — Isaiah Whitehead, the sophomore point guard from Coney Island who led Seton Hall to its first Big East men’s basketball championship in 23 years last weekend, is still saying, politely, that he does not know if he will jump to the N.B.A. after this season.

headline: At New Directors/New Films, a Glimpse of the Otherworldly
abstract: This year’s package leans toward the somber and includes assorted spirits, a number of slaughtered animals and a variety of environmental disasters.
lead_paragraph: As it does every year, New Directors/New Films is offering a globe-trotting sampler of more than two dozen features as well as miscellaneous short takes aimed at highlighting the work of emerging artists. This year’s package, which begins on Wednesday and includes 27 features — selected by programmers from the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art — leans toward the somber and includes assorted spirits, a number of slaughtered animals and a variety of environmental disasters, along with an occasional welcome flicker of joy. The following are our favorites from Week 1, in the order in which they are first screened.

headline: Review: ‘Fireworks Wednesday,’ a Domestic Drama From Iran
abstract: Asghar Farhadi’s film, set during the boisterous New Year celebrations in Tehran, dissects the imploding marriage of an affluent couple.
lead_paragraph: If you didn’t know that the continual explosions heard in Asghar Farhadi’s film “Fireworks Wednesday” were the sounds of firecrackers and cherry bombs celebrating the Persian New Year in the streets of Tehran, they could easily be mistaken for deadly wartime explosions in a city under siege. And in a way they are.

headline: Review: Jim Black Trio at Le Poisson Rouge
abstract: This show featured a new suite commissioned by Chamber Music America and due out as an album this summer.
lead_paragraph: The Jim Black Trio closed its show at Le Poisson Rouge late Monday night with a transfixing burst of turbulence called “Beariere.” Elias Stemeseder, the band’s pianist, whipped up a low-end fury out of which a melody surprisingly emerged, like a sparrow from a bramble. Thomas Morgan’s bass was a movable pivot, holding the center of the churn. Mr. Black, on drums, struck an elusive truce between bombast and finesse, driving his agenda along with the pulse of the tune.

headline: Sony PlayStation VR Will Cost $399 When It Arrives in October
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Headphones and Headsets']
abstract: The PlayStation VR, once connected to the company’s PS4, is intended to give Sony a head start, and price advantage, in the expanding virtual reality market.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sony Computer Entertainment is hoping to ride the coattails of its top-selling game console, the PlayStation 4, to gain traction in a new market: virtual reality.

headline: Inspections Will Close Washington, D.C., Metro on Wednesday
abstract: After an electrical fire, officials called for safety inspections that will shut down the subway system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The subway system here will shut down all day on Wednesday to allow for wide-scale safety inspections prompted by a fire earlier this week, officials said Tuesday. It will be the first time that the system, the nation’s second busiest, has closed for any reason other than bad weather in its four decades.

headline: Beyond Swipe Right: The Pickup Line Gets a Makeover
abstract: The migration of courtship online has resulted in a refinement of pickup lines far beyond ’70s singles-bar relics like “Hey baby, what’s your sign?”
lead_paragraph: Whither the pickup line?

headline: Statues in Torlonia Collection, Long Out of Sight, Will Soon Be on Public Display
abstract: The family’s foundation and Italy’s Culture Ministry have signed an accord to show the over 600 marble, bronze and alabaster statues and reliefs.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Torlonia family’s collection of ancient marble sculptures has long been the stuff of legend for art historians and archaeologists.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and More — Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and More — Photos of the Day

headline: March 15, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, Germany, Greece and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, Germany, Greece and Afghanistan.

headline: Review: ‘Miracles From Heaven,’ Starring Jennifer Garner as the Mother of a Sick Child
abstract: This deus-ex-machina tale, based on Christy Beam’s memoir, centers on a family whose faith is tested by a daughter’s illness.
lead_paragraph: Until it delivers an eye-rolling scene near the end, “Miracles From Heaven” is an unexpectedly effective tear-jerker. More surprising still, that late diversion doesn’t negate much of the movie’s early sincerity.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Names Former Regulator as Chief Regulatory Officer
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Anthony J. Albanese, the former acting New York State financial industry regulator, takes on the job as the Big Board wraps up a regulatory overhaul.
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange has completed an overhaul of its regulatory functions, naming Anthony J. Albanese, the former acting New York state financial industry regulator, as its chief regulatory officer.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Vladimir Putin
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Senate to Vote on GMO Food Labeling Bill
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Food', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering']
abstract: The senators will consider whether the government should require labeling on foods containing genetically engineered ingredients, an issue that has split the food industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate will grapple this week with perhaps the most contentious issue in the food industry: whether the government should require mandatory labeling on foods containing genetically engineered ingredients.

headline: Apple and Justice Dept. Trade Barbs in iPhone Privacy Case
keywords: ['Privacy', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The company said a ruling on unlocking the phone of a gunman in a mass shooting had to take into account the national debate over data privacy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Tuesday emphasized its opposition to a court order requiring it to help unlock an iPhone for law enforcement purposes, saying in a new legal brief that the government’s “methods for achieving its objectives are contrary to the rule of law, the democratic process and the rights of the American people.”

headline: Study of Zika Outbreak Estimates 1 in 100 Risk of Microcephaly
abstract: Roughly one in 100 women infected in the first trimester of pregnancy had such fetuses, a study of an outbreak in French Polynesia found.
lead_paragraph: During a recent outbreak of the Zika virus in French Polynesia, roughly one in 100 women infected in the first trimester of pregnancy developed a fetus with an abnormally small head and brain damage, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: Grand Jury Findings Against Franciscan Order in Pennsylvania
abstract: Three members of the Franciscan Friars are being charged with one count each of endangering the welfare of children and criminal conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: Three members of the Franciscan Friars are being charged with one count each of endangering the welfare of children and criminal conspiracy.

headline: Welcome to...
abstract: Ellen Barry traveled to Mela Thiruvenkatanathapuram — or MAY-la THEE-roo VEN-ka-ta NA-tha POO-ram, as a resident of the southeast state of Tamil Nadu might pronounce it.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Barry traveled to Mela Thiruvenkatanathapuram — or MAY-la THEE-roo VEN-ka-ta NA-tha POO-ram, as a resident of the southeast state of Tamil Nadu might pronounce it.

headline: FleetCor Technologies in Deal for Brazilian Toll Payments Company
abstract: FleetCor, based in Georgia, said it was impressed with how its acquisition, Serviços e Tecnologia de Pagamentos, has fared during Brazil’s downturn.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — FleetCor Technologies has agreed to acquire the Brazilian electronic toll payments company Serviços e Tecnologia de Pagamentos for $1.05 billion.

headline: Figuring Out What Valeant Is Really Worth
abstract: As Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ market value sinks, the company’s future may hinge on what it can get now for the companies it bought.
lead_paragraph: As investors dumped shares of the beleaguered Valeant Pharmaceuticals International on Tuesday, erasing more than $11 billion from its market value, the company’s previously large crowd of believers was becoming vanishingly thin.

headline: Alabama Prison Uprisings Come as State Grapples With How to Fix System
abstract: Gov. Robert Bentley’s proposal to relieve overcrowding by building four new facilities has been met with skepticism by many.
lead_paragraph: ATMORE, Ala. — When the video appeared on Facebook, it was as compelling as it was shaky and shocking: Using a contraband device, a state prisoner recorded and narrated nearly a minute of a prison riot here that had already led to a fire and the stabbings of two officials, including the warden.

headline: The Financial Alchemy That’s Choking SunEdison
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Solar Energy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: If SunEdison enters into bankruptcy, it will probably be because of unusual financial engineering and the failure of those involved to remember the lessons of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: If SunEdison enters into bankruptcy, the autopsy will no doubt reveal a suicide, finding the solar energy company done in by financial engineering that was too clever and by a failure of its executives and investment bankers to remember the lessons of the financial crisis.

headline: Canada: Man Charged in Attack at Recruiting Center
abstract: A Canadian man was charged with seven offenses after he injured two soldiers with a knife at a military recruiting center in northern Toronto.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian man was charged with seven offenses on Tuesday after he injured two soldiers with a knife at a military recruiting center in Toronto. The man, Ayanle Hassan Ali, 27, entered the center on Monday with a “very large knife” and attacked a soldier stationed near the door, said Toronto’s police chief, Mark Saunders. A second soldier was wounded trying to subdue Mr. Ali. Neither soldier was seriously injured. The police chief said that during the attack, Mr. Ali said, “Allah told me to come here and kill people.” Chief Saunders said the police did not know whether Mr. Ali, who was born in Montreal, was an Islamist radical.

headline: Live Model: Republican Primary Results
abstract: Live estimates of the March 15 Republican primary results.
lead_paragraph: Live estimates of the March 15 Republican primary results.

headline: Live Model: Democratic Primary Results
abstract: Live estimates of the March 15 Democratic primary results.
lead_paragraph: Live estimates of the March 15 Democratic primary results.

headline: Paul McCartney’s Tip to Michael Jackson Pays Off
abstract: Sony will pay $750 million for the Jackson estate’s share of Sony/ATV — a collection of more than a million songs, including the Beatles’ songs.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the twice-told tales of the music business: Decades ago, Michael Jackson received some sound investment advice from Paul McCartney.

headline: A Canadian Province’s Rocky Symbol Collapses Into Rubble
abstract: The tides that helped carve Elephant Rock, a natural stone formation in New Brunswick, Canada, out of the shoreline also played a role in its destruction.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Viewed at just the right angle, and maybe with a bit of squinting — and perhaps a little imagination — the natural stone formation resembled a charging elephant, about 100 feet high and up to eight feet wide.

headline: The Opening to Cuba Widens
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Ahead of President Obama’s trip to Cuba, the embargo has been eased to make travel between the two countries easier for Cubans and Americans.
lead_paragraph: Americans are still barred by law from traveling to Cuba as tourists, despite the Obama administration’s opening with that country. But  new rules  announced by the administration on Tuesday will make traveling there easier and cheaper.

headline: A Conversation With Michael S. Dana
abstract: Mr. Dana, 56, is the president and chief executive of Onex Real Estate Partners, the real estate arm of Onex, one of Canada’s largest private equity firms.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Dana, 56, is the president and chief executive of Onex Real Estate Partners, the real estate arm of Onex, one of Canada’s largest private equity firms.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $2.85 million

headline: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Says His Hand Is Improving
abstract: The defensive end said that an off-season operation had improved the function of his right hand and that he did not plan to use the wrapping he needed last season.
lead_paragraph: Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul said Tuesday that recent off-season surgery had improved the function of his damaged right hand and that he did not plan to use the mittlike wrapping he needed last season.

headline: Ex-President ‘Lula’ Could Avoid Prison by Joining Brazilian Cabinet
abstract: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, facing possible arrest in a graft inquiry, is reported to be a candidate for a post that would legally protect him.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Will Brazil’s besieged former president avoid going to prison by joining the government of his protégé, President Dilma Rousseff, as a cabinet minister with unrivaled influence?

headline: G.O.P. Path Recalls Democrats’ Convention Disaster, in 1924
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: There were fistfights and major influence by the Ku Klux Klan during the party’s convention at Madison Square Garden, an existential battle over the meaning of America.
lead_paragraph: A presidential candidate who banked on support from the Ku Klux Klan. Blunt demands to ban certain religions and races from playing a full role in society. Violence and disorder at campaign rallies.

headline: Ohio Exit Polls
abstract: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout Ohio on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout Ohio on Tuesday.

headline: Ohio Exit Polls
abstract: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout Ohio on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout Ohio on Tuesday.

abstract: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout Florida on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout Florida on Tuesday.

headline: Florida Exit Polls
abstract: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout Florida on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout Florida on Tuesday.

headline: New Work Rules Reshape M.L.B.’s Relationship With Cuban Prospects
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Defectors (Political)', 'Human Trafficking', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Free Agents (Sports)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A decision by the Obama administration could have a profound effect on the way major league teams sign Cuban baseball players.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced Tuesday that it would allow Cuban citizens to work in the United States and receive salaries from American companies, a decision that could have a profound effect on the way major league teams sign Cuban baseball players.

headline: Pressure on Valeant Puts William Ackman’s Image as Moneymaker at Risk
abstract: Mr. Ackman of Pershing Square has stayed in the stock and sustained enormous losses on paper.
lead_paragraph: As an investor, William A. Ackman lives or dies by his big bets. When he is right, the hedge fund titan earns billions of dollars and plenty of accolades.

headline: A Distant Second at Home, Marco Rubio Ends a Disappointing Campaign
abstract: The senator’s run was a cycle of hopes and disappointments as Republican voters were ultimately unwilling to entrust him with high office.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Marco Rubio tried everything to project experience and statesmanship. He held forth on the intricacies of Middle East geopolitics. He rattled off the dangers of a nuclear-armed North Korean dictator.

headline: With Sri Srinivasan, Indian Town Prays for a ‘Son’ on Supreme Court
abstract: Sri Srinivasan is known in Washington as a brilliant judge and possible Supreme Court nominee. In his family’s village in India, he is known as “our son.”
lead_paragraph: MELA THIRUVENKATANATHAPURAM, India — A bare-chested priest sat cross-legged in the temple of this farming village on a recent morning and recited all 1,008 names of Vishnu, the Hindu god, in the hope of soon receiving good news from the White House.

headline: Nick Denton, on Stand, Justifies Posting of Hulk Hogan Sex Video
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Gawker Media chief said that by posting the video, his editor “made a contrast between an American icon and the man behind that American icon.”
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Saying that a sex video featuring the former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan was newsworthy, Nick Denton, the founder and chief executive of Gawker Media, defended his website’s decision to publish it as he testified in a $100 million invasion-of-privacy lawsuit here on Tuesday.

headline: Student of Irish Language Brings to Life a Patriot of the Easter Rising
abstract: Ed Shevlin, a retired sanitation worker now in a master’s program in Irish studies, has shed new light on a fellow native of Rockaway, Queens, who took part in the 1916 Irish rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Ed Shevlin is hardly a typical academic.

headline: Bounty Hunter Tracks Chinese Companies That Dupe Investors
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Bounty Hunters']
abstract: Robert W. Seiden has built a legal specialty representing American investors who are suing Chinese companies saying that they were swindled.
lead_paragraph: Robert W. Seiden is a Wall Street bounty hunter. He tracks down executives of Chinese companies that listed on stock exchanges in the United States and then blew up.

headline: Rubio’s Exit and the G.O.P.’s Spoiled Buffet
abstract: The Republican race is down to three, two of whom still make party leaders queasy.
lead_paragraph: As he exited the race for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday night, Marco Rubio told a crowd of dispirited supporters that “this may not have been the year for a hopeful and optimistic message.”

headline: Ferguson Approves a Federal Plan to Overhaul Police and Courts
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After a 6-to-0 vote by the City Council, Ferguson must begin the long and costly process of implementing sweeping reforms to its criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The City Council here voted on Tuesday to approve a settlement with the Justice Department to overhaul the city’s police and courts, capping a tense few weeks of indecision over how to push forward a community at the center of more than a year and a half of racial upheaval in America.

headline: Review: ‘L’Elisir d’Amore,’ With Vittorio Grigòlo
abstract: Enrique Mazzola conducted this presentation of the Bartlett Sher production of the Donizetti opera at the Met.
lead_paragraph: In Donizetti’s “L’Elisir d’Amore,” the shy country lad Nemorino, in love with the beautiful, rich Adina, bemoans his poverty, lack of education and timidity. But when the tenor Vittorio Grigòlo sang the role on Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera, it felt like the subtitles should have read “I am somebody” rather than the libretto’s “I am nobody.”

headline: Ryan’s Budget Proposal Runs Into Opposition From Some Hard-Line Republicans
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: Hours before the House Budget Committee unveiled next year’s budget, members of the Freedom Caucus said they would oppose the plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul D. Ryan made his name as a master of budgets, putting forward sweeping documents that epitomized the Republican Party’s preference for slashing taxes, curtailing spending and shrinking government. But his first chance to pass a fiscal blueprint as speaker of the House is at risk of being derailed by the conservatives who forced a government shutdown in 2013 and ousted his predecessor last fall.

headline: Federal Agents Seize What They Called an Illicit Antiquity Headed for Asia Week
abstract: For the second time in a matter of days, an item scheduled to be sold at the celebration of Asian art, held in New York, was seized by agents.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in a matter of days, federal agents on Tuesday seized what they described as an illicit antiquity, valued at several hundred thousand dollars, and scheduled to be sold during New York’s Asia Week, a celebration of Asian art that includes museum exhibitions and sales by dealers and auction houses.

headline: Cornerstone of Cubs’ Quest Plays First Base
abstract: Anthony Rizzo is the pillar of a team that started spring training as the betting favorite to win the World Series — what would be its first title since 1908.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — There is no hiding it now. The Chicago Cubs, the most optimistic bunch of perennial losers you will ever meet, have built their foundation on Anthony Rizzo. He is their pillar, the player who holds up the party tent for a celebration 108 years in the making.

headline: Can Rubio's Exit Stop Trump?
abstract: Who, if anyone, will Rubio's supporters vote for now, and will that make a difference?

headline: What’s Next for Both Parties
abstract: Republicans must decide whether to embrace Donald Trump while Hillary Clinton needs to win over Bernie Sanders’s supporters.
lead_paragraph: After losing the presidential election in 2012, the Republican Party leadership put together an “autopsy” report that examined the causes of the defeat. It said that if the party was to win in 2016, it needed to diversify its appeal, reach out to minorities, “help everyone make it in America” and attack corporate malfeasance and even chief executives’ bonuses. With Donald Trump’s victories, those leaders face a difficult choice.

headline: Splash Another Add of Wine

I often solve puzzles in the kitchen, filling in the grid while things roast and simmer, thinking of answers while I stir and measure, so this theme was a cute coincidence for me. It also made me think of Julia Child, not because I match her chef chops in the slightest, but because my random memories of her shows are of her good-humored, loopy patter and her unbridled enthusiasm for all of the good stuff. A favorite quote: “The only time to eat diet food is while you’re waiting for the steak to cook.”

headline: Should Parents Reveal That a Father at Their Child’s School Is a Sex Offender?
keywords: ['Plagiarism', 'Sex Crimes', 'Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what determines the limits of privacy when the safety of minors is concerned.
lead_paragraph: My daughter goes to a public elementary school. Recently, one of the parents in our class discovered that a fellow parent, the father of a girl in my daughter’s class, was arrested in an undercover police operation for soliciting an underage female prostitute. Details of the undercover operation were posted online. He agreed to pay for sex with the underage prostitute, who would come to his house while his young children were asleep and his wife was away at work. He confessed to the crime but is not on the county’s searchable online database of sex offenders. While the principal of our school was alerted by another parent and met with the man and his wife (they are still married), information was not passed on to other parents because he is considered at low risk to reoffend. He does not volunteer at the school, at the request of the principal.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Asking What You Pay in Rent
abstract: Use math to avoid your friends’ rude questions. You know they can’t add.
lead_paragraph: Julia writes: My boyfriend, Mike, and I just moved into a house that’s fancier than what we’re both used to. When friends come over, they often ask what we pay in rent. Mike thinks we should just tell them, because they’re probably asking to see what’s attainable for themselves. I disagree.

headline: The Indian Spy Who Fell for Tibet
abstract: Sent by Britain to carry out a secret survey, Sarat Chandra Das became enchanted instead.
lead_paragraph: If it hadn’t been for a bout of malaria, Sarat Chandra Das might never have become a spy. As a civil engineer, he might have worked in Calcutta forever. But in 1874, upon recovering from his illness, he was offered a position as headmaster of the Bhutia Boarding School in Darjeeling. The mountain air would do him good, he thought, so he accepted. This was how, at 25, Das came to run a school for spies, training agents to work along the India-Tibet border, growing so besotted with Tibet himself that he made two surreptitious journeys to the kingdom.

keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: His feet froze solid. An avalanche buried him up to his neck. Villagers risked death to hide him. How Jan Baalsrud escaped the Nazis and became a Norwegian folk hero.
lead_paragraph: The young soldier was frightened and freezing. He’d just swum 70 yards through frigid water, fleeing the burning wreckage of an exploded boat. Climbing ashore, he heard gunfire, glanced backward and saw his friend on the ground, blood rushing from his head. Farther away, others in his unit were being rounded up or killed by the Germans. He was sure he would be next.

headline: 2 Female Suicide Bombers Attack Mosque Near Maiduguri, Nigeria, Killing Over 20
abstract: The militant Islamic group Boko Haram is suspected of carrying out the bombings, which also wounded 18 people, an army spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Two female suicide bombers detonated explosives on Wednesday morning in an attack on a mosque in northeastern Nigeria, killing 24 people and wounding 18.

headline: Delegates Endorse China’s 5-Year Plan but Resist Saying Much Else
abstract: Delegates overwhelmingly approved President Xi Jinping’s framework for China’s development, but they and their staff shied away from casual conversation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Not long after 8 a.m. on Wednesday, a line of buses roared onto cordoned-off Tiananmen Square in the heart of Beijing to drop off hundreds of delegates to the National People’s Congress. They walked quickly to the granite-pillared Great Hall of the People on the west side of the square for the final meeting of this year’s session.

headline: 1941: Nazis Forces Occupy Balkans
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazis forces occupy Balkans in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — With large-scale operations in the Balkans apparently imminent, there was speculation in diplomatic circles here today [March 16] about Fuehrer Adolf Hitler’s motives in moving south through the Balkans and running the risk of opening up a major front here. The Nazis have always been the first to argue that they wanted peace in southeastern Europe. They have said that they did not want war on two fronts and that they did not want to disturb the Reich’s economic hinterland. Yet the Germans have jeopardized the economic stability of one Balkan country after another by their military march to the south. — New York Herald Tribune, March 17, 1941

headline: Belgium Says Algerian Killed in Raid May Have Had Links to Radical Islam
abstract: Mohamed Belkaid, a 35-year-old who was in Belgium illegally, tried to open fire on officers and was shot and killed by a special forces sniper.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The man who was killed during a counterterrorism raid was an Algerian with potential links to radical Islam, Belgian prosecutors said on Wednesday. Two other suspects from Tuesday’s raid, which left four police officers wounded, remain on the run, the prosecutors said.

headline: Another Fashion Brand Loses a Designer

lead_paragraph: Adding to the disarray in the current fashion world, Ennio Capasa, creative director of Costume National, and his brother, Carlo Capasa, its chief executive, announced on Tuesday that they were leaving the brand they founded 30 years ago.

abstract: President Obama said he had chosen Merrick B. Garland, a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, as his nominee for the Supreme Court. Congressional Republican leaders vowed almost immediately to block the nomination process.

headline: David Tennant, a Former Doctor Who, Dons a Monarch’s Crown
abstract: Mr. Tennant plays the lead in “Richard II,” part of a tetralogy of Shakespeare historical plays coming to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: There are probably young actors today who look back a short distance to a performance by David Tennant — playing the Doctor in “Doctor Who,” or Alec Hardy in “Broadchurch,” or Kilgrave in “Jessica Jones” — as a formative influence on their work and career. Mr. Tennant, 44, looks back a bit further, to the late 1980s, when the Royal Shakespeare Company brought “Hamlet” to Glasgow with Mark Rylance in the title role.

headline: Fashion’s Return to the Age of Innocence

lead_paragraph: A romantic cascade of billowy blouses, buttoned collars and flowing hair summons the purifying spirit of a new spring.

headline: Britain, Don’t Leave the E.U., Only You Can Save It.
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The British may decide to leave the European Union this year. They should stay — because they’re the only ones who can save it.
lead_paragraph: Hamburg, Germany — DEAR Britons: I feel your pain. As a former Brussels correspondent still traumatized by the posting, I have no illusions left about the European Union’s shortcomings and overreaches. I won’t play the Good German, begging you to stay. If you feel you have to leave, of course you must. But there’s this: A Brexit isn’t in your national interest. And I believe that, in leaving, you would betray your nation’s heritage.

headline: Pakistan’s Supreme Court Lifts Travel Ban on Pervez Musharraf
abstract: Mr. Musharraf, a former military leader facing charges of treason, has been in poor health, and the ruling would let him seek treatment abroad.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Supreme Court on Wednesday withdrew a travel ban imposed on the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf, paving the way for him to seek medical treatment abroad even as he awaits trial on treason charges.

headline: How Muslim Governments Impose Ignorance
abstract: Across the Islamic world, censors limit access to ideas in the name of protecting religion. Whom are they really protecting?
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — I recently spent a few days in Malaysia, where I was promoting the publication of the Malay edition of my book, “Islam Without Extremes: A Muslim Case for Liberty.” The publisher, a progressive Muslim organization called the Islamic Renaissance Front, had set up several talks for me in Kuala Lumpur. As any author would be, I was happy to learn that the team was enthusiastic about my book and had been getting good feedback from audiences and readers. But I was troubled by something else that I suspect many Muslim authors have experienced: My publisher was worried about censorship.

headline: The East Village May Change, but the Strudel at Moishe’s Stays the Same
abstract: Moishe’s Bake Shop has served kosher goods to crowds of newcomers, regulars and former locals for decades, even as the neighborhood has undergone dramatic shifts.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood around Second Avenue and East Seventh Street has changed a good deal in the last four decades or so, since Moishe Perl opened his kosher bakery on a block that could be described as dicey, when he would often need to scatter a few drunks sleeping it off on the sidewalk when he opened up in the morning. Certainly the local streets never teemed with restaurantgoers, shoppers and multilingual tourists the way they do now on an ordinary Sunday afternoon.

lead_paragraph: After officials announced that Metro, Washington’s subway system, would be shut down for 29 hours, riders began preparations for another problematic travel day in a city already well known for its cramped and sometimes dangerous train commutes.

headline: 1966: Watts Rioting Erupts Again
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Riots break out again in Watts, Los Angeles, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hundreds of Negroes rampaged for six hours last night [March 15], leaving at least two persons dead and 26 injured in the Watts district of Los Angeles. A massive force of several hundred police swiftly sealed off a 36-square-block section in the predominantly Negro district, scene of last August’s blood riot. Then police with shotguns moved in to clear the streets of mobs firing guns, hurling bottles, looting stores and burning cars. Gov. Edmund G. Brown flew to Los Angeles, but decided against calling out the alerted National Guard. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 17, 1966

headline: ‘The Passion,’ a Live Musical on Fox
abstract: Tyler Perry is the host and narrator of this program broadcast from New Orleans that recounts the final hours of Christ’s life.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Perry’s work often embraces his Christian beliefs, so his role as the host and narrator of Fox’s “The Passion” might seem like divine casting. “I wanted to be involved,” he wrote on his Facebook page earlier this month, “because I was shocked to find out how many people in this country don’t know the story of Jesus Christ’s death and resurrection. I was also shocked at the amount of people under 25 who don’t believe in anything.”

headline: Money Zombies Without a Clue
abstract: In the comedy-drama “Dry Powder,” at the Public Theater, an equity firm and its top executives behave very badly.
lead_paragraph: Given how prominent private equity firms have become in the upper reaches of the economy, it’s surprising that they haven’t been mined for drama by more playwrights. Then again, the words “leveraged buyout” don’t exactly make you want to sit up and glue your eyes to the stage, now do they? The Public Theater enters the breach with “Dry Powder,” a star-laden comedy-drama by Sarah Burgess about a prominent firm’s maneuverings. Hank Azaria plays a financial titan who faces public outrage for giving himself a lavish engagement party after his company engineers huge layoffs at a grocery chain.

headline: Steampunk Notes Struck in an Alt-Paris
abstract: The animated “April and the Extraordinary World” includes a talking cat, a woman who lives inside a statue of Napoleon and visuals by Jacques Tardi.
lead_paragraph: Steampunk hits Paris in Christian Desmares and Franck Ekinci’s high-flying animated fantasy “April and the Extraordinary World,” coming to IFC Center on Friday, March 25. Imagining an alternate mid-20th century in which electricity has been only somewhat harnessed, the film depicts a chugging, sooty, clattery metropolis abounding with coal- and steam-powered contraptions.

headline: Exploring the Physical and Spiritual Relationship in a Four-Part Composition
abstract: “De Materie,” by the Dutch modernist composer Louis Andriessen, is directed by Heiner Goebbels in its American stage premiere at Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: The four-section opera “De Materie” by the Dutch modernist composer Louis Andriessen explores the relationship between matter and spirit. Heiner Goebbels directs what is billed as its American staged premiere, in the Park Avenue Armory’s Drill Hall, with visual elements including floating zeppelins.

headline: Chelsea Handler’s Netflix Talk Show to Debut in May
abstract: New episodes of Ms. Handler’s show, scheduled to premiere May 11, will run three times a week.
lead_paragraph: What will a topical talk show look like on Netflix, a streaming service that’s better known for releasing entire seasons of its content all at once and which has no programming schedule to speak of? Chelsea Handler offered a few clues on Wednesday about the ongoing Netflix series she’ll soon be hosting, presented as a handwritten memo to herself that she posted online.

headline: In Philadelphia, George Washington Slept Here — and Here
abstract: How many ways can you tell the story of the American Revolution? A new museum is confident it will find some more.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When walking the streets of the Old City area in Philadelphia, it’s easy to imagine being back in the late 18th century. A small 8-by-10-block section was where so many of the famous names of the period — George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Betsy Ross, John and Samuel Adams, Dolley and James Madison and, nearly everywhere, it seems, Ben Franklin — lived and socialized.

headline: Newark Schools to Test Pupils for Lead as Officials Cite Longstanding Problem
abstract: As many as 17,000 students may have been affected, but the immediate plan will be to offer testing to children who attend two early-childhood programs at schools where lead was detected in the water.
lead_paragraph: As they prepared to begin testing young children for lead poisoning this week, school officials in Newark on Wednesday acknowledged that water in the city’s schools had contained elevated levels of lead for years.

headline: Home Sweet Home Museum Changes Its Tune
abstract: Long billed as the birthplace of the lyricist for a popular Civil War-era song, a museum in East Hampton, N.Y., has set the record straight.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — For years, visitors to the Home Sweet Home museum, just a few blocks west of this village’s fancy shopping district, have been told that this 1750 saltbox was the birthplace of the actor and playwright John Howard Payne (1791-1852), and that it was the house he had in mind when he wrote the lyrics to what would become one of the most famous songs of the 19th century.

headline: Ex-President ‘Lula’ Joins Brazil’s Cabinet, Gaining Legal Shield

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — After the police raided his home and prosecutors sought his arrest, the former president of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, seemed destined to become the biggest figure caught in the widening corruption investigation upending Latin America’s largest country.

headline: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida Endorses Donald Trump
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida urged fellow Republicans to rally behind Donald J. Trump to focus on the general election. Mr. Scott made clear his rationale: that the party will rip itself to shreds trying to stop someone with a clear path to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida endorsed Donald J. Trump for president a day after the New York businessman won the state’s primary, and he urged fellow Republicans to rally behind him to focus on the general election.

headline: Samsung’s Smartphones Aren’t the Problem (Just Prune the Bad Apps)
abstract: Unlike its rival iPhone, Samsung burdens its devices with carrier bloatware and inferior apps. But this is easily remedied, just in time for the new Galaxy S7 models.
lead_paragraph: PITY the poor Samsung smartphone.

headline: On the Big Island, ‘Aloha’ Is a Way of Life
abstract: A laid-back, welcoming warmth came to characterize much of the Frugal Traveler’s visit to Hawaii — even when his rental car was hobbled by two flat tires.
lead_paragraph: Famously, the word “aloha” has several meanings. It’s often used, I found during my stay on the Big Island of Hawaii, as a noun loosely meaning a spirit of affection or compassion, one that has persevered through a complicated and sometimes painful history. Maintaining a tourist economy is a tricky dance between locals and visitors. Native Hawaiian families have the lowest mean income of all major ethnic groups in the state. Yet property is unaffordable for many, thanks to outside speculation. Nevertheless, as a visitor in Hilo I never felt resentment; only a laid-back, welcoming warmth wherever I went. That sense of aloha came to characterize much of my visit to Hawaii — even when my rental car was hobbled by two flat tires.

headline: How Garland Would Change Supreme Court
abstract: The New York Times reporter Adam Liptak discusses the nomination of Merrick B. Garland and why Republicans might block him.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reporter Adam Liptak discusses the nomination of Merrick B. Garland and why Republicans might block him.

headline: Syrian Kurds Hope to Establish a Federal Region in Country’s North
abstract: Such a move would fall well short of declaring independence but would most likely rile both the government and the main Arab-led opposition group.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian Kurdish parties are working on a plan to declare a federal region across much of northern Syria, several of their representatives said on Wednesday. They said their aim was to formalize the semiautonomous zone they have established during five years of war and to create a model for decentralized government throughout the country.

headline: At a New Dominican Port, Cruising With a Conscience
abstract: Forget snorkeling. Passengers on Carnival’s new Fathom line will visit schools and help make water filters on their shore excursions.
lead_paragraph: What first catches your eye as you descend into Puerto Plata are the majestic mountains looming over the roads. Next you will see gleaming waves that inspired the name of the province — plata means silver in Spanish.

headline: Washington Comes to Grips, Slowly, With Shutdown of Metro System
abstract: There was an unpredictable commute, but also relative calm, as the city completely shut down its subway system for a safety inspection on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Buses overflowed, bike lanes swelled and highways across Maryland and Virginia were stop-and-go as this city crawled its way through two elongated and unpredictable rush hours on Wednesday, brought on by a decision to shutter the region’s subway system for an emergency safety inspection.

headline: ISIS’ Industry of Rape: Our Reporters Answer Questions

lead_paragraph: An hourlong conversation included Rukmini Callimachi, a foreign correspondent for The Times who recently wrote about the Islamic State’s use of birth control to maintain its supply of sex slaves.

headline: Five Super-Cool Surfwear Labels From Hawaii
abstract: A crop of mostly thirtysomething locals is giving men something stylish to wear both on and off the beach.
lead_paragraph: The Hawaiians are usually given credit for having invented surfing, and yet until recently, surfwear — neon-splashed board shorts; baggy, logo-printed T-shirts — was usually made elsewhere. In the 1980s and ’90s, it was mostly produced by three Australian mega-brands: Quiksilver, Rip Curl and Billabong. Then, a few years ago, small labels like the New York-based Saturdays Surf and Pilgrim Surf + Supply reimagined what après-surf clothes should look and feel like, slimming down the cuts and upgrading the fabrics.

headline: The Battles of Wilmington, N.C. — in World War II, That Is
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A historic trail proposed for North Carolina would amplify the coastal city’s role in World War II.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, N.C. — This city has its share of museums and tourist attractions, including the Museum of the Bizarre (featuring a unicorn horn and a Sasquatch footprint); the Cape Fear Serpentarium (“Snakes! Exotic! Alive!”); and the popular Ghost Walk of Old Wilmington (“hear tales of ghostly occurrences”).

abstract: We may be obsessed with new gadgets, but we still cling to outdated items like turntables, film cameras and books.
lead_paragraph: For a glimpse of what teenagers are into these days, all you have to do is visit Abbot Kinney Boulevard in the Venice neighborhood of Los Angeles. On weekend nights, the half-mile shopping drag is packed with style-conscious kids who traipse past coffee shops, ice cream parlors and boutiques, often while taking selfies.

abstract: The Times asked longtime residents and recent arrivals in the country to share their experiences.
lead_paragraph: As Germany takes the lead in trying to stem a chaotic flow of migrants to Europe, it is also grappling with a challenge at home: how to integrate some of the  million migrants who arrived on the Continent last year.

headline: Some Senate Republicans Will Meet With Supreme Court Nominee
abstract: Two senators in tough re-election fights said they would meet with Judge Merrick B. Garland, unlike Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, insisted on Wednesday that Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s nominee for the Supreme Court, would not get a confirmation vote — or even a meeting with him — before Election Day, but a handful of other Republican senators said they would at least talk with Judge Garland when he came calling on Capitol Hill.

headline: All That Korean Art Is There for a Reason
abstract: The Korea Foundation has helped create permanent galleries at 18 American museums, part of a larger program to promote South Korea’s cultural offerings.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in December, the Arts of Korea Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was abuzz, as dignitaries from the South Korean government inspected the display, while members of the press watched. Then, Oh Seung-je, the director of the Korean Cultural Service of New York, and Daniel H. Weiss, the Met’s president, ceremonially signed a pact establishing a long-term partnership between the Met and South Korea’s Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism.

headline: Bancroft Prize Awarded to Books on Constitutional Convention and Native Americans
abstract: The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history, is awarded to three books.
lead_paragraph: A book on the 1787 Constitutional Convention and two books on the way encounters with Native Americans shaped the emerging American nation have won the Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.

headline: Eurovision Gets Even Better: Now, a Museum Exhibition
abstract: Visitors to Stockholm for the Eurovision Song Contest can also see an exhibition on the history of the competition at ABBA the Museum.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to this year’s Eurovision Song Contest in Stockholm will now have something to do in those long preshow hours. An interactive exhibition called “Good Evening, Europe!,” covering the history of the annual television competition, will open May 7, just before the start of the contest on May 10. (The finale is on May 14.)

headline: Images from “Ken. to be destroyed”
abstract: The artist and photographer Sara Davidmann shares pictures from her upcoming book, which honors her transgender uncle.
lead_paragraph: The artist and photographer Sara Davidmann shares pictures from her upcoming book, which honors her transgender uncle.

headline: Watch a Two-Week Museum Installation Process, in Just Two Minutes
abstract: A time-lapse video condenses the two weeks it took to assemble Rashid Johnson’s massive plant-covered sculpture, “Within Our Gates.”
lead_paragraph: When Rashid Johnson did the site inspection for his upcoming commission at the Garage Museum in Moscow, the Rem Koolhaas-designed museum was still incomplete. Now, almost a year after its opening, the New York-based artist is returning to the space for his first Russian solo show. His site-specific installation, “Within Our Gates,” is only the third commission to inhabit the museum’s airy atrium. “The lack of exhibition history presented a different set of challenges,” the artist says. “It was something that I looked forward to.”

headline: One Artist’s Quest to Honor Her Transgender Uncle
abstract: The photographer Sara Davidmann’s “Ken. To be destroyed” comes to Berlin, and to bookshelves.
lead_paragraph: “Growing up, I didn’t think about my family being extraordinary,” says the British artist and photographer Sara Davidmann. “But if I was to take myself out of the picture and to look at my family from the outside, it’s quite fascinating.” She first mentions her father, Manfred, a German-Jewish refugee who escaped Berlin for the U.K. via the Kindertransport. In Edinburgh, he met Davidmann’s mother, Audrey, an avid diarist and chronicler. (Later in life, she’d pin a tag to a particular cardigan in her closet as an “aide-mémoire”: It was, she wrote, “still wearable, but only open, over a dress.”) Her parents and Audrey’s sister, Hazel, account for three of the characters in Davidmann’s ongoing photo-based project, “Ken. To be destroyed.” The fourth player is Ken, Hazel’s husband and Davidmann’s uncle, an ophthalmic optician and ballroom dancer who came out as transgender in Scotland in the 1950s.

headline: An Afghan Bazaar Parachutes Into Washington
abstract: “Turquoise Mountain,” organized by the Sackler and Freer, imports rug weavers, jewelers, carpenters and other artisans into museum precincts to show off their crafts.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — This country’s arts and craft emporiums have long been deserted, given that few foreigners come here now, aside from soldiers and diplomats who are not allowed to go out and shop, and the odd aid worker or journalist who is. So if Americans are no longer going to Afghanistan, why not take Afghan artisans to America?

headline: Alma Thomas: Abstractions Inspired by a Firm Grasp of Reality
abstract: A retrospective of this painter is at the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College.
lead_paragraph: Alma Thomas (1891-1978) was born in Georgia, educated in Washington and worked as an art teacher in the public schools there for almost 40 years. During this time, she pursued a parallel career as a painter, participating in Lois Mailou Jones’s salon for African-American artists and studying with Jacob Kainen at American University.

headline: Kayla Itsines Is Winning Instagram Followers, One Ab Post at a Time
abstract: How a 24-year-old personal trainer from Australia became Instagram’s biggest fitness star.
lead_paragraph: You could say that Kayla Itsines has been in training for her current title, Instagram’s biggest fitness star, almost since birth. When she was a child and wanted to go anywhere — a friend’s, the playground, the beach — her father would tell her to do, say, 10 push-ups or 40 situps first.

headline: In ‘ESKASIZER,’ a Long Look at Flesh of All Ages
abstract: The video artists Andrea Lerner and Rosane Chamecki have created an installation in which four dancers are captured in extreme slow motion.
lead_paragraph: The Eskasizer machine, a relic of the 1950s, purported to do the all the work. Women intent on firming their bodies would strap themselves into its vibrating belt and let the inches melt off. Sadly, situps are more of a sure thing. But the vintage machine has inspired the choreographers and video artists Andrea Lerner and Rosane Chamecki — who collaborate as chameckilerner — to create “ESKASIZER,” an installation in which four dancers are captured in extreme slow-motion takes. Their skin, moving in waves, gradually transforms from rippling flesh into a more mysterious, unknowable entity; what starts out as a meditation on the female form gradually becomes a poetic look at skin and aging. On Sunday, March 20, at 3:30 p.m., the collaborators will host a discussion with other choreographers who work in film, including Jillian Peña. But spend time with the installation and its dancers, Gabri Christa, Hilary Clark, Jennifer Kjos and Sally Rhodes, who range in age from their 30s through their 60s. We never see their faces; their flesh has a will of its own.

headline: Trump’s Brain and U.S. Foreign Policy
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s latest answer to questions about his foreign policy team is horrifying.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, journalists have been asking Donald Trump, the Republican frontrunner for president, to name his foreign policy brain trust. Okay, it doesn’t have to be a panoply of knowledgeable people; how about even a handful?

headline: Trees Deal With Climate Change Better Than Expected

lead_paragraph: The bend-don’t-break adaptability of trees extends to handling climate change, according to a new study that says forests may be able to deal with hotter temperatures and contribute less carbon dioxide to the atmosphere than scientists previously thought.

headline: Video Shows Brazen Theft of Paintings From Verona Museum
abstract: Investigators said arrests were made in Moldova and Italy in the break-in last November.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian officials have arrested 12 people in connection with the brazen theft in November of 17 paintings, including works by Pisanello and Rubens, from a museum in Verona, the police said Wednesday.

headline: Fed Slows Down on Plans to Pursue Interest Rate Increases
abstract: While finding little domestic economic harm in recent market turmoil, policy makers expect to raise rates by just half a percentage point this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve has once again pared its plans for raising interest rates, citing the weakness of the global economy as a reason for greater caution about the prospects for domestic growth.

headline: Solving the Tully Monster’s Cold Case
abstract: A team of researches say they have solved the identity of a creature whose fossilized remains were uncovered more than half a century ago.
lead_paragraph: Since it was first uncovered more than a half a century ago, this kooky-looking creature known as the “Tully monster” has puzzled paleontologists who, frankly, could not make heads, tails or claws of its fossilized remains.

headline: Trump Rises
abstract: The Donald finds an extra five percent.
lead_paragraph: My insta-reaction to last night’s primaries focused on the defeat of Marco Rubio, but it’s worth saying something about the overall state of the race as well — and what I have to say, unfortunately for the anti-Trumpist cause, is that my analysis from eight days ago predicting a contested convention (and a not-Trump outcome) looks weaker than it did. The reason is straightforward: A week ago Trump was still averaging, as he’d averaged from the earliest contests onward, about 34 percent of the primary vote. But last night Trump won at least 39 percent of the vote in every state except Ohio, and even there, in his loss to John Kasich, he still came away with more than 35 percent. That five point boost is why he beat Ted Cruz in both Missouri and North Carolina: Cruz reached 40 percent in the former and the high 30s in the latter, which would have been enough to beat Trump in a lot of prior contests, from Michigan to Arkansas to Kentucky … but wasn’t enough to win this time around. And if that boost holds, if Trump’s new average is 40 percent, in a three-way race that could certainly open a path to 1,237 delegates; it’s still a path without a huge margin for error, but it makes his nomination much more likely than when he appeared to be stuck five points lower.

headline: Putin Warns Against Politicizing Doping Scandal
abstract: Russia’s president also criticized his nation’s sports officials for their handling of a scandal that has touched a number of the country’s athletes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday warned against politicizing the doping scandal that has touched a number of Russian athletes, and he criticized his nation’s sports officials for failing to take the issue seriously.

headline: Regulation Alone Will Not Change Bad Behavior on Wall St.

headline: Checklists and Tips to Help Streamline Spring Cleaning
abstract: It’s time for spring cleaning again, and some apps can help users stay organized while getting their homes in order.
lead_paragraph: SPRING is my favorite time of year. The weather improves, and it’s time to clean, sort and tidy up. O.K., I actually hate that last part. This year, however, I’m softening the blow with spring cleaning apps, starting with the simple but reliable Cleaning Checklist app.

headline: CBS Considers Selling Its U.S. Radio Business
abstract: A sale or other separation of the 117 AM/FM stations could generate up to $1.9 billion in gross proceeds, according to an investment bank.
lead_paragraph: The exit of CBS from the radio business looks in tune with the times. CBS, a $24 billion broadcaster, is considering a sale of its 117 stations in the United States, just as the Internet streaming service Pandora may be on the block. Both moves could make sense, given stiff competition from the likes of Spotify, waning advertising and other industry disruption. The trick will be to find buyers.

In reality, Mr. Dunn sought to help victims of abuse and advocated for transparency in communications.

lead_paragraph: Fashion month finally came to an end last week (or fashion 1.3 months, if you include men’s as well as women’s wear). It was a season of transition and self-examination, as designers posed questions about the point of the shows themselves, but certain trends stood out, both in style and substance, across the gender continuum. Vanessa Friedman, the women’s fashion critic of The New York Times, and Guy Trebay, the men’s wear critic, discuss the most notable of those trends and debate their significance.

Trump and Senator Ted Cruz are quietly directing their attention to a second, shadow election campaign — one that is out of sight, little understood but absolutely critical if Republicans arrive at their national convention with Mr. Trump short of a majority of delegates.

headline: A French Director on the Mash-up of Influences Behind His New Film
abstract: Arnaud Desplechin’s “My Golden Days” makes references to the work of Joyce, Yeats — and Desplechin himself.
lead_paragraph: “My Golden Days,” the latest film from the French director Arnaud Desplechin, is a constantly shifting catalogue of allusions to literature, film — even some of Desplechin’s previous work. Set mostly in the late 1980s, the coming-of-age film serves as an origin story for Desplechin’s 1996 film, “My Sex Life ... or How I Got Into an Argument.” The director revisits his characters Paul Dedalus and Esther — first played by Mathieu Amalric and Emmanuelle Devos — in their relationship as teenagers, but now uses an unknown cast that includes Quentin Dolmaire as Paul and Lou Roy-Lecollinet as his object of desire. The film is a referential collage, moving through a series of genres and incorporating a jukebox of dance-party pop songs and impressions of Desplechin’s eclectic cinematic taste.
