abstract: For after Lent (or before), Boiano Bakery in Mamaroneck and Red Barn Bakery in Irvington offer authentic confections to celebrate the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Even before Valentine’s Day, our local grocery installed an imposing wall of Easter candies: foil-wrapped Cadbury Creme eggs; Peeps in impossible shades of yellow, pink and blue; speckled malted milk balls made to mimic robins’ eggs — all the makings of an industrial sugar swoon.

headline: Three Iranian Women Use Art to Pierce Their Homeland’s Veil
abstract: Works by the artists, who now live in North America, are on display at the Hopper House in Nyack.
lead_paragraph: As Edward Hopper’s birthplace and primary residence until he was nearly 30, the Edward Hopper House Art Center promotes the idea that artists’ roots have an enduring influence on their creative development.

headline: Water is the Real Force Behind Breaking a Bottle With Your Bare Hands
abstract: St. Patrick’s Day introduces the possibility that glass shards will fly tonight. Fluid dynamics explain why a successful break is not an act of human strength.
lead_paragraph: St. Patrick’s Day introduces the possibility that a bottle will be broken tonight. If that happens, just know that a successful break is not an act of human strength, but rather a matter of harnessing the power of water. This is our GIF science lesson of the week.

headline: Dada Turns 100, and Still Astonishes, at Yale
abstract: An exhibition at the Yale Art Gallery explores the irreverent art movement that grew up in Europe after World War I.
lead_paragraph: “Dada is political.” “Dada conquers.” “Art is dead!” These are among the messages confronting visitors as they emerge from the elevator into “Everything Is Dada,” an exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery. The words are splashed across the wall in oversize uppercase lettering — or are they? Closer observation reveals that the wall is actually a slightly distorted mirror, and the statements, attributed to Max Ernst, George Grosz and other Dada artists, are printed backwards adjacent to the elevator. It is only as reflections that their meanings become legible.

headline: In ‘The Bronze,’ an Ex-Olympian Is Utterly Unbalanced
abstract: Melissa Rauch plays a foul-mouthed, sex-crazed former gymnast in this dark comedy about what happens after your career ends at 15.
lead_paragraph: Shiny leotards, corny music, bouncy pigtails and scary determination. When you think of a female gymnast, all those associations might come to mind. What doesn’t is a foul-mouthed, sex-crazed, allergy-medication-snorting adult woman with ample cleavage.

headline: Bridge Scandal Trial May Prevent a Trump-Christie Ticket
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The trial has now been pushed to September, putting it in prime time during the final months of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: One obvious theory behind Gov. Chris Christie’s surprise endorsement of Donald J. Trump in the Republican presidential race is that he wants to be Mr. Trump’s pick for vice president.

headline: At Hofstra, Printmaking From Dürer to Warhol and Beyond
abstract: Thirty pieces capture the evolution of an art form across five centuries.
lead_paragraph: What a difference 500 years make — in artistic styles, techniques and sensibilities.

headline: Review: ‘The Clan’ Presents a Sadist in a Benign Patriarch’s Clothing
abstract: This drama, by Pablo Trapero, depicts a father in 1980s Buenos Aires, who commits crimes as he colludes with Argentina’s military dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: “The Clan,” Pablo Trapero’s wrenching, exciting new film, could be described as an examination of the banality of evil. It’s the story, closely based on actual events, of an ostentatiously normal family involved in crimes enabled by a climate of political violence and repression.

headline: Review: For ‘Pee-wee’s Big Holiday,’ Walk Gingerly and Wear a Red Bow Tie
abstract: Pee-wee Herman (Paul Reubens) returns to picaresque road comedy in this movie on Netflix, produced by Mr. Reubens and Judd Apatow.
lead_paragraph: Like the Muppets and the Simpsons, Pee-wee Herman seems not to age. But in his new Netflix movie, “Pee-wee’s Big Holiday,” he does take things down a notch; he’s less frenetic and more reactive. Perhaps he knows that a lot of people watching this sweet, silly film will be in a mellower place than they were when “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” was on television more than a quarter-century ago.

headline: Tempers Flare in Brazil Over Intercepts of Calls by Ex-President ‘Lula’
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: An uproar accompanied the former leader’s swearing-in as President Dilma Rousseff’s chief of staff on Thursday and the release of recordings of him suggesting intimidation of investigators.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — “In Brazil, a poor man goes to jail when he steals,” a fiery left-wing congressman named Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said in 1988. “When a rich man steals, he becomes a minister.”

headline: A Woman’s Shot at the $20
abstract: Anything short of giving women a place of their own in the all-male pantheon of our paper money is an affront.
lead_paragraph: When we started “Women on 20s” a year ago to engage the nation in replacing Andrew Jackson with an iconic American woman on the $20 bill, we never imagined that Alexander Hamilton would be pleading for his life in a redesign of the $10 note. But now Lin-Manuel Miranda, the star who plays Hamilton in his own eponymous hit Broadway musical, is celebrating an assurance from Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew that Hamilton is safe. As Mr. Miranda tweeted to his followers, Lew told him, “You’re going to be very happy.” But will the redesign make women happy?

headline: Review: Flirting With Insights in ‘Sex With Strangers’ at George Street Playhouse
abstract: In the play, written by Laura Eason, two writers at a bed-and-breakfast have chemistry, but the most intriguing moments take place after the sex.
lead_paragraph: The most intriguing moments take place after the sex in “Sex With Strangers.” That’s partly the result of a script that saves its best writing until late in the play, and partly because this production, at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, sometimes struggles to find its groove.

headline: L’Herbier’s ‘L’Inhumaine’ Offers a Painterly Touch on a Silent Canvas
abstract: The director, an early French Modernist, enlisted the painter Fernand Léger in designing this Art Deco extravaganza from 1924.
lead_paragraph: The most self-consciously modernist French movie of 1924, lovingly restored on a new Flicker Alley Blu-ray, Marcel L’Herbier’s “L’Inhumaine” (“The Inhuman Woman”) is in some ways also the most old-fashioned — a super-stylized amalgam of mad science, stodgy acting and elaborate sets.

headline: Fed Lawyer Who Helped Bail Out, and Regulate, Wall St. Will Retire
abstract: Thomas C. Baxter Jr., who helped devise both Wall Street bailouts and enforcement actions against banks that broke the law, plans to leave the New York Fed in September.
lead_paragraph: Thomas C. Baxter Jr., a long-serving Federal Reserve lawyer who helped shape Wall Street bailouts during the financial crisis of 2008, is retiring from his post at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: BART Talks Back: Agency’s Twitter Account Responds to User Complaints
abstract: In an unusual move, BART described the system’s struggles with extreme candor. Some Twitter users applauded the frank responses; others parodied them.
lead_paragraph: For commuters in the San Francisco area, the announcement of delays Wednesday on the Bay Area Rapid Transit network from the struggling system’s Twitter account was no surprise.

headline: Review: ‘Thank You for Playing’ Is About Making ‘That Dragon, Cancer’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Cancer']
abstract: This documentary records the efforts of a video game programmer to create a game, “That Dragon, Cancer,” inspired by his son’s terminal illness.
lead_paragraph: As filmmaking has become technologically easier, more and more documentaries have sprung up that chronicle personal loss: a loved one’s struggle with cancer or dementia, for instance. “Thank You for Playing” isn’t as coherent and impactful as the best of these films, but it’s certainly unusual.

headline: Review: ‘The Program,’ a Docudrama on the Fall of Lance Armstrong
abstract: In this Stephen Frears film, Ben Foster plays Armstrong, the cyclist disgraced and stripped of victories after a doping scandal.
lead_paragraph: Two scenes in “The Program,” Stephen Frears’s patchy docudrama tracing the rise and fall of the disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong tell you all you need to know about this crude cinematic demolition job. In one, the Armstrong character (Ben Foster) studies himself in a mirror while rehearsing different versions of the statement, “I’ve never tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs.” No matter how he says it, the words ring false.

headline: Review: ‘A Space Program’ Adds Whimsy to a Mission to Mars
abstract: Van Neistat’s film is the record of the artist Tom Sachs’s installation that amused audiences at the Park Avenue Armory in 2012.
lead_paragraph: “The Martian,” Ridley Scott’s big-budget Hollywood adaptation of Andy Weir’s novel, gave a sense of how a state-of-the-art mission to the red planet might look. Now “A Space Program” offers a decidedly low-tech alternative.

headline: Review: ‘Everything Is Copy,’ a Son’s Tribute to Nora Ephron
abstract: Celebrities and family members discuss and honor Ephron’s tartness in this documentary from Jacob Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: Beaming and blunt in equal measure, “Everything Is Copy,” Jacob Bernstein’s gossipy tribute to his mother, the writer and director Nora Ephron, is bursting with so many fond and famous faces that you can imagine its subject swooning with delight — and then criticizing their makeup.

headline: Spotify Reaches Settlement With Publishers in Licensing Dispute
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music']
abstract: According to several people involved with the settlement on both sides, Spotify will pay over $20 million to settle the case.
lead_paragraph: Spotify will pay more than $20 million to music publishers to settle a long-running and complex dispute over licensing, according to an agreement announced on Thursday between the streaming service and the National Music Publishers’ Association, a trade group.

headline: Ad Wars Come to Arizona, Next Battleground in Republican Race
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign has reserved television airtime in Arizona, where the primary is Tuesday, and where a super PAC supporting Senator Ted Cruz and his campaign are also running or preparing to run ads.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign has reserved television airtime in Arizona, where primary voters will cast ballots on Tuesday, and where a super PAC supporting Senator Ted Cruz and his campaign are also running or preparing to run their own ads.

headline: ‘The Sellout’ Wins National Book Critics Circle’s Fiction Award
abstract: The Paul Beatty novel, and “Dreamland: The True Tale of America’s Opiate Epidemic,” a nonfiction title by Sam Quinones, were given the top prizes by the literary critics and editors’ group.
lead_paragraph: Paul Beatty’s novel “The Sellout,” a scorching satire that wrenches humor out of painful subjects like slavery, police violence and segregation, won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction on Thursday. The novel, which was widely praised by critics, features an unhinged social scientist and marijuana dealer who is taken before the Supreme Court for reintroducing segregation and owning a slave.

headline: Lawyer for Turing Said He Warned Against Drug Price Increase
abstract: The lawyer, Howard Dorfman, told a Senate panel that he told Martin Shkreli that the move would negatively affect Turing’s business and reputation.
lead_paragraph: The former general counsel of Turing Pharmaceuticals said on Thursday that he and other executives had repeatedly objected to a plan by Martin Shkreli, then chief executive, to impose a huge price increase on a decades-old drug.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bronze,’ a Former Gymnast Has Losing Ways
abstract: Melissa Rauch stars in this comedy about an Olympic medalist who is defined by her spitefulness and jealousy.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks back moviegoers were given an Olympic story, “Eddie the Eagle,” that made really, really sure the audience knew that its underdog hero was likable. Now comes a corrective of sorts: “The Bronze,” an Olympic-themed tale that goes way overboard in conveying that its main character is despicable.

headline: Review: In ‘The Birth of Sake,’ a Brew Made With Pride and Lots of Patience
abstract: Erik Shirai’s documentary opens a window into the unhurried and elaborate making of the Japanese liquor at a family-owned brewery.
lead_paragraph: Chronicling a season at a small family-owned brewery, Erik Shirai’s “The Birth of Sake” is an engrossing introduction to the traditional cultivation of the rice-based alcohol that is part of Japan’s cultural heritage. But the film’s true focus is an endangered way of life.

headline: Review: In ‘Ktown Cowboys,’ Men on the Prowl in Koreatown
abstract: Based on a popular web series, the film follows characters sampling various kinds of night life in Los Angeles as grown-up problems hover.
lead_paragraph: The latest project to prove that making a 10-minute webisode is nothing at all like making a feature film is “Ktown Cowboys,” a mess of a movie about five young men on the prowl in the Koreatown section of Los Angeles. They sample various forms of night life while grown-up problems bark at the door, and eventually bonding occurs, but the film doesn’t have the focus, pacing or plotting of the best of such bromance tales.

headline: TransCanada to Buy Columbia Pipeline Group in $10.2 Billion Deal
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The all-cash deal will make the Canadian company a major force in the distribution of natural gas produced in the northeastern United States.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — After failing to obtain approval for its Keystone XL oil sands pipeline, TransCanada said on Thursday that it would buy the Columbia Pipeline Group for $10.2 billion.

headline: Dr. Quentin D. Young, Public Health and Civil Rights Advocate, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: The doctor was a personal physician to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Barack Obama, and fought for universal health care.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Quentin D. Young, a tenacious advocate for public health care and social justice, and a personal physician to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Barack Obama when he lived in Chicago, died on March 7 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Accuracy Concerns on Testing Device for Blood-Thinning Drug
abstract: Thousands of reports say a device to measure the levels of warfarin with a drop of blood is malfunctioning, yet it remains on the market.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Gary Goldstein, a Florida internist, knew something was wrong with a blood-testing device in his office when, all of a sudden, it began giving out odd results.

headline: Review: In ‘Sweet Bean,’ a Delicacy Unites a Vendor and an Old Woman
abstract: A middle-aged Japanese cook who sells dorayaki from a stall without much enthusiasm awakens to life’s complexity when he takes on a much older assistant.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever wondered what became of the young Japanese actor who played the insouciant, too-cool-for-Elvis (he preferred Carl Perkins) rock-and-roll fan in Jim Jarmusch’s 1989 “Mystery Train” — well, Masatoshi Nagase, now nearly 50, doesn’t smirk even once in “Sweet Bean,” a new film directed by Naomi Kawase.

headline: Changing the Rules of the Women’s Game, With the Hope of Altering the Interest Level
abstract: At the college and professional levels, the women’s game is changing rules, adjusting playoff formats and taking advantage of prominent events in order to maintain and extend its audience.
lead_paragraph: Last spring in Indianapolis, the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball rules committee focused on ways to increase the sport’s appeal.

headline: Review: In ‘The Preppie Connection,’ Drug Smuggling at an Elite School
abstract: This film is inspired by events in 1984 at Choate Rosemary Hall in Connecticut, where a student was accused of smuggling cocaine to sell to classmates.
lead_paragraph: When the story broke in 1984 that a student at Choate Rosemary Hall had been accused of smuggling cocaine to sell to classmates at their elite Connecticut boarding school, it was shocking enough to make the national news.

headline: FIFA’s Financial Disclosures Show That Scandal Has Affected Its Bottom Line
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Company Reports', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: World soccer’s governing body spent $62 million on legal fees and $26 million on communications in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Caught up in international investigations and armed with top white-collar lawyers and consultants, FIFA made financial disclosures on Thursday that showed just how high the cost of scandal has been for world soccer’s governing body.

headline: Out of Race, Marco Rubio Returns to the Senate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After a disappointing end of his campaign for the Republican nomination, and with only 10 months left in his term, Senator Marco Rubio goes back to work at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He was once described, for better or worse, as the Republican Barack Obama — a fresh-faced first-term senator who just might walk away with his party’s presidential nomination. Instead, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida returned to his day job on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘The Brainwashing of My Dad’ Examines the Influence of Right-Wing News Media
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'News and News Media']
abstract: This documentary by Jen Senko shows how her father became what she considers a casualty of the most conservative elements of the media.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people, especially on the liberal side of the spectrum, will certainly identify with “The Brainwashing of My Dad,” Jen Senko’s documentary about how right-wing news programs, talk shows and Internet sites turned her once reasonable father into a raging embodiment of intolerance and suspicion. The film, though, feels as if it’s arriving late to its discoveries and, given the current political climate, as if it’s only scratching the surface.

headline: Beware the Upsets of March
abstract: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament began, and so did the upsets.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament began, and so did the upsets.

headline: As Hillary Clinton Sweeps States, One Group Resists: White Men
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: White men narrowly backed Hillary Clinton in 2008, but they are not getting behind her candidacy in force in major battleground states this year, rattling some Democrats.
lead_paragraph: White men narrowly backed Hillary Clinton in her 2008 race for president, but they are resisting her candidacy this time around in major battleground states, rattling some Democrats about her general-election strategy.

headline: Without Cares or Bogeys, Marc Leishman Thrives
abstract: Leishman’s bogey-free start at the Arnold Palmer Invitational was in contrast to last year, when, shortly after he missed the cut at this event, his wife fell gravely ill.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Australian Marc Leishman missed one green and did not find sand or water during his opening-round five-under-par 67 at the Bay Hill Club and Lodge on Thursday. If every round were so carefree, no one would suggest it was a misnomer to call golf a game.

headline: Review: In ‘The Confirmation,’ a Troubled Father and Tender Son Bond
abstract: This Bob Nelson character study stars Clive Owen as a troubled handyman who has more than stolen tools on his mind.
lead_paragraph: The pleasures are modest but rewarding in Bob Nelson’s character study “The Confirmation.” The story is seemingly simple: A handyman, Walt (Clive Owen), whose drinking cost him his marriage, has a weekend with his 8-year-old son, Anthony (Jaeden Lieberher), while his ex (Maria Bello) is on a church-sponsored couples retreat with her new man (Matthew Modine).

headline: Man Fatally Stabs Daughter’s Attacker in Harlem Subway Station
abstract: Herbert Burgess, 53, was selling MetroCard swipes when he got into an argument that ended in his death, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man who was selling MetroCard swipes at a subway station in Harlem was fatally stabbed by the father of a woman he had punched in the face, the police said on Thursday.

headline: Defense Secretary Calls Iranian Seizure of American Sailors ‘Outrageous’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On Thursday, Ashton B. Carter told the Senate Armed Services Committee that Iran’s actions in January may have violated international law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said on Thursday that Iran may have violated international law when it seized 10 American sailors in the Persian Gulf in January.

headline: Michigan Governor Tells Congress He Was Misled on Flint Water
abstract: Both Gov. Rick Snyder and Gina McCarthy, the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, were repeatedly pressed on their responsibility in the lead contamination scandal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Time and again, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan acknowledged in a tense congressional hearing Thursday that he had been aware of complaints about the drinking water in Flint, including from news reports his aides had emailed him. Yet he had accepted assurances, he said, that the problems were not severe.

headline: Review: ‘Take Me to the River’ Immerses a Teenager in Scandal at a Family Reunion
abstract: A gay California teenager who must closet his sexuality at a gathering in Nebraska suddenly finds himself a target of suspicion.
lead_paragraph: In Matt Sobel’s “Take Me to the River,” a gay California teenager becomes enmeshed in scandal during a family reunion in Nebraska. What looks like a coming-of-age premise, though, is upended by a dubious plot involving suspected sexual wrongdoing.

headline: Finally Back, Yale Will Stay Awhile After an Upset of Baylor
abstract: The 12th-seeded Bulldogs, making their first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance since 1962, made it a memorable one, stunning No. 5-seeded Baylor.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — James Jones, the Yale coach, walked across the floor, arms raised in triumph. He approached the Bulldogs fans in the stands at Dunkin’ Donuts Center and slammed his hands on the press table. Immediately behind him, the Ivy League player of the year, Justin Sears, lay on his back on the court, in equal parts frustration and elation.

headline: Port Authority Chief to Remain as Search for a Successor Continues
abstract: Patrick J. Foye had intended to step down as executive director at the end of March, but he was persuaded to stay until a new chief executive is picked.
lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Foye, the last executive director the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey expects to have, is not leaving at the end of the month after all.

headline: Where Merrick Garland Stands: A Close Look at His Judicial Record
abstract: Mr. Garland is known as an appeals court judge who respects Supreme Court precedent. His most charged cases, on national security and campaign finance, sometimes disappointed liberals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, has achieved a rare distinction in a polarized era. He has sat on a prominent appeals court for almost two decades, participated in thousands of cases, and yet earned praise from across the political spectrum.

headline: U.S. Service Members Punished for Strike on Hospital in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Defense Department has disciplined at least a dozen military personnel for their roles in an airstrike in October on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed 42 people, senior military officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department has disciplined at least a dozen military personnel for their roles in an airstrike in October on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed 42 people, senior military officials said, but they are not expected to face criminal charges.

headline: Shirley Temple’s Blue Diamond Ring Will Go Up for Auction
abstract: The 9.54-carat Fancy Deep Blue diamond ring she received from her father in 1940 has an estimate of $25 million to $35 million, at Sotheby’s Magnificent Jewels sale.
lead_paragraph: When Shirley Temple was around 12 and about to star in the 1940 film, “The Blue Bird,” she received a 9.54-carat Fancy Deep Blue diamond ring from her father that she kept until she died in 2014.

headline: Review: Iggy Pop and his ‘Post Pop Depression Tour’
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: His new album may be called “Post Pop Depression,” and he may hint that it’s his last, but at South by Southwest he was forceful and swaggering.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — An unruly life force battling the inevitability of decline and death. That’s the core of Iggy Pop’s new album, “Post Pop Depression” (Rekords Rekords/Loma Vista), which he has hinted may be his last. He’s not going quietly.

headline: Obama to Unseal Files on Argentina’s ‘Dirty War’
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: President Obama is moving to declassify records that could show what the United States knew about Argentina’s brutal crackdowns of the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is moving to declassify American military, intelligence and law enforcement records that could reveal what the United States government knew about Argentina’s brutal “dirty war” of the 1970s and ’80s, a senior adviser said on Thursday, hoping to pierce the shroud of secrecy that has surrounded a painful chapter in that country’s history.

headline: For Players, Classes Don’t End Just Because the Games Begin
abstract: Some student-athletes in the N.C.A.A. tournament take the student part of the description quite seriously.
lead_paragraph: It was a good day for smart kids at the N.C.A.A. tournament. For the future lawyers and doctors-in-training, for the future Wall Street executives and potential judges, for the soon-to-be leaders of science. For those overachievers — in this case, the student-athletes from Yale and Duke — and for their overachieving classmates who watched them win their first-round games.

headline: U.N. Officials Warned That Congolese Soldiers Were Linked to Rape
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Just months after troops from the Democratic Republic of Congo arrived on a peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic, allegations of sexual abuse began piling up.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — At least four senior United Nations officials warned of the risks of sending soldiers from the Democratic Republic of Congo on a peacekeeping mission to the neighboring Central African Republic when the idea arose in 2014. The soldiers had a history of using rape on the battlefield, the officials said. Within months of the soldiers’ arrival, allegations of sexual abuse began piling up against several of them.

headline: Review: ‘She Loves Me’ Is a Daydream of the Ordinary
abstract: The 1963 musical set in a 1930s perfume shop in Budapest has been rapturously revived by the Roundabout Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes vanilla ice cream can taste like sweet deliverance. Such is the discovery made by one Amalia Balash in the 1963 musical “She Loves Me” — which has been rapturously revived in a new production by the Roundabout Theater Company — when she receives a gift of this frozen confection from an unlikely suitor.

headline: Big Name in Guitars
abstract: Michael Wiesenberg beams us up.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Here’s a puzzle that’s truly themeless, with a paucity of tiny words, so I had to take my usual end-of-week approach of picking at factual clues to get it started. I knew RENOIR for 20A, and put ESTEE for 23A on autopilot (seems that there’s no other option for this oft-used clue, at least no 5-letter one). There were at least two more crossword chestnuts – ELOI and TBAR – that seem to get little use outside this realm, but that’s par for the course, I’d say. I also had ERNST Lubitsch and was pretty confident of VWS for 53D.

headline: Paul Ryan a Featured Guest Before Stop-Trump Donors
abstract: Representative Paul Ryan, the Republican House speaker who is the dreamed-of presidential candidate of Republican operatives hoping to stop Donald J. Trump, was a featured guest at a Florida dinner of leading donors.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul Ryan, the Republican House speaker who is the dreamed-of presidential candidate of many donors and Republican operatives hoping to stop Donald J. Trump, was a featured guest at a Florida dinner of party donors and strategists, an aide confirmed.

headline: Queens Teenager Arrested After Taking Loaded Gun to School, Police Say
abstract: The episode, involving a 15-year-old student at York Early College Academy in Jamaica, came two days after a fifth grader carried his grandfather’s loaded gun into another Queens school.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy was arrested on Thursday morning after taking a loaded gun to his high school in Queens, the police said, the second incident this week in which a student took a loaded gun to school.

headline: James Sheldon, Director, Dies at 95; Career Reflected TV’s Evolution
abstract: Over 40 years, he directed episodes of some 100 series in most every genre, including classic episodes of “The Twilight Zone” and “The Millionaire.”
lead_paragraph: James Sheldon, a versatile television director whose career spanned the industry’s first four decades and reflected the evolution of television programming, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Ted Cruz Plays to Fear of Immigrants in Arizona
abstract: An advertisement by the Cruz campaign features the father of a man who prosecutors say was killed by an illegal immigrant in Mesa, Ariz., last year.
lead_paragraph: Heading into Tuesday’s Arizona primary, Senator Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign has released a new ad, titled “Grant,” about a 21-year-old Mesa, Ariz., man who was killed last year, apparently by an illegal immigrant.

headline: Hilary Putnam, Giant of Modern Philosophy, Dies at 89
abstract: He was known for the breadth of his thinking, the vividness of his arguments and his penchant for self-questioning and willingness to change his mind.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Putnam, a Harvard philosopher whose influence ranged widely across many fields of thought, including mathematical logic, philosophy of mind and language, epistemology and metaphysics, died on March 13 at his home in Arlington, Mass. He was 89.

headline: Morocco Orders U.N. to Cut Staff in Disputed Western Sahara Territory
abstract: Reacting to comments from the U.N. leader, Morocco demanded the evacuation of 84 members of the organization’s mission in Western Sahara, where it has played a peacemaking role for 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Escalating an angry dispute with the leader of the United Nations, Morocco gave the organization a 72-hour deadline on Thursday to evacuate 84 members of its mission in the disputed Western Sahara territory.

headline: North Korea Fires Missile Into Sea, South Korea Says
abstract: The projectile, which appeared to be a medium-range ballistic missile, crashed into the waters off North Korea’s east coast.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea flouted United Nations resolutions on Friday by firing what appeared to be a medium-range ballistic missile into the sea between the Korean Peninsula and Japan, the South Korean military said.

headline: Man Suspected of Killing Roommate at Harlem Shelter Is Found Dead, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homeless Persons', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A body found in the Hudson River is thought to be that of Anthony White, 21, who was accused of killing a former teacher, Deven Black, 62, in January.
lead_paragraph: A citywide manhunt for a 21-year-old man who the police said fatally stabbed his 62-year-old roommate at a homeless shelter in Harlem came to an end this week after a body believed to be the suspect’s was found in the Hudson River.

headline: Corruption Scandals in Brazil Reach All the Way to the Top
abstract: Brazil is in the midst of its deepest political crisis in decades, with its president facing impeachment proceedings and many in Congress facing criminal or corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: Brazil is in the midst of its deepest political crisis in decades, with its president facing impeachment proceedings and many in Congress facing criminal or corruption charges.

headline: With Few Public Toilets, New York Has No Place to Go if You Have to Go
abstract: A decade ago, 20 self-cleaning, practically indestructible facilities were in a Queens warehouse, awaiting placement. Fifteen are still there.
lead_paragraph: Just before noon on Thursday, James Browar pushed out of a Starbucks on Eighth Avenue near Times Square, laden with news that was simultaneously getting worse and more urgent by the minute.

headline: Biden Names Leader for ‘Moonshot’ Cancer Campaign
abstract: Greg Simon, an experienced corporate executive who is battling cancer himself, will lead the initiative launched by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will announce on Friday a corporate executive to lead his “moonshot” cancer initiative, selecting an expert who began work in 2003 to lower barriers between science and cures.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Too Much’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing presents Tyler Ford’s poem “Too Much” alongside a 2015 Op-Ed column, “From Caitlyn Jenner to a Brooklyn High School,” by Nicholas Kristof.
lead_paragraph: March’s Poetry Pairing features Tyler Ford’s poem “Too Much” and a 2015 Op-Ed column, “From Caitlyn Jenner to a Brooklyn High School,” by Nicholas Kristof.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | schematic
abstract: This word has appeared in 28 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: schematic • \ski-ˈma-tik\ • adjective and noun

headline: Genocide and the Islamic State
keywords: ['Editorials', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The designation of the group’s actions as genocide puts a spotlight on the problems of Syrian refugees and other survivors of its brutal campaign.

To those it has now added the Islamic State’s rampage in Iraq and Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Thursday.

headline: The N.F.L. Comes Clean on Concussions

headline: Sven Lindblad Takes Passengers to the Wild Places
abstract: The head of Lindblad Expeditions on finding rare natural wonders by ship and promoting conservation consciousness.
lead_paragraph: In 1958, Lars-Eric Lindblad founded Lindblad Travel with a mission to explore the world; that included sending the first expedition cruise to Antarctica in 1966. In the 50 years since, Lindblad also pioneered cruising in the Galápagos and the Seychelles. Lars-Eric’s son, Sven Lindblad, spent six years as a photographer and filmmaker in East Africa before joining his father’s company and making it entirely ship-based under the name Lindblad Expeditions; he is its chief executive. Between a trip to Monaco for a conservation meeting and one to Cuba to develop a new cruise, Mr. Lindblad, 65, spoke about expedition cruising. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with him.

abstract: Michael B. Curry says he experienced the “given-ness of racism” in the church as a young man. He sees a connection between bigotry that blacks faced and the opposition to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: When Michael B. Curry was installed in November as the 27th presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, he spoke of racial reconciliation and finding new ways to spread the teachings of Jesus. His appointment as the first African-American leader of a predominantly white Protestant church that has long been associated with the American elite elevated the voice of a preacher who had focused his ministry on racial justice, an issue that is now playing out in the presidential campaign.

headline: I Love the U.N., but It Is Failing

abstract: I joined to protect the helpless from rape and murder. I never dreamed our own forces would be the rapists and murderers.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE worked for the United Nations for most of the last three decades. I was a human rights officer in Haiti in the 1990s and served in the former Yugoslavia during the Srebrenica genocide. I helped lead the response to the Indian Ocean tsunami and the Haitian earthquake, planned the mission to eliminate Syrian chemical weapons, and most recently led the Ebola mission in West Africa. I care deeply for the principles the United Nations is designed to uphold.

headline: U.N. Condemns Airstrikes That Killed 106 in Yemen
abstract: A Saudi-led coalition carried out the attacks, which appear to be the deadliest yet in its yearlong intervention in the civil war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The top United Nations human rights official condemned the Saudi-led coalition fighting in Yemen on Friday, citing repeated attacks on civilian targets in airstrikes, including an attack on a crowded village market this week that killed 106 people.

headline: Apple’s Engineers, if Defiant, Would be in Sync With Ethics Code
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Privacy', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: If Apple’s employees refused to help the F.B.I. access the contents of an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino shooters, their decision would be supported by the Association for Computing Machinery.
lead_paragraph: If Apple employees refused to perform the software engineering tasks that would be necessary to provide the F.B.I. with access to the contents of an iPhone used by one of the shooters in the December mass killing in San Bernardino, Calif., their decision would be explicitly supported by the code of ethics of a professional organization called the Association for Computing Machinery.

headline: Cracking the Mystery of the Missing iTunes Files
abstract: Apple’s iTunes software cannot play song files that have been moved or deleted, but the program tells you where to look for the lost tracks.
lead_paragraph: Q. What do I do when I try to play a track in iTunes and I get a message that says, “the song could not be used because the original file could not be found,” and it asks me if I’d like to locate it?

headline: Obama Says a Garland Rebuff Would Damage Supreme Court
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court to help enhance the reputation of an institution whose public approval has dropped substantially in this era of heightened political polarization, he said in an interview with National Public Radio.

headline: 2007-2016 | The Rosenthal Era in the Editorial Department
abstract: Andrew Rosenthal, son of a famed executive editor, was steeped in Times tradition but never bound by it as editor of the editorial page.
lead_paragraph: On the 13th floor of The New York Times building is a very exclusive portrait gallery.

headline: Claims of Age Bias Rise, but Standards of Proof Are High
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Age, Chronological', 'Retirement', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Even though a law meant to protect older workers has existed since 1967, proving discrimination has since been made tougher.
lead_paragraph: Julianne Taaffe and Kathryn Moon had been teaching English language skills to foreign students for decades at Ohio State University when they and their co-workers were jolted by a particularly blunt email.

headline: How to Fight Age Discrimination
abstract: Staying aware of developments in your field, among other steps, can help stave off bias, but if you still feel you are being treated unfairly, here’s what to do.
lead_paragraph: Age discrimination can happen to anybody, but it is  difficult to prove.

headline: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Is Captured in Brussels
abstract: Mr. Abdeslam had evaded the authorities for four months; his fingerprint was found in a residence raided by the police this week.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — He traveled back to Belgium unrecognized and unchallenged the day after the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris. His fingerprints were found in two apartments in Brussels in subsequent months, but he kept eluding the police dragnet, amid speculation that he might have escaped to Syria.

headline: Keri Russell Discusses ‘The Americans,’ Her Pregnancy and Life at 40
abstract: Ms. Russell and her onscreen husband, Matthew Rhys, star in this cold-war drama, which is back for Season 4 on FX.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough being a working mother, in real life or on television. Consider Keri Russell, who on a recent springlike day was at home with a fever — her children’s sniffles and the stress of shooting nine months into her pregnancy having led to what she laughingly called “the final takedown.”

headline: Shepherds’ Accountability When The Flock Is Abused
abstract: An indictment in Pennsylvania underscores the Catholic Church hierarchy’s failure to track abuse cover-ups.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, as a national scandal raged over the rape and molestation of school children by hundreds of Catholic priests, a panel of leading laity appointed by the national hierarchy to look into church responsibility candidly warned “there must be consequences” for the bishops who led years of cover-up. The bishops’ marked failure to follow through since by investigating fellow superiors was brought home this month in a scathing grand jury report in Pennsylvania. It found at least 50 priests and other church employees sexually molested hundreds of children in central Pennsylvania parishes for over four decades while church officials and some civil authorities knew but worked to conceal the crimes.

headline: ‘Ramones’: The Story Behind a Debut Album From Punk Pioneers
abstract: The producer Craig Leon, the manager Danny Fields and others reflect on the 1976 creation of the Ramones’ first album and its legacy.
lead_paragraph: The Ramones’ self-titled first album came out in April 1976, and by sales standards alone it was a flop, reaching only No. 111 on the Billboard chart.

headline: Making Luncheon Magazine
abstract: Frances von Hofmannsthal and Thomas Persson bring T into their London studio, where their new biannual art and culture publication is made.
lead_paragraph: Frances von Hofmannsthal and Thomas Persson bring T into their London studio, where their new biannual art and culture publication is made.

headline: Theology Schools, Facing Lean Times, Look to One Another and the Web
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Religion and Belief', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The institutions are breaking with tradition in order to survive, either merging, joining across religions or embracing distance learning.
lead_paragraph: CLAREMONT, Calif. — If you are looking for a manicured lawn and a gracious quadrangle — Gothic maybe, or redbrick with shutters on the windows — you will be disappointed.

headline: A New Magazine Marries Art, Style, Culture — and Lunch
abstract: T visited the London studio where Luncheon, which makes its debut this weekend at the new Dover Street Market in Haymarket, is made.
lead_paragraph: In an airy, light-filled space in the Rochelle School in London, what was once a charming Victorian classroom today serves as the office of Luncheon Magazine, a fresh-off-the-press independent title with a self-professed appetite for style and culture. Clues to the pedigree of its editors-in-chief Frances von Hofmannsthal and Thomas Persson are scattered throughout the Shoreditch studio. On a vast radiator lean a triptych of framed black-and-white prints: a shot of the photographer Paolo Roversi’s studio (where von Hofmannsthal served as a photographic assistant for some five years), a "Cigarettes" series by Irving Penn and an image of Leigh Bowery taken between portrait sittings with Lucien Freud. A copy of "The Private Life of Greta Garbo" sits on a desk with a handwritten note from the fashion designer Erdem Moralioglu (“He saw it and thought of me,” quips Persson).

headline: What’s Wrong With Latin American Early Education
abstract: Instead of building more day care centers, invest in cost-effective home visit programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in the 1980s, a group of social workers in Jamaica visited low-income homes one hour a week for two years, bearing age-appropriate toys for the kids and advice on child rearing for the parents. Researchers tracked the outcomes, and a generation later, the results are in.

headline: East Coast to Usher In Spring ... With a Snowstorm
abstract: Don’t blame the weather forecasters. They’re just doing their jobs.
lead_paragraph: You’ve got to be kidding.

keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Work done by women pays less because women do it, research shows.
lead_paragraph: Women’s median annual earnings stubbornly remain about 20 percent below men’s. Why is progress stalling?

headline: E.P.A. Faces Bigger Tasks, Smaller Budgets and Louder Critics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Clean Water Act', 'Clean Air Act']
abstract: Under attack by both parties, the agency is facing a tumultuous election year, with more work, fewer resources and its very existence at stake.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under fierce attack from the political right, and with even some Democrats questioning its competence, the Environmental Protection Agency is facing a tumultuous election year — with rising regulatory responsibilities, falling budgets and its very existence at stake.

headline: Texas Abortion Law Has Women Waiting Longer, and Paying More
abstract: Clinics and patients experience the effects of a 2013 state law that is at the center of a case being considered by the United States Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — When Amy found out around Christmas that she was pregnant, she wasted no time seeking an abortion. Her husband had just lost his job and the couple had been kicked out of their house, forcing their family of five to move in with his parents.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: A recommended read, baked fish and chips and more for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Miso Soup Delivers Deep Weeknight Flavor
abstract: A giant bowl of this vegetarian dish can make for a satisfying supper.
lead_paragraph: Here is a recipe for a fast meal: Put one teaspoon of miso in a mug and dissolve with a tiny bit of hot water to make a sort of loose paste. Add a squeeze of lime juice and fill the mug to the top with hot water from the kettle. Stir. You have just made the simplest form of miso soup, and a pretty tasty one.

headline: English Opera Reaches Labor Deal With Chorus
abstract: The deal with Equity, the musicians’ union, includes a pay cut and having chorus members move to nine-month contracts from yearlong ones.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The English National Opera announced Friday that it had reached an agreement with chorus members, who had earlier voted to strike on Friday evening over a proposal to cut salaries by around 25 percent and lay off four of the group’s 44 members.

headline: Paola Santarelli’s Dazzling Marble Collection
abstract: For Santarelli, one of the foremost private collectors in the world, the medium is the soul of Western civilization.
lead_paragraph: For Santarelli, one of the foremost private collectors in the world, the medium is the soul of Western civilization.

abstract: Outside Rome, Paola Santarelli’s house is a monument to the medium — which she believes is the soul of Western civilization.
lead_paragraph: Outside Rome, Paola Santarelli’s house is a monument to the medium — which she believes is the soul of Western civilization.

headline: Guido Westerwelle Dies at 54; German Foreign Minister Opposed Libya Incursion
abstract: A former leader of the Free Democratic Party, Mr. Westerwelle became the highest-ranking openly gay person in the German government.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Guido Westerwelle, who served as Germany’s first openly gay foreign minister and kept his country out of NATO’s intervention in Libya, died on Friday in Cologne. He was 54.

headline: From Kefir to ‘Cucamelons,’ Sampling the Next Wave of Natural Foods
keywords: ['Organic Foods and Products', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Sustainable Living', 'Food']
abstract: A guided tour of the Natural Products Expo West trade show in California offers insight into where natural and organic food trends are headed.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — If you had any remaining doubts about the popularity of organic and so-called natural foods, a visit to the Anaheim Convention Center here last week would have dispelled them. Inside its five vast halls, more than 3,000 exhibitors showed their wares to some 77,000 retailers, suppliers, investors and curiosity-seekers as part of the Natural Products Expo West, known among foodies as simply Expo West. Organic kefir, anyone?

headline: Thirteen Contemporary Artists Portray Their Own Children
abstract: Carrie Mae Weems, Nick Waplington and more share their never-before-published work with T.
lead_paragraph: As a young person learning her trade, the French artist Élisabeth Louise Vigée Le Brun (1755-1842) was trained exclusively in portraiture, a properly feminine pursuit. Vigée Le Brun then became a society portraitist, and for more than a century was looked down upon for that. (There’s a drawback to having your lucky break be a commissioned painting of Marie Antoinette.) At first Vigée Le Brun’s stepfather made off with much of her earnings; she then married a charismatic man of taste who again and again spent her money on finery, though he did successfully market Vigée Le Brun as an artist, and arranged high fees for her work. Some said the fees were too high, that she was not that good; others said her work was too good to have actually been done by a woman, that it must in fact have been done by a man, maybe a lover. Perhaps the most predictable of the gripes directed against Vigée Le Brun was Simone de Beauvoir’s: In dismissing a series of female artists, she wrote disparagingly of Vigée Le Brun that she ‘‘never wearied of putting her smiling maternity on her canvases,’’ even though only two of the extant Vigée Le Brun portraits are of herself with her daughter. Admittedly, they are particularly beautiful.

headline: Chappatte on the Supreme Court Nomination
abstract: President Obama selected Merrick B. Garland, a centrist appellate judge, who has drawn praise from members of both parties.
lead_paragraph: President Obama nominated Merrick B. Garland, a centrist appellate judge, who has drawn praise from members of both parties.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Into the Woods With the Fashion Institute of Technology
abstract: “Fairy Tale Fashion,” showing at the Museum at FIT, displays designer interpretations from children’s literature that are both beautiful and sinister.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Sloane Crosley
abstract: The writer shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer Sloane Crosley, whose new novel, “The Clasp,” is out now. She shares her list exclusively with T. (One Grand also currently has an installation at the Blue Bottle Café at the Platform in Culver City, Los Angeles.)

headline: A Farewell to the Dog Who Helped Him Off the Streets
abstract: In 2005, when Raymond Goynes first met Sonja, he was living in a refrigerator box in the entranceway of a building down the block.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Goynes went uptown to see Sonja one last time on March 8, a sunny Tuesday morning.

lead_paragraph: The writer and director Mike Birbiglia discusses his film about a New York improv group.

headline: When an Analyst Has a Stake in the Stock He Picks
abstract: Buried in the footnotes of an analyst’s recommendation to buy Tempur Sealy shares is a disclosure that he may receive compensation from the company.
lead_paragraph: File this column under: Why It Pays to Read the Footnotes.

headline: 1966: U.S. and Allies Back NATO
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. and its Atlantic allies back NATO, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The United States and 13 of its Atlantic allies solemnly declared today [March 18] that NATO is ‘‘essential’’ to their security and will continue. This was the first formal answer of all the other members of the alliance to President de Gaulle’s campaign to break up NATO and get it out of France.

headline: Some of Jonathan Anderson’s Favorite Photographs, Now on T-Shirts
abstract: The designer partnered with Ian David Baker on a clothing collection (and a book).
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Anderson first came across snapshots by the cult photographer Ian David Baker “in a very small magazine booklet that I bought a long time ago,” he says. The designer found “incredible strength and delicacy” in the stark black-and-white images, including intimate portraits of British boys at home and action scenes of Pride-goers parading through London. Last year, he and Baker, who is known for chronicling youth culture in the ’80s (and for his “Cruising Camera” spreads in the gay pin-up magazine Mister), partnered to sell prints on Anderson’s website.

headline: In ‘Daredevil,’ on Netflix, the Punisher Stirs Up the Gangs
abstract: In Season 2, a gun-happy former soldier threatens the residents of Hell’s Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The second season of “Daredevil” arrived on Netflix on Friday less than a year after Season 1, but it already feels as if it’s falling behind in the Marvel antihero race. “Jessica Jones,” another Netflix series based on a Marvel comics character, and the Marvel film “Deadpool” came along in the meantime and seduced audiences and critics with moody noir fatalism and wisecracking, fourth-wall-breaking nihilism. “Daredevil,” with its sincerity and the broad comic-book strokes of its storytelling, seems square in comparison.

headline: Popcast: Gwen Stefani Returns
abstract: Ben Ratliff, Times music critic and Caryn Ganz, Times pop music editor, discuss the singer’s new album.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff, Times music critic and Caryn Ganz, Times pop music editor, discuss the singer’s new album.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

headline: Poland’s Constitutional Crisis
abstract: The government’s attempt to weaken the constitutional tribunal is an assault on Polish democracy.
lead_paragraph: One tragedy in Poland’s gathering constitutional crisis is that it reveals the degree to which the right-wing leaders there don’t get the basics of democracy. In openly defying a ruling of the Constitutional Tribunal, the Polish high court, the ruling Law and Justice Party effectively set itself above the law in its march to authoritarian rule, ignoring all appeals, warnings and formal opinions from the United States, the European Union, international human rights organizations and its own opposition.

headline: Wave of Indigenous Suicides Leaves Canadian Town Appealing for Help
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Indigenous People']
abstract: Six people have killed themselves and over 140 have attempted suicide or expressed a desire to do it in the Cree Indian community of Cross Lake, setting off a public health crisis.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of an indigenous community in rural Canada have appealed to national authorities for help after a wave of suicides and attempted suicides set off a public health crisis in their remote town and revived a painful conversation about the relationship between the government and its native communities.

headline: Been There, Haven’t Done That
abstract: The poet Eileen Myles, who ran for the presidency in 1992 as a write-in candidate, is one of many women who have sought the country’s highest office.
lead_paragraph: March is Women’s History Month, and although the United States has never elected a woman as president, it hasn’t been for lack of trying — at least, that is, on the part of the women running for office. As the historian Ellen Fitzpatrick points out in “The Highest Glass Ceiling,” reviewed by Rebecca Traister this week, “more than 200 women have sought, been nominated, or received votes” for the presidency since the late 19th century. One of them was the poet Eileen Myles, who ran in 1992 as a write-in candidate. In a letter announcing her candidacy, Myles introduced herself (a “41-year-old American, a female, a lesbian, from a working-class background, a poet, performer and writer”) and promised to write all her own speeches in a campaign of “total disclosure”: “What you see is what you get.”

abstract: Fantasy and the familiar overlap in stories that conjure worlds of mystery and menace.
lead_paragraph: WHAT IS NOT YOURS IS NOT YOURSStoriesBy Helen Oyeyemi325 pp. Riverhead Books. $27.

lead_paragraph: Sitting in a Zen-inspired studio in a converted school building on the Lower East Side, the Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang bemoaned how his native country’s art is often squeezed between pronouncements of record auction prices and denouncements of China’s one-party political system when it is presented in the United States and to some extent Europe.

headline: Two Simple Techniques That Bring Out the Best in Cauliflower
abstract: Grilling and pickling adds a punch to this spring stew.
lead_paragraph: Winter isn’t coming, it’s going, but the supermarkets are still loaded with cauliflower, and that’s a depressing prospect. Some people love this albino broccoli, other people hate it, but no one thinks it’s very exciting.

headline: Scorsese, De Niro and Co-Stars Reunite for ‘Taxi Driver’ Screening
abstract: At the Tribeca Film Festival, the live conversation will include Jodie Foster and Cybill Shepherd.
lead_paragraph: “You talkin’ to me? Well I’m the only one here,” Robert De Niro, playing Travis Bickle, famously riffs in the mirror in “Taxi Driver.” Next month, many more will be listening when Mr. De Niro reunites with that 1976 film’s director, Martin Scorsese, its writer, Paul Schrader, and its co-stars Jodie Foster and Cybill Shepherd for a live conversation as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced on Friday.

headline: First Woman Nominated to Lead U.S. Combatant Command
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The White House is nominating Gen. Lori Robinson to lead all military forces in North America, under the United States Northern Command.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House will nominate Gen. Lori J. Robinson of the Air Force to lead all military forces in North America, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Friday. If confirmed by the Senate, General Robinson will become the first woman to head one of the United States combatant commands.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Most of the buzz around Padma Lakshmi’s new memoir, No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has centered on her ill-fated marriage to Salman Rushdie.
lead_paragraph: Heartburn: After two cookbooks and 11 seasons as the host of “Top Chef” on Bravo, Padma Lakshmi has earned the right to call herself a food expert. But that doesn’t mean her relatives in India want her (or for that matter her aunt Neela, who’s like a sister to Lakshmi) to cook for them. “To this day,” she writes in her memoir, “Love, Loss, and What We Ate” — new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list — “the elder women of my household in Chennai still regard Neela or me with suspicion whenever we enter the kitchen to make anything other than tea.”

headline: Linwood Barclay’s ‘Far From True,’ and More
abstract: In “Far From True,” a drive-in movie theater’s four-story screen collapses, crushing two cars in the front row.
lead_paragraph: Miss Marple’s St. Mary Mead and Jessica Fletcher’s Cabot Cove are cautionary examples of quaint little villages that will eventually run out of murderers and victims. Promise Falls, one of the upstate New York hamlets where Linwood Barclay sets many of his books, is already dangerously close to losing its tax base. FAR FROM TRUE (New American Library, $27) continues to thin out the populace, but in a strikingly original way. A local landmark, the Constellation Drive-In Theater, is folding forever, and on its last, nostalgic night of business the four-story movie screen suddenly collapses, crushing two cars in the front row.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s march toward the Republican presidential nomination has sent shock waves through American politics and, as he continued gobbling up delegates this week, the rest of the world has started quivering, too.

lead_paragraph: As the 2016 campaign limps through the primary season toward the national conventions, there are two mostly imaginary story lines that never fail to delight and amuse, even if they don’t teach much.

headline: Former Affymetrix Executives Seek to Break Up Deal With Own Bid
abstract: The offer to buy Affymetrix, a maker of genetic analysis technology, for $1.5 billion tops an existing takeover proposal by Thermo Fisher Scientific.
lead_paragraph: Months after Affymetrix, a maker of advanced genetic analysis technology, agreed to sell itself for $1.3 billion, some of the company’s former executives want to disrupt that deal — with the help of a Chinese financial backer.

headline: Stroller Valet Service at a Park Slope Condo
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Baby Carriages, Strollers and Carriers', 'Condominiums', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Developers of a condo at 251 First Street, Brooklyn, hope stroller storage and valet service will attract young families.
lead_paragraph: Parents of young children rely on their strollers as if they were extensions of themselves. The stroller not only serves as a child’s second home, it is also used as a grocery cart, a cup holder and a coat rack. But many are bulky and hard to store. They gobble space when parked by the doorway, or, to the dismay of those without children, in the hallways of residential buildings.

headline: The Fashion News to Know This Week
abstract: A “Pablo” pop-up, the CFDA Awards nominees and Nike’s self-lacing sneakers.
lead_paragraph: The usual suspects

headline: A $12.2 Million Condo for Katie Couric
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The news anchor and her husband of almost two years, the financier John P. Molner, buy a home on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Katie Couric and her husband of almost two years, the financier John P. Molner, bought an apartment on the entire 10th floor of 151 East 78th Street, a new limestone and brick condominium on the Upper East Side. At $12,168,087.50, the transaction was one of the most expensive sales of the week, according to city records.

headline: No Texts, Please, We’re Meditating
abstract: Increasing numbers of harried New Yorkers are gathering to close their eyes and just breathe.
lead_paragraph: When a photo of a wall covered in lush green foliage showed up on Grace Clarke’s Instagram feed, she felt an immediate urge to track it down. Stressed out and headed to a meeting at Madewell, where she works as a social media copy editor, Ms. Clarke saw that the wall’s location was on East Eighth Street in Manhattan at a meditation studio called MNDFL, which opened in November.

headline: Mike Birbiglia Discusses ‘Don’t Think Twice’ at SXSW
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Movies']
abstract: The writer and director talks about his film about a troupe of improv performers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — It’s a busy year for Mike Birbiglia. The comedian is currently onstage in New York in the one-man show “Thank God for Jokes.” But he took a short break from it earlier this week for a visit here to unveil a new movie, “Don’t Think Twice,” in which he acts, and which he wrote and directed. That film follows a troupe of improv performers through their lives on and off the stage. The cast includes Keegan-Michael Key and Gillian Jacobs (as a couple who are part of the troupe), as well as Chris Gethard, Tami Sagher and Kate Micucci. In this video, Mr. Birbiglia speaks about the film and how he constructed its improv scenes.

headline: A Park Avenue Duplex for $22.5 Million
abstract: A palatial duplex at 720 Park Avenue, a neo-Georgian building designed by Rosario Candela in the late 1920s, is about to enter the market.
lead_paragraph: The president of Vendome Press, a publishing house specializing in illustrated art and lifestyle books, is about to place on the market his longtime family home: a sprawling duplex at 720 Park Avenue, a neo-Georgian architectural gem designed by Rosario Candela in the late 1920s.

headline: Alumni Discover Yale’s Basketball Team (and They’re Charmed)
abstract: With Old Eli doing well in the N.C.A.A. tournament, Yale graduates are getting caught up in this whole March foolishness thing.
lead_paragraph: Elation and confusion are an unusual combination for victorious sports fans. But in New Haven and throughout the broader Yale community, the “We won!” euphoria of winning an N.C.A.A. tournament basketball game on Thursday quickly gave way to, “What did we win, exactly?” and “Can someone explain why this basketball game was so important?”

headline: Defense Department Redefines Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Dictionaries']
abstract: The Department of Defense has updated the definition of climate change in its homegrown dictionary.
lead_paragraph: So what does “climate change” mean, exactly?

headline: Popcast: Gwen Stefani Returns
abstract: The pop superstar rebounds from a breakup and rediscovers her first love: songwriting.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

headline: Gwen Stefani on Spirituality, Insecurity, Pharrell and ‘Truth’
abstract: Ms. Stefani speaks candidly (and plentifully) about what led her to make her most personal album yet — “This Is What the Truth Feels Like.”
lead_paragraph: In the 10 years since Gwen Stefani last released a solo album, she has had two sons, returned to No Doubt, become a TV personality and watched as her life “was literally blown up.” In an interview at her Beverly Hills home for an in-depth feature article, Ms. Stefani, 46, spoke candidly (and plentifully) about the circumstances that led her to make her most personal album yet — “This Is What the Truth Feels Like” (Interscope), out Friday — and how spirituality and the guidance of Pharrell Williams have shaped her artistic process. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Sumner Redstone’s Medical Records to Stay Private, Judge Rules
abstract: But some court documents will be made public, including emails. The ailing media mogul has been involved in a court battle over his mental competence.
lead_paragraph: The medical records of the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone will remain confidential, but some other court documents, including emails written by his nurses and a letter from Mr. Redstone to his daughter, Shari, will be made public, a California judge ruled on Friday.

headline: Review: ‘Krapp’s Last Tape,’ a Melancholy Tone Poem
abstract: Robert Wilson, as director, designer and actor, reinvents Beckett’s play at the Alexander Kasser Theater in Montclair, N.J.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — This is not, for the record, the same old Krapp. The chalk-faced, squealing, macabre dandy who has materialized at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University bears scant resemblance to the classically grizzled figure we’ve come to associate with the title character of “Krapp’s Last Tape,” Samuel Beckett’s 1958 assessment of a life from the vantage point of its weary end.

headline: Starwood Says Rival’s Counteroffer Tops Bid from Marriott
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Starwood said that a consortium led by the Anbang Insurance Group had presented an all-cash bid worth $78 a share, besting Marriott’s offer.
lead_paragraph: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide says a $13.2 billion takeover offer led by a Chinese insurer is superior to the one that was all but sealed by Marriott International — a deal that would have created the world’s largest hotel company.

lead_paragraph: A duplex in a neo-Georgian architectural gem designed by Rosario Candela in the late 1920s, is about to enter the market at $22.5 million.

abstract: Pocketing a breakup fee and moving on beats getting into a bidding war with Anbang over Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for Marriott International to check out of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide.

headline: Inside a Colombian Guerrilla Enclave
abstract: New York Times reporter Nicholas Casey makes a rare visit to a remote FARC camp as the rebels there await the outcome of peace talks in Havana.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporter Nicholas Casey makes a rare visit to a remote FARC camp as the rebels there await the outcome of peace talks in Havana.

headline: A Rebel Hide-Out Deep in the Colombian Jungle
abstract: A sprawling camp in the Andes is home to about 150 members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling camp in the Andes is home to about 150 members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.

headline: Steven Holl’s Design Chosen for Institute for Advanced Study
abstract: The architect’s firm has been selected to design Rubenstein Commons, a rare addition to the Institute’s campus in Princeton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Steven Holl, the architect behind Princeton University’s coming  Lewis Center for the Performing Arts, has another opportunity to make his mark on the New Jersey college town.

headline: In a Rebel Camp in Colombia, Marx and Free Love Reign
abstract: For the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, many of whom have never set foot in their country’s cities, the prospect of peace after 50 years means an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: IN THE MOUNTAINS OF COLOMBIA — The rebel camp is a Communist time capsule. An old guerrilla fighter sings songs about Che Guevara on his guitar as a crowd leans in to listen, armed with rifles and grenades.

headline: Assault Charges Against Man Shot in Texas Hospital Are Dropped
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Assaults', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Houston prosecutors dismissed their case against Alan Pean, who was shot last August in a confrontation with police officers working as hospital security guards.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have dropped assault charges against a college student with bipolar disorder who was shot in a Houston hospital room during a confrontation with two police officers moonlighting as security guards.

headline: Influences: Book Award Winners in Their Own Words
abstract: Winners of the 2016 National Book Critics Circle Awards were asked what book or writer had the most profound influence on their work.
lead_paragraph: Winners of the 2016 National Book Critics Circle Awards were asked what book or writer had the most profound influence on their work.

headline: Twitter Rules Out Long Tweets, Sticking to 140-Character Limit
abstract: Jack Dorsey, chief executive of Twitter, said in an interview with the “Today” show on Friday that the service liked brevity.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Twitter’s most dedicated fans threw a fit when news of a potentially major change in the service came to light: the 140-character limit, long one of Twitter’s defining characteristics, might be going away.

headline: Better Relations With Cuba
abstract: A reader praises President Obama’s easing of travel and financial restrictions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Protest Is Planned for Donald Trump’s Speech Before Pro-Israel Group
abstract: Rabbis and others from across the country are planning to attend the American Israel Public Affairs Committee event in Washington, and some are organizing a walkout during Donald J. Trump’s speech to protest views that they say conflict with Jewish values.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump could be staring at some empty seats when he comes to Washington on Monday to make a foreign affairs address before the American Israel Public Affairs Committee’s policy conference.

headline: Sgt. Pepper Builds a Real-Life Chitty Chitty Bang Bang on Long Island
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Movies', 'New York International Auto Show']
abstract: A retired police sergeant put five years and $100,000 into making his own model of the beloved film car, which was to make its public debut Friday at the New York International Auto Show in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It is a well-known story: A quirky tinkerer rolls a rusted old car into his workshop, casts around for some parts, and emerges — honk, honk! — with a magical motorcar.

headline: Steinhoff Drops Pursuit of Home Retail Group, Owner of Argos
abstract: Steinhoff, a South African company, said it had instead struck a deal to acquire the French electronics and appliance retailer Darty.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steinhoff International Holdings of South Africa said on Friday that it had abandoned its pursuit of the Home Retail Group as a potentially lengthy bidding war loomed and instead agreed to acquire the French electronics and appliance retailer Darty.

headline: How We Got to a Colombian Guerrilla Camp
abstract: The reporter Nicholas Casey describes the path he took to meet the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Nicholas Casey describes the path he took to meet the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.

headline: A Democrat and a Republican, on the Choices We Face
abstract: A New York Democrat feels his vote doesn’t count, and an evangelical explains his support for Donald Trump.

headline: An Educated Guess on How Much ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Will Make for Disney
abstract: Movie studios are notorious for revealing few financial details about their films. But an analyst recently estimated the latest “Star Wars” movie’s balance sheet.
lead_paragraph: Enormous attention is paid to box office results, in large part because of the lack of transparency at movie studios: There is no other publicly available financial data for films. Production costs? Reporters have to pry estimates out of sources. Marketing budgets? “We don’t discuss marketing,” is the standard studio response.

headline: Sexual Slavery: ISIS and Beyond
abstract: Readers, while horrified at fighters’ routine use of rape, say others, including mothers, may be complicit, and that it is not unique to ISIS.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Senator Phil Gramm, a Former Marco Rubio Supporter, Backs Ted Cruz
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has earned a defector from the shuttered campaign of Marco Rubio: Phil Gramm, the former Texas senator once cited by Mr. Cruz as “the senator I most admire.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz has earned a defector from the shuttered campaign of Marco Rubio: Phil Gramm, the former Texas senator once cited by Mr. Cruz as “the senator I most admire.”

headline: Review: New York City Opera, a Quiet ‘Sunday Morning’
abstract: David Hertzberg’s work for soprano and small ensemble is the highlight of the new City Opera’s first concert program.
lead_paragraph: “Sunday Morning,” a work for soprano and small ensemble by the young composer David Hertzberg, was originally commissioned by Gotham Chamber Opera. But when that company foundered last year before a planned performance could take place, the piece was scooped up by New York City Opera, which was rising from the ashes of bankruptcy at just the same time.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Into New York’s Housing Authority Is ‘Very Expansive,’ Its Chief Says
abstract: Shola Olatoye said the Justice Department had been looking at “every facet” of the agency’s operations amid a review of federal funds for health and safety problems.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the New York City Housing Authority said on Friday that her staff had turned more than 400 million records over to federal prosecutors who are reviewing tenant health and safety conditions as they try to determine whether the agency filed false claims for federal funds to address any problems.
