headline: Beach House at Webster Hall: The Art of a Set List
abstract: The band is in the midst of a very long, on and off cross-Atlantic tour that started last summer and will continue through August.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore dream-pop band Beach House’s sound thrives on repetition: lulling synthesizer drones, flowing guitar riffs and clipped phrases from the lead singer Victoria Legrand. But two Beach House shows will never be the same. The band switches up its setlist every night, pulling from all six of its albums and even asking for suggestions: Fans can submit three songs they most want to hear on the band’s website.

headline: Merrick Garland Battle Moves to Home Front as Senate Recesses
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: With senators back in their home states, the debate over the Supreme Court vacancy moved away from the corridors of power in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight over the vacancy on the Supreme Court shifted from close combat in the halls of Congress to a nationwide battle on Friday as senators returned to their home states for a two-week recess and Republican and Democratic leaders began aggressively making their cases in television and radio interviews, op-ed columns and public appearances.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: American Eugenics
abstract: Adam Cohen talks about “Imbeciles,” and Ellen Fitzpatrick discusses “The Highest Glass Ceiling.”
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

headline: The Nonsuch Dive
abstract: In the 1930s, two men in a ‘‘bathysphere’’ dove deeper — much deeper — in the ocean than anyone had before.
lead_paragraph: In the 1930s, two men in a ‘‘bathysphere’’ dove deeper — much deeper — in the ocean than anyone had before.

abstract: A Duke alumnus humbly offers his Yale counterparts a guide to proper spectating at their N.C.A.A. tournament game on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Greetings, Yalies!

headline: Review: Max Reger, an Orphan-Composer Adopted for a Night
abstract: The centerpiece of the American Symphony Orchestra’s “Giant in the Shadows” program is Reger’s 45-minute Piano Concerto with Peter Serkin as soloist.
lead_paragraph: Describing his approach to programming before Thursday’s concert by the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, the conductor Leon Botstein said, “We deal in the purgatory department.” Throughout history, he explained, some pieces seemed to go directly from their premieres to a lofty place in the heaven of the standard repertory. Others are consigned to hell.

abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

lead_paragraph: Belgium and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Gay Man in Georgia Describes Attack With Scalding Water
abstract: Marquez Tolbert said the boyfriend of his partner’s mother doused them with hot water as they slept. The man was charged with aggravated battery.
lead_paragraph: A young gay man said he was struggling to recover from severe burns after a man poured scalding water on him and his boyfriend while they were asleep in an Atlanta-area apartment last month.

headline: Examining Yiddish Theater, From Shtick to Stardom
abstract: The history of a dramatic phenomenon that acculturated immigrant Jews and propelled some to national fame.
lead_paragraph: During its New York heyday a century ago, the Yiddish theater, with its Shakespearean tragedies, tear-jerking melodramas and ludicrous comedies, was a proving ground from which some stars graduated to the borscht belt and beyond.

headline: The Mourning Dove, a Melancholy Crooner
abstract: The mourning dove, now one of the most abundant birds in New York State, adds a sober tune to the chorus of springtime chirpers.
lead_paragraph: The song of the mourning dove is a melancholy counterpoint to the dazzling chorus of migrant bird calls now just beginning to fill the earliest spring air. At this time of year, even before the snow completely melts, resident doves — those that chose to take their chances on a mild New York City winter — begin their amorous cooing in sobering tones.

headline: Warmer Winter Brings Forest-Threatening Beetles North
abstract: Southern pine beetles, which had never been found beyond the South, have been spotted in New England. They are capable of killing thousands of trees.
lead_paragraph: This winter has been the warmest on record in much of New England. And while many people enjoyed the T-shirt weather, it made Claire E. Rutledge, a researcher with Connecticut’s Agricultural Experiment Station, more concerned about what next season may hold.

headline: Mitt Romney Says He’ll Vote for Ted Cruz in Utah Caucuses
abstract: Mitt Romney will vote for Ted Cruz in Utah caucus Tuesday, but he is not describing it as an endorsement.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney plans to vote for Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in Utah’s caucuses on Tuesday, he wrote Friday in a Facebook post. He also seemed to call for Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to step aside to give Republicans a better chance to block Donald J. Trump’s bid for the nomination.

headline: March 18, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from Belgium, Ukraine, Greece and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Belgium, Ukraine, Greece and Cuba.

headline: Eight Gifts for Athletic Newlyweds
abstract: Some reasonably priced gifts for keeping fit after the wedding.
lead_paragraph: Some reasonably priced gifts for keeping fit after the wedding.

headline: Purim! The Musical
abstract: Norman Roth, 77, is a retired accountant who for the past 28 years has written a new Purim spiel skit each year.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue on West 68th Street in Manhattan holds a special celebration for Purim, the Jewish holiday that commemorates the saving of the ancient Jews of Persia from mass slaughter by Haman the Agagite.

headline: How Anna Kaiser, Fitness Entrepreneur, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Once a week, Ms. Kaiser, founder of the dance-based studios AKT and a host of ABC’s “My Diet Is Better Than Yours,” sleeps late and eats indulgently.
lead_paragraph: Anna Kaiser’s work schedule is nothing short of grueling. Ms. Kaiser, the founder and chief executive of AKT, a group of dance-based boutique fitness studios, said she puts in 14-hour days Monday through Saturday, shuttling between her four locations — two in Manhattan, one in the Hamptons and one in New Canaan, Conn. — to teach classes. She says she also manages to fit in private sessions with celebrity clients like the singer Shakira and duties as a host of an ABC reality series, “My Diet Is Better Than Yours.” She takes Sundays off. Ms. Kaiser, 36, lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Dr. Carlos K. Wesley, 41, a hair restoration surgeon, and their miniature Australian shepherd, Harlie.

headline: Barneys Celebrates Downtown Opening With Leather Jacket Charity
abstract: Fashion designers, artists and downtown scenesters celebrate the upscale department store’s return to Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a huge, full-circle moment,” Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said on Thursday night, standing in the lobby of his sparkly new store in Chelsea, among handbags by Fendi, Givenchy and Maison Margiela.

headline: What Do You Need to Do to Be a Supreme Court Justice?
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: There’s a very narrow path to the highest court in the land.
lead_paragraph: IF someone could weaponize credentials — if a person could have a résumé so impressive that the mere sight of it could turn the tide of a war — that person would be Merrick B. Garland. Degrees from Harvard. A Supreme Court clerkship. A partnership in a multinational law firm. Multiple senior roles at the Department of Justice. Nineteen years on the second-most-powerful court in the country. Now he’s just one very challenging confirmation vote away from his own seat on the Supreme Court.

headline: Review: Rocío Molina, Offering Dances of Wine and Glasses
abstract: Ms. Molina uses different tools to create new sonic landscapes for her flamenco — without sacrificing the art form’s purity.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish flamenco dancer Rocío Molina held her foot over the wineglass, as if it were the sword of Damocles. And then she smashed the glass to bits.

headline: The Nuclear Deal, Through Iranians’ Eyes
abstract: A photographer captures people’s views about the international agreement and the lifting of decade-old economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: A photographer captures people’s views about the international agreement and the lifting of decade-old economic sanctions.

headline: Calculate Your Economic Risk
abstract: What are the chances you will experience poverty in the near future?
lead_paragraph: TWO economic issues loom especially large in the United States today: widespread economic insecurity and soaring levels of income inequality. These are not just issues of interest to academics and policy makers; they are a prime concern of ordinary citizens. “How much economic risk do I face in the future?” you may wonder. “How does my risk differ from that of others?”

headline: Against a Stacked Deck, Some Midmajors Do March On
abstract: How can a midmajor compete with the big guys? With rare gems like Little Rock’s Josh Hagins, whose alternate path took him to their level.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Josh Hagins celebrated his 22nd birthday on Thursday by giving every college basketball fan in America a gift: a tremendous upset on the first day of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Rooting for the Robber Barons, at Least on the Screen
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds']
abstract: The charisma and audacity of wealthy characters in shows like Showtime’s “Billions” can win over even those who bemoan the greed of the financial industry.
lead_paragraph: This past week brought the announcement that the producer Ben Silverman, with partners, planned to create a television series based on Isn’t That Rich, Richard Kirshenbaum’s column in The New York Observer examining the habits of the Upper East Side penthouse class. Writing from the perspective of someone living in a 5,000-square-foot duplex on Fifth Avenue, Mr. Kirshenbaum, an advertising executive, isn’t agitating for upheaval. Voices quoted in his columns deliver lines like “It isn’t a Woody Allen movie anymore, it’s ‘Moscow on the Hudson,’” referring to New York in the age of Bill de Blasio, but the voices belong to people Mr. Kirshenbaum is working out with, in private gyms, in even more fantastical apartments.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Ups and Downs
abstract: There’s a roller-coaster effect as fashion soars between winter and spring.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a roller-coaster effect as fashion has soared between winter and spring from early February to last week. In response to the weather, women are nonchalantly tossing their coats and jackets over their shoulders. Colors are light. White faux fox collars add glamour. The new direction of fashion is not about shouting; it’s a whisper, an elegance redefined for a new era: navy blue coat, pinstripe trousers and, surprise, gold shoes (worn at 9 a.m.).

headline: Why We’re Not Making Plans for Coachella and Bonnaroo
keywords: ['Music', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Bonnaroo Festival (Manchester, Tenn)']
abstract: The New York Times pop-music critics lay out a new vision for how to cover the season’s live events
lead_paragraph: Each year, shortly after New Year’s Day, the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival announces the lineup for its late-April dates. In response, the pop-music critics of The New York Times look at the names on the list — last year’s Grammy winners, makers of breakthrough records two years ago, slow-boiling Spotify stars whose rise has been deeply commented on by us and hundreds of others — and we rub our foreheads. A few weeks later comes Bonnaroo’s announcement, for early June, and we have still not sorted out Coachella.

headline: Boulez and Harnoncourt, So Different, Yet More Alike Than They Realized
abstract: One championed early music, and the other was a modernist, yet more parallels can be drawn between the two than either might have preferred.
lead_paragraph: It’s as if the postwar period itself had died. Within two months, Pierre Boulez and Nikolaus Harnoncourt, the two avant-gardists who more than anyone in the last half-century redefined classical music, were gone.

headline: Review: ‘Double Falsehood,’ and Just Maybe a Double Byline
abstract: A play that may have been at least partly written by Shakespeare is mounted by the Letter of Marque Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Whether Shakespeare or someone else wrote it, you have to admire the prescience of “Double Falsehood,” at least as it’s being staged in a well-conceived production by the Letter of Marque Theater Company. Thanks largely to a scalding scene in the first half of the show, a central plotline seems as if it could be a commentary on the modern-day scourges of date rape and on-campus assaults.

headline: Why Is Sean Penn Suing Lee Daniels?
abstract: With a little help from Madonna, the actor and humanitarian seeks to dispel decades-old rumors given a second life thanks to the rise of social media.
lead_paragraph: Sean Penn is fighting. But not with his fists — repeat, not with his fists.

headline: Debra Messing on the Talk Show Circuit
abstract: The redheaded actress grabs dinner with her hairstylist, as she races from one interview to the next, promoting her TV shows.
lead_paragraph: Even huddled under an umbrella Debra Messing was impossible to miss as she left “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” the other week. There was the torrent of red hair. There was the explosive, infectious laugh.

headline: Review: Philharmonic Goes Dada With Esa-Pekka Salonen’s ‘Karawane’
abstract: Among the items on the program at David Geffen Hall was Leonidas Kavakos’s take on Sibelius’s Violin Concerto.
lead_paragraph: Not long into Esa-Pekka Salonen’s “Karawane,” a robust choral passage — the men sounding solemn, the women sinuous — begins to deflate just a bit. The sound starts to flatten into slight dissonance, as if the color is draining out of dozens of voices at once.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jason Stallman, Lynda Richardson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Review: Anais Mitchell Sings Her Own Work at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse
abstract: Ms. Mitchell’s appearance, part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, revealed a formidable songwriting talent.
lead_paragraph: Call it a musical coup d’état.

headline: Utah Ads Featuring Mitt Romney Target Donald Trump
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The “super PAC” formed to stop Donald J. Trump’s push for the Republican presidential nomination is spending $250,000 on television ads to run in Utah featuring Mitt Romney condemning the front-running candidate.
lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” formed to stop Donald J. Trump’s push for the Republican presidential nomination is spending $250,000 on television ads in Utah featuring Mitt Romney condemning the front-running candidate.

headline: Orchestras Get in Tune With Modern Black-Tie
abstract: What happened when Gabi Asfour, of the high-concept label threeASFOUR, set out to design uniforms for the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: As the recent Academy Awards ceremony reminded us, fashion loves nothing better than making movie stars look perfect for that one night a year.

headline: Review: A Program of Premieres by Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance
abstract: The company danced world premieres of Doug Elkins’s “The Weight of Smoke” and Larry Keigwin’s “Rush Hour,” and the New York premiere of Mr. Taylor’s “Sullivaniana.”
lead_paragraph: Premieres have been popping forth from Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance this week — with variable results. Wednesday’s gala began with a piece (new to New York) by Mr. Taylor, “Sullivaniana.” Like many Taylor creations this century, it seemed like a skillful preliminary sketch of something this master didn’t have the energy to turn into an interesting dance. It also looked neither American nor like modern dance.

headline: Review: ‘Too Blondes,’ a Cabaret of Comic Confusion
abstract: This show from Savannah & Chase, a.k.a. Savannah Brown and Chase O’Donnell, sends up the ’20s (the era) and the 20s (the age group).
lead_paragraph: Although they’re not related, the musical-comedy team Savannah & Chase, a.k.a. Savannah Brown and Chase O’Donnell, might be described as the Smothers Sisters. “Too Blondes,” their goofy, effervescent show at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, began with the kind of comedic confusion that used to be a running joke in Tom and Dick Smothers’ television variety show.

headline: Review: ‘Ideation,’ About an Office Team’s Morally Disturbing New Project
abstract: In Aaron Loeb’s play at 59E59 Theaters, co-workers take on an assignment that involves mass murder and the disposal of bodies.
lead_paragraph: They filter into the conference room, fatigued but triumphant, three guys just back from a consulting trip to Greece. Teasing one another, bantering with their boss, they’re a likable bunch — but only sort of. In the opening moments of “Ideation,” at 59E59 Theaters, an unsavory, even Mametian vibe underlies their swagger.

headline: Another Gallery Is Raided ­in Antiquities Case
abstract: Three items seized from a Manhattan gallery were valued at nearly $1 million.
lead_paragraph: In their fifth raid in a week focusing on South Asian antiquities they say were looted, investigators have seized three items from a leader in the field, the Nancy Wiener Gallery of Manhattan.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: European Union, Salah Abdeslam, Merrick Garland
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Senator Grassley’s Letter to the Wounded Warrior Project
abstract: In a March 18 letter, Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, asked Anthony Odierno of the Wounded Warrior Project for information concerning reports of lavish spending at the organization.
lead_paragraph: In a March 18 letter, Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, asked Anthony Odierno of the Wounded Warrior Project for information concerning reports of lavish spending at the organization.

headline: Senator Wants Data on Wounded Warrior Project, a Charity Under Fire
abstract: Recent news reports have raised questions about the treatment of employees and the spending of the country’s largest veterans’ charity.
lead_paragraph: A week after the top executives of the Wounded Warrior Project were fired amid accusations of lavish spending, an influential senator on a committee that oversees nonprofit organizations is asking for a detailed accounting by the country’s largest veterans’ charity.

headline: If John Kasich’s Go-To Line Seems Familiar, There’s a Reason
abstract: A favorite line of Gov. John Kasich — “I will not take the low road to the highest office in the land” — was also uttered by Senator John McCain during the 2000 primaries, and they have the same strategist.
lead_paragraph: With one catchy line, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has found a way to try to set himself apart from his more combative rivals.

headline: A Mix of Beer, Bragging Rights and Horse Races at the Cheltenham Festival
abstract: The meeting usually falls around St. Patrick’s Day and the Irish come in force to root for their horses against their English rivals’ for a year’s bragging rights.
lead_paragraph: PRESTBURY PARK, England — This is the place where horse stories become myths and the humans around them become legends. It is where horses glide over this soft ground, soaring over undulating hills as if they were big waves before taking flight over hurdles and steeplechase fences.

headline: Presidential Candidates Woo Arizona Voters on Immigration
abstract: Arizona is both a magnet for retirees and home to a growing Latino population. The state’s electorate is deeply divided on the question of immigration.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When Donald J. Trump campaigns in Arizona, he talks up the endorsements he has received from Jan Brewer, the former governor who signed some of the nation’s toughest immigration laws, and Sheriff Joe Arpaio, whose aggressive pursuit of illegal immigrants has prompted discrimination charges by the Justice Department.

headline: Evening Hours | Dance Performances and Art
abstract: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.

headline: SoundCloud Signs Licensing Deal With Sony
abstract: The streaming music service, which has deals with Warner Music, Universal and Merlin, says it will offer a version for paid subscribers this year.
lead_paragraph: SoundCloud’s tug of war with the music industry may finally be over.

headline: Elliot Gant, Marketer of the Button-Down Shirt, Dies at 89
abstract: The Gant brothers transformed the button-down into a fashion must, as noted by the comedian Bob Newhart and his “button-down mind.”
lead_paragraph: Linguists can’t precisely pinpoint when “button-down” was redefined from cutting-edge collegiate to uniformly conformist, but the marketing expertise of the Gantmacher brothers of Brooklyn probably had something to do with it.

headline: Merrick Garland Often Deferred to Government in Guantánamo Cases
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Judge Merrick B. Garland’s tendency to side with the government explains the mixed reaction among liberals to his Supreme Court nomination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a judge ordered a Guantánamo Bay prisoner freed because the evidence that he was a Qaeda member was too thin, the government appealed the ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. But as the detainee’s lawyers prepared to argue the case in January 2011, they had reason to hope that they might prevail again.

headline: Spring May Start With Snow in New York Region
abstract: After hints of warm weather in recent weeks, up to four inches of snow have been forecast to fall in New York City by Monday, and more in the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers may be clamoring for spring, but the city could still get one more gust of winter.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Middle Tennessee State Sets Tone on a Day of Upsets
abstract: The 15th-seeded Blue Raiders downed Michigan State, a title contender, in one of the most stunning first-round upsets in tournament history. And then the drama continued.
lead_paragraph: The odds looked strong for Michigan State — not just to make it past the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, but to roll on to the Final Four, the coveted perch Coach Tom Izzo has practically transformed into his home away from home.

headline: Hulk Hogan Awarded $115 Million in Privacy Suit Against Gawker
abstract: A Florida jury delivered a verdict in favor of the former wrestler in a suit over publication of a sex tape. It also found the site’s founder and its former editor liable.
lead_paragraph: The retired wrestler Hulk Hogan was awarded $115 million in damages on Friday by a Florida jury in an invasion of privacy case against Gawker.com over its publication of a sex tape — an astounding figure that tops the $100 million he had asked for, that will probably grow before the trial concludes, and that could send a cautionary signal to online publishers despite the likelihood of an appeal by Gawker.

headline: For Adam LaRoche, Blood Proves Thicker Than Infield Dirt
abstract: The White Sox’ designated hitter explained his decision to retire from baseball after he said the team ordered him to limit his son’s time in the clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you noticed, upon entering the clubhouse of the Chicago White Sox in Glendale, Ariz., this spring training, was the jersey hanging in the corner stall. It looked just like all the others and was given the same prominence, but it was much smaller. Its owner, Drake LaRoche, No. 25, is only 14 years old. His father, Adam, was the White Sox’ designated hitter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Forges Ahead With Jabs at Donald Trump
abstract: In Idaho, Utah and Arizona, which vote Tuesday, Mr. Sanders stuck to his core messages in trying to seize the mantle of electability from Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Undeterred by questions of delegate math or political momentum, Senator Bernie Sanders brushed off suggestions on Friday that his campaign had no way forward and forcefully made the case that he was the Democratic candidate better suited to defeat Donald J. Trump in a general election.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Airstrikes Against ISIS After It Gains Territory in Afghanistan
abstract: Some inside the administration and among national security experts have questioned whether the focus should be more on the Taliban than the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has significantly intensified its bombing campaign in Afghanistan in the past two months as part of President Obama’s widening war against the Islamic State militants who have seized territory outside of Iraq and Syria, according to senior military commanders.

headline: Yankees’ Starlin Castro Is Seeking New Walk-Up Song, and Other Hits
abstract: The Yankees’ new second baseman is leaving “Ando En La Verasace” by Omega behind because it is part of his legacy at Wrigley Field.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Dread had given way to resignation on a late October night at Wrigley Field. The Chicago Cubs, already trailing the Mets by three games to none in the National League Championship Series, were down by four runs before they even came to bat. By the bottom of the sixth, with the Cubs trailing, 6-1, the capacity crowd was glum, preparing for the inevitable.

headline: Jets Say Signing Ryan Fitzpatrick, Not Robert Griffin III, Is Still Focus
abstract: General Manager Mike Maccagnan played down Griffin’s recent two-day visit, repeatedly stressing the team’s desire to re-sign the free-agent quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick.
lead_paragraph: Jets General Manager Mike Maccagnan played down Robert Griffin III’s recent two-day visit and used a conference call with reporters on Friday to repeatedly stress the team’s desire to re-sign the free-agent quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick.

headline: Business Executive From China Is Charged in U.N. Bribery Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors charged Julia Vivi Wang with paying at least $500,000 in bribes to buy diplomatic positions with the government of Antigua for her husband and another man.
lead_paragraph: The broad United Nations corruption investigation that swept up a former president of the General Assembly expanded on Friday, as federal prosecutors charged a Chinese-born executive with paying at least $500,000 in bribes to buy diplomatic positions with the government of Antigua for her husband and another man.

headline: Accusations of Sexism and Racism Shake Ad Agency and Industry
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After J. Walter Thompson’s chief steps down, questions are raised about Madison Avenue’s culture and diversity in an era posing new challenges.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon at J. Walter Thompson’s headquarters on Lexington Avenue in New York, the departing chief executive, Gustavo Martinez, handed the reins of the storied advertising agency to his successor, Tamara Ingram.

headline: In Monthslong Hunt for Salah Abdeslam, Missed Chances and High Alerts
abstract: The prolonged search for Mr. Abdeslam, believed to have driven the car that carried terrorists to Paris, generated intense criticism of Belgian authorities.
lead_paragraph: The prolonged search for Mr. Abdeslam, believed to have driven the car that carried terrorists to Paris, generated intense criticism of Belgian authorities.

headline: Historic Win by Hawaii Puts an End to a Trying Week for California
abstract: Hawaii notched its first N.C.A.A. tournament win in history by toppling No. 4-seeded Cal, after a week in which the Golden Bears lost several key players and an assistant coach.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — As Cuonzo Martin paced the sideline, watching his best player get into foul trouble and his team play sloppy basketball, he kept reaching for a gold and blue towel. Every few plays, Martin, the California coach, would wipe his brow, dry his hands and clench the towel as his anger took hold.

headline: Fox News Slams Donald Trump for ‘Sick Obsession’ With Megyn Kelly
abstract: After Donald J. Trump resumed his attacks on the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly, the network said his words were “beneath the dignity of a presidential candidate who wants to occupy the highest office in the land.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump again turned his Twitter vitriol toward an old foe this week: Megyn Kelly, the Fox News anchor and frequent target of his social media ire. On Friday, the network said it had had enough.

headline: Joe Santos, a Mainstay of ‘The Rockford Files,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Santos, an actor with many television and film credits, often played characters who were tough but stressed, including an overworked detective on “Rockford.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Santos, a sturdily built, unpretentious character actor who had a memorable role as the overworked detective Dennis Becker on the popular 1970s drama “The Rockford Files,” died on Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Figure in Benghazi Inquiry Alters Suit on Firing
abstract: A former House staff member dropped part of a lawsuit saying he had been dismissed for failing to go along with a House panel’s “hyper-focus” on Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Republican staff member on the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, has dropped allegations in a lawsuit that he had been dismissed in part because he objected to the panel’s focus on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

headline: And They’re Off
abstract: The Cheltenham Festival usually falls around St. Patrick’s Day and the Irish come in force to root for their horses against their English rivals’.
lead_paragraph: The Cheltenham Festival usually falls around St. Patrick’s Day and the Irish come in force to root for their horses against their English rivals’.

headline: Halfcourt Heave Lifts Northern Iowa
abstract: JeQuan Lewis had 21 points, 8 assists and 7 rebounds, and tournament-tested V.C.U. held off a second-half charge to defeat seventh-seeded Oregon State in the West Region.
lead_paragraph: Paul Jesperson banked in a halfcourt shot at the buzzer to give 11th-seeded Northern Iowa a win over sixth-seeded Texas on Friday night in a West Region first-round game in Oklahoma City.

headline: Amid Scandals, Senior Judge in Brazil Suspends Ex-President’s Cabinet Nomination
abstract: The ruling was the latest twist in a political crisis that has Latin America’s largest country’s on edge.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A justice on Brazil’s highest court on Friday night suspended the nomination of the country’s former president to a cabinet post in President Dilma Rousseff’s government, the latest twist in a political crisis that has Latin America’s largest country on edge.

headline: 50 Ways to Leave The Donald
abstract: Rather than pursuing the Ted Cruz option, a lot of Republicans are maneuvering for a contested convention.
lead_paragraph: Rational Republicans are desperately trying to figure out a way to get rid of Donald Trump. Their desperation is so great, you’d expect someone to release a herd of crocodiles on Mar-a-Lago.

headline: Michigan State, Poised for a Deep Run, Crashes Into Middle Tennessee
abstract: No. 2-seeded Michigan State, an elite program fresh off a Final Four run, was toppled by 15th-seeded Middle Tennessee State.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — When did Jaqawn Raymond, Middle Tennessee State’s starting point guard, feel certain that his 15th-seeded Blue Raiders would defeat No. 2-seeded Michigan State and pull off one of the biggest upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history?

headline: Killing of Italian Student, Giulio Regeni, Puts Focus on Egypt’s Stability
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture']
abstract: The case of Mr. Regeni, who was tortured and killed, has Western officials debating how to address the worsening human rights situation in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Ever since the brutalized body of a 28-year-old Italian student, Giulio Regeni, was discovered on the  side of a road on Feb. 2, lurid theories have abounded about who, or what, was responsible for his death.

headline: Kathryn Reed Altman, Film Director’s Widow and Archivist, Dies at 91
abstract: Ms. Altman often spoke at retrospectives of Robert Altman’s work, was co-author of a book about him and was part of the 2014 documentary “Altman.”
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Reed Altman, who helped safeguard and enhance the artistic legacy of her husband, the film director Robert Altman, died on March 9 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Cholera Deaths in Haiti Could Far Exceed Official Count
abstract: Officially, 9,200 people have died in the epidemic that began after the 2010 earthquake. But the real figure could be much worse, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Deaths from the cholera epidemic that ravaged Haiti after the 2010 earthquake could be much higher than the 9,200 officially tallied so far because of underreporting during the initial outbreak, a new study suggests.

headline: Prince Announces Coming Memoir at Performance
abstract: The singer and songwriter’s autobiography will be published by the Spiegel & Grau imprint of Random House
lead_paragraph: Leave it to Prince to announce his new memoir with a last-minute invitation-only performance at a Manhattan nightclub.

headline: Obamacare’s Birth-Control ‘Exemption’ Still Tramples on Rights
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Its opt-out provision on birth control violates our faith.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-EIGHT years ago, I vowed to consecrate my life to living with, loving and caring for the elderly poor. Since then, I have been blessed to live in a community of women who seek to treat every elderly person in our care with love and respect — as if we were caring for Christ himself.

headline: The Ups and Downs of the Bradford Pear
abstract: Once celebrated, the invasive Bradford pear is now one of the most despised of trees.
lead_paragraph: Mount Rainier, Md. — SPRING arrives on Sunday, and in the nation’s capital, that means a certain tree is bursting in radiant cream-colored flowers.

headline: Foster Father Charged With Sexually Abusing 5 Boys on Long Island
abstract: Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu had 140 boys placed in his care over 22 years, despite several warning signs, a prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: A longtime foster father on Long Island has been charged with sexually abusing five boys, all of them his adopted sons, in a case where the authorities suspect there are many more victims.

headline: Inching Toward Safer Homeless Shelters
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: New York City is taking some first steps. The state needs to do its part, too.
lead_paragraph: No doubt about it: The crime statistics in New York City look rosy. But Mayor Bill de Blasio is not in a good position to boast — not when people are living on the streets and subways because they don’t want to be robbed, stabbed, beaten or killed in homeless shelters.

headline: Brazil’s Political Crisis Deepens
abstract: President Dilma Rousseff’s decision to largely shield her predecessor from prosecution by giving him a cabinet job has rightly outraged Brazilians.
lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is fighting for political survival as calls for her impeachment grow louder amid a widening corruption investigation and a tanking economy.

headline: What Planned Parenthood Really Does
abstract: Its health care services go well beyond abortion and birth control.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — A nurse took Tiara Thurman’s blood pressure at the Planned Parenthood health center in Akron. Ms. Thurman, 24, was at the clinic this week to get Depo-Provera, an injectable form of birth control that works for three months. The nurse asked Ms. Thurman about her family history, allergies and history of surgeries and pregnancy — she has a daughter, now 2. The nurse offered Ms. Thurman free condoms.

headline: Extremely Green
abstract: Byron Walden makes us an offering.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —This was an excellent, juicy puzzle by a master of Saturdays, Byron Walden. There was just enough for me to sink my teeth into before getting stumped, and the head-scratchers were conceived so well that finally finishing was true gratification.

headline: Schenn Brothers Have Been on Hot Streaks Since Being Separated by Trade
abstract: The Schenns had been teammates for three and a half years on the Philadelphia Flyers. Since Luke left for the Los Angeles Kings, both brothers have seen their play improve.
lead_paragraph: VOORHEES, N.J. — Brayden Schenn’s teammate, roommate, summer workout partner and regular dinner companion left town for good Jan. 6, headed on a plane to Los Angeles. That person also happened to be Schenn’s older brother, Luke.

headline: Sergio Arellano Stark, Chilean General Who Led Death Squad, Dies at 94
abstract: He helped install Augusto Pinochet as president in a 1973 coup and was implicated in the murder or disappearance of more than 75 Chileans.
lead_paragraph: Sergio Arellano Stark, a Chilean general whose airborne “Caravan of Death” murdered opponents of the 1973 coup that deposed Chile’s democratically elected president, Salvador Allende, died on March 9 in Santiago de Chile. He was 94.

headline: Upsets From Coast to Coast
abstract: The second full day of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament was full of unexpected victories.
lead_paragraph: The second full day of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament was full of unexpected victories.

headline: Larry Drake, Lovable Clerk on ‘L.A. Law,’ Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Drake’s role as Benny Stulwicz on “L.A. Law” began as a minor one but was expanded and earned him two Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Larry Drake, a longtime actor best known for his Emmy-winning role as a developmentally disabled character on the television drama “L.A. Law,” was found dead on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Prominent Tory Quits British Cabinet Over Welfare Cuts
abstract: The resignation of Iain Duncan Smith as Britain underscored tensions in the government of Prime Minister David Cameron over European Union membership.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, Iain Duncan Smith, resigned from the cabinet on Friday over proposed cuts to welfare payments, dealing a significant and unexpected blow to Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: Judge Revokes Bail for Owen Labrie, Man Convicted in ‘Senior Salute’ Case
abstract: A judge found that Mr. Labrie, who had been out on $15,000 bail pending an appeal, had violated his court-imposed curfew.
lead_paragraph: Owen Labrie, the New England prep school graduate who was free on bail after an October conviction for having sex with a minor in a ritual called “senior salute,” was jailed on Friday after a judge ruled that he had violated his court-imposed curfew.

headline: David Wright Seems Unbothered by Spine in First Game Back
abstract: Wright’s spinal stenosis did not appear to affect his ability to play on Friday, as he hit two solid singles in three at-bats.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With a stocked pitching staff and a solid lineup, the Mets are poised to build on their success last year.

headline: FlyDubai Plane Crashes at Russian Airport, Killing Over 60
abstract: All 55 passengers and seven crew members aboard died when the Dubai airliner crashed in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Boeing 737-800 from Dubai with 62 people aboard crashed early Saturday during a landing attempt at the airport in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight” arrives online. And “Dateline” reports on the death of a woman found in her mansion.
lead_paragraph: Quentin Tarantino’s latest talky, bloody foray into historical genre movies, “The Hateful Eight,” arrives online. And “Dateline” reports on the death of a woman found in her mansion.

headline: Corrections: March 19, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We’re not just at the center of the immigration discussion. The border is our backyard. We live the challenges of immigration every single day.”

headline: Serena Williams Closer to Making Her Indian Wells Return Triumphant
abstract: Williams, who last won the tournament 15 years ago in front of a hostile crowd, reached the final with a victory over Agnieszka Radwanska.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Fifteen years after she last won here in front of a virulently hostile crowd, Serena Williams booked a spot in the final of the BNP Paribas Open, beating Agnieszka Radwanska, 6-4, 7-6 (1), in a semifinal match Friday evening.

headline: ‘Obama Wins Either Way’: Our Best Comments of the Week
abstract: “Donald Trump is a kind of political Dr. Phil.” Readers react to the presidential primary results and the new Supreme Court nominee, Merrick Garland.
lead_paragraph: Here are the 10 comments of the week on the digital platforms of The New York Times, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Namaste and I Do
abstract: Brett Barakett and Meaghan Jarensky were married at their home in Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Brett Barakett and Meaghan Jarensky were married at their home in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Fighting a Fake Dating Profile, Together
abstract: Brett Barakett was shocked to find an online dating profile for his girlfriend Meaghan Jarensky. Their fight to remove the fake profile ended up in court.
lead_paragraph: Brett Barakett and Meaghan Jarensky didn’t find each other on a dating site, but a posting on Match.com — a blatantly counterfeit one — nearly broke them up.

headline: Donald Trump on Mitt Romney: ‘Are You Sure He’s a Mormon?’
abstract: Mr. Trump made the remark at a rally in Salt Lake City, home to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints’ headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in Salt Lake City — home to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints’ headquarters — Donald J. Trump questioned Mitt Romney’s membership in the faith on Friday, asking a crowd at a rally, “Are you sure he’s a Mormon?”

headline: What Happens When Millennials Run the Workplace?
abstract: At Mic, a media site created by and for 20-somethings, oversharing, acting entitled and second-guessing the boss are the norm.
lead_paragraph: Joel Pavelski, 27, isn’t the first person who has lied to his boss to scam some time off work.

headline: Teenage Drivers? Be Very Afraid
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue']
abstract: When it comes to younger drivers, helicopter parenting is a must. Here, some road rules.
lead_paragraph: Spend enough time having parenting conversations, as I’ve done personally and professionally for the last dozen years, and certain patterns emerge. In nine out of 10 cases, if you’re talking about highly motivated parents, the message to Mom and Dad is: back off, chill out, park the helicopter.

headline: Fighting Macular Degeneration
abstract: Advances are being developed to improve results against the so-called wet and dry forms of the condition.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are there any new treatments in the pipeline for age-related macular degeneration?

headline: A Mother’s Death, a Daughter’s Life: Remembering Natalie Wood
abstract: She lost her mother when she was 11 years old. Three decades later, Natasha Gregson Wagner has decided it’s time to talk about it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The home that Natasha Gregson Wagner shares with her husband, his sons and their daughter in Venice, a seaside neighborhood here, smells clean in a non-antiseptic way and, on a recent visit, faintly of the lilacs that rested in a vase on the kitchen countertop.

headline: Get Ready, Internet. The Pope Has Joined Instagram.
abstract: The pontiff, formerly known as Jorge Mario Bergoglio, is going by the Instagram name @Franciscus.
lead_paragraph: In the three years since Pope Francis joined Twitter, he has attracted more than 25 million followers in nine languages. On Saturday, the pontiff added a new app to his social media mix: The pope joined Instagram.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the White House to an improvised border camp in Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the White House to an improvised border camp in Greece.

headline: How Donald Trump Can Fall Short of His Delegate Target
abstract: He’s the favorite, but he’s vulnerable to further shows of strength from Ted Cruz and the consolidation of the opposition.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is about 550 delegates short of earning the 1,237 delegates necessary to win the Republican nomination.

headline: Carrier Workers See Costs, Not Benefits, of Global Trade
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: As factory jobs move abroad, the divide between the political and economic elite and the rest of Americans widens, placing the two groups at odds.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The fuzzy video, shot by a worker on the floor of a Carrier factory here in the American heartland last month, captured the raging national debate over trade and the future of the working class in 3 minutes 32 seconds.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: Discuss your solving experience of the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad and Mike Parse Virtual Reality Tech and the Apple Standoff
abstract: Examining virtual reality tech for gamers, mourning Google’s viral robots and revisiting the Apple-F.B.I. case.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Can I Break My Lease Over Subway Noise?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Noise', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Air Pollution', 'Condominiums', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Complaints about train vibrations, unruly guests and black chimney smoke.
lead_paragraph: Noise Problems

headline: Kirk Franklin Combines Faith and Fervor
abstract: Mr. Franklin will bring his rousing form of gospel to Kings Theater in Brooklyn on March 22.
lead_paragraph: “Thank you Kirk for standing by me through all the noise.” That was Kanye West on Twitter a few days ago, sharing his appreciation for Kirk Franklin, a pillar of the gospel music world for more than two decades who had worked on “Ultralight Beam,” the soaring opening number from Mr. West’s latest album, “The Life of Pablo.” Two top talents in collaboration — easy enough, right?

headline: NBCSN Announcer Rebecca Lowe Faces a Hiatus
abstract: Since being hired in 2013 from ESPN UK, Lowe has become the defining face of the Premier League at the NBC Sports Group.
lead_paragraph: Seven weeks remain in an improbable Premier League season. Leicester City is in first place. Manchester United is in crisis. Chelsea, the defending champion, is adrift after an early-season collapse.

headline: Wind Given as Possible Cause of Fatal Plane Crash in Russia

Especially popular: 14-carat gold rings, fashioned from thin stretches of hammered metal, chain links or tiny connected balls.

headline: Variety: An Antecedent Acrostic

It’s impressive and amazing how linguists and paleoanthropologists can create a rich picture of life, including sounds and emotions, from fossils and artifacts. For anyone interested in the history of words and language, this was a passage that was fun to discover.

headline: Puerto Rico Braces for Its Own Zika Epidemic

lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — Smoking cigarettes and huddling against the midnight chill, a group of Syrian men sat outside a mosque waiting for a smuggler’s call. It was their last chance, they said, to reach Europe.

lead_paragraph: If this were anything like a normal year, the Republicans would be favored to take the White House. That, at least, is what Ray Fair’s economic model has been saying consistently since November 2014.

headline: Paris Suspect Claims He ‘Backed Out’ of Stadium Bombing, Prosecutor Says

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Salah Abdeslam, believed to be the only direct participant in the November attacks in Paris who is still alive, told investigators on Saturday after being captured a day earlier that he wanted to detonate his suicide vest at the Stade de France soccer stadium on the night of the attacks but “backed out,” said the lead terrorism prosecutor in France.

headline: A Peek Inside Harry Potter’s New Hollywood World

headline: Charlotte Hornets, a Team Created in 2004, Set Its Wins Record in 1997

lead_paragraph: With the way the Charlotte Hornets have been playing recently, it may finally be time to retire the “Crying Jordan” meme. While the Internet’s Photoshop enthusiasts will undoubtedly be sad at no longer eliciting easy laughs by replacing the head in any photo with Michael Jordan’s tear-strewn face from his Hall of Fame acceptance speech in 2009, the fact that the meaning behind the original meme may no longer be valid takes away some of its humor.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Transparency in the Drone Wars
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Targeted Killings', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: The White House will soon say how many civilians the government thinks it has killed in drone strikes. That will be too little too late.
lead_paragraph: The White House is expected next month to disclose how many combatants and noncombatants government officials believe have been killed in drone strikes outside declared war zones. The Obama administration will bill this as an effort to peel back a layer of secrecy on a controversial counterterrorism program that has long been dogged by questions about its morality and legality. That will be too little, too late.

headline: Hollywood’s Fake Version of Nina Simone
abstract: The actress Zoe Saldana needed a prosthetic nose and skin-darkening makeup to play the singer.
lead_paragraph: The jazz artist Nina Simone was intimately familiar with the scorn that this society heaps upon dark-skinned black women. The world she was born into in the 1930s told her in every possible way that ebony skin, a broad nose and full lips offended Eurocentric standards of beauty and made women of her complexion unworthy of admiration.

headline: Life Among the Ruins
abstract: The ancient structures that the Islamic State destroyed in Iraq and Syria were not just relics.
lead_paragraph: NEXT month, the Temple of Baal will come to Times Square. Reproductions of the 50-foot arch that formed the temple’s entrance are to be installed in New York and in London, a tribute to the 2,000-year-old structure that the Islamic State destroyed last year in the Syrian town of Palmyra. The group’s rampage through Palmyra, a city that reached its peak in the second and third century A.D., enraged the world, spurring scholars and conservationists into action. Numerous nongovernmental organizations are now cataloging and mapping damaged cultural heritage sites in the region.

headline: Sarah Weiner
abstract: A sustainable-food advocate on Brazil, period dramas and couture dresses as wall art.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Weiner is a co-founder of Seedling Projects, a nonprofit organization based in San Francisco, which promotes sustainable food through events like its annual Good Food Awards.

headline: Building a Better Anonymouse Trap
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: Readers are embracing The Times’s stringent new policy on the use of anonymous sources. But some say they will believe it when they see it.
lead_paragraph: THE TIMES has a new way to handle information supplied by people who don’t want to be identified by name — also known as anonymous sources, or jocularly, because they are omnipresent and hard to control, as “anonymice.”

headline: Poisoned Water in Newark Schools
abstract: Sadly, the lead problem is not surprising, given the neglect by Congress and state governments.
lead_paragraph: Newark Public Schools recently acknowledged that the water at its schools has contained high levels of lead for years. This is shocking but, sadly, not surprising given the neglect of public schools, especially those in poor communities, by Congress and state governments.

headline: The World’s Modern-Day Lepers: Women With Fistulas
keywords: ['Fistulas', 'Women and Girls', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: The life-destroying condition is one reason women’s rights worldwide should be a social justice priority.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — ONE of the worst things that can happen to a woman or girl around the world is a fistula, an internal injury caused by childbirth (or occasionally by rape) that leaves her incontinent, humiliated and sometimes stinking.

headline: When Did Porn Become Sex Ed?
keywords: ['Sex Education', 'Pornography', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Conversations between adults and teenagers about what happens after “yes” remain rare.
lead_paragraph: THE other day, I got an email from a 21-year-old college senior about sex — or perhaps more correctly, about how ill equipped she was to talk about sex. The abstinence-only curriculum in her middle and high schools had taught her little more than “don’t,” and she’d told me that although her otherwise liberal parents would have been willing to answer any questions, it was pretty clear the topic made them even more uncomfortable than it made her.

headline: The Hidden Price of Mindfulness Inc.
abstract: As the practice of mindfulness is packaged and peddled, it’s hard not to wonder if something essential is being lost.
lead_paragraph: THE other morning, I woke up and brewed a cup of Mindful Lotus tea ($6 for 20 bags). On the subway, I loaded the Headspace app on my iPhone and followed a guided mindfulness exercise ($13 a month for premium content). Later in the day, I dropped by Mndfl, a meditation studio in Greenwich Village ($20 for a 45-minute class).

headline: Dying, With Nothing to Say
abstract: We want to make a proper ending out of a pointless loss. But there is only loss.
lead_paragraph: MY father died of a heart attack. He was with my mother, on his way home from a concert and dinner with friends, and he collapsed in the marble lobby of their building. There was no preparation. There were no last conversations.

headline: How a Fitbit May Make You a Bit Fit
abstract: Millions now have fitness-tracking devices. But are they any use?
lead_paragraph: Toronto — THE ultracompact, platform-agnostic, user-configurable mobile fitness device that Dr. Michael Joyner showed off at a recent sports technology conference caused a stir. The attendees had gathered to ponder the future of high-tech performance enhancement.

headline: All Things Come to an End. Even My 2001 Saturn.
abstract: S­hould you trust a mechanic named Rusty? Sometimes you have to.
lead_paragraph: Urbana, Ill. — WHEN you drive an old and shabby car, as I do, you try to make the best of it. There’s even a kind of reverse bragging involved: just how old, how shabby, how gruesomely it can shed parts and systems and still get you from place to place. There are cars in far worse shape than yours on the road. So you tell yourself. The ones whose mileage equals a trip to the moon and halfway back, the ones that need to be push-started every time, the ones lacking structural integrity in their roofs or floorboards.

headline: Owning Up to Torture
abstract: Men like Donald Trump and Ted Cruz don’t have to bear the cost.
lead_paragraph: IN March 2004, at Forward Operating Base St. Mere outside Falluja, Iraq, I was walking home from work. Ferdinand Ibabao, my close friend and fellow contractor, was walking with me. It had been a long day of interrogations, so we were looking forward to checking emails, and hearing about what our families were up to back home.

headline: The Man the Founders Feared

Trump last week, when he was asked by CNN what he thought would happen if he arrived at the Republican Convention this summer a few delegates short of the 1,237 needed to win outright and didn’t set forth from Cleveland as the party’s nominee.

headline: Republican Leaders Map a Strategy to Derail Donald Trump

Trump’s candidacy are preparing a 100-day campaign to deny him the presidential nomination, starting with an aggressive battle in Wisconsin’s April 5 primary and extending into the summer, with a delegate-by-delegate lobbying effort that would cast Mr. Trump as a calamitous choice for the general election.

headline: U.S. Marine Killed by Islamic State Rocket Attack in Iraq

headline: Chefs’ Camaraderie Lifts Basque Cuisine

headline: Sanctions Eased, Iran Sends Black Market a Strategic Warning
abstract: A billionaire businessman’s death sentence signals a crackdown on violators, but Iran still needs underground networks in order to recoup money and generate trade despite remaining obstacles.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The pastry shop, tucked away in an affluent west Tehran neighborhood and selling Disney-themed cakes and party hats, is not particularly notable except for one thing: It is owned and operated by Iran’s powerful Ministry of Petroleum.

headline: In Louisiana, the Poor Lack Legal Defense
keywords: ['Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Poverty', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The constitutional obligation to provide criminal defense for the poor has been endangered by funding problems across the country, but nowhere more so than in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: ABBEVILLE, La. — It was arraignment morning at the Vermilion Parish courthouse, the monthly catalog of bad decisions, hot tempers, hard hearts and hard luck. Natasha George, who until recently was one of 10 lawyers defending the poor of the parish, stood before the full gallery of defendants.

headline: Colombian Children Pay High Price Amid Peace Talks, U.N. Says
abstract: A quarter-million were displaced and 1,000 were recruited by nonstate combatants during the last three years of negotiations.

headline: A View of ISIS’s Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
abstract: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
lead_paragraph: Investigators found crates’ worth of disposable cellphones. All around Paris, they found traces of improved bomb-making materials. And they began piecing together a multilayered terrorist attack that evaded detection until much too late.

headline: ‘John Kasich Is Presidential,’ Ad Says, Implying His Rivals Are Decidedly Not
abstract: A new ad from the “super PAC” supporting Gov. John Kasich hopefully asserts that “character still matters.”
lead_paragraph: The party of Lincoln, Eisenhower and Reagan, thrown into turmoil by childish insults and riotous campaign rallies. “What’s happened?” asks a voice with the gruffness of a man old enough to remember at least two of those lionized leaders.

headline: El Niño Upsets Seasons and Upends Lives Worldwide
keywords: ['El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Drought', 'Floods', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Malnutrition', 'Medicine and Health']

headline: After Trailing Duke by 27, Yale Musters a Last Thrill on Its Way Out
abstract: Yale valiantly fought back, cutting the Duke lead to 3 points in the final minute, but succumbed in the end, ending their most successful basketball season in more than a century.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — At some point in every tournament game, the outcome becomes obvious and the focus for the loser invariably turns to the journey. Yale being Yale, that moment was bound to come sooner rather than later in the N.C.A.A. tournament, especially with a second-round matchup Saturday against Duke at Dunkin’ Donuts Center.

headline: Forced to Renew an Old Rivalry With Kentucky, Indiana Prevails
abstract: The Hoosiers and the Kentucky Wildcats, two legacy programs that ended a long-running nonconference series in 2011-12, played a tight game that ended in a slight upset.

headline: Jason Day Is Feeling the Heat as He Pursues a Wire-to-Wire Victory
abstract: Day on Sunday will try to become the first PGA Tour wire-to-wire winner since he pulled off the feat at the BMW Championship last September.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Anyone who wandered in out of the rain to catch the tail end of Jason Day’s news conference on Saturday might have thought he was describing having to drive home in clothes that were soaked to his skin. Day’s discomfort was a theme he kept returning to, but it had nothing to do with the awful weather that turned Bay Hill Golf Club into a sodden sponge in the afternoon. He was forecasting an uncomfortable 24 hours because of his standing as the tournament’s 54-hole leader.

headline: When Middle Tennessee Won, Syracuse’s Coaches Were Ready
abstract: Syracuse has already prepared to play a team that few people outside Murfreesboro, Tenn., expected would be playing in the tournament’s second round.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — After Syracuse beat Dayton, 70-51, on Friday, several of the Orange’s coaches watched the Midwest Region game between No. 15-seeded Middle Tennessee State and No. 2-seeded Michigan State at Scottrade Center. They knew they would be playing the winner.

headline: American Firm, Starwood, Signs Deal to Manage Hotels in Cuba
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The agreement, inked the day before President Obama arrives, will make this the first American chain to run hotels on the island in more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Starwood Hotels and Resorts is set become the first American hospitality chain to run hotels in Cuba in more than half a century, signaling the return of American companies to the Cuban travel market as the island gears up to receive a surge in visits from the United States.

headline: Well-Traveled Serb Finds a Home in Hawaii
abstract: Stefan Jankovic was born in Serbia in 1993, not long after the start of the Balkan civil war, and since then has made stops in Toronto, Florida, Missouri and Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Drago Jankovic was working Saturday morning in Canada, driving his truck, when he pulled out his phone and recorded a video for his son Stefan, who a day earlier helped Hawaii defeat No. 4-seeded California in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Drago was so full of pride, he sang a Hawaiian song and shouted as he drove.

headline: For Wisconsin’s Scorekeeper, Most Impressive Number Is His Age: 83
abstract: Otto Puls is in his 53rd year as the scorekeeper for the Badgers, who will play Xavier in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday.

lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Even for the sport’s best, any success against top-ranked Novak Djokovic — however relative — must be appreciated.

headline: Virginia’s Offense Comes Alive Against Butler
abstract: The Cavaliers, regarded as a ferocious defensive team, turned themselves into an offensive locomotive against Butler.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Virginia added to an unconventional N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament on Saturday night, but not in the manner of the upset stories that have ruled the first four days. The Cavaliers, regarded as a ferocious defensive team, turned themselves into an offensive locomotive against Butler.

headline: Protester Punched and Kicked at Donald Trump Rally in Tucson

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s second rally in Arizona on Saturday was studded with repeated interruptions from protesters, along with an incident in which a member of the crowd punched and kicked a protester and another that involved Mr. Trump’s campaign manager.

lead_paragraph: Sabina Devi Pendse and John Ivey Byck were married March 19 at Haven’s Kitchen, a cafe, cooking school and event space in New York. John C. Collins Jr., a friend of the groom’s family and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Spurs Add to Streak as Warriors Fall to 62-7
abstract: With Saturday night’s victory, San Antonio has now won 33 straight regular-season home games against Golden State dating to 1997.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The Golden State Warriors have been a history-making machine this season, overshadowing nearly every team that tries to impede their progress. The San Antonio Spurs, though, are assembling a magical season of their own, and they stifled the Warriors, 87-79, on Saturday night at AT&T Center to make a little history of their own.

headline: Trump Didn’t Put the Con in Conservatism
abstract: Flimflam came before the fall.
lead_paragraph: So, I’m in a time zone far, far away — and also still shaky, although I’m finally managing to hold down some food. Output will still be low, but I wanted to note something about the reactions to the John Harwood interview with Paul Ryan, which are very relevant to understanding the Republican mess.

headline: 1941: 3,000 Pigeons to Go Abroad
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: In a thinly-veiled ruse to skirt American neutrality, the birds were sent to “pigeon fanciers on the other side of the Atlantic’’ in 1941. Their true destination was the R.A.F.
lead_paragraph: Fear of breaking the United States neutrality law was neatly handled yesterday by Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General in New York, when he decided to send 3,000 young American homing pigeons to ‘‘pigeon fanciers on the other side of the Atlantic’’ instead of to the Royal Air Force, for which they are intended.
