lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: 1966: U.S. to Allow Wives’ Return To Vietnam
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. allows some government wives to join husbands in Saigon in 1966.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Despite the threat of terrorist activity against Americans here, the State Department has made a quiet decision to allow some governmental wives to join their husbands in Saigon. Most U.S. officials here, even those in the military who apparently will not be able to bring over wives, give their approval.

headline: At Site of Gay Man’s Murder, a Street Corner Acknowledges Its Past
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A street corner in Jackson Heights, Queens, commemorates Julio Rivera, who was killed in an attack in July 1990 that the authorities later called a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: There is little about the intersection of 78th Street and 37th Avenue to distinguish it from any other corner in Jackson Heights. Every day, dozens of parents — from dozens of countries — waiting for their children to be dismissed from school stand beneath a sign declaring the intersection “Julio Rivera Corner.” Many of them probably do not even notice it, yet with those three words, the sign acknowledges a tragic — and ultimately transforming — moment in Queens.

headline: Donald Trump Courts Wary Jewish Voters
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Donald J. Trump, whose disregard for the sensitivities of various religious and ethnic groups has hit a nerve among Jewish organizations, faces a difficult sell Monday.
lead_paragraph: On paper, Donald J. Trump is the last candidate one would expect to raise eyebrows within the Jewish community.

headline: Geoffrey H. Hartman, Scholar Who Saw Literary Criticism as Art, Dies at 86
abstract: Long associated with the Yale School of criticism, Professor Hartman examined a wide range of subjects, including Wordsworth, Judaica and trauma.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey H. Hartman, a literary critic whose work took in the Romantic poets, Judaic sacred texts, Holocaust studies, deconstruction and the workings of memory — and took on the very function of criticism itself — died on March 14 at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 86.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Relaxing at the market, trying Korean noodles and meatballs and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: Tyler Perry presents his live TV musical “The Passion.” And “Sisters,” starring Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, is streaming online.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Perry’s Easter season extravaganza, “The Passion,” is the latest entry in the growing genre of live TV musicals. And America’s favorite gal pals, Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, are back together in “Sisters,” streaming online.

headline: Turkish Member of ISIS Carried Out Istanbul Bombing, Official Says
abstract: Mehmet Ozturk was the perpetrator of a suicide bombing that killed four foreigners in Istanbul on Saturday, the Turkish interior minister said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Turkish member of the Islamic State was the perpetrator of a suicide bombing that killed four foreigners in Istanbul over the weekend, the Turkish interior minister said on Sunday.

headline: ‘Zootopia’ Is Still the Top Film, While ‘Allegiant’ Falters
abstract: The third installment of the ‘Divergent’ series, which received bad reviews came in second, only taking in $29.1 million at North American theaters.
lead_paragraph: No amount of slick marketing can sell a terrible movie.

headline: Why the Republicans May Do Little in Congress
abstract: The Republicans’ congressional strategy for the next six months will most likely be a variation of rope-a-dope, papering over schisms in their party.
lead_paragraph: Remember the first branch of American government? With all the attention to the presidential race and the partisan fight over President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court, Congress seems an afterthought.

headline: Donald Trump Faults Protesters Over Violence, Not Their Assailants
abstract: Mr. Trump said there had been a double standard in media coverage of recent episodes at his rallies in which his supporters had attacked protesters.
lead_paragraph: After his rallies in Arizona this weekend were marked by protests and violence, Donald J. Trump on Sunday complained of a “double standard” in coverage of those incidents and defended his campaign manager after video showed the manager grabbing a demonstrator by the collar and yanking him backward during a rally in Tucson.

headline: As Obama Arrives, Cuba Tightens Grip on Dissent
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Cuba, a police state working out how much to open up to the world and to its own people, has gone above and beyond to prevent embarrassing surprises.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama touched down in Cuba on Sunday, pledging to interact directly with the Cuban people and accelerate engagement between the United States and Cuba after more than a half-century of hostility.

headline: ‘Ip Man 3’ Distributor Is Punished Over Box-Office Fraud
abstract: Chinese regulators cracked down on Beijing Max Screen over inflation of ticket sales for the movie “Ip Man 3,” starring Donnie Yen and Mike Tyson.
lead_paragraph: Chinese film regulators have cracked down on the film distributor Beijing Max Screen over inflation of ticket sales for the movie “Ip Man 3.” Max Screen has admitted to inflating box-office figures by more than $8.6 million, and has been barred from releasing movies for a month, according to Xinhua News Agency.

headline: Sherwin-Williams to Buy Valspar for $9.3 Billion
abstract: The companies, two of the biggest names in paints, said they did not expect problems with antitrust regulators.
lead_paragraph: Sherwin-Williams’s famous logo shows a can of red paint pouring over a globe with the slogan “Cover the Earth.”

headline: A Signature ISIS Explosive in Europe
abstract: Triacetone triperoxide, which was used in the Paris attacks in November, has become the Islamic State's explosive of choice in Europe. Specialists in bomb detection explain why.
lead_paragraph: Triacetone triperoxide, which was used in the Paris attacks in November, has become the Islamic State's explosive of choice in Europe. Specialists in bomb detection explain why.

headline: Seeking Access to Facebook in China, Zuckerberg Courts Risks
abstract: The founder of the social networking service has learned Mandarin and charmed audiences. But with a public presence in China comes official scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In terms of publicity, it was a great weekend for Mark Zuckerberg in China.

headline: Bus Crash in Spain Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Buses', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'International Study and Teaching']
abstract: The bus was on its way back to Barcelona from a day of festivities in Valencia, and officials said they believed most of the victims were foreign students.
lead_paragraph: At least 13 students died on Sunday when a bus crashed on a highway in eastern Spain while on its way back to Barcelona from a day of festivities in Valencia, Spanish officials said.

headline: Garland Shouldn’t Be Considered After Election, McConnell Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, dismissed an idea that had been proposed by some Republicans as a protection against a more liberal nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, on Sunday dismissed the possibility of Republicans considering President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee after the November election, even if a Democrat were elected president or Republicans lost their majority.

headline: College Sharpshooters Add Theatrics to Their Quivers
abstract: In the N.C.A.A. tournament, a successful 3-point shot can elicit an elaborate pantomime involving a bow and arrow.
lead_paragraph: Cupid. Artemis. Robin Hood. Katniss Everdeen. Jamal Murray. Great archers, all of them.

headline: Villanova Routs Iowa to Advance to Round of 16
abstract: No. 2-seeded Villanova will meet No. 3-seeded Miami on Thursday in Louisville, Ky. The Wildcats had not advanced to the second week of the tournament in their last five appearances.
lead_paragraph: Since Villanova arrived in Brooklyn last week, the Wildcats have been shadowed by questions about their recent inability to advance past the round of 32 at the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Majority Threshold ‘Unfair’ in G.O.P. Nomination Process, Donald Trump Complains
abstract: Mr. Trump said on ABC on Sunday that he might not be able to clear the delegate threshold to clinch the Republican nomination outright because the campaign started off with so many candidates.
lead_paragraph: With the prospect of a contested convention looming over the Republican presidential primary, Donald J. Trump on Sunday complained about the party’s rules requiring a candidate to have a majority of delegates to clinch the nomination outright.

headline: After Loss, Warriors Are Bullish as Ever in Pursuit of a Record
abstract: Golden State remains focused on making N.B.A. history despite losing to its main rival in the West, the Spurs, in San Antonio on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Draymond Green of the Golden State Warriors was minutes removed from a rare loss when he fielded a question about the team’s pursuit of the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls for the best record in N.B.A. history. Green asked for clarification: What sort of work did the Warriors have ahead of them? Eleven wins in their final 13 games?

headline: John Kasich Says G.O.P. Senators Should Meet With Supreme Court Nominee
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio suggested on CBS that he might consider Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s pick, for the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio expressed openness this weekend to considering Judge Merrick B. Garland for the Supreme Court, only to later clarify that he was just being polite and would not, in fact, choose him for the court.

headline: Shukhov Tower in Moscow Placed on Monuments Watch List
abstract: The broadcast transmission tower has been placed on a list of endangered global cultural heritage sites.
lead_paragraph: The Shukhov Tower, a 1920s broadcast transmission tower in Moscow that is a landmark of modernist structural engineering, has been placed on the 2016 World Monuments Fund Watch list of endangered global cultural heritage sites.

headline: Cubans Pack the Streets for a Glimpse of President Obama
abstract: The president’s visit, the first by an American leader in nearly nine decades, holds the potential to exorcise one of the last ghosts of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Shouts of “U.S.A.!” and “Obama!” echoed over the stone plazas as President Obama and his family made their way around rain-slicked courtyards in Old Havana on Sunday evening, savoring the adulation of Cubans welcoming him warmly despite a driving rain as he began a history-making visit.

headline: Hillary Clinton Campaign Has Raised Millions Toward Beating Bernie Sanders
abstract: Despite donors urging her campaign to shift its focus to the general election, Hillary Clinton’s team continued to raise money for the primary by building up its grass-roots fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign raised more than $30.1 million in February to be used toward defeating Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary and began March with $30.8 million on hand, according to the campaign’s Federal Election Commission report released on Sunday.

headline: Amazon Leans on Government in Its Quest to Be a Delivery Powerhouse
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Delivery Services', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: New uses for commercial drones, 33-foot trucks, improved roads and bridges: Amazon and its lobbyists urge officials to support expansion efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since Jeff Bezos started the website Amazon to sell books, he has wrestled with how to deliver its products as quickly and cheaply as possible. Today, Amazon, now a retail giant, remains obsessed with this issue, building its own fleet of drones, buying trailers for trucks and signing up drivers for on-demand deliveries.

headline: Julie Kent on Her Plans for Showcasing Washington Dancers
abstract: Ms. Kent says her role as artistic director at Washington Ballet is all about embracing change.
lead_paragraph: Julie Kent told her Instagram followers about her new job earlier this month with a link to an article and a single word: “Surprise!”

headline: Review: ‘Witchcraft: The Jazz Magic of Cy Coleman’ Summons a Bygone Era
abstract: This show of Coleman’s stand-alone pop songs at the 92nd Street Y turns the clock back to the witty Manhattan night life of the mid-1960s.
lead_paragraph: By the end of Saturday’s opening-night performance of “Witchcraft: The Jazz Magic of Cy Coleman” at the 92nd Street Y, anyone present could be forgiven for imagining that the clock had magically been turned back to 1965 or thereabouts. In a shimmering musical mirage, the bygone Manhattan night life of 50 years ago came into view.

headline: Review: Orpheus’s Shifting Glimmers From Angled Glass
abstract: The chamber group performed Harold Meltzer’s “Vision Machine,” which was inspired by a Jean Nouvel building, at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: To New Yorkers whose daily commute takes them along the West Side Highway, Jean Nouvel’s building at 100 West 11th Avenue, which its architect describes as a “vision machine,” is a familiar sight, a curved structure set with thousands of angled glass panes that make a kaleidoscope of the blues, grays and greens of the sky and river.

headline: Classical Playlist: Brouwer, ‘Cantate Domino’ and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Chamorro, bandurria; Pedro Mateo González, guitar (Naxos)

headline: Review: Trinity Wall Street Presents Ginastera’s Raging ‘Cantata Para América Mágica’
abstract: Part of the “Revolutionaries” series marking the centenary of Ginastera’s birth, the program paired the cantata with Stravinsky’s “Les Noces.”
lead_paragraph: In 1961, two works by Alberto Ginastera — his Piano Concerto No. 1 and “Cantata Para América Mágica” — were given their premieres in Washington as part of the second Inter-American Music Festival. Have they ever been played in such proximity since?

headline: ‘War of the Worlds’ Shape-Shifts Onto the London Stage
abstract: This stage production, whose team includes the album’s writer, cranks up the excess of “Jeff Wayne’s Musical Version of the War of the Worlds.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Americans, “War of the Worlds” evokes images of panic and devastation in New Jersey set to the voice of Orson Welles crackling over the radio in 1938. But in Britain, a 1978 prog-rock album that dramatized H. G. Wells’s tale of Martian takeover is far better known.

headline: Review: ‘Kapoor & Sons’ Centers on an Indian Family’s Flaws
abstract: This film, directed by Shakun Batra, features comedy, drama, money troubles and at least one secret.
lead_paragraph: “Kapoor & Sons — Since 1921” isn’t about the dynastic family of Hindi movie directors, actors and producers. But it does star one of them, Rishi Kapoor (son of Raj, father of Ranbir), who heavily (and skillfully) made up plays Dadu, the about-to-be-90 paterfamilias of a clan made unhappy by the usual secrets and lies and long-cherished grudges.

headline: Flinging Emojis, Twitch Chatters Revel as Julia Child Cooks
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: This was the second time Twitch, a video streaming site, turned to a dead public television icon to branch out from its usual game-heavy content.
lead_paragraph: When I was a teenager, my friends and I had a blast watching television together — often really bad television — and mocking it ceaselessly. We became the entertainment, not whatever clumsy dialogue or plot twist we derided.

headline: Last-Second Tip-In Shines Spotlight on a Notre Dame Guard
abstract: The sixth-seeded Irish advanced to the round of 16 after overcoming a late 5-point deficit to defeat the No. 14-seeded Lumberjacks.
lead_paragraph: Entering Notre Dame’s matchup with Stephen F. Austin, Rex Pflueger was a sparingly used, little-known freshman guard for the Irish who had not scored a field goal since March 5.

headline: Review: Balanchine and Shakespeare Catch Some Waves in Miami
abstract: The Miami City Ballet has set its new production of Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” underwater.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As if to illustrate the effects of climate change, Miami City Ballet has set its new production of George Balanchine’s two-act “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” underwater. Transposing the action to the waterways of South Florida, the production is a peak of this company’s 30th-anniversary season. Although the staging does not makes much sense on its own terms and in no way improves the ballet, its daftness is agreeably harmless: You can vaguely enjoy some of its fantasies while seriously loving the choreography. And the Miamians’ dancing has all the wonderful immediacy that makes this company valuable.

headline: Review: In ‘Switched On,’ John Elder Robison’s Asperger’s Brain Is Changed
abstract: In this book, Mr. Robison tells how a treatment awakened him emotionally.
lead_paragraph: From an early age, it was clear that John Elder Robison had been wired with extra fibers for appreciating music. He could easily hear the difference between one kind of Fender bass and another. He could recognize which of 100 speakers in a sound system was groaning in distress. He could take any musical gizmo and, as Nigel Tufnel might say, make it go to 11. (His talent for creating fire-breathing guitars earned him a gig with Kiss as a young man.)

headline: Anger After Official Says WTA Players Ride on ‘Coattails’ of Men
abstract: Remarks by the director of the BNP Paribas Open overshadowed Victoria Azarenka’s defeat of Serena Williams, 6-4, 6-4, in the women’s final.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The final Sunday of the BNP Paribas Open, one of the biggest joint ATP-WTA events outside the Grand Slam tournaments, is often a showcase for tennis’s superstars, with the women’s and men’s finals played back to back.

headline: SXSW 2016
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Scenes from concerts by Iggy Pop, Drake and other performers at South by Southwest in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from concerts by Iggy Pop, Drake and other performers at South by Southwest in Austin, Tex.

headline: SXSW: From Exclusive Performances to Cellphone Souvenirs
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The initial lure of South by Southwest in 1987 was site-specific and ephemeral; now this music festival generates content for people who don’t have to be there.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — “I want everybody to download that song, and I want all of you singing that anthem.” Sentiments like that were heard all over South by Southwest music festival, which brought more than 2,000 acts to perform here over five frenetic days and nights. But that request came from Michelle Obama as she promoted “This Is for My Girls,” a single that benefits Let Girls Learn, a project encouraging girls’ education worldwide that was written by Diane Warren and is performed by Missy Elliott, Janelle Monáe, Kelly Rowland, Kelly Clarkson and others. The first lady shared a panel with Ms. Warren and Ms. Elliott along with Queen Latifah and Sophia Bush, extolling the cultural and economic benefits of girls’ education as well as diversity in every field. (Responding to an audience question, Ms. Obama also ruled out the possibility of her running for president.)

headline: Top-Secret
abstract: Michael Hawkins returns, and so do I.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Molweni, sawubona and hallo! Those are greetings in Xhosa, Zulu and Afrikaans, respectively.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Trust in Turkey and Greece on Migrants Comes With Risks
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Critics of the German leader’s new deal say it may violate human rights standards, particularly as Turkey veers from democracy and Greece struggles to process refugees.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel, alternately lauded for courage and reviled for recklessness in admitting more than one million migrants into Germany, finally has what she wanted: a European Union accord with Turkey to reduce and manage the influx.

headline: Jessica Lang Dance to Put Down Roots in Long Island City
abstract: “I hope that we can be a part of the fabric of the community,” Ms. Lang said.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Lang Dance, after several nomadic years of renting studio space around New York, is putting down roots in the culture-rich neighborhood of Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Paris Suspect Salah Abdeslam Said to Envision a ‘Restart,’ Officials Say
abstract: Belgium’s foreign minister also said there was an expanding number of people thought to be directly or indirectly involved in the Nov. 13 attacks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Salah Abdeslam, the man believed to be a direct participant in the November attacks in Paris who was arrested on Friday, was planning to “restart something” in Brussels, Belgium’s foreign minister said on Sunday.

headline: Tensions Rise in David Cameron’s Government Over E.U. Vote
abstract: The prime minister faces deepening fissures in his government, underscoring the risk that his party could be damaged over Britain’s ties to the Continent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With a referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union fewer than 100 days away, Prime Minister David Cameron faced deepening fissures within his government on Sunday, underscoring the risk that his Conservative Party could be torn apart over the country’s relationship with the Continent.

headline: Greece Struggles to Enforce Migrant Accord on First Day
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: After a European Union deal with Turkey took effect, migrants by the hundreds continued to reach the Greek islands, where processing centers were not yet adequately staffed.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece and the European Union scrambled on Sunday to put in place the people and the facilities needed to carry out a new deal intended to address the migrant crisis that is roiling Europe, as hundreds of migrants in rubber dinghies continued to land on the Greek islands from Turkey.

headline: U.S. Casts Wary Eye on Australian Port Leased by Chinese
keywords: ['Ports', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: Critics contend that the Chinese bought a front-row seat to spy on naval operations at the port of Darwin, which serves as a host base for the United States Marines.
lead_paragraph: DARWIN, Australia — The port in this remote northern Australian outpost is little more than a graying old wharf jutting into crocodile-infested waters. On a recent day, there was stifling heat but not a ship in sight. “Our pissy little port,” as John Robinson, a flamboyant local tycoon, calls it.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 21
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

abstract: Upstarts from smaller conferences largely hit a wall Sunday in the tournament, where most of the top seeds again prevailed.
lead_paragraph: Cinderella almost looked like a Lumberjack.

headline: Kraft Reveals Revamped Mac and Cheese, 50 Million Boxes Later
abstract: Last year Kraft reformulated its macaroni and cheese without artificial dyes or preservatives. Months later, the company told the public it had made the switch.
lead_paragraph: USUALLY when companies come out with a new and improved formula, they want the public to know. But when the item in question is an iconic food product, the calculus gets tougher. Every marketer remembers with a shudder the cautionary tale of New Coke.

headline: Manhattan Incompatibility: A Poem
abstract: Clashing restaurants, the High Line versus a run around the reservoir, bottle clubs as opposed to red wine: Heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hollywood Divided Over Movie Streaming Service
abstract: The Screening Room, a start-up supported by AMC, wants consumers to pay $50 to rent big-budget movies on the same day they arrive in theaters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tech entrepreneurs are always rolling into Hollywood with new services that are supposed to modernize the movie business. If only the dusty, old, dimwitted studios and theater companies would stop dragging their feet and sign up, all of the entertainment industry’s problems would be solved.

headline: Billy Eppler Is Rebuilding the Angels, but on a Fast Track
abstract: Billy Eppler, the Angels’ new general manager, who worked 11 seasons for the Yankees’ Brian Cashman, is adept at blending scouting and analytics.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Everybody wears red around the Los Angeles Angels. It has been their primary color since 2002, when they won their only World Series. They often wear red jerseys with red numerals. Their executives wear red golf shirts. Their players wear red undershirts, sweatshirts and shorts. The 3-foot Darth Vader figurine in the middle of the locker room? He wears a red jersey, too.

headline: Hawaii Struggles to Keep Rail Project From Becoming a Boondoggle
abstract: Critics of Honolulu’s elevated rail system, which is two years behind schedule, say too much effort and taxpayer money have been spent to give up on the plan now.
lead_paragraph: KAPOLEI, Hawaii — From the start — when Honolulu officials began talking about building a 20-mile elevated train line near the southern coast of Oahu — there were concerns. How much would it cost? What would it do to the character of a state that has long celebrated its natural beauty and isolation? Can an island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean handle the kind of ambitious public works project one would associate with urban centers like Boston and New York?

headline: Cash (From Cans) Is King
abstract: The Thrifty Redemption Center in Borough Park, Brooklyn, where individuals can get paid for empty bottles and cans. The city has tried to limit the practice.
lead_paragraph: The Thrifty Redemption Center in Borough Park, Brooklyn, where individuals can get paid for empty bottles and cans. The city has tried to limit the practice.

headline: New York City Fights Scavengers Over a Treasure: Trash
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Salvage', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: As the city sets new recycling goals, it is cracking down on people and teams who pick metals, cardboard and plastic from the trash and cash them in.
lead_paragraph: The video begins with ominous notes from a piano and an image of crime scene tape. The camera pans to men hunched over garbage pails, sifting for bottles, and a stoop-shouldered woman towing a shopping cart full of cans. Some might feel sympathy for these collectors, but the video makes clear that the New York City Sanitation Department, which made the video and posted it online, wanted them to be seen as something else: common criminals.

headline: Donald Trump Is a Punch Line for Obama, Who Is Getting More Jokes Ready
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The president has made so many direct or indirect references to Mr. Trump that the real estate tycoon has become something of a stump-speech trope for the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump’s transformation from reality TV star to presidential candidate threatening to tear apart the Republican Party is eliciting a mixture of disbelief, outrage and laughter among Democrats, and none more so than President Obama.

headline: Russian Town Says Bleak Film Depiction Went Heavy on the Vodka
abstract: Residents of Teriberka, while not embracing the gloomy movie “Leviathan,” take comfort in the view that their home is no worse than countless other places.
lead_paragraph: TERIBERKA, Russia — Tatyana Trubilina, the head of the local council in this desolate Russian outpost on the Barents Sea, wanted to make a few things absolutely clear: Not all 1,000 residents are alcoholics; not everyone is depressed; and nobody has committed suicide, at least not recently.

headline: A Manchester Derby With an Unfamiliar Focus: The Future
abstract: For the past decade, City or United finished first or second in the Premier League. Mediocre seasons for both meant that changes were in the offing.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The 171st game between Manchester City and Manchester United was, much like the previous 170, emotional. There were fans in blue (City) and fans in red (United). There was chanting (some of it encouraging) and singing (some of it crude). There was, it seemed, a fair bit of prematch drinking. All pretty standard.

headline: As Coal’s Future Grows Murkier, Banks Pull Financing
abstract: After helping to drive Wall Street’s profits for generations, the coal industry is in a free fall, and even daring investors are reluctant to risk trying to save it.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of miners were on strike and coal prices were skyrocketing in October 1902. Afraid of unrest, President Theodore Roosevelt sought the help of John Pierpont Morgan.

headline: Obama Begins Visit to Cuba
abstract: President Obama on Sunday became the first sitting United States president to visit the island since 1928.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Sunday became the first sitting United States president to visit the island since 1928.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elderly', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Mr. Sanders’s message has made him the choice of the Snapchat generation, but Mrs. Clinton is doing fine counting on voters who came of age with Polaroids.
lead_paragraph: LAKE WORTH, Fla. — The afternoon of the Florida primaries last week, Sylvia Wolfson, 87, and more than a dozen other retirees scurried around an office set up with trays of cookies from Costco and large-print instructions on how to unlock the restroom door.

headline: Queens Bouncer With Imposing Physique Is Remembered as a Peacemaker
abstract: Elsworth Reid, 43, died this month after trying to break up a fight at a restaurant in the South Ozone Park neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: He had the look of an enforcer, a tough man with 22-inch biceps. But the bouncer known by almost everyone as Dale had a reputation around Johnny’s, a hopping Caribbean restaurant and bar in the South Ozone Park neighborhood of Queens, for his ability to ease alcohol-inflamed tensions without having to get physical.

Reynolds Tobacco Company participated in an international money laundering scheme, using drug money to buy tobacco, in violation of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO.

abstract: The artificial heart became a media sensation in the 1980s as it both raised hopes and spread controversy. Today, its impact on medical science is still playing out in surprising ways.
lead_paragraph: The artificial heart became a media sensation in the 1980s as it both raised hopes and spread controversy. Today, its impact on medical science is still playing out in surprising ways.

abstract: While Mr. Trump’s presidential bid benefits from constant coverage, that coverage is also a lifeline to news outlets as they jockey for survival.

headline: Making Bracket Wasn’t a Given, but Syracuse Looks as if It Belongs
abstract: The Orange sweated making the tournament at all. The Blue Raiders had to knock off a No. 2 seed to advance. In the end, Syracuse pulled away in the second half to make the round of 16.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Few expected to see either team playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday. Syracuse had needed the equivalent of a favorable roll in the men’s basketball selection committee room one week earlier even to be in the bracket. And Middle Tennessee State had to accomplish probably the biggest upset of the tournament to advance to the round of 32.

headline: Oregon Slips Past St. Joseph’s; Texas A&M Needs Two Overtimes
abstract: The Ducks held on against the eighth-seeded Hawks, and the third-seeded Aggies overcame a 10-point deficit with less than 30 seconds left in regulation on their way to a win over Northern Iowa.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — With about 90 seconds remaining, trailing by 1 point, Oregon zipped the ball around until it found Dillon Brooks, its best shooter, open on the wing. St. Joseph’s players kept swiveling their heads, trying to keep up and stay in position, but with this Oregon team, no matter where the ball landed, it would not have been ideal.

headline: Self-Correcting Beyond a Web Era Marked by Sensationalism
keywords: ['Privacy', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: By the time a jury awarded Hulk Hogan damages from Gawker for its publication of a sex tape, the site and others were already self-correcting in the direction of privacy.
lead_paragraph: The trial involving Gawker and Terry Bollea, better known as Hulk Hogan, over the publication of a sex video raised timeless legal questions about privacy and freedom of the press. The result, with the jury awarding Mr. Bollea $115 million in compensatory damages, could threaten Gawker’s existence.

headline: For Potvins, a Chance to Reflect on a Shared Islanders’ Legacy

headline: Artificial Hearts Ticking Along Decades After Jarvik-7 Debate
abstract: A device first tried in 1982 extended lives but raised ethical questions. While its descendants are used only as temporary “bridges” to transplants, regulators are mulling the possibility of again approving permanent implants.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, meaning 1982, there was the Jarvik-7, an artificial heart made of plastic and metal and intended for permanent implantation in a human being.

headline: Jason Day Leads All the Way at Arnold Palmer Invitational
abstract: Jason Day became the first wire-to-wire leader of this tournament since Fred Couples in 1992.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Jason Day was hitting out of the sand to a green sloping toward a water hazard. If he got up and down for par, Day would win the Arnold Palmer Invitational by one stroke. The shot was not easy, and the circumstances made it harder. The crowd ringing the 18th green at Bay Hill Golf Club included the tournament host, Palmer, who was seated in a cart a few yards away with an unimpeded view of Day’s sandy soliloquy.

headline: Four Candidates Seek Westchester County District Attorney Post
abstract: The position is in a wealthy commuter area that has helped lift occupants to higher-profile jobs, including the chief judge of New York State.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — On its face, the job of Westchester County district attorney seems like a fairly staid one. An affluent bedroom community of New York City, with pockets of poverty, the county is rife with neither violent crime nor corporate malfeasance.

headline: Affymetrix Rejects $1.5 Billion Takeover Bid
abstract: The company said the offer, which was meant to derail its sale to Thermo Fisher Scientific, was not a “superior proposal” to the Thermo Fisher deal.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Affymetrix, a maker of advanced genetic analysis technology, on Sunday rejected an 11th-hour takeover bid meant to derail its planned sale to Thermo Fisher Scientific for $1.3 billion.

headline: For Transgender New Yorkers, a Center of Their Own in the Bronx
abstract: The Bronx Trans Collective will be the city’s first major multiservice center specifically for transgender people, offering programs and services that were previously scattered across different sites.
lead_paragraph: Eli Berry cannot go to stores or restaurants without being asked if he is a man or a woman. A mall security guard once demanded that he show identification to use a public men’s room.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']

Levey, executive director of the FreedomWorks Foundation, a conservative group determined to block President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, sat with his communications director for a quick review of what his message to the American public should be.

headline: When M.L.B. Broke the Ice With a Game in Havana
abstract: Ahead of the Tampa Bay Rays playing in Havana on Tuesday, a look back at the Baltimore Orioles’ exhibition game against the Cuban national baseball team in 1999.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, the Tampa Bay Rays will play an exhibition game against the Cuban national baseball team in Havana. The moment will surely stand out, but it will not be nearly as groundbreaking as the game the Baltimore Orioles played there 17 years ago.

headline: Maryland’s First 3-Pointer, on 16th Try, Goes a Long Way
abstract: The fifth-seeded Terrapins, who had trouble this season with spunky teams, held off the 13th-seeded Rainbow Warriors to advance to a round of 16 matchup against top-seeded Kansas.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — The Hawaii guards had been harassing Maryland guard Melo Trimble all game long, pressing him, bumping him, chasing him. The Rainbow Warriors had set the tone with their aggressive play, getting in the Terrapins’ faces, trying to intimidate the higher seed, and it seemed to be working, as Maryland missed its first 15 3-point attempts.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 6: The Adventures of Richie and Ernst
abstract: Surprisingly, Richie does more cocaine this week.
lead_paragraph: This week’s “Vinyl” is an hour of Richie and Devon revisiting their pasts. For Devon, that means staying with her friend Ingrid at the Chelsea Hotel, talking about how lonely she is in Connecticut and posing nude for Ingrid’s artist boyfriend. For Richie, that means snorting cocaine and then snorting more cocaine.

headline: Q. and A.: Noah Bean on Portraying David Bowie
abstract: Mr. Bean discusses his cameo as Mr. Bowie in Sunday night’s episode of “Vinyl,” which was filmed months before the musician’s death in January.
lead_paragraph: Portraying David Bowie at his 1970s peak was a tall enough order for an actor while the rock icon was still alive. But to be the first in those platform shoes and that red mullet since Mr. Bowie’s death in January, at the age of 69, added another layer of anxieties.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 14: Tennessee Waterfalls, Strategic Bites and a Tragic Loss
abstract: It’s as we always knew — Eugene’s hair is the true source of his power.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t wake up and face your what? The suspense is killing me!

abstract: Lucy Prebble’s play at the Barrow Street Theater centers on a young man and woman who question their emotions during a four-week pharmaceutical trial.

headline: Minnesota’s Amanda Kessel Tops Off Return With a National Title

lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.H. — As she savored the moment — an unexpected joy, if one was to believe the N.C.A.A. seeding committee — Amanda Kessel had one overriding thought: This was why she had come back.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: San Antonio at Oklahoma City
abstract: The Spurs, whose remarkable season has somehow been quiet, will meet a Thunder team that may have reached a turning point.
lead_paragraph: The San Antonio Spurs defeated the Golden State Warriors, 87-79, on Saturday. The loss was the Warriors’ first to a team in the N.B.A.’s top tier. Previously, they had been 1-0 against the Spurs, 3-0 against the Oklahoma City Thunder and 2-0 against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 9: Bobby the Profiteer
abstract: This is the first episode to throw Bobby’s “master-of-the-universe” status into question.
lead_paragraph: “Axelrod Hall will not be named Axelrod Hall forever,” I predicted in the recap to the second episode of “Billions,” when Bobby moved to buy the naming rights to a symphony hall and etch his name in the firmament. But who could have guessed the request to remove the Axelrod name would come this soon?
