headline: A Presidential Rebuke to the Saudis
abstract: President Obama has forced a conversation about the increasingly troubled American-Saudi relationship into the open.
lead_paragraph: It is rare for an American president to skewer a friendly government publicly. But that’s what President Obama did last week in presenting a well-considered analysis of troubles in the relationship with Saudi Arabia.

headline: Will a Liberal Supreme Court Limit Money in Politics?
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Instead of rolling back Citizens United, we should seek to make it easier for people without wealth to run and be heard.
lead_paragraph: The words “Citizens United,” especially when amplified by a vigorous Democratic presidential nomination fight, have become a potent shorthand for the influence of great wealth over American democracy. With the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, the possibility of reversing the 2010 decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Committee quickly became a live issue in the election and in the shadowboxing over Justice Scalia’s replacement.

headline: What Mexico Thinks About Trump
abstract: Could the candidate’s angry words destroy relations with America’s Southern neighbor?
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — IN 2011, when the Republican presidential hopeful Herman Cain proposed building an electric fence on the Mexican border, it predictably caused shock waves south of the Rio Grande. Priests, the press and a former president expressed outrage. Mr. Cain quickly pulled back, saying he was just kidding. “That is not a serious plan,” he said. “America needs to get a sense of humor. That is a joke, O.K.?”

headline: Learning Lessons From Outrage
abstract: The current political crisis shows that we must constantly struggle for what we choose to be as a country.
lead_paragraph: There is so much we have learned from this painful election season and the rise of a demagogic real estate developer.

headline: Religion and Birth Control at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The Obama administration has bent over backward to accommodate religious objectors, but they won’t take yes for an answer.
lead_paragraph: If the harm that Senate Republicans are inflicting on the nation by refusing to consider filling the Supreme Court vacancy were not already self-evident, a case that the remaining eight justices are hearing on Wednesday drives the point home.

headline: The Prison-Commercial Complex
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The way that phone companies gouge inmates is criminal.
lead_paragraph: ORANGE, Conn. — LAST week, an order from the Federal Communications Commission that caps rates for United States prison telephone calls went into effect. A late stay by a federal appeals court, sought by phone companies suing the F.C.C., had threatened to delay the order’s implementation. The stay affects several portions of the F.C.C.’s regulation, but key rate caps and restrictions on charges now apply — to the delight of advocates for prisoners and their families who have long criticized the call rates as a form of price gouging.

headline: Exposure: Chernobyl
abstract: The vacation I took as a young boy in a Russian seaside town in the spring of 1986 seemed entirely normal.
lead_paragraph: I am on a sleeper train, traveling from Moscow to Anapa, a town in Southern Russia, on the shore of the Black Sea. It is April 26, 1986, a week before my sixth birthday. We have been en route for nearly two days and the provisions we brought from home are running down. The train has stopped at the station in Rostov-on-Don, 700 miles away from our home on the outskirts of Moscow.

headline: Q. and A.: The Artist Zhang Hongtu on Appropriating Mao’s Image
abstract: Mr. Zhang discusses his early embrace of Mao’s teachings, his family’s tribulations and what he hoped his art would accomplish.
lead_paragraph: Zhang Hongtu, a Chinese-born artist who came to the United States in 1982 and is now based in New York, won early attention for his “political pop” works appropriating the ubiquitous image of Mao Zedong, notably his portrait of Mao superimposed on a Quaker Oats carton and his reimagining of da Vinci’s “Last Supper” with Mao occupying the position of Jesus Christ and his 12 disciples.

headline: North Korea Launches Short-Range Projectiles, Seoul Says
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The projectiles, launched from the east coast, landed in the sea between the Korean Peninsula and Japan, the South Korean military said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched several short-range projectiles off its east coast on Monday, the South Korean military said.

headline: Obama in Cuba: An Activist Awaits
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Amid the euphoria of President Obama’s visit is a darker reality for the artist Danilo Maldonado Machado, who has been jailed for his work. He hopes this week will spotlight Cuba’s repression.
lead_paragraph: Amid the euphoria of President Obama’s visit is a darker reality for the artist Danilo Maldonado Machado, who has been jailed for his work. He hopes this week will spotlight Cuba’s repression.

headline: News Q’s | Obama Becomes First U.S. President to Visit Cuba in Nearly 90 Years
abstract: What is symbolic about President Obama’s trip to Cuba?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Obama Arrives in Cuba, Heralding New Era After Decades of Hostility.”

headline: John Roberts Criticized Supreme Court Confirmation Process, Before There Was a Vacancy
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ten days before Justice Antonin Scalia died, Chief Justice Roberts said that the Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, and leave politics out of it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered some blunt remarks about the Supreme Court confirmation process. The Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, he said, and leave politics out of it.

headline: Stay or Go? Cuban Entrepreneurs Divided on Where to Stake Futures
abstract: While many leave for the United States, business owners opting to remain are creating an expanding class, optimistic despite serious challenges.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — As an inside joke about all the cookies they scorched on the road to establishing a successful bakery, Antonio and Sandra Camacho Rodríguez named their Havana sweets shop the Burner Brothers.

headline: Student Question | What Old, Worn Out Thing Can You Just Not Part With?
abstract: Why do people tend to get sentimental over things that other people don’t value at all?
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, people look forward to replacing old, worn things with newer, better models. But this isn’t always true.

headline: After Funeral and Cremation, a Shock: The Woman in the Coffin Wasn’t Mom
abstract: Val-Jean McDonald’s sons are struggling to grasp how they could have said their last goodbyes to a stranger dressed in their mother’s clothes.
lead_paragraph: After a long battle with cancer, Val-Jean McDonald, mother of eight sons, with more than 20 grandchildren, almost as many great-grandchildren and three great-great-grandchildren, died on Dec. 18 at the age of 81.

headline: E.L.L. Practice + Prompt | Basketball Superstar Stephen Curry
abstract: In this post, English language learners practice interpreting similes while they learn about the N.B.A. star Stephen Curry.
lead_paragraph: Note: We invite any English-language-learner student 13 years or older to post comments in response to the writing prompts in this post.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 21, 2016
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 25, 2016

headline: Cruise and Rail News: Shackleton Tour; Pets on Amtrak
abstract: What you need to know if you’re planning a trip, including new theme cruises (opera and ballet included) on Silversea.
lead_paragraph: RETRACING SHACKLETON’S ROUTE

headline: A New View of Appendicitis
abstract: Appendicitis is very treatable, and surgery is no longer the only option.
lead_paragraph: Gwen Deely’s story is an example of how not to deal with a health crisis when traveling abroad. She realizes she’s lucky to be alive.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Cuba, Salah Abdeslam, iPhone
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: Springtime Snow
abstract: Monday: A touch of the white stuff, some political stand-up, and dinosaurs for breakfast.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:14 a.m.

headline: Empathy May Be Overrated in an Election, and in a Leader
keywords: ['Empathy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: It’s not clear that the trait matters much to voters, and some social scientists argue that empathy is biased and parochial.
lead_paragraph: Is empathy an essential virtue for a presidential candidate?

headline: Amid a Graying Fleet of Nuclear Plants, a Hunt for Solutions
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: To avoid a shortage of generating capacity in coming decades, the industry is looking at options like advanced reactors and licensing extensions.
lead_paragraph: The H.B. Robinson nuclear power plant, about 70 miles from Columbia, S.C., has been producing electricity with few interruptions since the Nixon administration. But as of now, its fate is clear: The plant will have to shut down by 2030, when it will be six decades old.

headline: Lamb for Easter, Grass Fed and Antibiotic Free
abstract: After years of searching, FreshDirect finds a purveyor to meet its needs.
lead_paragraph: After three years, Stefan Oellinger, who is in charge of meat for FreshDirect, has secured a consistent supply of grass-fed, hormone- and antibiotic-free lamb from a local farm and has it in time for Easter. Drew Lewis, the fourth-generation owner of Brothers Ridge Farm in Newark Valley, N.Y., is raising the lambs on 310 rolling acres of meadow. The meat, mainly from crossbreeds, is mild, tender and rimmed with fat. Cuts include racks, roasts with or without the bone, stew meat, chops, shanks, cutlets and a boneless cut called the loin chump, which is popular in England and is like a thick steak: Grass-fed local lamb, $7.49 to $39.99 a pound, freshdirect.com.

headline: Better Than Drugstore Chocolates
abstract: These bars from Valerie Confections are accented with sea salt, cocoa nibs or raspberry.
lead_paragraph: Take a break from tinfoil-wrapped eggs and pastel Peeps with these old-fashioned chocolate bars for modern tastes. Showing rabbit scenes in relief, they are made of dark chocolate dusted with sea salt, milk chocolate with cocoa nibs, and white chocolate streaked with raspberry. The Los Angeles chocolatier who makes them also fashions delicate petits fours iced in white chocolate, filled with lemon or cassis and adorned with crystallized pansy petals: Easter bars, $10, and petits fours, $50 for a dozen, from Valerie Confections, 888-706-1408, valerieconfections.com; or petits fours, $65, at Dean & DeLuca stores, deandeluca.com.

headline: Coffee and Cocktails Served at the Bar
abstract: Kobrick Coffee Company, a 1920s wholesaler, opens a cafe in the meatpacking district.
lead_paragraph: Kobrick’s has been roasting and selling coffee wholesale since 1920, first in Lower Manhattan and now in Hoboken, N.J. But in today’s coffee culture, the family’s fourth generation, Scott Kobrick and his sister, Nikole Kobrick, thought the company should also have a retail presence. With the approval of their mother and uncle, who are still involved in the company, the siblings have opened a cafe in the meatpacking district where baristas do double duty as mixologists, pouring Negronis as easily as macchiatos after 4:30. And not just any Negronis. Using a Japanese cold-brew drip contraption, they infuse the drink with coffee, adding a dimension of earth-driven bitterness. Other drinks, made with and without the coffee component, include a Bloody Mary that relies on a Chemex carafe to produce. They are working with Tobin Ludwig of Hella Bitters to create cocktails. Wines and light food are also served: Kobrick Coffee Company, 24 Ninth Avenue (13th Street), 212-255-5588, kobrickcoffee.com.

headline: A Coloring Book From the Garden
abstract: “Edible Paradise” offers intricate images to challenge would-be artists.
lead_paragraph: Images of produce from the garden and the market in this coloring book by Jessie Kanelos Weiner are as intricate as French tapestries, presenting an artistic challenge for adult and accomplished child alike. Why not make it a shared activity? Be Henri Rousseau and take a realistic approach, coloring strawberries red, or let your inner Vlaminck emerge as you create bright yellow asparagus, turquoise turnips and green honeybees: “Edible Paradise: A Coloring Book of Seasonal Fruits and Vegetables” by Jessie Kanelos Weiner (Universe Publishing, $16.95 paper).

headline: Gelato Flavors Leaning Into Spring
abstract: At A.B. Biagi, brighter flavors for warmer days.
lead_paragraph: Anticipating spring, Antonio Biagi, a gelato maker in NoLIta, has started churning out lighter, brighter flavors. High on the list is the innocent-looking caipirinha sorbet, white as a lily but lip-smacking with lime and reinforced with cachaça. Mr. Biagi, who is from Brazil, also offers a creamy new “unflavored” flavor he calls bossa nova milk, which gets its richness from its texture and does wonders for an affogato made with intense Brazilian coffee: A. B. Biagi, 235 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), 212-219-8094, abbiagi.com.

headline: Serving Sardines With the Proper Fork
abstract: The owner at Suprema Provisions collects them.
lead_paragraph: They probably used small, multi-tined sardine forks in “Downton Abbey”; they also have them at the new Suprema Provisions in the West Village, where one of the owners, Stephen Werther, is a collector and happy to share his passion with customers. Alas, the forks are for service only and not for sale. So order sardines, the high-quality, tinned kind that this market and wine bar carries, and snack on them with the proper vintage fork: Suprema Provisions, 305 Bleecker Street and 88 Seventh Avenue South, 646-964-4994, supremaprovisions.com.

headline: A Smaller iPhone and Other Highlights From Apple’s Product Event
abstract: Times reporters provided live analysis from the event, where the tech company introduced a smaller iPhone, a smaller iPad Pro and new bands for the Apple Watch.

headline: Sharing Everyday Cooking Through a New Food52 App
abstract: Photograph it, tell how you made it and wait for the favorites and comments.
lead_paragraph: An interactive and addictive app for the iPhone and iPad that allows cooks to share images of everyday dishes and tell how they made them is coming from Food52 on Tuesday. The app, (Not)Recipes, has the look and feel of Instagram; you can favorite posts as well as comment on them. Filters help that roast chicken that didn’t quite brown the way you wanted it to look as if it did: Free at the iTunes App Store.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Pull Financing From Coal Industry
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Insurance', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Sherwin-Williams to Buy Valspar | Starwood Says Anbang Has the Superior Offer
lead_paragraph: BANKS PULL FINANCING FROM COAL INDUSTRY | Wall Street’s retreat from the coal industry is an ominous sign for a sector already in decline,Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. JPMorgan Chase said it would no longer finance new coal-fired power plants in the United States or other wealthy nations. Bank of America, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley have made similar decisions.

headline: China Says It Found Ring Said to Sell Improperly Stored Vaccines
abstract: The police say they are searching in dozens of provinces for 300 people involved in the illegal sales beginning in 2010.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police in China say they have uncovered a criminal ring suspected of selling improperly stored vaccines in dozens of provinces.

headline: Twitter at 10: ‘A Window Into Other Lives’
abstract: Twitter has become a cultural phenomenon, though not one without growing pains. Neil deGrasse Tyson, Margaret Cho and others reflected on their experiences.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has become a cultural phenomenon, though not one without growing pains. Neil deGrasse Tyson, Margaret Cho and others reflected on their experiences.

headline: Belgian Police Name Man Suspected of Being Salah Abdeslam’s Accomplice
abstract: Najim Laachraoui was with Mr. Abdeslam, who is charged with terrorist murder over the Paris attacks, as they passed between Hungary and Austria in September.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian authorities on Monday identified a man suspected of being an accomplice of Salah Abdeslam, who was captured on Friday and charged with terrorist murder in the Paris attacks of Nov. 13. They had asked for the public’s help in finding him.

headline: A Reconsideration of Children and Screen Time
abstract: In a rapidly evolving digital world, screen time can mean many different things, inviting a fresh look at the effects, if not major changes.
lead_paragraph: The digital world is changing around us at a dizzying pace; parents want guidance, and pediatricians want to answer their questions with helpful and scientifically valid advice. The American Academy of Pediatrics’ policy on children and media is probably best known for two recommendations: to discourage any screen time for children under 2, and to limit screen time to two hours a day for older children.

headline: Donald Trump Isn’t Alone in Exploiting the Word ‘University’
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Names, Organizational', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'For-Profit Schools', 'ACCREDITATION']
abstract: Students have been taught to trust places called universities, even though few of them actually are.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years ago, Donald J. Trump linked his name to one of the older get-rich-quick ventures in the book: the real estate seminar. Enticed by the promise of their own quick riches in a then-hot real estate market, students gathered in hotel conference rooms for free introductory classes where instructors offered special knowledge and financing — but only if students signed up for additional, increasingly expensive classes.

headline: Mr. Trump Goes to Washington, to Meet the Establishment
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump will be in Washington on Monday, addressing the conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. That’s about where the similarities in their days will end.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump will be in Washington on Monday, addressing the conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac. That’s about where the similarities in their days will end.

headline: In One-Party Vietnam, Independents Vie for Assembly Seats
abstract: A group of around two dozen activists and celebrities, more than in years past, are running as independents for the country’s rubber-stamp National Assembly.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Taking the stage here on Friday, the singer-songwriter Mai Khoi launched into her hit song “Vietnam,” an optimistic ode to the country’s landscape and people. But the rest of her set list included songs, such as one called “Cuffed in Freedom,” that addressed hot-button social issues like corruption, gender inequality and official restrictions on artistic expression.

headline: Cuba Heads for Miami
abstract: A revolution is not a bed of roses. Nor is the end of the revolution.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — So Havana is 20 years behind Ho Chi Minh City on the development cycle that brings you bulldozed historical districts; traffic-clogged streets; a skyline of cranes; fancy golf courses for expats and the local elite; lattes galore; burger joints; smartphones everywhere; a middle class with disposable income; the seductions of credit; fragrant shopping malls; brand heaven (or hell); the end of virgin beaches; massive real estate developments with names like “Central Park”; offshore fortunes for the political architects of capitalist communism; resorts with their manicured lawns; casinos; mass tourism; social media; 6 percent annual growth; mom-and-pop entrepreneurship; suburbia and sprinklers; private schools for kids with Ivy League colleges already in their sights; Asian and Latin American versions of the American dream; and a population fired up and sort of freed by the opportunity to make a buck for the first time in generations.

headline: James Patterson Has a Big Plan for Small Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: This summer, the popular novelist will start testing a new line of short novels that cost less than $5 and can be read in a single sitting.
lead_paragraph: People already read James Patterson’s books — and in staggering numbers. Last year, he and his team of writers had 36 books land on the New York Times best-seller list. To date, he has published 156 books that have sold more than 325 million copies worldwide.

headline: IHS and Markit, Providers of Data and Analytics, Agree to Merge
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: The combined company, IHS Markit, will provide services to more than 50,000 customers and will have about $3.3 billion in annual revenue.
lead_paragraph: The data and analytics providers IHS and Markit have agreed to combine in an all-stock transaction that will take IHS, which is based in Colorado, to London.

headline: Marriott Raises Bid for Starwood
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Starwood deemed Marriott’s new proposal as superior to the one brought last week by a consortium led by the Anbang Insurance Group.
lead_paragraph: Marriott International sweetened its bid for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide with more cash, greater synergies and a higher breakup fee. That still may not be enough to deter the Anbang Insurance Group of China and its co-investors from making a counteroffer — yet again.

headline: Cuba Meeting Between Obama and Castro Exposes Old Grievances
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: During an extraordinary news conference, the leaders’ exchanges underscored how far the two nations have to travel to fully restore relations.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama stood beside President Raúl Castro on Monday and declared a “new day” of openness between the United States and Cuba, but old grievances and disputes over human rights marred a groundbreaking meeting and underscored lingering impediments to a historic thaw.

headline: China’s Coast Guard Rams Fishing Boat to Free It From Indonesian Authorities
abstract: The boat was stopped for fishing illegally and was being towed to port when the Chinese took it back, prompting Jakarta to summon the Chinese ambassador to a meeting.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — China’s Coast Guard rammed one of the country’s fishing boats to pry it free from the Indonesian authorities who had seized it over the weekend, angering the Indonesian government and heightening yet another diplomatic dispute over the South China Sea.

headline: The Long Shadow of Argentina’s Dictatorship
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama’s visit on the 40th anniversary of a brutal military coup has reopened old wounds.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — When President Obama lands in Buenos Aires this week, he will be arriving on the eve of one of the most traumatic dates in our history. On March 24, Argentina commemorates the 40th anniversary of a military coup that “disappeared” thousands of people, a deep trauma in Argentina’s national psyche.

headline: A Shake-Up at Valeant Signals the End of an Era
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Valeant’s chief will step down, one of many changes made by the drug maker, which faces a growing list of questions from investors and regulators.
lead_paragraph: As recently as last summer, J. Michael Pearson styled himself as a brash and bold executive with a new way of thriving in pharmaceuticals: buying other companies, slashing costs and sharply raising prices on undervalued drugs.

headline: Breathing Life Into Spaces Well Beyond 6 Feet Under Beijing’s Streets
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Basements and Cellars', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A start-up that turns unused basements into community centers wants to reimagine the future of the city’s underground spaces — many of them former bomb shelters.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Digua Shequ community center in Beijing is painted in cheery pastel tones and festooned with colorful paper dragons hung from the ceiling. Inside are a hair salon, a cafe and a gym — normal shops for a typical neighborhood — except that they are underground.

headline: Florida Town Curbs Debauchery, and Pays the Price
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Social Media', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Parties (Social)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Beaches', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Panama City Beach, stung from the party-hard reputation it has gained, is now finding that a move to tone things down might have been bad for business.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla. — The sun was sublime, the flour-soft sand could scarcely have been more tempting and the D.J. music thumped loudly enough to jiggle the beer cups resting on nearby tables. All that was missing were the throngs of booze-soaked, sunburned spring breakers who usually swarm this beach town during March.

headline: 19 Yemeni Jews Arrive in Israel, Ending Secret Rescue Operation
abstract: They came from an ancient and once-vibrant group that became increasingly imperiled by violence and war.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — They landed in Israel late at night — a man in a dark suit and traditional headdress, wheeling a suitcase; a mother, veiled, in a long black robe and holding a sleeping toddler; and a rabbi carrying a Torah scroll believed to be more than 500 years old.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Samsung Appeal on Apple Patent Award
abstract: In December, Samsung agreed to pay Apple $548 million in damages for infringing part of the design of the iPhone, but it reserved the right to appeal the case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from Samsung on what it must pay Apple for infringing on part of the design of the iPhone. In a brief supporting Samsung, companies including Google and Facebook said the legal framework governing the design patents at issue was “out of step with modern technology.”

headline: The Times on the Air: ISIS’s Sex Slavery, Trump and More
abstract: A weekly recap of the radio and television appearances of New York Times journalists.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters, columnists and executives participated in interviews about their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from radio and television.

headline: 1966: Court Lifts ‘Fanny Hill’ Ban
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: U.S. Supreme court lifts ‘Fanny Hill’ Ban in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court refused today [March 21] to modify or discard its nine-year-old obscenity yardstick. But it held that Massachusetts went too far in banning the sale of ‘‘Fanny Hill,’’ the 18th-century novel about a prostitute.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Challenge to Colorado’s Marijuana Laws
abstract: The justices also rejected the reasoning of a Massachusetts court in a Second Amendment case upholding strong limits on stun gun ownership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an unusual lawsuit challenging Colorado’s legalization of recreational marijuana and told a Massachusetts court to take a new look at a Second Amendment case involving stun guns.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Faulting Donald Trump, Calls Israel’s Security ‘Nonnegotiable’
abstract: Hillary Clinton pledged to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee that she would stand unyieldingly with Israel and warned that her potential Republican rival, Donald J. Trump, would be an unreliable partner for one of America’s closest allies.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton pledged on Monday that she would stand unyieldingly with Israel and warned that her potential Republican rival, Donald J. Trump, would be an unreliable partner for one of America’s closest allies.

headline: Cleanse Creep
abstract: Cleansing our digestive system is no longer enough. Today we’re urged to purify closet, kitchen, desktop, checkbook, behavior and spirit.
lead_paragraph: A peculiar thing about humans is that we’re persistently disturbed by reminders that we are, in fact, mammals who sweat, shed, bleed and expel foul matter on a daily basis. Entire industries exist to subdue the horror of having a body. Plentiful aisles in the drugstore are devoted to it. You’d think humans would have gotten used to the beastlier realities of existence by now. We’ve had millions of years to get used to it.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Back to basics with an egg-in-a-hole and inspiration for a week of cooking.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Apple and Justice Dept. Prepare to Face Off in Court
abstract: The issue is complicated, the stakes are high and both sides expect the case will end up in the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the behavior of the federal government, Apple may want to revive its old slogan, “Think Different.”

headline: Putting Your Twitter Feed Back in Chronological Order
abstract: If you do not care for the social media site’s recent change to your timeline, you can turn it off in your account settings.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why is my Twitter feed suddenly out of chronological order?

headline: This Week’s Most Sensible Comment by a Republican
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There hasn’t been a lot of competition. But so far, Rick Perry is winning.
lead_paragraph: You know things are going badly when Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas and failed presidential candidate, sounds more sensible than anyone else in the Republican Party.

headline: Where Republican Senators Stand on the Supreme Court Nomination
abstract: Fourteen Republicans and all Democrats are needed to break a filibuster and confirm the nominee.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen Republicans and all Democrats are needed to break a filibuster and confirm the nominee.

headline: Learning How to Deal With the Haters
abstract: If you don’t handle criticism in the proper way, it can have a major impact on your ability to do work that matters in the world.
lead_paragraph: We all like to act as if we’re immune to the vitriol of haters. It’s almost cool to pretend that it doesn’t affect us, like we’re all bulletproof and have some kind of armor against it.

headline: Drake’s Very Own: On Dennis Graham’s Instagram
abstract: Graham, father to rapper Drake, uses his Instagram to bolster his relationship with his son.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social media presences of celebrities.

headline: Apple May Be Willing to Risk Contempt Charge
abstract: A judge can hold Apple in contempt for refusing to comply with an order to unlock an iPhone, but the threat may be ineffective.
lead_paragraph: Parents are known at times to deliver an ultimatum to a recalcitrant child by saying, “Do this, or else!” The question is what that the frequently undelivered punishment may actually be.

headline: At Microhotels, the Price Is Right and the Space Is Tight
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Some chains are shrinking the size of hotel rooms to as small as 65 square feet to draw deal seekers and compete with Airbnb. Unpacking is optional.
lead_paragraph: On a recent business trip to New York, Kelly Buck went small for her hotel room — as in 100 square feet.

headline: What Spring (and Fall) Looks Like From Space
abstract: An image from the Meteosat-9 satellite shows Earth on the vernal equinox, the official start of spring in the Northern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: [This article has been updated for 2020’s autumnal equinox. Sync your calendar with the solar system.]

headline: France Takes a Back Seat to Germany in E.U. Migrant Crisis
abstract: The French appear to be losing ground as a voice to be reckoned with in Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French-German couple has always been assumed to be the engine of the European Union, the crucial team at the heart of a sprawling, unruly family of 28 nations.

headline: Certainty Despite Randomness
abstract: Test your logical and geometric reasoning with three beverage-glass puzzles.
lead_paragraph: Cheers! This week we toast the arrival of spring with three beverage-glass challenges. We’ll start with Laura Feiveson, an M.I.T.-trained economist at the Federal Reserve Board and regular Numberplay contributor. Here’s Laura with two problems that may surprise even the most experienced puzzle-solver:

headline: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Is Convicted of War Crimes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Mr. Bemba led a militia that committed rape and murder in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003, the International Criminal Court found.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The International Criminal Court convicted a Congolese politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, of war crimes and crimes against humanity on Monday, finding him culpable for a devastating campaign of rape, murder and torture in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003.

headline: No Regrets After Double Mastectomy, but Questions Remain
abstract: More women are opting to remove the healthy breast as well as the cancerous breast, but that doesn’t improve quality of life, new findings show.
lead_paragraph: Vivien Foldes says she does not regret having her breasts removed five years ago after she was found to have an early-stage cancer.

headline: Boaty McBoatface: What You Get When You Let the Internet Decide
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A proposal by a British agency to let the Internet name a research ship is the latest in a trend of web users having some fun with public polls.
lead_paragraph: A proposal by a British government agency to let the Internet suggest a name for a $287 million polar research ship probably seemed like a good idea at the time.

headline: Mezzaluna, the Little Restaurant That Started a Revolution
abstract: The nationwide spread of the Italian trattoria can be traced back to this Manhattan pioneer of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: An urbane, soft-spoken former auto executive, Aldo Bozzi does not fit the mold of a driven Manhattan restaurateur — much less one who almost single-handedly, if inadvertently, set off a restaurant revolution in the United States and beyond.

headline: The Last Thaw: U.S.-Cuban Relations in Pictures
abstract: President Obama’s visit to Cuba heralds the end of decades of enmity and hostility between that country and the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s visit to Cuba heralds the end of decades of enmity and hostility between that country and the United States.

headline: Why the Republican Establishment Doesn’t Like John Kasich
abstract: The Ohio governor’s only path to the nomination runs through the party’s convention — where he may get a cool reception.
lead_paragraph: Improbable as it seemed just two months ago, the one remaining “establishment” Republican presidential candidate in the race is John Kasich, whose last name many voters still can’t pronounce. (Try remembering it this way: “Kasich” rhymes with “basic.”) After winning Ohio last Tuesday, Kasich has potentially denied Donald Trump the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination outright. And he goes into tomorrow’s primaries (in Arizona and Utah) as an antagonist to Ted Cruz, whose quest to close the gap between him and Trump is complicated by Kasich’s continued presence.

headline: A Wise Move on Marijuana by the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Black Markets', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'States (US)']
abstract: The court has sensibly decided not to take a case brought by Nebraska and Oklahoma challenging Colorado’s marijuana legalization.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has sensibly decided not to take a case brought by Nebraska and Oklahoma challenging the way in which Colorado legalized marijuana. The plaintiff states had a weak case backed up with little in the way of evidence.

headline: 1941: Search for German Battleships
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British naval units search for German battleships in the battle of the Atlantic in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Powerful British naval units are searching the Atlantic for two 26,000-ton German battleships, the Scharnhorst and Gneisenau, which, it was learned here today [March 21], are at large in Western waters, threatening British commerce. The two are the most powerful ships yet used by the Nazis for commerce raiding. The fact that two 26,000-ton ships should be detached from the German fleet indicates that the Germans realize the hopelessness of ever meeting the British Navy in a fleet action and are willing to gamble some of their finest units in the Battle of the Atlantic. — New York Herald Tribune, March 22, 1941

headline: Like a Green Juice, but Boozy
abstract: Matthew Biancaniello shares an arugula-packed recipe from his new book of culinary cocktails, “Eat Your Drink.”
lead_paragraph: In simpler times, a great barman was associated with a place — sleek or divey, he was always there. But this is the age of the pop-up, and like many great chefs, Matthew Biancaniello takes his cocktail craft on the road. Since he left his post at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel’s Library Bar over three years ago, the L.A.-based mixologist has been mostly consulting, traveling and writing — and making his farm-to-glass drinks on occasion, at special events.

headline: Fantasy Sites DraftKings and FanDuel Stop Taking Bets in New York
abstract: The move on Monday was part of an agreement with the state attorney general’s office, which had accused them of illegal gambling.
lead_paragraph: Two of the largest daily fantasy sports operators, DraftKings and FanDuel, stopped taking bets in New York on Monday as part of an agreement with the state attorney general’s office, which had accused them of illegal gambling.

headline: New York State Regents Elect Betty Rosa as Chancellor
abstract: Dr. Rosa, a former New York City school principal and superintendent, was chosen to lead the board, which sets education policy for the state.
lead_paragraph: The members of the State Board of Regents on Monday elected Betty A. Rosa, a former New York City principal and superintendent, as the new chancellor, signaling a sharp shift in the state’s education policies after dramatic protests by parents.

headline: New York City Bill to Call for Free Tampons in Public School Restrooms, Shelters and Jails
abstract: City Council members are joining a growing national movement to improve access to feminine hygiene products, and will introduce proposals for free tampons and pads in public restrooms, homeless shelters and correctional facilities.
lead_paragraph: New York City Council members are joining a growing national movement to improve access to feminine hygiene products, and on Tuesday will introduce proposals for free tampons and pads in city public school restrooms and homeless shelters, and easier access at correctional facilities.

headline: Campaign 2016: What’s Next?
abstract: Times Political Editor Carolyn Ryan chats with political reporters Maggie Haberman and Michael Barbaro about the Presidential campaign and what to expect next.
lead_paragraph: Times Political Editor Carolyn Ryan chats with political reporters Maggie Haberman and Michael Barbaro about the Presidential campaign and what to expect next.

headline: Chris Rock to Talk With J.J. Abrams at Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: Other discussions at the April event will include Tom Hanks, Jodie Foster and Tina Fey.
lead_paragraph: At the Oscars, bits by the host, Chris Rock, in which he was inserted into nominated films like “The Martian” were among the highlights of a much-criticized ceremony. The director J.J. Abrams’s company Bad Robot had a hand in those spoofs. And now Mr. Rock and Mr. Abrams will sit down for a conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival next month, one of several talks that organizers announced on Monday.

headline: Fidel Castro Is Out of Sight as Obama Visits Cuba
abstract: A once towering figure in hemispheric politics is gradually fading into irrelevance.
lead_paragraph: This is not how they imagined it.

headline: Experimental Vaccine Shows Promise Against a Form of Dengue
abstract: A study of 41 volunteers showed that all 21 who got the vaccine and were deliberately infected with a mild form of dengue did not have any replicating virus.
lead_paragraph: An experimental dengue vaccine worked almost perfectly in a small trial in which volunteers were deliberately given a mild form of the disease, scientists said last week.

headline: Moqueca Offers Flavors of Brazil in a Tropical Fish Stew

lead_paragraph: I visited Brazil late last year expecting to sample moqueca (moe-KAY-cuh), a tropical fish stew, on its home turf and to bring back a recipe.

keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']

lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Just before Christmas in 2003, a twin-engine Cessna plane crashed into the Claremont, Calif., home of Sheri N. Pym. The house was destroyed and the pilot was killed.

abstract: The drug maker revealed accounting issues, a search for a new chief executive and new board seats as it struggles with debt and a falling stock price.

lead_paragraph: With mothers and medical providers clamoring for answers about postpartum depression, scientists are beginning a major effort to understand the genetic underpinnings of mood disorders that afflict millions of women during and after pregnancy.

Donald Trump promises riots in Cleveland if the Republican Party tinkers with the rules and tries to nominate another candidate. President Obama suggests authenticity is overrated and urges Democratic donors to unite behind Hillary Clinton. What’s next?

lead_paragraph: “Modern Problems” is a lousy Chevy Chase movie from 1981. But I saw it on HBO when I was 7 or 8, and whenever it was on, I would watch it. So its lousiness is separate from its being memorable. What I remember especially well is the end.

headline: How Four Architects Envision the New SFMOMA — as Jewelry
abstract: The museum called on Diana Schimmel, Alice Roche, Marion Cage and Andrea Panico to translate its new Snøhetta-designed façade into necklaces, earrings and more.
lead_paragraph: For fans of the sort of jewelry that’s best described as “architectural,” the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has something better: It has commissioned four trained architects to translate the museum’s new building into wearable designs. In May, the museum opens a new expansion by the Norwegian architecture firm Snøhetta. “Who would match a Botta building with a Snøhetta building? It really is a challenge. They are as crazy as me,” laughs the Buenos Aires-based architect Diana Schimmel, of Mario Botta’s original 1995 design for the museum. Schimmel’s pieces for the capsule collection similarly play on the merging of disparate elements; she’s paired, in a mix of gold and silver, Botta’s iconic round oculus and the striated lines of the new annex into a single entity.

headline: After Conquering Europe, Eurovision Is Coming to Asia
abstract: The Eurovision Song Contest announces plans for an Asian competition, starting in Australia next year.
lead_paragraph: The spectacle of the Eurovision Song Contest — which since 1956 has crowned the continent’s best amateur pop number in a flamboyant televised competition that reaches as many as 200 million viewers — is coming to Asia.

headline: Judge Garland to Meet With More Senators This Week
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Judge Garland returned to Capitol Hill to try to persuade Republican senators to reconsider their decision not to take up his nomination to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: While the fight over President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court has largely shifted from Washington to congressional districts, Judge Garland is still planning to meet with senators this week.

lead_paragraph: POCATELLO, Idaho — When the Rev. Jim Jones, pastor of the Blazing Grace Church here, approached the lectern at City Hall, he was holding a copy of the Quran.

headline: Judge Approves Orange County Register Sale to Digital First
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Newspapers']
abstract: A higher bid by Tribune Publishing for the California newspaper had been blocked by a court order at the request of the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Last week, Tribune Publishing won an auction for a coveted asset — Freedom Communications, the parent company of The Orange County Register and The Press-Enterprise of Riverside, Calif. On Monday, however, the company could only watch as the sale of Freedom to Digital First Media was approved by a judge.

headline: BP and Statoil Pull Employees From Algeria Gas Fields After Attack
abstract: An affiliate of Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for a grenade attack that hit one of the largest natural gas fields in Algeria.
lead_paragraph: BP and the Norwegian oil company Statoil announced on Monday that they were withdrawing their employees from two of Algeria’s largest natural gas fields after Islamic terrorists staged the second attack in three years on their installations.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Analysts at Keefe Bruyette & Woods on Monday waded into the debate over breaking up the nation’s biggest banks, releasing a report that urges Citigroup to split up.

headline: Selections from Of Rare Origin’s Aviary Collection
abstract: Leslie Tcheyan and Octavia Giovannini-Torelli debut their new pieces here.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Tcheyan and Octavia Giovannini-Torelli debut their new pieces here.

headline: Intricate Jewelry, From a Mother-Daughter Duo
abstract: Leslie Tcheyan and Octavia Giovannini-Torelli’s first collection for Of Rare Origin is inspired by birds — and Grandma.
lead_paragraph: Flicking through photographs on her smartphone, the jewelry designer Leslie Tcheyan lands on a nonpareil early ’90s snapshot: She’s wearing a grayish, shoulder-padded blazer, with one arm around her 10-year-old daughter, Octavia Giovannini-Torelli (who’s missing at least one of her front teeth). Both are dripping in diamonds. “It was Take Your Daughter to Work Day and Mom arranged breakfast at Harry Winston’s; I wore a turtleneck and Mom was devastated because I selected all of these huge necklaces,” says Giovannini-Torelli, laughing. “I remember, so vividly, her saying, ‘I can’t believe you wore that.’” Tcheyan, known to others as Che, is a jewelry-industry veteran: Over the last three decades, she worked at Fred Leighton and then began designing packaging and displays for the likes of Schlumberger, Verdura, Sotheby’s and numerous retail jewelers. This led to consulting for Verdura and other brands, all the while sourcing gems and antiques, and manufacturing contemporary pieces worldwide for private clients.

headline: Only a Man Could Forget When Women Ruled Tennis
keywords: ['Tennis', 'Women and Girls', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'BNP Paribas Open (Tennis)']
abstract: A tournament director said female players “ride on the coattails of the men,” but it wasn’t that long ago when the women had the more compelling matchups and story lines.
lead_paragraph: Of all the sports platforms from which to suggest that women “go down every night” on their knees and “thank God” for male counterparts to whom, they owe, in effect, their livelihoods, the last one we might have expected it from was tennis.

headline: The House That Art, Fantasy and Mystery Built
abstract: In Santa Fe, in a structure funded by George R. R. Martin, 135 artists created an immersive storytelling experience.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Santa Fe-based art collective Meow Wolf introduced “The House of Eternal Return” — an interactive, multimedia art experience that one of Meow Wolf’s co-founders, Vince Kadlubek, refers to as “immersive storytelling.” And appropriately for the otherworldly space, created by a team of 135 artists, maestros-of-fantasy like George R. R. Martin and Neil Gaiman attended the opening.

headline: Inside ‘The House of Eternal Return’
abstract: Take a tour of Meow Wolf’s first permanent exhibition, located in Santa Fe and funded by George R. R. Martin.
lead_paragraph: Take a tour of Meow Wolf’s first permanent exhibition, located in Santa Fe and funded by George R. R. Martin.

headline: Credit Default Swaps Make Restructuring More Difficult
abstract: An exchange offer involving Norske Skog shows the growing difficulty of restructuring distressed companies and of knowing where bondholders’ interests lie.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago I wrote an article predicting that the growth of credit default swaps would make it increasingly difficult to restructure distressed companies. The drama surrounding a Norwegian paper maker shows that, if anything, I understated the potential problem.

headline: For a New ‘Rainbow,’ Donald McKayle Is Still Explaining
abstract: Dayton Contemporary Dance Company will perform “Rainbow ’Round My Shoulder,” Mr. McKayle’s 1959 work about life on a chain gang, for Paul Taylor’s season at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: “Ah haaa!”

headline: Review: Met Chamber Ensemble, Led by Levine, Explores Schoenberg and Mozart
abstract: A pioneering Schoenberg serenade scored for seven instruments, and one from Mozart, with seven movements, were on the program at Weill Recital Hall.
lead_paragraph: A conductor’s most important contributions to a performance occur during rehearsals, long before an audience is present. So James Levine deserves much credit for the Met Chamber Ensemble’s winning performances of demanding serenades by Schoenberg and Mozart on Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. His effectiveness conducting the actual performance was harder to assess.

headline: Review: ‘The Year of the Runaways,’ About Fighting for Scraps in a New Country
abstract: Sunjeev Sahota’s second novel, shortlisted for the 2015 Man Booker Prize, follows three young Indian migrants who have made their way to Britain.
lead_paragraph: Even as waves of refugees fleeing the war in Syria have created an urgent world crisis, many immigrants who have already made it to Europe have been grappling with prejudice, poverty and unemployment. No recent novel does a more powerful job of capturing the day-to-day lives of such immigrants than Sunjeev Sahota’s second book, “The Year of the Runaways,” which was shortlisted for the 2015 Man Booker prize.

headline: Holding Out in Harlem, but Not Holding a Grudge
abstract: With no good alternatives to sell, a family decided to stick with their brownstone but work with the developer that is building a condominium around it.
lead_paragraph: The blog post should have been the least of Tracy Butler’s worries, what with the demolition and excavation work going on on three sides of her family’s 129-year-old brownstone on West 123rd Street. Yet four months later, it still bemused her.

headline: Attack Reported on Mali Hotel Used by European Union Military
abstract: The European Union’s military mission said in a Twitter post that its headquarters in Bamako had been assaulted. It reported no casualties.
lead_paragraph: Unidentified assailants attacked a hotel on Monday that is used by European Union military officials in Bamako, the capital of Mali, an African nation that has struggled with recurrent instability and assaults by Islamist militants.

headline: Leon Cooperman and Omega Advisors Receive S.E.C. Notice
abstract: The hedge fund told investors that it received a notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission about a possible enforcement action.

headline: Parrots Are a Lot More Than ‘Pretty Bird’
abstract: Out of the cage, they speak their own language, make tools, and wreak havoc on plants and researchers’ efforts alike.
lead_paragraph: Juan F. Masello never intended to study wild parrots. Twenty years ago, as a graduate student visiting the northernmost province of Patagonia in Argentina, he planned to write his dissertation on colony formation among seabirds.

headline: An Australian Chef in Hong Kong, Serving Casual French Fare
abstract: Months after abruptly shuttering Bones in Paris, James Henry has opened a new restaurant and pop-up — and shares his whole roast chicken recipe with T.
lead_paragraph: Since the nomadic Australian chef James Henry abruptly closed his acclaimed Paris bistro Bones last August, he has been waiting for his next project to begin. And finally, it has — in Hong Kong. Beginning Monday, he’s offering the city a taste of his new restaurant that just opened there, with a weeklong pop-up during Hong Kong’s contemporary art fair.

He’d been asked to perform “Not That Deep,” one of his tough early singles, and offered instead to do something a little more polished. “I can soften it up, put on a shirt,” he recalled in an interview leading up to that performance, “and they’re like, ‘Nah, nah, nah.’”

headline: Most Republicans Feel Embarrassed by Campaign, Poll Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided, while Democratic voters see their side as unified, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll.
lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the harsh attacks and negative tone of their presidential contest, broad majorities of Republican primary voters view their party as divided and a source of embarrassment and think that the campaign is more negative than in the past, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll released on Monday.

headline: Why Sanders Trails Clinton Among Minority Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']

lead_paragraph: Asked during a January debate why he trailed Hillary Clinton so badly among minority voters, Senator Bernie Sanders said he would gain ground once those voters became familiar with his track record and agenda on the economy and criminal justice.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Of the 1,252 adults across the country interviewed by phone March 17 to March 20, 1,058 said they were registered to vote.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from March 17 to 20 with 1,252 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,058 said they were registered to vote.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on What Voters Think About the Campaign
abstract: Broad majorities of Republican primary voters say they believe the party is divided, are embarrassed by the party’s presidential campaign and consider a contested convention to be bad for the party. Democratic primary voters say their party is much more unified, but their race is tighter, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: Broad majorities of Republican primary voters say they believe the party is divided, are embarrassed by the party’s presidential campaign and consider a contested convention to be bad for the party. Democratic primary voters say their party is much more unified, but their race is tighter, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Chanel, Dior, Fendi and Kors Unveil Latest Offerings at Baselworld
abstract: Luxury timepieces designed for women, a rapidly growing segment, angled for some of the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — Each year, some 150,000 industry insiders and haute horlogerie fanatics descend upon this small town, near the German and French borders, for Baselworld, the biggest watch fair in the world.

headline: Jury Tacks On $25 Million to Gawker’s Bill in Hulk Hogan Case
abstract: A jury said the wrestler was entitled to punitive damages, on top of a $115 million judgment last week, in an invasion-of-privacy suit over a sex tape.
lead_paragraph: A Florida jury assessed Gawker Media millions more in punitive damages on Monday for having invaded the privacy of the retired wrestler Hulk Hogan, adding to the $115 million it awarded in compensatory damages last week.

headline: Roles of Race and Partisanship in Legislative Maps Argued at Supreme Court
abstract: The case of Wittman v. Personhuballah asks if Virginia lawmakers had run afoul of the Constitution by putting too many black voters in an oddly shaped district.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court wrestled on Monday with the role race may play in drawing legislative maps.

headline: U.S. Says It May Not Need Apple’s Help to Unlock iPhone
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'iPhone']
abstract: A court hearing set for Tuesday was canceled in the Justice Department’s bid to gain access to phone data in the San Bernardino mass shooting inquiry.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The Justice Department said on Monday that it might no longer need Apple’s assistance in opening an iPhone used by a gunman in the San Bernardino, Calif., rampage last year.

headline: After Oregon Standoff, Birding Is Back
abstract: The Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, site of a 41-day occupation, is now mostly open, in time for a popular bird festival.
lead_paragraph: In a lifetime of offbeat travel experiences, searching for mating sage grouse in a snow squall may rank as one of my oddest pursuits.

headline: U.S. Ends Spying Case Against Former Envoy
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: A lawyer for Robin L. Raphel said charges would not be filed against the ex-diplomat, whose home and office were searched by F.B.I. agents looking for evidence that she was spying for Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has closed its espionage investigation into the former American diplomat Robin L. Raphel and will file no charges, her lawyer said on Monday, ending a case that had put her under a cloud of suspicion over her ties to Pakistan for more than a year.

headline: Outfitting Hasidic Women With Stylish, Yet Modest, Fashions
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Women and Girls', 'Hasidism']
abstract: New businesses are making it easier for Jewish shoppers to adhere to the rules of tznius, or modesty, while retaining some sartorial flair.
lead_paragraph: Sifting through the crop tops and sheer blouses for sale at Junee, a boutique in Borough Park, Brooklyn, is an unexpected clientele: some of New York City’s most modest women.

headline: North Carolina: State to Consider Blocking Charlotte Anti-Bias Law
abstract: The General Assembly will hold a special session to consider blocking a city ordinance that would broaden protections for gay and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: The General Assembly will hold a special session on Wednesday to consider blocking a Charlotte ordinance that would broaden local protections for gay and transgender people. The measure — which officials in Charlotte, North Carolina’s largest city, approved last month — is to take effect April 1 and forbids discrimination in public accommodations, like restrooms, because of a person’s sexual orientation or gender expression. Opponents, including Gov. Pat McCrory, condemned the plan as a threat to public safety, and at least three-fifths of the Republican-controlled House and Senate agreed to the special session. In a statement on Monday, legislative leaders said, “We aim to repeal this ordinance before it goes into effect to provide for the privacy and protection of the women and children of our state.”

headline: Donald Trump Calls Himself ‘Lifelong Supporter’ of Israel
abstract: Mr. Trump expressed his solidarity with Israel in passionate terms, promising a gathering of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee that as president he would always stand up for it against its enemies in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump expressed his solidarity with Israel in passionate terms on Monday, promising a gathering of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee that as president he would always stand up for it against its enemies in the Middle East.

headline: Bob Adelman: From Civil Rights to Making a Difference
abstract: Bob Adelman, a chronicler of the civil rights era who died over the weekend, was convinced photography could change the world.
lead_paragraph: Bob Adelman, a chronicler of the civil rights era who died over the weekend, was convinced photography could change the world.

headline: Bob Adelman: From Civil Rights to Making a Difference
abstract: Bob Adelman, a chronicler of the civil rights era who died over the weekend, was convinced photography could change the world.
lead_paragraph: Bob Adelman, a photographer known for his sweeping, dramatic and intimate coverage of the civil rights movement, was found dead in Miami Beach, Fla., over the weekend. The Miami Herald reported that a friend discovered him at his home Saturday with a head wound.

headline: New Reality Looms: Only a Friendly Senate Will Confirm Justices
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Deal Appears to Curb Migrant Flow, but Greece Still Faces ‘Uphill Effort’
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Some 48 hours after the European Union reached a refugee deal with Turkey, Greek officials confronted widespread confusion about how to handle refugees.
lead_paragraph: MYTILENE, Greece — Standing on the southern coastline of the island of Lesbos, Molhim Zreiki peered through binoculars across the narrow strait of the Aegean Sea dividing Greece from Turkey. During the past nine months, hundreds of thousands of refugees had crossed these waters on smuggler rafts to reach Europe.

headline: Reaction to Obama Trip Reflects Change in Cuban-Americans

lead_paragraph: HIALEAH, Fla. — As he took a final bite of his ham croqueta at Morro Castle cafeteria, Carlos Sanchez distilled the significance of President Obama’s visit to Cuba into one word: hope.

headline: Uncle Who Provided Gun Gets 100 Years in Chicago Shootings

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — By 25, Donnell Flora was a regular in the court system here. He had been convicted of shoplifting, found guilty twice in stolen property cases and sentenced to prison for drugs.

headline: Morocco Asks That U.N. Close Western Sahara Military Office
abstract: The request was an indication that an escalating dispute between the Moroccan authorities and Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon over the disputed territory is not abating.
lead_paragraph: Morocco has asked the United Nations to close a military liaison office in Western Sahara, a spokesman for the organization said on Monday, an indication that an escalating dispute between the Moroccan authorities and Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon over the disputed territory is not abating.

headline: Bob Adelman, Whose Vivid Photos Captured Civil Rights Struggle, Dies at 85

lead_paragraph: Bob Adelman, a freelance photographer whose vivid images of unspeakable brutality and despair brought segregation and the civil rights movement home to Americans in the 1960s, died on Saturday in Miami Beach. He was 85.

keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

headline: Marine Base in Northern Iraq Is Confirmed by Pentagon
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The disclosure followed a rocket attack by the Islamic State that killed one Marine and wounded several others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon acknowledged on Monday that it had established a small base in northern Iraq staffed solely by American Marines, a disclosure that followed an Islamic State rocket attack over the weekend that killed one Marine and wounded several others.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Sheriff Joe Arpaio, Immigration Proxy for Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Arpaio, the sheriff in Maricopa County, Ariz., whose tactics made him the face of hard-line anti-immigration policies, has endorsed Mr. Trump.

lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Darius McCollum’s transit exploits have appeared in police reports and newspapers. Then came the news this month that his story might be turned into a movie starring Julia Roberts.

headline: Andrew S. Grove Dies at 79; Intel Chief Spurred Semiconductor Revolution

lead_paragraph: Andrew S. Grove, the longtime chief executive and chairman of Intel Corporation who was one of the most acclaimed and influential personalities of the computer and Internet era, died on Monday at his home in Los Altos, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Vow to Protect Israel but Differ on Means
abstract: The candidates previewed for an influential pro-Israel audience a debate on foreign policy that could play out this fall if they face each other in the general election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump on Monday presented sharply different views on how the United States should deal with the Middle East and its relationship with Israel, previewing for an influential pro-Israel audience a debate on foreign policy that could play out this fall if they face each other in the general election.

headline: Big Ten’s Freshman Proposal Splits Universities
abstract: A proposal to lower the age limit of incoming freshmen by one year, to 20, has agitated the hockey community, pitting a number of traditional powers against many smaller programs.
lead_paragraph: College hockey appears to be in great shape.

headline: The Arrest of Salah Abdeslam, a Paris Suspect, Ends Manhunt, Not Questions
abstract: The arrest of Mr. Abdeslam, a suspect in the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks, highlights the challenges authorities face in the insular Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The attacks on the airport and a subway station in Brussels on Tuesday have intensified questions about the Belgian authorities’ ability to thwart terror in the city. This article, published on Monday, examines how the lone surviving suspect from the Paris terror attacks in November managed to elude capture for months afterward.

headline: Building a Bridge of Bats and Balls Across a Divide
abstract: Luke Salas traveled to Cuba in 2012 with a dream of using baseball as a cultural exchange between two longtime foes. With a recent thaw in relations, Salas, a Cuban-American, now envisions the sport’s renaissance in the land of his ancestors.
lead_paragraph: On the day he planned to make baseball history, Luke Salas got a ride in a 1950s-era clunker of a car to a field that was little more than a sandlot, in a small town outside Havana.

headline: Donald Trump Pushes Serious Image in the Capital
abstract: Mr. Trump’s whirlwind day in Washington was part of his effort to demonstrate that he is running a serious presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump came to Pennsylvania Avenue on Monday and offered a freewheeling, circuslike glimpse of what the nation’s capital might look like if he is successful in his quest to occupy that big, white house on the 1600 block of the street.

headline: Clinton and CAFTA
abstract: A trade blast from the past.
lead_paragraph: Joel Benenson, Hillary Clinton’s number-cruncher/strategist, has an interesting note up about the implications of the Ohio primary. The rules of the game require, of course, both that he be totally positive about his candidate and that he profess a certainty about the meaning of every victory that I’m fairly sure he does not, in fact, possess. The truth is that nobody can be sure exactly why Ohio was so different from Michigan; the big takeaway from the Ohio result was, instead, that the yuge Michigan polling miss was an outlier rather than a harbinger, and that — combined with the big HRC delegate gain on 3/15 — moves a Clinton nomination from highly likely to overwhelmingly probable.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I actually welcome President Castro commenting on some of the areas where he feels that we’re falling short, because I think we should not be immune or afraid of criticism or discussion as well.”

headline: A Team Looking to Bounce Back Turns to a Pitcher With the Same Goal
abstract: The Giants signed Jeff Samardzija for five years and $90 million, and gave a six-year, $130 million contract to another right-hander, Johnny Cueto, hoping to continue their recent tradition of winning World Series in even-numbered years.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The first baseman’s toss was high, but Jeff Samardzija was there, racing from the mound and gliding through the air by the bag at Scottsdale Stadium on Monday. He plucked the ball from the sky and landed with his foot in the right place.

headline: The Kurds’ Push for Self-Rule in Syria
abstract: A proposal for a semiautonomous region in Syria might be an idea worth building on.
lead_paragraph: One important political outcome of the Syrian war could be a decision by Syrian Kurds to establish a semiautonomous region in the northern part of the country. The move entails risks and has been condemned by Turkey and even some Kurds, but could offer a model for decentralized governance in a federated Syria.

headline: Admiration of Robinson Lingers for Fans in Cuba

lead_paragraph: For his historic trip to Cuba, President Obama took two guests sure to make a strong connection with baseball-crazed fans on the island: Rachel Robinson, the widow of Jackie Robinson, who broke the color barrier in the major leagues, and the Robinsons’ daughter, Sharon.

headline: Jack Masey, Whose Exhibitions Showed American Culture to World, Dies at 91
abstract: A designer whose model American kitchen was the stage for a 1959 argument between Nikita S. Khrushchev and Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
lead_paragraph: Jack Masey, a designer for the United States Information Agency whose model American kitchen, part of an exhibition in Moscow in 1959, provided the stage for an argument about communism and capitalism between Nikita S. Khrushchev and Vice President Richard M. Nixon, one of the Cold War’s most memorable confrontations, died on March 13 in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Review: In ‘Typhoid Mary,’ Showtime for a Dying Patient
abstract: Carl Holder’s “An Intimate Evening With Typhoid Mary,” at the New Ohio Theater, mixes memory and cabaret.
lead_paragraph: Even in the isolation room, people come and go: a nurse, giving a sponge bath; a doctor, trailing a herd of students; an orderly, carting away the trash. Only the pale bald figure in the bed remains, dying of some horrid unnamed illness. This is Marty, and he has a simple plan for escaping the tedium and pain: Retreat into his own mind and put on one last cabaret show.

headline: One Way of Ordering Things
abstract: Don Gagliardo and Zhouqin Burnikel get things in order.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial ‘Win Valuable Prizes’ Alert! If you haven’t already done so, it’s not too late to sign up for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, running April 1-3 in Stamford, Conn. Click here to register, and click here to see the evil sadists, sorry, I meant top-shelf constructors who will contribute their talents to the tournament. See you there!

headline: Review: ‘Wolf in the River,’ Adam Rapp’s Latest Tale of the Dysfunctional and Dispossessed
abstract: This new play, performed by the Bats, the Flea Theater’s resident company, centers on a wistful 16-year-old surrounded by a feral and violent clan.
lead_paragraph: A ripe mound of earth, festering with sickly flowers and garbage, rises from the upstairs stage of the Flea Theater these days. Audience members in the front row for “Wolf in the River” — which opened on Monday night in a highly intimate in-the-round production — could easily lean over and rub their faces in the muck, which may well be the symbolic intention of this play’s creator, Adam Rapp.

headline: Islanders, Listless in Loss, Allow Flyers to Close In
abstract: The Islanders blew a chance to put distance between themselves and the only team with a bona fide chance of knocking them out of a playoff spot, falling at home against surging Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders surely needed a home-ice lift after a rough three-game trip that dropped them into a wild-card position. They have been strong at home all season, with 21 of their 38 wins at Barclays Center.

lead_paragraph: Rick Nash did not whoop, because he never does, but he exhaled as his shoulders drooped in relief Monday after his first goal since Dec. 30. He had missed 20 games with a bone bruise and had yet to rediscover the net since his return.

headline: Scientists Warn of Perilous Climate Shift Within Decades, Not Centuries
abstract: Findings published on Tuesday are likely to replay a debate among climate scientists that started when a draft version of the paper came out last year.
lead_paragraph: The nations of the world agreed years ago to try to limit global warming to a level they hoped would prove somewhat tolerable. But leading climate scientists warned on Tuesday that permitting a warming of that magnitude would actually be quite dangerous.

keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Research', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sensors']

But another huge data resource — sensor data from smartphones — lags behind as a fuel source for major research advances.

headline: Live Free or Trump
abstract: #NeverTrump Republicans want a spoiler. They should look to the Libertarian Gary Johnson.

lead_paragraph: THE long-endangered Republican Deficit Hawk is now extinct.

headline: The Middle-Age Surge
abstract: The image of midlife as a time of crisis is almost the opposite of what this period in life is really about.
lead_paragraph: The phrase almost completes itself: Midlife … crisis. It’s the stage in the middle of the journey when people feel youth vanishing, their prospects narrowing and death approaching. So they become undone. The red Corvette pops up in the driveway. Stupidity reigns.

headline: What Are We Voting For?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Economy', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins trade ideas on health care and economics — and how these issues play out for Clinton, Trump and Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. Well, Smackdown Tuesday went more or less as expected: a big night for Trump and Clinton, with both of them moving closer to becoming the nominees. It’s not a done deal yet, though, on the Republican side, where some still hope for an open convention. Taking this idea head on, Trump told CNN that in that scenario, if he lost, “I think you’d have riots. I’m representing a tremendous — many, many millions of people.”

headline: Elegant Bird Discovers Junk Food
abstract: Instead of making the arduous journey south for the winter, white storks prefer to stay at a garbage dump in Portugal.
lead_paragraph: A new study shows that the glorious annual migration of white storks from Europe to Africa is being disrupted by the birds’ growing addiction to junk food in the garbage dumps below their flight path. Thousands no longer make the crossing for the winter, preferring to build year-round nests at rubbish pits in Spain and Portugal where they conserve energy and have an easier time breeding and defending their nests.

headline: A Partisan Prescription for Paralysis
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: By failing to confirm scores of qualified nominees, Senate Republicans are giving credence to the view that official Washington is irreparably broken.
lead_paragraph: The refusal by Senate Republicans to consider the nomination of Judge Merrick Garland for the Supreme Court vacancy has rightly prompted indignation. But it is only the most glaring example of unreasonable intransigence by lawmakers who have turned the process of appointing senior federal officials into a political game.

headline: Our Water System: What a Waste
keywords: ['Water', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Population']
