headline: Letting (Some of) India’s Women Own Land
abstract: Finally, the right to own land in their own name has begun to change the way thousands of very poor women farm and feed families in some parts of India.
lead_paragraph: This month, 600 women gathered under a huge blue-and-yellow-striped tent in Baripada, a small city in Odisha, a state in India’s east. They were among India’s most neglected people. Widowed, abandoned or divorced, many had ended up living like servants in the households of their fathers, brothers or in-laws.

headline: Strikes Claimed by ISIS Shut Brussels and Shake European Security
abstract: The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the blasts, which occurred four days after the capture of a suspect in the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Bombs packed with nails terrorized Brussels on Tuesday in the deadliest assault on the European heartland since the Islamic State’s attacks on Paris four months ago, hitting the airport and subway system in coordinated strikes that were also claimed by the militant extremist group.

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi Nominated as Minister in Myanmar’s Government

abstract: Asesinan a un activista mientras estaba al aire conduciendo un programa de radio dirigido a residentes desplazados de un pequeño pueblo en México.

Yo estaba en su pueblo en Sinaloa para filmar mi documental “Los reyes del pueblo que no existe”, acerca de las familias que decidieron quedarse después de que sus hogares fueron inundados a raíz de la construcción de la presa Picachos al noroeste de México.

headline: Unsilenced
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Censorship', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media', 'Levees and Dams']

headline: ‘Arcadia,’ by Iain Pears
abstract: In a novel of interconnected real and imaginary worlds, plots run in all directions on the time continuum.
lead_paragraph: Nobody can tangle a text like Iain Pears. His best-known novel, “An Instance of the Fingerpost,” explored a 17th-century Oxford murder and its aftermath through the memoirs of four unreliable narrators, each hotly disputing the others’ versions of reality, science, religion and justice. After nearly 700 pages of deposition, when the guilty are finally sorted from the hard-to-call-innocent, many readers will understandably have already lost track of their scorecards. Now, almost 20 years later, Pears’s latest novel presents a complexly interwoven series of narrative entanglements that stretch across time, alternate universes and at least several textual realities — from Elizabethan pastoral romance and multiple universe theory to a Narnia-like fantasy world and Cold War international intrigue. What’s the difference between all these systems of order, knowledge and storytelling? the attentive reader might ask. And the answer might well be: no difference at all. They are equally “real” and equally “unreal” — take your pick.

headline: How Can Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders Both Be ‘Populist’?
keywords: ['English Language', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How a term from the Gilded Age came to define an election season full of us-versus-them bluster on both right and left.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders share an upbringing in New York’s outer boroughs and a repugnance for trade deals, but the similarities pretty much end there. Sanders routinely inveighs against “corporate America”; Trump is an executive of almost 500 business entities, more than 200 of which are named after himself. Trump lends his name to a line of power ties and cuff links; the adjective most often applied to Sanders’s wardrobe is “rumpled.” Yet journalists routinely refer to both men as “populists.” How can a word that purports to describe both a proud socialist and an arrogant billionaire have any meaning?

headline: Should Parents of Children With Severe Disabilities Be Allowed to Stop Their Growth?
abstract: Caring for people with severe mental and physical limitations becomes vastly harder as they get older. Some parents believe medically stunting them is the answer — but is it ethical?
lead_paragraph: Ricky gazed up toward the pine trees as his mother, Cindy Preslar, pushed him along the village road in an orange jogging stroller. She was marking the route for the Summer 2014 Run Through the Clouds 10K, a fund-raiser for the public schools in Cloudcroft, N.M. “You’ll run with Dad and Max tomorrow,” she said. “Right, Ricky?” She ruffled his fine blond hair. By “run” she meant “ride” — Ricky was 7, but his legs were unable to bear his full weight. As a result of a complication during pregnancy, Cindy says, he was born with a form of cerebral palsy known as spastic quadriplegia with static encephalopathy, which meant permanent brain damage and severely limited eyesight because of cortical vision impairment.

headline: 1941: U.S. Labeled as Enemy
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: U.S. labeled as enemy by Italian Fascists, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Every city in Italy will celebrate tomorrow [March 23] the twenty-second anniversary of the founding of the Fascist party. There will be a display of flags, parades, oratory and other accompaniments of a national holiday. On the eve of the celebration, spokesmen of the party told the public today that the revolution of Fascism, originally purely Italian, had grown into a world-wide revolution in which the Anglo-Saxon ‘‘pluto-democracies’’ were the enemy. Editorials in the ‘‘Relazioni Internazionali,’’ a leading Italian weekly on foreign affairs, and in ‘‘Il Giornale d’Italia’’ made it clear that the United States was now included in the Fascist list of foes. — New York Herald Tribune, March 23, 1941

headline: 1966: Anglican Protests Over Talks

The five already had caused a scene at London Airport and tried to create another at Rome’s Leonardo da Vinci International Airport, wearing apronlike affairs saying ‘‘Archbishop Ramsey is a traitor to Protestant Britain.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 23, 1966

headline: American Cut Brings a Downtown Steakhouse Uptown
abstract: Also, Fair Weather Bushwick is like an intimate dinner party, Impero Caffè is Scott Conan’s latest, and Rider opens in the Brooklyn music space National Sawdust.
lead_paragraph: American Cut Like the chef, the bar area wears downtown black. But this branch of Marc Forgione and LDV Hospitality’s TriBeCa steakhouse is an uptown affair, in the historic Lombardy hotel, steps from Park Avenue in Midtown, so glamour rules. The main dining room, with 132 seats, has the original leaded windows, echoed in the chevron-patterned glass dividers and warmed with rich gold and rosy tones. A wine room with tasting tables runs behind the bar. Steaks are the mainstays, with a 42-ounce tomahawk and a 52-ounce porterhouse that’s flamed with marrow butter. There are grilled fish options, a Caesar salad tossed tableside and the chef’s signature chile lobster in a sriracha and butter sauce served with toast. Aiming for a piece of power-lunch action, the midday menu offers a sandwich of pastrami cured in-house and a quick prix fixe menu with the option of dessert to go. (Opens Wednesday): 109 East 56th Street, 212-388-5277, americancutrestaurants.com.

abstract: A study of 14 cases showed that Merrick B. Garland, the Supreme Court nominee, favored the police and prosecutors 10 times, bolstering his reputation as a moderate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a jury found a man guilty of several gun and drug offenses, he took his case to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. In the spring of 1998, two of the judges on a panel that heard his case agreed to vacate two of his convictions, saying that the evidence was too thin to support one, and the trial judge had made a mistake that tainted the other.

headline: David Chang’s Next Restaurant, Ando, Will Be Delivery Only

lead_paragraph: David Chang doesn’t want you to know the location of his next restaurant. In a new article in Fast Company magazine, the chef says that this spring he plans to open a place called Ando, devoted exclusively to food that’s delivered to customers.

headline: The Voluntourist’s Dilemma
keywords: ['Orphans and Orphanages', 'Philanthropy', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Missionaries']
abstract: Are vacationers who spend spring break volunteering in developing countries really helping anyone?
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, when I was working as a reporter based in Haiti, I came upon a group of older Christian missionaries in the mountains above Port-au-Prince, struggling with heavy shovels to stir a pile of cement and sand. They were there to build a school alongside a Methodist church. Muscular Haitian masons stood by watching, perplexed and a bit amused at the sight of men and women who had come all the way from the United States to do a mundane construction job.

headline: Review: Anthony Cheung’s ‘Elective Memory,’ a Response to Beethoven
abstract: Jennifer Koh and Shai Wosner played this piece at the 92nd Street Y, where it was part of Bridge to Beethoven, a series reflecting on that composer’s sonatas.
lead_paragraph: When the violinist Jennifer Koh asked Anthony Cheung to write a piece for her, responding to Beethoven, he happened to be already working on “Lyra,” a commission from the New York Philharmonic partly inspired by that composer’s Fourth Piano Concerto.

headline: In Brussels, Europe Is Struck at Its Heart
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Obama’s ponderous approach to ISIS runs enormous risks.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, SPAIN — It is not working. President Obama’s slow-but-steady strategy to defeat the Islamic State is clawing back a little territory in Syria and Iraq but is doing nothing to dent the charismatic appeal of the militant group, disrupt its propaganda or prevent it from killing Europeans.

headline: Review: ‘Heartbeat,’ a Hospital Drama, Goes Above and Beyond Credulity
abstract: Melissa George, as the spunky Dr. Alexandra Panttiere, leads the cast of this new NBC series.
lead_paragraph: The situation is growing desperate in America’s fake hospitals. Not from a financial crisis or a nursing shortage. It’s a desperation of plotting. The medical-drama genre is now so exhausted that hospital shows have to go to absurd lengths to make viewers pay attention, and that has never been more evident than in “Heartbeat,” which begins on Wednesday on NBC.

headline: With Brussels Airport Shut Down, What Travelers Need to Know

headline: The Death of the Latin American Left
abstract: What are the lessons from the end of the “pink tide”? Watch out for corruption.
lead_paragraph: The Latin American left has had a miserable few months. In Argentina, Venezuela and Bolivia, it was decisively defeated in three different kinds of elections. The president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, most likely seeing the trends around him, decided to abandon his attempts to remain in power. In Chile, corruption scandals are tightening around previously respected leaders. Most recently, the web of graft has caught one of the most revered figures among Latin America’s 21st-century leftists: the former president of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

headline: Review: Joshua Bell Plays Tchaikovsky at David Geffen Hall
abstract: This violinist and the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields performed a rendition of Tchaikovsky’s Violin Concerto that contrasted sharply with a new recorded version.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Bell and the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields gave a crisp, accomplished rendition of Tchaikovsky’s Violin Concerto on Monday evening at David Geffen Hall. But during the performance my mind kept drifting to a version of that work that’s been surging out of my headphones in recent days.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Honest Message in Cuba
abstract: In a moving speech, the president hailed and challenged Cubans as he called on their leaders to embrace democratic reforms.
lead_paragraph: President Obama began his speech to the Cuban people on Tuesday with humility and grace. “Cultivo una rosa blanca,” he said, reciting the opening line of one of the most famous poems by José Martí, the island’s national hero. “I plant a white rose.”

headline: A Furniture Maker’s Quest: Create Everything From Scratch

headline: Political Substance Abuse: Donald Trump’s Washington Press Conference
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here’s what Donald Trump said on Monday at the Old Post Office in Washington, D.C.
lead_paragraph: This installment of Political Substance Abuse is set in the “Old Post Office,” in Washington, D.C., a historic building that The Trump Organization is converting into a hotel. Donald Trump held a press conference there on Monday as part of a day trip to the nation’s capital that many media commentators called “trying to look presidential.” Mr. Trump met with legislators on Capitol Hill and visited the editorial board of the Washington Post, where he revealed that rather than solely advising himself on foreign affairs, he sometimes relies on a collection of mostly-unknown advisers, who help him advise himself. He sat down to an on-camera, in-person interview on CNN, instead of phoning it in, as he usually does, then capped his day by speaking at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee’s conference. Mr. Trump had an actual speech written for his AIPAC appearance, and he used a teleprompter, despite saying, in Florida last week, verbatim: “No teleprompters. Do you notice? I’m not reading speeches. No reading speeches. No reading speeches. Speak from the heart, and from the head. But speak from the heart. We gotta do it. We gotta do it. We speak from the heart. And from the head! You know? Let’s not forget that. But we’ve gotta do it.”

headline: Flamenco Shows of Intimacy, Passion and Spectacle
abstract: For dance fans in New York, the madness this March has been the flood of flamenco, including performances by Ballet Flamenco de Andalucía and Noche Flamenca.
lead_paragraph: For dance fans in New York, the madness this March has been the flood of flamenco. After the four-day Festival Ay! Mas Flamenco at Symphony Space at the start of the month, three weeks of Flamenco Festival New York followed, bigger than ever. Productions at City Center and Carnegie Hall were augmented by a series of intimate shows at Joe’s Pub. As soon as those ended, on Saturday, the beloved local troupe Noche Flamenca moved right in to Joe’s Pub to extend the madness for another week.

headline: Beach House’s New Transportive Performances Double as Art
abstract: This spring, the Baltimore dream-pop duo is breaking from its typical tour mold with several immersive concerts.
lead_paragraph: The members of the dream-pop duo Beach House tend to spend their time onstage swathed in brilliant hues, or backlit by stars. When Victoria Legrand and Alex Scally take to their instruments (keyboards and guitar, respectively), they’re washed in shades of fuchsia and violet; the outlines of their bodies and the flourish of their movements are the only things that keep them from melting into the saturated field of color behind them. Their backdrop recalls the fluorescent lightscapes of James Turrell — gradual, simple spreads of brilliance that serve as a perfect foil to the ethereal music they’ve been crafting since they met and began to work together in 2004.

headline: Standing With Brussels Against Terrorism and Fear
abstract: The impulse to rein in civil liberties and freedoms after a barbaric attack only serves the terrorists’ end.
lead_paragraph: This time the bombs exploded in Brussels, at the airport and on a metro train, brutally snuffing out at least 30 lives and wounding hundreds. The airport and much of the city were shut down, the police dragnets spread and the anguished questions arose: Why? How did the Islamic State, which claimed responsibility, plan this attack? Was this retaliation for the arrest last week of the last surviving Paris bomber? What have we missed?

headline: Art of the Anecdote: Presidential Candidates’ Speeches to AIPAC
keywords: ['Elections', 'International Relations', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The personal stories candidates told at Monday’s conference shed light on their personalities.
lead_paragraph: Personal anecdotes, especially when deployed in debates, tend to register as shallow, self-aggrandizing attempts to show that a candidate has compassion, experience, or a compelling history. But at times the vignette a candidate chooses sheds light — for better or worse — on his or her personality. At Monday’s conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee in Washington, a prime opportunity to woo pro-Israel voters, every candidate drew from examples of terrorist outrages against Israel to condemn extremists in the Middle East. Ted Cruz, John Kasich, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton all appeared in person, delivering staunch and often hawkish pledges to defend Israeli national security. Bernie Sanders did not appear in Washington but delivered his AIPAC speech at a school in Salt Lake City, where he was campaigning. Mr. Sanders reiterated America’s commitment to “guaranteeing Israel’s survival” but he also criticized Israel’s “disproportionate responses to being attacked” by Palestinians.

headline: Kevin Hart to Publish Memoir Next Year
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The comedian and actor is the latest to land a book deal in what has become a pitched battle among publishers for memoirs and autobiographies from prominent comics.
lead_paragraph: Like most comedians, Kevin Hart takes a confessional tone in his stand-up. He has made intimate and often uncomfortable jokes about his father’s cocaine addiction, his mother’s death from cancer, his marriage and divorce, and his experience being a parent.

headline: Boy With Gun at Brooklyn Middle School Is Charged
abstract: The 14-year-old boy’s weapon, a 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun, was unloaded, but the magazines included nine rounds, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old boy took an unloaded gun in his backpack to a Brooklyn middle school on Tuesday, the third time in a week that a student has been caught with a firearm on a New York City school campus, the authorities said.

headline: Queens Man Convicted of Murder for Dragging Victim Under Car
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: After a fistfight outside a baby shower in 2014, Kevin Weekes returned to his car and drove into the crowd, killing one person and injuring another, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old Queens man was found guilty on Tuesday of driving into a crowd and killing a man pinned under his car after a fight at a baby shower in 2014, prosecutors said.

headline: Raiders’ Owner Looks to Las Vegas as Possible New Home
abstract: Mark Davis has put Las Vegas at the top of his list, even if many N.F.L. owners have sent word that they consider the idea a nonstarter because of the association with gambling.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — With all the criticism the N.F.L. has taken about its stance on gambling and daily fantasy sports, perhaps the last place a team might land is Las Vegas.

headline: Goldman Banker in Document Leak Case Avoids Prison
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Rohit Bansal was facing up to a year in prison after pleading guilty to taking documents from a source inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
lead_paragraph: A former Goldman Sachs banker who pleaded guilty to taking confidential documents from a source inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was sentenced to probation on Tuesday, bringing to a close an episode that embarrassed the bank and the New York Fed alike.

headline: A Blurry Photo Hints at ISIS Tradecraft
abstract: The men identified as central suspects were decidedly calm, had trimmed beards, wore single gloves that might have disguised detonation handles and probably had bombs in suitcases.
lead_paragraph: The grainy image captured on a surveillance camera at Brussels Airport shows three men pushing luggage carts into the check-in terminal. Their expressions seem casual, even relaxed.

headline: A Well-Traveled Jordan Spieth Adjusts to Being the Main Attraction
abstract: Spieth, the world’s top-ranked player, will be the main attraction this week at the World Golf Championships match-play event in his home state of Texas.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The handshake line for the superstar formed near the courtside seats reserved for Jordan Spieth, his girlfriend and four other friends during the Mavericks’ game last week against the Golden State Warriors in Spieth’s hometown, Dallas. As Stephen Curry entered the court for pregame warm-ups, Spieth stood alongside other avid basketball fans and extended his left arm to try to make a connection with Curry, who jogged right past him.

headline: Puerto Rico Fights for Chapter 9 Bankruptcy in Supreme Court
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In court on Tuesday, Puerto Rico argued that its exclusion from Chapter 9 leaves the island with few options to alleviate its worsening finances.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Debt-laden Puerto Rico went toe to toe with its creditors at the Supreme Court on Tuesday, arguing that it has been wrongly locked out of the bankruptcy courts, the only place it can reasonably expect to restructure its crushing debt.

headline: New York Police Increase Patrols Around 20 Clubs to Combat Knife Violence
abstract: Police officials said they were targeting areas linked to nearly a quarter of knife crimes this year.
lead_paragraph: Police officials said on Tuesday that they would increase enforcement around 20 bars and clubs in New York City with a disproportionate share of the stabbings and slashings that have resulted in a surge in knife violence this year.

headline: Nuclear Plant Leak Threatens Drinking Water Wells in Florida
keywords: ['Water', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Radiation', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Water Pollution', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: A finding that a Florida nuclear power plant is leaking polluted water has environmentalists threatening to sue over the safety of Biscayne Bay and the surrounding ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When Florida’s largest power company added two nuclear reactors to an existing plant that sat between two national parks — Biscayne Bay and the Everglades — the decision raised the concerns of environmentalists and some government officials about the possible effects on water quality and marine life.

headline: Apple Policy on Bugs May Explain Why Hackers Would Help F.B.I.
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: Apple does not pay hackers to find and report bugs, which may explain why a third party has offered to help the government break into an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a third party went to the F.B.I. with claims of being able to unlock an iPhone, many in the security industry said they were not surprised that the third party did not go to Apple.

headline: Mets and Yankees Brace for a Future Without Smokeless Tobacco

headline: Leon H. Charney, Investor, Cable TV Host and Peace Broker, Is Dead at 77
abstract: Mr. Charney helped bring about the Camp David peace accords in 1978 by arranging secret talks between the Egyptian president, Anwar el-Sadat, and the Israeli prime minister, Menachem Begin.
lead_paragraph: Leon H. Charney, an entertainment lawyer who expanded his portfolio to become an author, a television host, a real estate mogul and a back-channel peace broker between Egypt and Israel, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Birth Defects Tied to Zika in Panama
abstract: The World Health Organization said the death of a baby with an unusually small head and brain damage was new evidence of the epidemic’s spreading throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Panama has reported its first case of birth defects associated with the Zika virus, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday — new evidence of the epidemic’s potentially dangerous effects spreading throughout the region.

headline: A Victory for the Visitors, but a Celebration for the Fans
abstract: As President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba watched, James Loney homered for the Rays, who won the first game in 17 years between a major league club and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The ball soared off the bat of Tampa Bay’s James Loney in the top of the fourth inning and headed toward the stands in right field that were painted with the slogan “Sport, Conquest of the Revolution.”

headline: Top Experts Confounded by Advisers to Donald Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who has promised to hire the world’s brightest minds to make up for his lack of political experience, turned to little-known counselors to guide him in foreign affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump finally began to reveal the names of his foreign policy advisers during a swing through Washington this week, the Republican foreign policy establishment looked at them and had a pretty universal reaction: Who?

keywords: ['Football', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Dementia', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Brain', 'Concussions']

lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — With the expectation that more N.F.L. players will suffer dementia from repeated head hits, businesses that cater to people with memory loss are gearing up for what could be droves of new clients in the near future.

lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Leading Cuban dissidents, including some who have been critical of President Obama’s policy of engaging with the Cuban government, spent nearly two hours on Tuesday discussing human rights with the president.

headline: Presidential Candidates Walking a Tightrope Over the Fight on Terrorism
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In the current atmosphere, a strike like the one on Tuesday in Brussels rekindles every debate about whether the United States should use diplomacy, isolation or military might.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ten hours before terrorists struck Brussels, Donald J. Trump was on television describing his strategy for confronting the Islamic State: He would pound it with airstrikes, but any ground action must be taken by the United States’ partners in the region. He did not mention, if he knew, that this was a pretty close approximation of President Obama’s approach.

headline: Porous Borders and Calcified Security Aid Islamic State in Europe
abstract: The Islamic State has chosen the capitals of Western Europe to score military victories, and has been aided by a combination of porous borders and a calcified security apparatus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies have spent nearly 20 months bombing the Islamic State in classic military style — barraging Syria and Iraq in an effort to dislodge the group from its seat of power.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Gentrification', 'Zoning', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Under the new housing rules, private developers will be compelled to build low-cost rental units, a centerpiece of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s efforts to blunt neighborhood gentrification.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council passed sweeping changes to the zoning code on Tuesday, compelling private developers to build low-cost rental units and handing Mayor Bill de Blasio a victory on the centerpiece of his efforts to blunt neighborhood gentrification.

headline: 3 Men Killed in Queens House Fire
abstract: Firefighters found the victims, who were unconscious and unresponsive, inside a two-story home in the Elmhurst neighborhood late on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Three men died after a fire broke out in a house in Queens late on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: Fine Arts Museums in San Francisco Picks Max Hollein as Next Director
abstract: Mr. Hollein, director of the Städel Museum in Frankfurt, will oversee the de Young Museum in and the Legion of Honor in San Francisco starting June 1.
lead_paragraph: In a surprising move, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco has gone beyond the United States for its next director, hiring Max Hollein away from the Städel Museum in Frankfurt.

headline: Derek Jeter Emerges at Rays-Cuba Game in Havana
abstract: The former Yankees shortstop, a part of Major League Baseball’s delegation to Cuba, joked with President Obama, who was sitting nearby.
lead_paragraph: After a year spent mostly out of the spotlight, Derek Jeter was front and center Tuesday afternoon, sitting in the stands in Havana to watch the Tampa Bay Rays take on the Cuban national team, joking with President Obama, who was sitting nearby, and taking part in an interview on ESPN, which broadcast the game.

headline: Review: ‘Dry Powder,’ a High-Finance Comedy Drama
abstract: Claire Danes and John Krasinski are rival partners at a private equity firm in Sarah Burgess’s play about shenanigans in the world of big money.
lead_paragraph: Calling all Bernie Sanders fans. There’s a pageant of red meat for you onstage at the Public Theater, where Sarah Burgess’s “Dry Powder,” about rapacious wheeling and dealing in the world of high finance, opened on Tuesday night. Take your forks and knives — and heck, your pitchforks, too — and dig in!

headline: Minuet Meter
abstract: Alex Boisvert and Jeff Chen dance toward a record of some sort.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s possible to overthink a theme, and today I did just that. Maybe you did, too. I have to say that I honestly didn’t see this one coming. Bravo to Alex Boisvert and Jeff Chen for pushing the envelope, because I don’t believe that anyone else has taken this type of theme this far.

headline: Jan Nemec, Czech Filmmaker Known for Works of ‘Dream Realism,’ Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Nemec’s surreal and parable-like films made him one of the leading lights of the country’s new wave in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Jan Nemec, whose surreal, parable-like films made him one of the leading lights of the Czech new wave in the 1960s, died on March 18 in Prague. He was 79.

abstract: Residents in Union City, N.J., home to many Cuban exiles, expressed unease and some optimism about the U.S. and Cuba mending their relationship
lead_paragraph: Union City, N.J.

headline: Belgian Golfer, Set to Begin Tournament in U.S., Has Heavy Heart
abstract: Thomas Pieters spent hours combing through news sites and texting friends and family back home on the eve of a World Golf Championship match-play event.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Belgian golfer Thomas Pieters awakened in his hotel room Tuesday to a buzzing smartphone. It was around 6 a.m. on the eve of Pieters’s debut in the World Golf Championship match-play event at Austin Country Club. Pieters, 24, scrolled through the numbers and saw that friends from all over the world had contacted him, and his heart sank. He said he “kind of knew” before he turned on the television that terrorists had struck again.

headline: U.S. Strike in Yemen Kills Dozens in Qaeda Affiliate, Officials Say
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The airstrike was the latest sign that the Pentagon is hastening its strikes against militants in the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American airstrike on Tuesday killed dozens of fighters at a mountainous training camp used by the Yemeni affiliate of Al Qaeda, Pentagon officials said, the latest sign that the military is hastening its strikes against militants in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Charles Kaufman, Transformative Leader of Mannes College of Music, Dies at 87
abstract: In his 16 years as the dean, Dr. Kaufman staved off bankruptcy, bolstered programming and oversaw a partnership with the New School.
lead_paragraph: Charles Kaufman, who led a faculty coup that spared the century-old Mannes College of Music in Manhattan from a troublesome merger in 1979 and then restored it to fiscal soundness, died on March 17 at his home in Hillsdale, N.J. He was 87.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Season 1, Episode 8: We the Jury
abstract: Apparently, being on the jury for this case was the absolute worst.
lead_paragraph: Was being a juror on the O.J. Simpson trial so miserable that one of them actually tried to escape and run away?

headline: In Havana, Rapprochement Through the Lens of ESPN
abstract: The game between the Rays and the Cuban national team was a television spectacle, presented as a sporting event, with President Obama as the star of the day.
lead_paragraph: The game between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Cuban national team in Havana on Tuesday was a television spectacle, presented by ESPN as a game entwined in international politics. The visuals were clear from the frequent cuts between the on-field action and President Obama and President Raúl Castro, who were sitting together at Estadio Latinoamericano. Economic policy was laid out in Obama’s remarks about how business from America will help give the United States leverage in Cuba.

headline: Steven Matz Struggles, but Luis Severino Doesn’t as Yankees Beat Mets
abstract: Severino outpitched Matz in a matchup of young star starters as Matz’s rough spring training continued.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Steven Matz exited after another disappointing spring training start, and later when he met with reporters, he did not show any sign of emotion. Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, had talked to him about taking a cue from Matt Harvey and Jacob deGrom and maintaining his composure and exuding calmness.

headline: Clinton and Trump Win Arizona; Cruz Picks Up Utah; Sanders Takes 2
abstract: Tuesday’s Western contests came after Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton both demonstrated strength in a string of recent primaries.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump overwhelmed their rivals in the Arizona primaries on Tuesday, a show of might from two presidential front-runners who are hoping to avoid prolonging the nominating contest and begin training their fire on each other.

headline: Jack Antonoff Will Track the Glory Days of CDs for a Book
abstract: The rarefied world of vinyl is not the only realm in the history of record stores, said Mr. Antonoff, who is preparing a book celebrating the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: In the age of streaming music, there is no shortage of nostalgia for record stores that fostered a sense of community and also sold tangible products. But in mourning that mostly bygone era of erudite clerks and obscure, collectible titles, it’s possible to overlook the very recent past — namely, the more mainstream ’90s CD culture, with its megachains like Tower Records and Sam Goody.

headline: Hillary Clinton Attacks Donald Trump in Arizona Victory Speech
abstract: Hillary Clinton used a victory rally on Tuesday night to sharply challenge the leading Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump, calling him a “demagogue” who was “inciting bigotry and violence.”
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Hillary Clinton used a victory rally here on Tuesday night to sharply challenge the leading Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump, calling him a “demagogue” who was “inciting bigotry and violence” and whose “bullying behavior” called for a timeout.

headline: Women Balancing Work and Family
abstract: After Alice Proujansky’s first child was born, she set out to photograph women who — like her — were balancing the demands of a career and family.
lead_paragraph: When Alice Proujansky was pregnant with her first child, a man at a party came up to her and remarked, “You’ll never want to go back to work when you see those baby’s eyes.” Ms. Proujansky doesn’t remember her reply. “Probably something like, ‘Well, I doubt that will happen,’ ” she said. “Documentary photography isn’t exactly the kind of career people are lukewarm about or just fall into and out of. And my children’s eyes are beautiful, but they won’t pay my student loan bills either!”

headline: John Coltrane’s ‘A Love Supreme’ and Billy Joel’s ‘Piano Man’ Join National Recording Registry
abstract: John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme,” Billy Joel’s “Piano Man,” and coverage of Wilt Chamberlain’s 100-point game are being added to the Library of Congress’ National Recording Registry.
lead_paragraph: John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme” and Billy Joel’s “Piano Man” are part of the incoming class added to the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress this year. The diverse crop of new inductees also includes the Vienna Philharmonic’s 1938 recording of Mahler’s Ninth Symphony, Metallica’s “Master of Puppets” and live coverage from Wilt Chamberlain’s 100-point game.

headline: No Contraception? No Equality

abstract: The Supreme Court should not abridge women’s right to health care.

The plaintiffs want to extend the 2014 ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, which recognized the right of certain for-profit companies to a religious exemption from the act’s requirement that employers’ health plans provide contraceptive coverage.

headline: Waiting for Round 2 in the Phone Fight
abstract: The iPhone case is currently at a halt, which means the debate over privacy will continue.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice says that it might have found a way to unlock an iPhone used by a terrorist without Apple’s assistance. For the moment, this has halted a legal confrontation between the government and the company. But the question of whether the government can compel Apple to assist it in unlocking its phones remains unanswered, which means that similar disputes will continue to develop.

headline: Brothers Among 3 Brussels Suicide Attackers; Another Assailant Is Sought
abstract: Ibrahim el-Bakraoui attacked the airport and his brother Khalid attacked the subway, Belgian officials said, as an inquiry drew links to the 2015 Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Brussels suicide bombers included two Belgium-born brothers with a violent criminal past and suspected links to plotters of the Islamic State’s Paris attacks last November, the authorities said on Wednesday, raising new alarms about Europe’s leaky defenses against a militant organization that has terrorized two European capitals with seeming impunity.

headline: Credit Suisse Chief Says Risky Bets Were a ‘Surprise’

headline: Ossining, N.Y.: History, Parks and ‘Mad Men’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The village of Ossining, N.Y., on the Hudson, is rich in pre-Revolutionary War history, and is also the site of the Sing Sing Correctional Facility.
lead_paragraph: The village of Ossining, N.Y., on the Hudson River in Westchester, has a surprisingly large place in American culture, given its three-square-mile size. Rich in pre-Revolutionary War history, it is also the site of the state-run Sing Sing Correctional Facility and was home to both the author John Cheever and the fictional character of Don Draper in the AMC series “Mad Men.”

headline: Global Crises Shadow, and Overshadow, Obama’s Foreign Trips
abstract: The White House has struggled to calibrate its message when violent events like the attacks in Brussels have arisen while the president is overseas.

headline: The Uber Model, It Turns Out, Doesn’t Translate
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Parking Garages and Lots']
abstract: The ride-hailing service is a giant, but companies that aim to get stuff done on demand for customers, like food delivery, grocery shopping and parking, are faltering.

So a year and a half ago, when I discovered the valet-parking app Luxe, the heavens parted, choirs began singing and double rainbows colored the sky. This, I was convinced, could be the next big thing.

keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations']

headline: Cuba Says It Has Solved Racism. Obama Isn’t So Sure.
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a speech in Havana, the president noted America’s and Cuba’s similar struggles with racism, spotlighting an issue the Cuban government says is settled.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama spoke of his Kenyan heritage. He talked about how both the United States and Cuba were built on the backs of slaves from Africa. He mentioned that not very long ago, his parents’ marriage would have been illegal in America, and he urged Cubans to respect the power of protest to bring about equality.

headline: At Columbus Circle, a New Home for Underground Gourmets
abstract: Sit-down restaurants and retail stores are poised to open in an upscale transformation of the 59th Street-Columbus Circle subway station.
lead_paragraph: Sit-down dining is coming to the subway.

headline: Chocolate Can Boost Your Workout. Really.
abstract: Cyclists performed better after two weeks of supplementing with dark chocolate, compared to those who ate white chocolate or their usual diets.
lead_paragraph: Adding a little dark chocolate to a training diet may effortlessly improve endurance performance, according to a new study of sports nutrition. The findings provide ammunition both for athletes looking for an edge and those hoping for an excuse to indulge.

lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida who left the presidential race after the South Carolina primary, endorsed Ted Cruz on Wednesday, becoming the most prominent member of the Republican establishment to support the Texas senator as he tries to slow Donald J. Trump’s efforts to capture the presidential nomination.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There is a Vancouver Forest in Beijing, a Thames Town in Shanghai and an Oriental Yosemite in Dalian, China.

headline: After Taking a Shower, Shower Your Lawn?
abstract: There is a new alternative to a fake, spray-painted or well-watered lawn in drought areas: water cleaned and reused from showers and sinks.
lead_paragraph: Food from garden to table. Solar power from roof to outlet. And now soapy water from your own shower to your lawn?

lead_paragraph: Is someone going to start listening to House Speaker Paul D. Ryan?

headline: Fresh Off Grand Slam Win, England Appears Energized by Its New Coach
abstract: England won its first Six Nations Grand Slam since 2003 earlier this month, and it will face a sterner test in June when it will have a three-test series against Australia.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — England has celebrated its first Six Nations Grand Slam in 13 years, but the challenge it faces in Australia in June will most likely be significantly sterner and should give its new coach, Eddie Jones, a clearer picture of where his team sits in rugby union’s global pecking order.

headline: Australian Energy Giant Woodside Delays Large Offshore L.N.G. Project
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The decision to postpone the plan, called Browse, comes as prices for the fuel in Asia have fallen steeply.
lead_paragraph: Woodside Petroleum and its partners, including the energy giants Royal Dutch Shell and BP, have decided to delay indefinitely the development of a huge liquefied natural gas project off Western Australia, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

headline: How Much Money Is Enough?
abstract: Most of us want our children to have the best of everything, but not too much of anything.
lead_paragraph: Most of us want our children to have the best of everything, but not too much of anything.

headline: Brioni Announces Its Own Unconventional Hire
abstract: Justin O’Shea, the brand’s new creative director, has no formal training as a designer.
lead_paragraph: Justin O’Shea, former fashion director of the German e-commerce giant MyTheresa, has been appointed creative director at Brioni, the latest unorthodox hiring by a luxury brand as the sector strains for innovative approaches in an ever more competitive environment.

headline: How to Stop the Bouncing Between Insurance Plans Under Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Millions of Americans move back and forth between Medicaid and the insurance marketplace, inconveniencing patients and costing taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are finding Obamacare to be unstable ground.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Just Saying No to a Baby Registry
abstract: Don’t be afraid to start a bonfire of stuffed animals.
lead_paragraph: Viola writes: I am a grown woman starting a family with my beloved wife. I know what I want to have for my child in my home and take pleasure in being able to afford those things. My family insists that if I don’t provide them with a registry, they will just get me gifts anyway. How can I prevent this and maintain my status as a kind person?

headline: Must a Woman Confront a Bigoted In-Law?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Autism', 'Gender', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on speaking out against an offensive family member, educating strangers on gender-neutral language and more.
lead_paragraph: My father-in-law is quietly racist, sexist and anti-gay. He was kind enough to offer me a job at his firm. I had previously voiced my (respectful) dissent, but this became tiring when I saw him every day. I began to ignore his comments but felt guilty, because I believe that silence equals complicity. One day, after he said something particularly mean and I said nothing, I assuaged my guilt by making a donation to Planned Parenthood. Since then, I’ve adopted a strategy of donating to different organizations whenever I fail to speak up. The amounts are small, but large enough to be uncomfortable for me; I see these as a kind of punishment for not being courageous or energetic enough to keep standing up to him.

headline: We’re More Honest With Our Phones Than With Our Doctors
abstract: How health-tracking apps reveal new truths about our bodies.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, an undergraduate psychology student at Wellesley College named Martha McClintock noticed something interesting: Women who spent a majority of their time together tended to get their periods around the same time. She suspected that menstruating bodies could influence one another somehow, but it was just a hunch. So she asked 135 of her fellow students to keep track of their cycles. Three times that year, she quizzed them about their period start and which women they socialized with the most.

headline: After a Fire, Megabus Passengers Stranded on Compensation
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Buses', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: We were all grateful and fortunate to escape unharmed. But weeks after, we found a lack of recourse to collect thousands of dollars in lost property.
lead_paragraph: When I exited my Megabus a few weeks ago in Milwaukee, Wis., saying goodbye to my fellow passengers and ending what had been an extremely eventful, harrowing trip, I had a sinking feeling that the events of the day would quickly be glossed over and forgotten. The bus I was on had erupted into a ball of fire on the Interstate, endangering our lives and destroying the bus and most of my fellow passengers’ baggage (I did not lose any property). Thankfully, we all managed to get away unharmed. But while my tweetstorm garnered attention, I knew that because there were no injuries, Megabus would very likely not be taken to task for the incident, beyond some bad P.R.

headline: How Aerial Surveillance Has Changed Policing — and Crime — in Los Angeles
abstract: Inside the city’s pioneering air-support division.
lead_paragraph: The air-support division of the Los Angeles Police Department operates out of a labyrinthine building on Ramirez Street in the city’s downtown, near the Los Angeles River. A looming mass of utilitarian architecture tucked beside the 101 Freeway, the complex appears to have no real public face; here the view from the street matters little. Instead, like much of the city around it, the air-support division makes more sense when seen from above.

headline: With Jeb Bush’s Backing, Ted Cruz Makes Push to Stop Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Cruz is spending time on Mr. Trump’s turf for a second day in a row, as he tries to galvanize support in the establishment behind his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the results of the contests in Arizona and Utah, the dual-track primaries move forward to the next big test, Wisconsin, on April 5. But in the Republican battle, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is spending time on Donald J. Trump’s turf for a second day in a row, as he tries to galvanize support in the establishment behind his candidacy.

headline: The Islamic State’s European Front
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The world’s most dangerous jihadist group is in retreat in the Middle East. That’s bad news for Europe.
lead_paragraph: The bombs that exploded in the Brussels airport and at a central metro station on Tuesday morning, killing at least 30 people, came as only the latest in a string of terrorist outrages on a continent that is starting to see horrific violence as the new normal. Hours later the Islamic State claimed responsibility.

headline: HSBC Adds Former Chief Executive of Standard Life to Board
abstract: The appointment of the former chief, David Nish, comes as the British lender continues to shake up its board before it names a successor to its chairman.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — HSBC said on Wednesday that it would add the former chief executive of the insurer Standard Life as a director, as the British lender continues to shake up its board.

headline: Whiting Foundation Announces Winners of 2016 Awards for Writing
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Each of the 10 chosen writers receiving a cash award of $50,000. The awards are given for “early-career achievement and the promise of superior literary work to come,” according to the Whiting Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the 2016 Whiting Awards were announced on Wednesday night at the New-York Historical Society, with each of the 10 chosen writers receiving a cash award of $50,000. The awards are given for “early-career achievement and the promise of superior literary work to come,” according to the Whiting Foundation.

headline: Prime Suspect in Koala’s Murder: Los Angeles’s Mountain Lion
keywords: ['Mountain Lions and Cougars', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: A mountain lion known as P-22 lives near the zoo, and was seen there the night of the crime. And who else could have climbed the nine-foot fence?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The murder was grisly. A koala disappeared from the Los Angeles Zoo one night this month. Its body, mangled and bloody, was found the next morning on a nearby hillside.

headline: Regrouping After the Death of a Top Executive
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Small Business', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The loss of a founder or another crucial figure means those leading a small business must make important decisions while still in shock and grief.
lead_paragraph: After three years of planning and design work, XTI Aircraft, a start-up in Englewood, Colo., developing an experimental jet, was poised to finally leave the runway. The company had lined up its executive team, received its first patent and begun a crowdfunding campaign for its next stage of development work.

headline: A Hairbrush in the Tuba
abstract: It’s five minutes to Act 1 at the Metropolitan Opera, and a colleague’s brush is way down the brass bell, beyond reach.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

abstract: A brick townhouse in Baltimore, a house in Florida and a view of water in Washington.
