headline: Judge Orders Extradition to U.S. in ‘Flash Crash’ Case
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Extradition', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Navinder Singh Sarao, a British trader, is accused by American authorities of contributing to turmoil that led the Dow to fall more than 600 points.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A judge ruled on Wednesday that Navinder Singh Sarao can be sent to the United States to face criminal charges accusing him of playing a role in the May 2010 “flash crash” in the United States stock market.

headline: Alabama: Head of Police Agency Fired
abstract: The governor said an inquiry at the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency had “found a number of issues, including possible misuse of state funds.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Robert Bentley fired the state law enforcement secretary, Spencer Collier, on Tuesday after an internal review. In a statement, Mr. Bentley said the inquiry at the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency had “found a number of issues, including possible misuse of state funds.” The state attorney general’s office is expected to review the results of the inquiry, which began in late February. Mr. Collier, a former state legislator, has been on medical leave since last month and could not be reached for comment on Tuesday night.

headline: Russia, Light on Cash, Weighs Risks of a Heavy Tax on Oil Giants
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Taxation', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Shale']
abstract: Times are so tight the Kremlin may soon dip into the one reserve it holds sacred: the funds its oil companies need to invest to ensure future production.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As the gusher of oil money that underpinned the rise of President Vladimir V. Putin has dwindled in the price slump, the Kremlin has found ways to keep the economy chugging along, albeit at a reduced rate, spending down rainy day funds and cutting wages and pensions.

headline: 1941: Marking Greek Independence
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 15,000 parade on Park Avenue to celebrate Greek independence in 1941.
lead_paragraph: The national colors of Greece, Great Britain and the United States fluttered along Park Avenue yesterday, carried by a long column of Greeks and Americans of Greek descent, to mark the 120th anniversary of the beginning of the Greek war of independence.

headline: For Apple, Potential Flaw May Be a Wake-Up Call
abstract: Now that a third party claims to have cracked the iPhone’s encryption, Apple may need to revisit how it safeguards its products.
lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook has found himself in a strange position. It looks like someone knows about an important flaw in Apple’s flagship product, and won’t tell its chief executive what it is.

headline: Taking Someone Off Your iPhone’s Blocked List
abstract: Apple’s iOS 9 system makes it easy to block — and unblock — contacts who try to call you.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do you unblock a number that had been previously blocked on the iPhone 6?

headline: In Defense of Moderate Drinking (Again)
abstract: A new study is leading some to say “alcohol may not be good for you after all,” but it excludes a lot of research.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I wrote an article here on The Upshot discussing the potential health effects of alcohol. I pointed out that the scientific research said moderate drinking isn’t bad for you; indeed, it might even offer some benefits.

headline: Don Cheadle on Becoming Miles Davis
abstract: In “Miles Ahead,” Mr. Cheadle stars as the jazz trumpeter and composer in a film he also directed.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Don Cheadle was not looking to play Miles Davis. He had done biopics before, starring as Sammy Davis Jr. in “The Rat Pack” (1998), which earned him a Golden Globe, and as the hotelier and accidental humanitarian Paul Rusesabagina in the 2004 film “Hotel Rwanda,” for which he received an Academy Award nomination. Mr. Cheadle had played the street hoops star Earl Manigault, a.k.a. the Goat, in “Rebound” and the radio D.J. Petey Greene in “Talk to Me”.

headline: Blogger Gets Jail Term in Singapore for Posts Said to Incite Ethnic Hatred
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The pregnant Japanese-Australian woman was arrested while on vacation in Singapore with her husband, who also faces charges.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Japanese-Australian woman was sentenced on Wednesday to a 10-month jail term in Singapore over blog posts that besmirched foreigners in the city-state.

headline: Rule to Require Employers to Disclose Use of Anti-Union Consultants
abstract: The Labor Department says workers are often in the dark about who is trying to sway them when they exercise their labor rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Labor Department on Wednesday released the final version of a rule requiring employers to disclose relationships with the consultants they hire to help persuade workers not to form a union or support a union’s collective bargaining position.

headline: Raiding the Sex Shop for the Latest Fashion
abstract: Fetish wear has infiltrated the runways and woven itself inextricably into the fabric of fashion.
lead_paragraph: “Hmm … I’ll have what she’s having,” I thought last week as I watched the Saint Laurent spring runway show online, the model’s ball-bearing hips sheathed in a black latex bodysuit.

headline: Three Rules of Kremlin Power
abstract: Stalin and Putin follow the same playbook for being a successful autocrat.
lead_paragraph: AT a recent awards ceremony at the Kremlin for scientists, artists and public intellectuals, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia couldn’t help but recount his country’s achievements. But he also offered a word of caution. “We still have a lot of unsolved problems and questions,” he said. “It is certainly no time for us to be ‘dizzy with success.’”

headline: Ex-Trader Tom Hayes Ordered to Pay $1.2 Million in Libor Case
keywords: ['Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Mr. Hayes was the first person to go to trial in Britain and be convicted on criminal charges related to the manipulation of the benchmark interest rate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A judge on Wednesday ordered Tom Hayes, a former UBS and Citigroup trader, to forfeit more than 878,000 pounds, or about $1.2 million, in bonuses and other compensation because of his conviction last year of manipulating a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: ‘Daredevil’ Season 2: Watched It All? Let’s Talk
abstract: After watching all 13 episodes, our critic says that more isn’t necessarily more.
lead_paragraph: Bingeing through the full second season of “Daredevil” exposes you to some of the promises and the pitfalls of Netflix original series. This adaptation of the Marvel comic book about a blind vigilante doesn’t pander to its audience, unless your definition of pandering includes taking the demands of the superhero and crime-noir genres seriously and conscientiously to be a form of pandering per se. And you can see Netflix’s dollars at work, in the explosions and elaborate props and endless waves of ninjas. (O.K., maybe it’s the same 10 ninjas over and over again.)

headline: Sext and the Single Girl
abstract: In “Girls and Sex,” Peggy Orenstein investigates the effects of hookups, pornography, alcohol, celebrities and social media on the intimate lives of young women.
lead_paragraph: GIRLS AND SEXNavigating the Complicated New LandscapeBy Peggy Orenstein303 pp. Harper. $26.99.

headline: Square Teams Up With Facebook to Offer Ads That Can Be Gauged
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The online payments company will allow its customers to buy and target Facebook ads and then use sales data to assess the impact of those ads.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Square has long pitched itself to small businesses as a one-stop shop for processing customers’ credit cards. Now the company wants to help get more of those customers in the door.

headline: As Coal Prospects Decline, a Colorado Town Reconsiders Marijuana
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Coal', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Mines and Mining', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Hotchkiss banned marijuana shops after the state legalized the drug in 2012. But now it is weighing replacing its lost coal earnings with marijuana money.
lead_paragraph: HOTCHKISS, Colo. — This mountain town of coal miners and organic farmers wasted no time in saying no to marijuana. After Colorado’s 2012 vote legalizing marijuana, local leaders concerned about crime and the character of their tranquil downtown twice voted to ban the recreational and medical pot shops springing up in other towns.

headline: Rise Up! Sourdough Nation
abstract: Getting started with sourdough, a no-recipe chicken gratin and more for the middle of the week.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Doctors Experiment With New Way of Fixing the A.C.L.
abstract: Preliminary results suggest that healing an original A.C.L. without the usual grafts may be a viable option in the future.
lead_paragraph: Anterior cruciate ligaments often tear on the sports field, and after a complete rupture, they are notoriously hard to get to heal.

headline: What Obama Should Know About Macri’s Argentina
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The U.S. must not overlook the new president’s cavalier attitude to democratic institutions.
lead_paragraph: During his trip to Argentina this week, President Obama is unlikely to visit Milagro Sala. A prominent social activist in the northwestern province of Jujuy, Ms. Sala was arrested in January at the behest of Gov. Gerardo Morales, a political ally of the country’s new president, Mauricio Macri.

headline: Flint Water Crisis Inquiry Finds State Ignored Warning Signs
abstract: An independent task force charged with investigating the city’s tainted water also laid part of the blame on environmental racism.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel has concluded that disregard for the concerns of poor and minority people contributed to the government’s slow response to complaints from residents of Flint, Mich., about the foul and discolored water that was making them sick, determining that the crisis “is a story of government failure, intransigence, unpreparedness, delay, inaction and environmental injustice.”

headline: Bob Mould’s Advice: Keep It Simple and Avoid Streaming Music Services
abstract: The guitarist and former frontman, who has a new record, “Patch the Sky,” has found a comfort zone in direct songs.
lead_paragraph: By now, Bob Mould knows what he’s good at.

headline: MoMA Revisits the 1960s
abstract: The museum has narrowed its focus for a show that will include drawings, design, film and more.
lead_paragraph: The installation of the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection has for years been the purview of one or two curators from its department of painting and sculpture, who concentrate almost exclusively on those mediums. But faced with reinstalling its fourth-floor permanent collection galleries after a Picasso sculpture show, MoMA is suspending a familiar postwar narrative. Instead, it has narrowed the focus to the 1960s, one of the most artistically diverse decades of the 20th century, while inviting 17 curators to collaborate on a wide-angle view of the period’s achievements.

headline: Shapes of Morocco at New York Live Arts
abstract: In a 55-minute solo work that uses chalk and tape, Radouan Mriziga focuses on the patterning so frequently seen in the country of his birth.
lead_paragraph: Radouan Mriziga considers himself an artisan as well as a dancer and choreographer. He treats his body as a tool to fashion not only changing shapes in space but also forms on the floor on which he moves. In “—55,” his 55-minute solo that is to have its American premiere as part of the Live Arts Live Ideas festival, he uses chalk and tape to trace intricate lines and circles on the stage while he dances. His bodily motions may vanish, but his designs remain.

headline: ‘You, Me and the Apocalypse’: Are We Ready for the End?
abstract: A lot of hopes are riding on diverting a comet and finding a savior as the show’s season finale airs.
lead_paragraph: “You, Me and the Apocalypse” hasn’t been the ratings success that NBC hoped for, but it has been one of the season’s most enjoyable series nonetheless. Its finale is Thursday night, March 31, and the fate of the world hangs in the balance. A comet is on a collision course with Earth, and multiple plot threads have been counting down to impact day. A lot of hopes were riding on a plan to divert the comet with a nuclear blast, but — well, we’ll say no more here in case you want to binge this very binge-able series later.

headline: Flint Water Advisory Task Force Report
abstract: Findings of the Flint Water Task Force, created by Michigan Governor Rick Snyder to investigate lead contamination in the city’s water supply.
lead_paragraph: Findings of the Flint Water Task Force, created by Michigan Governor Rick Snyder to investigate lead contamination in the city’s water supply.

headline: In Zayn Malik’s ‘Mind of Mine,’ a Singer Eager to Reclaim Parts of Himself
abstract: In a solo album after five years with One Direction, Mr. Malik sings a song in Urdu, a reminder of how pop has not fully allowed him to breathe.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most impassioned vocals on “Mind of Mine,” the solo debut of the One Direction dissident Zayn Malik, come on a modest mid-album interlude called “Flower.” The producer Malay plays a gentle folk-influenced guitar figure, and Mr. Malik exhales deeply atop it and then begins singing with deeply centered but controlled fervor, “Until the flower of this love has blossomed/Until this heart is at peace.” Then, three times, he pleads, “Give me your heart.”

headline: ‘Fully Committed,’ a Restaurant Story, Is Broadway Bound
abstract: Starring Jesse Tyler Ferguson, this one-person play by Becky Mode was an Off Broadway hit in 1999.
lead_paragraph: Take a funny hit show that had a long run in a small Off Broadway theater in the late 1990s, add a charismatic television star and revive it on Broadway: This formula worked well for “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” which debuted in 1998 and triumphantly arrived uptown with Neil Patrick Harris in 2014.

headline: Sam Peckinpah Features at Film Society
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center will screen all 14 of this director’s features, beginning with three westerns.
lead_paragraph: Sam Peckinpah (1925-1984) was known for his movies about savage collisions between old eras and new, reflecting his own experience as a director who straddled the studio system and New Hollywood. Difficult and headstrong, Mr. Peckinpah made films that critics said glorified carnage and were more than faintly misogynistic. Even so, his bleak morality tales re-energized several genres.

headline: Jen Shyu Presents ‘Song of Silver Geese’ at Roulette
abstract: This singer and composer’s latest project, “Song of Silver Geese,” is a “ritual music drama” performed in seven languages.
lead_paragraph: The ambition of the singer and composer Jen Shyu keeps pushing outward. She has drawn large parts of her music from travel and study in places including East Timor, Taiwan and Indonesia, where she has learned spoken languages, folk narratives, dances and instrumental techniques. At home in New York, she invests this knowledge in improvisation, working with some of the best jazz musicians around. There’s great erudition in her work, but she wears it lightly; what you notice, both in her singing and her band-leading, is wild originality, purpose and discipline. Ms. Shyu’s latest project is “Song of Silver Geese,” a “ritual music drama” performed in seven languages. It is written for her band, Jade Tongue, as well as a string quartet, and the dancer Satoshi Haga serves as her narrative foil. Its first performance, with the Mivos Quartet, will be on Monday, March 28. (Roulette, Brooklyn; roulette.org.)

headline: ‘Yardbird’ Imagines a Ghostly Charlie Parker Encore
abstract: This opera features the tenor Lawrence Brownlee in the role of the sax legend.
lead_paragraph: The tenor Lawrence Brownlee is familiar to New York opera audiences for his precise coloratura and smooth bel canto singing. This week, he shows off a different side of his artistry — including wordless scat riffs — in the role of Charlie Parker for the New York premiere of “Yardbird,” an opera by the composer Daniel Schnyder and the librettist Bridgette A. Wimberly.

headline: 1966: Chinese-Soviet Split
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Peking breaks off party relations with the Soviets in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Peking’s rulers broke off Communist party relations with the Soviet Union today [March 23], creating a rupture between the two great powers that appeared impossible to heal.

headline: Google Showcases Its Cloud Efforts, Determined to Catch Up to Rivals
abstract: A two-day conference featuring machine learning software and tools is aimed at demonstrating Google’s commitment to cloud computing.
lead_paragraph: In the cloud computing business, Google’s technology prowess is rarely questioned. Its commitment, however, has been doubted.

headline: John Legend to Co-Produce Play About Dick Gregory
abstract: The play, called “Turn Me Loose,” will star Joe Morton and will feature an original song by Mr. Legend.
lead_paragraph: John Legend, the Oscar-winning musician, has signed on to produce a new Off Broadway play about Dick Gregory, the influential comedian and civil rights activist.

headline: For One Los Angeles Designer, Jewelry Mingles With Fine Art
abstract: Kathryn Bentley of Dream Collective brings T into her midcentury home in Montecito Heights.
lead_paragraph: For the designer Kathryn Bentley, jewelry is as much about sculpture as it is fashion, thanks to a background in academic fine art and an affinity for raw materials. Her brand and four-year-old store in Silver Lake, Dream Collective, is evidence of her magpie eye, and serves as an indicator of her latest influences: She stocks everything from stoneware peace pipes by the artist Ben Medansky to the cult perfume range by Coqui Coqui. “I am rarely looking at other jewelry,” she says. “Art is my inspiration. And how things are made — the actual hands-on part of it. That’s what is interesting for me.”

headline: At Home With Kathryn Bentley in Montecito Heights
abstract: The jewelry designer, sculptor and owner of Dream Collective takes T on a tour of her midcentury home.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry designer, sculptor and owner of Dream Collective takes T on a tour of her midcentury home.

headline: Republicans Channel the Bundys With Federal-Land Bill
keywords: ['Federal Lands', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: Representatives from Utah have taken the Bundy gang’s demands as their own cause.
lead_paragraph: Say what you will about Utah’s delegation to the House of Representatives, they don’t negotiate with insurrectionists, terrorists or common criminals. They waited a whole month after a group of armed fanatics seized control of federal lands in Oregon, threatening to kill federal or local law officers, before they gleefully took on the criminal gang’s demands as their own cause.

headline: Seattle Man Descends From 80-Foot Tree After 24 Hours
abstract: The long-bearded man had been in the sequoia tree downtown since Tuesday morning, creating a national spectacle.
lead_paragraph: Equipped with snacks and warm clothing, an agitated man climbed an 80-foot sequoia tree in downtown Seattle and defied efforts to bring him down for more than 24 hours before finally descending Wednesday.

headline: These Apps Promise to Encrypt Your Smartphone Communications
abstract: Signal, Wickr Me and others use encryption to allow users to privately share photos, make voice calls and send texts and emails.
lead_paragraph: THE topic of smartphone security and secure communication is front and center these days, thanks to the battle between Apple and the F.B.I. over opening up an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., mass attackers.

headline: Exploring the Cordillera de los Frailes in Bolivia
abstract: In the Cordillera de los Frailes of Bolivia, the Jal’qa people commune with another world.
lead_paragraph: In the Cordillera de los Frailes of Bolivia, the Jal’qa people commune with another world.

headline: In the Mountains of Bolivia, Encounters With Magic
abstract: A trek through Bolivia’s dramatic Cordillera de los Frailes reveals the fantastical culture and art of the indigenous Jalq’a people.
lead_paragraph: With a face as creased as a walnut shell and a smile as gleeful as it was toothless, 98-year-old Augustina Lamagril welcomed us into the small shop inside her adobe home. Rickety wooden shelves were stocked with sardines, cigarettes, beer, soda, kitchen utensils, light bulbs and other household goods. Beneath posters of the Virgin Mary and baby Jesus, two metal-framed beds were heaped with blankets. From the ceiling — rice sacks that had been stapled together — the corpses of hummingbirds dangled from strings, drying.

headline: What Canada Learned From Rob Ford (and What America Could)
abstract: The Toronto mayor’s fiascos say something unnerving about the outer limits of politics.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everything about Rob Ford, the former Toronto mayor who died on Tuesday at 46, was text, needing little subtext. He looked like a character in a Coen Brothers film: corpulent, corrupt, but with a clear knack for physical comedy. Tossing a ceremonial football, he’d trip over his own feet. Trying to dash around the City Council room, he’d plow into a mild-looking woman in a kelly green suit. Something about the picture of him standing with his crack-cocaine dealers added texture to his story. It is impossible to imagine what would have happened if that mind had been implanted in another sort of body.

headline: Malik Taylor, Phife Dawg of A Tribe Called Quest, Dies at 45
abstract: He was a wry and agile rapper from Queens who would refer frequently to his home base, Linden Boulevard and 192nd Street, throughout his career.
lead_paragraph: Malik Taylor, the wry and agile rapper known as Phife Dawg, who as a member of A Tribe Called Quest brought left-of-center hip-hop to the masses, died on Tuesday at his home in the San Francisco Bay Area. He was 45.

headline: The Kitchen Announces Spring Season
abstract: The season opens with Joan Jonas’s “They Come to Us Without a Word II.”
lead_paragraph: Joan Jonas, whose “They Came to Us Without a Word” at the Venice Biennale last year was seen as a triumph, will bring a version of the work to the Kitchen to open its spring season.

headline: Names of the Brussels Victims Emerge Online, One by One
abstract: Families and friends are turning to social media to find out the fates of the missing.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after the deadly suicide bombings in Brussels on Tuesday, relatives and friends of Léopold Hecht, a Belgian college student, were hoping that he would emerge safely from the chaos. Without his cellphone, maybe, and perhaps in a hospital bed, but safe.

headline: Obama Declares a New Partnership After Talks With Argentine Leader
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Obama met with the President Mauricio Macri as part of a trip aimed at improving America’s standing in the region.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Obama on Wednesday declared a fresh era of partnership between the United States and Argentina, saying he stood ready to support Mauricio Macri, the country’s new president, in his bid to improve the nation’s economy and credibility on the world stage.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Too-Long Road to Recovery
abstract: The cost-cutting announced Wednesday by the Swiss bank’s chief executive, Tidjane Thiam, could have been done much earlier.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse is closer to making acceptable returns for shareholders — but it has taken too long a road to get there.

headline: Uncovering the Links Between the Brussels and Paris Attackers
abstract: At least two of the attackers are believed to have had roles in both plots.
lead_paragraph: At least two of the attackers are believed to have had roles in both plots.

headline: Musical Adaptation of ‘Roman Holiday’ Aims for Broadway
abstract: The newest version of the musical, “Roman Holiday – The Cole Porter Musical,” is to be presented at the Golden Gate Theater in San Francisco starting on May 24, 2017.
lead_paragraph: A musical adaptation of “Roman Holiday” will be staged in San Francisco during the spring of 2017, with a planned transfer to Broadway that fall, the show’s producers said Wednesday.

headline: Brussels Attacks Rekindle Debate Over Airport Security
abstract: Experts say that despite the risks, there are practical limits to imposing additional screening measures on the millions of people who travel each day.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the hours after the attacks in Brussels on Tuesday, many countries quickly added soldiers and police officers at airports and rail and subway stations, hoping to reassure passengers and deter other potential terrorists.

headline: Alabama Governor, Robert Bentley, Denies Having Affair With Aide
abstract: Mr. Bentley, responding to accusations by Spencer Collier, who had been fired as the state’s top law enforcement official, admitted making sexually charged remarks.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama acknowledged Wednesday that he had made inappropriate and sexually charged remarks to one of his closest aides, but he denied an accusation that he and the woman had pursued a physical relationship.

headline: For the Bulls, Change Has Not Been for the Better
abstract: Under Fred Hoiberg, the Bulls were supposed to learn to score. Instead, they have regressed, on offense and defense, from when Tom Thibodeau was coach.
lead_paragraph: An N.B.A. playoff team with a great defense and a building-block star fired its polarizing coach and replaced him with a rookie coach who had been a sharpshooter in the 1990s. It was a recipe that worked so well for the Golden State Warriors that the Chicago Bulls went out and did virtually the same thing a year later.

headline: Poll Suggests Donald Trump Would Be Weak Candidate in November
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Donald J. Trump would be the weakest Republican presidential candidate to face off against Hillary Clinton in a general election matchup, according to a new poll that shows Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John Kasich as stronger nominees against the Democratic front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump would be the weakest Republican presidential candidate to face off against Hillary Clinton in a general election matchup, according to a new poll that shows Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John Kasich as stronger nominees against the Democratic front-runner.

headline: Valeant Has Few Options to Remove a Recalcitrant Director
abstract: Howard Schiller has been accused of improper conduct, but he refuses to leave quietly, and Valeant Pharmaceuticals is stuck.
lead_paragraph: Howard B. Schiller, the former chief financial officer and a current board member of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, refuses to leave quietly, and a quirk in the laws makes it likely that he will be around a bit longer.

headline: Risky Rats Give Clues on Brain Circuitry Behind Taking a Chance
abstract: A new study found that a specific type of neuron in a certain brain region helps galvanize whether or not a risky choice is made.
lead_paragraph: When people make risky decisions, like doubling down in blackjack or investing in volatile stocks, what happens in the brain?

headline: Steps Arranged by Women, With History, at Dance Theater of Harlem
abstract: This company’s new initiative, Women Who Move Us, created to support new work by women, could signal the start of a new artistic direction.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the world of ballet has been scrutinized and criticized for two things: its lack of diversity and the paucity of female choreographers. Dance Theater of Harlem has the first one covered. This season, it will do something about the second.

headline: A ‘Festival Summit’ by Hunter
abstract: The British wet-weather fashion brand trades the runway for a London jazz club.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last December, Hunter — the British wet-weather brand — announced that it was giving up its slot on the London Fashion Week schedule.

headline: Lead Problems Elsewhere Prompt New York Schools to Show Drinking Water Is Safe
abstract: The Education Department was sending letters home with students that include an address for a website where parents can track the results of lead testing in schools.

headline: Fight to Keep Alternative Energy Local Stymies an Industry
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Some officials and residents are promoting less centralized energy-generating systems instead of giant transmission networks, and conflict is growing.
lead_paragraph: COWGILL, Mo. — Up and down the center of the country, winds rip across plains, ridges and plateaus, a belt of unharnessed energy capable of powering millions of customers, with enormous potential to help meet national goals to stem climate change.

headline: Demography Is Destiny? Teaching About Cause and Effect With Global Population Trends
abstract: In this lesson, we use The Times to investigate important global demographic trends today, and we consider what these trends might and might not mean for the future.
lead_paragraph: There’s a common saying: Demography is destiny. It holds that population trends and distributions determine the future of a country, region or even the entire world. For example, if the human population increases too fast or too slowly, or if there are too many young or old people, then certain outcomes are likely to follow, such as economic boom or bust, political unrest or mass migration.

headline: Brussels Attack Victim, Olivier Delespesse, Remembered as a Devoted Colleague
abstract: A co-worker of Mr. Delespesse, 45, a civil servant, described him as “very playful” and “someone who was deeply interested in people.”
lead_paragraph: When Olivier Delespesse, who was seldom late, did not show up for work on Tuesday, his colleagues said they began to worry. They made desperate appeals on Facebook to find him.

headline: From Paris, With Vinyl: Courrèges, Space Age Pioneer, Flies Again
abstract: The Courrèges designers arrive in New York to celebrate the label’s return.
lead_paragraph: Lapin à la moutarde (rabbit in mustard sauce) is a grandmotherly French classic that has not yet had a wide revival among those New York restaurants that have made a fetish of pork belly and foie gras.

lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., affirmed statements made by a top league executive who said that football-related head trauma was linked to brain disease.

lead_paragraph: It is hard to turn back after going big. When people moved up to big-screen televisions, nobody wanted to switch back to small TVs. Larger computer monitors have also ruined smaller screens for many people.

lead_paragraph: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The New York Times will pose questions from readers (and some of our own) to notable showrunners.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the United States declared war on Al Qaeda after the Sept. 11 attacks, American leaders took the fight to the militant group’s hide-outs in Afghanistan, a faraway and failing state, with an invasion and occupation.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an address billed as an examination of the future of politics, Speaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin on Wednesday admonished politicians in both parties for debasing political discourse, urging candidates to lift their gaze toward matters of serious policy and to strive for civility.

abstract: On the care, feeding and wrangling of fog.
lead_paragraph: The barometric pressure affects it. So do the whims of air-conditioning systems. Under the wrong circumstances, it could get whooshed into the crowd the moment the curtain rises.

headline: Face-Off Between Strongmen Exposes Afghanistan’s Political Rifts

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In northern Afghanistan, a dispute over billboard portraits of the country’s vice president has inflamed tensions between two of the most powerful regional strongmen, exposing internal political strains even as the government faces a dire challenge from Taliban offensives.

headline: Fitness Entrepreneur Pleads Guilty in Wire Fraud Case
abstract: Joshua Newman, a fitness entrepreneur, bilked at least 30 investors out of about $3.1 million, authorities said.

headline: Family Sees TV Talent Scout Where Israeli Authorities See Jihadist Spy
abstract: Majd Oweida, 22, was arrested on his way out of Gaza. He said he was seeking contestants for a show, but he was charged with hacking airport computers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The young man was on his way out of Gaza on an innocent-seeming mission: to scout potential contestants for his embryonic “Palestinians Got Talent” television show and meet the show’s West Bank staff in Ramallah. He had an Israeli permit for the journey.

headline: Moynat Sets Up Shop on Madison Avenue
abstract: Nike is hosting a sneaker convention, 3.1 Phillip Lim is introducing a new bag, C21 Edition is having a men’s designer suit event, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Moynat, the French luxury travel-goods house, will open a New York shop. Inside a cathedral-like space in one of the 19th-century brownstones just south of the old Whitney Museum, you will find the 160-year-old heritage label’s full range of women’s and men’s leather goods and accessories, luggage and textiles, including a store-exclusive Danse bag in supple nubuck leather inspired by the rectangular volume of a classic trunk ($3,593). At 937 Madison Avenue.

headline: U.S. Should Follow Canada’s Lead on Heroin Treatment
abstract: To combat a crisis, Vancouver opened a supervised-injection center.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA — The crisis that led officials in Ithaca, N.Y., to consider opening a supervised-injection center for heroin users, part of what the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has called a national epidemic of overdose deaths, is sadly familiar to us here.

lead_paragraph: Times editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal talks about Brussels, a proposal to exploit land in Utah and Game of Thrones

headline: Review: ‘Batman v Superman’ ... v Fun?
abstract: The film, pitting Ben Affleck against Henry Cavill, largely serves as an extended trailer for a slate of coming DC Comics movies like “Wonder Woman.”
lead_paragraph: What an adversarial time this is. Hulk Hogan versus Gawker. “The People v. O. J. Simpson.” Bernie versus Hillary. Trump versus Everybody. And now Batman versus Superman. One of these things is not like the others, I know. Two of the most famous good guys in pop culture can’t really be enemies, can they? The Gotham Bat and the Man of Steel inhabit the same intellectual-property universe, and the fight between them is, depending on how you look at it, either a diabolical stunt cooked up by Lex Luthor or a cynical cash grab engineered by DC and Warner Brothers.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Says He Will Retire After 2017 Season
abstract: Rodriguez told ESPN on Wednesday that he would retire at the end his current 10-year deal with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez has been in the major leagues for over two decades, will turn 41 in July and has compiled an incredibly complicated résumé that includes the fourth most career home runs in baseball, three Most Valuable Player Awards and a yearlong drug suspension.

headline: Hillary Clinton Dismisses Rivals for ‘Reckless Actions’ in Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Speaking in the heart of Silicon Valley, Hillary Clinton called for an “intelligence surge” to defeat the Islamic State and offered a sharp rebuke to the national security credentials of her Republican presidential rivals.
lead_paragraph: In her most vigorous assault yet on her Republican rivals, Hillary Clinton on Wednesday ridiculed the foreign policy prescriptions of Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz, calling them “reckless actions” that would alienate America’s closest allies, demonize Muslims and empower Russia.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Mom/Not Mom/Aunt
abstract: The actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson reads the story of a gay couple’s need and a sister’s gift.
lead_paragraph: In the 11th episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson (“Modern Family,” “Fully Committed” on Broadway) reads “Mom/Not Mom/Aunt” by Jerry Mahoney.

headline: Boston Lyric Opera Announces Itinerant 2016-17 Season
abstract: The company will mark its 40th anniversary by presenting four operas on four different Boston stages as it continues to search for a permanent home.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Lyric Opera, which is leaving its longtime home at the Shubert Theater, announced on Wednesday that it would mark its 40th anniversary next season by presenting four operas on four different Boston stages — including the East Coast premiere of Calixto Bieito’s staging of Bizet’s “Carmen” — as it continues to search for a permanent home.

headline: Ted Cruz Deplores ‘Liberal, Left-Wing Values’ While Lobbying for New York Votes
abstract: Considered an underdog in the state’s primary next month, Senator Ted Cruz seemed to connect with a Manhattan audience, some of whom even cheered his “New York values” remarks.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz spoke in a stately reception hall — with two chandeliers, cushioned seats and what appeared to be a gilded eagle — as a vendor out front, on Manhattan’s West 51st Street, sold knockoff bags and heavily discounted wool hats.

headline: Republican Pennsylvania Senator to Meet With Merrick Garland
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The announcement by Patrick J. Toomey, who faces a tough re-election fight, was an apparent response to calls for him to consider the Supreme Court nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Patrick J. Toomey, a Pennsylvania Republican facing a difficult re-election fight in a Democratic-leaning state, said Wednesday that he would meet with Judge Merrick B. Garland, an apparent response to calls for him to consider President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee.

headline: Yi Fuxian, Critic of China’s Birth Policy, Returns as an Invited Guest
abstract: The University of Wisconsin researcher says that China’s economy will never surpass America’s because of its aging population and shrinking labor force.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Eight thousand miles is a long way to fly someone so he can tell you you’re wrong.

headline: Journalist Jailed in Eastern India Over Social Media Post
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Social Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Prabhat Singh was accused of circulating obscene material and arrested after a post criticizing the police and calling for protections for reporters.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A journalist in eastern India was arrested after he posted a message on social media criticizing the police and calling for legal protections for reporters in the violence-scarred region, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Doug DuBois’s “In Good Time”
abstract: The photographer’s work goes on view this week at Aperture Foundation, presented by the Hermès Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s work goes on view this week at Aperture Foundation, presented by the Hermès Foundation.

headline: Everyday Portraits That Go Beyond Intimacy
abstract: Doug Dubois’s first midcareer survey — subjects include teenagers on an Irish council estate and Dubois’s mother — is on view starting this week.
lead_paragraph: “If my work was as good as an Hermès bag, or sold as much, well, that would be nice!” jokes the photographer Doug Dubois. But Hermès has offered a different kind of validation for Dubois’s intimate portraiture: Cory Jacobs, who’s served as the label’s go-to photography curator for the last seven years, has curated Dubois’s first midcareer survey, “In Good Time,” which opens this week at the Aperture Foundation in New York.

headline: Prosecutor Won’t Seek Prison for Peter Liang, Ex-Officer Convicted in Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: District Attorney Ken Thompson said Mr. Liang, who was found guilty in a fatal shooting at a Brooklyn housing project, should receive probation.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office announced on Wednesday that it would not seek prison time for the former New York City police officer convicted last month in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in a housing project in East New York.

headline: Let’s Bring Back the Spring Coat
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Denim and leather will never go out of style, but try welcoming the new season with a change. Plus: mesh socks and a smart new Polish label.
lead_paragraph: Denim and leather will never go out of style, but try welcoming the new season with a change. Plus: mesh socks and a smart new Polish label.

headline: Review: ‘The Caped Crusade’ and Batman’s Reach Beyond — Gasp! — Comic Book Lore
abstract: Glen Weldon’s book is a roaring getaway car of guilty pleasures — film gossip, comic-book esoterica, tales of nerd rage — for more than Bat-fans.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, I would have said that the world could be divided into two types of people: Those who think deeply about the hermeneutics of Batman, and those who do not. That was before reading Glen Weldon’s “The Caped Crusade: Batman and the Rise of Nerd Culture.” I’m now of the mind that there’s a continuum from normals to nerds. I land somewhere in the middle.

headline: Brighter Lights, Bigger City: The Odeon’s Second Act
abstract: The restaurant acquires new life thanks to the arrival of Condé Nast downtown (plus regular infusions of new money).
lead_paragraph: The publisher and TriBeCa resident Judith Regan was in her reliable old neighborhood restaurant the Odeon the other day when she smelled something different in the air, and it certainly wasn’t a new entree on the menu.

headline: Inside the Button Shop
abstract: Tender Buttons is in a tiny Manhattan townhouse, but it may house millions of buttons, practical, whimsical and collectible.
lead_paragraph: Tender Buttons is in a tiny Manhattan townhouse, but it may house millions of buttons, practical, whimsical and collectible.

headline: Cure for the Lost Button
abstract: Tender Buttons, on the Upper East Side, sells modern and collectible versions and is popular with celebrities in search of the very small treasures.
lead_paragraph: If everything else were destroyed, buttons would not be a bad representation of the last few centuries of human history. They have recorded, in miniature, the French Revolution, the construction of the railroads, whaling voyages and countless modern fascinations: dogs, cartoons, telephones, martinis.

headline: Bruins’ Stempniak Brings Long Résumé and New Uniform to Garden
abstract: Lee Stempniak, who has played for nine N.H.L. teams, will face the Rangers on Wednesday in the 782nd game of his itinerant career.
lead_paragraph: Lee Stempniak, a 33-year-old Boston Bruins forward (and former Blue, Maple Leaf, Coyote, Flame, Penguin, Ranger, Jet and Devil) arrived at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday for the 782nd game of his much-traveled N.H.L. career.

headline: Joe Garagiola, a Catcher Who Called a Better Game on TV, Is Dead at 90
abstract: A player in the majors for nine forgettable seasons, he went on to become a colorful broadcaster for NBC, which also made him a host of the “Today” show.
lead_paragraph: Joe Garagiola, who spent nine forgettable seasons in the major leagues as a weak-hitting catcher and then parlayed his witty tales of life as a baseball underachiever into a far more notable career as a folksy broadcaster and television personality, died on Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 90.

headline: Donald Trump Accuses Muslims of Ignoring Terror Plots in Their Midst
abstract: A day after the terror attack in Brussels, Mr. Trump said Muslims bore responsibility for such attacks because they had been looking the other way.
lead_paragraph: A day after Islamic State terrorists detonated suicide bombs in Brussels, Donald J. Trump, the leading Republican presidential candidate, said that Muslims bore responsibility for such attacks because they had been looking the other way.

headline: Phife Dawg: An Everyman Hero of Hip-Hop Stands Proudly Small
abstract: Even though the rapper Malik Taylor, known as Phife, was game to brag in his rhymes, his modesty was more striking.
lead_paragraph: Hip-hop excels at poeticizing excess. Wealth, toughness, libido, swagger: The more of it there is, the thinking often goes, the better the song will be.

headline: Turning Discarded Items Into Art About Race in America
abstract: The artist Rodney McMillian has three East Coast shows running concurrently.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles artist Rodney McMillian has an ambivalent relationship with mass-produced home furnishings. On the one hand, he has rescued several examples from oblivion, like the time-ravaged lounge chair he wrestled into his car on a corner of Sunset Boulevard and later declared an artwork — untouched, stuffing spewing forth. It’s the kind of ready-made that Duchamp might have chosen if he had grown up in a working-class African-American family in Columbia, S.C., as Mr. McMillian did.

headline: Postcards to Donald Trump Show Deep Support and Reservations
abstract: A focus group of Republicans and G.O.P.-leaning voters was asked: What would Mr. Trump be like as a fifth grader? And what should his theme song be?
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — On Tuesday night, a group of Republican and Republican-leaning voters here had a decision to make about Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘De Materie,’ of Matter, Spirit and Sheep
abstract: Heiner Goebbels’s staging of the 1988 opera by the Dutch Modernist master Louis Andriessen is being performed at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Surely this is the first opera production to include 100 sheep among its performers. Heiner Goebbels’s staging of Louis Andriessen’s “De Materie,” which originated in 2014 in Germany, arrived in the vast Drill Hall of the Park Avenue Armory on Tuesday, with dozens of sheep from the Pennsylvania countryside in its cast.

headline: Progeny of the Rolling Stones Make Their Mark
abstract: As band members are mythologized in a coming museum exhibition, their scions make their cultural presence felt.
lead_paragraph: As band members are mythologized in a coming museum exhibition, their scions make their cultural presence felt.

headline: Review: Juan Siddi, With His Own Troupe, Makes a Return
abstract: Mr. Siddi and his Flamenco Santa Fe company are performing at the Joyce Theater 13 years after Mr. Siddi first appeared there.
lead_paragraph: It had the makings of a triumphant return. A young dancer first appears at the Joyce Theater in New York as a new member of a respected company. Thirteen years later, he comes back with his own troupe, named after him.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum to Receive $4.8 Million
abstract: The grant is meant to help the museum recover from severe damage incurred four years ago during Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation will give $4.8 million to the South Street Seaport Museum, which is recovering from severe damage incurred four years ago when Hurricane Sandy flooded streets around the seaport, according to state and museum officials. That damage came as the museum was just beginning to emerge from a decade of economic difficulties.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Brussels, Flint, Batman
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mudslinging Trumps the ‘Middle Way’ in Tibetan Exiles’ Election
abstract: Final voting was held for the political leadership of exiled Tibetans, a position that is often overshadowed by the presence of the Dalai Lama.
lead_paragraph: DHARAMSALA, India — It is often said that the lower the stakes, the more vicious the politics. And so it might be said of the just-concluded campaign for political leader of the Tibetan government in exile, which, given the exalted status of the Dalai Lama, was a bit like voting for the vice president to a sitting president.

headline: As Terrorists Cross Borders, Europe Sees Anew That Its Intelligence Does Not
abstract: At least one of the people named in the Brussels attack had been deported by Turkey with indications that he was a jihadist.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If another example of the failure of European intelligence services to share and act on information about potential terrorists was needed, Wednesday’s identification of the bombers in the deadly Brussels attacks the day before certainly provides it.

headline: ‘Who’s Crazy?,’ an Obscure Avant-Garde Film Project, Is Reborn
abstract: This offbeat 1960s movie, with the Living Theater company and music by Ornette Coleman, will finally have its premiere in New York.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the late 1960s when artistic vanguards joined forces: Andy Warhol produced an album with the Velvet Underground, the rock star John Lennon teamed with the conceptual artist Yoko Ono, and Norman Mailer tried his hand at experimental films.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Girl, Instagrammed: The Web Animation of a Book Review Cover
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Times’s Book Review editor, Pamela Paul, takes us inside the creation of an animated Web-based illustration.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. Here, Pamela Paul, editor of the Book Review, takes us inside the creation of an animated Web-based illustration used in a review of “Girls and Sex” by Peggy Orenstein.

headline: Review: ‘The Catch’ Is a Glossy Game of Cat and Mouse
abstract: An owner of a private investigation company is conned by the man she is planning to wed.
lead_paragraph: The 2015-16 television season has been a glossy one, full of shows about rich and powerful characters and their luxurious lives. Is there room for another? The schedulers at ABC think so, but the one they’re unveiling Thursday night, “The Catch,” seems from the premiere as if it could grow annoying pretty quickly.

headline: Son of Wrongly Cremated Woman Comes Forward, Resolving a Macabre Mystery
abstract: After a funeral home mix-up, the family of Val-Jean McDonald wondered whose body was put in her coffin. The son of the other woman saw an article about the error and told his story.
lead_paragraph: Annie Pearl Little, 82, died on Christmas Day. On the day of her funeral at McCall’s Bronxwood Funeral Home in the Bronx, the manager there called her only son, Donald Little.

headline: Other Stories of Funeral Home Mix-Ups
abstract: In response to an article about a funeral that included the body of the wrong woman in the coffin, readers wrote in to share similar accounts.
lead_paragraph: In response to an article about a funeral that included the body of the wrong woman in the coffin, readers wrote in to share similar accounts.

headline: Léopold Hecht, Actor, Law Student and Brussels Attack Victim
abstract: Mr. Hecht, who was a second-year law student at the Université Saint-Louis, was memorialized on social media for his sense of humor and improv theater performances.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Léopold Hecht was a second-year law student at the Université Saint-Louis in Brussels who enjoyed skiing and had a knack for acting.

headline: New York International Auto Show
abstract: Media previews began on Wednesday, with the unveiling of many new models. The show opens to the public on Friday and runs through April 3.
lead_paragraph: Media previews began on Wednesday, with the unveiling of many new models. The show opens to the public on Friday and runs through April 3.

headline: Review: Daymé Arocena Mixes a Cosmopolitan Vibe With an Earthy Tone
abstract: Ms. Arocena played at Subrosa with a jazz trio that had the harmonic and rhythmic complexities of hard-bop and the melodic grace of Brazilian pop.
lead_paragraph: The Cuban singer and songwriter Daymé Arocena was dressed entirely in white, the color of santería ceremonies, when she performed at Subrosa on Tuesday night, and she started her late set with a song invoking Yemayá and Ochún, the saints of oceans and rivers. Her voice opened up to approach the earthy, full-throated cries of Afro-Cuban ritual chants. But the music surrounding her was far from traditional. It was jazz from a piano-bass-drums trio, with the harmonic and rhythmic complexities of hard-bop and the melodic grace of Brazilian pop. Ms. Arocena unites cosmopolitan musicianship with deep roots.

headline: Review: Steven Page, an Ordinary Guy, Reflects on Middle Age
abstract: Mr. Page, a former member of Barenaked Ladies, focuses on songs from his new album, “Heal Thyself Pt. 1: Instinct” at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: Steven Page doesn’t fit the image of a pop performer. Stocky, in his mid-40s, with a cherubic face and graying hair, he is a founding member of Barenaked Ladies, the boisterous Canadian pop band with a fervent cult following, which he left in 2009 after two decades.

headline: Review: Wadada Leo Smith and Vijay Iyer Share Their Influence Through Duets
abstract: Mr. Smith, a trumpeter, and the pianist Vijay Iyer draw a large part of “A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke” from the visual artist Nasreen Mohamedi.
lead_paragraph: “A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke”

headline: Will the Supreme Court Buy Faulty Logic on Religious Freedom?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: For four Supreme Court justices, a “substantial” burden on religious freedom may be whatever a religious objector says it is.
lead_paragraph: What is a “substantial” burden on religious freedom? For four Supreme Court justices, the answer may be: whatever a religious objector says it is.

headline: Review: Layers in ‘Tropix,’ From Céu
abstract: This Brazilian singer-songwriter’s fourth album is stylistically varied, intricately detailed and slyly coherent.
lead_paragraph: “Tropix”

headline: Liang Sentencing Letter
abstract: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, told a judge that his office was not requesting any jail time for Peter Liang, a former New York police officer convicted of manslaughter in a 2014 shooting.
lead_paragraph: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, told a judge that his office was not requesting any jail time for Peter Liang, a former New York police officer convicted of manslaughter in a 2014 shooting.

headline: John Kasich Rejects a G.O.P. Call to Quit to Block Donald Trump
abstract: Despite a poor showing on Tuesday and Jeb Bush’s endorsement of Ted Cruz, Mr. Kasich said that he was still the best option to stop Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Republicans desperate to stop Donald J. Trump from capturing the presidential nomination increased the pressure Wednesday on Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to quit the race, with Jeb Bush joining the growing number of party figures throwing their weight behind Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Ted Cruz, Day After Brussels Attacks, Belittles Donald Trump on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With the presidential race refocused on issues of national security, Mr. Cruz cast Mr. Trump as dangerous and ill prepared.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz on Wednesday relentlessly belittled the foreign policy acumen of Donald J. Trump, casting him as dangerous and ill prepared one day after the terrorist attacks in Brussels refocused the presidential race on issues of national security.

headline: Valeant Losses Push Ackman Hedge Fund Down 25% for Year
abstract: William A. Ackman’s devotion to Valeant continues to cost him dearly, something he shares with John Paulson.
lead_paragraph: For investors in William A. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management, the recent ride down continues to be hair-raising.

headline: Quantity of Explosive Found in Belgium Surprises Officials
abstract: The explosive, triacetone triperoxide, can be made with basic chemistry skills and relatively simple equipment, but the process is risky and tedious.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by the Belgian authorities that they had confiscated more than 30 pounds of the explosive TATP from a dwelling used by the attackers in Brussels was, in some ways, an expected development. But it contained one detail that bomb-disposal technicians and security officials regarded with surprise: the quantity of the particular explosive involved.

headline: Shira Scheindlin, Judge Behind Stop-and-Frisk Ruling, Will Step Down
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Judge Scheindlin handled major First Amendment cases in her long tenure on Federal District Court and found in a controversial ruling that the New York police had engaged in racial profiling.
lead_paragraph: Judge Shira A. Scheindlin, whose more-than-21-year tenure on the Federal District Court in Manhattan included a critical role in a controversial stop-and-frisk ruling affecting the Police Department, said on Wednesday that she would resign from the bench in late April.

headline: Rita Gam, Midcentury Hollywood Actress, Dies at 88
abstract: In addition to her films, Ms. Gam was known for having been Sidney Lumet’s first wife and one of Grace Kelly’s bridesmaids.
lead_paragraph: Rita Gam, who made her eye-catching Hollywood debut without saying a word and played a real-life bridesmaid at the fairy-tale wedding of her former roommate Grace Kelly, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 88.

headline: As Alex Rodriguez Talks Retirement, Bartolo Colon Takes Different Approach
abstract: The 42-year-old Colon, whom the Mets are relying on to provide depth, said he would like to keep pitching as long as he stays healthy.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez and Bartolo Colon, the elder statesmen of their teams, chatted and joked about sticking together Tuesday before the Yankees played the Mets.

headline: Columbia Professor Files Sexual Harassment Suit Against University
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Business Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Enrichetta Ravina, an assistant professor at the business school, said university officials belittled her complaints that a colleague and mentor made repeated advances toward her.
lead_paragraph: Enrichetta Ravina thought the professor was her mentor, helping her get access to an invaluable trove of data for her research into how workers allocate their retirement savings. It was scholarship, she believed, that could help her earn tenure at Columbia Business School.

headline: Northeastern’s Journey to N.C.A.A. Tournament Began With a Trip Abroad
abstract: Northeastern (22-13-5), the fourth seed in the Midwest Region, revived its season after playing in an tournament in Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Northeastern men’s hockey team needed to get away — far away — to save its season.

headline: Outside Panel to Examine Police Shootings in Chicago
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Amid skepticism about an internal review board, which almost always sided with officers, a third party was chosen to look into past investigations.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For years, the agency charged with investigating police shootings here has routinely sided with officers who have fired their weapons. But amid widespread skepticism of those results, officials announced Wednesday that an outside law firm would examine past shootings involving officers with an eye toward restoring confidence in the review process.

headline: Crisis in Brazil Widens With Report of Firm’s Payments to Politicians
abstract: It was not clear if the payments were illegal, with analysts pointing out that the amounts differed from declared contributions, and with politicians asserting that they had done nothing wrong.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the latest twist to Brazil’s colossal corruption scandals, the country’s already beleaguered political establishment found itself under siege on Wednesday over revelations of payments made to figures across the ideological spectrum by the construction giant Odebrecht.

headline: At New York Auto Show, a Parade of New Models
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: Vehicle sales are running at a record pace, which means the car industry is willing to invest in new products and technology.
lead_paragraph: Vehicle sales in the United States are running at a record pace, prompting automakers to consider ways to capitalize on the boom times.

headline: North Carolina Bans Local Anti-Discrimination Policies
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gender']
abstract: The move came in response to passage of a Charlotte ordinance letting transgender people use public bathrooms that correspond with their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina legislators, in a whirlwind special session on Wednesday, passed a wide-ranging bill barring transgender people from bathrooms and locker rooms that do not match the gender on their birth certificates.

headline: Steps That Europe Must Take Now After Brussels
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Transit Systems', 'Police', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)']
abstract: Intelligence and police agencies must cooperate, rail and air travel must be made secure, and authorities need to earn the trust of Muslims.
lead_paragraph: The nature and full extent of the connection between the terrorist attacks in Brussels on Tuesday and the arrest, last Friday, of Salah Abdeslam, suspected of handling the logistics in November’s Paris attacks, is still unknown. Didier Reynders, Belgium’s deputy prime minister, said Mr. Abdeslam was planning to “restart something” in Brussels.

headline: Ken Howard, 71, Actor and SAG-Aftra Union President, Dies
abstract: Mr. Howard presided over the merger of the screen actors’ and television and radio actors’ unions, giving members a greater voice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ken Howard, an Emmy Award-winning actor who earned acclaim starring in “The White Shadow” in the 1970s and was the sitting president of Hollywood’s largest union, which he helped form in 2012, died on Wednesday. He was 71.

headline: F.B.I. Clash With Apple Loosed a Torrent of Possible Ways to Hack an iPhone
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy', 'iPhone', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: The prominence of the case has stimulated people worldwide to try to get into the device, and now the government has to check out their ideas.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For weeks, the United States government has said that the only way to open an iPhone used by a gunman in a mass shooting was to get Apple’s help, a position that set off a clash between the technology giant and law enforcement.

headline: For N.C.A.A. Tickets, Even Players Have to Barter
abstract: When demand exceeds supply, players often turn to bartering — or other methods — to procure tournament tickets from their teammates.
lead_paragraph: When Teyvon Myers learned that West Virginia was headed to Brooklyn for the opening rounds of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, he knew it was time to call in favors.

headline: Advertising Industry Wrestles With Bias After a Lawsuit
abstract: A conference in Miami aimed at charting the industry’s future was instead heavy with discussion about sexism in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — The advertising industry gathered here this week at a South Beach hotel expecting to grapple with the big questions that threaten its future in a rapidly changing media landscape.

headline: Joe Garagiola, an Everyman on the Field and in the Booth
abstract: He was a regular guy, a not-so-great ballplayer with a terrific sense of humor that revolutionized sportscasting.
lead_paragraph: Joe Garagiola’s career as a baseball announcer had nothing to do with being well trained or slick or having a beautiful baritone. He was a regular guy, a not-so-great ballplayer with a terrific sense of humor that revolutionized sportscasting. He could make you laugh with a phrase that skewed standard baseball speech or make you sit up to listen to some new insight. As a catcher, he had a complete vision of the field.

headline: As Siblings Again Unite to Unleash Terror, Experts Ask What Drives Them
abstract: Khalid and Ibrahim el-Bakraoui join a list of brothers involved in nearly every major terror attack on Western soil since three sets of Saudi siblings helped carry out the 9/11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The identification of Khalid and Ibrahim el-Bakraoui as suicide bombers in the deadly Brussels attacks is confronting investigators and counterterrorism experts with a disturbingly recurrent question: Why do so many terrorists turn out to be brothers?

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Twisting Career May Be Nearing Its End
abstract: Rodriguez has been endlessly fascinating, impossible to ignore from his first day in professional baseball, in 1993, until his last, most likely in late 2017.
lead_paragraph: There has never been another career quite like the twisting, twisted epoch of Alex Rodriguez — which will end, it seems, after the 2017 season. The news seemed somewhat obvious already, since Rodriguez will be 42 that July, but other careers have lasted longer.

headline: U.N. Seeks Ways to Try North Koreans for Human Rights Abuses
abstract: The Human Rights Council will appoint a panel to identify legal avenues for prosecuting North Korean leaders for crimes detailed in a 2014 report.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council decided on Wednesday to appoint a panel of experts to explore legal avenues for prosecuting North Korean leaders for crimes against humanity.

headline: Texas A&M Looks Forward, but Savors Improbable Win Over Northern Iowa
abstract: Texas A&M climbed into the round of 16 after overcoming a 12-point deficit with just over a half minute left in the game.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — As Texas A&M was descending into a 12-point deficit with just over half a minute left on Sunday, the players’ cellphones began filling up with condolence texts. The theme: awesome season, way to fight, too bad the season had to end.

headline: Review: ‘Really’ Compares the Fixed Image With Life’s Flux
abstract: Jackie Sibblies Drury’s stylishly contemplative new play is a meditation on the nature of photography.
lead_paragraph: The title of Jackie Sibblies Drury’s stylishly contemplative new play, which opened on Wednesday night at the Abrons Arts Center, is unadorned by punctuation. But it comes with its own built-in question mark, or ellipsis, or both.

headline: Reach a Conclusion
abstract: David Liben-Nowell and Tom Pepper reach their own conclusion.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Oops!” Alert! As you might have noticed, there was a typo in the Thursday puzzle. It’s fixed now. If you were solving in Across Lite, please re-download the puzzle and thank you for your patience. If your streak was broken and you would like it restored, please write an email to us via the Feedback Form on our main web puzzle page and let them know that you would like your streak restored.

headline: Don’t Sell These Point Guards Short
abstract: There is a surprising number of small guards with outsize roles playing deep in the N.C.A.A. tournament this year.
lead_paragraph: When the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament resumes Thursday in the round of 16, the key to advancing, for most teams, might be a little closer to the floor than usual.

headline: New York Muslims Reject Ted Cruz’s Prescriptions for Monitoring
abstract: The senator’s call for police officers “to patrol and secure” Muslim communities drew the scorn of those who found the comments wrongheaded and insensitive.
lead_paragraph: As Arbab Razvi watched her 4-year-old students play with blocks and beads in her prekindergarten classroom on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn, she had to raise her voice — to scold Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Rikers Guards Beat Inmate to ‘Set the Tone,’ a Prosecutor Says
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Assaults', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Jahmal Lightfoot was battered by men responsible for curbing violence at Rikers Island, a Bronx prosecutor said as nine jail officers accused of taking part in the beating went on trial.
lead_paragraph: Jahmal Lightfoot was unarmed, outnumbered and savagely beaten by men responsible for reducing violence at Rikers Island, a Bronx prosecutor said on Wednesday as the trial began for nine correction officers charged with assaulting Mr. Lightfoot when he was an inmate at New York City’s main jail complex and then lying about it.

headline: Close Hometowns Mean Close Ties at Villanova
abstract: Villanova, just a few miles from Philadelphia, has a roster that is something of a throwback, composed almost exclusively of players from the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Darryl Reynolds is used to teammates asking where to find the best cheesesteak. It comes with the territory of playing basketball for Villanova, just a few miles down the Main Line from Philadelphia.

headline: S.E.C. Orders Exxon Mobil Shareholder Vote on Climate Data
abstract: A resolution, if approved, would force the energy giant to outline for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has told Exxon Mobil it must include a resolution on its annual shareholder proxy that, if approved, would force the company to outline for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change and the legislation that aims to combat it.

headline: Murder Conviction Vacated for Man Who Served 20 Years
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Richard Rosario, 40, was released after prosecutors conceded that he had been denied effective counsel in a 1998 murder case.
lead_paragraph: Richard Rosario’s daughter fanned herself in a hallway of the Bronx County Hall of Justice on Wednesday. She was beginning to sweat, she said. Mr. Rosario’s son, Richard Jr., milled around and spoke in soft tones about being only a toddler when his father was sent away. A lawyer rushed away from the courtroom, carrying a suit in a garment bag for the elder Mr. Rosario to wear for his appearance.

headline: Dean Skelos and His Son Ask Judge to Spare Them a Prison Sentence
abstract: Mr. Skelos, the former New York Senate majority leader, and his son, Adam, who were convicted on corruption charges, requested to be allowed to perform community service instead.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dean G. Skelos, the former New York Senate majority leader, and his son, Adam B. Skelos, who were convicted of all eight bribery, extortion and conspiracy counts against them in December, asked a judge on Wednesday to let them avoid prison and be sentenced to perform community service.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Season 4, Episode 2: The Pastor Problem
abstract: Wednesday night’s episode, “Pastor Tim,” was full of gloom, foreboding and violence.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday night’s episode of “The Americans” was titled “Pastor Tim,” which was a clever bit of bait and switch. Paige’s curly-haired confidant appeared only on clandestine audio recordings (when Elizabeth finally found the spot on the church tapes where Paige told him her parents were Soviet spies) and in a nightmare — when Elizabeth imagined Paige finding him dead.

headline: Brothers in Arms
abstract: A short explanation of how brothers keep turning up as suspects in terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: A short explanation of how brothers keep turning up as suspects in terrorist attacks.

headline: Art Basel Hong Kong Opens to Less Frenzy
abstract: Some dealers noted that the atmosphere seemed more muted than last year, with fewer collectors in attendance and less frenetic first-day buying.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The first floor of the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center was already bustling when Lin Han arrived at the opening of Art Basel Hong Kong, Asia’s most important art fair.

headline: New York State Contractor Is Said to Threaten Privacy of Millions With Outsourcing
keywords: ['Outsourcing', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Privacy', 'Archives and Records', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Focused Technologies, hired by the state to digitize fingerprint records and other confidential material, has agreed to pay a $3.1 million settlement after illegally outsourcing the work to India.
lead_paragraph: The task was as simple as it was delicate.

headline: New Rules Aim to Reduce Silica Exposure at Work Sites
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Building (Construction)', 'Silica']
abstract: The Labor Department rules address the long-known danger of silica, whose particles can cause silicosis, a disabling and sometimes fatal lung disease.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Department plans to announce on Thursday new rules that sharply reduce workplace exposure to silica, a potentially deadly mineral found in materials commonly used in construction and hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

headline: Professors’ Group Says Efforts to Halt Sexual Harassment Have Stifled Speech
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Education']
abstract: A report by the American Association of University Professors called on the Department of Education and universities to draw a sharper line between sexual behavior and speech on campus.
lead_paragraph: The growing federal emphasis on combating sexual harassment on campus, along with universities’ broadening definitions of inappropriate sexual behavior, has had a chilling effect on academic freedom and speech, especially on female professors in areas like gender studies, a report released Thursday by the American Association of University Professors said.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | figurine
abstract: This word has appeared in 28 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Rangers Strengthen Position and Deal Bruins Another Loss
abstract: The Rangers furthered their push for the playoffs and home-ice advantage in the first round with a victory over Boston, which has lost four straight.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers tightened their grip on second place in the Metropolitan Division and moved closer to a playoff berth and home-ice advantage in the first round by rolling past the stumbling Boston Bruins, 5-2, on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: ShondaLand presents its latest guilty pleasure, “The Catch.” And Christopher Abbott discovers the pains of adulthood in “James White.”
lead_paragraph: ShondaLand presents its latest guilty pleasure and hardheaded heroine in “The Catch,” on ABC. And in the intimate film “James White,” Christopher Abbott stars as a young man struggling to reckon with the realities of adulthood.

headline: Entire Yahoo Board Would Be Ousted if Starboard Value Gets Its Way
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Hedge Funds', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The increasingly exasperated activist hedge fund, which memorably tormented Darden Restaurants, the Olive Garden owner, is seeking to claim its biggest corporate scalp yet.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tensions between Yahoo and its most outspoken shareholder, the activist hedge fund Starboard Value, were already running high when the two sides agreed early this year on a face-to-face meeting in Manhattan.

headline: Beyond Braveheart and Nessie: Myths and Legends in Scotland
abstract: In a country whose national animal is a unicorn, Kieran Dodds has sought to define just what it means to be Scottish.
