headline: Beyond Braveheart and Nessie: Myths and Legends in Scotland
abstract: In a country whose national animal is a unicorn, Kieran Dodds has sought to define just what it means to be Scottish.
lead_paragraph: Today would have been Scotland’s first Independence Day.

headline: An Ancient and Proven Way to Improve Memorization; Go Ahead and Try It
abstract: Showing the power of using colorful images and well-known locations.
lead_paragraph: In January, I devoted every walk from my home to the train to the contemplation of work details, hoping to improve my recall of them. That was my New Year’s resolution, and so far I’ve stuck to it.

headline: The Republicans’ Sin of Endorsement
abstract: Really, what have they got left to lose?
lead_paragraph: How can things get worse for Republicans? Jeb Bush turned out to be a terrible candidate. Marco Rubio turned out to be an annoying twit. Donald Trump is a nightmare. Something had to be done, and so the solid, steady moderate elite decided the best strategy was to rally around … Ted Cruz.

headline: Trumpism After Trump
abstract: How will the Republican Party remake itself after the great schism of 2016?
lead_paragraph: There is now no possibility that the Republican Party will survive its rendezvous with Donald Trump unbroken.

headline: Overreacting to Terrorism?
abstract: Brussels survived this week’s terror attacks, but it may not survive climate change.
lead_paragraph: Are terrorists more of a threat than slippery bathtubs?

headline: Dangerous World, Serious Leaders
abstract: Bombast is hollow, braggadocio is meaningless. This country needs its most stable and steady hands to guide it.
lead_paragraph: There is starting to be a sad, somber repetitiveness to the horror of terror attacks and the world’s reaction to them.

headline: The Senate Defers to the N.R.A.
abstract: On the Supreme Court nomination, senators aren’t just refusing to do their job — they are delegating it to paranoid far-right lobbyists.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that the most important voice in the Supreme Court nomination battle is not the American people’s, as Senate Republicans have insisted from the moment Justice Antonin Scalia died last month. It is not even that of the senators. It’s the National Rifle Association’s.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Other Candidates on Counterterrorism
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'Torture', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: After the Brussels attacks, the G.O.P. front-runners offered bravado, while Clinton articulated a sensible approach to counterterrorism.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for Tuesday’s terrorist attacks in Brussels to seep into the American presidential race. Predictably, the two leading Republicans called for severe measures against Muslims. Donald Trump also reiterated his faith in waterboarding suspected terrorists and Senator Ted Cruz said the police must “patrol and secure” Muslim neighborhoods.

headline: Can the European Center Hold?

headline: Lasting Damage for G.O.P.? Young Voters Reject Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Youth', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Research shows that political beliefs tend to be set in youth, which means Republicans could face long-term harm from a Trump nomination.
lead_paragraph: To understand the concern, and in some cases the panic, of many Republican officials over Donald Trump, consider this fact: Young people generally don’t like him. The potential of losing an election is one thing, but as polling numbers suggest, the Trump brand could weigh on the G.O.P. for a generation.

But in the end, New Zealanders chose decisively to keep their century-old flag, a blue ensign with Britain’s Union Jack in the upper left corner and the four stars of the Southern Cross in red on the right.

headline: As the Sabbath Nears in Israel, Soccer Becomes a Test of Faith
abstract: Television rights and scheduling logistics have put fans and professional players who are trying to observe the Jewish Sabbath in a tough position.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The halftime whistle blew, and Shimon Levy gathered his belongings. While most fans at Teddy Kollek Stadium converged on the concession stand for a soda or a coffee, Levy walked past the line and toward the exit. It did not matter that this second-division soccer game between Hapoel Jerusalem and Maccabi Herzliya on a Friday afternoon was delicately poised — tied at 0-0 after a handful of chances for both sides — and it did not matter that Levy had come to watch his son, who plays for the home team. Levy said he had no choice but to leave.

headline: Running on Vacation
abstract: Running while traveling can be a challenge, but one experienced road warrior has some tips to make it easier.
lead_paragraph: On the second day of a recent two-week road trip, I woke up at a Holiday Inn off Interstate 95 in Santee, S.C., and drove to a nearby state park. I was in my fifth week of marathon training and needed to complete three miles, so why not do so in a new place I might never see again? I’ve run in many unfamiliar towns and cities — Chicago; Minneapolis; Seattle; San Francisco; St. Pete Beach, Fla.; Freeport, Me.; Rome — and each jaunt has given me a unique look at a part of the world I might have missed otherwise.

headline: Jazz Records Reissued, Thanks to Readers of The Times

headline: ‘Shuffle Along’ and the Lost History of Black Performance in America
abstract: Minstrelsy. Blackface. Mugging. Out of this twisted past came one of the first successful all-black Broadway musicals. Now an ambitious revival is bringing it back.
lead_paragraph: Ninety-­five years ago in New York, a journalist named Lester Walton bought a ticket to see a much-­buzzed-­about new show, a “musical novelty” that had opened about a week before at the Sixty-­Third Street Theater. Or the Sixty-­Third Street Music Hall, as it was more properly called. A kind of multipurpose performance space, not very big, not very nice, “sandwiched in between garages,” Walton wrote, and “little known to the average Broadway theatergoer.” You could rent the place for the night. It had philosophical lectures, amateur violin recitals and religious meetings, and during the day it showed silent movies: “ ‘Pudd’n Head Wilson,’ with Theodore Roberts, tomorrow.” But on this evening — and for many months to come, as it turned out — the stage belonged to an all-black show called “Shuffle Along,” a comedy with lots of singing and dancing. A problem: The music hall had no orchestra pit, and this show needed an orchestra. It needed space for the band, which happened to include a 25-year-old musician known as Bill Still, later to become the famous composer William Grant Still, but in 1921 a mostly unheard-­of young man from Arkansas, switching among the six or seven instruments he taught himself to play. The production was forced to rip out seats in the front three rows to make room. These were people used to improvising. Among themselves, they referred to the show as “Scuffle Along.”

headline: Rick Wilson Would Take Clinton Over Trump
abstract: The Republican strategist on why his party’s front-runner is a crude lunatic but continues to lead in the polls.
lead_paragraph: You’ve gained lots of fans on the left thanks to your vicious descriptions of Trump and his supporters. Once, on MSNBC, you called his base ‘‘childless single men who masturbate to anime.’’ That was in reference to the alt-right part of his base. I wish I could take credit for it being a broader smear. If one is going to insult a group of people who think that Trump is their own private postmodern Hitler, one ought to be specific.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Hasbro Joy for All
abstract: The comfort a robot pet provides the aged is like all cat love: hard to understand, but it works.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a notable pet psychic told me that my cat might be possessed. There may be some truth to this. Whenever my cat hears the sound of a voice on speakerphone, she runs into the room with the fires of hell behind her eyes and sinks her teeth into my leg. Movie night in my home has become a twisted Pavlovian exercise, with my hand hovering above the mute button just in case a character needs to, for whatever reason, talk on a phone.

headline: Travel and Allergies: What to Do When Animals Are on Board
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'ALLERGIES', 'Pets', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Asthma', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals']
abstract: With a growing number of pets on planes and trains and in hotels, reseating and hypoallergenic rooms are options for travelers with allergies.
lead_paragraph: Allergies to peanuts, shellfish, dogs, cats and other triggers haven’t stopped 31-year-old Allie Bahn, a fourth-grade teacher and blogger from Boston, from living in Italy for three years and in Australia for seven months. She keeps medication and sanitary wipes handy. Still, she’s had mystery attacks while traveling, including a severe one last fall that forced her to flee a hotel in the middle of the night. Consequently, she prefers renting apartments, as she can interview the owners, and calls airlines in advance to determine her risk.

headline: In Hindsight, an ‘American Psycho’ Looks a Lot Like Us
abstract: When Bret Easton Ellis’s novel was published in 1991, he and his protagonist, Patrick Bateman, were equally vilified. But Bateman’s bloodlust, materialism and obsession with Donald J. Trump are all part of our current cultural fabric — including a new Broadway musical adaptation.
lead_paragraph: When Bret Easton Ellis’s “American Psycho” was about to be published in 1991, word of its portrait of a monster — an amoral young Wall Street serial killer named Patrick Bateman, who nail-gunned women to the floor before doing vastly worse to them — was met with outrage.

abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is trying to peel away delegates from Donald J. Trump in New York, where they will be allocated by congressional district unless Mr. Trump clears 50 percent, and in Wisconsin, where he hopes to win outright.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential primary race, once a frenzied sprint of rallies and retail stops, has become a grind-it-out slog. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is opening up two fronts against Donald J. Trump — trying to peel away delegates in New York, where they will be allocated by congressional district unless Mr. Trump clears 50 percent, and in Wisconsin, where he hopes to win outright.

headline: The Queen of Entrees, Restored
abstract: A contemporary (and vegetarian) adaptation of the splendid, regal chartreuse.
lead_paragraph: I first happened upon it one morning, while flipping through the Time Life Foods of the World book ‘‘Classic French Cooking’’: a photograph of an alabaster edible dome, mosaicked in carrots and turnips, with molding of green beans and English peas, its base edged by slabs of bacon and sausage and glazed tiny onions, looking for all the world like a frosted vegetable cake. It was called a chartreuse. A few days after gazing on its strange countenance, for a different reason entirely, I found myself reading about La Grande Chartreuse — not a food but a monastery built on a white Alpine ridge, reached by a single road winding through a great massif into medieval clouds, in Roy Andries de Groot’s 1973 culinary travelogue, ‘‘Auberge of the Flowering Hearth.’’ And about the Carthusians, an old silent order of vegetarians who spend their days alone in cells. I became transfixed by the dish and the monks and resolved to find out what connected the two.

headline: He Knows the Drill: Benjamin Walker Works to Make ‘American Psycho’ Sing
abstract: In this adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis’s novel, Mr. Walker is working out and absorbing his character, a smooth banker who sidelines as a killer.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekday morning, the actor Benjamin Walker put down the plastic rat he had been caressing, stripped down to his underwear and began a run-through of “American Psycho,” which opens at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on April 21. Bestriding the rehearsal room like a pomaded colossus, he sang and danced to Duncan Sheik’s electronic music, slicing and stabbing as Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa’s book demands.

headline: 1891: Mafia Agents at Work
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Mafia agents at work in the U.S. in 1891.
lead_paragraph: The metropolitan police are working assiduously to check the rapidly-growing organization of Italians in the country, which has the avowed object of taking a sanguinary revenge upon Americans for the New Orleans lynching. Detective sergeants Perezzo and Lissaro have been especially detailed to watch the movements of their countrymen. They have succeeded in tracing the whereabouts of two leaders of the Mafia in New Orleans, who arrived in New York on Friday. They are being shadowed by Inspector Byrne’s men, who have orders that on the first sign of an attempt to incite their compatriots to violence the two are to be arrested. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 25, 1891

headline: New York Legislature Cries Uncle on Ultimate Fighting

lead_paragraph: New York is about to end its hold-out position as the last remaining state to ban mixed martial arts fighting — the free-wheeling, rock ‘em, sock ‘em gladiatorial combat that was emphatically ruled out as too barbaric a sport 19 years ago. Since then M.M.A. or ultimate fighting, as it is known, has become an irresistibly popular entertainment across the nation while enacting rules to rein in some of the more spectacular violence: No more throat shots, groin kicks, hair pulling and finger breaking.

lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet announced Thursday that it would focus on new and recent works next season, with a spring festival dedicated to dances it has commissioned in recent decades, world premieres by Alexei Ratmansky and Justin Peck, and, after a notable absence of new works by women in recent seasons, premieres by Annabelle Lopez Ochoa and Lauren Lovette.

headline: Review: ‘My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2’ Is Something Tired, Something New
abstract: This long-awaited sequel to the hit romantic comedy, again written by and starring Nia Vardalos, is a washed-out recycling of ethnic clichés and exhausted jokes.
lead_paragraph: Even those who have spent the last 14 years pining for a sequel to “My Big Fat Greek Wedding” — by most accounts, the highest-grossing American romantic comedy — will rue that longing when they experience “My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2.” The imagination expended on the title being a fair indicator of how much was lavished on the rest of this embarrassingly awful retread.

lead_paragraph: Six months after he learned that his Volkswagen-made car violated clean-air rules, Tony German was still waiting to learn what to do about it. After a court ruling on Thursday, he might have to wait even longer.

headline: Madam, Kindly Remove Your Elbow From My Nose
abstract: New Yorkers tend to be prickly about our 12 to 18 inches of our personal body space. Sharing space — at the movies, on the subway, in the bike lanes — is even harder.
lead_paragraph: From what I’m seeing on the subway, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s “Dude, Stop the Spread” campaign has failed. I am not surprised. Teaching manners to New Yorkers is like trying to teach a dog to take small bites — it goes against our nature.

headline: A Daughter’s Looks Aren’t Everything
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Media', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Also, an artist persists in trying to solicit backing from a friend’s friends, and sibling housemates lay down the law on one’s desire to have her boyfriend stay the night.
lead_paragraph: I have a 6-year-old daughter who is very pretty. She didn’t get her looks from her father or me, and we would find her beautiful no matter what. But people we meet love to point out how “gorgeous” and “stunning” she is. I worry that she may begin to internalize the message that her looks are her most important attribute. But saying, “She’s really smart, too,” seems like a bragging response to a compliment. And I don’t want to chastise people who mean well. Any thoughts?

headline: Gordon Parks’s “Segregation Story”
abstract: The photographer’s series following one Mobile, Ala., family first ran in Life magazine in 1956, and is just as powerful 60 years later.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s series following one Mobile, Ala., family first ran in Life magazine in 1956, and is just as powerful 60 years later.

headline: Revisiting Photos That Find Tenderness Amid Inequality
abstract: Gordon Parks’s “Segregation Story” images first ran in Life magazine 60 years ago; they are equally powerful today.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Parks’s “Segregation Story” images, first published in Life magazine in 1956, are as important today as they were 60 years ago. Though the civil rights movement is most commonly associated with black-and-white photography, these images — which are part of an exhibition opening tomorrow at Weinstein Gallery in Minneapolis — were shot on color film, and connect past and present in a more immediate way. Parks brought an equally tender and frank eye to capture and honor the intimate, everyday moments of the Thornton family and their community in Shady Grove and Mobile, Ala., showing us how they managed to live “normal” lives in conditions that were anything but. Moments of happiness, love and strength, like a church gathering or a family outing to the ice cream stand, take place under codified inequality.

headline: Weinstein Company Opposes Bill on Religion in Georgia
abstract: Weinstein said it would cancel plans to film a Lee Daniels movie there after the Assembly passed a bill that some say would lead to discrimination.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Weinstein Company, no stranger to political controversy, has threatened to end its film production in Georgia over the state’s proposed Free Exercise Protection Act, which aims to let religious officials and organizations avoid acting in violation of their beliefs. Critics say the proposed law would lead to discrimination against gay people.

headline: Desert Camping in and Around Joshua Tree

headline: Review: Philip Hanson’s Poetic Fragments, a Trippy Synthesis of Visual and Verbal
abstract: This Chicago Imagist’s paintings at James Cohan, with snippets of Emily Dickinson and William Blake, evoke mandalas intended to encourage meditation.
lead_paragraph: In funky, hallucinatory paintings by the Chicago artist Philip Hanson, at James Cohan, lines by Shakespeare, William Blake and Emily Dickinson appear as if seen in the fever dreams of a dying literature professor. Mr. Hanson came of age in the 1960s in the company of Jim Nutt, Roger Brown and other Chicago Imagists, and he was included in the 2014 Whitney Biennial. With his new works, he is creating soul-stirring synergies of the visual and the verbal.

headline: Three Young Labels Making Old Methods New Again
abstract: The founders of Etkie, Kinsfolk and Mataano employ artisans trained in ancient practices to create their globally minded clothing and accessories.
lead_paragraph: A crop of new jewelry and fashion designers are incorporating practices they discovered while traveling to their ancestral homes. Here, three brands taking cues from ancient methods — and employing artisans trained in them.

headline: In California Desert, Father and Daughter Find the Sublime
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Camps and Camping', 'Deserts', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Desert camping with a daughter leads to moments of profundity — and some loud-as-you-want shouting.
lead_paragraph: One night not long ago, my 6-year-old staggered out of her room for the fourth time, hellbent on conveying the specific anguish of insomnia. “It’s like I’m a puzzle piece for … a puzzle about nighttime but I’m a … daytime piece and I just can’t fit.” My first thought was, Go the heck to sleep (though not in those exact words). My second: The kid’s ready for the desert.

headline: Review: Beyond Irascible, the Art of Hedda Sterne
abstract: Ms. Sterne was known for her appearance in a 1951 Life magazine photo of artists protesting an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: When the new Whitney Museum of American Art opened last year, one painting in its inaugural exhibition, “America Is Hard to See,”  stood out: Hedda Sterne’s “New York, N.Y., 1955.” That dark-red-and-green work, made with an airbrush-and-enamel paint technique, looked particularly contemporary — like early graffiti painting or the recent work of Keltie Ferris.

headline: LACMA Fetes the Goldstein House

lead_paragraph: The museum held a reception in honor of the famous midcentury home.

Cuomo appears close to victories on raising the minimum wage and instituting paid family leave across New York, achievements that would cement his carefully cultivated reputation for progressive leadership.

headline: Review: The Painter Ellsworth Kelly’s Love Affair With Photography
abstract: The Matthew Marks gallery is exhibiting more than 30 gelatin silver prints by Mr. Kelly, which walk a line between the actual and the abstract.
lead_paragraph: In 1862, Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres led a group of French artists and intellectuals in a campaign against photography, signing an official petition denouncing the “industrial” method as anathema to the artist.

headline: High Above Beverly Hills, LACMA Fetes the Goldstein House
abstract: The famous Lautner house, recently bequeathed to the museum, was the backdrop for a party on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: It was a house party — as in, a party for an actual house. On Wednesday night, an art crowd shuttled up the hill and down the driveway of the famous Sheats Goldstein residence in Beverly Hills, the midcentury masterwork recently bequeathed to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. “I’ve been working for 10 years trying to figure out who to give the house to,” said its colorful owner, James F. Goldstein, a 70-something real estate developer and basketball and fashion enthusiast with a nearly all-leather wardrobe — cowboy hats, too. “I’m happy it’s going to someone local.”

headline: The Ten-Dollar Founding Father Without a Father: Teaching and Learning With ‘Hamilton’
abstract: How will you teach with this “revolutionary musical about taking your shot, speaking your mind and turning the world upside down”? Here are some ideas for subjects across the curriculum.

headline: California Grapes That Flourish in Splendid Isolation

lead_paragraph: LAYTONVILLE, Calif. — Something is missing at Alder Springs Vineyard, 140 rolling acres high on a rugged 6,000-acre ranch outside this small town in northern Mendocino County.

headline: Review: Adam McEwen’s ‘Harvest’ Explores the Movement of People, Vehicles and Information
abstract: The artist’s austere objects at Petzel Gallery include paintings of urban tunnels, a security checkpoint installation and graphite sculptures evoking supercomputers.
lead_paragraph: Adam McEwen is an excellent journeyman artist who keeps a low profile behind an astute recycling of objects and images. His work has a streamlined intelligence, attention to detail and austere beauty that make it seem transparent yet mysterious, straightforward yet perverse. His latest show, “Harvest” at Petzel Gallery, takes its theme from one of Jean-François Millet’s paintings of gleaners in a field — talk about detail work. Its sculptures and paintings examine the movement of people, vehicles or information through relentlessly controlled channels.

headline: David Hammons Is Still Messing With What Art Means
abstract: The artist, in his untrackable way, has been exploring race, class and wealth for five decades. His first official career survey in 25 years is a good time to take stock.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t stand art actually. I’ve never, ever liked art.” So the artist David Hammons told the art historian Kellie Jones in a 1986 interview. Then why do you make it? Ms. Jones asked. Because, Mr. Hammons offered, art is about symbols and “outrageously magical things happen when you mess around with a symbol.” Precisely such things are happening in the exhibition “David Hammons: Five Decades” at Mnuchin Gallery.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. accused Senate Republicans on Thursday of abandoning their duties and damaging their country by leaving a Supreme Court seat vacant, forcefully rejecting Republicans’ use of one of his speeches to justify their blockade.

headline: Perfume That Smells Like ‘Checking Into a Fantasy’
abstract: Folie à Plusieurs’ newest scent is inspired by moments in Gaspar Noé‘s “Enter the Void.”
lead_paragraph: When you first smell Folie à Plusieurs’ line of Le Cinéma Olfactif perfumes, you might detect sandalwood, nutmeg or musk. But the packaging lists the ingredients as “when eyes first meet,” “cold sweat breaks at night,” “this could be love,” “porcelain figurines forgotten by prayer” and “glitter powder” — the emotional essences of movies like “Mood Indigo,” “La Haine” and “Blow Up.” “Typically, you create a product and figure out how to make an experience,” says Kaya Sorhaindo, who founded the brand two years ago, and named it for the shared psychosis condition, folie à deux. “We wanted to look for new references, new areas of inspiration and not pull from the same pool as all of the other perfumeries.”

headline: Better Than Pot Brownies, by a James Beard Award-Winning Chef

lead_paragraph: When the news broke that the decorated pastry chef and cookbook author Mindy Segal had partnered with Illinois’s largest medicinal marijuana grower, eyebrows were raised — and not because the outspoken Chicago iconoclast would be out of place making pot pastries. Rather, the thought of being able to purchase edibles crafted by a James Beard Award-winning chef — Segal would be the pioneer — seemed more like a stoner’s dream come true than a legitimate business venture.

headline: Review: Ana Mendieta’s Experimental Films, Still Potent, at Galerie Lelong
abstract: The works testify to the political and feminist bent of this artist, who hit her stride early as a student at the University of Iowa in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Ana Mendieta, who died in 1985 at 36, didn’t have time to be a late bloomer, and she wasn’t. She was doing mature, adventurous work while still an art student at the University of Iowa in the early 1970s, as is evident in the 15 short works in “Experimental and Interactive Films,” at Galerie Lelong.

keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Art', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The museum expects to choose an architect by the end of the year to redesign its expansion.
lead_paragraph: Preservationists can rest easy on at least one score: The Frick Collection will be keeping its gated garden.

headline: Plan to Rescue Puerto Rico Advances, Led by House Republicans
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Bankruptcies', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plan falls short of permission for the island to restructure its $72 billion debt, and would involve close federal oversight.
lead_paragraph: Politicians in Washington are coalescing around a financial plan to rescue Puerto Rico, just weeks before an expected major default on bond payments that would spread more turmoil through the island’s shaky economy.

headline: Review: Carrie Moyer’s Conflagration of Canvases
abstract: Ms. Moyer explores the push-pull of potential opposites in an exhibition of new paintings at DC Moore.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Moyer’s new paintings bring to mind the opening lines of Robert Frost’s famous epigram, “Fire and Ice,” hinting at the equally destructive powers of love and hate: “Some say the world will end in fire, Some say in ice. From what I’ve tasted of desire/I hold with those who favor fire.”

headline: New Zealand Decides to Keep Its Flag
abstract: Prime Minister John Key of New Zealand announced that despite having over 10,000 options, citizens have voted to stick with their current flag.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister John Key of New Zealand announced that despite having over 10,000 options, citizens have voted to stick with their current flag.

headline: Review: Delivering a Touch of Big Band Through a Jazz Collective
abstract: Michael Formanek and Ensemble Kolossus showcased their debut album, “The Distance,” in a two-night show at the Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: For a deceiving stretch of its first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, Ensemble Kolossus sounded like a top-flight big band. The group, led by the bassist and composer Michael Formanek, was playing “Echoes,” a dark-hued tune in a swinging mid-tempo, defined by cagey dialogue between woodwinds and brass. It wasn’t hard to picture the piece in the repertory of the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra, or one of the better conservatory bands.

headline: Sex Education, Still Languishing
abstract: Sex educators and others discuss a vital topic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: F.D.A. Encourages Hard-to-Abuse Generic Pain Pills
abstract: The federal agency proposed guidelines to help drugmakers develop generic opioids that are hard to crush or dissolve.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed guidance on Thursday for drugmakers to encourage the development of generic versions of abuse-deterrent formulations of opioids. Abuse-deterrent pills are hard to crush or dissolve so that they cannot be injected or snorted. There are no such generic forms on the market today.

headline: Kevin Turner, Ex-Player Who Fought N.F.L. on Concussions, Dies at 46
abstract: Turner, a former running back, was a plaintiff in a lawsuit against the N.F.L. He died after being treated for A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Turner, a lead plaintiff in a concussion-related lawsuit brought by more than 5,000 former players against the N.F.L., died on Thursday. He was 46.

headline: Review: ‘Get a Job’ Portrays Work as an Object of Ambivalent Desire
abstract: Miles Teller stars in this episodic comedy as a young man whose girlfriend doesn’t think he’s serious enough about his low-level corporate work.
lead_paragraph: Generically written but featuring a promising cast, “Get a Job” is a long-shelved movie, mostly about 20-somethings entering the sink-or-swim labor force. Miles Teller, Anna Kendrick, Bryan Cranston, Marcia Gay Harden and Alison Brie star in this comedy, which was shot in 2012 and, packed with evergreen bromides, was deemed relevant for 2016.

headline: Documents Related to Fetal Tissue Research Investigation
abstract: A collection of documents from both sides of the debate on fetal tissue research shows the controversy surrounding the investigation and the science. The following documents include letters from members of Congress, letters from medical practitioners and email exchanges on tissue requests.
lead_paragraph: A collection of documents from both sides of the debate on fetal tissue research shows the controversy surrounding the investigation and the science. The following documents include letters from members of Congress, letters from medical practitioners and email exchanges on tissue requests.

headline: Apple’s First Foray Into Original TV Is a Series About Apps
abstract: Apple said it would work with two veteran television executives and the entertainer Will.i.am on the show, about which it disclosed few details.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s ambitions to go head to head with Netflix and create its own lineup of exclusive movies and TV shows has long been the subject of much chatter and speculation.

headline: A Raga Renaissance Flowers in Brooklyn
abstract: A nonprofit collective is helping to revive a classical genre while embracing a range of hybrid fusions.
lead_paragraph: The jeweled raiment and serene kohl-rimmed eyes of Saraswati, the Hindu goddess of knowledge, music and the arts, were projected on a screen behind the stage one recent evening at Pioneer Works, the exhibition and performance space in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Review: ‘Jane Wants a Boyfriend’ Looks at Autism Through a Sister’s Eyes
abstract: This William C. Sullivan film follows a 20-something with autism as she searches for a significant other under her sister’s protective watch.
lead_paragraph: Polished and often clever, William C. Sullivan’s “Jane Wants a Boyfriend” examines autism in the context of sisterly ties and intimate relationships. It’s a gold mine for emotional sparks, and in its title character, “Jane” offers the kind of role (see “Rain Man”) that is catnip to actors.

headline: Books on Wheels
abstract: Parnassus Books, a popular independent bookstore in Nasvhille, has added a bookmobile to visit food truck rallies, farmers’ markets and more, taking its products to the customers.
lead_paragraph: Parnassus Books, a popular independent bookstore in Nasvhille, has added a bookmobile to visit food truck rallies, farmers’ markets and more, taking its products to the customers.

headline: Ann Patchett’s Nashville Bookstore Hits the Road, With Dogs in Tow
abstract: The arrival of bookmobiles in Nashville and other cities indicates that independent bookstores are making a comeback after years of decline.
lead_paragraph: Nashville’s newest bookstore is an old van.

headline: To Beat the Rush, Americans Rush to Cuba, Overloading Services
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRPORTS', 'United States International Relations', 'Shortages']
abstract: The huge increase in American travel to Cuba is leading to shortages in food, gas and hotel rooms, plus a sharp rise in prices that will only steepen.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In Viñales, a lush valley about 100 miles from Havana, cabdrivers are charging stranded foreigners $10 to sleep in the back of their taxis.

headline: Review: ‘Born to Be Blue,’ Portrait of a Trumpeter as a Heroin Addict
abstract: Ethan Hawke plays Chet Baker in this extended riff on a jazz life written and directed by Robert Budreau.
lead_paragraph: “It makes me happy.”

headline: On Business Issues, Republicans Might Want a Justice Garland
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Merrick Garland’s record as an appeals judge suggests he might be the best Supreme Court nominee Republican senators could hope for.
lead_paragraph: Memo to the Republican senators who refuse to consider President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, Merrick Garland: When it comes to business issues, Judge Garland is about as good as you could hope for.

headline: Review: ‘They’re Watching,’ and Reality TV Is Capturing Every Eerie Second
abstract: This found-footage horror film from Micah Wright and Jay Lender separates itself from much of the genre’s low-budget fare with its amusing premise.
lead_paragraph: “They’re Watching,” a horror film by Micah Wright and Jay Lender, does a commendable amount with very little, using an amusing premise to separate itself from much of the genre’s low-budget fare.

headline: Ferragamo Parts Ways With Its Designer
abstract: Massimiliano Giornetti is the latest men’s wear designer to step down from a high-profile perch.
lead_paragraph: The relentless parade of entrances and exits in the design offices of major fashion labels of late — which has given the industry the whiplash pace of a Benny Hill chase — shows no sign of abating. On Thursday, Salvatore Ferragamo announced that Massimiliano Giornetti, its creative director, has left the brand.

headline: Brussels Attacks Add Urgency to Debate Over Britain’s E.U. Membership
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: A former director of the British intelligence service said on Thursday that the security of the nation would benefit if it departed from the bloc.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The terrorist attacks in Brussels are stoking an already heated debate in Britain over the country’s membership in the European Union.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended
abstract: The regulations will be suspended on Friday because of Good Friday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Alas, Poor William Shakespeare. Where Does His Skull Rest?
abstract: Researchers have uncovered evidence that they say indicates his skull was stolen from his grave by a local doctor in 1794.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Curst be he that moves my bones” reads part of the inscription above Shakespeare’s grave at Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon. But apparently, someone did.

headline: Review: ‘Fastball,’ on the Mechanics and Poetry of a Pitch
abstract: This documentary, written and directed by Jonathan Hock, offers a batter’s point of view on trying to hit a superior fastball.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2012, baseball fans were treated to “Knuckleball!,” a documentary about that fickle pitch and the athletes who throw it. Now comes the polar opposite, from a batter’s point of view: “Fastball,” an enjoyable examination of baseball’s most basic pitch.

headline: When Journalism Becomes Diplomacy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: President Obama has a habit of using the news media to ask foreign leaders difficult or awkward questions he doesn’t necessarily want to raise on his own.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has a habit of using the news media to ask foreign leaders difficult or awkward questions he doesn’t necessarily want to raise on his own.

headline: Ibrahim and Khalid el-Bakraoui: From Bank Robbers to Brussels Bombers
abstract: The brothers, who were among three suicide bombers who carried out the Brussels attacks on Tuesday, had violent criminal records.
lead_paragraph: The two Belgian brothers who blew themselves and 31 other people up in Brussels on Tuesday started out as carjackers and bank robbers before graduating to terrorism.

headline: Review: ‘Orphic Moments,’ With Feast, at National Sawdust
abstract: A program pairing a new dramatic cantata by the composer Matthew Aucoin with an innovative staging of Gluck’s “Orfeo ed Euridice.”
lead_paragraph: Since National Sawdust opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in October, it has been an intimate, adaptable space for modest-size concerts. While it is no place for traditional opera, a performance on Wednesday night demonstrated that it might be ideal for productions that revitalize the art form at a time when it could use some shaking up.

headline: Review: In Juilliard Dances Repertory, the Past Is a Path
abstract: This annual program gives rising students a chance to perform works by the likes of Paul Taylor and Jerome Robbins.
lead_paragraph: At the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on Wednesday, when Juilliard students performed Paul Taylor’s “Roses,” it was easy to imagine several leaving the theater, crossing West 65th Street and jumping onstage with Paul Taylor’s company, performing that very moment in another part of Lincoln Center.

headline: Man Rents VHS Tape. Doesn’t Return It. Ends Up in Handcuffs.
abstract: Fourteen years ago, a North Carolina man rented “Freddy Got Fingered” and failed to return it. This week, the long arm of the law caught up with him.
lead_paragraph: The law caught up with a wanted man on the streets of North Carolina this week.

headline: “You Are What You Wear”
abstract: A song performed by the original London cast of American Psycho
lead_paragraph: A song performed by the original London cast of American Psycho

headline: Review: Yundi Plays Chopin at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The Chinese pianist performed a program of Chopin with one encore from Ren Guang.
lead_paragraph: In comments sections and email inboxes and on social media they’re a familiar presence: the caps-lock fiends whose utterances are rendered in uppercase letters, a typographical approximation of shouting.

headline: Review: ‘Baskin,’ From Turkey, Blends Style and Gore
abstract: This horror story, directed by Can Evrenol, focuses on a police officer who’s called to an ominous mansion.
lead_paragraph: Tickling the mind even as it lurches the gut, “Baskin,” a stylish, shape-shifting horror film from Turkey, pulls a bait-and-switch. It abruptly morphs from a sinuous psychological thriller into a buffet for gore enthusiasts, without ever totally losing its elegance — unless your definition of that word could never encompass a graphic disembowelment or an unexpected stabbing of an eye.

headline: Review: In ‘Valley of Love,’ Isabelle Huppert and Gérard Depardieu as Mourning Parents
abstract: The film, set in an otherworldly Death Valley landscape, depicts a once-married couple reflecting on a son who committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: Watching Isabelle Huppert and Gérard Depardieu sweat it out in Death Valley amid tears, fights and swigs of wine has its obvious attractions. That at any rate seems to be the operating logic behind “Valley of Love,” a logy, woo-woo drama about a former couple who, at the request of their son, who killed himself earlier that same year, have come to find answers in the California desert. There, under the sheltering sky and unforgiving sun, they travel high and low on a journey that takes them into canyons, sand dunes, a lost past, their shared memories and finally the ineffable.

headline: My Life as Nicholas Kristof’s Assistant
abstract: Liriel Higa looks back on two years of embassy cajoling, expense tallying and, oh yes, fact-checking those myriad “back-of-the-envelope calculations.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Liriel Higa looks back on her two years in the trenches with a certain globe-trotting, cause-championing Times columnist.

headline: Review: ‘I Saw the Light,’ a Hank Williams Biopic
abstract: The British actor Tom Hiddleston stars (and sings) as the music legend, leading with charm and a twang in this film written and directed by Marc Abraham.
lead_paragraph: In the big-screen memorial “I Saw the Light,” the music legend Hank Williams strums a guitar and hits the road and the bottle, all while flashing a smile as blinding as the lights of a semi on a dark highway. He also sings, but each time he does it’s a reminder that it’s not Williams on the soundtrack but the British actor Tom Hiddleston. As Hank, Mr. Hiddleston leads with charm and a twang, keeping the beat with his shoulders, hips and feet. He looks as good as the movie, but if you want to hear what white soul music sounds like you need to fire up the real Hank Williams.

headline: In Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, Some Missed Connections
abstract: The choreographer’s current project is historically important, but there’s something failing to happen here.
lead_paragraph: When dance succeeds, it creates an alchemy of time and space that transfigures the action; life itself becomes brighter, keener, more momentous. That alchemy is happening too seldom with Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance in its current three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater. Few of the dances are projecting well enough into the Koch’s depths and breadths to register; and the connection of music and movement doesn’t often click into focus.

headline: Review: Adam Hochschild’s ‘Spain in Our Hearts,’ About a Strangely Literary Conflict
abstract: Mr. Hochschild’s book, about Americans in the Spanish Civil War, follows reporters, authors and others who fought in a war the United States never entered.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish Civil War (1936-39) was not a splendid little war. It was an especially vicious one. Some 500,000 people died, most in combat or by political execution. A right-wing coup, led by Francisco Franco and backed by Hitler and Mussolini, toppled a democratically elected government.

headline: Review: ‘April and the Extraordinary World,’ Animated Sci-Fi From France
abstract: In an altered century with stunted technology, a Parisian and her talking cat try to figure out why so many scientists are disappearing.
lead_paragraph: Who says they don’t make mind-bending French science-fiction animated movies like they used to? Well, very few people, if any, I reckon. But the thought — or something similar to it — crossed my mind while watching “April and the Extraordinary World,” a beautiful, inventive and uncannily satisfying new example of animated sci-fi from, yes, France.

keywords: ['Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Listing the Playboy Mansion for sale prompted expressions of interest from potential buyers of the entire company.
lead_paragraph: Playboy Enterprises, the parent company of the iconic men’s magazine, has retained investment bankers and has begun exploring a sale, people with knowledge of the discussions said on Thursday.

headline: Garry Shandling, Star of Groundbreaking Sitcoms, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Shandling was known for walking the tightrope between comedic fiction and show-business reality on two sitcoms.
lead_paragraph: Garry Shandling, a comedian who deftly walked a tightrope between comic fiction and show-business reality on two critically praised cable shows, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 66.

headline: Indiana Governor Signs Abortion Bill With Added Restrictions
abstract: The law signed by Gov. Mike Pence holds doctors liable if a woman has an abortion because of objections to the fetus’s race, sex or a disability and restricts fetal tissue donation.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Indiana’s governor signed a bill on Thursday that adds broad limits to women’s access to abortions, banning those motivated solely by the mother’s objection to the fetus’s race, gender or disability, and placing new restrictions on doctors.

headline: The Modern Degas You Haven’t Seen
abstract: Nearly 100 years after the revered artist’s death, he’s getting his first solo show at the Museum of Modern Art — focusing on experimental works on paper.
lead_paragraph: On the brink of the centenary of his death next year, the revered French artist Hilaire-Germain-Edgar Degas is having his first solo show at the Museum of Modern Art. “Edgar Degas: A Strange New Beauty” is a large but thrillingly intimate exhibition centering on the artist’s monotypes — the most seductive of all print mediums — and their modernizing effect on his art.

lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: No Flipping: Remembering Garry Shandling
abstract: The comedian and actor found his signature role playing a fake talk show host whose insecurities were all too real.
lead_paragraph: Garry Shandling, a deadpan comic’s comic who found his signature role playing a fake talk show host with real insecurities, died on Thursday. He was 66.

headline: Theater Listings for March 25-31
abstract: From a palace in 19th-century Siam, to a funeral home in 1970s Pennsylvania; with struggling playwrights in England, or frolicking lovers in postwar Paris — as different as these musicals are, they have one commonality: As of next month, each will have been open on Broadway for a year. The productions include, clockwise from top left: “An American in Paris,” with Leanne Cope; “Fun Home,” with Beth Malone, left, and Emily Skeggs; “Finding Neverland,” with Laura Michelle Kelly; “Something Rotten!,” with Brian d’Arcy James, center; and “The King and I,” with Ken Watanabe and Kelli O’Hara.
lead_paragraph: From a palace in 19th-century Siam, to a funeral home in 1970s Pennsylvania; with struggling playwrights in England, or frolicking lovers in postwar Paris — as different as these musicals are, they have one commonality: As of next month, each will have been open on Broadway for a year. The productions include, clockwise from top left: “An American in Paris,” with Leanne Cope; “Fun Home,” with Beth Malone, left, and Emily Skeggs; “Finding Neverland,” with Laura Michelle Kelly; “Something Rotten!,” with Brian d’Arcy James, center; and “The King and I,” with Ken Watanabe and Kelli O’Hara.

headline: A Gleeful Ode to Late-’80s Fashion, From the New ‘American Psycho’ Musical
abstract: “You Are What You Wear,” by the show’s lyricist Duncan Sheik, is full of tongue-in-cheek references to that era’s clothes and food trends.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t quite see it as a musical, at first blush, at all,” the Grammy and Tony-winning musician and composer Duncan Sheik admits of Bret Easton Ellis’s 1991 novel “American Psycho” — a stage adaptation of which, with music and lyrics by Sheik, has just begun previews on Broadway.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian authorities pressed ahead Thursday with a case against the founders of two prominent human rights organizations, part of a crackdown on civil society organizations that have documented government abuse.

abstract: Senator Ted Cruz, smarting over Donald J. Trump’s menacing Twitter messages about his wife, thrashed his rival on Thursday and defended his wife, Heidi, in strong terms.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz, smarting over Donald J. Trump’s menacing Twitter messages about his wife, thrashed his rival on Thursday and warned him to “leave Heidi the hell alone.”

abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Batman v Superman,” “My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2” and “I Saw the Light.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Batman v Superman,” “My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2” and “I Saw the Light.”

headline: N.F.L. Issues Statement About Article and The Times Responds
abstract: After an article examined flaws in the N.F.L.’s early concussion research and the league’s ties to the tobacco industry, the league responded with a statement disputing various aspects. The Times then responded.
lead_paragraph: Hours after The New York Times published an article on Thursday that examined deep flaws in the N.F.L.’s early concussion research and the league’s ties to the tobacco industry, the league responded with a statement disputing various aspects of the article.

headline: The Legacy of A Tribe Called Quest
abstract: Their embrace of Afrocentrism showed me how I could fit into hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in the suburbs of Boston, where I was the top-ranked singles player on my prep school’s tennis team and obsessed with rap music by Run-DMC, LL Cool J and KRS-One. But I felt like I was eavesdropping on someone else’s conversation when I listened to them. Those guys were streetwise kings of the hood from mighty New York, urban jungle warriors so ultra masculine they were like comic book superheroes.

headline: Julian Niccolini, Co-Owner of Four Seasons Restaurant, Pleads Guilty to Misdemeanor Assault
abstract: Mr. Niccolini, initially charged with felony sexual abuse after an encounter that left a woman with scratches and bruises, will remain free unless he breaks the law in the next 12 months.
lead_paragraph: Julian Niccolini, a longtime co-owner of the Four Seasons, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor assault on Thursday in a deal with prosecutors to resolve an allegation that he sexually abused a 28-year-old woman during a party at the celebrated Manhattan restaurant in May.

headline: Review: ‘The Pirate La Dee Da,’ a Tale of a Runaway Princess
abstract: This Atlantic for Kids production at the Linda Gross Theater packs in surprises while offering lessons on gender roles and income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Avast, all ye sexists! Piracy has never been an exclusively male pursuit.

headline: Law Graduate Who Sued Her School Loses at Trial
keywords: ['Law Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The Thomas Jefferson School of Law defended its data on graduate employment, which Anna Alaburda said in her suit was misleading, and a jury rejected her claims.
lead_paragraph: A jury in San Diego on Thursday rejected claims by a law graduate, Anna Alaburda, that the Thomas Jefferson School of Law enticed her to enroll by using misleading graduate employment figures.

headline: Albert Camus, Stranger in a Strange Land: New York
abstract: The French writer spent three months in the city in 1946. Seventy years later, a monthlong festival is celebrating his residency.
lead_paragraph: When a boat carrying Albert Camus sailed into New York Harbor in March 1946, he was hailed as a moral emissary from war-ravaged Europe and the glamorous embodiment of a newfangled philosophy known as Existentialism.

headline: Challenge to Yahoo’s Board Makes a Sale More Certain
abstract: Starboard Value is putting up a slate to replace every director on Yahoo’s board, an unusual step that means the race is on to sell the company.
lead_paragraph: Starboard Value’s announcement that it has nominated a full slate of directors to replace the Yahoo board means one thing: The race is on to sell Yahoo. The only question now is whether it happens before or after Yahoo’s annual meeting.

headline: ‘Tom Sachs: Tea Ceremony,’ at the Noguchi Museum
abstract: This installation displays constructions relating to the ancient Japanese tradition of chanoyu, the ritualized preparation and serving of tea.
lead_paragraph: Founded by the Japanese-American sculptor Isamu Noguchi to preserve and exhibit his art, the Noguchi Museum in Queens has never offered a solo exhibition dedicated to another artist since its opening in 1985. Until now, that is: “Tom Sachs: Tea Ceremony,” an installation of clunky constructions relating to the ancient Japanese tradition of chanoyu, the ritualized preparation and serving of tea, is the first. It sets up an intriguing dialogue with Noguchi’s art, and there will be exhibitions devoted to other artists in the future, which is a good thing for this museum. Showing only Noguchi’s work year after year doesn’t encourage return visits, and it’s exciting to imagine shows of those who have operated in the fertile cross-cultural space between East and West, artists as varied as Ad Reinhardt and Mariko Mori. It’s a good thing for Mr. Sachs, too, as seeing his project in the context of Noguchi’s oeuvre makes it considerably more interesting than it would be on its own.

headline: ‘Death by Hanging’ and ‘I Want to Live!’ on DVD
abstract: The films, one set in Japan and the other in the United States, both explore the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese director Nagisa Oshima (1932-2013) was not known for action films, but he was, as his colleague Shohei Imamura called him, a “samurai” — a militant modernist with a taste for razor-sharp social critiques.

headline: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a Republican, Says Donald Trump Shouldn’t Be Nominee
abstract: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a moderate Republican in a blue state, said Donald J. Trump should not be the party’s standard-bearer and that he would consider voting for another candidate in November if Mr. Trump wins the presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Joining the ranks of leading Republicans who will not commit to supporting Donald J. Trump if he becomes the party’s standard-bearer, Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland said Thursday that Mr. Trump should not be the party’s presidential nominee and that he would consider voting for another candidate in November if he is.

headline: What It’s Like to Work for Nicholas Kristof
abstract: Sometimes working for Nicholas Kristof means getting to meet Malala Yousafzai. Other times, it means watching a grainy, covertly recorded video of chickens’ necks being slit.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes working for Nicholas Kristof means getting to meet people like Malala Yousafzai. Other times, it means repeatedly watching a grainy, covertly recorded video of chickens’ necks being slit to verify that the speed is, in fact, faster than two per second. I’ve worked for Nick for a year and a half, and since I’m about to move on to a new position within the Editorial Department, he invited me to share my thoughts on what I’ve learned.

headline: Port Authority Pledges Billions for Airport Upgrades and New Bus Terminal
abstract: The agency’s board voted to build a bus complex in Midtown Manhattan and update La Guardia and Newark Liberty International Airports.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted on Thursday to spend tens of billions of dollars on transforming La Guardia Airport, enhancing Newark Liberty International Airport and building a new central bus terminal in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Feeling G.O.P. Peril, Muslims Try to Get Out Vote
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: National advocacy groups are encouraging mosques to turn themselves into voter registration centers before the November election so that Muslims can make their voices heard at the polls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American Muslims are watching in growing horror as Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz battle for the Republican presidential nomination, outdoing each other with provocative proposals that have included Muslim registries, immigration bans and fleets of police patrolling their neighborhoods.

headline: Accountability, at Last, for Bosnia’s Agony
keywords: ['Editorials', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The conviction of a former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, for war crimes serves as a warning to extremist leaders everywhere.
lead_paragraph: With the conviction of the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic for war crimes, a United Nations tribunal has provided an overdue measure of justice for the victims of some of the worst atrocities since World War II. He is the most senior official to be held accountable for the horrific events of the 1992-1995 Bosnian war.

headline: Gas Prices Will Be Low for Easter, but Don’t Get Used to It
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: Gas prices for the Easter weekend will be the lowest in over a decade. But don’t be fooled — they’re still going up.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With gasoline prices at their lowest point for the Easter weekend since 2004, holiday travelers have something to cheer about.

headline: Anri Sala Discusses the Impulses Behind His Video Art
abstract: Mr. Sala, the celebrated Albanian-born artist, speaks his mind via Skype. His work is the subject of an exhibition at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Not many exhibitions get the welcome that has greeted “Anri Sala: Answer Me,” at the New Museum in Manhattan. Roberta Smith, co-chief art critic of The New York Times, praised Mr. Sala’s “roiling explorations, mostly in video, of sound, time, color, architecture and the politics of modern life.” In The Guardian, Jason Farago referred to Mr. Sala’s “unrivaled capacity to excavate the sullied dreams of Modernism, and to imagine a future on the ruins of the recent past.”

headline: Playoffs Not Assured, but Crucial Win Relieves Pressure on Islanders
abstract: A win against Ottawa ended a four-game losing streak, aiding the Islanders’ push for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Islanders center Frans Nielsen breathed a distinct sigh of relief after his team ended a four-game winless streak, its longest of the season, with a 3-1 home victory over Ottawa on Wednesday.

headline: Report Offers a Mixed View of Health Care Law Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office says the overall cost of insurance coverage will be higher than was predicted last year, but much lower than was expected in 2010.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More people will be enrolled in Medicaid than predicted a year ago, fewer will be covered through the new public insurance marketplaces and the overall cost of insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act will be higher than expected last year, the Congressional Budget Office said Thursday.

headline: Back From a Knee Injury, Federer Tries to Catch Up
abstract: Roger Federer returned to action at the Miami Open, where he mostly faced questions about doping and gender equity.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Roger Federer will probably think twice before running a bath for his twin daughters again after what happened to his knee and to his beloved sport in his absence.

headline: Illinois Supreme Court Deals Another Blow to Rahm Emanuel
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Organized Labor', 'Strikes', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Illinois Supreme Court holds that scaling back future pension benefits for Chicago’s city workers while requiring them to pay more is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Illinois Supreme Court on Thursday dealt another setback to Mayor Rahm Emanuel, ruling that a 2014 law that required Chicago city workers to pay more toward their retirements while also scaling back their future benefits was unconstitutional.

headline: Nicholas Scoppetta, Former Foster Child Who Led Child Welfare Agency, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Scoppetta, who served under four New York City mayors, was the first commissioner of Children’s Services and also led the fire and investigation departments.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Scoppetta, who as a neglected son of Italian immigrants was rescued by child welfare workers and raised in foster homes, and was later hailed for devoting half a century to public service overseeing New York City’s child welfare, investigation and fire departments, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: North Carolina Gay Bias Law Draws a Sharp Backlash
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: On social media and in public rallies, civil rights groups, businesses and politicians expressed dismay at the law, which was passed by the Republican-controlled legislature.
lead_paragraph: A day after Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina signed a sweeping law eliminating anti-discrimination protections for all lesbians, gays and bisexuals and barring transgender people from using bathrooms that do not match the gender they were born with, the battle lines were clear in a bitterly divided state.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It should be an unmistakable red flag that a team does not report any concussions over multiple years.”

headline: Wisconsin Race Frames Dispute Over Supreme Court Nominee
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: A rematch in a Senate contest is playing out as a proxy battle over the appointment of a Supreme Court justice.
lead_paragraph: PEWAUKEE, Wis. — Senator Ron Johnson, a Tea Party conservative up for re-election in a swing state, looked out at a crowd of supporters and reassured them that he and his fellow Republicans would be resolute in blocking President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court.

headline: Makayla Epps’s Roots in Kentucky Run Deep
abstract: The Wildcats’ junior guard has a proud family history in Kentucky, and after a narrowly averted tragedy, her career has flourished.
lead_paragraph: The leading scorer on the Kentucky women’s basketball team that will compete at home (sort of) Friday night in a round-of-16 game in the Lexington Regional was almost a one-and-done player, in the gravest sense.

headline: After Retirement Report, Alex Rodriguez Plays Coy on Questions About His Future
abstract: A day after confusing reports surfaced about his possible retirement, Alex Rodriguez did little to clarify the situation.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez was driving with his two young daughters on Wednesday when they asked him a complicated but appropriate question: Was he retiring?

headline: In Belgium, a Country of Divisions, Patriotism Remains Subdued
abstract: The attacks this week in Brussels have prompted relatively restrained displays of solidarity across the country, which has long had an identity crisis.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In the United States, the Sept. 11 attacks unleashed an outpouring of patriotism. After the attacks in and around Paris on Nov. 13, the tricolor of the French flag was ubiquitous as the country channeled its grief.

headline: France Arrests Citizen Tied to Terrorist Plot in ‘Advanced Stages’
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The French interior minister said the authorities were raiding an apartment building in the northern suburbs of Paris after the arrest.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s interior minister announced on Thursday that a French citizen had been arrested on suspicion that he was involved in a terrorist plot in the “advanced stages” of planning.

headline: Ken Thompson, Brooklyn Prosecutor, Emerges as Shrewd Victor in Akai Gurley Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In the sort of polarizing police misconduct case that can define a career, Mr. Thompson gambled with trying an officer who fatally shot an unarmed man.
lead_paragraph: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, dropped a memorable line at the end of his letter this week recommending no prison time for Peter Liang, the former New York City police officer convicted of manslaughter last month in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in a housing project stairwell.

headline: Experts Question Whether Salah Abdeslam Will Provide Answers on Attacks
abstract: The terrorism suspect’s capture has raised the prospect of an intelligence bonanza, but there are reasons to doubt that he will be of much help.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One living terrorist, now sitting in a maximum-security cell in the Belgian city of Bruges, could unlock Europe’s two deadliest terrorist attacks. But will he cooperate?

headline: Angry Arizona Voters Demand: Why Such Long Lines at Polling Sites?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: The long lines at Arizona polling places this week point toward potential problems ahead nationally at a time when 16 states will have new voting restrictions in place.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Cynthia Perez, a lawyer, stopped by a polling site on her way to work here on Tuesday, thinking she could vote early and get on with her day. She changed her mind when she found a line so long she could not see the end of it.

headline: N.Y.U. Raising Student Workers’ Pay to $15 an Hour
abstract: The university’s president said the minimum wage would be increased over the next three academic years.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers in Albany debate raising New York’s minimum wage to $15, administrators at New York University said on Thursday that its student workers would be ahead of the curve.

headline: Iowa State Guard Faces Big Fan: Virginia’s Coach
abstract: Matt Thomas, a 6-foot-5 junior guard at Iowa State, was heavily recruited by Virginia, the Cyclones’ opponent on Friday in the Midwest Regional.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In an odd twist, Matt Thomas has a longer relationship with the Virginia men’s basketball coach, Tony Bennett, than he does with his coach at Iowa State, Steve Prohm.

headline: Brussels Suicide Bomber Wasn’t One of Ours, Bahamas Says
abstract: Khalid el-Bakraoui, one of the suicide bombers in Brussels, was listed as a Bahamian citizen in an Interpol arrest warrant because of a “clerical error.”
lead_paragraph: It was a minor mystery in the terrorism investigation that has gripped Europe: Was one of the suicide bombers who carried out the devastating attacks on Brussels on Tuesday really a citizen of the Bahamas?

headline: New York City Turns Over Files on Building Sale Subpoenaed by Comptroller
abstract: Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller, took what his office called the rare step of filing a subpoena after the lifting of a deed restriction on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration has turned over documents in response to a subpoena by the New York City comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, over the lifting of deed restrictions and the sale of a building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that made a $72 million profit for a private nursing home operator.

headline: Mother and Son Killed and Third Person Injured in Staten Island Shooting
abstract: The police said the gunman opened fire around 6 p.m., fatally striking a 47-year-old woman in the head and her 21-year-old son in the face.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed a mother and her son and injured another person in a shooting outside a public-housing project on Staten Island on Thursday evening, the police said.

headline: Mighty Wolverines Back on Top of Their Game
abstract: After missing the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament the last three years, Michigan, a nine-time Division I champion, is back in it, led by the college game’s most potent line.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The University of Michigan men’s hockey team has 35 N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, 24 Frozen Four berths and nine national championships — all records.

headline: Review: ‘Bright Star’ Beams Nostalgia Underscored by Fiddles and Banjos
abstract: Steve Martin and Edie Brickell are behind this slice of vintage Americana that gives Carmen Cusack her Broadway debut.
lead_paragraph: Bluegrass on Broadway? Yes sirree. The warming sounds of banjos, fiddles and even an accordion are filling the Cort Theater, where the musical “Bright Star” opened on Thursday, bringing a fresh breeze from the South to the spring theater season.

headline: Statements for the Record
abstract: Ian Livengood takes us into the weekend with a trippy themeless.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Well, this was a trippy one. I had a lot of fun solving this one by Ian Livengood, but that’s par for the course. Mr. Livengood makes fun puzzles.

headline: Potent From Long Distances, Villanova Takes a Big Step
abstract: Ryan Arcidiacono and Kris Jenkins each scored 21 points, and the Wildcats made 10 3-pointers to rout Miami and clinch their first appearance in a regional final since 2009.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Like a wildcat spotting prey, Ryan Arcidiacono opened his eyes wide. On an inbounds play under Villanova’s basket Arcidiacono, a 37.5 percent 3-point shooter, was left open on the left side. He caught the pass and stepped into his shot. Swish.

abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City. headline: After Athletes’ Killings, Geneseo Teams Rally Back
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'NCAA Ice Hockey Championships', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The Geneseo hockey team has reached the Division III Final Four while grieving the stabbing deaths of defenseman Matthew Hutchinson and Kelsey Annese, a basketball player.
lead_paragraph: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Shortly after 11 a.m. Thursday, a slap shot away from the rink where the United States once famously beat the Soviet Union, the 25 remaining members of the State University of New York Geneseo hockey team gathered near center ice, huddling in blue and white, speaking not about a miracle, but a mission.

headline: Egypt Implicates 4 Men Killed by Police in Death of Italian Student
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The Interior Ministry said property belonging to a student who disappeared in January was found at the home of a gang member’s sister. Many worldwide had blamed Egyptian security forces.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Interior Ministry said Thursday that Egyptian officers killed four men who the ministry suggested were responsible for the murder of an Italian doctoral student whose brutalized body was found in early February showing extensive signs of torture.

headline: Henri Bonneau, Wine Producer Known for Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Bonneau, a 12th-generation French vigneron, rejected modern methods to issue powerful wines that recalled how they might have tasted a century or two ago.
lead_paragraph: Henri Bonneau, an acclaimed producer of Châteauneuf-du-Pape, whose wines were as renowned for their almost otherworldly beauty, complexity and intensity as they were rare and hard to find, died on March 21 in Marseille, France. He was 77.

headline: Oklahoma Puts Its Experience to Use While Cruising Past Texas A&M
abstract: Jordan Woodard scored 22 points, Buddy Hield had 10 rebounds and Isaiah Cousins collected 10 assists as the Sooners advanced to the round of 8.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. —  Texas A&M set out to contain Buddy Hield, the player of the year candidate from Oklahoma, and the Aggies were successful, holding Hield to 17 points, well under his postseason average of 31.5 points per game. The Aggies trapped Hield in the corners and limited his touches, but it was like trying to bottle experience. The No. 2-seeded Sooners are far more than a one-man team, as they demonstrated Thursday night in their 77-63 victory against No. 3-seeded Texas A&M in a West Regional round of 16 game at Honda Center.

headline: Back-to-Back Wins Give the Knicks a Rare Streak
abstract: Two straight victories over the Bulls created a bright spot for the Knicks in an otherwise gloomy season.
lead_paragraph: After corralling a defensive rebound midway through the fourth quarter, Jose Calderon peeked up and spotted Derrick Williams streaking down the left sideline.

headline: Couple Linked to Petraeus Inquiry Drops Suit Against Government
abstract: The lawyers for Jill and Scott Kelley broke ties with them, and Ms. Kelley said that she has since difficulty finding new representation for the case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Florida couple on Thursday dropped a lawsuit over the federal government’s disclosure of their identities in connection with the F.B.I. investigation that uncovered evidence that David H. Petraeus, the C.I.A. director at the time, was having an affair.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | gusty
abstract: This word has appeared in 32 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: gusty • \ˈgəs-te\ • adjective

headline: As LeBron James Concentrates on Playoffs, and Fans Focus on Him, Cavaliers Fall to Nets
abstract: James played down the criticisms he has recently faced, which include unfollowing the Cavaliers’ Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: A small storm began brewing this week in Cleveland. By Wednesday, it had gathered enough strength to cause concern in Los Angeles and Miami, as New York prepared for the brunt of its force Thursday, with effects expected to linger until Saturday, when the Cavaliers play the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: March 25
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from a precinct in the Bronx where killings persist and Ithaca, N.Y., which is considering an unorthodox anti-heroin plan.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from a precinct in the Bronx where killings persist and Ithaca, N.Y., which is considering an unorthodox anti-heroin plan.

headline: Oregon Makes Pac-12 Look Good by Dismantling Duke
abstract: After thrashing Duke on Thursday, No. 1-seeded Oregon must overcome No. 2 seed Oklahoma on Saturday in the regional finals.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At the dawn of the men’s college basketball season, the Pacific-12 was considered in many circles to be the sport’s premier conference. And despite legions of doubters east of its time zone, the league entered the N.C.A.A. tournament with seven invitees and a No. 2 ranking in the respected rating percentage index, or R.P.I.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: “Jurassic Park,” which gave birth to a seemingly endless film franchise, airs on AMC. And last year’s remake of “Point Break” streams online.
lead_paragraph: “Jurassic Park,” the textbook blockbuster from Steven Spielberg that gave birth to a seemingly endless franchise, provides small-screen entertainment for a Friday night. And last year’s remake of “Point Break,” which has the look of X Games fan fiction, is streaming on iTunes.
