headline: Crazy About Money
abstract: Elite Republicans may not like Ted Cruz, but they like his policy positions.
lead_paragraph: In this year of Trump, the land is loud with the wails of political commentators, rending their garments and crying out, “How can this be happening?” But a few brave souls are willing to whisper the awful truth: Many voters support Donald Trump because they actually agree with his ideas.

headline: The Post-Trump Era
abstract: As awful as Donald Trump is, it will be exciting to witness the coming re-creation of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: This is a wonderful moment to be a conservative. For decades now the Republican Party has been groaning under the Reagan orthodoxy, which was right for the 1980s but has become increasingly obsolete. The Reagan worldview was based on the idea that a rising economic tide would lift all boats. But that’s clearly no longer true.

headline: Trump’s Terror Dependency
abstract: Monumentally ill prepared to be president, he listens only to himself — and what his gut tells him is to do all he can to make people feel afraid.
lead_paragraph: Among the volley of lies spit out of the coarse mouth of Donald Trump on a daily basis is his claim that he’s leading Hillary Clinton in the general election matchup for president. “I beat Hillary in many of the polls that have been taken, and each week I get better and better,” he said earlier this month.

headline: Transgender Law Makes North Carolina Pioneer in Bigotry
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Lawmakers in North Carolina hastily passed a law that prevents cities from protecting gay and transgender people from discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Charlotte, N.C., spent more than a year carefully considering and debating an antidiscrimination ordinance that was passed in February to promote the city’s culture of inclusiveness. State lawmakers quashed it on Wednesday by passing an appalling, unconstitutional bill that bars transgender people from using public restrooms that match their gender identity and prohibits cities from passing antidiscrimination ordinances that protect gay and transgender people.

headline: The Racism at the Heart of Flint’s Crisis
abstract: A task force appointed by the Michigan governor, Rick Snyder, details the state government’s disregard for the lives of poor and black residents.
lead_paragraph: An important new report makes clear the principal cause of the water crisis in Flint, Mich.: the state government’s blatant disregard for the lives and health of poor and black residents of a distressed city.

headline: Philippines Releases Ship Linked to North Korea
abstract: The Jin Teng was seized after being listed in United Nations sanctions against North Korea, but was later removed from the list, Reuters reports.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippines has released a cargo ship linked to North Korea that it had seized as part of tough new United Nations sanctions imposed on the reclusive country, an official said on Friday.

headline: News Q’s | In N.F.L., Deeply Flawed Concussion Research and Ties to Big Tobacco
abstract: What questions are raised by the New York Times investigation?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “In N.F.L., Deeply Flawed Concussion Research and Ties to Big Tobacco.”

headline: Leaving New York City
abstract: Three couples detail their moves to find more space in the areas surrounding New York.
lead_paragraph: Three couples detail their moves to find more space in the areas surrounding New York.

headline: From the City to the ’Burbs, Step by Step
abstract: With New York City real estate prices skyrocketing, new services aim to help city dwellers decide whether to move beyond the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: For some buyers confronted with the high cost of New York City real estate, moving to the suburbs is a no-brainer. The prospect of more space for the money, a grassy yard and a less crowded public school outweighs the longer commute, the need for a car (or two) and the limited food-delivery options. Other buyers, however, would rather squeeze their growing family into a studio than abandon city life.

headline: Should Mother Teresa Be Canonized?
abstract: Given questions about the type of care the Catholic nun provided to the poor, is Pope Francis right to make her a saint?

headline: A Field Guide to Male Intimacy
abstract: The son of a gay father struggles with stereotypically masculine conversations and rituals.
lead_paragraph: When my car’s battery died on a bitterly cold January day, my father refused to come to my apartment in south Minneapolis to give me a jump.

headline: Recognizing Spring, Scientifically
abstract: We turned to scientists and asked them to decode the seasonal changes all around us, and reveal some that might not be as easy to detect.
lead_paragraph: We turned to scientists and asked them to decode the seasonal changes all around us, and reveal some that might not be as easy to detect.

headline: A Mailman Handcuffed in Brooklyn, Caught on Video
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: After Glen Grays, a 27-year-old African-American mail carrier, shouted at four plainclothes police officers, he was handcuffed, frisked and taken to their unmarked car.
lead_paragraph: Late in the afternoon on St. Patrick’s Day, Glen Grays, a 27-year-old African-American mail carrier, was making his rounds in Crown Heights, in Brooklyn, about to leave a package at 999 President Street. Mr. Grays prides himself on getting to know the community he serves, he told me on Wednesday. He figures out who is sick, or old, or enfeebled, and makes sure that their parcels, especially if they contain medication — “I can shake a box and usually figure that out,” he said — land directly at the doors of the people waiting for them, even if they live in fourth- or fifth-floor apartments, in walk-up buildings.

headline: When Washington Met Hollywood: At Lunch With Cory Booker and Susan Sarandon
keywords: ['Movies', 'United States Politics and Government', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: The senator and the actress discuss their childhoods, careers and activism, particularly their shared outrage over mass incarceration of black males.
lead_paragraph: Susan Sarandon hobbled into the restaurant in a cast boot and shiny Teamsters jacket emblazoned with the name “Sue.” But Senator Cory Booker’s first question for the actress was about a tattoo that runs down her back. (“It’s my kids’ initials — and my granddaughter’s,” she replied.)

headline: Soft and Cuddly? John Kasich’s Old Colleagues Don’t Recognize Him
abstract: Although the Ohio governor presents an aura of civility and kindness, some recall a government career punctuated by confrontations, critiques and undiplomatic remarks.
lead_paragraph: As he tries to halt the momentum of Donald J. Trump, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio tells people they are made special by the Lord. He urges them to invite lonely widows out to dinner. He freely dispenses hugs.

headline: Love at a Distance
abstract: Tired of the New York dating scene, Linnea Sanderson decided to search for eligible men near her parents in New Hampshire. That’s where she found Robert Davidson.
lead_paragraph: Tired of the New York dating scene, Linnea Sanderson decided to search for eligible men near her parents in New Hampshire. That’s where she found Robert Davidson.

headline: Two Weddings Are Better Than One
abstract: Linnea Sanderson and Robert Davidson’s first wedding started with a polar bear plunge and their second took place on Leap Day.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Linnea Sanderson always had a basketball in her hand. When at age 14, her steady rise as a player was cut short by a serious back injury suffered during a pickup game, she bounced back, becoming a competitive tennis player and swimmer.

headline: Student Question | Should Transgender People Be Allowed to Use the Bathroom of Their Choice?
abstract: Are you more sympathetic to the argument that it is discriminatory not to allow transgender people to use the bathroom of their choice, or do you agree more with those who feel that it would violate the privacy and safety of others? Why?
lead_paragraph: North Carolina legislators just passed a wide-ranging bill barring transgender people from bathrooms and locker rooms that do not match the gender on their birth certificates.

abstract: In this short documentary, Latinos grapple with defining their ethnic and racial identities.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, Latinos grapple with defining their ethnic and racial identities.

headline: Iranian Sweets Fit for a Cleric or King
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Family Business', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Cookies']
abstract: Three generations have been making cookies and candies for the last century at a shop in central Iran.
lead_paragraph: YAZD, Iran — This desert provincial capital in central Iran is known for its honesty, generosity, high clay walls, fine woven silk textiles, a pre-Islamic Zoroastrian fire temple and soaring wind towers that naturally cool rooms below.

headline: The Humor of Garry Shandling: Keenly Aware, With Hair Jokes
abstract: Garry Shandling’s comedy, always inward looking, also shined a light onto the television industry.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for Garry Shandling, who died Thursday at the age of 66, to ask the audience what they thought of his hair. As a stand-up comic, he led with his neuroses, telling dark and cuttingly self-deprecating jokes in between wide, needy grins. “I’m dating a homeless woman,” goes the setup to one joke. “It was easier talking her into staying over.”

headline: Look Out for the Trump Pivot!
abstract: It’s coming one of these days — the rituals of politics demand it.
lead_paragraph: So now we’re all just sitting around waiting for Donald Trump to pivot. As in, change. We demand and expect that of party front-runners at this stage of a primary campaign.

headline: San Francisco, ‘the Silicon Valley of Recycling’
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Foreign officials flock to the Bay Area to find out more about Recology, a plant that recycles 30-foot tall debris piles each day.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Robert Reed, who is enjoying a surprising career turn as a busy tour guide at the latest hot spot here, stood smiling one recent sunny morning before 10 foreign dignitaries and journalists. They included the mayor of Genoa, Italy, and the general consuls from Italy, Canada and Switzerland.

headline: Small-Business Lobbying Group Steps Into Supreme Court Fight
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Small Business', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell has noted that Judge Merrick B. Garland is opposed by the National Federation of Independent Business and that the small-business lobbying group has never before inserted itself in a high-profile court fight.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, in making his case against Judge Merrick B. Garland, has noted that Judge Garland is opposed by the National Federation of Independent Business and that the small-business lobbying group has never before inserted itself in a high-profile court fight.

headline: New York Today: An Egg-Decorating Tradition
abstract: Friday: The art of pysanky, Luna Park opens, and political egg hunts.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:21 p.m.

headline: Man Detained in North Korea Confesses to Spying for South
abstract: The man, Kim Dong-chul, who claims to be a naturalized American citizen, apologized for trying to steal military secrets in collusion with South Koreans.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A man claiming to be a naturalized American citizen held in North Korea since October confessed to committing crimes against the country and pleaded for mercy on Friday, news agencies reported from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.

headline: A New Spin on Senior Living
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Indian-Americans', 'Elder Care', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Places like ShantiNiketan, a retirement community for Indian-Americans, are examples of what may be a growing niche of the assisted living industry.
lead_paragraph: Ram and Geeta Chandran had always planned to move into a senior community after they retired. The couple had no children, and “we knew we had to move to a retirement community so we wouldn’t be lonely in a huge house,” said Geeta Chandran, 72, a family physician.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Chocolate and the Secret to Happiness
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: When Friends Are ‘Like Family’
abstract: The comfort of a close bond can sometimes morph into the restraints of bondage.
lead_paragraph: “My friends are the sisters I was meant to have,” a woman told me. Another said that her friends are more precious than her sisters because they remember things from her past that her sisters don’t and can’t, since they weren’t there. And a man commented that he didn’t enjoy a particular friend’s company all that much, but it was beside the point: “He’s family.”

headline: Hong Kong Bookseller Is Said to Return to Chinese Mainland
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Police']
abstract: One day after the once-missing bookseller, Lee Bo, reappeared in Hong Kong, local news media reported that he was driven in a van to a border crossing.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The appearance of a missing Hong Kong bookseller who returned on Thursday from mainland China has done little to quell public doubts about his case. One day after he spoke to the police and immigration officers in Hong Kong, local news media reported that the bookseller, Lee Bo, had returned to mainland China.

headline: The 3.13.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE MUSIC ISSUE

headline: A Risky Kiss in Karachi
abstract: It’s not just fooling around.
lead_paragraph: There are few things more sobering for two young people than trying to outrun the police in Karachi, Pakistan, after they catch you drunkenly making out in the middle of the night.

headline: What’s Your Pleasure?
abstract: Bartenders embrace the challenge of “bespoke” cocktails, tailored to fit the drinker’s whim.
lead_paragraph: Most bartenders are familiar with this situation: A customer says he wants a drink with tequila — but not a margarita. Maybe something kind of fruity — but not too sweet. And, oh, bitters. He is crazy about bitters. And cider. Cider’s great.

headline: How to Ford a River
abstract: Watch the current. Keep your shoes.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Even relatively shallow water can knock you off your feet,’’ says George Spearing, a retired firefighter from New Zealand who has crossed hundreds of rivers on solo wilderness treks, including a five-month, 2,650-mile hike from the Mexican border to British Columbia and a six-week journey along Wales’s coastline. ‘‘Each time I cross a river, the power of water amazes me,’’ he says.

headline: ‘Exit Strategies’
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Best Time to Visit Luxor? An Egyptologist Says Now
abstract: Nicholas Reeves, the noted Egyptologist, says the timing and prices are right for a trip to Cairo, Aswan and the tombs of Luxor.
lead_paragraph: The story sounds more like the plot of a riveting suspense movie than real life: Does the tomb of Tutankhamen in the Valley of the Kings in Egypt have hidden rooms with the never-found tomb of the powerful Queen Nefertiti?

headline: Tricia Clarke-Stone: Putting Passion Ahead of Pedigree
abstract: Ms. Clarke-Stone, the chief executive of Narrative, looks for prospective employees who can match her drive.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Tricia Clarke-Stone, C.E.O. of Narrative, a marketing and technology firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Bill Walton’s Long, Strange Tale of N.B.A. Survival
abstract: A basketball legend looks back with surprising gratitude on a life plagued by physical agony.
lead_paragraph: Bill Walton arrived at the San Diego Natural History Museum carrying a large black chair. I watched him walk with it, a little stiffly, past the Moreton Bay fig tree outside. The tree is one of the city’s grand natural treasures: more than 100 years old, nearly 100 feet tall, hugely spread, still standing despite a century of weather and air pollution and climbing children. It’s so large that it made even Walton, one of basketball’s dominating giants, look small.

headline: Arguments Get Personal Between Donald Trump and Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: All week, Donald J. Trump has slowly escalated a war of words on Twitter against Senator Ted Cruz based on an ad by a “super PAC” started by people who want to stop the New York developer from getting the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: From his home at Mar-a-Lago, Donald J. Trump stirred up new controversy this week in the Republican presidential primary — and new alarm among party leaders that the front-runner for the nomination will drive away women from candidates running farther down the ballot in the fall.

headline: The Only Girl at Her Science Camp
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Science and Technology', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As a Latina girl who dreams of being a NASA inventor, my 7-year-old daughter’s path is unlikely to be smooth, and the deck remains stacked against her.
lead_paragraph: My 7-year-old daughter has pretend space launches in our living room. She loves Tinkerbell not because she has sparkly wings, but because she is a “tinker” fairy that can fix anything. Signing her up for summer camp should be a chance to simply let her grow and explore her interests as a budding scientist or engineer. Yet we are aware that as a Latina girl who dreams of being a NASA inventor, her path is unlikely to be smooth, and the deck remains stacked against her.

headline: Market for Chinese Art Is Increasingly in China
abstract: Despite a slump in other areas of collecting, Chinese buyers continue to seek out outstanding examples of their cultural heritage around the world.
lead_paragraph: The art market is feeling under pressure from the outside world.

headline: John Kerry, in Brussels, Says ISIS Is Faltering in Mideast
abstract: The secretary of state traveled to Belgium to demonstrate American support after the attacks and said that backing for the Islamic State in the Middle East was eroding.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State is desperately lashing out in Europe because its base in the Middle East is rapidly eroding, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday in Brussels, where he traveled to demonstrate the United States’ support for Belgium three days after bombs killed 31 people, including at least two Americans.

headline: Health Savings Accounts: Unloved, but Worthwhile
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances', 'Retirement']
abstract: People don’t save much for things they don’t expect — like serious illness. But the accounts offer a cushion, and have no use-it-or-lose-it provision.
lead_paragraph: Health savings accounts offer a rare, triple-tax benefit to those who are able to contribute and who qualify to save for future medical needs — which, among other things, means having a health insurance plan with a deductible of at least $1,300. Money goes into an H.S.A. tax-free, grows tax-free and is withdrawn tax-free, if spent on eligible medical costs.

headline: Credit Cards Encourage Extra Spending as the Cash Habit Fades Away
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Personal Finances', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: Using plastic instead of dollars encourages consumers to pay more for everyday items than they might otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Nina Falcone has given up on cash.

headline: Finding a Job That Works for You
abstract: Experts say that those choosing a career can often be misled by their biases to follow a parent’s path or to look only at a field’s tangible rewards.
lead_paragraph: Sunil Yapa was bouncing from college to college, searching for a career, when he decided to return to a familiar place: his hometown, State College, Pa. There, he found himself in the building where he had often visited his father, Lakshman, a geography professor at Penn State. He took his dad’s classes, helped him write a draft of a book about the social construction of poverty and earned a bachelor’s degree in geography in 2003.

headline: New Hampshire Drug Data
abstract: The latest drug data from New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: The latest drug data from New Hampshire.

headline: Heroin Epidemic Is Yielding to a Deadlier Cousin: Fentanyl
abstract: Cheaper and far more potent, the synthetic painkiller is becoming the drug of choice for some addicts — and is killing them more quickly.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — When Eddie Frasca was shooting up heroin, he occasionally sought out its more potent, lethal cousin, fentanyl.

headline: California Chrome’s Global Fan Club Spreads to Dubai
abstract: If California Chrome can win Saturday's $10 million Dubai World Cup, he will become the all-time leading thoroughbred in career earnings with $12.5 million.
lead_paragraph: After Art Sherman, the 79-year-old trainer of the 2014 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner California Chrome, arrived in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, from Southern California on Monday, he tried his best to sleep, but it was of no use.

headline: Je Suis Sick of This
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: After yet another terrorist attack in Europe, can life return to normal?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — WHEN I moved to Europe 12 years ago, my biggest concern was whether I’d ever speak decent French. Practically every American I knew came to visit, many saying they dreamed of living here, too. I didn’t worry much about far-right political parties, or the European Union. I certainly didn’t fret about terrorism.

headline: Family of Elita Borbor Weah, Brussels Victim, Mourns One Loss, Then Another
abstract: A native of Liberia who lived in the Netherlands, Ms. Weah was on her way to the United States to attend a funeral when she was killed at the airport.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Before Elita Borbor Weah set foot in Brussels Airport on Tuesday, her family was already in mourning.

headline: Death of a Little Student
abstract: The tragic death of a boy in a fire brings out how strongly such a loss can affect an educator as well as a family.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
abstract: An exhibition in London looks at performance art and photography, a festival brings over 200 music acts to Estonia, and two contemporary art shows run in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: Tallinn, Estonia

headline: David Dixon, Despite a Reassuring Text Message, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Mr. Dixon, 51, a British software developer and father, told his family he was safe after the airport blast — then he went to the Maelbeek subway station.
lead_paragraph: David Dixon had not heard about the explosion at Brussels Airport until a concerned aunt  in Britain sent a text message asking if he was safe. He told her he was, and then he made his way to the Maelbeek subway station.

headline: Online Music Calls the Tune, With Less Pay for the Piper
abstract: Revenue from music sales has been flat for years, despite a growing market for vinyl albums. Some musicians find a better outlet in live performances.
lead_paragraph: Some say that on the Internet, content is king, because that is what draws audiences. Maybe — but if so, its crown is not very golden.

headline: How to Live Without Windows 10
abstract: If you cannot upgrade to Windows 10 and you do not want to buy a new PC, you may still have alternatives.
lead_paragraph: Q. My computer is not compatible with Windows 10. What will happen in the future? I do not want to get a new computer.

headline: Getting Workers to Save More for Retirement
abstract: Changing how people think about the money they save is one of the central tenets of a movement that is based on behavioral finance.
lead_paragraph: Saving for retirement should be simple arithmetic — the longer your money has to grow, the more money you should have when you stop working. But saving today for a distant tomorrow isn’t so simple, and has a great deal to do with how people think about money.

headline: Suite Dreams: What You Get for $75,000 a Night
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: If you’re the sort of traveler who desires a private pool, a grand piano or seating for 24 in your hotel room, look no further
lead_paragraph: If you’re the sort of traveler who desires a private pool, a grand piano or seating for 24 in your hotel room, look no further

headline: Apps That Make Saving as Effortless as Spending
abstract: In a consumer culture designed to encourage spending, new tools aim to reverse that pattern.
lead_paragraph: A new crop of electronic financial tools is trying to help Americans save.

headline: ‘Batman v Superman’ Battles the Critics
keywords: ['Movies', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Savage reviews have drawn the ire of fans online, but it remains to be seen if they can rescue the caped heroes at theaters this weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” has been ripped apart by critics. The movie had sunk to a 31 percent on Rotten Tomatoes as of this writing, joining other critically disparaged superhero films like the “Fantastic Four” reboot of 2015 (9 percent) and “Green Lantern,” from 2011 (26 percent).

headline: Are Luxury Suites Worth the Splurge? Hotels Are Banking on It
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: As the luxury market thrives, new hotel suites with eye-popping price tags promise private check-in, rooftop Jacuzzis and killer views.
lead_paragraph: Le Dôme,  a nearly 900-square-foot suite in Le Cinq Codet in the heart of Paris, is named for its striking views of the golden Dôme des Invalides, under which Napoleon is entombed. But if that vista doesn’t grab you, wander over to the other end of the private terrace, past a half-dozen deck chairs (all yours) and gaze at the Eiffel Tower. And should you grow tired of that, there is always the Jacuzzi, from which you can look out over the mansard rooftops of the Seventh Arrondissement and polish off the Champagne and chocolates that were left while you were out. Inside there’s a couch shaped like a croissant, a curved OLED television, two bathrooms, a dressing room and a tub ringed with white rose petals.

headline: The Art of Saying No as a Philanthropist
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Declining a request for money can be hard for philanthropists and other donors, but it need not be harsh or a drawn-out process.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES the hardest part of being a philanthropist is saying no — particularly if the request comes from worthy organizations or equally well-heeled friends.

headline: Going to New Heights to Please Buyers
abstract: Higher ceilings generally increase construction costs, but developers feel the money is well spent since high ceilings lend themselves to grander spaces.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, if you were looking to buy a condominium with high ceilings, your choice was limited to prewar apartments, lofts or penthouse units. Now several developers are offering new condo projects that have soaring ceilings in more than half the building, giving buyers the option of taking a unit on a lower floor with ceilings 11 feet or higher.

headline: Ebola, Ruthless to Families, Leaves Liberian Man Alive and Alone
abstract: Gaye Dumbai got the news that greets so many other survivors: His relatives — 13 in all — were dead. Now, more than a year later, he has his life back, but it is not the same life.
lead_paragraph: DOLOS TOWN, Liberia — As Gaye Dumbai came trudging up the dirt road, heading toward the overgrown cemetery where his mother is buried, villagers came out of their houses despite the pouring rain to get a closer look at him.

headline: Tweetness of Life
abstract: A public service notice.
lead_paragraph: Just a notice: I’ve run into several people recently who didn’t know that I am now doing some direct postings to my Twitter account, in addition to the automatic posting of links to this blog. Some of the tweets are even substantive. So if you are a blog follower, you might want to check that account too — no need to join Twitter yourself!

headline: Medical, Dental, 401(k)? Now Add School Loan Aid to Job Benefits
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Credit and Debt', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Employers like Fidelity have begun instituting student loan repayment benefits, a policy likely to gain traction with American companies.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Amanda Danner and her husband make what feels like a mortgage payment. But they don’t yet own a home.

headline: What Reagan Didn’t Do
abstract: About that rising tide.
lead_paragraph: I suppose I shouldn’t add to the woes of the reformocons, the people who wanted to move the GOP forward with new ideas — but have learned that they have no constituency. (Marco Rubio betrayed their hopes even before he imploded.) Still, one thing I have been seeing lately is statements along the lines of “When Reagan cut taxes and regulation, it created a rising tide that raised all boats — but times have changed, and now we need policies that address the needs of working families.”

headline: In Yahoo, Another Example of the Buyback Mirage
abstract: A company’s overall profit growth is unaffected by share buybacks, $6.6 billion since 2008 in Yahoo’s case.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the great investment conundrums of our time: Why do so many stockholders cheer when a company announces that it’s buying back shares?

headline: Q. and A.: Bryshere Y. Gray on ‘Empire’ and Navigating Hollywood
abstract: Mr. Gray plays Hakeem Lyon on the hit Fox series, which returns on March 30.
lead_paragraph: In Season 2 of the Fox smash “Empire,” Hakeem Lyon was kidnapped and later betrayed his father, Lucious, plotting to become head of the family music business himself. And when the show returns on March 30, Hakeem may just be a father, too — with his dad’s former fiancée.

headline: Human Trafficking on Trial in Thailand
abstract: The prosecution of 92 people is just a first step in reining in a huge criminal industry.
lead_paragraph: The first witness in the largest human-trafficking trial in Thai history was called to testify last week in a court in Bangkok. The witness, a Rohingya Muslim from Myanmar, told of being beaten and starved by gun-toting captors on the boat that ferried him and more than 200 others to a trafficking camp in Thailand.

headline: Obama Family Vacations: Highlights From 2009-2015
abstract: A look at some of the first family's trips together over the first seven years of the president's tenure in office.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the first family's trips together over the first seven years of the president's tenure in office.

headline: 1916: Ship Survivors Land at Dover
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Only 70 survive the attack on the Sussex and land at Dover in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Latest reports received indicate that eighty persons lost their lives on board the Sussex when she was torpedoed or struck a mine in the Channel yesterday [Mar. 24] afternoon. There were 386 passengers on board and the crew numbered 50.

headline: Obama Family Spring Break: Making History and Doing the Tango
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: From a historic visit in Cuba to downtime at a remote park in Argentina, the first family makes a holiday of one of President Obama’s last big trips in office.
lead_paragraph: BARILOCHE, Argentina — The presidential motorcade wove down winding roads flanked by steep grass-covered hills and a deep-blue alpine lake, delivering President Obama and his family to the trailhead of a hike through the lush woods of one of Argentina’s most spectacular regions.

headline: China Said to Detain Several Over Letter Criticizing Xi
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The four employees of Wujie News, a state-run website, include two top editors. A freelance writer previously detained indicated he has been released.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese security officers appear to have detained several people in their investigation of a mysterious, fiery letter posted online this month that strongly criticized President Xi Jinping and demanded that he resign.

headline: Sweep Leads to 5 Arrests, a Foiled Plot and a Paris-Brussels Connection
abstract: Najim Laachraoui, 24, who blew himself up at Brussels Airport, made two of the explosive vests used in the assaults on the French capital in November.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Counterterrorism officials widened a sweep targeting suspected Islamic State operatives to several European countries on Friday, reporting newly uncovered links between the Brussels and Paris massacres, at least five arrests and the foiling of what France described as an advanced plan for another attack.

headline: Water Is Her Element
abstract: Krystal Lara’s parents thought she should learn to swim. Now a senior at Stuyvesant High School, she’s backstroking toward the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Krystal Lara’s parents thought she should learn to swim. Now a senior at Stuyvesant High School, she’s backstroking toward the Olympics.

headline: A Top ISIS Leader Is Killed in an Airstrike, the Pentagon Says
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The killing of Abd al-Rahman Mustafa al-Qaduli comes as the U.S. appears to be having increased success targeting the Islamic State’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American Special Operations forces in eastern Syria killed a top Islamic State commander this week, Pentagon officials said Friday, part of a monthslong campaign the Obama administration boasts is eviscerating the Islamic State even as the group continues to demonstrate the power to sow violence in Western Europe.

headline: Her Parents Thought Swimming Lessons Were a Good Idea
abstract: Krystal Lara is one of very few Latinas in her class at Stuyvesant High School, and in the pool. She’s backstroking her way toward the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the middle of the pool, Krystal Lara began to wonder when her hand would brush tile. She knew she was winning her race, but like most backstrokers in unfamiliar waters, she had only a vague sense of how far she had left to go. With her face cocked upward, she discerned her progress by the overhead lights retreating out of sight in a fluorescent blur.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: BEYOND: Our Future in Space, by Chris ­Impey. (Norton, $16.95.) Though advances in space exploration may have stalled in recent decades (the most recent manned lunar expedition was more than 40 years ago), an innate desire to explore seems to be coded into human DNA. Impey, an astronomer, outlines the array of innovative developments that may render forays into space routine.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: IMBECILES: The Supreme Court, American Eugenics and the Sterilization of Carrie Buck, by Adam Cohen. (Penguin Press, $28.) A superb history of eugenics in America, organized around a 1927 case about forced sterilization.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: James Patterson’s “Private Paris,” No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, is the author’s 13th book to spend time on the lists in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Fast Fiction: “Private Paris,” the latest thriller in James Patterson’s series about the global private eye Jack Morgan, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. The book (written with Mark Sullivan) is Patterson’s 13th to spend time on the best-seller lists in 2016 — an astounding number by any measure, but evidently not enough for the restless Patterson, who recently announced plans to entice new readers with a series of shorter, more plot-based books. “You can race through these; they’re like reading movies,” Patterson said in an interview with Alexandra Alter of The Times. It’s true that Patterson’s novels, although famous for their fast-moving chapters, aren’t especially terse — “Private Paris” runs almost 450 ­pages. But more plot-based? That’s like McDonald’s expanding its market through intravenous injections of salt, sugar and fat. It will probably work like a dream.

headline: Growing Up in a Bad Neighborhood Does More Harm Than We Thought
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Income', 'Research', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: A new study suggests that when a child moves out of a troubled area, the results in later life may be even more positive than economists once believed.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood in which you grow up is a major determinant of your economic success as an adult. That’s been known for a while, but new research suggests that the effects may be much larger than social scientists previously understood.

headline: Posthumous Novel With a Beat
abstract: Ali Eskandarian’s deeply autobiographical first novel arrives three years after the Iranian-American musician was murdered in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ali Eskandarian’s deeply autobiographical first novel, “Golden Years,” is about an Iranian-American musician and his group of friends in New York, living for the classic cocktail of sex, drugs and possible fame. It’s a book that arrives with an unusual — and unusually tragic — back story.

headline: Comic Fiction
abstract: New books by Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney, Mona Awad, Elizabeth McKenzie and Helen Ellis.
lead_paragraph: THE NESTBy Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney353 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.

headline: Thomas the Tank Engine’s Expanding World
abstract: With an eye toward global audiences, and after some criticism about lack of diversity, new characters are being added to “Thomas & Friends.”
lead_paragraph: Thomas’s friends are finally getting a little more diverse.

headline: Millennial Days
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Youth', 'Social Media', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Why is it distasteful or indulgent for young women to confess to the darkest times in their lives?
lead_paragraph: “By definition, younger memoirists (those under the age of 40) have a deficit in perspective,” Noelle Howey wrote in the Book Review last year. Wait 10 or 20 years, the wisdom goes, and reap insights that would elude your younger self. Countless life stories have been told brilliantly through this long-range lens: Lidia Yuknavitch’s “The Chronology of Water,” Kathryn Harrison’s “The Kiss,” Mary Karr’s “The Liars’ Club.” Karr even echoes Howey in her new book, “The Art of Memoir”: “If you’re young, you might wanna wait.”

headline: Bruce Wagner’s ‘I Met Someone’
abstract: A novel of Hollywood goings-on stars hustlers and climbers, parental yearnings and baroque twists.
lead_paragraph: I MET SOMEONEBy Bruce Wagner369 pp. Blue Rider Press. $27.95.

headline: John Jodzio’s ‘Knockout’
abstract: Stories featuring Taser-happy humans and a collapsing giraffe.
lead_paragraph: KNOCKOUTStoriesBy John Jodzio196 pp. Soft Skull Press. Paper, $15.95.

headline: ‘The Best Place on Earth,’ by Ayelet Tsabari
abstract: Short fiction on the search for identity in Israel and beyond.
lead_paragraph: THE BEST PLACE ON EARTHStoriesBy Ayelet Tsabari256 pp. Random House. $26.

headline: ‘As Close to Us as Breathing,’ by Elizabeth Poliner
abstract: A novel of family life in a Jewish summer community shortly after World War II.
lead_paragraph: AS CLOSE TO US AS BREATHINGBy Elizabeth Poliner358 pp. A Lee Boudreaux Book/Little, Brown & Company. $27.

headline: ‘Smarter Faster Better,’ by Charles Duhigg
abstract: A journalist pairs eight ideas for increasing productivity with stories of success.
lead_paragraph: SMARTER FASTER BETTERThe Secrets of Being Productive in Life and BusinessBy Charles DuhiggIllustrated. 380 pp. Random House. $28.

headline: ‘Gone With the Mind,’ by Mark Leyner
abstract: In Mark Leyner’s novel, a writer and his mother head to the mall to read from his ‘autobiography.’
lead_paragraph: GONE WITH THE MINDBy Mark Leyner250 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $25.

headline: ‘American Girls,’ by Nancy Jo Sales
abstract: Nancy Jo Sales believes we should be very worried about the effects of social media on teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN GIRLSSocial Media and the Secret Lives of TeenagersBy Nancy Jo Sales404 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: A $22.2 Million Penthouse Atop a Landmark
abstract: A full-floor penthouse at the top of the landmark Manhattan House on the Upper East Side is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: An immense, full-floor penthouse at the top of the Manhattan House, a condominium conversion of a white-brick landmark building with a private garden on the Upper East Side, sold for $22,168,630 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Plans for Easter, pulled lamb shoulder and more for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Why We Think We’re Better Investors Than We Are
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Optimism', 'Memory']
abstract: Psychologists weigh in on some of the biases and cognitive errors that help explain why we think we are better at active investing than we really are.
lead_paragraph: From their earliest days, the loosely confederated research efforts that came to be known as behavioral economics spawned a large quantity of studies centered on securities investment. This was not because the field’s pioneers were especially interested in stocks and bonds, nor was the early research commonly underwritten by financial services firms.

headline: Investing for Your Future Health Care
keywords: ['Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Personal Finances', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Elder Care']
abstract: Interest in long-term care insurance has waned, even as the conversation about how to take care of an aging population grows.
lead_paragraph: Ken Dychtwald, who is 65 and is the chief executive officer of Age Wave, a consulting and research company focused on aging, decided in his 50s that he and his wife should buy long-term care insurance so they wouldn’t be a burden on each other or their children if they became ill or disabled.

headline: When Not Paying Attention Pays Off
abstract: Re-evaluating your investment portfolio too frequently can lead to lower returns in the long run.
lead_paragraph: Pay attention to your teacher. Pay attention to detail. Pay attention, pay attention, pay attention! Our entire lives we’re warned: Pay attention, or.… Well, you know. The worst will happen.

headline: A Nearly Foolproof Method for Golden, Crunchy Chicken Breast
abstract: Chicken Milanese, dressed with a kicky olive relish, is easier and faster than regular fried chicken.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor skinless, boneless chicken breast, so often heartbreakingly overcooked. Dry, stringy, bland, sad. What’s doubly sad is that it really doesn’t have to be that way.

headline: 1966: France Pledges to Aid India
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France pledges to aid India in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Charles de Gaulle, in talks with Indian Prime Minister Mrs. Indira Gandhi, today pledged France to help India industrialize, diplomatic sources said.

headline: The Times on the Air: Brussels Attackers’ Motives, Trump as Daddy Warbucks, India’s New Generation
abstract: A weekly recap of the television and radio appearances of New York Times journalists.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. Below are highlights from television and radio interviews featuring Times reporters, columnists and executives.

headline: Baby Boomers Are Finding a Second Career in Politics
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Retirement', 'Local Government', 'Careers and Professions', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Older people are filling an increasing number of elected offices, in many ways an extension of their broader interest in political activism.
lead_paragraph: STEVEN PONTO was a senior lawyer at a financial services technology company when it was sold in 2009. Some colleagues were relocating to Jacksonville, Fla., the headquarters of the new parent, but he didn’t want to leave the small city outside Milwaukee where he had lived since 1990.

headline: Seeking Painkillers in the Emergency Room
abstract: “Why wouldn’t I give patients a Percocet prescription? It makes their life easier and my life easier,” a colleague said to me recently. But that’s not the answer to the opioid epidemic.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, a patient well known to the emergency room where I work came in requesting his usual cocktail of narcotic pain medications. It was early Saturday morning, before the usual bustle of patients had begun, and I had some time.

headline: Fruits and Vegetables to Fight Cataracts
abstract: Here’s another reason to eat your veggies and fruits high in vitamin C: You may reduce your risk of vision loss from cataracts.
lead_paragraph: Here’s another reason to eat your fruits and veggies: You may reduce your risk of vision loss from cataracts.

headline: In a Florentine Palazzo, History with a Dash of Playfulness
abstract: In the aptly named Garibaldi Blu Hotel, the conspicuous color theme is everywhere, mixed with quirky touches like a lifelike statue of Batman.
lead_paragraph: Rooms from 140 euros (about $156); from 250 euros in high season.

headline: This Design Firm Fights Bad Taste From Within
abstract: The duo behind Studio Job embraces kitsch and chaos, sex and death, history and politics in their work.
lead_paragraph: After a few minutes with the Flemish designer Job Smeets, you start to feel sorry for the water jug at his elbow. Sleek and minimal, it seems a perfectly normal pitcher from, say, Umbra or Ikea, but Mr. Smeets prods it like something rotten. He holds it up, literally and figuratively, as a symbol of what’s wrong with design.

headline: How Many People Have Been Killed in ISIS Attacks Around the World
abstract: More than 1,200 people outside of Iraq and Syria have been killed in attacks inspired or coordinated by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 people outside of Iraq and Syria have been killed in attacks inspired or coordinated by the Islamic State.

headline: Turkey Abruptly Closes Espionage Trial of 2 Journalists to Public
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The move was criticized by journalists and anti-government and human rights activists who wondered if the defendants could receive a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A long-awaited trial of two Turkish journalists facing potential life sentences on espionage charges began Friday, but was quickly closed to the public and news media, prompting outrage and concerns over whether the proceedings could be free and fair. A subsequent postponement, until April 1, did little to stanch the criticism.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Girls and Sex’
abstract: This week, Peggy Orenstein talks about “Girls and Sex”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; John Williams discusses “The Throwback Special”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Peggy Orenstein talks about “Girls and Sex”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; John Williams discusses “The Throwback Special”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: In ‘The Larry Sanders Show,’ Larry, Garry and the Audience Made a Comic Love Triangle
abstract: This seminal HBO series captured the neediness of performers, and the shifting emotions they feel toward their audiences.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you hear in “The Larry Sanders Show” is Hank Kingsley (Jeffrey Tambor), the sidekick to the late-night host Larry Sanders (Garry Shandling), preparing the members of the studio audience of the show within the show. The host, he tells them, needs their help — their applause, their affirmation. “The better you are,” he says, “the better Larry is.”

headline: Call It What It Is: A Rabble
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Trump brings out the mob latent in a political crowd.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS don’t have a vocabulary to describe the pernicious behavior of political crowds, but our forefathers did. John Adams favored a strong executive to guard against “the mob.” He thought that partisans of popular democracy like Thomas Jefferson or Tom Paine ignored the dangers of populist passion. The people, he wrote, can be as tyrannical as any king. That division contributed to the formation of the first parties — Adams’s Federalists and Jefferson’s Democrats.

abstract: A reader writes that there’s no need for “fanciful mental cartography.”

headline: 1910s | Easter Colors for the Gray Lady
abstract: Color printing of The New York Times did not begin in 1993. New research discloses that it was inaugurated at least 80 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: Forget that parade on the avenue, Fifth Avenue.

headline: Products and Competition Stretch Market for ‘Athleisure’ Clothing
abstract: Seemingly every clothing brand and retailer wants in on clothing made both for exercise and for everyday wear, but the market is becoming crowded.
lead_paragraph: The beams are still bare in Yogasmoga’s first Manhattan store, juice bar and fitness studio. But Rishi Bali raves that he is building the next Lululemon — only better.

headline: The Imprint of Racism
abstract: A reader debunks the phrase, used by whites, “I don’t think about race.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alexander and Sascha Pinczowski, Siblings on Way to New York, Killed at Brussels Airport
abstract: The Dutch siblings, who traveled the world and considered New York a second home, were on the phone with their mother when two bombs exploded.
lead_paragraph: Alexander and Sascha Pinczowski were siblings living in Belgium, but they never lingered in one place for long. The children of a hotel manager, they had lived in Turkey, Greece and Germany, and were on their way back to New York, a city they both loved, when they arrived at the departures hall at Brussels Airport on Tuesday.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Simon Critchley
abstract: The philosopher shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the philosopher Simon Critchley, whose many books include "Faith of the Faithless” and "Bowie,” an excursion through the songs of David Bowie. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Donald Trump’s Trail of Comments About Women
abstract: Over the years, Mr. Trump has said several things that some find to be sexist and offensive.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump says regularly that he “cherishes” women and that he would be their greatest advocate as president, but his latest feud with Ted Cruz — in which he threatened the Texas senator’s wife, Heidi, and reposted an unflattering picture of her on Twitter — has resurfaced questions about his history of making comments that some find to be sexist. Over the years, Mr. Trump has said several things that his critics have called offensive. This is a sampling of such comments.

headline: Can North Carolina Get Away With Rolling Back L.G.B.T. Rights?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Gender']
abstract: A new law and the shifting politics of tolerance.
lead_paragraph: In a bill that zoomed through with head-spinning speed, the North Carolina legislature rushed Wednesday to strip rights from L.G.B.T. people. The excuse for the bill was to restrict transgender people to using the public restroom that matches the gender on their birth certificates. But the Republican-led Legislature went far beyond bathrooms. Lawmakers also blocked cities and counties from protecting people from discrimination, based on sexual orientation or gender identity, in restaurants, hotels, taxis or any form of public accommodation. It’s a sweeping law — and it represents a backlash against the strides L.G.B.T. people have made in other arenas this year, one that yanks North Carolina back in time.

headline: Chief Justice John Roberts’s Duty
abstract: The head of Fix the Court calls on the chief justice to offer solutions to partisan entrenchment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Republicans Continue Their Attacks on Fetal Tissue Research
abstract: New subpoenas from the House Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives could put researchers at risk.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in the House launched a politically-motivated attack on fetal tissue research and abortion rights when they created the Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives, which held its first hearing earlier this month. Now they plan to continue their campaign by issuing 17 subpoenas seeking the names of researchers, students and others.

headline: Bound for U.S. and His ‘Georgia Peach,’ He Died in Brussels
abstract: Bart Migom was on his way from Belgium to Atlanta to visit his American girlfriend, Emily Eisenman, when the bombs went off.
lead_paragraph: Bart Migom was on his way from Brussels to Atlanta on Tuesday to see the woman he called his “Georgia peach” and “partner in Christ.”

headline: How Buyers React When Prices Rise and Fall
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: People overreact to price or income changes within a category like gasoline, working to save or splurge more than they would for a similar change in overall income.
lead_paragraph: When gasoline prices spike, do you go in search of the station with the lowest price or wait in a long line to save 5 cents a gallon? When prices fall, do you splurge and pay 10 cents more for brand-name gasoline that promises to make your engine run more smoothly?

headline: The Fashion News to Know This Week

headline: Why I Don’t Make Financial Decisions on My Smartphone
abstract: Smartphones can encourage us to tap and swipe quickly, which can lead us to neglect the long-term consequences of our behavior.
lead_paragraph: According to a recent survey by the Federal Reserve, 52 percent of adult smartphone owners use mobile banking services. It’s easy to understand the appeal of these financial apps, as they give us the ability to get real-time updates on our account balances and spending. Research I conducted with Yaron Levi has shown that such updates can deliver real benefits, helping people cut their spending by 15.7 percent.

headline: Discovery of Navy Shipwreck Solves 95-Year-Old Mystery
keywords: ['Shipwrecks (Historic)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Tugboats and Towboats']
abstract: The U.S.S. Conestoga, a Navy tugboat that disappeared in 1921, has been found in shark-infested waters about 30 miles west of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: A Navy tugboat that disappeared after it sailed from San Francisco in 1921 has been found by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration researchers in shark-infested waters about 30 miles west of San Francisco, putting an end to a 95-year-old mystery.

headline: Lawyer Defending Russian Soldier in Ukraine Is Found Dead
abstract: Yuri L. Grabovsky had been representing a serviceman detained last year and suspected by Ukrainian officials of being in eastern Ukraine on a military mission.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Ukrainian lawyer who was defending one of the Russian servicemen currently on trial in Ukraine was found dead on Friday, a government official said during a news conference in Kiev, Ukraine’s capital.

headline: Life Insurance Tries to Lighten Up
abstract: An industry takes aim at significant barriers to selling its complicated products that also remind potential customers of their own mortality.
lead_paragraph: A new television commercial features babies learning to walk. Some manage a few steps before plopping to the ground. “You see them through all of life’s ups and downs,” a woman’s voice says as the ad ends.

headline: David Peralta’s Relentless Push From Independent Ball to the Majors
abstract: David Peralta, once a failed pitcher in the Cardinals system, reinvented himself and wound up hitting .312 for the Diamondbacks last year.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — David Peralta had a dream and a problem. His dream was to play baseball again. His problem was that he could not afford it.

abstract: Readers, including an aid worker and former U.N. employees, expand upon a Sunday Review article.

headline: Victims’ Neighbor Sought in Deadly Staten Island Shooting
abstract: Investigators said they believed the shooting outside the Mariner’s Harbor Houses occurred after a confrontation over money the suspect thought he was owed.
lead_paragraph: The animosity between the two men on Staten Island festered for years. Anthony Morales believed that Anthony Rivera, his neighbor in the Mariner’s Harbor Houses, owed him $15,000, and he would not let the 21-year-old forget about it, law enforcement officials said.

headline: The Race Is On to Control Artificial Intelligence, and Tech’s Future
abstract: Amazon, Google, IBM and Microsoft are using high salaries and games pitting humans against computers to try to claim the standard on which all companies will build their A.I. technology.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The resounding win by a Google artificial intelligence program over a champion in the complex board game Go this month was a statement — not so much to professional game players as to Google’s competitors.

headline: Review: Greek Leanings, With an Element of Surprise, at 251 Lex
abstract: At this restaurant in Mount Kisco, N.Y., what you don’t order can be even better than what you do.
lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to the new 251 Lex in Mount Kisco we ordered several starters, and were surprised when a plate of small dumplings was placed in front of us. We hadn’t requested the sheep-cheese gnudi “spanakopita,” but I’ve rarely been so happy about a kitchen error. Delicate and creamy, with just a hint of crunch from phyllo crumble, the dish had a subtle undercurrent of truffle pesto and scallion butter.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Terrifying Approach to ‘Religious Liberty’
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The recommendations of his “Religious Liberty Advisory Council” are predictable — and predictably disturbing.
lead_paragraph: Despite his hundreds of rallies, his many interviews and his hyperactive Twitter feed, it’s still really hard to tell the difference between what Donald Trump actually believes, what he says to whip up his crowds, and what he says merely because it popped into his head one afternoon.

headline: When Obama Came to Town
abstract: For an American student spending a semester abroad in Havana, the president’s visit brought a real-life twist to her studies in U.S.-Cuba relations.
lead_paragraph: Havana — On Monday, the first full day of President Obama’s historic visit to Cuba, the professor of my class on Cuban-United States relations, a woman in her 40s, wheeled a TV into our classroom in the José Martí building at the University of Havana, the set looking like it dated from the 1970s.

headline: What I Love | Chris Grabenstein

abstract: The Upper West Side apartment of the best-selling children’s book author Chris Grabenstein is filled with whimsy.
lead_paragraph: The Upper West Side apartment of the best-selling children’s book author Chris Grabenstein is filled with whimsy.

headline: A New Breed of Opera Diva: Sheep
abstract: How do you cast and direct an avant-garde opera starring 100 sheep in New York City — in the middle of lambing season, no less?
lead_paragraph: The unlikeliest stars of New York’s spring opera season were raised humbly in rural Pennsylvania on pop and country-western music, but they are already showing prima donna tendencies. Not only did a whole new dressing room have to be built for them backstage, but it also had to be soundproofed and kept fully stocked with their favorite snacks: grain and a hay mixture of timothy, orchard grass and red clover.

headline: Chris Grabenstein at Home on the Upper West Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The Upper West Side apartment of the best-selling children’s book author Chris Grabenstein is filled with whimsy.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Upper West Side apartment of the author Chris Grabenstein are greeted by a retro-futuristic “robot” that the artist Steve Heller assembled from vintage found pieces: a stainless-steel pool filter torso, a stereo amplifier head and shock-absorber legs. It’s a cross between the Tin Man from “The Wizard of Oz” and Rosie, the maid from “The Jetsons,” and a suitably wacky welcome to the world of Mr. Grabenstein.

headline: Tribune Chief Discusses Transforming a Mature Media Company
abstract: Peter Liguori talked about the transformation of Tribune and the broader media industry during a recent interview in his New York office.
lead_paragraph: Peter Liguori, the longtime television executive, was appointed the new chief executive of the Tribune Company in 2013, just two and a half weeks after the newspaper and TV company emerged from an agonizing four-year bankruptcy process.

headline: ISIS Suicide Bomber in Iraq Kills Dozens at Soccer Game
abstract: The police say the attack devastated a crowd in the town of Iskandariya, south of Baghdad, at a game sponsored by a powerful Shiite militia.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber detonated his explosive belt at a soccer game in a town south of Baghdad on Friday, killing at least 31 people, including the town’s mayor, provincial police officials said.

headline: Review: From Scratch, in Ridgewood, Focuses on Italy’s Simple Pleasures
abstract: The restaurant’s Italian owners use a mix of imported goods and local produce to evoke the flavors of their homeland.
lead_paragraph: A pool of creamy mozzarella spilled out of the grilled zucchini wrapped around the thick round of cheese. With every pleasurable bite, I had to remind myself that I was in Ridgewood and not Campania, Italy.

headline: Teacher at Islamic School ‘Torn From Her Family by Cowards’ in Brussels
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Loubna Lafquiri, mother of three boys and a gym teacher, died in the bombing at the Maelbeek Metro station in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: A gym teacher at an Islamic school in Brussels, Loubna Lafquiri was dedicated to teaching children respect for others, self-confidence, perseverance and forgiveness, all with a love and appreciation for Islam.

headline: Face Masks for the Morning — That You Leave on All Day
abstract: A new crop of no-rinse products promises to replenish the skin and make it easier to apply makeup.
lead_paragraph: The masking hour is, traditionally, a period of required sequestration — a nighttime ritual designed to rebalance your skin in privacy. But a new breed of no-rinse masks can be applied in the morning and left on all day, providing benefits when they’ll actually be visible: the waking hours. Stronger than daily-use creams, and easier to walk around in than sheet masks, the new leave-on-all-day variety is about skin preparation — not restoration. “When you rinse a mask off, that ends your skin’s absorption,” says Tata Harper, whose popular all-natural skin-care line features several no-rinse options. “Leave-on masks extend the time your skin has to absorb benefits.” These formulas are translucent and porous enough to work well with other products, offering a lifted, protected and smoothed-out base for further skin care and makeup. What keeps them within the realm of masks is their potency — most require a brief period to fully absorb and typically aren’t recommended for daily use.

headline: Syrian Army Said to Be Closer to Retaking Palmyra
abstract: A state news agency said the army regained control of the citadel in Palmyra after heavy fighting with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After days of raging battles with Islamic State militants, Syrian Army units and allied government militias backed by intensive Russian airstrikes on Friday recaptured the strategically important citadel in Palmyra, Syrian state television reported, citing a military source.

headline: Review: Schout Bay Tavern in Long Island, a Pub With an Irreverent Side
abstract: A brasserie offers a playful approach to modern cuisine, encouraging diners to mix and match entrees and their accompaniments.
lead_paragraph: Schout Bay Tavern, named after the colonial Dutch term for Manhasset Bay, opened quietly on the village’s main street just before Labor Day in 2015. Since then, positive word of mouth has brought much of the neighborhood to its chic, modern doorstep.

headline: Louisville Is a Grumpy N.C.A.A. Host as Its Team Sits One Out
abstract: March sadness has overtaken Louisville, Ky., which is hosting an N.C.A.A. tournament regional but whose college team is serving a postseason ban.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Monkey Wrench, a bar in the Highlands neighborhood here, hosted a “March Sadness” event Friday night. Fans gathered to watch taped broadcasts of the three games in which the Louisville men’s basketball team won national championships, in 1980, 1986 and 2013. Wearing red was required, and, per tradition, the song “Mahgeetah” by the Louisville band My Morning Jacket was played after victory was secured.

headline: Bernie Sanders Consistent Over Decades in His Call for ‘Revolution’
abstract: The candidate has always spoken about what he sees as an economy rigged against the working class and a campaign finance system that corrupts politicians.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — On the night of the New Hampshire primary, the high-water mark of his presidential campaign, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont called his rout of Hillary Clinton “nothing short of the beginning of a political revolution” and vowed to stop the “billionaire class” from buying elections.

headline: How to Stop Overprescribing Antibiotics
abstract: Doctors give them out far too often. But there are ways to stop that.
lead_paragraph: ANTIBIOTICS are an indispensable weapon in every physician’s arsenal, but when prescribed unnecessarily for nonbacterial infections like the common cold, as they too often are, they provide no benefit and create problems. They wipe out healthy bacteria and can cause side effects like yeast infections and allergic reactions. Worse still, they contribute to the rise of “superbugs” that resist antibiotic treatment.

headline: Four Museums’ Most Ephemeral Artworks: the Flowers in the Lobby
abstract: A look at the blooms that welcome visitors to Neue Galerie, the Frick Collection, the Jewish Museum and the Met.
lead_paragraph: At several New York museums, lobby flower arrangements can be as meticulously tended as the art on display. Here, the stories behind four of them.

headline: ‘Shuffle Along’ Schedule Adjusted for Illness and Tweaks
abstract: Four performances were canceled because Audra McDonald, the show’s star, was ill.
lead_paragraph: “Shuffle Along,” among the more anticipated shows of the spring season on Broadway, canceled four preview performances this week, citing the illness of its star Audra McDonald, and is taking an unusual, but long-scheduled, four-day hiatus next week to make revisions.

headline: The South Fails Again at Fair Pay
abstract: North Carolina’s new anti-LGBT bill also displays regressive thinking on the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: The state minimum wage in North Carolina is $7.25 an hour, the same as the federal minimum wage. No localities in North Carolina have their own higher minimums.  Nor is it likely that they could enact higher minimums even if they wanted to because in North Carolina, the state — not the city or county — generally calls the shots on important matters of local concern.

headline: Review: Beyond First Impressions at Bantam’s Mockingbird Kitchen
abstract: The restaurant’s chef and owner, Samantha Tilley, draws on Asian, South American and French flavors for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: A sign out front of Mockingbird Kitchen and Bar in Bantam reads “The Bantam Inn,” creating the impression that passers-by might be able to stop in for the night. Inside, on the ground floor of the two-story colonial-style house, the prominence of the bar, which anchors a dining space split between two rooms, and a menu heavy with burgers and pub-grub appetizers, suggest more of an elbows-on-the-counter sort of burger joint than fine dining.

headline: Lose With Cruz: A Love Story
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention']

lead_paragraph: IT was clear to me weeks ago, even before Marco Rubio threw in the towel, that the G.O.P. was getting ready to cuddle with Ted Cruz.

headline: Queens Man Accused of Making Over 30 False Calls to 911
abstract: Kenneth Campbell repeatedly reported fake emergencies to dispatchers during February and March, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: There was a call to 911 reporting an elderly person had fallen and suffered a head injury, and a call that a pregnant woman had gone into labor. There were calls complaining of gas leaks and the smell of smoke.

headline: Sally Field on the ‘Newest Stage’ of Her Life
abstract: The 69-year-old actress talks about fame, younger men and her new film, “Hello, My Name Is Doris.”
lead_paragraph: If Sally Field nursed a hope of dodging notice at the Whitney Museum of American Art this month, that hope was crushed when she stretched her 5-foot-3-inch frame on an outsize banquette, its cushioned surface an apparent invitation to relax.

headline: At Exhibitions in Peekskill, Art in Plain English
abstract: The Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art considers the impact of words, both the pleasant and the unpleasant kinds.
lead_paragraph: Visitors entering the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill will find themselves standing beneath a cluster of shiny silver umbrellas that seem to be tumbling in the wind. Looking up, they will notice that lines of text have been cut into each umbrella. On the wall below, as if raining from above, silver letters are arranged vertically to form words: “kindness,” “dream” and others.

headline: The Director’s Director: Chantal Akerman
abstract: The director, who died in October, was an enormous influence on many filmmakers and is the subject of a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: Has any director used the kitchen to such devastating effect as Chantal Akerman?
