abstract: Mason Wells, a 19-year-old Mormon missionary in Belgium, describes how he survived the terrorist attack at the Brussels Airport.
lead_paragraph: Mason Wells, a 19-year-old Mormon missionary in Belgium, describes how he survived the terrorist attack at the Brussels Airport.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pink!
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Orchids']
abstract: The color is a fashion statement during these first weeks of spring, most noticeably on coats.
lead_paragraph: The color is a fashion statement during these first weeks of spring, most noticeably on coats. Although the formal Easter parade (and its requisite flower-laden hats and orchid corsages) has long disappeared, fashion has rejuvenated the color for today. An interesting note is the orchid blossom: Originally the orchid was plucked from a plant and worn on Easter on its own, but in the 1920s, florists started adding ribbons, and by the late ‘30s and ‘40s, the single blossom got mucked up with pink tulle and glitter. Today, the beautiful orchid has returned to its natural state. The plants shown here at the Union Square Saturday Greenmarket are from Silva Orchids, which has been passed down through three generations of growers, who have grown many of the same plants for decades.

headline: Ted Cruz Blames Donald Trump and ‘Henchmen’ for Tabloid Report of Affairs
abstract: The Texas senator, dismissing a National Enquirer article as “garbage,” insisted that it was peddled by his campaign rival through close allies.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz on Friday accused Donald J. Trump “and his henchmen” of peddling an article in a supermarket tabloid alleging that Mr. Cruz had engaged in extramarital affairs.

headline: Wind Power Transmission Project in Plains Earns U.S. Approval
abstract: The decision signals that the Obama administration remains committed to encouraging the spread of renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: A major transmission project aimed at bringing wind energy out of the Texas and Oklahoma panhandle cleared a significant hurdle on Friday as the Energy Department announced it would allow the project to go forward.

headline: In ‘For Worse,’ an Affair Doesn’t Wreck a 30-Year Marriage
abstract: The play by Deborah Rennard, in its world premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, portrays two women in love with a scoundrel.
lead_paragraph: A husband and wife are shaken and stirred when their 30-year marriage hits the rocks of infidelity in “For Worse,” a new play presented by the New Jersey Repertory Company, which lately seems to be absorbed with the topic of marital discord.

headline: Evening Hours | The Young Fellows Ball at the Frick and More
abstract: Bill Cunningham covers events in March.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham covers events in March.

headline: Knicks Show Some Life, but Focus Is on Team’s Next Incarnation
abstract: The biggest questions facing the Knicks continue to be: What becomes of Carmelo Anthony, and who will coach this group?
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony isolates on Derrick Rose, ready to do the bump-and-shimmy that is his career-long groove. Another Chicago player drops off to help defend him, and a stork-thin Latvian cuts beyond the top of the key.

headline: In ‘The Path,’ on Hulu, Losing Faith Means Losing Love
abstract: The streaming service’s first full-fledged hourlong drama series unbraids the ties that bind.
lead_paragraph: UPPER NYACK, N.Y. — On an idyllic hilltop that slopes down to the Hudson River, about 40 minutes northwest of New York City, a rustic retreat owned by the Sisters of Our Lady of Christian Doctrine has been transformed into the Meyerist Movement compound.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Rukmini Callimachi, Damon Darlin and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: From Relationships to Murder and Mayhem
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Jack Dana, the leading character of Mr. Begley’s 2015 work, “Killer, Come Hither,” returns in a sequel, and both novels are a departure from the author’s usual fiction.
lead_paragraph: Louis Begley sat at the dining room table in his light-filled Sagaponack house, carefully comparing the text of his newest book, “Kill and Be Killed,” with the German translation on the screen of his laptop, making sure it was all correct.

headline: C.D.C. Offers Guidelines for Delaying Pregnancy After Zika Exposure
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Women who have tested positive for the virus or had symptoms should wait at least eight weeks before trying to get pregnant, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: Federal health authorities said for the first time on Friday how long couples who have been exposed to the Zika virus should wait before trying to get pregnant.

headline: Jon Bernthal: From Walking Dead to Plain Deadly
abstract: Mr. Bernthal has built a career by playing tightly wound tough guys on shows like “The Walking Dead” and “Daredevil.”
lead_paragraph: It takes almost the entire first episode of the second season of “Daredevil,” the Netflix series about the Marvel crime fighter, before a new nemesis named Frank Castle utters a single line of dialogue.

headline: In ‘Sex With Strangers,’ Reconciling Lust With Literary Values
abstract: The play by Laura Eason, at TheaterWorks in Hartford, is an examination of a modern odd-couple relationship.
lead_paragraph: It was, of course, only a matter of time, and that time has arrived: In “Sex With Strangers,” Laura Eason’s delightful two-person play at TheaterWorks in Hartford, a laptop, clunky and antiquated, has gone from being a signifier of the newest technology to a sight gag. It’s one of many sly, charming jokes in this disarmingly up-to-the-minute examination of a peculiarly modern odd-couple relationship. But Olivia and Ethan are not as odd as all that, and thanks to the appealing actors who play them under Rob Ruggiero’s unerring direction, Courtney Rackley and Patrick Ball, you just can’t help rooting for them to get together — even with all the obstacles Ms. Eason has quite deliberately put in their way.

headline: After Brussels Attacks, a Slow Process to Confirm Families’ Worst Fears
abstract: Relatives around the world were still waiting for word about missing loved ones, prolonging the agony of those already suffering.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — From his home in Tennessee, Levi Sutton has spent three days trying to figure out what happened to his half brother and sister-in-law, Justin and Stephanie Shults, who were at the Brussels international airport when the bombs went off.

headline: ‘Roberto Devereux’ at the Met, and a Soprano’s Triple Crown
abstract: In a Metropolitan Opera first, Sondra Radvanovsky completed Donizetti’s Tudor cycle, confirming her stardom.
lead_paragraph: The applause and bravos for the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky were so frenzied at the end of Donizetti’s “Roberto Devereux” at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night that she looked overwhelmed, almost a little frightened.The audience members knew, it seemed, that they had just witnessed an emotionally vulnerable and vocally daring performance, a milestone in the career of an essential artist.

headline: Edna O’Brien Is Still Gripped by Dark Moral Questions
abstract: This 85-year-old Irish writer discusses her career and her latest novel, “The Little Red Chairs,” which is her first in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One day in the late 1960s, the novelist Edna O’Brien was strolling around London with Marlon Brando, with whom she had just spent a (chaste) night. “Are you a great writer?” Brando asked.

headline: For Gonzaga Guard, Speed Bumps on the Road Back
abstract: The Bulldogs gave guard Eric McClellan a third chance, and he is paying them back in points.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As a high school senior in Austin, Tex., Eric McClellan knew very little about Gonzaga.

headline: Shakespeare, the Book Tour
abstract: A fleet of First Folios is on a barnstorming tour of all 50 states. We caught up in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: VERMILLION, S.D. — Visitors to this town of about 11,000 on a bluff near the Missouri River have long been surprised to learn that it’s home to a set of rare Stradivari stringed instruments, which are housed in a museum here along with the world’s oldest playable harpsichord, the oldest surviving cello and some 15,000 other historic instruments.

headline: Review: The Necks and Alvin Curran Play at the Whitney Museum
abstract: The Australian trio and the composer brought contrasting styles to the concert on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Necks created an hour of exquisite, constantly evolving tintinnabulation on Thursday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art, sharing a bill with a solo performance by the composer Alvin Curran. It was a rare United States appearance by this Australian trio, which has been collaborating for 30 years on music that defines a particular, meditative intersection of Minimalism, with its systematic repetition, and jazz, with its improvisatory openness. The Necks explore motion within stasis and freedom within boundaries, applying detailed, subtle virtuosity and the stamina of nonstop playing to summon a rapturous concentration.

headline: Review: ‘Bajillion Dollar Propertie$’: Flip, Flop or Flee?
abstract: This new show on the Seeso comedy streaming service spoofs reality shows that focus on real estate.
lead_paragraph: Real-estate reality shows seem to have reached some kind of parody tipping point. “They’re Watching,” a mildly amusing horror movie released on Friday, is about a reality TV crew that goes to Moldova to film an expatriate’s fixer-upper story and stumbles into the occult. But if you want to see this annoying genre lampooned especially mercilessly, the caustic new “Bajillion Dollar Propertie$,” on the Seeso streaming service, is the destination for you.

headline: Guatemala Stuns the U.S. in a Qualifier
abstract: The United States suffered a disconcerting 2-0 loss to Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier that raised more questions about where the team was headed under Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — The United States traveled here to face a fragile opponent, intent on using its two games against Guatemala in a five-day span to quickly clinch a berth in the next round of World Cup qualifying.

headline: Friday Not Music: Prologue to The Canterbury Tales
abstract: Whan that Aprill blogging.
lead_paragraph: A really springlike day, and my freshman-year poetry class came back into my head:

headline: Review: Ensemble Signal Returns to Winter With ‘Schnee’
abstract: Members of the group, conducted by Brad Lubman, performed this work as part of the Miller Theater’s Composer Portraits series.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for the start of spring, an icy blast poured from the stage at the Miller Theater on Thursday evening: “Schnee” had returned to New York.

headline: Banging Pots and Beating Dogs in a Polarized Brazil
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Money Laundering', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Politics have gotten so bad in my country that you can’t take your dog for a walk safely.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — IF you’re in Brazil these days, you shouldn’t wear red. Or grow a beard. In the current political climate, you’ll risk being tagged as a Communist and a supporter of the leftist Workers Party. You could be bullied and called mortadela (a sausage commonly regarded as a poor man’s food).

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘The Hundred We Are’ Explores Aging and Delusion
abstract: This Origin Theater production by Jonas Hassen Khemiri, at the Cell in Chelsea, follows a woman at war with herself.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of “the show must go on” stories, the New York production of the Swedish drama “The Hundred We Are” stands out for its gallantry. Jonas Hassen Khemiri’s original script, a portrait of a woman at war with her various selves, calls for a cast of three.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Brussels, Ted Cruz, Donald Trump
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Dam, Small and Unsung, Is Caught Up in an Iranian Hacking Case
abstract: The Bowman Avenue Dam in Rye Brook, N.Y., may pale next to hydroelectric power generators, but its computerized sluice-gate drew the attention of the Iranians, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — The United States has many colossal dams, hydroelectric power generators like Hoover and Grand Coulee so monumental in scale and purpose that they have been celebrated in song by Woody Guthrie and others.

headline: Thinking Big and Bigger About New York
abstract: Jim Venturi floated audacious plans to overhaul New York’s transportation hubs, and now he has more inventive plans for the region.
lead_paragraph: In November 2014, the Sunday Metropolitan section published an article about a man named Jim Venturi and his audacious plan to overhaul transit in New York. His ideas were big stuff: close Rikers Island and use the land for runways for La Guardia Airport; connect them to subways and railroads by a huge new station and convention center in the Port Morris section of the Bronx; create another transit hub and business district in Sunnyside, Queens; add a light-rail line from Red Hook up through Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn to western Queens.

headline: Najim Laachraoui, 24, Bomb Maker for Paris and Brussels Attacks
abstract: What is known about a former engineering student who blew himself up at Brussels Airport on March 22.
lead_paragraph: One of the bombers who blew himself up in Brussels this week was also the bomb maker who assembled the suicide vests for two of the terrorists who carried out the Paris attacks.

headline: Unbroken Vows
abstract: The nuns of the Franciscan Handmaids of the Most Pure Heart of Mary, based in a brick house in Harlem, make up one of only three predominantly black orders in the country.
lead_paragraph: The nuns of the Franciscan Handmaids of the Most Pure Heart of Mary, based in a brick house in Harlem, make up one of only three predominantly black orders in the country.

headline: The Nuns of Harlem
abstract: The 14 sisters of the Franciscan Handmaids of the Most Pure Heart of Mary make up one of only three predominantly black orders in the country.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes, people who do not know our life feel that we are magic people,” said Sister Precilla Takuh. “We are just normal people, like any other person, but because we have that call, we responded to it and became who we are.”

headline: How the Novelist Douglas Kennedy Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Kennedy, a self-proclaimed “jazz junkie” who splits his time living in Europe, Maine and Montreal, enjoys a workout, a play, music and one cigar.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Kennedy, a novelist from New York who is very popular in France, was back in town recently after some time away, and he took note of the things that made him feel at home. “It’s such a vocal, loud place,” he said. “Coming out of the subway the other day, I heard a cabdriver having an argument with someone, and he said, ‘Are you dumb or just stupid?’ I hear that and feel I’m home.” Mr. Kennedy, 61, spends much of the year in Europe and Maine, or commuting to Montreal, where his wife, Christine Ury, a psychoanalyst, lives and works. His home in New York is an apartment in Koreatown. His latest book, “The Blue Hour,” is a smash you know where.

headline: Deaf and Hard of Hearing Fight to Be Heard
keywords: ['Deafness', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Discrimination', 'Sign Language', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: New Yorkers are turning to the courtroom to enforce their rights, including access to sign-language interpreters.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Callis wanted to get her mother a gym membership for Christmas last year. When she called to arrange a consultation, she mentioned that her mom (who lives in Arizona) is deaf and would need a sign-language interpreter for the session. The health club said it would not provide a signer. Ms. Callis — who became an Internet sensation during Hurricane Sandy as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s exuberant sign-language interpreter — told the club that it was actually required by law to do so. Still it refused, and Ms. Callis, who was calling from Manhattan, gave up.

headline: The Mayor Does the Town, His Way
abstract: In his two years in office, Bill de Blasio has been a somewhat reluctant bon vivant. But does a city where tourism is booming need a cheerleader in chief?
lead_paragraph: Yes, he has seen “Hamilton.”

headline: Peter Brown, Star in TV Westerns and Soap Opera, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Brown acted in “Lawman” and “Laredo” and later played a doctor in the daytime drama “Days of Our Lives.”
lead_paragraph: Peter Brown, who had starring roles in two television westerns in the 1950s and ’60s and later acted in soap operas, died on Monday in Phoenix. He was 80.

headline: Martyrs With Guns and the Easter Rising
abstract: In Ireland’s uprising, I saw romance. Now political violence makes me feel only remorse.
lead_paragraph: HE was very old, in his 90s, but looking sturdy, like the truck driver he once was. He was a distant cousin by marriage, on the branch of the family that had stayed in Ireland. When I visited him there last summer, in a nursing home in Kilrush, County Clare, I was not sure he knew who I was, but we connected over an old rebel song we both remembered.

headline: Democrats See Gains as Donald Trump Targets a Wife
abstract: Donald Trump’s nasty skirmish with Ted Cruz about Mr. Cruz’s wife, Heidi, has played into a Democratic strategy to defeat Mr. Trump in November: to portray him as an unabashed sexist.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz may have urged Donald J. Trump to leave his wife, Heidi, “the hell alone,” but there is one group that is quietly hoping Mr. Trump’s attacks on his rival’s spouse and other women will continue indefinitely: Democrats.

headline: Israel Begins Murder Investigation of Soldier Who Shot Palestinian
abstract: Video emerged showing a soldier shooting an assailant in the head as he lay on the road near a Jewish settlement in the West Bank city of Hebron.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said on Friday that a soldier who shot a Palestinian assailant in the head as he lay motionless on the ground was being investigated on suspicion of murder. The announcement was highly unusual and underscored the seriousness of the case, which was filmed and quickly spread over social media.

headline: Backlash as Senator Breaks Ranks on Supreme Court Hearings
abstract: Senator Jerry Moran, Republican of Kansas, could face a primary challenge over support of nomination hearings for Judge Merrick B. Garland.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Jerry Moran, Republican of Kansas, faced a barrage of criticism from conservative groups on Friday after he broke with his party’s leadership by saying he favored holding hearings on President Obama’s nominee for the Supreme Court.

headline: A Revived Challenge to Islam as Bangladesh’s State Religion Goes to Court
abstract: Amid rising concerns about extremism, a 28-year-old petition supporting secularism has been revived, and the country’s Supreme Court is to hear the challenge on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — It came as a surprise to Serajul Islam Choudhury, a retired English professor, to learn that his petition to drop Islam as Bangladesh’s state religion would finally be heard in court on Sunday.

headline: Wrong Man Convicted of 1957 Murder in Illinois, Prosecutor Says
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The defendant, an ex-police officer, is seeking to have his conviction overturned in the case of a 7-year-old girl who was kidnapped and strangled.
lead_paragraph: It was hailed as a victory for the persistence of justice. Some five and a half decades after a 7-year-old girl was kidnapped, strangled and stabbed in rural northern Illinois, Jack McCullough, a military veteran and former police officer, was convicted of the killing in 2012 in what was believed to be one of the oldest American cold cases to result in an arrest.

headline: Earl Hamner Jr., Who Created ‘The Waltons,’ Dies at 92
abstract: Also a novelist, Mr. Hamner wrote episodes of “The Twilight Zone” before CBS picked up the series about a mountain family that was based on his own.
lead_paragraph: Earl Hamner Jr., who drew on warm memories of his Depression childhood in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia to create the enormously popular 1970s television series “The Waltons,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 92.

headline: Robert De Niro Defends Screening of Anti-Vaccine Film at Tribeca Festival
keywords: ['Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)', 'Movies', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Autism', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The decision to screen the movie, which was directed by a former doctor whose medical license was revoked, has reignited a debate about autism and vaccines.
lead_paragraph: In a decision that has dredged up the widely debunked link between vaccines and autism, the Tribeca Film Festival plans to screen a film by a discredited former doctor whose research caused widespread alarm about the issue.

headline: Exemptions May Color Deal to Lift New York State’s Minimum Wage
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers in Albany could soon announce an agreement to raise hourly pay to $15, but that minimum might not apply statewide.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Over the last several years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has repeatedly invoked a mantra of New York as “one state,” a place where all people, upstate and downstate, are treated equally.

headline: In Ruben Tejada’s Presence, Curse on Mets Continues
abstract: The Mets released Tejada, once their shortstop of the future, and in the week after he signed with the Cardinals are winless in eight games.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Ruben Tejada ranged over to field a high-bouncing ground ball, but he took his eye off the ball for an instant, and it bounced around his glove. Rather than boo, some Mets fans at Tradition Field chuckled.

headline: Florida Governor Signs Law to Cut Funding for Abortion Clinics
abstract: The law appeared to be aimed at Planned Parenthood, which said on Friday that it could mean the end of birth control, cancer screenings, STD tests and other services
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida signed a law on Friday that cut state funding to clinics that perform abortions.

headline: Long Denied Pensions, Pioneers of the Women’s Game Are Seeing Reasons for Hope
abstract: When the Women’s Tennis Association created its pension in 1991, athletes who retired before then were left out. Now, former players want to rectify that.
lead_paragraph: At the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., before the debate over equal prize money in tennis was renewed and the tournament director resigned over disparaging comments about the women’s game, a behind-the-scenes meeting took place that aimed to close another gap in compensation for female players.

headline: A Mysterious Killing on the Upper East Side Unsettles Residents
abstract: Christopher Cooley, 78, was found dead in his apartment with a necktie around his neck and a pillow over his head. On Friday, the city’s chief medical examiner declared the death a homicide.
lead_paragraph: While Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson filmed their 94th episode of “Elementary,” the CBS detective series, on the Upper East Side in Manhattan on Friday, a real-life homicide mystery took a new turn just one block away.

headline: Poor Outing Puts Ivan Nova in Bind With Yankees
abstract: Nova gave up six runs (five earned), struck out five, issued two walks and was called for a balk.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Ivan Nova walked off the mound Friday, a lonely trudge toward the dugout after an exasperating four and two-thirds innings that might have lost him the last spot in the Yankees’ starting rotation to C. C. Sabathia.

headline: Roger Federer, Citing Illness, Withdraws From Miami Open
abstract: Roger Federer’s comeback from knee surgery will have to wait until the Monte Carlo Masters next month.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer’s comeback from knee surgery will have to wait until the Monte Carlo Masters in two weeks. Federer, the former world No. 1, withdrew Friday from the Miami Open in Key Biscayne, Fla., because of a stomach virus.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I just wanted animals to do what they do. It’s very poetic, and unpredictable. You never know what they’re doing next.”

headline: Belgium Fears Nuclear Plants Are Vulnerable
abstract: Belgian authorities fear that Islamic State militants may try to attack, infiltrate or sabotage nuclear plants or obtain nuclear or radioactive material.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As a dragnet aimed at Islamic State operatives spiraled across Brussels and into at least five European countries on Friday, the authorities were also focusing on a narrower but increasingly alarming threat: the vulnerability of Belgium’s nuclear installations.

headline: Guatemalan Soccer Scandals Drain Fans’ Interest in Game
abstract: The corruption scandal that has rocked FIFA has hit soccer in the Americas especially hard, and perhaps nowhere are the problems as endemic as Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Consider what representing the Guatemalan national soccer team entails at the moment. Three former top officials of the country’s soccer federation are under indictment in the United States, including one who FIFA is claiming defrauded it of several million dollars. The reigning Guatemalan champion, Antigua, has eight players facing suspension for failed drug tests; the players blame supplements that they say were provided by the club’s owner. Another league owner, also recently the interim president of the soccer federation, is the brother of an accused drug kingpin who is in jail in the United States.

headline: Trump, Cruz, Kasich and the Ladies
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION']
abstract: One thing these guys have in common is a desire to put themselves in charge of the reproductive rights of the women of America.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk about the Republican presidential candidates … and women.

headline: Obama: The Anti-Anti-Nuke President
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Uranium', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Is he undercutting his own nonproliferation agenda?
lead_paragraph: NEXT week President Obama will welcome world leaders to Washington for his fourth Nuclear Security Summit, a biennial event he initiated to mobilize global action to prevent terrorists from acquiring atomic bombs.

headline: Clusters of Mountains
abstract: In which we help cheer up Damon Gulczynski.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you’re a visual person, you might take a look at the empty crossword grid before you solve and notice the pattern of black and white squares. I always wonder why constructors choose the patterns they do. Sometimes it plays into a puzzle theme, sometimes it doesn’t.

headline: Robert Ebeling, Challenger Engineer Who Warned of Disaster, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Ebeling, who lobbied alongside his colleagues for the postponement of the shuttle’s launch, carried the burden of the disaster throughout his life.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, Bob Ebeling drove to the headquarters of the aerospace contractor Morton Thiokol in Brigham City, Utah, to watch the launch of the space shuttle Challenger. On the way, he leaned over to his daughter Leslie and said: “The Challenger is going to blow up. Everyone’s going to die.”

headline: Santiago Erevia, Once Denied Medal of Honor Over Ethnicity, Dies at 69
abstract: After a Pentagon investigation, Mr. Erevia, a Vietnam veteran, was eventually bestowed the nation’s highest award for valor by President Obama in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Santiago Erevia, a Vietnam War veteran and retired mail carrier who had been denied the nation’s highest military honor for 45 years because he was Hispanic, died on Tuesday in San Antonio. He was 69.

headline: The N.C.A.A.’s Women Problem
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'College Athletics', 'Women and Girls', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: It is sending signals that men’s sporting events are more important.
lead_paragraph: Northampton, Mass. — AS they enter the third round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament this weekend, the University of Connecticut Huskies have won 71 consecutive games. Seventy-one! And they won national championships in 1995, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014 and 2015 — that’s 10 times in the last 21 years, and nine times in the last 15. Now, that’s major news. Only it isn’t … because this is the UConn women’s team.

headline: Time to Rethink U.S. Relationship With Egypt
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Washington should examine its assumptions about the repressive government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
lead_paragraph: Since the Egyptian military took power in a coup in the summer of 2013, the Obama administration’s policy toward Egypt has been moored in a series of faulty assumptions. The time has come to challenge them and to reassess whether an alliance that has long been considered a cornerstone of American national security policy is doing more harm than good.

headline: At N.C.A.A. Tournament, One Motto Fits Many Teams
keywords: ['Uniforms', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'Basketball (College)', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'T-Shirts (Apparel)', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Basketball teams facing off at the N.C.A.A. tournament may sometimes have the same corporate sponsor, such as Nike or Adidas, which would most likely prefer to have one slogan fit all.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The members of the Oklahoma men’s basketball team have a motto, “Play for each other.” The Sooners took the saying to heart in their round-of-16 victory over Texas A&M on Thursday, producing their most concerted effort of the season. But the Oklahoma players will not have “Play for each other” emblazoned across their chests Saturday when they take the court against the Oregon Ducks in the West Regional final.

headline: Holding On to New Voters in November
abstract: Turnout for the primaries has been high. But the parties shouldn’t take that enthusiasm for granted come November.
lead_paragraph: The nation has reached the halfway mark in the 2016 presidential primaries. It’s difficult to draw big conclusions from the small slice of Americans who vote in primaries, but turnout among Democratic voters has been  less enthusiastic than among Republicans, with roughly five million more votes cast in Republican primaries than in Democratic ones. That suggests Democrats will need to do more to motivate their constituencies to vote in November.

headline: Andy Grove’s Warning to Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: A 2010 essay urges “job-centric” economics and politics, involving an all-out commitment to American manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: The praise this week for Andy Grove, who died on Monday at age 79, has been wrapped up in praise for Silicon Valley, where he was a towering figure in the semiconductor revolution and the longtime leader of Intel, the world’s biggest supplier of microprocessors.

headline: Pentagon Chief Used Personal Email After White House Query
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ashton B. Carter continued to use a personal account for government work at least four months after the White House questioned the Pentagon about why he was using it, the released emails show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter continued to use a personal email account for government work for at least four months last year after the White House questioned the Pentagon about why he was using it, according to copies of Mr. Carter’s emails released by the Defense Department on Friday.

headline: A Mess Left by Occupiers at the Malheur Wildlife Refuge in Oregon
abstract: Photos posted by the federal agency that oversees the refuge showed an open latrine, broken electronics and clusters of trash.
lead_paragraph: At first, it can be unclear what you are seeing. The photographs on the federal Fish and Wildlife Service’s Flickr page resemble, by turns, a trashed office, a seriously disorganized farm, possibly an abandoned construction site or an especially messy recreation room in someone’s home.

headline: With ‘I-95 Edge,’ Irish Show Badgers the Exit
abstract: Notre Dame, whose roster includes players from the mid-Atlantic corridor by design, survived a frenzied final minute to edge Wisconsin and reach the round of 8.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A peculiar smell greeted the Notre Dame basketball team Thursday when it got off its bus. The scent, an industrial bouquet of exhaust and grime, offended the noses of players hailing from the Midwest and farther afield. To which guard Matt Farrell, a proud New Jersey native, retorted: “We’re right by the interstate. Get used to it.”

headline: Headed to U.S. for a Belated Celebration, Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann and her husband were traveling to New York City for their first anniversary. She died in the attack, and he is in a coma.
lead_paragraph: After almost a year, Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann and her husband were overdue for a honeymoon.

headline: Even With the Crowd Behind It, Iowa State Trails From Start to Finish
abstract: United Center in Chicago was overrun with fans in the red and gold colors of Iowa State, but Virginia cruised to a victory over the Cyclones.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A typical road game in the Atlantic Coast Conference can build a steely resilience for teams that regularly travel that circuit. A good squad must weather raucous arenas in places like Durham and Chapel Hill, in North Carolina, in order to prosper. Virginia has certainly done that.

headline: Teenager Shot in Head Outside Harlem Housing Project, Police Say
abstract: The man, 17, was in critical condition on Friday night, the police said, and no physical description of a suspect was available.
lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old boy was in critical condition on Friday night after he was shot in the head outside a Harlem housing project, the police said.

headline: Geneseo Falls to Wisconsin-Stevens Point in Semifinals
abstract: The State University of New York at Geneseo’s pursuit of its first N.C.A.A. Division III title came to a halt with a 5-1 drubbing by Wisconsin-Stevens Point in the semifinals in Lake Placid, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The State University of New York at Geneseo’s pursuit of its first N.C.A.A. Division III title came to a halt with a 5-1 drubbing by Wisconsin-Stevens Point in the semifinals in Lake Placid, N.Y. Stevens Point, ranked No. 3 in the West, will play St. Norbert in Saturday’s championship game.

headline: North Carolina Prevails Over Indiana With History in the Air
abstract: The Tar Heels and the Hoosiers, two storied programs, resumed their acquaintance in Philadelphia, and North Carolina’s hot shooting led to a blowout.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It might well be the most fearsome college basketball team in the country, but in the vulnerable moments before tipoff, North Carolina relies on a routine of flying elbows and gyroscopic hips.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: ABC presents the old-Hollywood epic “The Ten Commandments,” and Medici.tv live-streams Bach’s timeless “St. Matthew Passion” oratorio.
lead_paragraph: It’s Easter weekend, and broadcasters have planned accordingly. On ABC the old-Hollywood epic “The Ten Commandments” tells the story of Moses and the parting of the Red Sea, which figures in Easter Vigil services. And Medici.tv live-streams Bach’s timeless “St. Matthew Passion” oratorio.

headline: Corrections: March 26, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 26, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Big Boasts Against Huskies Lead to Hard Falls Before Them
abstract: When teams publicly challenge Connecticut before a game, it serves to motivate the undefeated Huskies.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Before Duquesne’s round-of-32 game against Connecticut in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, the Dukes bluntly said they would not be distracted by the illustrious UConn aura. They believed that the Huskies, then 33-0 and winners of 70 games in a row, were in fact beatable.

headline: ‘I Miss the Innocence of a Pre-9/11 World’: Our Top 10 Comments
abstract: Readers react to the attacks in Belgium, President Obama’s visit to Cuba, Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: The Tinder Dating Pool Isn’t Completely Shallow
abstract: Some people view the website as a place to find one-night stands, but some of its users have found spouses.
lead_paragraph: Shana Claudio left the bar on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for her third Tinder date of the day. She had already met a finance type for brunch that Sunday in October 2013 through the dating app (he was a bit superficial), and she found the second guy, whom she met for a drink, forgettable.

headline: Humans of New York Founder Takes On Donald Trump
abstract: A critical open letter to the presidential candidate became one of the most-shared posts ever on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Stanton, the nimble shutterbug behind the immensely popular photo blog Humans of New York, has worked hard to filter politics and moral judgments out of his posts, intent on maintaining objectivity as he captures his subjects in words and on film, letting them speak for themselves.

headline: Holdouts of the Social Media Age
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Though most people under 50 are online, a few choose to remain elusive on Twitter and such, trying to preserve their privacy, sanity — and noteworthiness.
lead_paragraph: When Ottessa Moshfegh published her debut novel, “Eileen,” last August, she did so without an online publicity apparatus.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Brussels to Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Brussels to Cuba.

headline: The N.R.A. Reimagines Classic Fairy Tales, With Guns
abstract: The group has published a different take on the Grimm brothers’ stories, which now feature the protagonists, such as Little Red Riding Hood, with weapons. Advocates of gun control express concern.
lead_paragraph: The world of make-believe can be a scary place, but never fear: Thanks to a series of reimagined fairy tales published online by the National Rifle Association, classic characters like Hansel and Gretel are now packing heat.

headline: North Korean Propaganda Video Depicts Nuclear Strike on Washington
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Propaganda', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The video uploaded Saturday includes a warning to “American imperialists” not to provoke the North.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea released a propaganda video on Saturday that depicts a nuclear strike on Washington, along with a warning to “American imperialists” not to provoke the North.

headline: 1916: Rebels Rise Up in Dublin
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Irish nationalists seized locations in the city during Easter in 1916.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, a group of Irish nationalists in Dublin took up arms against British rule and proclaimed the establishment of an Irish republic.

headline: Fighting a Cage Match to Turn UFC Into a National Phenomenon
abstract: Two brothers have worked to bring what some critics have derided as “human cage fighting” into the lucrative mainstream of spectator sports.
lead_paragraph: It has been a while since Frank and Lorenzo Fertitta tried to choke each other into submission. The brothers took private jujitsu lessons in the early 2000s, and at the end of each they were given the chance to try new moves in a dojo in Las Vegas. But you reach a certain age (Frank is now 54, Lorenzo is 47) and turn up in Forbes (which estimates each brother is worth $1.6 billion), and brawling starts to seem like a bad idea.

headline: Schools Nationwide Still Grapple With Lead in Water
abstract: The Flint, Mich., crisis has cast attention on the issue, but in schools from Jersey City, N.J., to Los Angeles, problems have dragged on for years.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Anxious parents may wonder how a major school system like Newark’s could overlook lead in the drinking water of 30 schools and 17,000 students. The answer: It was easy. They had to look only a few miles away, at the century-old classrooms of the schools here, across the Hackensack River.

headline: Digging Further Into a Water Problem
abstract: Three reporters offer perspective on water safety in public schools. Bottled water and agitating for local action are among their suggestions.
lead_paragraph: While the water crisis in Flint, Mich., has focused attention on water safety, many of the country’s 13,500 public school districts take the purity of their water for granted, experts say. Yet lead contamination has been found in schools nationwide.

headline: Forget the New iPhone. For Apple, It’s All About the Dollar.
abstract: When the dollar strengthens, sales of iPhones abroad are worth less in American currency, hurting profits and knocking down share prices.
lead_paragraph: Don’t obsess about the svelte new iPhone or the price cut for the Apple Watch.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: Discuss the “Little Variety” puzzles here.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad and Mike on How Apple’s New, Smaller iPhone Is Easing the Pain
abstract: The battle between Apple and the F.B.I. fizzled a bit last week, but the company’s return to a scaled-down, cheaper smartphone is something worth discussing.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: New Brussels Attack Suspect Is Charged, Prosecutors Say
abstract: A man identified in the Belgian press as Fayçal Cheffou has been accused of terrorist murders. The authorities say he was deeply involved in the plot.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Federal prosecutors in Belgium announced Saturday that they had arrested a suspect believed to have been deeply involved in the Brussels plot. He was charged with participating in a terrorist group, in terrorist murders and in attempted terrorist murders.

headline: When Mouse-Proofing Fails
abstract: Dealing with a co-op’s vermin problem; making peace with a super; and improving ventilation.
lead_paragraph: My co-op apartment has recently experienced an onslaught of mice. Since my building provides only a perfunctory monthly exterminator visit, I hired my own pest-control expert to “mouse-proof” the apartment, as well as an exterminator. Still, the mice find new entry points. They must be living in the building’s walls, so wouldn’t this be the building’s problem, too? Can I demand that the co-op board deal with this?

headline: Forgotten Victims of Terror
abstract: Before Brussels, a wave of terror attacks whipped through Turkey, the Ivory Coast, Yemen and elsewhere. But these events appeared to garner less international attention. We went there, and asked why.
lead_paragraph: Before Brussels, a wave of terror attacks whipped through Turkey, the Ivory Coast, Yemen and elsewhere. But these events appeared to garner less international attention. We went there, and asked why.

headline: Possible Pilot Error Is Cited in FlyDubai Crash in Russia
abstract: The pilots turned off autopilot, Russian state television said, but may have accidentally turned on a stabilizing fin, leading to a loss of control.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — An error by a crew member committed during adverse weather conditions may have been responsible for the crash of a passenger jet last week in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don that killed 62 people, a report broadcast by Russian state television said.

headline: A Ski Town Greenhouse Takes Local Produce to Another Level
abstract: Vertical Harvest, a multilevel hydroponic greenhouse in downtown Jackson, Wyo., is bringing year-round fresh vegetables to a place better known for its snow.
lead_paragraph: The Wyoming soil, iced over for eight months of the year, is not particularly hospitable to heirloom tomatoes, baby basil or lettuce plants. Instead, vegetables are trucked in from California, Mexico and other more fecund parts of the world. Yet starting this spring, Vertical Harvest, a farm in the resort town of Jackson, will begin churning out a projected 100,000 pounds of fresh produce a year.

headline: Variety: Vowel Play
abstract: John M. Suarez and Will Shortz offer us a new Variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Every once in a while, Will Shortz likes to throw us a curve ball, just to see if we’re paying attention. Week after week, we solve our acrostics and our PandAs and our Split Decisions without thinking much about it, so Mr. Shortz will occasionally change things up by running a totally different kind of puzzle.

headline: The National Museum of African American History and Culture Prepares to Open
abstract: This Smithsonian museum, conceived in 2003, is readying itself for a September debut in Washington.
lead_paragraph: This Smithsonian museum, conceived in 2003, is readying itself for a September debut in Washington.

headline: The Scourge of Taxi TV, and a Tacky Move by HP
abstract: Taxi TV cannot disappear quickly enough. And HP tries to pitch an extended warranty to a customer who called to complain about a defective printer.
lead_paragraph: Before our episode begins, a brief word about Taxi TV, which longtime readers may recall is deeply reviled by the Haggler. Until recently, when you turned off these wretched mobile screens, they would actually go dark. No longer. Now, the off switch doesn’t work. Or rather, it works, but when you hit it, the screen simply toggles between a home page and an advertisement.

headline: A Hard-Driving Executive’s Year of Learning to Let Go
abstract: Karan Bajaj returned to India to study yoga and simplify his life, and he returned to work with a newfound willingness to take risks on new ideas.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Indian Himalayas, I saw a steady stream of professionals — doctors, engineers, lawyers — leave their careers and live in ashrams and caves near my village. I never fully understood their motives. But 20 years later, I had the same strong urge to spend an extended time in silence and find a deep center of stillness within me after my mother’s untimely death from cancer.

headline: Putting Virtual Reality to Work at the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: Loren Hammonds, an associate programmer for the festival, helps select the event’s feature-length films and multimedia virtual reality projects.
lead_paragraph: Loren Hammonds, 39, is an associate programmer for the Tribeca Film Festival in New York.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Findings on Concussions Won’t Change the N.F.L.’s Behavior

headline: In Brussels Bombing Plot, a Trail of Dots Not Connected
abstract: Only on the morning of the attacks did chemical odors and other strange hints come together to form a clear picture of what had been happening at the apartment used as a bomb-making workshop.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The stench of chemicals emanating from the sixth-floor apartment made the owner of the building gag. Other odd happenings at the mostly empty housing block in northern Brussels prompted an anxious resident in the area to alert the police. A taxi driver who picked up three young men at the block smelled a noxious odor leaking from their curiously heavy luggage as he drove them to Brussels Airport.

headline: In Donald Trump’s Worldview, America Comes First, and Everybody Else Pays
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a 100-minute interview, Mr. Trump said he might halt purchases of oil from Arab allies like Saudi Arabia unless they commit greater resources to fighting the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential front-runner, said that if elected, he might halt purchases of oil from Saudi Arabia and other Arab allies unless they commit ground troops to the fight against the Islamic State or “substantially reimburse” the United States for combating the militant group, which threatens their stability.

headline: A Case of Deadly Delusions
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Radovan Karadzic’s casual embrace of killing, and his denial about it, set him apart among the most brutal of leaders.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — To the last, there was no contrition, no plea for forgiveness, no scintilla of regret for the 100,000 lives lost and tens of thousands of families crushed in the blood bath in Bosnia that his obsessions unleashed nearly a quarter of a century ago.

headline: Transcript: Donald Trump Expounds on His Foreign Policy Views
abstract: An edited transcript of a telephone interview with the Republican presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Over two telephone conversations on Friday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, discussed his views on foreign policy with Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger of The New York Times. Here is an edited transcript of their interview (or just the highlights).

headline: Highlights From Our Interview With Donald Trump on Foreign Policy
abstract: The presidential candidate on spying on allies, the possibility of a nuclear-armed Japan and his “America First” view of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Over two telephone conversations on Friday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, discussed his views on foreign policy with Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger of The New York Times. Here are some excerpts we highlighted (and an edited transcript).

headline: In Everybody’s Corner, a Boxing Gym for All
abstract: The Toronto Newsgirls Boxing Club was not built specifically for transgender people, but all are welcome.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — From the doorway of the Newsgirls Boxing Club, all the trappings of a standard boxing gym are in view. The full-size ring is to the immediate right, its red, white and blue ropes and black mat at once festive and menacing.

headline: Bernie Sanders Seizes 3 States, Sweeping Democratic Contests
abstract: Mr. Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in Washington, Alaska and Hawaii, which held nominating contests on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders routed Hillary Clinton in all three Democratic presidential contests on Saturday, infusing his underdog campaign with critical momentum and bolstering his argument that the race for the nomination is not a foregone conclusion.

headline: Me and My Doppelgänger
abstract: When two people in rather public professions have the same name, things can get confusing.
lead_paragraph: TAKE a glance at who wrote this article and you’ll understand the problem. Who’s who?

headline: Opioid Use and Abuse
abstract: Patients and doctors discuss the management of these drugs.
lead_paragraph: Patients and doctors discuss the management of drugs that can be helpful or harmful.

headline: Christopher Catrambone
abstract: An insurance magnate and philanthropist on life at sea, resisting temptation, shocking drone footage and practical jokes.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Catrambone is an insurance magnate with who has used his personal wealth to found the Migrant Offshore Aid Station, or MOAS, which rescues migrants and refugees adrift in the Mediterranean, Aegean and Andaman Seas.

headline: Obama’s Last Tango
abstract: Barack Obama leaves the stage as he began, dramatically alone and absolutely sure of himself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — BARACK OBAMA is tangoing into history, and there’s something perfect about that.

headline: Who Is Ted Cruz?
abstract: How a determined nerd ended up as Donald Trump’s last rival.
lead_paragraph: ENOUGH, for one week at least, about the strange victories of Donald Trump. Let’s talk about the mysteries of his last real competitor, Ted Cruz.

headline: Please Cancel Your Vacation to North Korea
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Americans don’t get dictatorships. They don’t know to be afraid.
lead_paragraph: NORTH KOREA recently sentenced Otto Warmbier, an American college student and tourist, to 15 years of hard labor. Not surprisingly in the surveillance state to end all surveillance states, there are security camera images of Mr. Warmbier trying to steal a propaganda sign from an off-limits area of the hotel. In photographs from the trial, he seemed utterly shocked that he was being prosecuted.

headline: The Future for Flint’s Children
abstract: Thousands drank lead-contaminated water and will require long-term medical and educational help.
lead_paragraph: Flint, Mich. — THE World Health Organization’s “action level” for lead contamination in drinking water — indicating the need for intervention — is 10 parts per billion. The Environmental Protection Agency’s action level is 15 parts per billion.

headline: Who Has the Candidate’s Ear?
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: As the lists of advisers are revealed, some names jump off the page. Elliott Abrams? Carl Icahn?
lead_paragraph: What does a presidential candidate’s choice of advisers tell us about the candidate?

headline: Wall Street’s Retreat From King Coal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Natural Gas', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal']
abstract: Coal-state politicians who won’t listen to environmental arguments should take a look at where the big money is headed.
lead_paragraph: The grave environmental damage from coal-fired power plants has done nothing to deter the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, from decrying a “war on coal” and orchestrating his own war against the Obama administration’s climate change agenda. But he and other coal-state Republicans would be foolish to ignore the growing consensus on Wall Street that King Coal, for all its legendary political power, has turned into a decidedly bad investment.

headline: My Mother’s Garden
keywords: ['Welfare (US)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Poverty', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Education (K-12)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We were one of the few black families in the housing project. A small plot of green made it feel more, and less, like home.
lead_paragraph: IT was my first year as a scholarship student at a school that prized itself on teaching the skill of dispassionate debate. I quickly learned that the best thing you could bring to an argument was “objectivity.”

headline: Protecting Employees’ Health Data
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Privacy', 'Discrimination', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: As analysis techniques evolve, Americans need federal protections to make sure the information isn’t used to discriminate against them.
lead_paragraph: Does your back hurt? Do you have diabetes? Are you taking birth control pills?

headline: My Shared Shame: The Media Helped Make Trump
abstract: We journalists failed the public by letting ourselves get played by Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: THOSE of us in the news media have sometimes blamed Donald Trump’s rise on the Republican Party’s toxic manipulation of racial resentments over the years. But we should also acknowledge another force that empowered Trump: Us.

headline: Don’t Grade Schools on Grit
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tests and Examinations', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The scientist behind character assessment says this is not what she meant.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia — THE Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once observed, “Intelligence plus character — that is the goal of true education.”

headline: Naked Lady Politics
abstract: A Trump versus Cruz fight over their wives makes one thing clear: Women are objects to them, not people.
lead_paragraph: Since they were old enough to understand words, I’ve been trying to teach my daughters the nature of permanence, as it relates to the World Wide Web. The Internet is forever, I tell them; the public is brutal, and they need to keep their clothes on whenever a camera-equipped device is around. Those spring break pictures on Facebook will be the first thing the Senate Judiciary Committee sees when it’s deciding whether to approve their nomination.

headline: Donald Trump’s Secret Weapon: Blue-State Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: He is showing surprising strength among blue-state Republicans.
lead_paragraph: THE Republican establishment typically has a dependable ally in the primaries: the blue-state Republicans. They’re relatively affluent, well educated, moderate and secular, which usually makes them a natural partner to offset the more populist, religious and conservative outsider candidates who often rally the party’s Southern base.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Few Questions About the Specials
abstract: I have some dietary restrictions I need to tell you about.
lead_paragraph: WOW, everything sounds delicious. I just have a few questions about the specials, even though you described them in great detail. I have several dietary restrictions I need to bring up. Don’t worry, they’re entirely self-enforced and in no way ordered by a medical professional. If my boyfriend were here, he’d back me up.

headline: God Is a Question, Not an Answer
abstract: How can atheists and believers stop acting like enemy combatants in a spiritual or intellectual war?
lead_paragraph: Near end of Albert Camus’s existentialist novel “The Stranger,” Meursault, the protagonist, is visited by a priest who offers him comfort in the face of his impending execution. Meursault, who has not cared about anything up to this point, wants none of it. He is an atheist in a foxhole. He certainly has not been a strident atheist, but he claims to have no time for the priest and his talk of God. For him, God is not the answer.

headline: Loved and Loathed, a ‘Cynical Optimist’ Keeps Up the Fight
abstract: Richard W. Pound, who was chairman of the commission that delivered a damning report on Russia’s doping problems, is still charging hard at big issues.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Pound never won an Olympic medal, and he finished a distant third in his only campaign for president of the International Olympic Committee.

headline: André Adam, Retired Diplomat and Brussels Victim
abstract: A foreign service career that included posts with the United Nations and in the United States, Africa, Europe and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — André Adam, then Belgium’s ambassador to the United Nations, displayed some of what his family called characteristic good cheer at a Belgian festival in New York in 2000.

headline: University of California Adopts Statement Condemning Anti-Semitism
abstract: The measure was an attempt to combat hostility toward Jewish students amid growing opposition on campuses to Israeli policies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the University of California’s Board of Regents unanimously adopted a statement condemning anti-Semitism on its campuses, it became the first public university system to do so since the push for economic boycotts of Israel emerged on campuses across the nation.

headline: Yankees Pare a Crowd Behind the Plate
abstract: Austin Romine, Gary Sanchez and Carlos Corporan have been competing to be catcher Brian McCann’s backup, but Sanchez was demoted last week .
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Early last week, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked about the three-way fight to be catcher Brian McCann’s backup.

headline: How Do You Tell the Story of Black America in One Museum?
abstract: The National Museum of African American History and Culture, opening in Washington in September, had some delicate decisions to make about slavery, Bill Cosby and President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the National Museum of African American History and Culture was conceived in 2003, Barack Obama was a state senator in Illinois; the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the death of Trayvon Martin was years in the future; and Bill Cosby was a symbol of family decency.

headline: Frank Deng, ‘Spirited’ Chinese Entrepreneur and Brussels Victim
abstract: Deng Jingquan, also known as Frank Deng, had founded in Internet start-up not long after finishing college.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Deng Jingquan, also known as Frank Deng, was a young Chinese entrepreneur and frequent traveler who, just a couple of years after finishing his studies, founded his own technology company.

headline: Fast Start by Guatemala Keeps United States Off Balance
abstract: The second goal by Guatemala encapsulated the current state of the United States, which has often looked inattentive and uninspired.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — When Guatemala goalkeeper Paulo Motta sent an unusually low, darting goal kick searing down the middle of the field, midfielder Michael Bradley tracked the ball, preparing to put his head to it. But at the last instant, Bradley flinched and pulled back.

headline: For Notre Dame’s Star Guard, Family Came First
abstract: Demetrius Jackson found the stable home life he craved when he moved in with his best friend’s family.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — There was a time when Demetrius Jackson, Notre Dame’s star point guard, played basketball just to forget his sadness.

headline: Migrants in Greece, Ready to Go Anywhere in Europe, Scramble to Enter E.U. Relocation Program
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)']
abstract: Once Germany-bound, many refugees stranded in Greece are hoping the program will come through for them as European security tightens after the Brussels attacks.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Under the glare of a naked light bulb, in the tiny one-room apartment where he has taken shelter with three other young Syrian refugees, Ismail Haki clutched the folded white card on which he has pinned all his hopes.

headline: Warriors Will Rest, but Not Until the Playoffs
abstract: Coach Steve Kerr says his young players like Stephen Curry, Draymond Green and Klay Thompson wouldn’t want to sit games out as San Antonio’s older veterans sometimes do.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Just a week ago, concern for Stephen Curry’s welfare among the general Bay Area populace swelled in the wake of two substandard performances. Against the San Antonio Spurs and the Minnesota Timberwolves, Curry shot 10 of 35 from the field and 3 of 21 from 3-point range. The basketball gods appeared to be asleep at the wheel.

headline: George Lucas’s Museum Plan Inspires ‘Clout Politics’ in Chicago
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Land Use Policies', 'Museums']
abstract: A lakefront museum proposed by Mr. Lucas has turned a faded parking lot of crumbling asphalt into one of the most fiercely contested pieces of land in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel has been publicly subdued in recent months, his caustic temperament largely under wraps as Chicago struggles through problems on all sides: a crime wave, financial troubles, public distrust and a struggle over civil rights.

headline: Pitch Imperfect
abstract: Another reason to admire Patrick Blindauer’s mind.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I love a Patrick Blindauer Sunday puzzle, don’t you? His mind goes to places that are just fascinating to me, and today’s puzzle is no different, as long as you like two things: ad pitches and anagrams.

headline: A Dual Citizen of Belgium and Italy, With a Cosmopolitan Spirit
abstract: Patricia Rizzo, killed in the Brussels attacks, was at home in both countries, and an independent streak motivated her to move back and forth between the two.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Rizzo, a dual citizen of Belgium and Italy, embodied the cosmopolitan spirit of thousands of Brussels-based residents from across the European Union’s 28 member states, who effortlessly navigate language and borders.

headline: U.S. Accountants Who Found Adventure in Europe Among Brussels Victims
abstract: Officials on Saturday confirmed the deaths of Justin and Stephanie Shults, a couple who had settled in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: Justin and Stephanie Shults, a couple from the American heartland found adventure in the heart of Europe.

headline: North Koreans Rely on Smuggled Cellphones to Connect to the Outside World
abstract: Mobile phones smuggled from China are an increasingly vital way for North Koreans to reach relatives who have defected abroad.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The man drove Ju Chan-yang to a mountain overlooking North Korea’s border with China. He looked around, making sure they were alone. Then he dialed his Chinese cellphone and handed it to her.

headline: Using Arithmetic to Unify the G.O.P. Against Donald Trump
abstract: Bar graphs and schoolroom animation are employed in a political action committee’s ad that proclaims “a vote for Kasich actually helps Trump.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a basic reason not to vote for Gov. John Kasich, the ad proclaims: math. Through chalkboard arithmetic and some condescending narration, a new ad from the Club for Growth political action committee adds an anti-Kasich message to its anti-Trump campaign, accusing Mr. Kasich of splitting the opposition to Donald J. Trump.

headline: Another First for Cuba: A Concert by the Rolling Stones
abstract: Cuban music fans hoped Mick Jagger would break down the gates to political and social change that Cuban leaders had already cracked open.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Five decades after his music was banned in this Communist country, Mick Jagger stood — and sang, jumped and performed his signature dance moves — before hundreds of thousands of adoring fans Friday night in Cuba and declared: “Times are changing.”

headline: Sent Home to Australia, but Still Jailed for Chinese Crimes
abstract: Part of a prisoner exchange, Matthew Ng says he is now incarcerated for crimes he did not commit in a nation that would not consider his actions illegal.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Since he was arrested in 2010, Matthew Ng has lost his $100 million business, his health and his family.

headline: With Obama Visit to Cuba, Old Battle Lines Fade
abstract: The president’s engagement policy and Raúl Castro’s minor opening to free-market ideas have created a new dynamic for Cuba that reveals what the country could become with more freedom to evolve.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — For decades, Cuba and the United States have framed their relationship as a conflict of opposites: Communism vs. capitalism; Cuban loyalists vs. Cuban exiles; the state vs. the individual.

headline: After an Indictment, Turks Give U.S. Prosecutor a Hero’s Welcome Online
abstract: A Twitter post announcing charges against the tycoon Reza Zarrab has made Preet Bharara, U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, a social media sensation.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The indictment of a prominent Turkish businessman unsealed last week has made an unlikely hero of a man most Turks had never heard of: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, who brought the charges against the tycoon, Reza Zarrab.

headline: With a Barrage of 3-Pointers, Oklahoma Overpowers Oregon
abstract: The second-seeded Sooners, behind the senior guard Buddy Hield’s 37 points, were too much for the top-seeded Ducks as Oklahoma reached the Final Four for the fifth time in the program’s history.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — With five seconds left in the first half of the West Regional final, the Oklahoma senior guard Buddy Hield put up a shot from a spot midway between the halfcourt line and the 3-point arc. The ball slipped through the net to give the Sooners an 18-point halftime lead.

headline: Syracuse Strikes, Making No Apologies
abstract: Even if many analysts roll their eyes at the prospect of this Syracuse team’s advancing to the Final Four, the Orange players and coaches feel they are right where they should be.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Syracuse was slotted into the N.C.A.A. tournament as the No. 10 seed in the Midwest Region, there were many complaints that the Orange should never have been invited at all.

headline: Robert De Niro Pulls Anti-Vaccine Documentary From Tribeca Film Festival
keywords: ['Movies', 'Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Autism', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The announcement was a reversal of Mr. De Niro’s previous decision to show a film about the widely dismissed link between vaccinations and autism.
lead_paragraph: Facing a storm of criticism over its plan to show a documentary about the widely debunked link between vaccines and autism, the Tribeca Film Festival on Saturday pulled the film from its schedule next month.

headline: Mike Krzyzewski, the Emperor Coach
abstract: In Krzyzewski’s estimation, Dillon Brooks, an Oregon sophomore, had violated the winner’s code and was fit to receive an imperial dressing down.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — My first experience with an emperor coach took place more than 25 years ago in Bloomington, Ind., in the court of Bob Knight.

headline: Lawyer in Oklahoma Bombing Commends Garland in Letter to Obama
abstract: Stephen Jones, who defended Timothy J. McVeigh, sent this letter to President Obama in February recommending Judge Merrick B. Garland as a potential nominee for the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Jones, who defended Timothy J. McVeigh, sent this letter to President Obama in February recommending Judge Merrick B. Garland as a potential nominee for the Supreme Court.

headline: Merrick Garland Is a Deft Navigator of Washington’s Legal Circles
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, has advanced as a centrist in a city where ambition is often rewarded when accompanied by partisan loyalty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twice a day, for breakfast and lunch, Benjamin R. Civiletti, attorney general to President Jimmy Carter, invited his seven special assistants — mostly young graduates of the nation’s most prestigious law schools — to his private dining room at the Justice Department for casual conversation or friendly debate.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If Saudi Arabia was without the cloak of American protection, I don’t think it would be around.”

headline: After a Busy 2015 and an Extended Rest, deGrom Struggles to Regain His Velocity
abstract: After taking off extra time during the off-season, Mets starter Jacob deGrom has struggled to regain his pitch speed. But Manager Terry Collins is not worried.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Just watching Jacob deGrom pitch on Saturday, everything looked fine. Freddie Freeman was fooled, swinging through one of deGrom’s fastballs for a strikeout. But the center field scoreboard said the pitch had been only 92 miles per hour.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of March 20
abstract: Arizona held primaries, five other states had caucuses, and several candidates made stops in the nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Arizona held primaries, five other states had caucuses, and several candidates made stops in the nation’s capital.

headline: Villanova Ousts Kansas With Relentless Defense
abstract: No. 2-seeded Wildcats harassed Kansas’ top scorer, Perry Ellis, with double-teams and handed the Jayhawks their first loss in more than two months to advance to the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Early in the second half, the Villanova freshman Jalen Brunson made the poor decision to drive and try a tough layup, which he missed, prompting a Kansas fast break — three words that should strike fear into the heart of any Kansas opponent.

headline: Cavaliers, and Reality, Crash Down on the Knicks
abstract: Two nights after a surprising win over the Bulls, the Knicks fell back to earth, as LeBron James and Cleveland routed them at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James peeled his body off a courtside chair early Saturday and ambled onto the court at Madison Square Garden. The arena was quiet as the Cleveland Cavaliers began to warm up for their morning shootaround. James grabbed a ball and flung up a few midrange jump shots.

headline: Jessica Rosenthal, Jonathan Amoona
abstract: The couple met in 2012 at a Memorial Day gathering.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Morgan Rosenthal, the daughter of Faith S. Rosenthal and Lewis Rosenthal of Hewlett Harbor, N.Y., was married March 26 to Jonathan Joseph Amoona, the son of Naomi B. Usdan of Woodsburgh, N.Y. Rabbi Lev Herrnson officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

headline: Julie Dennis-Litinger, David Warren
abstract: The couple met in January 2010 through a mutual friend at a party in New York.
lead_paragraph: Julie Victoria Dennis-Litinger and David Wertheimer Warren were married on March 26 at 1 Hotel South Beach in Miami Beach. Rabbi Gary Glickstein officiated.

headline: Talya Bock, Raphael Cohen
abstract: The couple met at a synagogue in Washington and then reconnected three years later on JDate.
lead_paragraph: Talya Rahel Bock and Raphael Saadya Cohen are to be married March 27 at Beth Sholom Congregation and Talmud Torah in Potomac, Md. Rabbi Elie Kaunfer is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Anna Stetsovskaya and John Hamilton: An Airman’s Message in the Sand
abstract: The bride and groom lived on different continents, but still managed to find a way to make it work.
lead_paragraph: Anna Stetsovskaya and John Wesley Hamilton were married March 26 at the Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif., by Alan C. Schoen, who was appointed a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Santa Clara County.

headline: Corey Briskin and Nicholas Maggipinto
abstract: The couple met at Brooklyn Law School.
lead_paragraph: Corey Michael Briskin and Nicholas James Maggipinto were married March 26 at the Lighthouse, an event space in New York. United States Representative Kathleen M. Rice, Democrat of New York, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Ann Henstrand, Stephen Broadie
abstract: The bride and groom met at an insurance conference in 1992 and started dating in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Ann Mary Henstrand and Stephen William Broadie were married on March 26 in Danville, Calif. John Henstrand, the bride’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Swain House, a community center in Hap Magee Park.

headline: Sydnie Henkin, Alexander Fogelson
abstract: The bride and groom were married five years to the day of their first date.
lead_paragraph: Sydnie Laura Henkin, a daughter of Susan L. Henkin and Edward R. Henkin of Amagansett, N.Y., was married March 26 to Alexander Isaac Fogelson, the son of Linda B. Fogelson and Stephen L. Fogelson of New York. Rabbi Judith Kempler officiated at Il Mercato, an event space in New Orleans.

headline: Nathan Soland, Joseph Wehri
abstract: The couple met when they both worked in Target’s corporate offices.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Bruce Soland and Joseph Carl Wehri were married March 26 at Aria, an event space in Minneapolis. Cristina Rivard, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Rebecca Corwin, Jared Mesznik
abstract: The bride, a doctor in neonatal/perinatal medicine, and the groom, who works at Morgan Stanley, first met when she was 7 and he was 9.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rebecca Allyn Corwin and Jared Gil Mesznik were married March 26 at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Rabbi Elliot J. Cosgrove officiated.

headline: Leonard Freed on Postwar Jewish Life in Amsterdam
abstract: A new book revisits and expands upon Leonard Freed’s early documentation of Amsterdam’s Jewish residents rebuilding their lives after the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: A new book revisits and expands upon Leonard Freed’s early documentation of Amsterdam’s Jewish residents rebuilding their lives after the Holocaust.
