abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Leonard Freed’s Photos of Postwar Jewish Life in Amsterdam
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Photography']
abstract: A new book revisits and expands upon Leonard Freed’s early documentation of Amsterdam’s Jewish residents rebuilding their lives after the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: Few archivists can compete with Brigitte Freed when it comes to preservation and attention to detail. For the half-century that Leonard Freed photographed — and in the nine years since his death — Mrs. Freed has amassed, organized and protected the contact sheets, diaries, binders and prints that comprise her husband’s legacy, which began long before he joined Magnum in 1972.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Brussels, Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: A Supreme Court Pioneer, Now Making Her Mark on Video Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Education (K-12)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'E-Learning']
abstract: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor said she had never played video games until a few years ago. But now she is using them to teach students valuable civics lessons.
lead_paragraph: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, who turned 86 on Saturday, has many achievements to her name, including serving as a state senator in Arizona and becoming the first woman appointed to the Supreme Court, where she served for almost a quarter-century.

headline: 1916: Pancho Villa Is Surrounded by Americans
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War and Revolution']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Mexican chieftain and 200 of his followers sought refuge in the mountains as American troops neared in 1916.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Pancho Villa, rebel chieftain, who has kept Northern Mexico in a ferment for the last five years, is making his last stand in the Sierra Madre mountains, seventy-five miles south of the American border.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Syrian Troops Said to Recapture Historic Palmyra From ISIS
keywords: ['Assyrian Civilization', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The end of the ancient city’s nearly yearlong occupation brought a rare measure of international praise for President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army said Sunday that it had fully captured Palmyra, routing Islamic State fighters who had occupied the city with its ancient ruins for almost a year, and handing President Bashar al-Assad a strategic prize. It also gave Mr. Assad something more rare: a measure of international praise.

headline: The Trade Deficit Isn’t a Scorecard, and Cutting It Won’t Make America Great Again
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Trying to eliminate the trade deficit could mean giving up levers of power that allow the U.S. to get its way in international politics.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump believes that a half-trillion-dollar trade deficit with the rest of the world makes the United States a loser and countries with trade surpluses like China and Mexico winners.

headline: That Strange Country Smell
abstract: A little boy, unaccustomed to the suburban outdoors, asked his mother a somewhat chilling question on Central Park West.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1966: World Cup Trophy Found By Briton Walking His Dog
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The trophy that England won in the 1966 World Cup, which was stolen from an exhibition, was discovered near London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The stolen world soccer cup was found here tonight [March 27] by a man taking his dog for a walk along a quiet suburban street, police said. A massive police hunt had been under way since the solid gold trophy — emblem of the world’s soccer championship — was stolen from a London exhibition a week ago.

headline: Fight
abstract: Two men entered the ring for their first professional fight. Then something went wrong.
lead_paragraph: PART 1

headline: Tensions Erupt in Brussels, and Police in 4 Countries Make Arrests
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'Forgery', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Memorials for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Brussels were interrupted on Sunday by far-right protesters.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The police in at least four countries arrested new suspects during the weekend in the Paris and Brussels terrorist attacks, as memorials in central Brussels to the victims of Tuesday’s bombings were briefly overrun by hooligans.

headline: A Painted Heart Leaves a Black Mark on an Artist’s Record
abstract: Hans Honschar said his creation, with a subway signboard as his canvas, was art, but the Police Department called it graffiti. Their difference of opinion played out on an R line platform in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Nature abhors a vacuum,” Hans Honschar said, and so does he.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Easter, early signs of spring, all kinds of burgers and a tribute to the rapper Phife Dawg.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: On Campaign Trail, Republicans Tone Down Criticism of Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The explanation may be that for all its controversy and imperfections, the sweeping law has taken hold.
lead_paragraph: No issue has aroused more partisan passion over the past six years than the Affordable Care Act. Yet the law is playing only a secondary role in the American elections.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: The third season of “Orphan Black” arrives on Amazon. And Judy Garland and Fred Astaire star in the 1948 movie musical “Easter Parade.”
lead_paragraph: The third season of “Orphan Black,” the binge-worthy thriller in which Tatiana Maslany plays more than five clones (and counting), arrives on Amazon. And celebrate the holiday with Judy Garland and Fred Astaire in the movie musical “Easter Parade.”

headline: Blast at a Crowded Park in Lahore, Pakistan, Kills Dozens
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The blast, which appeared to be caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at a park popular with families, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suicide bomber set off a powerful blast close to a children’s swing set in a public park on Sunday evening in the eastern city of Lahore, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300, rescue workers and officials said.

headline: Ballez to Combine Two Classic Tales in Nontraditional Form
abstract: “Sleeping Beauty and the Beast” — created by Katy Pyle, artistic director of Ballez — reimagines Tchaikovsky’s 1890 ballet “The Sleeping Beauty” and the 18th-century fairy tale “Beauty and the Beast” to question traditional gender roles and tell the “herstory” of New York’s lesbian activists.
lead_paragraph: Ballez, a company that restages classic works with a “queer” twist, will present the world premiere of its “Sleeping Beauty and the Beast” as part of this year’s La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival.

headline: American Tech Giants Face Fight in Europe Over Encrypted Data
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As Apple battles the F.B.I. over “unlocking” an iPhone, European governments are pushing for greater access to people’s digital lives.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Silicon Valley’s battle over encryption is heading to Europe.

headline: Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Continue Clash Over Spouses
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas traded insults on Easter Sunday morning over recent smears against their wives.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas traded insults on Easter Sunday morning over recent smears against their wives, while Mr. Trump ruled out creating internment camps for American Muslims and said he would study a proposal to allow delegates to bring guns to the Republican National Convention.

headline: Batman vs. Superman, by the Numbers
abstract: A look at how have the two franchises have matched up at the box office over the years.
lead_paragraph: With Batman and Superman battling each other for the first time in a feature film, here’s a look back at how the two have stacked up onscreen in live-action theatrical releases before “Batman v Superman.”

headline: Jim Harrison, Poet, Novelist and Essayist, Is Dead at 78
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: A darkly comic master of the novella, Mr. Harrison was also known for his poems and essays on food.
lead_paragraph: Jim Harrison, whose lust for life — and sometimes just plain lust — roared into print in a vast, celebrated body of fiction, poetry and essays that with ardent abandon explored the natural world, the life of the mind and the pleasures of the flesh, died on Saturday at his home in Patagonia, Ariz. He was 78.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Picks Eddie Johnson as Chicago’s Interim Police Chief
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The mayor rejected three candidates that had been recommended by a police board as he seeks to repair Chicago’s relationship with its police force.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel has informed some city leaders that he has chosen an interim superintendent of police, rejecting three candidates that had been recommended by the police board, as he seeks to repair Chicago’s fractured relationship with its police force.

headline: Museum’s Plan to Include Cosby Material Draws Criticism From Accusers
abstract: Several women say that the National Museum of African American History and Culture should not take note of the comedian’s career unless it also mentions their sexual-assault accusations.
lead_paragraph: Several women who have accused Bill Cosby of sexual assault say they are upset that the new National Museum of African American History and Culture plans not to mention their accusations in an exhibition that recognizes Mr. Cosby’s pioneering work in comedy and television.

headline: N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference Chips Away at West’s Dominance
abstract: This season, the East currently has eight teams with winning records in line for playoff berths, while in the West, three postseason contenders do not have winning records.
lead_paragraph: That the East rhymes with least has been an unfortunate coincidence during the past decade of basketball, in which the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference has struggled to keep up with its more glamorous Western rivals. But as the current season winds down, a look at the standings reveals the tables may have turned ever so slightly.

headline: Emily Schwend Wins Yale Drama Award
abstract: She will receive a $10,000 award for her play “Utility.”
lead_paragraph: Emily Schwend has won the 2016 Yale Drama Series prize for “Utility,” a family drama set in Texas. “Utility” received a critic’s pick in The Times when it opened Off Broadway last month; Laura Collins-Hughes described it as a “skillfully constructed, beautifully acted domestic drama about struggling simply to make do.”

headline: Miley Cyrus and Alicia Keys Join ‘The Voice’ as Coaches
abstract: The singers will replace Pharrell Williams and Christina Aguilera on the next season of the NBC show.
lead_paragraph: Miley Cyrus and Alicia Keys are the latest pop stars to serve as coaches on “The Voice.” The pair will replace Pharrell Williams and Christina Aguilera on the eleventh season of the NBC musical show starting in the fall.

headline: U.S. Men’s Soccer Team Adds Two Players Before World Cup Qualifier
abstract: Midfielders Christian Pulisic and Graham Zusi joined the roster before Tuesday’s match against Guatemala. The injured Fabian Johnson and Matt Besler were returned to their club teams.
lead_paragraph: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann added the 17-year-old Borussia Dortmund midfielder Christian Pulisic to the American roster for Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier against Guatemala in Columbus, Ohio.

headline: Keep the Militias Out of Mosul
abstract: Iraq’s government successfully retook Ramadi last year with an inclusive, nonsectarian strategy. Let’s repeat that.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The liberation of Ramadi in the closing days of 2015 was a rare moment of success for Iraq. It has given Iraqis an opportunity to examine what works and what doesn’t in the fight against the Islamic State. It has also generated a momentum that we should capitalize on if we truly want to expunge the jihadist group from Iraqi soil, including from the crucial city of Mosul, and take the first steps toward a meaningful reconciliation for our country.

headline: Bernie Sanders Challenges Hillary Clinton to Debate in New York
abstract: Mr. Sanders, appearing on “Meet the Press,” expressed concern that Mrs. Clinton might not debate him now that she is far ahead in the race to win the Democratic nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont challenged Hillary Clinton on Sunday to a debate in New York before the state’s primary on April 19 and expressed concern that Mrs. Clinton might not debate him now that she is far ahead in the race to win the Democratic nomination.

headline: Keeping Nuclear Weapons From Terrorists
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: As terrorists seek further destruction, global nuclear powers must aggressively plug lingering security gaps in energy and weaponry material.
lead_paragraph: The recent attacks in Belgium and elsewhere would have been catastrophic if the terrorists had gotten their hands on nuclear weapons or even a primitive “dirty bomb,” which combines nuclear material with conventional explosives. International efforts to prevent access to such weapons have made significant progress in recent years, but there is still a long way to go.

headline: Israeli Court Strikes Down Natural Gas Development Deal
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Obama administration has hopes that gas export efforts will help build peaceful relations between Israel and its neighbors in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s High Court of Justice struck down on Sunday a deal that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reached in December to enable the development of a major offshore natural gas field.

headline: Sabrina Esmael Fazal, Nursing Student and Brussels Victim
abstract: Ms. Fazal, 24, grew up in Ottignies, Belgium. She was killed in the attack at the Maelbeek train station.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Sabrina Esmael Fazal, 24, a bubbly Belgian nursing student, had once worked as a correspondent for a website run by and for members of the Congolese diaspora.

headline: On C.T.E. and Athletes, Science Remains in Its Infancy
abstract: While playing football and the disease are linked, questions remain about how much risk each player has of developing it, and why some are more prone than others.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, Mass. — In a small room banked by refrigerators of preserved brains, a pathologist held a specimen up to the light in frank admiration. Then it was time to cut — once in half and then a thick slice from the back, the tissue dense and gray-pink, teeming with folds and swirls.

headline: Hood Museum Renovation Causes a Split
abstract: A plan for this museum in New Hampshire expands the space, but detractors say its architects are stepping on the legacy of the institution’s designer.
lead_paragraph: To those concerned about the renovation of the Hood Museum of Art, the situation is charged with paradox: The architects Billie Tsien and Tod Williams, who protested the Museum of Modern Art’s dismantling of the Folk Art Museum they designed in Manhattan, are now transforming the Hood, an award-winning museum designed by Charles Moore at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H.

headline: Review: In ‘The Nest,’ a Family Pot to Split Sets Sibling Relations to a Slow Boil
abstract: In Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney’s debut novel, the death of a father and the prospect of money he left his children put a host of plot threads in motion.
lead_paragraph: “The Nest” is a novel in the Squabbling Sibling genre. Unless such stories are told by someone of the caliber of Chekhov or Dostoyevsky, they tend to be domestic comedies padded with lucky coincidences and studded with old grudges. And they need to be set in motion by some convenient family crisis and venue.

headline: Karlheinz Stockhausen’s ‘Klang,’ an Epic Cycle at 3 Met Museums
abstract: This 21-piece work by the creator of grandiose spectacles of sublimity and kitsch was performed at the Met, the Met Breuer and the Cloisters.
lead_paragraph: Religion as art, art as religion: This is the dual ethos of the modern encyclopedic museum, preserving objects of devotion in a secular age. It could also be the motto of the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen, the creator of grandiose spectacles of sublimity and kitsch, whose works fed his deeply idiosyncratic spiritual practice and vice versa.

headline: For ‘Batman v Superman,’ a Supersized Box Office
abstract: The Warner Bros. film took in an estimated $170.1 million in North America and an additional $254 million in simultaneous release overseas.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As a box office megadraw, “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” more than did its job, taking in an estimated $170.1 million in North America and an additional $254 million in simultaneous release overseas.

headline: A Baseball Renaissance on Florida’s East Coast
abstract: Abandoned by major league teams headed to other parts of the state or to Arizona, the area languished. But now the Astros and the Nationals will share a new facility in Palm Beach County.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — When the Palm Beach County commissioner Priscilla Taylor attended a groundbreaking in November for the spring training baseball complex being built here, her car wound up with two flat tires.

headline: Alex Da Corte’s ‘Free Roses’ Puts His Eccentricities on View
abstract: In this installation, at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, Mr. Da Corte takes disparate items and combines them in his signature style.
lead_paragraph: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. — A group of 16 kindergartners on a tour of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art here stumbled upon a gallery last week where a show was being installed and the children halted in their tracks.

headline: Winsome
abstract: Gary Cee knows how to start off our solving week.
lead_paragraph: BREAKING ADMINISTRIVIAL MORE A.C.P.T. PRIZES ALERT! Thanks to a generous, last-minute donation from PuzzleSocial, home of the popular Daily Celebrity Crossword, the prizes for this year’s American Crossword Puzzle Tournament have been doubled! The A.C.P.T. prize pool was close to $7,500. It will now be $15,000. This will be by far the most money ever awarded at a live crossword event anywhere in the world. Rather than the old prizes being simply doubled, the extra money will be allotted to MORE winners, and one of them could be you. Click here to read more about how the prizes have increased.

headline: David Cross’s ‘Making America Great Again!’ Skewers Resentment-Filled Dogma
abstract: In his new show, which stopped at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Cross deploys a tighter comedic style with provocative punch lines.
lead_paragraph: To understand the appeal of Donald J. Trump, shift your focus from political pundits (who have repeatedly underestimated him) to stand-up comics.

headline: Review: Bombino, Mokoomba, Jojo Abot and Others Play Africa Now! at the Apollo
abstract: Bands performed songs from Niger, Ghana and Zimbabwe at this show, which included Alsarah and the Nubatones, a group led by a Sudanese singer.
lead_paragraph: There were screams of joy from the Apollo Theater audience when Bombino, from Niger, played guitar solos on Saturday night, headlining the Africa Now! concert. Yet if Bombino is a guitar hero, he may be the most laconic one ever. His solos aren’t long or fast; they mostly circle through the same riffs, each just a handful of notes, that drive his songs. He seizes the foreground with a fiercer attack, a note or two placed differently, a sudden trill — stings and jabs and displacements, not discourses. Over the relentless beat of his band, those were more than enough to ignite an already dancing crowd.

headline: Review: ‘The Seagull and Other Birds’ Turned Upside Down
abstract: The experimental Irish troupe Pan Pan turns one of modern drama’s seminal works inside out.
lead_paragraph: You’ll recognize Masha right away. True, she’s wearing standard-issue ballet gear like everybody else. But her tutu is black. And it’s not long — shortly after the audience is encouraged to help sing a curtain-raising rendition of the Boomtown Rats’ “I Don’t Like Mondays” — before she clinches the identification with her immortal signature line: “I’m in mourning for my life.”

headline: For ‘The Flash’ and ‘Supergirl,’ Power to Pass Through Network Walls
abstract: On Monday night, the title hero on “The Flash” will leap across networks, racing from his CW series to appear on CBS’s “Supergirl.”
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, two of the most famous comic book heroes of all time punched each other senseless to big box office success. This week, over on the small screen, two of their cousins are pairing off in a less contentious fashion.

headline: Review: ‘Extra Shapes’ Balances Movement, Sound and Light, Times Three
abstract: This dance, part of the Kitchen’s “From Minimalism Into Algorithm,” repeats the same 17-minute sequence three times, revealing new details each time.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the music for a dance overpowers the movement; sometimes lighting steals the show. In other cases dancing itself outdoes everything else. In “Extra Shapes,” which had its New York premiere on Friday at the Kitchen, the choreographer DD Dorvillier gives equal weight to all three elements — movement, sound and light — assigning each to a colored strip of carpetlike flooring. Pink is for sound, white for light, brown for movement. The analogous image offered in publicity materials — a slice of Neapolitan ice cream — turns out to be entirely accurate.

headline: The Neanderthals, the Denisovans and Us
abstract: A study of global genomes has found that our ancestors are even more varied than we thought.
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly 160 years since we Homo sapiens, or “wise people,” first got an inkling through Charles Darwin and the discovery of Neanderthal remains that we are just another evolving species on this planet. In recent years, the pace of new discoveries — made possible by advances in a broad array of disciplines, including biotechnology, genetics and paleontology — has increased.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 28
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Along With President Obama, the 21st Century Visited Cuba
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Age, Chronological', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: In many ways, including a sharp visual contrast with President Raúl Castro, who is 84, Mr. Obama’s stay showed younger Cubans a prospect for an inviting future.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The White House made sure the wireless signal inside the Grand Theater of Havana was strong and fast last week as President Obama made his case for change to the Cuban people. He spoke of evolution and burying old wounds from before he was born. He bluntly challenged President Raúl Castro of Cuba, sitting across the hall, to change his ways.

headline: Hotel Chains and Travel Websites in a Tug of War for Customers
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: As brand loyalty dwindles, Hilton and Marriott have begun campaigns encouraging consumers to skip web agents like Expedia and book directly for low prices and perks.
lead_paragraph: A recent Hilton commercial that shows people tapping away on their phones and computers as the Rolling Stones song “(I Can’t Get No) Satisfaction” plays seems relatively benign, as does the tagline, “Stop Clicking Around.”

headline: Mayor de Blasio and Assembly Speaker Coordinate Closely in State Budget Fight
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio keeps in touch with Speaker Carl E. Heastie to make sure New York City’s interests are represented in budget talks in Albany.
lead_paragraph: They have been talking with gathering frequency and exchanging texts regularly, with Carl E. Heastie, the State Assembly speaker, firing off messages from his iPhone and Mayor Bill de Blasio responding — painstakingly — on his decidedly more antiquated device.

headline: California Nears Deal to Adopt a $15 State Minimum Wage
abstract: If approved, the wage would increase incrementally from $10 over the next six years. A similar measure is also being considered in New York.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California lawmakers have reached a tentative deal to raise the state minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2022, potentially signaling the biggest advance yet in a campaign to increase pay for low-income workers that has reverberated in the Democratic presidential contest and in cities across the country.

headline: Bangladesh Editor Faces 79 Court Cases After an Unusual Confession
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Newspapers', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Treason and Sedition', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: After admitting it was wrong to have years ago published allegations against the prime minister, Mahfuz Anam could be sentenced to 175 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The math alone is a bewildering exercise for Mahfuz Anam, the editor of Bangladesh’s most popular English-language newspaper. Since February, the number of legal claims against him has climbed to 79 cases: 62 for defamation and 17 for sedition.

headline: Small Gains in the U.S. and Concerns in China
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Reports for hiring, personal spending and income are expected, along with Janet Yellen’s first speech of 2016 and bleak bank reports out of China.
lead_paragraph: On Monday at 8:30 a.m., the Commerce Department will report new data on personal consumption and income for February. Economists expect a small increase of 0.1 percent in both income and spending, in line with other muted economic data reported recently.

headline: Seeded 10th, Syracuse Is One of the Last Four Left
abstract: The 10th-seeded Orange defied their skeptics and rode a No. 10 seed all the way to the ultimate week of the college basketball season.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Shortly before Coach Jim Boeheim cut down the net to celebrate a most improbable victory, he grabbed a microphone and noted to the assembled fans that he had just witnessed the best comeback in Syracuse’s long, rich basketball history.

headline: Easter Creativity on Display
abstract: At the annual Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival in Manhattan, there was plenty for spectators to gawk at.
lead_paragraph: At the annual Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival in Manhattan, there was plenty for spectators to gawk at.

headline: Creativity on Parade in Easter Bonnet Festival, a Rite of Spring
abstract: The yearly celebration in Manhattan drew spectators with its display of unusual hats, including one made entirely of parking tickets.
lead_paragraph: A partial list of the headwear on display at the Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival in Manhattan on Sunday included rabbit ears, silk flower arrangements, Easter eggs bobbing like antennae and Easter baskets so securely fixed to their owners’ heads that they could withstand high winds.

headline: Ted Cruz Names Friends, but Silence From G.O.P. Brass Deafens
abstract: As Ted Cruz tries to unite Republicans opposed to Donald J. Trump, the senator is seeking the support of the party establishment that he has long criticized.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz was naming friends.

headline: A Castro Met a Free Press, and the World Watched It Live
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As President Raúl Castro of Cuba stammered over questions from the news media, it was a reminder of the signs of regression concerning President Obama and the press back home.
lead_paragraph: The thing about dictators is they don’t have to answer any stinking questions from the press. We call it undemocratic; they call it job security.

headline: Who Will Become a Terrorist? Research Yields Few Clues
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Research', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The question of what turns people toward violence — and whether they can be steered away from it — has bedeviled governments around the world for generations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The brothers who carried out suicide bombings in Brussels last week had long, violent criminal records and had been regarded internationally as potential terrorists. But in San Bernardino, Calif., last year, one of the attackers was a county health inspector who lived a life of apparent suburban normality.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve had parents come into my practice, their child had a single concussion and they think he or she has permanent brain damage. There’s no basis for that.”

headline: At Easter, Congregation Vows to Rebuild New Jersey Church After a Fire
abstract: A fire ripped through the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, but parishioners celebrated the holiday in another location and vowed to rebuild the sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — The old church has sat just up a hill from a main street here since 1870. Its towering steeple has been looked at from blocks away. Its red and beige sandstone walls and 19th-century stained-glass windows have enticed thousands of people to stop and gaze.

headline: Record Wildfire Comes to Kansas, as Do Lifesaving Neighbors
abstract: Firefighters and other volunteers who rushed to the affected areas were credited with helping avert deaths in a blaze said to be the state’s largest.
lead_paragraph: MEDICINE LODGE, Kan. — The towering fire approached Don Gerstner’s house last week with such fury that there was no time to pack. All he and his wife, Carol, could do was scurry to their Toyota pickup and speed past a row of flaming trees toward the relative safety of a nearby road.

headline: ‘Big Boy League’ A.C.C. Rules the Final Four
abstract: With a kaleidoscope of talent — from elite recruits to juniors, seniors and postgraduates — the A.C.C. has served notice that it is built for the short and long run.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Speaking to the news media on Saturday, Virginia Coach Tony Bennett put a sharp point on the Atlantic Coast Conference’s dominance in the N.C.A.A. tournament over the past two seasons.

headline: Ethereum, a Virtual Currency, Enables Transactions That Rival Bitcoin’s
abstract: In addition to virtual currency, Ethereum also provides a way to create online markets and programmable transactions known as smart contracts.
lead_paragraph: A new virtual gold rush is underway.

headline: Juan Lagares Pushes Hard for Playing Time
abstract: The Mets outfielder dealt with an elbow injury, regressed at the plate and lost his job during the stretch run last season. Now he’s 20 pounds lighter and is ready to battle.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Juan Lagares was in the New York area one day this winter, grinding through another grueling training day with Jose Reyes, when a Mets fan approached him and said that the Mets were re-signing Yoenis Cespedes, the slugger who had become a fan favorite during the Mets’ 2015 playoff run and had displaced Lagares in center field.

headline: Saburi Departs a City of Restaurants, Taking a Japanese Cuisine With It
abstract: A restaurant in Kips Bay, Manhattan, is considered the only establishment in New York to serve Japanese-style Chinese food. It is closing this week, to a small chorus of laments.
lead_paragraph: The restaurant Saburi has been an unassuming presence on a quiet street in the Manhattan neighborhood of Kips Bay for 10 years. It can seem unremarkable and even neglected. Its gates are frequently shuttered, lunch lures few customers and old reviews of the restaurant have collected dust in the window. But the sparse pub-style establishment morphs at night.

headline: Silicon Valley Looks to Artificial Intelligence for the Next Big Thing
abstract: Tech’s new architecture melds large computing clouds and artificial intelligence to create efficient computing resources and data-based businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the oracles of Silicon Valley debate whether the latest tech boom is sliding toward bust, there is already talk about what will drive the industry’s next growth spurt.

headline: An Ancient Caravan Town in China Is Reborn
abstract: In a project praised by Unesco, a Swiss-led team spent years renovating the square of Sideng Village, with an eye toward historical consistency that is rare in China.
lead_paragraph: SHAXI, China — The woman shuffled around her shop in the village square, telling visitors how she came to be selling wooden swords and woven slippers to tourists rather than tending to her fields.

headline: A Streetcar Not Desired by Everyone in Brooklyn
abstract: Some residents of Red Hook, Brooklyn, see the proposed streetcar system as an opportunity to bring in needed development, while others want to keep it off the map.
lead_paragraph: A streetcar that would snake along the East River in Brooklyn and Queens, perhaps bringing a flurry of new development along the waterfront, has the residents of one neighborhood lining up on either side of the proposal.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Cavaliers at Hawks
abstract: The Hawks will have a chance to measure themselves against the Eastern Conference’s top contenders this week, including Friday’s game against Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the Atlanta Hawks were a surprise offensive success. Relying heavily on the 3-pointer, the Hawks took the N.B.A. by storm, shooting their way to the top seed in the Eastern Conference with one of the most efficient attacks in the league.

headline: Charter’s $67 Billion Cable Merger Hinges on the Cord Cutters
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Charter Communications is poised to gain F.C.C. approval to join with Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, and streaming looms large in the deal.
lead_paragraph: Charter Communications is within striking distance of finally capturing its prize.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 7: California Beach Party
abstract: “Vinyl” might be at its best when it’s unencumbered by Richie’s substance abuse and domestic drama.
lead_paragraph: A California beach house full of ’70s rock stars: it could be a Madame Tussauds exhibit or an opening segment for Jimmy Fallon, but it proves to be a potent setting for “Vinyl.” Richie and Zak have come to Los Angeles to sell the American Century corporate jet to a rival record label — one that’s doing better than them, with three albums in the Top 10. Its proprietor invites them to a party, where he tells Richie, “Never leave New York — the anger suits you.”

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 15: Who Won’t Survive the Season?
abstract: One episode to go, and Negan is on his way.
lead_paragraph: He said he’d be all right, right?

abstract: An estimated 500 positions will be cut as part of a reorganization that the global news organization attributed to shifts in the media landscape.
lead_paragraph: The global news organization Al Jazeera said on Sunday that it would cut an estimated 500 positions as part of a reorganization that it attributed to shifts in the media landscape.

headline: Ben Gray to Leave TPG Capital in Asia
abstract: Mr. Gray, the co-head of TPG in Asia, will leave at the end of year and is said to be setting up his own Australia-focused investment firm.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Ben Gray, the co-head of TPG Capital in Asia, will leave the American private equity firm amid reports that he is setting up his own Australia-focused investment firm.

headline: Top-Seeded North Carolina Fills Last Spot in Final Four
abstract: The Tar Heels defeated sixth-seeded Notre Dame in the East Regional final to advance to their record 19th Final Four.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Earth has managed to orbit the sun for the last seven years in spite of one of college basketball’s great injustices. Somehow the Final Four had been contested each spring since without the presence of North Carolina, challenging an enduring belief among its supporters that if God were not a Tar Heel, then why is the sky Carolina blue?

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 10: How Low Can Bobby Go?
abstract: This week’s episode imagines Bobby as a creature of pure capitalism.
lead_paragraph: “I was, for a time, supposed to be a grandmaster …”

headline: Eric Staal Provides Spark, but Rangers Fall Short
abstract: Staal scored both goals for the Rangers, but the Penguins forged a 3-2 victory at Madison Square Garden when Sidney Crosby scored at 4 minutes 30 seconds of overtime.
lead_paragraph: Eric Staal, who joined the Rangers a month ago, surely was waiting for a night like the one he finally enjoyed Sunday against the surging Pittsburgh Penguins.

headline: Mother Mary Angelica, Who Founded Catholic TV Network, Dies at 92
abstract: She was a popular and influential host on the Eternal Word Television Network, where she criticized liberalizing trends in the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Mother Mary Angelica of the Annunciation, a cloistered Franciscan nun who founded the largest Roman Catholic television network in the country, and used it unstintingly to criticize liberalizing trends in the Catholic Church, died on Sunday. She was 92.

headline: French Journalist Is Detained at U.N. War Crimes Tribunal
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Florence Hartmann, a former correspondent for Le Monde, has been locked up at the tribunal prison to serve a pending seven-day sentence for contempt of court.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Shortly before the announcement of a genocide verdict on Thursday for Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, security guards at the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia received an extraordinary order from the court presidency: They were told to arrest a French journalist, Florence Hartmann, who could be found outside the tribunal gates with survivors of the Bosnian war.

headline: How the G.O.P. Elite Lost Its Voters to Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The party establishment abandoned its most faithful voters, blue-collar workers who faced economic pain while donors, lawmakers and lobbyists prospered.
lead_paragraph: The manufacturing executives had gathered in an Atlanta conference room last year to honor their senior United States senator, Johnny Isakson, for his tireless efforts on their behalf in Washington. But as the luncheon wound down, Mr. Isakson found himself facing a man from Coweta County. The man, Burl Finkelstein, said trade policies with Mexico and China were strangling the family-owned kitchen-parts company he helped manage, and imperiling the jobs it provided. Mr. Isakson politely brushed him off, Mr. Finkelstein recalled, as he had many times before.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda: Give Puerto Rico Its Chance to Thrive
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Alexander Hamilton fought to help his island home. Now the creator of “Hamilton” is asking Congress to help his.
lead_paragraph: ON Aug. 31, 1772, a hurricane devastated the island of St. Croix, the home of the teenage Alexander Hamilton. In a letter one week later, he described the force of the storm and the destruction it caused as “sufficient to strike astonishment into angels.”

headline: Trade, Labor, and Politics
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Must workers suffer from globalization? The political parties appear to have swapped positions on policy.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of things about the 2016 election that nobody saw coming, and one of them is that international trade policy is likely to be a major issue in the presidential campaign. What’s more, the positions of the parties will be the reverse of what you might have expected: Republicans, who claim to stand for free markets, are likely to nominate a crude protectionist, leaving Democrats, with their skepticism about untrammeled markets, as the de facto defenders of relatively open trade.

abstract: The estate tax could address income inequality. But no one’s going to raise it.

headline: Let Voters Decide the Court’s Future
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Voters elected a Republican Senate majority in 2014 in part to restrain the president’s judicial overreach.
lead_paragraph: JUSTICE ANTONIN SCALIA was among the greatest jurists in our nation’s history. Following an era of unchecked judicial activism, he became a model of careful jurisprudence, reinvigorating an originalist interpretation of the Constitution for a new generation. Justice Scalia’s approach was grounded in the words of legal texts, and not in a judge’s personal preferences or the vagaries of popular political beliefs.

headline: A Modern System of Debtor Prisons
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Too many state and local governments have been jailing citizens who are unable to pay fines, fees and penalties.
lead_paragraph: Court systems commonly raise revenue by punishing people who commit minor offenses with fines, fees and penalties that can pile up, driving them into poverty. Worse still, state and local governments often jail people illegally for nonpayment, putting them at risk of losing their jobs and homes.

headline: The State Assault on Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Twenty-three states have tried to defund the family-planning organization in the months since a similar effort failed in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, after  deceptively edited videos were used to accuse Planned Parenthood of selling fetal tissue, congressional Republicans voted to block all federal financing for the organization, and threatened to shut down the entire federal government if they didn’t get their way.

headline: Republican Self-Destruction
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On both the state and national levels, the party is demonstrating a willingness to let voter anger drive their actions.
lead_paragraph: Whatever one may think about the current president and the two Democrats duking it out to replace him, you have to admit that they have, by and large, conducted themselves with an admirable level of civility and couth becoming of the office.

headline: A Game Changed History, but It’s Hardly Been Seen Since
abstract: The 1966 N.C.A.A. championship game remains a landmark event because Texas Western started five black players against an all-white Kentucky. Now it will be seen again on ESPN.
lead_paragraph: The 1966 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament was a pre-March Madness event. Only 22 teams were in it. The tournament was not carried by a major network, let alone the four that televise it now. But it remains a landmark event because Texas Western started five black players against Adolph Rupp’s all-white Kentucky in the championship game and won, 72-65.

headline: Instead of Coating a Pan, a Textured Finish
abstract: All-Clad has a new line of nonstick skillets.
lead_paragraph: All-Clad, the cookware company, is introducing a new line of triple-ply stainless steel skillets and sauté pans that are reasonably nonstick without using special coatings. The inside bottom surface of the pans is textured like Bubble Wrap with a patented pattern of little bumps that allow for better release than smooth stainless steel. The pan has an aluminum core for conductivity. I abused a skillet with eggs and potatoes, and found it quite easy to clean. Besides skillets, there is a sauté pan and a fish pan, most of which are compatible with induction burners: All-Clad d3 Armor cookware, $110 to $255 at Williams-Sonoma, williams-sonoma.com.

headline: And You Thought the Line Was Long for Cronuts
abstract: From Dominique Ansel and Deuki Hong, Korean French dip sandwiches.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to turn a standard French dip sandwich into a Korean French dip or KFD, as Deuki Hong, the chef at Kang Ho Dong Baekjeong, and the pastry chef Dominique Ansel call it? Start by baking a long roll, a soft potato bread studded with black garlic. Then spread kimchi on one side and garlic butter on the other. Generously fill it with Mr. Hong’s slow-roasted beef. For dipping, choose either mushroom or serrano chile kalbi jus. The two chefs are turning out 300 sandwiches a day and selling them this weekend only first come first served on Friday, starting at 6 p.m., and Saturday and Sunday starting at noon: KFD Sandwich, $22, Dominique Ansel Kitchen, 137 Seventh Avenue South (Charles Street), dominiqueanselkitchen.com.

headline: ScienceTake | Itching to Be Popular
abstract: Researchers interested in the costs and benefits of social behavior studied Japanese macaques, looking for ties between social contacts and lice.
lead_paragraph: Researchers interested in the costs and benefits of social behavior studied Japanese macaques, looking for ties between social contacts and lice.

headline: Japanese Monkeys Like to Socialize, Even With Nits to Pick
abstract: Researchers interested in the costs and benefits of social behavior studied Japanese macaques, looking for ties between social contacts and lice.
lead_paragraph: Social life is good for you, even when your friends have lice — if you’re a Japanese macaque.

headline: How to Spot and Treat a Child’s Hernia
abstract: Surgery to correct a hernia is straightforward and usually done as an outpatient procedure.
lead_paragraph: When my twin sons were 2½, their pediatrician detected a hernia in the right groin of one of the boys. The doctor minced no words: The hernia would not repair itself and surgery was necessary to avoid a serious, potentially life-threatening complication. But he added reassuringly that the operation was routine and the patient nearly always goes home the same day.

headline: A Snack Endorsed by the Walrus and the Carpenter
abstract: For happy hour or late at night at the wine bar Upholstery Store.
lead_paragraph: Canadian oysters, east and west coast at $1 each, are the happy-hour and late-night snack at the Upholstery Store, Kurt Gutenbrunner’s wine bar. Pay more and you can have them elaborately garnished with raw tuna and caviar, sea urchin with pickled cabbage, cucumber and mint or passion fruit with seaweed. Alongside, consider wines suggested by Leo Schneemann, the sommelier and manager: Oysters, $1 each; garnished, two for $7, from 5 to 7 p.m. and after 10:30 p.m., Upholstery Store, 713 Washington Street (11th Street), 212-929-6384, upholsterystore-ny.com.

headline: Smoked Fish and Brisket in Brooklyn
abstract: Two brothers searching for the delicatessens they loved in childhood.
lead_paragraph: The brothers Zach and Alex Frankel were reared on the Upper West Side of Manhattan but live in Brooklyn now and missed the local smoked fish emporiums of their childhood. So they are doing something about it: opening on Saturday on the border between Williamsburg and Greenpoint their own version of the appetizing shops they love. Zach Frankel has been in the restaurant business as a manager and chef; his brother’s career has been in music. Together, as they put it, they’re “paying homage to Barney Greengrass, Murray’s and Russ & Daughters,” with the usual white glazed tiles and old family photos. In addition to selling smoked fish, pastrami, bagels and bialys, they have a chef, Ashley Berman, chopping chicken livers, making matzo ball soup and braising brisket based on a recipe from Anita Frankel, the brothers’ grandmother, for fork-tender beef, a tad sweet in the older generation tradition: Frankel’s Delicatessen & Appetizing, 631 Manhattan Avenue (Bedford Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-389-2302, frankelsdelicatessen.com.

headline: In the Aftermath of a Smokehouse Fire, a Small Happy Result
abstract: Three salamis from the Tuscan chef Cesare Casella.
lead_paragraph: When a fire in January destroyed the smokehouse at S. Wallace Edwards & Sons in Virginia, many heritage pork producers were left with an oversupply. Chefs and ham and sausage makers jumped in to buy and use the pork, including Cesare Casella, the Tuscan chef. Currently without a restaurant, he has expanded a line of salamis made for him by Giorgio’s Salami and Sausage, and he’s working on cured ham. For now, there is a meaty, peppery Salametto Dolce, a Salametto Piccante with persistent heat, and a coarser, sweetly herbaceous Finocchiella: Cesare Casella Salamis, $39 for two one-pound pieces, $59 for a sampler of all three from Heritage Foods, 718-389-0985, heritagefoodsusa.com.

headline: Morning Agenda: Ethereum Challenges Bitcoin
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Law Schools', 'MICROSOFT CORP', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Virtual Currency']
abstract: Yahoo and the Buyback Mirage | Law Graduate Who Sued Her School Loses at Trial
lead_paragraph: ETHEREUM CHALLENGES BITCOIN | A new virtual gold rush is under way. Ethereum, a rival to Bitcoin, has soared in value and climbed 1,000 percent over the last three months,Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Ethereum’s rise has attracted attention from giants like JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft and IBM.

headline: New York Today: Magic in Midtown
abstract: Monday: Inspired by Houdini, Mexican dance, and must-see illusionists.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:38 p.m.

headline: Malaysia’s Immigrant Worker Debate
abstract: The country’s powerful economy has drawn in millions of foreigners, at the cost of sharp social tensions.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — On a recent weekend excursion out of the city, I stopped for coffee at a cluster of roadside shops selling refreshments for travelers heading to the jungle-shrouded highlands that form the spine of Malaysia. A young man was sweeping the small yard outside the outbuilding that housed the restrooms; he was the janitor and handyman, he said, but he was wary when I tried to strike up a conversation.

headline: Man Arrested as ‘Third Bomber’ in Brussels Attack Is Freed; Hunt Is Renewed
abstract: The police, appealing to the public for help, said the real assailant remained at large.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A noisy citizen journalist who reveled in verbal and physical fights in public spaces, Fayçal Cheffou never quite fit the profile of a furtive underground operative for the Islamic State. Yet that was the role assigned to him when the Belgian authorities announced that he had been charged with terrorism and the Belgian news media identified him as the “third bomber” at Brussels Airport in last Tuesday’s attacks.

headline: Trump's New World Disorder
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump thinks America is being ripped off and NATO is obsolete, but war in Estonia or the East China Sea could be the biggest rip-off of all.
lead_paragraph: Goodbye to all that. Now we know that Donald Trump would rip up the post-1945 world order, trash an “obsolete” NATO, lean toward a Japan with nukes rather than the “one-sided agreement” that leaves the United States responsible for Japanese defense, tell Saudi Arabia that it “wouldn’t be around for very long” without American protection, and generally make clear that “we cannot be the policeman of the world.”

headline: The Benefits of Spicing Up a Breast-Feeding Mother’s Diet
abstract: Children who were nursed as babies may accept more foods later because they’ve experienced a variety of flavors from the start.
lead_paragraph: When I had my children I felt that there was a tendency by experts, including those in my own pediatric profession, to push certain principles that took all the fun out of life. This played out for me, in particular, after I gave birth to my first child, and was told as part of my breast-feeding “support” that I should avoid all spicy foods, because they would upset the baby. Like any good Cambridge, Mass., mother, I turned this into an argument about multiculturalism (“What about the mothers in Sichuan?”), but what I really thought was that it harked back to some old ideas about spices heating up the blood, and generally making life too interesting for the nursing mother.

headline: Bracing for Further Side Effects of an Increasingly Toxic Mix
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republican presidential primary turned surreal over the past week as Donald J. Trump threatened to “spill the beans” about the wife of his rival Ted Cruz and reposted side-by-side photographs making an unflattering comparison of her with his own wife.
lead_paragraph: In the past week, the Republican presidential primary has gone from the sober to the surreal. There is now a little over a week before a pivotal contest in Wisconsin, and the candidates will be focusing more and more attention on the state governed by Scott Walker, one of their former rivals.

headline: Schools Are Slow to Learn That Sleep Deprivation Hits Teenagers Hardest
keywords: ['Sleep', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Younger people need more sleep than adults, and they face antiquated school schedules.
lead_paragraph: As a pediatrician, I find that there are few topics that parents want to discuss more than sleep. Parents worry about their own sleep deprivation when babies arrive. Later, they worry about their children’s. I almost never encounter patients who are convinced that they’re getting the recommended amount of sleep.

headline: Why Your Perfume No Longer Reeks
abstract: It’s a phenomenon known as olfactory adaptation, or odor fatigue, which occurs with continuous exposure to a smell.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do we become desensitized to a perfume we are wearing while others can still smell it?

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The subsidiary, which provides information technology services to hospitals and governments, is being sold in preparation for Dell’s takeover of EMC.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dell has agreed to sell its Perot Systems subsidiary, which provides information technology services to hospitals and governments, to the Japanese technology company NTT Data for almost $3.1 billion, NTT Data said in a regulatory filing on Monday.

headline: Q. and A.: Duncan Clark on ‘Alibaba: The House Jack Ma Built’
abstract: Mr. Clark’s new book explores how Mr. Ma built the Chinese e-commerce platform that is now one of the world’s most valuable companies.
lead_paragraph: Duncan Clark is known in Beijing as a savvy commentator on China’s rapidly morphing tech world. A British citizen who first came to China in 1994, he learned the language and stayed for two decades. His background as an investment banker specializing in telecommunications at Morgan Stanley in London and Hong Kong helped him understand in the mid-1990s that the China market was about to take off.

headline: Israel Changes Tack After Standoff With Brazil Over Dani Dayan
abstract: Plans to name the former settler leader as envoy to the South American nation were dropped after Brasília refused to approve the appointment.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After a monthslong diplomatic standoff with Brazil over plans to install a former settler leader as its ambassador there, Israel pulled back on Monday — reassigning him to a post in the United States after the government in Brasília refused to approve his appointment.

headline: Kale-Romaine Caesar Salad
abstract: Kale gives this tangy Caesar salad staying power.
lead_paragraph: Kale gives this tangy Caesar salad staying power.

headline: For a Better Caesar, Get Kale Into the Mix
abstract: The sturdy green, added to romaine, produces an updated classic that can keep awhile. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: The Caesar, done right, is a multiplatform salad. Beyond the taste of the thing — which is spectacular — it is experienced across all the senses, a riot of contrasts, cold and crunch.

headline: Keen Pain in Pakistan Over Lives ‘Shattered Into Pieces’
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Terrorism', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']

lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Riaz Masih and Nasreen Riasat had been married for four years, with their first child on the way in just a month, when they decided a slow walk in the park would be just the thing to enjoy a pleasant Sunday evening in Lahore.

headline: 1916: French Shatter German Attack
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: French shatter German attack at Haucourt-Malancourt, near Verdun, in 1916.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Though the Germans have not entirely given up the struggle in the Verdun theatre, their attacks have lost the ‘‘bite’’ which they once had. The Crown Prince yesterday flung his troops against the French Haucourt-Malancourt lines west of the Meuse, but the French communiqué states that ‘‘the successive waves of the assault’’ were repulsed at every point. If the Crown Prince is seeking to bolster up the German people’s illusion that there is yet hope for the success of his Verdun offensive, he must attempt something much bigger and more serious than yesterday’s half-hearted attack. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 29, 1916

headline: Dealers Report Strong Sales at Art Basel Hong Kong
abstract: Sales appeared to be strong at the fourth edition of Art Basel Hong Kong, despite concerns about the impact of the recent economic slowdown in China on the international art market.

headline: Republican Rivals Talk Tough, but Even Presidents Have Limits

lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, has proposed surveilling Muslim neighborhoods. His chief rival, Donald J. Trump, says he would deport millions of undocumented immigrants and allow the use of torture. The campaign has also produced calls for carpet bombing in Syria and steps to rein in the press at home.

headline: For Ivanka Trump, It’s a Boy — Donald’s Eighth Grandchild
abstract: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential front-runner, became a grandfather for an eighth time when his daughter, Ivanka, gave birth to her third child. She and her husband, Jared Kushner, named the boy Theodore James.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump now has a “Ted” in his life … a Ted he actually likes.

headline: Trade Deficits: These Times are Different
abstract: Sometimes mercantilism isn’t wrong.
lead_paragraph: Neil Irwin has a good think piece on Trumpism and the trade deficit; but as Dean Baker rightly suggests, it arguably suffers a bit from being a discussion of the effects of trade deficits in normal times. And these times aren’t normal.

headline: Making the Technology of the Future Work Today
abstract: Silicon Valley is busy integrating virtual reality, artificial intelligence and other tech into everyday life, but it will take time to figure out how.
lead_paragraph: “I stood alone in an empty room beside a ferocious dinosaur,” writes Brian X. Chen. He isn’t happy about it. Yet.

headline: Oculus Rift Review: A Clunky Portal to a Promising Virtual Reality

lead_paragraph: A dream of science fiction, which is how Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg describes virtual reality, is about to come true.

headline: Chinese Writer in Germany Says 3 Siblings Are Detained Over Xi Letter

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A liberal Chinese writer living in Germany has said security officers in China detained three members of his family in connection with a mysterious online letter that denounced the iron-fisted rule of President Xi Jinping.

headline: Happily Ever After, Locked and Loaded: N.R.A. Fairy Tales
abstract: The N.R.A. is reimagining stories like “Hansel and Gretel” to familiarize children with guns.
lead_paragraph: Standing your ground just got much easier for Hansel and Gretel. The National Rifle Association’s rewritten version of the children’s fairy tale has the two young innocents packing rifles as they come upon the witch’s gingerbread house. (The tale doesn’t say whether the rifles are rapid-fire Bushmasters with 30-shot banana clips of ammunition, as at the real-life Sandy Hook school massacre where 20 children were murdered.) “Gretel stood at the ready with her firearm just in case, for she was a better shot than her brother,” reports the reworked account, which ends happily with no gun play.

headline: Mélanie Defize, Brussels Victim, Was a Music Lover With a ‘Candid Smile’
abstract: Ms. Defize, 29, a producer at an independent label in the city, was a baroque violinist who contributed articles to an opera-focused publication.
lead_paragraph: Mélanie Defize lived for music.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In a striking defeat to religious conservatives, Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia said Monday that he would veto a bill intended to protect critics of same-sex marriage.

headline: Review: Rihanna on Tour, Part Preacher, Part Dominatrix, All Human
abstract: In the first of two sold-out shows at Barclays Center on her world tour for her album “Anti,” Rihanna proved to be the most present she has ever been onstage.
lead_paragraph: There wasn’t much to look at in terms of set design during Rihanna’s Sunday-night concert at Barclays Center in Brooklyn. Oversized plastic cocoons throbbed with pulsing air on either side of the stage. About two-thirds into the show, a huge shower curtain dropped from the ceiling; for a while, it displayed multicolored psychedelic swirls, and shortly after, foam came tumbling down it from the top, as if Rihanna had let the world’s largest washing machine overflow.

headline: How Often Terror Attacks Strike Pakistan
abstract: The suicide bombing in Lahore, Pakistan, on Sunday is only one of dozens of attacks that have killed hundreds of civilians in Pakistan in recent years, with the Taliban or its splinter groups claiming responsibility for many.
lead_paragraph: The suicide bombing in Lahore, Pakistan, on Sunday is only one of dozens of attacks that have killed hundreds of civilians in Pakistan in recent years, with the Taliban or its splinter groups claiming responsibility for many.

headline: 1966: Soviet Congress Bars Critic

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Alexander T. Tvardovsky, the most important spokesman for liberal Soviet artists and writers, apparently has lost his influence in the inner circles of the Communist party, according to indications on the eve of the opening of the 23d congress.

headline: A Monogram as Skillfully Made as the Suitcase It Adorns
abstract: For the next month, NYC-based illustrators will hand-paint custom fonts onto the young label’s new carry-on.
lead_paragraph: To create the first carry-on in their new luggage line, Away Travel, Jen Rubio and Steph Korey remember going through 20 different wheel designs before choosing the almost-silent Japanese Hinomoto 360-degree spinners. And the suitcase’s other features (among them: a built-in battery for iPhone charging, waterproof zippers, a removable laundry bag and an embedded TSA-approved lock) are as carefully considered. For the next month, three NYC-based illustrators — Scott Biersack, Alaina Sullivan and Jen Mussari — are on hand to customize the design with hand-painted initials. “Monogramming to me, as a kid, was L.L. Bean,” says Mussari, whose lettering typically takes cues from sign-painting and ’50s automotive racing. She and the other artists made fonts specifically for the project. “The style represents both my interests and the brand’s connection to speed.”

headline: Scientists Find a Way to Predict U.S. Heat Waves Weeks in Advance
abstract: A pattern of ocean temperatures in the Pacific significantly raises the odds of extreme heat in the eastern United States as much as 50 days later.
lead_paragraph: Deadly summer heat waves in the eastern United States may be predictable nearly two months before they occur, giving emergency planners and farmers more time to prepare, scientists reported on Monday.

headline: Jill Abramson, Former New York Times Editor, to Write Guardian Column

headline: 13 Great Recipes for Right Now
abstract: The perfect Caesar salad, a drink with activated charcoal and more for the week.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Gangs']

headline: Sprawling Mural Pays Homage to Cairo’s Garbage Collectors
abstract: The artist eL Seed used more than 50 buildings as his canvas to celebrate the Egyptian capital’s trash collectors, who are largely viewed as second-class citizens.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The intricate mural took shape over the past few weeks, little noticed at first, spreading across a harried quarter of Cairo where Egypt’s garbage collectors live, amid overflowing bundles of this overcrowded city’s trash.

headline: Yana Gilbuena Goes Around the World on a Sharp Blade
abstract: For a Filipino chef making pop-up dinners all over, the travel-ready mandoline is a must.
lead_paragraph: Yana Gilbuena is dreaming of banana leaves in Antarctica, heaped with a feast of chicken feet, pork intestines and crab-fat rice.

headline: Martin Gardner’s Favorite Funny Quickies
abstract: Let’s test our logical funny bone with 30 morsels of misdirection from recreational mathematician Martin Gardner.
lead_paragraph: Happy April Fools Week! Let’s celebrate this ancient tradition with a sampling of favorite foolish puzzles by the late recreational mathematician Martin Gardner. The series was originally featured in Issue 28 (April 1983) of the The Four Star Puzzler and is used with generous permission of the publisher. (Check out Games World of Puzzles at their website here.)

headline: Alex Lee, Former Chef at Daniel, Joins Starr Restaurants
abstract: After dropping out of sight, a marquee chef returns to run a growing empire of kitchens.
lead_paragraph: When Alex Lee resigned his pressure-cooker position as executive chef at Daniel in 2003 to become the executive chef at Glen Oaks country club in Old Westbury, N.Y., he may as well have gone to Mars. A high-profile star seemed to have left the picture.

headline: Sherpa: They Die, We Go Home
abstract: In just a few weeks, hundreds of climbers from around the world will descend on Everest. Now is the time to address the longstanding and pervasive exploitation of Sherpa by the international climbing community.
lead_paragraph: The morning of the avalanche was quiet. It was still unseasonably cold at base camp but the stiff winds had loosened, and for the first time in a week I felt healthy. I knocked the frost off of my sleeping bag and headed to the mess tent for a cup of instant coffee. It was April 18, 2014. Our team was scheduled to set off from base camp at first light for an acclimatization climb through the Khumbu Icefall, but we were still recovering from a dhal bhat-induced gastrointestinal disaster of the variety that makes you miss your mom. We decided to stay put another day.

headline: Tough Re-election for G.O.P. Moderate Is Getting Tougher
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

headline: A Literary House Keeps the Village Spirit Alive
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'National Book Awards', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House, home to N.Y.U.’s Creative Writing Program, is an artistic enclave where one might find Jonathan Safran Foer eating a sandwich, or Sharon Olds having tea.
lead_paragraph: Light radiated from the large, leaded front window of 58 West 10th Street on Thursday night, as it does most Thursdays and Fridays. Books and journals spanned the windowsill, and a soft yellow garland of stained glass framed the back of a man’s head. Up the stoop and inside, under another rope of vines sculpted into the ceiling, the voice of Major Jackson filled the parlor as he read poems from his collection “Roll Deep.”

headline: Wall Street Scion Is Accused of Faking Investments

headline: In 2 Minutes, Bangladesh Rejects 28-Year-Old Challenge to Islam’s Role
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Religion and Belief', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The High Court dismissed a petition, filed in 1988, that aimed to remove the designation of Islam as the state religion and struck a nerve among Bangladeshis.

headline: Learning to Take Responsibility When Things Go Wrong
abstract: It’s common to blame others for our problems, but that reaction doesn’t solve anything. It’s more valuable to learn from your mistakes.
