headline: A Singer-Songwriter Changes His Name — and His Perspective
abstract: Listen to an exclusive new track from Soren Juul, the artist formerly known as Indians.
lead_paragraph: The Danish singer-songwriter Soren Juul isn’t afraid to mix things up. After scoring a solo hit in 2013 with the album “Somewhere Else,” recorded under the pseudonym Indians, Juul returns this summer with his first album under his own name, “This Moment,” out June 17. “With a moniker, it’s kind of like you’re protecting yourself,” says Juul, whose spare yet evocative songs have garnered comparisons to Bon Iver and M83. “I don’t really need the safety net anymore.”

headline: Let Them Make Noise: A ‘Dining Club’ Invites Toddlers
abstract: For parents who have given up dining in fancy restaurants, Nibble and Squeak offers a chance to eat in style with the children.
lead_paragraph: There are many things to love about my toddler daughters (ages 20 months and almost 4 years), but dining out together is not one of them. My husband and I take them to the local diner or Mexican restaurant every Saturday night because I need a break from cooking, and the girls have to learn how to dine out.

headline: Using Apps to Ease the Headache of Navigating Airports
abstract: Smartphone apps like one from American Airlines are part of a trend to give travelers customized information and turn-by-turn directions at airports worldwide.
lead_paragraph: For Brett Fox, just getting around an airport could be difficult enough. From check-in to security lines to finding a meal that he actually wants, it added stress to the journey.

headline: U.S. Anti-Gang Sweep Yields Over 1,100 Arrests
abstract: Most of those arrested were part of “sophisticated organizations” that traffic guns, drugs and people across United States borders, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have arrested more than 1,100 people since February as part of an enforcement campaign against gangs that traffic guns, drugs and people across United States borders, officials said.

headline: In the Major Leagues, Female Scouts Are Few. Their Skills Aren’t.
abstract: Some women with an eye for baseball talent have been overlooked, including part-time scouts who worked during a long stretch when M.L.B. had no female full-timers.
lead_paragraph: When the Seattle Mariners hired 22-year-old Amanda Hopkins in December, it was widely reported that she was the first full-time female scout employed by a Major League Baseball team since the 1950s — which seems to be true.

headline: Lauriane Visart, 27, Belgian Lawyer, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Many Belgians got to know Ms. Visart, who was killed in a suicide attack at the Maelbeek subway station, after her father gave a moving interview.
lead_paragraph: Lauriane Visart was intent on using her law degree for the public good.

headline: At 84, an Artist Tries Something New: Displaying His Work
abstract: The sculptor Arthur Kern has been working in isolation for decades. Now he has his first solo show since the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — One of the benefits when people think that you are dead is that you do not have to attend social occasions. This is how Arthur Kern sees it, though he has been so detached from local art circles for so long that he was unaware that some of his former colleagues had assumed the worst.

headline: Wisconsin Radio Host’s Combative Interview Surprises Donald Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s radio interview with Charlie Sykes, a popular host in Milwaukee, went downhill quickly after Mr. Sykes admonished Mr. Trump that “here in Wisconsin we value things like civility, decency and actual conservative principles.”
lead_paragraph: Charlie Sykes, a popular radio host in Milwaukee, welcomed Donald J. Trump to his state in a phone interview on his program on Monday, explaining that “here in Wisconsin we value things like civility, decency and actual conservative principles.”

headline: Chicago Teenager in Video Against Gun Violence Is Shot and Wounded
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Youth', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control', 'Firearms']
abstract: Zarriel Trotter, 13, who appeared in an award-winning video about the effect of gun violence on the city’s black youth, was hit in the back by a stray bullet, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old Chicago boy who appeared in an award-winning public service video about the effect of gun violence on the city’s black youth was shot in the back and critically wounded, officials said Monday.

headline: ‘Barbara Cook: Then and Now’ Is Postponed Off Broadway
abstract: Ms. Cook’s one-woman show that was scheduled to begin performances on April 12, has been postponed.
lead_paragraph: “Barbara Cook: Then and Now,” the Broadway star’s one-woman show that was scheduled to begin performances on April 12, has been postponed.

headline: Gilding the Croissant With Nutella, or Olives and Rosemary
abstract: At Épicerie Boulud, 3 new versions of the classic French pastry.
lead_paragraph: Don’t call François Brunet, Daniel Boulud’s baker, a purist when it comes to croissants. His flaky, buttery standard-bearer, which has long been sold plain or with almonds, now comes filled and iced with Nutella (ramping up the classic pain au chocolat) and in a savory Provençal version, with black olives and rosemary, perfect alongside some good yogurt or goat cheese for breakfast or lunch. There’s also a raspberry-chocolate version: Croissants, $3.25 to $4.25 at Épicerie Boulud, 1900 Broadway (64th Street) and Plaza Food Hall, 1 West 59th Street, epicerieboulud.com.

headline: A Challenge to Soccer’s Version of Solitary Confinement
abstract: A European player is challenging a practice known as training alone, soccer’s version of solitary confinement, in which a player is forced to accept an employer’s demands or endure a punitive regimen.
lead_paragraph: TIRANA, Albania — Sebino Plaku, a player for the Polish professional soccer team Slask Wroclaw, sat across a small desk from the club’s president and vice president.

headline: Visiting the World of Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen: On The Row’s Instagram
abstract: The only social media presence for the previously ubiquitous pair is through the Instagram account for their fashion line.
lead_paragraph: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen have been famous since before they could talk. In the three decades since, they’ve never identified as any one thing, choosing instead to market themselves as two golden girls who might, under the right circumstances, show up at your slumber party.

headline: Sean Combs to Open Charter School in Harlem
abstract: The hip-hop mogul known as Diddy steered the creation of the Capital Prep Harlem school, scheduled to open in fall 2016, he said.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul known as Diddy, steered the creation of the Capital Prep Harlem school, scheduled to open in fall 2016, he said on Monday.

headline: Drilling Is Making Oklahoma as Quake Prone as California
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: The chance of a destructive temblor in the next year is as great in parts of Oklahoma and Kansas as it is in California.
lead_paragraph: Californians have lived with the risk of a damaging earthquake for centuries. Now Oklahomans, and some Kansans, face the same threat, federal seismologists said on Monday.

headline: Raghavendran Ganesan, Father Saving to Return to India, Dies in Brussels Attack
abstract: The 30-year-old software engineer’s family had appealed to Indian officials and others via social media in a frantic search for their lost relative.
lead_paragraph: A photograph of Raghavendran Ganesan, 30, on Facebook shows the software engineer at his wedding in 2014, embracing his bride, his neck adorned with garlands as flower petals filled the air surrounding the couple.

headline: Police at U.S. Capitol Shoot Man With Gun at Screening Point
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Assaults']
abstract: The Capitol was locked down for about an hour afterward, and the man was taken to a hospital. A woman was also injured.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The police on Monday shot a man who pointed a gun at them in a screening area just outside the United States Capitol, briefly unnerving the city a week after the bombings in Brussels.

headline: Saudis Announce Prisoner Swap With Houthis in Yemen Conflict
abstract: It was only the second publicly announced prisoner swap since the Saudis’ intervention a year ago, and by far the biggest, ahead of a planned April 10 cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia announced a large prisoner swap on Monday with its Houthi rebel adversaries in the Yemen war — 109 Yemenis for nine Saudis — in what appeared to be meant as a signal that the two sides would honor a cease-fire planned for April 10.

headline: Pandora’s Worrisome Sign: Return of the Founder as C.E.O.
abstract: Technology companies that turn back to their creators have a mixed track record.
lead_paragraph: Pandora sent a bad signal Monday when it said Brian McAndrews, its chief executive, had been replaced by Tim Westergren, its co-founder, in a worrisome sign amid news that the streaming-music service might be for sale. Technology companies that turn back to their creators later in life also have a mixed track record.

headline: Using a Hardware Keyboard With an Android Device
abstract: Typing on a glass screen is not for everyone, but you can link a portable keyboard to your Android tablet for heavy-duty data entry.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do you make an external keyboard work with an Android tablet?

headline: Selling More Cars in China
abstract: Automakers have been expanding manufacturing in China as the market there has been booming. Although car sales are projected to rise again this year, the Chinese economy has been slowing down, which could extend to a slowdown in the car market.
lead_paragraph: Automakers have been expanding manufacturing in China as the market there has been booming. Although car sales are projected to rise again this year, the Chinese economy has been slowing down, which could extend to a slowdown in the car market.

headline: Automakers Expanding in China May Soon Face Weakening Demand
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Consumer Behavior', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: China is the world’s largest market for new cars, but its slowing economy could leave automakers with too many factories and not enough buyers.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The new $1.3 billion Cadillac factory on the outskirts of Shanghai is a shrine to modern manufacturing, the kind of facility that automakers all over the world dream of building but can seldom afford.

headline: Study of Theranos Medical Tests Finds Irregular Results
abstract: A report published in The Journal of Clinical Investigation compared blood test results from Theranos with some from two large laboratories.
lead_paragraph: Finger blood tests from Theranos, the medical start-up, produced more irregular results than conventional tests offered by the nation’s two largest clinical laboratories, researchers reported Monday in the first published independent assessment of the company’s tests.

headline: After Fatal Bombing in Pakistan Park
abstract: Residents and government officials weighed in on a suicide bombing in the Gulshan-e-Iqbal Park in Lahore, Pakistan, on Easter that killed 69 people.
lead_paragraph: Residents and government officials weighed in on a suicide bombing in the Gulshan-e-Iqbal Park in Lahore, Pakistan, on Easter that killed 69 people.

headline: Vietnam’s Battle With Tuberculosis
abstract: A country’s stunning progress against tuberculosis may be threatened by reduced support for a health care system stretched thin.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, VIETNAM — Dr. Bui Xuan Hiep, the head of tuberculosis control in this city’s Hoang Mai district, paged proudly through a large handwritten patient log.

headline: The Story Behind Petra Collins’s Most Beloved (and Strange-Looking) Possession
abstract: Emily Spivack interviews creative types about their favorite objects, including this one out-of-place candlestick that illuminates the photographer’s past.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: ‘Dinosaurs Among Us’ Retraces an Evolutionary Path
abstract: An exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History documents the recently established link between dinosaurs and modern birds.
lead_paragraph: At a preview of the new American Museum of Natural History exhibition “Dinosaurs Among Us,” scientists gave a tip of the hat to Thomas Henry Huxley, the man who proposed in the 1860s that dinosaurs never really vanished from Earth. Most did go extinct, but their evolutionary legacy lives all around us. They are birds, all 18,000 species of them.

headline: A National Monument in Utah
abstract: A tribal leader writes that “we do not view our ancestral homeland as a battleground between state and federal control.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Broadway Enjoys a Spring Fling at the Box Office
abstract: Thirteen musicals each grossed more than $1 million for the week, and “Waitress” got off to a strong start in previews.
lead_paragraph: Spring has arrived on Broadway, financially as well as seasonally.

headline: Lincoln Brigade Homage
abstract: John McCain’s tribute to some unrecognized heroes was well deserved, a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: All We Like Sheep
abstract: A reader takes issue with an opera’s use of sheep.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis
abstract: A financial adviser to the island’s creditors writes that any restructuring must help preserve its access to the capital markets.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Former Head of Honduran Federation Pleads Guilty in FIFA Case
abstract: Rafael Callejas admitted in federal court in Brooklyn that he had solicited and accepted bribes from businessmen who sought media and marketing rights.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Callejas, a former president of Honduras who was accused of taking bribes in his role as president of that country’s soccer federation, pleaded guilty on Monday in the United States’ world-soccer corruption case.

headline: Valeant’s Accounting Error a Warning Sign of Bigger Problems
abstract: Investors have other reasons to remain concerned about the accuracy of the company’s financial statements.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International’s accounting confession may have sounded like a rounding error.

headline: Zika Study Could Help Overcome an Obstacle to Vaccine Research
abstract: Scientists describe a type of immune-deficient mice that lost weight, became lethargic and died when infected with Zika.
lead_paragraph: The first new mouse model in which the Zika virus can be tested was described in a medical journal on Monday.

headline: Affymetrix to Stick With Thermo Fisher’s Takeover Proposal
abstract: After examining a new offer from Origin Technologies, Affymetrix concluded that Thermo Fisher’s bid, while $3 a share lower, remained superior.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — What briefly appeared to be a potential bidding war for Affymetrix, a genetics analysis technology maker, fizzled out on Monday after the company chose to stick with a takeover bid from Thermo Fisher Scientific over a higher bid from a Chinese-backed suitor.

headline: Intrigue Surrounds Absence of Mets’ Matt Harvey
abstract: General Manager Sandy Alderson said Harvey would miss a spring training start because of a “nonbaseball medical issue,” and Manager Terry Collins said Harvey’s arm was fine.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The Mets had everyone on their major league roster take the 40-mile trip here on Monday for the team’s final Florida road game of spring training. It was a tradition, designed to be a bonding experience with opening day less than a week away.

headline: Review: ‘Pioneers!#goforth,’ Presented From the Ceiling
abstract: Actors in William Burke’s play describe futile searches for authenticity and originality, while dangling in a rope net.
lead_paragraph: Outside, the daffodils have blossomed, and new leaves are unfurling from the trees. But inside the performance space Jack in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, blizzard conditions prevail. During William Burke’s sometimes interesting and sometimes exasperating “Pioneers!#goforth,” swirling snowflakes coat the hair, bags and sweaters of the assembled crowd.

headline: Serena Williams and Andy Murray Fall at Miami Open
abstract: Not even Williams, the hometown favorite and three-time defending champion, or Murray, the No. 2 men’s player, was immune to the spate of bad luck at this year’s Miami Open.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Not even the hometown favorite and three-time defending champion, Serena Williams, or the men’s No. 2 player, Andy Murray, is immune to the spate of bad luck that has befallen players at this year’s Miami Open.

headline: Review: Four Days of Luigi Nono in ‘Utopian Listening’
abstract: The conference, at Tufts University, included three electroacoustic concerts.
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass. — Even in contemporary music circles, Luigi Nono remains a peripheral presence. Rectifying that was the aim of “Utopian Listening,” a fruitful conference held from Wednesday to Saturday at the Granoff Music Center at Tufts University here, with cosponsorship from Harvard.

headline: CNN Hires David Gregory as Political Analyst as 2016 Campaign Heats Up
abstract: Mr. Gregory, the former “Meet the Press” host, will focus on “New Day” for the network, which also hired Angela Rye, formerly of the Congressional Black Caucus, as a commentator.
lead_paragraph: David Gregory, who endured a long and difficult exit from his perch as the host of NBC’s “Meet the Press,” is returning to a regular role on television as a political analyst on CNN, the network announced on Monday.

headline: Review: ‘Solos’ Features Four Women in Works Reflecting the Arab World
abstract: Marie Al Fajr, Mona Gamil, Leyya Mona Tawil and Amira Chebli presented this dance program at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: The very news of a program of four female soloists in various ways linked to, or deriving from, Egypt, Syria and Tunisia was tantalizing. How many here know much about the dance of those countries? How many here have experienced the creativity of the women there?

headline: 1954 | In Harm’s Way on Capitol Hill
abstract: Two Times correspondents were not just witnesses to a shooting in the Capitol. One was slightly injured. The other helped a wounded congressman.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a metro reporter, looks back at The Times’s coverage of — and involvement in — a shooting on Capitol Hill in 1954.

headline: Caucuses, the Media and ‘America First’
abstract: Readers share their views of the political landscape.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Lab Girl,’ Hope Jahren’s Road Map to the Secret Life of Plants
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Ms. Jahren’s book, at its best, does for botany what Oliver Sacks’s essays did for neurology, what Stephen Jay Gould’s writings did for paleontology.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Nabokov once observed that “a writer should have the precision of a poet and the imagination of a scientist.” The geobiologist Hope Jahren possesses both in spades. Her engrossing new memoir, “Lab Girl,” is at once a thrilling account of her discovery of her vocation and a gifted teacher’s road map to the secret lives of plants — a book that, at its best, does for botany what Oliver Sacks’s essays did for neurology, what Stephen Jay Gould’s writings did for paleontology.

headline: An Appraisal: Taking Big Bites of Jim Harrison’s Voracious Life
abstract: Mr. Harrison’s hungers and how he satisfied them spill out in his prose and poetry.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t read the fiction of Jim Harrison, who died on Saturday at 78, for plot. You read it for its appetites. Mr. Harrison was our poet laureate of lumbering desire. His books declared: If you aren’t taking big bites out of whatever life is on offer to you, you are doing it wrong.

headline: LCD Soundsystem, Split Up in 2011, Joins the Reunion Circuit
abstract: The band played on Sunday at Webster Hall, the first of two shows before a headlining set in April at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.
lead_paragraph: With all the right fanfare, the celebrated dance-rock act LCD Soundsystem called it quits in 2011. There was the momentous farewell announcement; a run of sold-out shows, including a three-hour-plus spectacle at Madison Square Garden; and a documentary, “Shut Up and Play the Hits,” chronicling the heartache with which the frontman, James Murphy, decided to step away from the stage, seemingly forever.

headline: For Syracuse, Four Victories but Little Vindication
abstract: Could a team like Valparaiso be in the Final Four if it, instead of the Orange, had received an at-large N.C.A.A. tournament berth? We’ll never know.
lead_paragraph: Tenth-seeded Syracuse’s rise from a team that many thought did not merit a spot in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament to a surprise Final Four participant — the result of its 68-62 upset of top-seeded Virginia on Sunday night — deserves every ounce of marvel being thrown its way.

headline: U.S. Says It Has Unlocked iPhone Without Apple
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'iPhone']
abstract: The Justice Department announcement, in a court filing, ends an immediate legal battle over the San Bernardino shooting case but raises questions about Apple’s security.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Justice Department said on Monday that it had found a way to unlock an iPhone without help from Apple, allowing the agency to withdraw its legal effort to compel the tech company to assist in a mass-shooting investigation.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Supreme Court Skeptical on a Speedy Trial Argument
abstract: A Montana man’s lawyer argued that the 14 months he spent waiting to be sentenced on a bail-jumping conviction violated his Sixth Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brandon T. Betterman pleaded guilty to jumping bail in the spring of 2012. He spent the next 14 months in a Montana jail waiting to hear what his punishment would be.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Plants Remember You if You Mess With Them Enough
abstract: Scientists tried to test whether they could train a Mimosa pudica plant to change its behavior.
lead_paragraph: Plants are reviving after a long winter, helped along by warming temperatures and increased light.

headline: Fidel Castro Criticizes Barack Obama’s Efforts to Change Cuba
abstract: “We do not need the empire to give us anything,” the former president of Cuba wrote in Granma, the official Communist Party newspaper.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, offered a critical response on Monday to President Obama’s recent visit to his country, declaring that despite the warming relations between the two Cold War enemies, “we do not need the empire to give us anything.”

headline: Donald Trump Hires Paul Manafort to Lead Delegate Effort
abstract: Donald J. Trump, girding for a long battle over presidential delegates and a potential convention floor fight, has enlisted the veteran Republican strategist Paul J. Manafort to lead his delegate-corralling efforts, according to people briefed on the plans.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, girding for a long battle over presidential delegates and a potential floor fight at the Cleveland convention, has enlisted the veteran Republican strategist Paul J. Manafort to lead his delegate-corralling efforts, according to people briefed on Mr. Trump’s plans.

headline: Filing to Drop Case Against Apple
abstract: The Justice Department said that it had found a way to unlock an iPhone without help from Apple, allowing the agency to withdraw its legal effort to compel the company to assist in a mass-shooting investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said that it had found a way to unlock an iPhone without help from Apple, allowing the agency to withdraw its legal effort to compel the company to assist in a mass-shooting investigation.

headline: Peter Stanford, Steward of New York’s Maritime History, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Stanford left an advertising career to found the South Street Seaport Museum in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Peter Stanford, who turned a boyhood obsession with boats into a commitment to preserve the South Street Seaport and commemorate New York City’s maritime history with a museum and a parade of tall ships celebrating the nation’s bicentennial, died on Thursday in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Arizona Election Official Apologizes for Long Wait at Polls
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Anger bubbled over as Helen Purcell, who cut the number of polling places in Maricopa County to 60 from 200, spoke at a hearing at the State Capitol.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A protester was led off in handcuffs from the visitors’ gallery of the Arizona Legislature on Monday amid a fractious debate over Primary Day last week, when a drastic cutback in polling locations left tens of thousands of Arizonans unable to vote, forced to cast provisional ballots or made to wait in long lines for hours in the high heat.

headline: ESPN Steps Back From Authenticity of 1966 Texas Western Broadcast
abstract: After doubts were raised by a producer of a documentary on the historic victory, ESPN conceded it might be showing coaches’ or scouts’ film synchronized to a radio call.
lead_paragraph: ESPN backed away on Monday from its definitive claim that the version of the 1966 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship game it is showing Wednesday night is the actual television broadcast of Texas Western’s historic 72-65 victory over Kentucky.

headline: ‘Lula,’ Ex-President of Brazil, Lashes Out at Judge Overseeing Corruption Inquiry
abstract: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said the judge, Sergio Moro, was trying to ruin him by releasing intercepts of his telephone conversations.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on Monday accused the judge overseeing the investigation into the country’s colossal graft scandal of trying to ruin him by releasing intercepts of his telephone conversations.

headline: Pandora Replaces Chief, Aiming to Reinvent Itself Midstream
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Tim Westergren, a co-founder of Pandora, becomes chief executive as the online music company tries to regain its competitive edge.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media became a powerhouse in online music primarily by doing one thing: tailoring song after song to the tastes of its listeners, along with the occasional ad. For a decade, it worked well, as Pandora came to dominate Internet radio.

headline: Central African Republic: More Peacekeepers Accused
abstract: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, one involving the possible rape of a 14-year-old girl by Burundian soldiers, a spokesman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Monday. The spokesman, Stéphane Dujarric, told reporters at a daily briefing that the peacekeeping mission in the country had received the allegations on Friday. The other case, he said, involved a Moroccan peacekeeper’s relationship with a woman. None of the suspects were identified. The Central African Republic, one of the world’s most dysfunctional countries, has become an epicenter of sexual abuse allegations against United Nations peacekeepers, an issue that has tarnished their image as protectors of the helpless. The latest allegations came to light two weeks after the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution endorsing toughened discipline proposed by Mr. Ban against violators, including repatriation of entire contingents implicated in systematic abuse.

headline: Argentina: President Won’t Fund Leftist TV Network
abstract: Argentina’s president, Mauricio Macri, will cut its funding of a regional television network started by the Venezuelan government in 2005.
lead_paragraph: The pro-business administration of Argentina’s president, Mauricio Macri, will cut its funding of a regional television network started by the Venezuelan government in 2005. The country is pulling out of Telesur, a self-styled leftist alternative to mainstream media, because of a lack of “pluralism” and being shut out of financial decisions, the Communications Ministry in Argentina said. “Argentina was a partner prohibited from sharing our view,” Hermann Lombardi, the communications minister, said in a radio interview. Telesur was a pet project of Hugo Chávez, the former Venezuelan president, who envisioned a strong socialist voice to counteract what he perceived as unbalanced news coverage from major broadcasters like CNN’s Spanish service. In addition to Venezuela, sponsor countries include Bolivia, Cuba, Ecuador and Nicaragua. Relations between Argentina and Venezuela have deteriorated since Mr. Macri’s center-right government took office in December 2015. His predecessor, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, had maintained strong bonds with Mr. Chavez.

headline: In Emails, N.H.L. Officials Conceded Concussion Risks of Fights
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'Concussions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Exchanges between Commissioner Gary Bettman and his top lieutenants contradict what the league has said publicly in defending itself from players’ lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L.’s top officials have privately acknowledged that fighting could lead to concussions and long-term health problems, including depression, and that so-called enforcers frequently use pills “to ease the pain,” according to emails unsealed during a continuing court battle with former players.

headline: Federal Judge in Puerto Rico Calls Walmart Tax Unlawful
abstract: A federal court throws out the island’s new tax, saying a financial crisis is no reason to demand revenue it isn’t entitled to.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in San Juan on Monday threw out a new tax that Puerto Rico had tried to impose on the American retailing giant Walmart, calling it unlawful.

headline: Scenes From Palmyra Indicate ISIS Slowed Assault on Treasures
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Assyrian Civilization', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A day after Syrian troops recaptured the city, television footage showed severe damage to ancient sculptures. But there is hope that many works can be reconstructed.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As photographs and video footage emerged on Monday from the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra, antiquities experts were relieved and horrified at what Islamic State militants had wrought in the months they had controlled the city.

headline: Donald Trump’s Success Upends Battle for Control of Congress
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Republican lawmakers are trying to distance themselves from Mr. Trump, while Democrats seize on the chance to run against a candidate who has offended huge sections of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the Republican primary is upending the campaign for control of Congress, as Republican lawmakers seek to distance themselves from him while Democrats seize on the chance to run against a candidate who has offended huge sections of the American electorate.

headline: If You Want to Make a ‘Hamlet,’ You Have to Break Some Rules
abstract: If David Carl as Gary Busey as Hamlet is not exponential enough, the New York Shakespeare Exchange is offering “Hamlet” to the 10th power.
lead_paragraph: At any given moment in New York, Shakespeare is being reimagined somewhere, whether on a big stage or in a black box. Now, for instance, you can sample 11 alternative Hamlets for the price of two.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Dangerous Babble on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Donald Trump offers up disturbing, incoherent views on nuclear weapons and other national security issues.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump might use nuclear weapons to go after Islamic State terrorists. Or maybe not. In a recent spate of interviews, including with The Times, he was unable or unwilling to clarify his disturbing views on this and other critical national security issues, which sometimes shift from one minute to the next.

headline: Another Bombing, This Time in Pakistan
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Editorials', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The Pakistani government has long cynically used Taliban groups as proxy fighters.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s Taliban has struck again. The group Jamaat-e-Ahrar has claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing on Sunday in a park in Lahore crowded with families, including many Christians enjoying an Easter outing. The bomber set off his explosives near a swing set, killing at least 69 people and injuring more than 300 others.

headline: ValueAct Pays a Price for Its Supporting Role at Valeant
abstract: ValueAct deserves credit — or blame — for virtually everything that happened to Valeant Pharmaceuticals over nearly the last decade.
lead_paragraph: Bill Ackman gets a lot of ink and a lot of criticism as one of the largest investors behind the crisis-ridden Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

headline: A 16-Year-Old Boy Killed, and an East Harlem Neighborhood’s Grief
abstract: As relatives and friends tried to make sense of the killing of Juwan Tavarez, officials were investigating whether the killing was part of a dispute between rival crews.
lead_paragraph: Juwan Tavarez was sitting in the kitchen with his family in their East Harlem apartment on Friday afternoon when his mother sent him to the market. She was cooking a Good Friday feast of fish and rice but had run out of sugar for the habichuelas con dulce.

headline: $15-an-Hour Minimum Wage in California? Plan Has Some Worried

abstract: Supporters of the G.O.P. who are under 30 are much more likely to support a path to citizenship for immigrants in the United States illegally than older Republican voters, according to a survey published on Tuesday. That divide could mean trouble in the general election for either of the party’s leading candidates.
lead_paragraph: Young Republicans are much more likely to have favorable views of immigration and to support a path to citizenship for immigrants in the United States illegally than are older Republican voters, according to a survey  published on Tuesday by the Public Religion Research Institute, a nonpartisan research group. The divide could mean trouble in the general election for either of the two leading Republican candidates, Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, who have called for mass deportation of 11 million undocumented immigrants.

headline: Who’s ‘They’?
abstract: As English changes to accommodate people with nontraditional gender identities, the plural pronoun used as a singular is becoming more acceptable — but that doesn’t mean it’s always the right word.
lead_paragraph: We are witnessing a great explosion in the way that human beings are allowed to express their gender identities. We are also hearing a lot of awkward conversations. What are we supposed to ... call everyone? A recent scene on HBO’s “Girls” riffed on this problem, drawing a linguistic fault line down a Brooklyn street. On one side is a no-frills coffee joint run by Ray Ploshansky, the show’s resident grumpy old man. (He’s, like, 38.) Across the street, a hip new cafe springs up and instantly hoovers up Ray’s clientele.

headline: Why Airline Hijackings Became Relatively Rare

Terrorist hijackings were a later development, but after reaching a grim apex on Sept. 11, 2001, they have become less and less common.

abstract: A change in the nomination process opened the door to candidates who could attract grass-roots followings even if they repelled party leaders.
lead_paragraph: The closer Donald J. Trump draws to winning the Republican presidential nomination over opposition from party leaders, the more his detractors ask: How can this happen?

headline: China to Survey Children Left Behind by Migrant Workers
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Researchers say these children often suffer from anxiety and depression in the absence of their parents, and exhibit high rates of juvenile delinquency.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government plans to conduct the country’s first comprehensive survey of rural children left behind by parents who have migrated to cities in search of work, the China Youth Daily has reported.

headline: Yemen’s President: A Path to Peace
abstract: How to stop the Houthis and rebuild Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Aden, Yemen — One year into the intervention here by the Arab coalition led by Saudi Arabia, and backed by the Yemeni National Army, I can tell my people with confidence that we are working hard to restore peace. The Houthi rebels’ military position has been weakened, and peace talks will resume next month. A cease-fire is to begin on April 10, leading up to the talks. The Houthis must respect it.

headline: 1916: Torpedo To Be Used As Evidence
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Torpedo provides evidence that the Sussex was attacked by German submarine in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Proof that the Sussex was attacked by a German submarine will be offered to the United States by the British Admiralty in the shape of parts of the torpedo which exploded in the bows of the Channel steamer. Enough of the projectile has been found in the Sussex, which has been towed to Boulogne, to refute absolutely the theory that a floating mine did the damage. Beside this tangible evidence the Admiralty asserts that the British destroyer which picked up the survivors from the Channel steamer in the lifeboats at three o’clock on the morning after the attack, was twice fired on by the German submarine. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 30, 1916

headline: Children Pay ‘Highest Price’ as Yemen Falls Apart, U.N. Says
abstract: The conflict and the deteriorating humanitarian conditions in the Middle Eastern country put it at risk of becoming a failed state, Unicef reported.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A yearlong conflict is threatening to cause a humanitarian catastrophe in Yemen, one of the world’s poorest countries, the United Nations reported on Tuesday, saying that “children are paying the highest price.”

headline: Russia Shows What Happens When Terrorists’ Families Are Targeted
abstract: Donald J. Trump was widely condemned when he called for the United States to “take out the families” of terrorists. But Russia has been doing that for years.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Donald J. Trump, the leading Republican presidential candidate, was widely condemned when he called for the United States to “take out the families” of terrorists.

headline: Apple iPhone Standoff Ends, for Now
abstract: The legal standoff is over, but the iPhone now seems less secure, and legal issues of personal privacy and public security were not hashed out.
lead_paragraph: The Feds solved one mystery, and may have left the rest of us with several more.

headline: Saving Notes and Highlights in iBooks
abstract: After you have taken the time to mark up an iBook, you can pull out a copy of your highlights and notes for later use.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I save and print the selections and notes I’ve taken in iBooks?

headline: Donald Blankenship Prosecutors Urge Jail in Mine Safety Case
abstract: The prosecution asked a judge to sentence Mr. Blankenship, chief executive of Massey Energy when 29 workers were killed in an explosion, to a year.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor has urged a judge in West Virginia to sentence Donald L. Blankenship, who was chief executive of Massey Energy Company when 29 workers were killed in a mine explosion, to the maximum of a year in jail for conspiring to violate safety standards.

headline: Mets’ Matt Harvey Is Treated for Blood Clot in Bladder
abstract: After disclosing his ailment, Harvey said he would do light activity Tuesday and throw a few innings Wednesday, setting him up to start on opening day onSunday.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt Harvey walked into the Mets’ clubhouse on Tuesday morning, his head held high, as if nothing were wrong. The Mets had announced the day prior that he was dealing with an unspecified, nonbaseball-related ailment, and now the only physical sign that something had been amiss was the red hospital band around his wrist.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 16: Petra and Jane’s Growing Friendship
abstract: This was one of the most heartwarming episodes of the season.
lead_paragraph: Last week, “Jane the Virgin” introduced the viewers to a brand new dramatic element: the Curse of Pablo Alonso Segura. “Cursed” characters are a staple in soap operas (and maybe even doubly so in telenovelas) because they are a fun, simple way to wreak a little havoc on the main cast without worrying about finding down-to-earth explanations for all the strange occurrences. This week, Pablo and Alba quickly rekindle their fiery relationship decades after they last saw each other, but are the flames worth all the bad luck that follows Pablo around?

headline: Gov. Scott Walker, a Week Before Wisconsin Votes, Endorses Ted Cruz
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a week ahead of his state’s primary, threw his support behind Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign, praising the Texas senator’s tax plan and foreign policy views and calling him a principled conservative who has shown a willingness to take on Washington.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin threw his support behind Senator Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign on Tuesday, calling him the strongest conservative to represent the Republican Party in the general election and defeat Hillary Clinton if she is the Democratic nominee.

headline: Obama Steps Up U.S. Effort to Fight Abuse of Heroin and Painkillers
abstract: The president spoke at a drug abuse conference, and the administration said it would expand treatment centers and increase the use of drugs that counter opioids.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Obama, confronting a national epidemic of heroin and prescription drug abuse, met here Tuesday with recovering addicts, doctors and law enforcement officials to underscore his determination to tackle a problem some critics say he left until too late in his administration.

headline: A Red Carpet for Amazon in Fall River, Mass., and Hopes for More
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: An Amazon warehouse will give Fall River, Mass., the cash to tackle a host of improvements planned for its downtown, propelling a city strategy.
lead_paragraph: FALL RIVER, Mass. — For this former mill town, the deal to secure a large Amazon distribution center means much more than the $3.78 million coming from the land sale and the successful culmination of three years’ worth of negotiations.

headline: Victory for Unions as Supreme Court, Scalia Gone, Ties 4-4
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Government Employees', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: When the California teachers case was argued, Justice Antonin Scalia was still alive, and the court appeared ready to hand public unions a setback.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court handed organized labor a major victory on Tuesday, deadlocking 4 to 4 in a case that had threatened to cripple the ability of public-sector unions to collect fees from workers who chose not to join and did not want to pay for the unions’ collective bargaining activities.

headline: 1966: Red Nations Said To Be Equal
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S.S.R. proclaimed a doctrine of equality for Communist nations in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Soviet Union’s leaders today proclaimed a doctrine of equality for Communist nations as the 23d congress of the nation’s Communist party opened in the Kremlin. Soviet party chief Leonid I. Brezhnev, in a speech running more than four hours, said each country should decide its own course without interference by other Communist countries or parties. The policy was aimed immediately at Communist China but also took note of the situation within the Communist bloc that has been developing steadily ever since Yugoslavia, then Albania and China, and finally Romania drew out from under the long shadow of the Kremlin. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 30, 1966

headline: ‘Café Society,’ New Woody Allen Movie, Will Open Cannes Festival
abstract: This is the third time that a film by Mr. Allen has opened the Cannes festival.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Café Society,” a new Woody Allen movie starring Kristen Stewart and Jesse Eisenberg, will open this year’s Cannes Film Festival on May 11, organizers announced on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Pasta is among the many delights at the chef Missy Robbins’s restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

abstract: This Italian restaurant in Williamsburg is something of a rarity: the sole focus of a talented midcareer chef.
lead_paragraph: My one-sentence review of Lilia for the too-long-didn’t-read crowd: Missy Robbins is cooking pasta again.

headline: Review: In ‘The Path,’ a Cult Is Only as Strong as Its Following
abstract: This Hulu drama about a fictional cult in upstate New York offers glimpses into a fascinating subculture, but the series is sluggish and unfocused.
lead_paragraph: Before Aaron Paul was Jesse Pinkman, Walter White’s meth-making pupil in “Breaking Bad,” he was a regular on HBO’s “Big Love” — a drama about a polygamist sect, which explored abuse in the name of religion and the solace of an unorthodox faith.

headline: Shaping Health Policy for Millions, and Still Treating Some on the Side
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Dr. Patrick H. Conway, chief medical officer at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, keeps one foot on the front lines as he works to improve the health system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On weekdays, Dr. Patrick H. Conway is one of the most powerful doctors in America, steering federal health programs that spend nearly $1 trillion a year while shaping health policies that affect tens of millions of citizens.

headline: The Chinese Club Is Reborn in Brooklyn
abstract: Also, Between the Bread adds a branch in Chelsea, Il Bambino lands in Greenwich Village, David Chang has a new Momofuku project in the works, and more.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Club The family history that has inspired this Chinese-Indian restaurant goes back to the days of the Raj. Stacey Mehta Lo, who owns it with her husband, the chef Salil Mehta, was born in Darjeeling, India, where her great-grandfather ran the Chinese Club, a “refuge for Chinese expats,” as she put it. He served Chinese food, especially the cuisine of his Hakka heritage, a culture concentrated on the southern coast of China. Local Indians who came to the club to gamble also liked the food but wanted more Indian flavors, Ms. Mehta Lo said. Mr. Mehta’s menu is long, with dishes like Darjeeling Hakka lo mein, Chinese Club beef short rib with daikon, beer-battered General Tso’s chicken and Indian-Chinese vegetable fritters. The couple also owns the Malaysian restaurant Laut, near Union Square: 208 Grand Street (Driggs Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-487-4576, thechineseclubnyc.com.

headline: No Guns Allowed at Republican Convention, Secret Service Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Firearms', 'Gun Control', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: The Secret Service said it would forbid attendees to carry firearms at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July, neutralizing a debate that had put pressure on the candidates to take a side on the issue.

headline: Starwood Bidder Is a Reclusive Chinese Insurer With Opaque Backing
abstract: Anbang, which is in a bidding war for Starwood Hotels, is controlled by a murky group of interconnected companies and led by a reclusive chairman.
lead_paragraph: He is often compared in the media to Warren E. Buffett. Like the American billionaire, he is leveraging his control of an insurance company to become one of the biggest names in global finance. Like Mr. Buffett, he looks to be acquiring an immense personal fortune.

headline: Is Color Correcting Makeup Your New Best Friend?
abstract: A slew of primers in green, yellow, pink or lavender promise to “correct” your skin tone. What do they really do?
lead_paragraph: New color correcting makeup, in highly pigmented shades like canary yellow and pistachio green, seems better suited to an afternoon of decorating Easter eggs than a morning in front of the bathroom mirror.

headline: Avicii Retires From Performing Live
abstract: The 26-year-old Swedish musician wrote an open letter explaining why he’s leaving the lucrative life of a touring D.J.
lead_paragraph: Avicii, the reigning Swedish prince of electronic dance music, is done for now with the extravagant, vagabond life of an international touring D.J.

headline: Yacht Vacations: Not Just for the Rich
abstract: Several companies offer seven-day yacht charters for $10,000 or less; most of the boats have multiple bedrooms and are suited for families and groups.
lead_paragraph: A vacation on a yacht may conjure up images of billionaires and celebrities, but it’s not just for the rich and famous. Several companies offer seven-day yacht charters for $10,000 or less; most of the boats have multiple bedrooms and are suited for families and groups. Travelers can either hire a captain or sail the vessel themselves.

headline: Obama Faces a Tough Balancing Act Over South China Sea
abstract: Relations between Beijing and Washington are at their lowest point in 15 years, buffeted by China’s territorial claims over the strategic waterway.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When dozens of world leaders gather for a summit meeting in Washington on Thursday, President Obama will meet privately with only one of them: President Xi Jinping of China.

headline: Introducing the Gallery Restaurant
abstract: From London to Los Angeles, small art spaces are opening on-premise eateries.
lead_paragraph: Most art museums boast a stylish eatery or two but, until recently, it was rare to find a gallery that offered anything more than wine and cheese. Now, smaller spaces are playing a bigger game. In 2014, Hauser & Wirth opened Roth Bar & Grill in Bruton, England, with an on-site garden and meat-salting room. The gallery group’s second restaurant, Manuela, in Los Angeles, debuts this summer. At Gagosian in New York, Kappo Masa’s omakase draws the power-lunch crowd. And the artist Damien Hirst and the restaurateur Mark Hix have recently opened Pharmacy 2 in London at Hirst’s Newport Street Gallery, serving creative spins on traditional British and European fare.

headline: Corey Lewandowski, Donald Trump’s Campaign Manager, Is Charged With Battery
abstract: His formal arrest was detailed in a police report that cited new security-camera images showing Mr. Lewandowski pulling a reporter out of his way after Mr. Trump spoke in Florida on March 8.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, was charged with battery Tuesday by the police in Jupiter, Fla., who said he had grabbed a reporter this month as she tried to ask Mr. Trump a question.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: SoundCloud Starts Subscription Plan, Taking On Spotify and Apple
abstract: SoundCloud’s $10-a-month service will give users access to millions more songs and allow them to listen offline.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after signing its final licensing deal with a major record company, the online music service SoundCloud has introduced its long-awaited subscription plan. The new program gives customers access to a much wider range of music than is available on competing services like Spotify and Apple, and it offers artists and their labels the promise of royalties.

headline: Staten Island Murder Suspect Is Shot During Capture in Pennsylvania
abstract: The man, Anthony Morales, 49, was shot and critically injured as he reached for a handgun during his apprehension along the Appalachian Trail, about 115 miles west of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in a fatal shooting on Staten Island that left a mother and her son dead was critically injured when he was captured on Monday night in Pennsylvania, the police said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Tuesday that the United States economy remained on track despite a rough start to the year because the drag from weak growth in other countries was being offset by lower borrowing costs.

headline: Bank of England to Raise Bank Capital Buffer as Safeguard
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The buffer is intended to ensure that British banks can provide lending and other essential banking services during times of financial stress.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England said on Tuesday that it would increase the size of a capital buffer it requires banks to hold to ensure they can provide lending and other essential banking services in times of financial stress.

lead_paragraph: ROSEMEAD, Calif. — Betting that the future of the power industry lies in selling far more than just energy, Edison International, parent to one of the nation’s largest electric utilities, is starting a business to offer energy consulting and management services to commercial and industrial customers.

keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobiles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: For years, Volkswagen ran ads that emphasized how efficient, fun and, above all, clean its diesel cars were. A series of online ads last year featured three sisters debunking old wives’ tales about diesel, including that it was dirty and that it smelled bad.

headline: Donald Trump Is Bringing Message of Jobs and Trade to Paul Ryan’s Hometown
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Donald J. Trump, who has risen to front-runner status in part by channeling anti-establishment rage against Republicans, is kicking off his quest for the support of Wisconsin voters at a rally on Tuesday afternoon in Janesville, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan’s hometown.

headline: Jessica Knoll Reveals the Rape Behind Her Novel, ‘Luckiest Girl Alive’
abstract: The author of the best-selling thriller has told readers that the sexual assault she portrayed as fictional was based on her own experiences.
lead_paragraph: By every conventional measure, Jessica Knoll’s thriller, “Luckiest Girl Alive,” was a wildly successful literary debut. It sold more than 450,000 copies and spent four months on the best-seller lists. Foreign rights sold in more than 30 countries. The actress Reese Witherspoon optioned the film rights, and Ms. Knoll wrote the screenplay.

abstract: Replacing sitting time with just standing or moderate physical activity could counteract the effect.
lead_paragraph: Sitting too much may increase the risk of dying prematurely, while replacing sitting time with just standing or moderate physical activity could counteract the effect.

headline: Patty Duke, Child Star and Oscar Winner, Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Duke came to wide public notice when she starred as Helen Keller in “The Miracle Worker.”
lead_paragraph: Patty Duke, an Oscar-winning actress renowned at midcentury as a child star of stage, film and television, who, amid public struggles with bipolar disorder, went on to cultivate a respected career in adulthood as an actress and mental-health advocate, died on Tuesday at a hospital near her home in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho. She was 69.

headline: Montenegro Expels Foreigners Linked With Japanese Cult

lead_paragraph: The government of Montenegro has expelled 58 foreigners suspected of being associated with Aum Shinrikyo, the Japanese doomsday cult that staged a deadly nerve gas attack on Tokyo’s subway in 1995.

headline: Ibiza’s Idyllic Off-Season
abstract: In summer, the island is synonymous with E.D.M. superclubs. In springtime, it’s a quiet oasis of relaxation.
lead_paragraph: Summer in Ibiza has become synonymous with E.D.M. superclubs and celebrity debauchery. But in springtime, the island proves a haven for travelers seeking holistic relaxation, an oasis of flowering almond trees and red dirt hills evocative of Tuscany. Rustic yet luxurious resorts, or agroturismos, like Atzaró offer thermal spas and quiet, understated rooms. Restaurants like La Paloma (above and at right) and the stylish new Aubergine serve local produce in sight of where it was grown. And CoCoq, a new homewares market in an airy former warehouse, facilitates the most soothing kind of shopping.

headline: Joe Bradley’s “Krasdale”
abstract: The artist’s new paintings go on view this week at Gagosian’s 980 Madison Ave. gallery.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s new paintings go on view this week at Gagosian’s 980 Madison Ave. gallery.

headline: For an Anticipated New Show, a Shape-Shifting Artist Reinvents His Practice — Again
abstract: Joe Bradley’s “Krasdale” painting series is his first for Gagosian Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks before his first Gagosian show, the artist Joe Bradley is still in the thick of things. On the walls of his Brooklyn Navy Yard studio, wet canvases face off amid the organized chaos of paint buckets, unstretched linen and a lonesome espresso machine. “These ones are mostly finished,” Bradley says, motioning to a triptych of large abstract compositions. “Others need radical surgery.” The eight or so works in progress that ring the room represent six months of development — an ongoing self-editing process that won’t stop until the paintings are on their way to the gallery. “Just knowing the deadline is looming, some kind of performative thing kicks in,” Bradley explains. “Otherwise you could play with something indefinitely.”

headline: #NeverReformConservatism at the Wall Street Journal
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Journal editorial page goes all in for a “do nothing, change nothing” response to Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: I see that the Wall Street Journal editorial page has risen to the defense of House Speaker Paul Ryan’s relatively muted response to Trumpism, and what they’ve come up with is quite … revealing. In my deliberately tart critique of Ryan and the rest of the G.O.P. leadership, I suggested that he and other prominent conservatives were taking a “first, change nothing; second, do nothing” approach to the challenge of Trumpism, and essentially lying still and hoping the danger would pass over. The Journal’s counter-argument is a straightforward endorsement of exactly that approach: Trumpism too shall pass, the editorial avers, and in the mean time the important thing is to maintain the purity of Journal-approved conservatism, and to refuse any aid and comfort to all those deviationists and splittists who think that the party might not have exactly the right economic agenda for the voters and the times.

headline: Review: In ‘Everybody Wants Some!!,’ Casual Sex and Casual Philosophizing
abstract: Richard Linklater calls his latest film, set in 1980, a “spiritual sequel” to “Dazed and Confused,” his 1970s high school masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody Wants Some!!” is many things — a baseball caper, a sex farce, a campus romance, a campus bromance — but the film’s real claim to distinction may be that it’s the least suspenseful ticking-clock movie ever. We start out counting down the days and hours over the last long weekend before the beginning of the fall semester at a Texas college, and at the end of the movie (spoiler alert? are you kidding me?) it’s time for class.

headline: Starwood’s Takeover Offer From Anbang Is Risky, but Worth It
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Heavy interest from rival hoteliers means Starwood can afford to take the Anbang Insurance Group’s offer, which is $4.64 more per share than its deal with Marriott.
lead_paragraph: Call it the $4.64 question. That’s how much more per share the Anbang Insurance Group of China has offered to entice Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide away from a deal with Marriott International. Anbang’s new $14 billion bid is about 6 percent sweeter, but it also comes with uncertainties. Heavy interest from rival hoteliers means Starwood can afford the risk and accept.

headline: Considering Earthquake Threats in California and Oklahoma
abstract: The Times’s Adam Nagourney and Michael Wines discuss a report that says the chance of a destructive earthquake is as great in Oklahoma and parts of Kansas as it is in California.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma and neighboring states have been grappling with an increase in earthquakes tied to the boom in oil and gas production over the past 15 years. Adam Nagourney, the Los Angeles bureau chief for The New York Times, and Michael Wines, who has covered this subject,  discussed Monday’s report that because of these man-made quakes, Oklahoma is as much at risk for a damaging quake as California. Here is an excerpt from their conversation:

headline: Gwen Stefani Skips Spotify and Still Opens at No. 1
abstract: The singer’s new solo album, “This Is What the Truth Feels Like,” debuted at the top of the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: For months now, the music industry has been conducting a test. The latest guinea pig is Gwen Stefani, and she has passed with flying colors.

headline: Yves Cibuabua, ‘Husband and a Father First,’ Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Mr. Cibuabua, a business school graduate and the father of two young daughters, progressed from working as a cleaner to a job in financial securities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Yves Cibuabua, a Congolese business school graduate living in Brussels, was known among family and friends for his gumption and determination: By age 27, he had progressed from doing stints as a cleaner and a supermarket cashier to working in the financial securities department of Banque Eni, part of the Italian energy giant.

headline: A Cecil Taylor Retrospective at Whitney Museum
abstract: The Whitney Museum will host a 10-day retrospective of Cecil Taylor’s work in music, poetry, dance and theater.
lead_paragraph: Cecil Taylor is the latest jazz great to take over a museum space. The Whitney Museum of American Art will turn over its fifth floor to his work next month for a 10-day retrospective, “Open Plan: Cecil Taylor,” that will include concerts, listening sessions, archival videos, scores and poetry. Mr. Taylor will kick things off with a mixed music and dance performance with Min Tanaka and Tony Oxley on April 14.

headline: The Playgrounds of Pakistan
abstract: I remember a childhood of pleasant thrills, not terror.
lead_paragraph: Not far from the house where I grew up in Karachi, Pakistan, there was a children’s amusement park. It sat on top of a hill, its slides and swings beckoning children from the houses below. As summer vacations dragged on, my brother and I would hear the gleeful screams of other children, and we begged my mother to take us. It wasn’t an easy sell. “The swings are so rickety,” she would say one day. “Aren’t you afraid you will fall out of the spinning wheel?” she would say on another. We were a little afraid, but we ached to go. That park was the only one we knew, and if it was shabby, its toy horses and pretend cars worn and weary, it still held the promise of exhilaration.

headline: Japanese Chefs, French Cuisine: Six Restaurants to Visit in Paris
abstract: Where to go to find some of the most exquisite and celebrated French food in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Where to go to find some of the most exquisite and celebrated French food in Paris.

abstract: A new generation of Japanese chefs now run some of the most acclaimed French restaurants in Paris.
