headline: Japanese Chefs Make Their Mark in Paris
abstract: A new generation of chefs from Japan run some of the most acclaimed French restaurants in Paris — a city that isn’t known for embracing outsiders.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The pithiviers de canard at Clown Bar, a historic restaurant in Paris with circus-themed glazed tiles from the 1920s, is an exquisite rendering of a classic dish. Duck breast surrounded by minced duck meat, topped with duck foie gras and baked inside a pastry shell the color of varnished teak, it is a flaky, tender, succulent argument for why we still worship traditional French cuisine.

headline: An Indian Spice Mix, Sambhar Masala, for All Seasons
abstract: Cooking teacher Raghavan Iyer shares a simple spice mix to bring the flavors of Indian cuisine to American cooks.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Like a friendly drill sergeant, Raghavan Iyer was not going to pretend that making the spice mix he was about to teach 13 Emory University cafeteria cooks how to prepare was easy.

headline: The Sock Queen of Alabama
abstract: In Alabama, New Life for the Fading Sock Business.
lead_paragraph: In Alabama, New Life for the Fading Sock Business.

headline: Climate Policy’s Advocates Take Page From Same-Sex Marriage Playbook
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coal', 'Federal Courts (US)']
abstract: Environmentalists started a campaign, like one used before the Supreme Court’s gay rights ruling last year, to win backing for President Obama’s effort to cut greenhouse gases from coal plants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months ahead of a federal court hearing on President Obama’s signature climate change rule, a coordinated public relations offensive has begun — modeled after the same-sex marriage campaign — to influence the outcome of the case.

headline: Exxon Mobil Climate Change Inquiry in New York Gains Allies
abstract: A group of attorneys general announced support for an investigation by Eric Schneiderman of New York into Exxon Mobil’s statements on global warming.
lead_paragraph: More government officials are asking what Exxon Mobil knew about climate change.

headline: Aline Bastin, Who Loved to See and Photograph the World, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Ms. Bastin, a press and communications manager for the Community of European Railway and Infrastructure Companies, was killed in the attack on the Brussels subway.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Aline Bastin loved to travel, but on March 22, she was taking a train simply to go to work.

headline: Louis Bacon’s Charity Says It Was Victim of Executive Accused of Fraud
abstract: The Moore Charitable Foundation of Louis M. Bacon says it put $25 million into what federal authorities call a fraudulent scheme by Andrew Caspersen.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund billionaire Louis M. Bacon’s charitable foundation was a victim of a fraudulent scheme by the 39-year-old Wall Street executive Andrew Caspersen, the foundation said on Tuesday.

headline: How Well Do You Know Your Partner? Readers Offer Still More Pre-Marriage Questions
abstract: Readers respond to '13 Questions to Ask Before Getting Married' with more of their own.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to '13 Questions to Ask Before Getting Married' with more of their own.

headline: Nic Coopman, ‘Unflappable’ Belgian Working for U.S. Company, Dies in Brussels Attack
abstract: Mr. Coopman traveled often throughout Europe and to the United States for his job, in which he specialized in automation and electrical controls.
lead_paragraph: Nic Coopman, a Belgian who worked for an American manufacturing company, often passed through Brussels Airport to catch flights around Europe. He was on his way to Zurich when he was dropped off outside the departure hall last Tuesday, according to an executive at his company.

headline: Damage After Man Climbs and Camps in Seattle Tree? $7,800
abstract: A man who spent more than 24 hours in a 90-foot sequoia tree in downtown Seattle, tearing off branches and pelting people with pine cones, did damage in the thousands of dollars, experts said.
lead_paragraph: For more than 24 hours last week, Cody Lee Miller perched in a giant sequoia tree in downtown Seattle, pelting people and cars with pine cones and tearing off branches to throw like spears into the street below.

headline: Ukraine Ousts Viktor Shokin, Top Prosecutor, and Political Stability Hangs in the Balance
abstract: Mr. Shokin had been criticized for turning a blind eye to corruption, but political observers said he played an important role in balancing competing interests.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Bowing to pressure from international donors, the Ukrainian Parliament voted on Tuesday to remove a prosecutor general who had clung to power for months despite visible signs of corruption.

headline: The Sock Queen of Alabama
abstract: When the onetime sock capital of the world’s industry collapsed, it was “like a vacuum cleaner pulled all the people out of town.” But then Gina Locklear had an idea.
lead_paragraph: FORT PAYNE, Ala. — Nine years ago, when she was 27 and unhappily selling real estate, Gina Locklear went to her parents with a proposition. She wanted to make socks. Not the basic white socks the family had specialized in, but fashionable socks, with organic cotton and dyes.

headline: Spin-Splaining, Donald Trump Edition
abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign manager has been charged with battery. But, says the campaign, “he was not arrested.”
lead_paragraph: When police charge a presidential front-runner’s campaign manager with battery for manhandling a woman, “he was not arrested” might seem like an insufficient response from the campaign.

headline: In Comic-Con v. Comic Con, Proceedings Are Opaque
abstract: A judge sealed all business information in the trademark case against a Salt Lake copycat.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From Hollywood’s court docket: “Off the record, on the QT, and very hush-hush.”

headline: Dilma Rousseff Loses Support From Key Part of Brazilian Coalition
abstract: The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party’s leaders voted to split from the president’s party, a move that could increase the likelihood of her being impeached.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A crucial part of Brazil’s governing coalition withdrew support for President Dilma Rousseff on Tuesday, a move that could increase the likelihood of her impeachment and deepen Brazil’s political and economic crises.

headline: Winter Sports Athletes Ask for the Doping Spotlight
abstract: When will the World Anti-Doping Agency take a hard look at winter sports after being shown sweeping corruption in track and field?
lead_paragraph: OSLO — World sport resembles a failed state.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Diaa Hadid, Jason Zinoman and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: G.O.P. Senators’ Intransigence on Court Nominee
abstract: Readers take issue with an Op-Ed article by Senator Orrin G. Hatch.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Makes a Terrorist Isn’t a Mystery
abstract: Readers offer ideas to prevent radicalization.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum to Open New Space for Contemporary Art
abstract: The expansion is intended to raise the profile of Bentonville, Ark., as an arts destination.
lead_paragraph: In London, it was a hulking electric power station (now the Tate Modern). In North Adams, Mass., it was an electronics plant (whose buildings now house the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art). In Beacon, N.Y., it was a Nabisco cracker-box factory (now home to Dia:Beacon, the mecca of Minimalist and Conceptual art). And next in the march of postindustrial artification, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark. — home to Walmart — has announced plans to transform a defunct Kraft cheese plant into a raw space for contemporary-art exhibitions, artists’ projects, music, theater and film.

headline: Pakistan Releases Video of Indian Officer, Saying He’s a Spy
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: In a six-minute video, the officer, who was arrested this month, acknowledges carrying out a list of operations. India has denied that he is an intelligence operative.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Civilian and military leaders in Pakistan accused India on Tuesday of sponsoring and orchestrating terrorism and separatist movements, presenting what they said was clear evidence: a video confession.

headline: Review: In George Lopez’s Show, ‘Lopez,’ He Mostly Plays Himself
abstract: The series, on TV Land, joins a large group of semi-autobiographical comedies that have sprung up over the years.
lead_paragraph: George Lopez’s new comedy, “Lopez,” fits in a saturated section of overlap in TV’s current Venn diagram: “Semi-Autobiographical Comedies,” “‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Homages” and “Shows That Overestimate How Interesting Show Business Is.” “Lopez,” which debuts on Wednesday on TV Land, isn’t a bad example of these kinds of series, but if you show up this late to the party, you have to do something pretty extraordinary to be the guest of honor.

headline: Strange Fruits
abstract: We’re in a Golden Age of specialty produce (and that’s a good thing).
lead_paragraph: In a world of very few absolutes, here is one: Nature has no more perfect offering than fruit, nothing that seems better engineered to delight and entice humankind’s every sense. But of course, the real purpose of fruit is not to make humans happy, but to make more fruit: While it is the result of a relentless biological process that we happen to enjoy, the creation of fruit itself — from its larval stage (if you will) as a flower to its dropping from the tree or bush onto the ground and growing into a new tree or bush — would go on whether we were there to appreciate it or not.

headline: Review: ‘I Don’t Belong Anywhere’ Explores the Life and Work of Chantal Akerman
abstract: Marianne Lambert, who directed this documentary, was a production manager for Ms. Akerman, the groundbreaking Belgian director, who died in October.
lead_paragraph: It’s challenging to make a movie about a filmmaker who was such a master at telling her own story. In “I Don’t Belong Anywhere: The Cinema of Chantal Akerman,” Marianne Lambert makes a sensitive attempt at portraying Ms. Akerman, a groundbreaking director, and her work, displaying a comfort level perhaps born of working as a production manager for her subject.

headline: Anonymous Call for Xi to Quit Rattles Party Leaders in China
abstract: A far-reaching investigation into the origin of the letter, which first appeared on the Internet, has drawn more attention than the document itself.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An anonymous letter calling on President Xi Jinping to resign for the good of China and his own safety seemed to be digital rumor-mongering when it appeared on the Internet this month. It spread by email and lingered on a small domestic Chinese news site before it was removed.

headline: Review: ‘Sex and Broadcasting,’ With the Emphasis on the Latter
abstract: The story of WFMU, a listener-supported radio station kept alive in the era of corporate financing by sometimes wacky labors of love.
lead_paragraph: Hardly as salacious as its name suggests, the documentary “Sex and Broadcasting — A Film About WFMU” paints an affectionate portrait of this Jersey City radio station  (91.1 FM in the New York City area, and 90.1 in the Hudson Valley), which remains listener-supported at a time when corporate or umbrella funding is the norm. (The first half of the title comes from a book on community radio by Lorenzo W. Milam.)

headline: 13 Detroit School Principals Charged in Vendor Kickback Scheme
abstract: A federal prosecutor said $2.7 million of about $5 million in supply orders over several years was fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: In Detroit’s crumbling schools, where the threat of insolvency means that basic repairs, supplies and even teachers are in short supply, 13 principals conspired with a vendor to defraud the system, siphoning away millions of dollars, federal agents and prosecutors charged on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Poetry by Lucia Perillo and Amit Majmudar
abstract: Ms. Perillo’s “Time Will Clean the Carcass Bones” is a career overview; Mr. Majmudar’s “Dothead” also spans many subjects, from immigration to medicine to James Bond.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone in the world seems to be writing poems,” the poet Anne Sexton warned a fledgling versifier in 1965, “but only a few climb into the sky.”

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, EgyptAir
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.N. Panel’s Call for Transparency Highlights Limits of Oversight
abstract: A report from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon gave recommendations to the General Assembly president, who does not report to the secretary general.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Five months after a former president of the United Nations General Assembly was accused of accepting bribes to buy items like hand-tailored suits and Rolex watches, a task force appointed by the United Nations secretary general recommended greater transparency in the way money is raised and spent by that office.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Lester C. Thurow, Economist Who Seized the Spotlight, Is Dead at 77
abstract: A prolific writer and popular public speaker, Mr. Thurow sounded an early alarm about the growing income gap between rich and poor Americans.
lead_paragraph: Lester C. Thurow, a prominent and provocative economist who earned a dedicated following through his long writing and speaking career, and who was known for his prescient warnings about the growing income gap between rich and poor Americans, died on Friday in Westport, Mass. He was 77.

headline: Supreme Court Hints at Way to Avert Tie on Birth Control Mandate
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Less than a week after oral arguments, the court called for supplemental briefs in an unusually elaborate order that seemed to envision new federal regulations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday issued an unusual order indicating that the justices are trying to avoid a 4-to-4 deadlock in a case pitting religious freedom against access to contraception.

headline: From Flank Steak to Saint Laurent
abstract: A look back at Lady Gaga’s style evolution.
lead_paragraph: A look back at Lady Gaga’s style evolution.

headline: On the Way to a Night at the Opera
abstract: A camera follows a new staging of Donizetti’s “Roberto Devereux,” from early rehearsals through the final curtain on opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: A camera follows a new staging of Donizetti’s “Roberto Devereux,” from early rehearsals through the final curtain on opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: A Night (and Many Days) Backstage at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: To capture the work that goes into an opera’s elaborate staging, James Estrin, a Times photographer, observed weeks of rehearsals for the Met’s “Roberto Devereux.”
lead_paragraph: Behind its facade of white travertine and auditorium of red velvet and gold leaf, the Metropolitan Opera is essentially a factory — one that is never busier than when it is building and staging a new production, like Donizetti’s “Roberto Devereux,” which opened last week.

headline: Explaining Valeant: The Main Theories
abstract: Reasons given for the turmoil at Valeant Pharmaceuticals include its cuts in research and development, its drug pricing and investors’ influence.
lead_paragraph: Whether experiencing schadenfreude or finding insight, many think they know what is responsible for the turmoil at Valeant Pharmaceuticals International as it falls from a darling of Wall Street to its punching bag.

headline: ‘Ranger’s Apprentice’ to Be Adapted as Film, Financed by Chinese Firm
abstract: An entertainment company started by the former Disney chairman Dick Cook has tapped Paul Haggis as director of a film based on a popular children’s series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A former chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Dick Cook, said on Tuesday that his long-planned solo entertainment company would adapt the best-selling “Ranger’s Apprentice” children’s book series as its first film after a deal with a Chinese company for at least $500 million in financing.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $6.2 million

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: The best-selling sports books in February 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in February 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Omarosa Manigault Says Donald Trump Might Have to Tell Corey Lewandowski, ‘You’re Fired’
abstract: You didn’t hear this from the candidate, but Ms. Manigault, a stalwart supporter of Mr. Trump’s campaign and a former contestant on “The Apprentice,” said that Mr. Trump would likely dismiss Mr. Lewandowski, his campaign manager, if he fails to win the Wisconsin primary.
lead_paragraph: It was odd enough to see Omarosa Manigault, the reality television star known for her villainous turn on “The Apprentice,” dissecting the presidential race with Wolf Blitzer during a live interview on CNN on Tuesday.

headline: A Clean, Simple Backpack — and Store — From a Cult Hat Label
abstract: The designer Janessa Leoné has expanded her line just as she unveils a brick-and-mortar outpost in Culver City.
lead_paragraph: “I keep using the word ‘intentional,’ but everything is very intentional,” says the Los Angeles-based designer Janessa Leoné, who launched her eponymous line of hats in the fall of 2012. Last season, she expanded her range to include bags — a traditional messenger and a cross-body that doubles as a clutch — and, now she’s added a backpack. “I wanted to ensure that it doesn’t seem like an afterthought, that I’m doing handbags,” she says. “I wanted everyone to know I spent a lot of time on them.”

headline: Simmering for Decades, Anger About Trade Boils Over in ’16 Election
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Economy', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Bashing trade deals has proved a winning strategy for Donald Trump, but economists mostly agree they have benefited American households significantly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is in the midst of one of the longest economic expansions in its history. Even American factories have lately added hundreds of thousands of jobs.

headline: ISIS Fighters Laid Mines Around Palmyra’s Ancient Ruins Before Retreating, Syrians Say
abstract: Islamic State fighters were reported to have booby-trapped Palmyra’s archaeological treasures before retreating.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian forces that recaptured the storied city of Palmyra from Islamic State occupiers this past weekend have encountered dozens of mines that the expelled militants laid as booby traps around treasured ancient ruins sites, Syria’s state media reported Tuesday.

headline: Bronx Baby’s Death in August Ruled a Homicide, Officials Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Christopher Rhodes died from blunt force trauma to the head that his father said was the result of a fall from a child seat, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The death of a 4-month-old Bronx boy from a head injury over the summer is being investigated as a homicide after a ruling by the New York City medical examiner, the authorities said.

headline: Vince Boryla, an N.B.A. Jack of All Trades, Dies at 89
abstract: Boryla buoyed two franchises three decades apart — the Knicks as a player and coach in the 1950s and the Denver Nuggets as the general manager in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Vince Boryla, who buoyed two National Basketball Association franchises three decades apart — the Knicks as a player and coach in the 1950s and the Denver Nuggets as the general manager in the 1980s — died on Sunday at his home in Englewood, Colo. He was 89.

headline: Latest Plan to Rescue Puerto Rico Is Met With Disdain on Island
abstract: The plan calls for putting Puerto Rico’s finances under a presidentially appointed oversight board — a bitter pill to many on the island.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans released a draft of a rescue plan for Puerto Rico on Tuesday that they hoped could quickly garner bipartisan support and win over skeptics on the island, on Wall Street and in Congress.

headline: Lew Defends Sanctions, but Cautions on Overuse
abstract: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew on Wednesday will hail the success of economic sanctions against Iran and others, but warn against their overuse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With an eye to President Obama’s legacy and his own, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew on Wednesday will hail the success of economic sanctions against Iran and other global offenders, but warn that their overuse could threaten the primacy of the United States and the dollar in the world economy.

headline: Emergency Over Ebola Has Ended, W.H.O. Says
abstract: West African countries can contain the few new cases that arise, and “the likelihood of international spread is low,” the World Health Organization concluded.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola epidemic that killed thousands of people in West Africa is no longer an international public health emergency, the World Health Organization announced on Tuesday.

headline: That Spontaneous Buzzer-Beater Was Probably a Season in the Making
abstract: Players rehearse all season for a moment such as Bronson Koenig’s buzzer-beater for Wisconsin against Xavier in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The crowd was standing, the clock was nearing all zeros, the light atop the basket was about to turn red, and one revolution after another, the 3-point attempt from Bronson Koenig of Wisconsin arced toward victory or overtime.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka and C. C. Sabathia Soothe Yankees’ Doubts
abstract: With spring training nearly over, two of the team’s key pitchers responded with outings that should solidify their places in the rotation.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — As if six weeks of spring training had not been enough to define who belongs where in the Yankees’ pitching hierarchy, a bit of drama was manufactured on Tuesday.

headline: The Archdiocese of New York Raises Funds by Auctioning a Popemobile
abstract: The car, a black Fiat 500 Lounge, was one of two that Pope Francis used during his New York City visit last year.
lead_paragraph: The used hatchback up for auction comes with low mileage, a premium sound system and a glass roof. But because it once carried Pope Francis around New York City, bidders are willing to pay several times its Kelley Blue Book value.

headline: Apple’s New Challenge: Learning How the U.S. Cracked Its iPhone
abstract: The company lacks information on the method used to break into the iPhone of a gunman in San Bernardino, Calif.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Now that the United States government has cracked open an iPhone that belonged to a gunman in the San Bernardino, Calif., mass shooting without Apple’s help, the tech company is under pressure to find and fix the flaw.

headline: Major Companies Press North Carolina on Law Curbing Protections From Bias
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory accused critics of a “vicious nationwide smear campaign” regarding a law ending antidiscrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — The onslaught of criticism, economic sanctions and a lawsuit being leveled at Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina grew on Tuesday, as the largest corporation in his state joined the fight against a new law that eliminated anti-discrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: FIFA Official Plans to Fight Conspiracy Charges
abstract: Juan Ángel Napout, a Paraguayan, has pleaded not guilty, and a judge wants to set his trial date at a hearing next month.
lead_paragraph: In the many hours of audio recordings that United States prosecutors have on defendants in their world-soccer corruption case, Juan Ángel Napout, a FIFA executive arrested in December, speaks precious few words.

headline: Republican Senator Meets With Garland, and Urges Colleagues to Follow
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Senator Mark S. Kirk of Illinois chastised other members of his party and called President Obama’s Supreme Court pick “one of the most eminent judges in the country.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mark S. Kirk of Illinois on Tuesday became the first Republican to meet with Judge Merrick B. Garland and said he hoped the meeting would influence other Republicans to at least sit down with President Obama’s choice to fill a Supreme Court vacancy despite pressure from party leaders not to consider his nomination.

headline: Unions Win, but the Court Is Still Hobbled
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining']
abstract: Senate Republicans continue to block consideration of President Obama’s nominee, which means many more 4-to-4 “decisions” like Tuesday’s are coming.
lead_paragraph: In January, the Supreme Court heard arguments in a major labor case whose outcome could affect the lives of millions of Americans. On Tuesday, six weeks after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, the court’s eight members announced that they were deadlocked in a 4-to-4 vote.

headline: How to Live (Well) in New York City on Less Than Zero
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Shelters', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: Thousands of city households that reported negative income took in significant capital gains, a benefit built into tax codes.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you will be pleased to know that the number of New York City households reporting incomes of more than $1 million has climbed by 47 percent, from 14,795 in 2009 to 21,764 in 2013.

headline: Spotify Expected to Sign $1 Billion Financing Deal
abstract: The music streaming service is about to close on a $1 billion deal that would double the amount of financing it has raised since its founding a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Spotify is about to close on a $1 billion deal that would double the amount of financing the music-streaming company has raised since its founding a decade ago, people briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

headline: As Nuclear Security Summit Begins, Materials Remain Vulnerable to Theft
abstract: As President Obama gathers leaders for his last Nuclear Security Summit, tons of materials that terrorists could use to make small nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain vulnerable to theft.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama gathers world leaders in Washington this week for his last Nuclear Security Summit, tons of materials that terrorists could use to make small nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain deeply vulnerable to theft. Still, Mr. Obama’s six-year effort to rid the world of loose nuclear material has succeeded in pulling bomb-grade fuel out of countries from Ukraine to Chile, and has firmly put nuclear security on the global agenda.

headline: Hillary Clinton Accuses Donald Trump’s Campaign of ‘Inciting Violent Behavior’
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said an episode in which Mr. Trump’s campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, grabbed a reporter was part of a broader campaign of “aggressive behavior.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton carefully waded into the controversy engulfing Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, telling reporters on Tuesday that an episode in which Mr. Trump’s campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, grabbed a reporter was part of a broader campaign that had been “inciting violent behavior and aggressive behavior.”

headline: Medicaid Joins Minimum Wage as Complication in Budget Talks
abstract: With a Thursday deadline nearing, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposed Medicaid cuts and a $15 an hour statewide wage were sticking points in the Legislature.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Of this, everyone in the State Capitol seems certain: New York will eventually have a budget. The question is when.

headline: United States Rolls in World Cup Qualifier
abstract: Clint Dempsey’s early goal ignites a rout and helps quiet criticism of Coach Jurgen Klinsmann — at least for now.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Peace of mind arrived early Tuesday night, with the sight of Clint Dempsey galloping at a full sprint across the striped grass at Mapfre Stadium, his arms spread out like airplane wings.

headline: Video: Remembering Patty Duke
abstract: Ms. Duke was at one time one of the best-known young actors in the world.
lead_paragraph: Patty Duke, who died on Tuesday at 69, overcame a painful childhood to become one of the best-known young actors in the world. After appearing in commercials and a few television shows as a child, she found fame on Broadway, starring with Anne Bancroft in William Gibson’s “The Miracle Worker.” The play, about Helen Keller and her teacher, Anne Sullivan, ran from 1959 to 1961. Ms. Duke reprised the role in the 1962 film version of “The Miracle Worker,” which Bosley Crowther praised in The Times for retaining the play’s “absolutely tremendous and unforgettable display of physically powerful acting.” Ms. Duke won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for the performance — at 16, she was then the youngest actor to win that award.

headline: New York City Housing Authority Faulted for ‘Significant Flaws’ in Elevator Safety
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Elevators and Escalators', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: A report by the Department of Investigation, started after an 84-year-old man died in an elevator in December, said the housing agency was too slow to react to problems on elevators.
lead_paragraph: The death of an 84-year-old man in December in an elevator at a Bronx housing project exposed “significant flaws” in how public housing officials complied with safety laws and responded to urgent complaints about elevator breakdowns from residents across the city, the Department of Investigation has found.

headline: Environmentalist’s Concern
abstract: Andrew Reynolds gives us extra bang for our puzzle bucks.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Midweek is when you start to see the trickier themes and clue/entry pairings, for those of you who haven’t been solving that long. There are two schools of thought on this. You can either be intimidated and run away, or you can face your cruciverbal demons and benefit from the extra value these puzzles provide.

headline: Living on the Lower East Side
abstract: The neighborhood, which started as a mix of impoverished immigrants, is becoming less gritty with new residential construction underway.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood, which started as a mix of impoverished immigrants, is becoming less gritty with new residential construction underway.

headline: John Kasich Criticizes Donald Trump’s Knowledge of Foreign Policy
abstract: Expanding on his contention that neither Mr. Trump nor Senator Ted Cruz can win in November, Mr. Kasich also warned that the Republican presidential nominee could put control of the House and Senate at risk.
lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Gov. John Kasich ridiculed Donald J. Trump’s knowledge of foreign policy on Tuesday, offering unusually acidic words in the wake of last week’s terrorist attacks in Brussels.

headline: Female Artists Are (Finally) Getting Their Turn
abstract: Curators and gallerists say women-only exhibitions are long overdue, and can shine a light on neglected artists.
lead_paragraph: At the peak of her career in 1976, Georgia O’Keeffe refused to lend her work to a pivotal exhibition in Los Angeles, “Women Artists: 1550 to 1950.” It was one of a wave of all-female shows — some 150 — that decade to spotlight artists largely ignored by major museums and galleries. But O’Keeffe, the most famous female artist of her day, saw herself in a different category — “one of the best painters,” period.

headline: Bratton Has ‘Strong Concerns’ About Arrest of a Mailman in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: After a widely seen video showed the arrest of Glen Grays by four police officers, the police commissioner says the officers have been removed from their assignments.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s police commissioner expressed “strong concerns” on Tuesday about the arrest of an African-American mail carrier who was at work in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn when he was taken into custody amid an altercation with four police officers.

headline: Donald Trump Starts Wisconsin Bid in Ryan’s Hometown
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Mr. Trump, the anti-establishment voice, kicked off his quest at a rally in Janesville, the hometown of Speaker Paul D. Ryan — the button-downed, clean-cut steward of the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Donald J. headline: Checking on Bullying at the Doctor’s Office
abstract: After hearing my young patient’s story, I now make it a point to ask all my patients if they are being made fun of or bullied at school.
lead_paragraph: I let out a huge sigh as I picked up the next chart in clinic. “Chief complaint: Behavioral concerns” was typed out on the top of a thick packet of papers. My young patient was sitting on the exam table comfortably. His parents sat stoically with furrowed brows in the chairs next to him. They were nervous, rigid, clearly concerned.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What to Call Night-Shift Meals
abstract: A taste of justice for those of us eating dinner at 7 a.m.
lead_paragraph: Rachel writes: My fiancé, Ryan, works night shifts. When he wakes up at 3 p.m. and eats a turkey sandwich, he calls that “breakfast”; I think it’s lunch. When he gets home from work at 7 a.m., he’ll often have a beer with his “dinner,” which I insist is breakfast. Who is right?

headline: Courtney B. Vance Knows What Made Johnnie Cochran Tick
abstract: The actor on facing the police as a black man, code switching and the unresolved issues of the O.J. trial.
lead_paragraph: You play the defense attorney Johnnie Cochran on the FX series “American Crime Story.” You’ve said that you celebrated the O.J. verdict back in 1995: “I cheered for Emmett Till. I cheered for all the strange fruit that had hung on the trees for three centuries.” Do you think O.J. deserved to benefit from all of those tragedies? Whether or not he deserved to benefit from it, I don’t know. I mean, is any of us deserving of grace?

headline: What Do You Owe the Friends You Unwittingly Scammed?
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Family Leaves', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on doing business with acquaintances, taking advantage of maternity leave and Volkswagen’s responsibility to its customers.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, a friend of mine encouraged her friends, including me, to buy what turned out to be fraudulent securities. This friend believed the securities were legal, but they were part of a large fraud enterprise resulting in a loss of millions to hundreds of investors. As an agent, she arranged for her friends to buy some $250,000 of these investments. The perpetrators of the fraud are being brought to trial this year, but it appears that about half the money is gone.

headline: What Happened When Venture Capitalists Took Over the Golden State Warriors
abstract: After racking up a historic N.B.A. season, the team’s owners — most of them from Silicon Valley — think their management style deserves some of the credit. Are they right?
lead_paragraph: It was still dark one morning early this year when Joe Lacob, the majority owner of the Golden State Warriors, drove his Mercedes station wagon through the Stanford University campus. He parked near the business school, then walked down a sidewalk through a drizzle to meet a group of Silicon Valley executives. The ex-C.E.O. of OpenTable, now a partner at Andreessen Horowitz, was coming. So were a founder of the online-learning start-up Curious and a managing director of Vanguard Ventures. On another morning, they all might have met at a charity event or a TED Talk. But it was a Tuesday, and that meant basketball.

headline: Diving With Great White Sharks in Mexico
abstract: In Isla Guadalupe in Mexico, dives to see great white sharks have more of an eco-tourism focus than operations that may antagonize them.
lead_paragraph: In Isla Guadalupe in Mexico, dives to see great white sharks have more of an eco-tourism focus than operations that may antagonize them.

headline: A Too-Perfect Picture
abstract: How can we tell when a photograph is giving us the truth about a place and not simply trafficking in fantasy?
lead_paragraph: You know a Steve McCurry picture when you see one. His portrait of an Afghan girl with vivid green eyes, printed on the cover of National Geographic in June 1985, is one of the iconic images of the 20th century. McCurry’s work is stark and direct, with strong colors, a clear emotional appeal and crisp composition. His most recent volume of photographs, “India,” is a compendium of the pictures he took in that country between 1978 and 2014, and it also gives us the essential McCurry. There are Hindu festivals, men in turbans, women in saris, red-robed monks, long mustaches, large beards, preternaturally soulful children and people in rudimentary canoes against dramatic landscapes.

headline: EgyptAir Hijacking Suspect Says He Acted Out of Desperation

lead_paragraph: LARNACA, Cyprus — Seif Eldin Mustafa, the Egyptian man who grabbed the world’s attention by hijacking an EgyptA ir   flight and diverting it to Cyprus, has admitted his crimes to Cypriot investigators but insisted that he acted out of desperation, prosecutors said on Wednesday during his first court appearance.

headline: 1916: German Offensive Is Repelled
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: New German offensive is repelled near Verdun in 1916.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, the Crown Prince dares not admit the complete failure of his Verdun offensive. On Wednesday night the battle-worn German troops were hurled against the positions they had lost in the Bois d’Avocourt. A series of desperate assaults was met by withering fire from the French artillery, machine-guns and rifles. The fighting was particularly furious in front of the réduit d’Avocourt, and the French communiqué indicates the awful slaughter that took place by the brief statement that the German dead lay piled in heaps before this fortified work. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 31, 1916

headline: Team of Rival Scientists Comes Together to Fight Zika

lead_paragraph: With the Zika virus spreading largely unchecked in Latin America and the Caribbean by way of a now-notorious insect, some of the nation’s leading mosquito researchers are striving to assemble a state-of-the-art DNA map that they say will help them fight the disease with the mosquito’s own genetic code.

headline: Pop-Up Stores Thrive in a World of Failing Retailers
abstract: The stores don’t sign long leases, stash away much cash or carry big credit lines. And consumers can meet the designers and touch their works, which cannot be done online.
lead_paragraph: During trips to war-torn countries like Afghanistan, Jane Mosbacher Morris discovered, to her alarm, that women had little control over their finances. Some were forbidden to work or even touch money. The antidote, she decided, was starting an online market stocked with artisan works made by survivors of war, genocide, human trafficking and other abuses. The site To the Market would put much-needed money into their hands.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France announced on Wednesday that he was withdrawing a proposal to strip French citizenship from dual nationals convicted of terrorism, ending a monthslong debate that convulsed his governing Socialist Party, dominated political discussion after the November terrorist attacks, and led to the resignation of the justice minister.

headline: $830,000 Houses in North Carolina, Virginia and Illinois
abstract: This week’s properties include an old gristmill in North Carolina, a modern home in Virginia and a foursquare in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: SNOW CAMP, N.C.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Backs Missile Program
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei supported the tests and criticized a former president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who has said that talks are more important.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader backed the country’s missile program on Wednesday, criticizing a prominent ayatollah who had suggested that in the future, negotiations were far more important.

headline: Bushwick Fire Tears Through a Block of Rowhouses
abstract: The blaze devastated a block in the rapidly gentrifying Brooklyn neighborhood on Tuesday night and left dozens of people without a home.
lead_paragraph: A rapidly spreading fire tore through a half-dozen wooden rowhouses in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Tuesday night, devastating a block in the rapidly gentrifying neighborhood and leaving dozens of people without a home.

headline: House Hunting in ... Spain
abstract: Home prices are up after years of steady declines, but the rebound is sluggish, because of an oversupply of inventory and Spain’s depressed economy.
lead_paragraph: AN EIGHT-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN THE CENTER OF BILBAO

headline: Resurrected on Broadway: ‘An Act of God,’ This Time with Sean Hayes
abstract: Mr. Hayes will play the title role in this show that imagines God offering a new version of the Ten Commandments for today’s world.
lead_paragraph: Cue the Second Coming puns. “An Act of God” is returning to Broadway.

headline: Car-Pooling Helps Uber Go the Extra Mile
keywords: ['Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Riders pay less and drivers transport more riders at once with the UberPool service, which could have a big impact on local economies and the national transportation infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: One day not long ago, an Uber driver picked up a passenger in San Francisco’s gritty Tenderloin district. Let’s call our passenger Abby, because her real name has been lost to database anonymization, an effort to keep her identity private.

headline: The Quiet Research That Led to a Resounding Success in Diabetes Prevention
keywords: ['Diabetes', 'Medicare', 'Research', 'Exercise', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Everyone wants a “major breakthrough,” but small-scale research efforts often make the biggest difference in the health of Americans.
lead_paragraph: More than 86 million people, including 22 million people 65 or older, have pre-diabetes, which increases their risk of heart disease, strokes or diabetes. As we’ve watched that number grow, it has somehow felt that despite billions of dollars of research and intervention, there’s little we can do.

headline: State Street to Buy G.E.’s Asset Management Business
abstract: The deal is the latest sale as General Electric retreats from finance and refocuses on its industrial roots.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — General Electric said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its asset management business to the State Street Corporation in a transaction worth up to $485 million.

headline: UberPool and the Marvels of Measurement
abstract: Services like UberPool, which matches multiple riders heading in the same directions to cut costs, show consumers love some kinds of surveillance.
lead_paragraph: William Hewlett, the Silicon Valley pioneer who was a co-founder of Hewlett-Packard, once said, “You cannot manage what you cannot measure.” Today’s technology entrepreneurs seem out to prove that the better you measure something, the more you can manage is an equally powerful truth.

headline: Taking Control of the Windows 10 Control Panel
abstract: The familiar old Control Panel screen still lives within Windows 10, but you do not have to dig around the system to find it.
lead_paragraph: Q. I miss having the Control Panel in an easy-to-reach spot on the new Windows Start Menu. Is there any way to get to it faster in Windows 10 besides running a search for it?

headline: Relax, U.S. Soccer Fans. Making the World Cup Shouldn’t Be a Problem.
abstract: After an easy victory over Guatemala, Jurgen Klinsmann and his team can breathe a little easier.
lead_paragraph: American soccer fans breathed a sigh of relief after the men’s national team drilled Guatemala, 4-0, on Tuesday night in Columbus, Ohio. A 2-0 loss in Guatemala City on Friday had seemed to put the United States in peril of not qualifying for the 2018 World Cup.

headline: U.S. Dance Companies to Tour in Exchange Program
abstract: The choreographers Larry Keigwin, Stephen Petronio and Reggie Wilson will take their troupes to nine countries for the sixth season of DanceMotion USA.
lead_paragraph: The choreographers Larry Keigwin, Stephen Petronio and Reggie Wilson will take their companies on tour to nine countries around the world for the sixth season of DanceMotion USA, a cultural exchange program presented by the State Department and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Q. and A.: Ashton Kutcher Talks About His New Netflix Comedy
abstract: “The Ranch” stars Mr. Kutcher and Danny Masterson as two brothers on their family’s financially strapped Colorado homestead.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade ago, Ashton Kutcher and Danny Masterson stepped out of that hazy circle of dope smoke as best bros in “That ’70s Show.” Now they’re back together as brothers, stepping into parental tensions and barnyard detritus, on “The Ranch,” a new Netflix comedy created by Don Reo and Jim Patterson, executive producers on “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Peter Chernin Aims New Streaming Service at Social Media Users
abstract: Fullscreen, owned by Mr. Chernin and AT&T, will offer 800 hours of ad-free programming and allow users to interact with one another in real time for $5 a month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Peter Chernin, who has made a career of beating Hollywood at its own game, is moving deeper into a crowded corner of the entertainment industry: streaming services.

headline: New Albums From Azealia Banks and Anoushka Shankar
abstract: Ms. Banks’s outrageous self-possession plays out vibrantly on “Slay-Z.” Also, new works by Florian Weber and Hayes Carll.
lead_paragraph: SLAY-Z

headline: Is It O.K. if Your Vote Is a Lie? Ask a Canadian
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Strategic voting has come to the fore in the G.O.P. race, but what about the noble notion of being “honest” with your vote?
lead_paragraph: After an Upshot article about strategic voting — “You Say You Loathe Ted Cruz? You Still Might Want to Vote for Him”— one reader had a question:

headline: Jesse Tyler Ferguson Skewers Food Culture on Broadway
abstract: The “Modern Family” star will play a restaurant full of roles in the antic one-man show “Fully Committed.”
lead_paragraph: Securing a table at Gramercy Tavern, the abidingly debonair restaurant on East 20th Street, can, after 22 years, still feel a matter of tooth and claw. You might imagine that Jesse Tyler Ferguson, a star of ABC’s “Modern Family” and five-time Emmy nominee, need barely lift a pinkie to claim one.

headline: Late December
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Death and Dying', 'Christmas']
abstract: After 63 years of marriage, a man’s devotion to his wife is unbroken by Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: If you hang around long enough, you’ll start losing things. Youth, hair, money, your mind, your spouse, your keys, a parent, a sock, a child. Loss throws life out of balance. It demands a reaction.

headline: Late December
abstract: After 63 years of marriage, a man’s devotion to his wife is unbroken by Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: After 63 years of marriage, a man’s devotion to his wife is unbroken by Alzheimer’s.

headline: 1966: France Invites Americans
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: French tourist officials invite Americans to France in 1966.
lead_paragraph: While President Charles de Gaulle is inviting the American military out of France, his tourist officials are inviting Americans in — and, for the first time, right into the very private French home. Under its ‘‘Welcome and Kindness Campaign,’’ the government will also drop a unique invention, the famous ‘‘smile checks.’’ These were given to tourists last summer to reward especially pleasant and helpful citizens. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 31, 1966

headline: What Should The New York Times Sound Like?
abstract: The New York Times is hiring an Executive Producer to help answer that question.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is hiring an Executive Producer to help answer that question.

headline: P-Funkers and Others Come Together to Help Bernie Worrell
abstract: The Black Rock Coalition has organized a benefit for Mr. Worrell, the influential keyboardist in Parliament-Funkadelic, who has Stage 4 cancer.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Worrell’s 1978 debut solo album, “All the Woo in the World,” was both a declaration of independence and a pledge of allegiance, building on the same sonically intrepid, unsinkably grooving style he had honed as the influential keyboardist in Parliament-Funkadelic. The album’s title has now been repurposed for an all-star benefit concert, presented by the Black Rock Coalition, a nonprofit artists’ collective, on Monday night, April 4, at Webster Hall. Proceeds will support Mr. Worrell, 71, who has Stage 4 lung cancer. George Clinton and Bootsy Collins, his P-Funk brethren, will be on deck. As will the singer Nona Hendryx, a driving force behind the event; Living Colour, the best-known Black Rock Coalition band; Jerry Harrison of Talking Heads; and the director Jonathan Demme and the actress Meryl Streep, who have both worked with Mr. Worrell on film. The many other performers include the bassist-producer Bill Laswell and the keyboardist Paul Shaffer. Whatever happens, it should be funky. (8 p.m., websterhall.com.)

headline: On ‘Catastrophe,’ a Monster-in-Law and More Chaos
abstract: The Amazon show, which stars Sharon Horgan, Rob Delaney and Carrie Fisher, starts its second season.
lead_paragraph: When last we saw Sharon Horgan and Rob Delaney in Amazon’s “Catastrophe,” their unplanned pregnancy had led them beyond the altar to a honeymoon maelstrom — something about her gnarly toenails — that threatened to end things before they’d barely begun. Then her water broke. What calamities could Season 2 possibly bring?

headline: ‘Havana’ Arrives at the Joyce Theater
abstract: The choreographer Pedro Ruiz’s “Club Havana” returns as part of Ballet Hispanico’s spring season.
lead_paragraph: If tourism boards made dances instead of posters, “Club Havana,” by the Cuban-American choreographer Pedro Ruiz, would be a winning campaign. When Mr. Ruiz created this cheerful work in 2000 for Ballet Hispanico, his alma mater, few Americans had the opportunity to experience the city firsthand. A dance party with splashes of conga, rumba, mambo and cha-cha, “Club Havana” is the Technicolor version of Cuba — flouncy skirts in rainbow hues, swiveling hips and sly smiles that beckon audiences to visit, which might be possible soon. And now “Club Havana” returns to the Joyce for Ballet Hispanico’s spring season (Tuesday, April 5, through April 10). Filling out the program are Gustavo Ramírez Sansano’s boisterous “Flabbergast” and Ramón Oller’s “Bury Me Standing,” a meditation on Gypsy life and culture set to traditional Eastern European and Spanish popular music. Saturday’s family matinee program offers a sampling of additional repertory from this charismatic company, now marking its 45th anniversary. (joyce.org.)

headline: 7½ Great Midweek Recipes
abstract: Cheese steaks, jazzed-up popcorn and a no-recipe chicken thigh dinner.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Kino! A Festival of German Films
abstract: Isabelle Stever’s “The Weather Inside” and a restored “The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari” are included in this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: Be careful what you wish for. In “The Weather Inside,” an ominous film about internal turmoil in an Arabian hot zone, the jaded main character, Dorothea, says, “I wish a boy from the circus would suddenly appear and carry me off.” But the relationship she falls into eventually morphs from diverting to ominous. Maria Furtwängler, who plays Dorothea, and the film’s director, Isabelle Stever, are scheduled to be on hand when “The Weather Inside” opens this year’s Kino! Festival of German films on Thursday, April 7, at Landmark’s Sunshine Cinema in the East Village. The festival runs through April 14 and also features a restored “The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,” which will be screened on April 11 with a live soundtrack by the D.J. Raphaël Marionneau. Eleven feature films are on the schedule, including three others by female directors: “The Spiderwebhouse” by Mara Eibl-Eibesfeldt; “Hedi Schneider Is Stuck,” by Sonja Heiss; and “The Fassbinder Story,” a documentary by Annekatrin Hendel. For schedule and locations: kinofestivalnyc.com.

headline: Pianists Alexandre Tharaud, Kirill Gerstein and Shai Wosner Hit Stage and Crypt
abstract: Keyboard virtuosos appear in programs covering Beethoven, Bach and Liszt, as well as new pieces.
lead_paragraph: Three talented pianists take the stage in coming days. On Monday, April 4, the suave Frenchman Alexandre Tharaud, who recently released a recording of Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations, goes down into the crypt at the Church of the Intercession, an intriguing performance space, to play that masterpiece. (8 p.m., deathofclassical.com.)

headline: ‘The Mapping Journey,’ Bouchra Khalili’s Searing Refugee Project
abstract: Stateless migrants from the Arab world recount their stories in eight videos to be screened in the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium.
lead_paragraph: In the Moroccan-French artist Bouchra Khalili’s powerful video work “The Mapping Journey Project,” the formal elements are pared to necessities: a paper map of the world; a hand holding a marker, drawing lines on the map across oceans and borders; a voice of a man or a woman telling a first-person story, sometimes harrowing, always arduous, of immigrating illegally from the Middle East or Africa to Europe in search of a better life.

headline: To Feed Hungry Minds, Afghans Seed a Ravaged Land With Books
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Education', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A volunteer organization founded by a teenager has worked to reopen schools and create libraries in some of the Afghan provinces hardest hit by war.
lead_paragraph: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — At first glance, it is not much of a library: two shelves of about 1,600 books and magazines in a basement room deep into a dusty alley of adobe homes in rural Panjwai District, in southern Afghanistan. The mattresses and blankets stacked in the corner still give the vibe of the guest quarters the room once was.

headline: Businessman and Dictator Face Off as Congo Lurches Toward Abyss
abstract: Analysts say the tycoon Moïse Katumbi is best positioned to win Congo’s next election. There is just one problem: There might not be an election.
lead_paragraph: LUBUMBASHI, Democratic Republic of Congo — Sitting in his palatial living room amid lots of marble and white leather, Moïse Katumbi gives off an unmistakable air of being content with his place in the world.

headline: Hollande Withdraws Constitutional Change
abstract: President François Hollande of France decided not to push changing the country's constitution to add a clause allowing convicted terrorists to be stripped of their French nationality.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France decided not to push changing the country's constitution to add a clause allowing convicted terrorists to be stripped of their French nationality.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Rushing to Brussels
abstract: Dan Bilefsky, a Times reporter based in London, takes us behind the scenes of his reporting on the recent attacks in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, feature and opinion items come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Dan Bilefsky, a Times reporter based in London, describes his coverage of the recent attacks in Brussels.

headline: Foxconn’s Deal to Buy Sharp Is a Test for Japanese Reform
abstract: Instead of taking the easy route, Sharp is going to the bidder with the most capabilities, and incentives, to make it profitable and productive.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing pretty about the details of Foxconn’s deal to take control of Sharp.

headline: Is Europe Safe for Travelers? Yes, Experts Say, but Here Are Some Tips
abstract: American tourists seem unfazed by recent terror attacks, but travel experts do suggest some basic precautions.
lead_paragraph: When Corey Patterson heard about the terrorist attacks in Brussels last week, he had a clear-cut response to people who asked if he was going to cancel a coming trip to Belgium.

headline: Michael Stipe Previews David Bowie Tribute Shows With Jimmy Fallon Performance
abstract: The second of two memorial concerts in New York will be available to stream online on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Big-name musical tributes to the late David Bowie just keep coming.

headline: Donald Trump Continues to Stand by Corey Lewandowski’s Side
abstract: Donald J. Trump continued to defend his campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, after the release of a videotape that showed he put a hand on a Breitbart News reporter he had previously denied touching.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump continued to defend his campaign manager on Wednesday after the release of a videotape that showed he put a hand on a Breitbart News reporter he had previously denied touching.

headline: ‘The A Word’ Places Autism Front and Center
abstract: The six-part BBC drama, scheduled to air in the United States this summer, puts a modern spin on family dysfunction, placing autism at its center.
lead_paragraph: Early in the first episode of “The A Word,” a six-part BBC series that premiered on March 22, 5-year-old Joe Hughes has a meltdown at his birthday party. As his parents try to get him to blow out the candles on his cake and his classmates awkwardly stare, the pressure gets the best of Joe and he ends up facedown on the carpet, unable to move or interact with those around him.

headline: Wim Wenders to Direct an Opera for Berlin Company
abstract: Wim Wenders, the filmmaker, will direct Bizet’s “Les Pêcheurs de Perles” for the Berlin’s Staatsoper.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — He has directed more than 30 films in a career spanning four decades, but Wim Wenders, now 70, will soon dip into unfamiliar waters. The Berlin Staatsoper, one of Germany’s foremost opera houses, has announced a collaboration with the filmmaker as part of its 2016-17 season.

headline: In Tourist-Heavy Maui, Finding Deals and Aha Moments
abstract: Away from the resorts, the food is cheap and the natural beauty plentiful and accessible.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally you get those “aha” travel moments — epiphanic flashes when you see or experience something so enchanting that a thought occurs to you: “Yep, that alone just made the entire trip worth it.” On Maui, the tourist-heavy and second-largest Hawaiian island, I was lucky enough to experience one of those.

headline: Expa Labs Will Nurture Tech Start-Ups a Few at a Time
abstract: The program, Expa Labs, will take a smaller-scale approach to helping start-ups grow from idea to prototype to marketable product.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Throw a rock in any direction in Silicon Valley and it may strike a start-up incubator, one of the now-ubiquitous programs aimed at helping entrepreneurs nurture their ideas into full-fledged businesses with funding and advice.

headline: New F.D.A. Guidelines Ease Access to Abortion Pill
abstract: The move was a victory for abortion rights advocates who had been fighting laws in states like Texas, North Dakota and Ohio that required providers to follow the original F.D.A. labels.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has relaxed the guidelines for taking a pill that induces abortion, reviving one of the most contentious issues of the abortion debate. The change allows women to use the drug further into pregnancy and with fewer visits to the doctor.

headline: As New York Debates $15 Minimum Wage, a Bronx Company Makes It a Reality
abstract: While Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pushes for a higher hourly wage, the experience of one business illustrates the impact that such an increase could have on many companies.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not New York State’s minimum wage is raised to $15, Steven Alvarado will still see that increase in his paycheck.

headline: Minneapolis Officers in Jamar Clark Shooting Will Not Face Charges
abstract: The two officers involved in the death of Mr. Clark, an unarmed black man shot during a confrontation, acted with justification, the prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — For more than 30 minutes on Wednesday, the prosecutor described in exacting detail the fatal shooting in November of an unarmed black man by the police and his reasons for not charging the two officers involved.

headline: ‘Archer’ Knocks at the Door of ‘The Simpsons’ and ‘South Park’
abstract: Adam Reed’s FX animated series, beginning its seventh season, is embracing its longevity with a few changes.
lead_paragraph: Ponder the paradox: Television’s most acclaimed scripted series are praised for their ever-deepening characters, yet some of its longest-running shows feature characters who, by many measures, evolve barely, if at all. They are animated series, “The Simpsons” and “South Park” foremost, and they seem as if they could run forever.

headline: MetLife Wins Battle to Remove ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: MetLife has been fighting since 2014 to remove the designation because of the extra regulatory scrutiny it brings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Opponents of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul won an important battle on Wednesday as a federal judge here stripped the “too big to fail” label from the insurance company MetLife.

headline: A Move Toward the Mainstream
abstract: The World Chess Candidates tournament in Moscow this month afforded the sport the opportunity to show a more glamorous side.
lead_paragraph: The World Chess Candidates tournament in Moscow this month afforded the sport the opportunity to show a more glamorous side.

headline: Masters of Chess, Not Self-Promotion
abstract: The American Fabiano Caruana’s failure to win a Moscow tournament was a blow to those hoping to turn the World Chess Championship in New York into a huge spectator event.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In the chandeliered ballroom of Pashkov House, an 18th-century mansion on a hill overlooking the Kremlin, a chess grandmaster dressed in a jacket that seemed several sizes too big declined offerings of canapés, vodka and wine.

headline: The Upside to Technology? It’s Personal
abstract: In his final column, Nick Bilton reflects on the pros and cons of things like social networks and driverless cars, as well as their human side.
lead_paragraph: As a longtime tech columnist, I’ve seen the dark side of technology. I’ve written about the privacy minefields of Facebook and other social networks. I’ve looked at the hate and bullying that people inflict on Twitter. I’ve seen how the front-facing camera on our smartphones can turn us into narcissists.

headline: Puff Daddy Hosting Bad Boy Reunion Concert Celebrating the Notorious B.I.G.
abstract: The May 20 show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn will feature Jay Z, Mary J. Blige, Faith Evans and more associated artists.
lead_paragraph: Puff Daddy is getting the family back together again.

headline: Corporations Grow Nervous About Participating in Republican Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Corporations', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The companies are facing pressure from civil rights groups to stay away from the Cleveland convention, given the emergence of Donald J. Trump as the probable nominee.
lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s best-known corporations are nervously grappling with what role they should play at the Republican National Convention, given the likely nomination of Donald J. Trump, whose divisive candidacy has alienated many women, blacks and Hispanics.

headline: Microsoft Trumpets Windows 10, and Pushes Into Sci-Fi Tech
abstract: The new operating system has had the fastest adoption rate of any Windows version, and the company revealed plans for artificial intelligence and augmented reality projects.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft continues to bank on its Windows operating system. But the software giant is also increasingly staking out new technology areas, including software that can have natural conversations with people.

headline: ‘The Secret Subway,’ by Shana Corey
abstract: A picture book resurrects a long-forgotten mini-subway built under New York City streets in 1870.
lead_paragraph: THE SECRET SUBWAYBy Shana CoreyIllustrated by Red Nose Studio32 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: Vanishing Languages, Reincarnated as Music
abstract: With a sense of racing against time, composers are conducting field research with the goal of preserving or celebrating lost tongues in their work.
lead_paragraph: The Unesco Atlas of the World’s Languages in Danger is a melancholy document, charting the 3,000 or so languages that experts predict will vanish by the end of this century. For the most part, ethnographers and linguists are helpless in the face of the gradual erasure of collective memory that goes along with this loss of linguistic diversity.

headline: Climate Model Predicts West Antarctic Ice Sheet Could Melt Rapidly
abstract: The computer program, which accurately modeled past sea levels for the first time, predicts up to three feet of sea level rise from Antarctica by 2100.
lead_paragraph: For half a century, climate scientists have seen the West Antarctic ice sheet, a remnant of the last ice age, as a sword of Damocles hanging over human civilization.

headline: Israel Polarized Over Soldier Who Killed Wounded Palestinian
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: While many Israelis denounced the shooting, others expressed outrage at their military’s high command for prosecuting the soldier, calling him a hero.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The case of the Israeli soldier who shot a Palestinian assailant in the head as he lay wounded and subdued on the ground is whipping up a public and political storm and posing a rare challenge to the military’s high command, usually the most popular body in the country.

headline: Boyle Heights Gallery Scene in Los Angeles Is Still Growing
abstract: The founders of the new Pssst art gallery say they will focus on artists from underrepresented groups.
lead_paragraph: Downtown Los Angeles and the blocks to its east seem to be in the midst of a takeover by warehouse-size art spaces these days, but that doesn’t mean there isn’t room for more. Two young artists, Barnett Cohen and Jules Gimbrone, have announced plans to open an artist-directed, nonprofit gallery and artist residency in a 5,000-square-foot warehouse in the Boyle Heights neighborhood.

headline: In Settlement, Newark Agrees to a Series of Police Department Reforms
keywords: ['Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The proposed reforms are meant to address unconstitutional practices uncovered by a three-year investigation, including improper searches and excessive use of force.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Federal officials announced on Wednesday that a sweeping settlement had been reached to reform the Newark Police Department after a three-year investigation uncovered a pattern of unconstitutional practices, including improper searches and stops and excessive use of force.

headline: What Does Donald Trump Want?
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Reality Television', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: If elected, would he really deport 11 million people? Or is he just saying that to get crowds to adore him?
lead_paragraph: In a 1976 “Saturday Night Live” skit, Dan Aykroyd and Gilda Radner play a husband and wife who nearly come to blows over whether “New Shimmer” is a floor wax or a dessert topping. Fortunately, Chevy Chase intervenes. “Calm down, you two,” he says, “New Shimmer is a floor wax and a dessert topping.”

headline: Tata Steel Plans to Sell British Plants, Threatening 15,000 Jobs
keywords: ['Steel and Iron', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Profits at the Indian-owned Tata Steel have been squeezed by cheap Chinese imports, and the company suggested that it would consider closing its plants if no buyer came forward.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron faced a new economic and political challenge on Wednesday after the Indian owner of much of Britain’s steel industry said it could no longer swallow the large losses being generated by its plants and would try to sell them.

headline: Obama Commutes Sentences for 61 Convicted of Drug Crimes
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Ex-Convicts', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The action by the president to free the federal inmates — a third serving life terms — underscored his commitment to overhaul sentencing laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ismael Rosa, a salsa singer serving a lifetime prison sentence for drug crimes, had often promised his lawyers that he would sing for them if he ever won his freedom.

headline: Pulled From Festival, Anti-Vaccination Film Will Run in Theater
keywords: ['Movies', 'Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Autism', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “Vaxxed: From Cover-Up to Catastrophe,” which was just cut from the Tribeca Film Festival, is to open at the Angelika Film Center in New York on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A documentary about the widely discredited link between autism and vaccines, which was pulled from the Tribeca Film Festival, will now be released in a New York City theater on Friday, its distributors have said.

headline: Facebook’s Live Videos Get Lots of Looks but No Money Yet
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Despite the appeal of the nascent product, any revenue gain for broadcasters remains a vague promise.
lead_paragraph: When severe weather passed through the Atlanta area early this month, Brad Nitz, a meteorologist for a local television station, WSB-TV, fed viewers live video updates on the station’s website, as he has done for years.

headline: Sizing Up Apple’s New Downsized Devices
abstract: Game apps show off the graphics ability of Apple’s new, smaller iPhone and iPad Pro, and some productivity apps are well suited to the devices.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone SE and the 9.7-inch iPad Pro were the two headline-grabbing devices that Apple unveiled last week. The gadgets stand out because they go against a recent trend of larger screen sizes; both devices have smaller screens than their immediate predecessors.

headline: Lead in Newark Schools
abstract: The A.C.L.U. of New Jersey writes that “state and city officials must ensure that such exposure never happens again.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Donald Trump’s Comments on Foreign Affairs
abstract: Jerry Brown, the governor of California, and another reader discuss an editorial criticizing Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kenneth Feinberg Named to Lead Terrorism Compensation Fund
abstract: Mr. Feinberg, who handled claims by victims of the Sept. 11 attacks and the BP spill, will oversee a fund for victims of state-sponsored terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has appointed Kenneth R. Feinberg, the lawyer who administered compensation for victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, as special master to oversee a new fund to compensate victims of state-sponsored terrorism.

headline: Donald Trump Becomes Reflective During a Rocky Period
abstract: Donald J. Trump ditched his usual stump speech and became unusually reflective, regaling an audience at St. Norbert College in Wisconsin with tips on success, the value of money and an admission that the rigors of being a presidential candidate can sometimes take a toll.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government may not freeze assets needed to pay criminal defense lawyers if the assets are not linked to a crime, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday in a 5-to-3 decision that scrambled the usual alliances.

headline: What’s New in the Beauty Aisle
abstract: New products from Glytone and Fiona Stiles to enhance your skin tone. Plus: British hairstylist Lucinda Ellery offers a new solution for hair loss.
lead_paragraph: Glytone Enhance Brightening Complex, $70 at dermstore.com, a combination of glycolic and azelaic acids, gently lightens hyperpigmentation by breaking up pigment proteins. What’s nice is that it can be applied all over, unlike the often-prescribed skin-lightener hydroquinone, a spot treatment. That makes this cream ideal for larger areas like the hands and décolletage (it’s mild enough for the thin skin there, too). Expect to see results in three months — a lengthy commitment, yes, but in the meantime you’ll get the radiance-boosting benefits of exfoliation. But don’t forget the sunscreen: Glycolic acid increases sun sensitivity.

headline: European Court Backs Britain in 2005 Subway Killing by Police
abstract: The decision is likely to end the fight by relatives of the shooting victim, a Brazilian misidentified as a suicide bomber, to have British officers charged.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Wednesday that British prosecutors were within their authority not to prosecute police officers who shot to death a Brazilian man in a subway station in 2005 after mistaking him for a suicide bomber. The case is likely to end the long fight by relatives of the man, Jean Charles de Menezes, 27, to have the British police charged with his killing.

abstract: The government said it would appeal the release of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the murder of Chris Hani in 1993.
lead_paragraph: The South African government will appeal a judge’s decision to grant parole to the killer of Chris Hani, a leading anti-apartheid activist who was assassinated in 1993, a spokesman for Justice Minister Michael Masutha announced on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: The family of an unarmed teenager who was fatally shot by a police officer last year in Seneca, S.C., has agreed to a $2.15 million settlement to drop their lawsuit against the police, a lawyer for the family said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Producers Will Change Job Posting, but Not Commitment to Diverse Casting
abstract: After Actors’ Equity criticized a casting call seeking “nonwhite men and women” for the hit Broadway musical, the show’s producers said that anyone was welcome to audition.
lead_paragraph: The hit musical “Hamilton” has drawn widespread praise for its use of a diverse cast to explore American history. But a casting call seeking “nonwhite men and women” to audition for the show drew criticism from the union representing theater actors, prompting “Hamilton” to say Wednesday that it will amend its language to make clear that anyone is welcome to try out for the show.

But the program announced Wednesday by the Harris Theater for Music and Dance in Chicago is a bit different: The theater named Brian Brooks its first choreographer in residence, and will spend $600,000 over three years to allow him to create works for several different dance companies.
