lead_paragraph: Of all the things that could distinguish the four teams remaining in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament — record, size, talent, experience — one factor may be undervalued: penmanship.

headline: Nick Waplington’s “A Display of Panic at a Moment of Absolute Certainty”
abstract: The artist, best known as a photographer, is showing a new series of paintings and drawings in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The artist, best known as a photographer, is showing a new series of paintings and drawings in Los Angeles.

headline: A Legendary Photographer (and McQueen Collaborator) Debuts Paintings
abstract: The artist Nick Waplington, best known for his backstage fashion work, opens an exhibition this week in L.A. that contains no photos.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Nick Waplington famously captured Alexander McQueen as he prepared his final winter collection, which became the basis for “Working Process,” a show held last year at the Tate. But Waplington’s latest exhibition, “A Display of Panic in a Moment of Absolute Certainty,” opening Saturday at the Los Angeles gallery These Days, contains no snapshots whatsoever — rather, it is comprised solely of paintings and drawings. Much like the McQueen series, which the designer wanted to be “dirty and messy,” Waplington’s new work reveals a constant concern of his 30-year career: an affinity for barely contained chaos, whether in garbage dumps, the hills above the West Bank city of Ramallah or the maelstrom of fashion shows. None of the paintings in the show, Waplington’s first stateside exhibition sans photography, have a single vantage point, a conscious choice to make it “deliberately difficult to perceive order,” he explains. “My paintings deal with this inner world, whereas my photographic work deals with the world around me,” says Waplington, who will appear Thursday in New York at the Rizzoli bookstore alongside Isaac Mizrahi, whose backstage scene he documented every season from 1989 to 1993. “I guess the basic difference is with photography the canvas is full and with painting it’s empty. Both give me problems.”

headline: NBC to Produce ‘A Few Good Men’ Live, Written by Aaron Sorkin
abstract: The broadcast, based on Mr. Sorkin’s Broadway play, will air in early 2017
lead_paragraph: NBC said on Wednesday that in early 2017 it will broadcast a live version of “A Few Good Men,” Aaron Sorkin’s 1989 Broadway play that was later adapted into a popular 1992 film starring Jack Nicholson and Tom Cruise. Mr. Sorkin, who also wrote the film’s screenplay, before going on to greater renown as a creator of television series like “Sports Night” and “The West Wing,” will write the script.

abstract: Mr. Trump, pressed on his support for an abortion ban, envisioned “some form of punishment” for women having the procedure. Hours later, he revised himself.

headline: Review: For Pennsylvania Ballet, Transitions Onstage and Off
abstract: This Philadelphia company is presenting works by the choreographers Trey McIntyre, Nicolo Fonte and Matthew Neenan at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: All dance companies are, inevitably, in perpetual transition, but that’s unusually pronounced just now at Pennsylvania Ballet, which opened a program of 21st-century choreography on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Since Angel Corella became the company’s artistic director in 2014, large numbers of dancers have come and gone. Some of those dancing in New York this week have arrived since Mr. Corella joined the company, while others are in their final season.

headline: In the Flower District, Galleries Bloom
abstract: In the last few years, Tin Pan Alley and its surrounding area has become home to several prominent art spaces.
lead_paragraph: Slotted between the wholesalers, flower peddlers and midrange hotels, a new crop of galleries have sprung up in New York’s flower district. They’re in the area for various reasons, but they share one thing in common — a love for their neighborhood. “We decided to move into the flower district and Tin Pan Alley because it has history and personality, like our gallery. It’s a part of a New York that exemplifies what this city used to be like,” says Galeria Nara Roesler’s artistic director, Alexandra Garcia Waldman. Waldman oversees the Brazilian gallery’s recently opened outpost on Tin Pan Alley — the stretch of 28th Street between Sixth Avenue and Broadway — but this is not the curator’s first time in the city; she went to school here and has been back and forth ever since. This April, Waldman promotes the films of Cao Guimarães, one of Brazil’s most prolific artists of the 1980s. As Guimaraes’s first solo show in New York, the exhibition exemplifies the gap Nara Roesler hopes to fill in the cultural landscape.

headline: Spring Hair Care Tips and Tricks From a French Colorist
abstract: Christophe Robin shares holistic at-home recipes for lighter and healthier locks.
lead_paragraph: “If you take good care of your hair, the color should last six weeks no problem,” says the French hair colorist Christophe Robin, who’s opening a new salon in Paris soon. He also believes that springtime is when your locks grow — “like vegetation,” he says, attributing the correlation to the increased hours of daylight. In preparation of the season ahead, Robin shares with T his holistic tips and tricks to detox, soothe and lighten strands.

headline: Review: ‘The King and Queen of Malibu,’ a History of Paradise
abstract: David K. Randall’s book is the true story of the battle over shoreline in California.
lead_paragraph: On the map, it’s about 25 miles of shoreline sealed off by a chain of mountains. But a map can’t convey the wildly divergent terrain of saw-toothed peaks and plunging canyons, of peaceable beaches and fast-encroaching tides, of sun and clear skies and floods and wildfires and mudslides.

headline: James McBride on the Godfather of Soul and Getting His Innocence Back
abstract: Mr. McBride, the novelist, has written “Kill ’Em and Leave,” a book about the life of James Brown, including the voices of those who knew him.
lead_paragraph: The novelist and musician James McBride was recently teaching six eager but distractible children to play keyboards in the basement of a modest church in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn. With much patience, he got them to recognize and play a B flat. A few minutes later, a student announced that she was about to lose a tooth. The rest of the class goaded her to pull it out, and when she did, Mr. McBride dropped it into a plastic bag for safekeeping.

headline: The National Jazz Museum in Harlem Finds a Permanent Home
abstract: The museum’s goal is to do public programming that reflects its commitment to jazz outreach at the street level.
lead_paragraph: The National Jazz Museum in Harlem has always been, like the music it honors, a study in adaptability. For the last 15 years, it has operated out of a modest fourth-floor space in East Harlem, while developing big plans for a permanent home. Now, after weathering a few disappointments, the museum has relocated to a new storefront on West 129th Street, in a move that signals not only an improvement to its public facilities but also a renewal of its mission.

abstract: A new book, “The Devil’s Diary: Alfred Rosenberg and the Stolen Secrets of the Third Reich,” reveals how two men uncovered a Nazi artifact.

The diary of Alfred Rosenberg, a Nazi theorist whose views on race are thought to have helped incite Hitler’s persecution of Jews, vanished after its author was convicted of war crimes and hanged at Nuremberg in 1946.

It’s a giddy mix for sure, but Ms. Kloss, the model-slash-entrepreneur-slash-New York University student, pulls it off with aplomb.

headline: The Pathos of Republican Reformers
abstract: Why did they ever think they had a chance?
lead_paragraph: Ross Douthat has a wonderfully written, heartfelt takedown of the WSJ editorial page, which is — surprise! — dead set against any deviation from the tax-cuts-for-the-rich agenda. Definitely worth reading. But my question is, did Republican reformers like Douthat really think there was any chance that their ideas would achieve headway within the party? If so, they were remarkably naive.

abstract: The announcement by the National Liberation Army, known as the E.L.N., raised hopes that the end of a 50-year conflict could be near.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The National Liberation Army, Colombia’s second-largest rebel group, said Wednesday that it would begin negotiations with the government, strengthening hopes that the end of a 50-year rebellion in Colombia could be at hand.

lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — Jason Aaron Baca is good-looking, not handsome like the Ryans (Gosling and Reynolds) or rugged like Daniel Craig, who is fetching in a tailored Tom Ford suit. But when Mr. Baca, 42, slipped on a pair of dark aviator glasses recently, he looked remarkably like Tom Cruise in “Top Gun.”

headline: Adrienne Corri, Actress Known for ‘A Clockwork Orange,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Over almost five decades Ms. Corri acted in a wide range of roles for directors like Stanley Kubrick, David Lean and Jean Renoir.
lead_paragraph: Adrienne Corri, an actress whose movie career lasted nearly five decades and encompassed a wide range of roles, but who was probably best known as the victim in an infamous rape scene in Stanley Kubrick’s “A Clockwork Orange,” died on March 13 at her home in London. She was 84.

headline: A Supreme Court Hijacking
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: The right tries to get the Supreme Court to interpret the Religious Freedom Restoration Act to mean anything the right says it means.
lead_paragraph: There was lots of talk about hijacking the other day at the Supreme Court — not in a criminal case, but in the argument on how far the government must go to shield nonprofit religious organizations from the Affordable Care Act’s requirement to include birth control in employer health care plans.

headline: If Starwood Makes a Deal With Anbang, Can It Be Done?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: The hotel company Starwood faces considerable risk in completing a buyout transaction with the Chinese insurer Anbang.
lead_paragraph: Among the many issues Starwood Hotels & Resorts faces in negotiating a deal with Anbang Insurance Group, the secretive Chinese insurance giant, is a stark one: Any deal Starwood negotiates may not be worth the paper it is printed on.

headline: In San Jose, Poor Find Doors to Library Closed
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The library, owed $6.8 million in fees for overdue and lost items, prohibits children who can’t pay but need the library the most from borrowing materials or using its computers.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When Damaris Triana, then 8, lost several “Little Critter” books that she had borrowed for her sister, the library here fined her $101 — including $40 in processing fees — a bill that was eventually turned over to an agency to collect from her parents.

headline: The Clemency Backlog Continues
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: President Obama’s commutation of 61 unjustly long sentences was another small step in the right direction, but still far from enough.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, President Obama commuted the sentences of 61 people convicted of federal drug and firearm crimes, more than a third of them  serving life in prison.

headline: An Austerity Plan That Would Punish the City
abstract: Despite promises from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, budget maneuvering in Albany could leave a big hole in New York City’s finances.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations in Albany over the New York State budget are hurtling toward an April 1 deadline with a cliffhanger question unanswered: How much damage will the budget do to New York City?

headline: Marching Toward a $15 Minimum Wage
abstract: New York lawmakers have the opportunity to enact a more realistic living wage as a minimum for the whole state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo clearly wants New York to be the first state to enact a statewide minimum wage of $15, but if so, he and the State Legislature will have to move fast to beat California, where on Monday state lawmakers and Gov. Jerry Brown reached a deal on a higher minimum. Mr. Cuomo has included a statewide minimum of $15 in his latest budget. But with an April 1 deadline for the budget, he has an uphill fight to sway Republicans who control the State Senate. His challenge now is to get them to go along without giving too much away.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Buoyed by Poll, Sprints Through Wisconsin
abstract: The senator spent Wednesday crisscrossing Wisconsin, hosting events in three cities and arguing that his stances on trade deals, campaign finance and foreign policy make him a stronger candidate than Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont spent Wednesday crisscrossing Wisconsin, hosting events in three cities and arguing that his stances on trade deals, campaign finance and foreign policy make him a stronger candidate than Hillary Clinton.

headline: Mets Exit Camp, Eager to Be 0-0 Again
abstract: A 12-1 loss to the Nationals left the Mets with a 13-game winless streak to end their Grapefruit League schedule, but they felt positive heading into the season.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When the Mets’ starters exited their game against the Washington Nationals game on Wednesday, they retreated to the clubhouse, cleaned out their lockers and waited for the blowout to end. They had 18 pizzas delivered in the eighth inning and were later whisked away to a bus, which would take them to the airport and their flight out of Florida.

headline: Northern California Is Hit by Wave of Overdoses From a Disguised Drug
abstract: A powerful synthetic drug that is being disguised and illegally sold as a prescription painkiller has caused six deaths in less than a week in Sacramento County, Calif.
lead_paragraph: A powerful synthetic drug that is being disguised and illegally sold as a prescription painkiller has caused six deaths and 22 overdoses in Sacramento County, Calif., in less than a week, an official said.

lead_paragraph: “My grandfather was a law man.” (Pronounced: Moo-mah-lah-di boo-ya do-ray mine)

headline: Cuomo Offers Tax Cut in Effort to Strike a Budget Deal
abstract: Mr. Cuomo announced the framework of a deal for $1 billion in tax cuts for families earning less than $300,000. He also continued to push for a $15 minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Offering a billion-dollar tax cut and assurances that New York City would not be stuck with a $250 million Medicaid bill, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo inched closer on Wednesday to presenting an on-time budget with one major issue seemingly standing in his way — an increase in the minimum wage.

headline: Playing Alongside a Friend Now Known as Caitlyn
abstract: As a teenager, Danielle Kang became close to Caitlyn Jenner, then known as Bruce, a member at Sherwood Country Club outside Los Angeles, where Kang honed her game.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — At the 10th tee, one of Danielle Kang’s amateur playing partners greeted her with the news that she had holed out from the fairway for an eagle on Mission Hills Country Club’s par-4 first hole.

headline: Lengthy Shutdowns in Washington, D.C., Metro System Are Possible
abstract: Repairs to Washington’s aging subway could require the closure of entire rail lines for months at a time, the system’s chairman said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Repairs to Washington’s aging subway could require the closure of entire rail lines for months at a time, the system’s chairman, Jack Evans, said Wednesday. At the very least, Mr. Evans said, riders should expect the closure of segments of individual lines for extended periods.

headline: How New York Allowed Gentrification for $16 Million
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Nursing Homes', 'Gentrification', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The Rivington House deal, netting by far the largest sum received by the city for a deed change during the de Blasio administration, went largely unnoticed, despite community efforts to retain the building as a long-term care center.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, as Mayor Bill de Blasio worked to change zoning codes to compel the creation of more affordable housing, an obscure New York City agency quietly lifted all restrictions on the use of a former nursing home on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Letter Warning Mayor Bill de Blasio of Rivington House Conversion Risks
abstract: A local community board raised alarm over the lifting of a deed restriction last year on Rivington House, a former AIDS hospice on the Lower East Side, warning that it could be resold as luxury apartments.
lead_paragraph: A local community board raised alarm over the lifting of a deed restriction last year on Rivington House, a former AIDS hospice on the Lower East Side, warning that it could be resold as luxury apartments.

headline: Shifting From Wisconsin, Hillary Clinton Tells New Yorkers That She’s One of Them
abstract: In a forceful opening bid to win New York, which she represented in the United States Senate for eight years, Mrs. Clinton presented herself as the quintessential hometown candidate.
lead_paragraph: With Bernie Sanders making headway in Wisconsin before next week’s vote there, Hillary Clinton turned her energies on Wednesday to winning a more pivotal contest: the New York primary on April 19, where a Sanders victory would be a humiliating outcome for her.

headline: Cal Clutterbuck Churns Out Big Goals for Islanders
abstract: Cal Clutterbuck’s hard-nosed play alongside linemates Casey Cizikas and Matt Martin often proves to be a difference-maker for the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — Cal Clutterbuck and John Tavares were linemates for two seasons a decade ago when they were playing junior hockey for the Oshawa Generals.

headline: Paul Pontallier, Who Gave New Life to a Bordeaux Estate, Dies at 59
abstract: Mr. Pontallier helped restore Château Margaux, a celebrated name in the history of wine, to pre-eminence and served as its passionate embodiment.
lead_paragraph: Paul Pontallier, who helped restore the celebrated Bordeaux producer Château Margaux to pre-eminence and served as its passionate embodiment around the world, died on Sunday. He was 59.

headline: Shannon Bolin, 99, Actress Who Starred in ‘Damn Yankees,’ Dies
abstract: Ms. Bolin played Meg Boyd in both the Broadway and film version of the 1950s musical.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Bolin, an actress and singer best remembered as Meg Boyd, the loyal and heartsick wife who was left behind in the original Broadway production of “Damn Yankees” as well as the subsequent movie adaptation, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 99.

headline: At Vegas 16, a Bet on Basketball and, Someday, Greater Ticket Sales
abstract: The Vegas 16 tournament, created this year to attract teams that were not invited to the N.C.A.A. tournament, is the newest event in the increasingly crowded postseason.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Far from the hysteria of March Madness, its billion-dollar television deal and its sold-out stadiums, the largely empty arena at the Mandalay Bay Events Center this week reverberated with the sounds of bouncing basketballs, squeaking sneakers and coaches’ loud, sometimes profane exhortations.

headline: Trump and Abortion
abstract: He’s poorly informed even on his own position.
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought Donald Trump couldn’t say anything more shocking, he suggested that women who get abortions should be punished.

headline: Governor of Alabama, Robert Bentley, Says He Won’t Quit
abstract: As the scandal involving Gov. Robert Bentley’s sexually charged conversations with an adviser unfolds, some lawmakers are talking about impeachment.
lead_paragraph: RUSSELLVILLE, Ala. — The governor of Alabama wanted to talk about broadband.

headline: Campaign Season’s Anti-China Tone Is Likely to Cloud Meeting With Obama
abstract: As President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China prepare to meet, Beijing is viewing the vitriol from candidates like Donald J. Trump as a gauge of American intentions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama refused to bash China when he ran for the White House in 2008, which set him apart from other candidates. None of Mr. Obama’s would-be successors are showing similar restraint. Some, like Donald J. Trump, are bashing Beijing with gleeful abandon.

headline: UConn’s Singular Feats Reveal a Double Standard
abstract: Seeking their fourth straight title, the Huskies are dismissed by some as bad for women’s basketball. But the U.C.L.A. men’s team and Roger Federer were lauded during their eras of dominance.
lead_paragraph: Late on the night of April 9, 2013, Jeff Walz, coach of the Louisville women’s basketball team, had dinner in a New Orleans restaurant after losing the national championship game. One of his companions was Rick Pitino, in from Atlanta after coaching the men’s team to the title the previous night.

headline: Injuries Threaten to Pare Yanks’ Loaded Bullpen
abstract: With Andrew Miller and Bryan Mitchell sustaining injuries on Wednesday, the Yankees’ formidable bullpen could be perilously thin when the season begins.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As Andrew Miller left the Yankees’ clubhouse early Wednesday evening, his bruised right wrist heavily bandaged, he felt lucky to be merely annoyed.

headline: Self-Congratulatory Words
abstract: Ellen Leuschner and Jeff Chen say what they mean.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Just beautiful. Ellen Leuschner has now had seven crosswords published in The New York Times, six of them collaborations with either Jeff Chen or Victor Fleming. She’s back today with Mr. Chen, and she’s quickly becoming a favorite constructor of mine.

headline: Before a Trump Rally, Protesters Lay Plans Behind the Scenes
abstract: So conflict-prone have Donald Trump’s campaign rallies become that they have prompted an elaborate game of cat-and-mouse that takes place out of view of the television cameras.
lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Clearing the metal detectors does not necessarily mean entry into a Donald J. Trump campaign rally. Getting past the private security guards is but one interim step as well. The key hurdle is bypassing the Trump sentries, the eagle-eyed loyalists in black suits who are the ultimate determiners of who gets in and who stays out.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 11: Hakeem Rises
abstract: In typical “Empire” fashion, the show almost immediately resolved last year’s cliffhanger.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long recess, but “Empire” is finally back to gather the pieces of all the lives that the dramatic midseason finale shattered. Rather than making us wait for a resolution to the murder attempt against Andre Lyon’s wife, Rhonda, Episode 11 immediately reveals that she survived but her baby didn’t.

headline: A New Verse in the Ballad of Ellis Island’s First Immigrant
abstract: An Irish tenor had sung the story of the immigrant Annie Moore many times, but it became more than an old tune when he learned he had a special connection to her.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Paul Linehan, a 47-year-old tenor from Narraghmore in County Kildare, Ireland, would sing those lines from the maudlin Irish ballad “Isle of Hope, Isle of Tears,” but last week, for the first time, he choked on the lyrics.

headline: Pentagon Plans More Prisoner Transfers From Guantánamo
abstract: The Defense Department has informed Congress that it intends to transfer up to a dozen more prisoners from the military prison in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department has informed Congress that it intends to transfer up to a dozen more prisoners from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a United States government official said late Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Season 4, Episode 3: Who’s Up for a Trip to Epcot?
abstract: Has there ever been a television character as hard to kill off as Pastor Tim?
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been a television character as hard to kill off as Pastor Tim of “The Americans”? On Wednesday night, for the second week in a row, his ticket was ready to be punched. But once again he was saved at the last minute — saved by, of all things, the glanders virus, which appears to have escaped its bottle, infected Gabriel and forced Elizabeth and Philip into an informal quarantine.

headline: At Work in Gold
abstract: Scenes from the factory of the Italian jeweler Roberto Coin.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the factory of the Italian jeweler Roberto Coin.

headline: Aftershock: How Terrorism Sways Politics
abstract: In Germany, it’s Pegida. In Greece, Golden Dawn. And in France, it’s the National Front. Fueled by fear, Europe’s far-right political movements are gaining momentum. A New York Times documentary.
lead_paragraph: In Germany, it’s Pegida. In Greece, Golden Dawn. And in France, it’s the National Front. Fueled by fear, Europe’s far-right political movements are gaining momentum. A New York Times documentary.

abstract: “Archer” gets a career makeover. David Hasselhoff spoofs himself. And Tom Hanks and Gary Goetzman look back at the 1980s.

abstract: In a culture in which women’s lives are controlled by their husbands, Anahit Hayrapetyan has dedicated herself to documenting crimes in Armenia that have long been swept under the rug.
lead_paragraph: In a culture in which women’s lives are controlled by their husbands, Anahit Hayrapetyan has dedicated herself to documenting crimes in Armenia that have long been swept under the rug.

headline: Gail Minglana Martinez, Mother in Air Force Family, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: All six members of her family were wounded in the attack on Brussels Airport. The others, her officer husband and four children, remain hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: They posed against a bright yellow background, both of them in blue shirts, broad smiles across their faces.

lead_paragraph: This week Lens is featuring photographers from around the world who have been chosen to attend the fourth annual New York portfolio review.

headline: The Republican Gun-Free Zone
abstract: If you want to be safe from being shot by a well-armed Donald Trump or Ted Cruz, go to the G.O.P.’s convention.
lead_paragraph: Latest in the long, long line of Controversies We Weren’t Really Expecting: the right to bear arms at the Republican National Convention.

headline: ‘Bernie or Bust’ Is Bonkers
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Elections are not always between a dream candidate and a dreaded one. Sometimes they’re between common sense and catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders’s surrogate Susan Sarandon went on MSNBC’s “All in With Chris Hayes” earlier this week and said something that made folks’ jaws drop.

headline: Adventures in the Trump Twittersphere
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Donald Trump’s rise shows just how powerless media gatekeepers are.
lead_paragraph: EVERY morning since August, I have steeled myself to enter an alternate universe. I scroll through social media feeds where people are convinced that Congress funds the Islamic State, that our president hates this country and wants it to fail and that Donald J. Trump is the only glimmer of hope in this bleak landscape.

headline: Is Voting Out of Self-Interest Wrong?
keywords: ['Elections', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The fact is, we do. And in some cases, it can be ethically justified.
lead_paragraph: It is a staple of American politics to criticize those who vote simply out of their own self-interest. Democrats often denounce the superrich for supporting candidates who promise to lower their taxes; Republicans frequently say workers opposed to free trade put their job security over the nation’s economic health. In particular, it’s easy to think of elections as primarily a clash between conflicting economic interests.

headline: Suppress Votes? I’d Rather Lose My Job
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The Supreme Court gutted important parts of the Voting Rights Act in 2013. It is time to restore those protections, writes a Republican congressman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DURING my 10 years in the Wisconsin State Legislature, I spent significant time in Milwaukee’s majority black neighborhoods. I listened as constituents described obstructions to their constitutional right to vote.

headline: Dalian Wanda Group Seeks to Delist Its Commercial Property Arm
abstract: The potential privatization of Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties comes just 15 months after it raised $3.7 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Dalian Wanda Group of China said Thursday that it may privatize its commercial property company in a deal that could be worth about $4 billion.

headline: With ‘Gigs’ Instead of Jobs, Workers Bear New Burdens
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'United States Economy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Employers are succeeding in shifting some of the burden of providing social insurance onto workers.
lead_paragraph: If you believe the Silicon Valley sloganeers, we are in a “gig economy,” where work consists of a series of short-term jobs coordinated through a mobile app. That, anyway, is both the prediction of tech executives and futurists and the great fear of labor activists.

headline: News Q’s | How New York Gets Its Water
abstract: How do you imagine the water you drink gets to you?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “How New York Gets Its Water.”

headline: Is China's Policy Toward North Korea Changing?
abstract: This month, Beijing backed U.N. sanctions against Pyongyang. Is this evidence of a power shift in the region?

headline: A Husband’s Transgender Secret Takes Its Toll
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Children and Childhood', 'Marriages']
abstract: A happy marriage unravels as he faces his need to become a woman.
lead_paragraph: In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates Helps a New Panther Leave Its Print
abstract: Written by the National Book Award winner, this new comic-book version of the Black Panther arrives as the character joins the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
lead_paragraph: The Black Panther may not be the mightiest superhero on the planet, but he’s certainly among the coolest. Created in 1966, he was the first black superhero in mainstream comics. While his cape-wearing peers spend their off hours slogging away at mundane day jobs — reporter at a major metropolitan newspaper, say — the Panther is a king, the sovereign ruler of Wakanda, the fictional, technologically advanced African nation. And then there’s his costume: skintight and jet black from head to toe. His former wife, Ororo Munroe (Storm of the X-Men), can summon hurricanes.

headline: In Brooklyn, More Space for the Money
abstract: Jenny Mak and James Nguyen found a one-bedroom in Carroll Gardens that they could convert to a two-bedroom.
lead_paragraph: For more than five years, Jenny Mak lived in a one-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side, not far from her alma mater, Columbia University, where she is an administrator, a teacher and a student adviser.

headline: A Terror Attack, Then Far Right Moves In
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Attacks in Brussels and Paris, as well as a surge of migrants, have left parties like France’s National Front with the political winds at their back.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — In the United States and Europe, mainstream political parties find themselves besieged. Two-party systems that were once stable are under new pressure, fracturing and creating openings for populists on the extremes, left and right.

headline: A Hole in North Korean Sanctions Big Enough for Coal, Oil and Used Pianos
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Smuggling', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: When the United Nations approved tougher restrictions, it was understood they would work only if China complied. So far, border enforcement has been spotty.
lead_paragraph: DANDONG, China — Before he drives the beat-up taxi into North Korea, Mr. Qin does two things. He packs a bribe, often something as simple as fresh apples or bananas, or sometimes as much as $200. And he snips the car’s radio wires.

headline: Thin Air Equals High Pressure, at Least for Rockies Pitchers
abstract: In the Rockies’ latest attempt to help their pitchers, they are raising parts of Coors Field’s outfield wall. But it may be time for something more radical.
lead_paragraph: Shortly into spring training, the Colorado Rockies announced that they would raise  Coors Field’s outfield fences. Well, some of them, anyway: From right-center field to straightaway right field, the height of the wall is nearly doubling, to 16 ½ feet; down the left-field line, it is going to 13 feet from 8 feet.

headline: Colorado Pitching Coaches Want an Atmosphere of Confidence
abstract: Steve Foster and Darren Holmes will try to persuade the Rockies’ young staff to challenge hitters at high altitude, avoiding walks and self-doubt.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — With the fifth overall pick in the 1992 expansion draft, the Colorado Rockies chose Darren Holmes, a relief pitcher from the Milwaukee Brewers. The prospect of working a mile above sea level did not intimidate Holmes, who had pitched well in a brief stint for the Brewers’ Class AAA team, based in Denver. He soon developed a simple theory about pitching there.

headline: Signs of Wisconsin Backlash Against Donald Trump, Who Trails in Poll
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The Stop Trump movement may never have another opportunity like the one in Wisconsin, where resistance to Mr. Trump was high even before his latest controversies.
lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — The danger signs are mounting for Donald J. Trump in Wisconsin: Right-wing radio hosts are flaying him, Gov. Scott Walker and other elected Republicans have endorsed Senator Ted Cruz, and a new poll showed Mr. Cruz with a 10-percentage-point lead in the state before Tuesday’s primary.

headline: Student Question | Should Schools Be Teaching, and Evaluating, Social-Emotional Skills Like ‘Grit’?
abstract: Should schools teach, and then evaluate you on, qualities like self-control, resilience and conscientiousness?
lead_paragraph: According to a recent article, more and more schools are pushing not just to teach, but also to measure students’ social-emotional skills, like empathy and perseverance.

headline: A Push to Get Out the Vote in New York
abstract: Spurred by relatively low turnout in the state in recent elections, groups representing business leaders are hoping that by highlighting a law requiring employers to give their workers two hours of paid leave to head to the polls, they can help lift participation in the coming primaries.
lead_paragraph: As the New York presidential primaries on April 19 draw nearer, groups of business leaders are joining together in an effort to help people vote by highlighting a state law that requires employers to give their workers two hours of paid leave to head to the polls.

headline: Nuclear Summit Meeting to Begin in Washington With Terrorism Risks a Central Topic
abstract: President Obama will host 50 heads of state in Washington beginning on Thursday to try to enhance worldwide security of nuclear materials, a meeting with new urgency given suspicions of terrorist groups’ interest in a nuclear plant in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: Fifty heads of state will convene in Washington beginning on Thursday to try to enhance worldwide security of nuclear materials, a meeting with new urgency given suspicions of terrorist groups’ interest in a nuclear plant in Belgium.

headline: Ask Well: Is Swimming in Pools Safe During Pregnancy?
abstract: Swimming is considered one of the safest forms of exercise for pregnant women.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Talking Abortion, Donald Trump Gives Rivals on Both Sides Fresh Fodder
abstract: In a town-hall-style forum on MSNBC, Donald J. Trump, a late-in-life convert to an anti-abortion view, said that he believed, should there be a ban put in place on the procedure, that women who get one should face a “punishment” of as-yet-undetermined length.
lead_paragraph: Every day, it seems that Donald J. Trump must soon run out of ways to counteract negative perceptions of his campaign. And yet, he has continued to find new ones, as he did on Wednesday.

headline: Six Months Pregnant and Asking, ‘Am I Depressed?’
abstract: Something changed after I acknowledged that I was struggling, that I needed help: I started to feel better.
lead_paragraph: On a walk with my husband through Joshua Tree National Park in late January, I felt sad for no reason in particular. Or maybe for lots of really good reasons. I wasn’t sure which it was.

headline: What I Learned From Kristi Yamaguchi
abstract: Growing up as a Korean adoptee in a white family was often confusing and isolating. But watching someone who looked like me dominate on the ice changed everything.
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw her she wasn’t even skating. I was flipping through the handful of channels our TV could pick up with its rabbit-ear antenna when I glimpsed her waving from the tallest podium at the 1991 World Figure Skating Championships, dazzling in rhinestone-studded hot magenta, with her high hair-sprayed bangs and million-watt smile. She’s Asian, I thought. There’s an Asian girl on television, and everyone is cheering for her.

headline: A Korean Noodle Dish for Lonely Hearts
abstract: Jajangmyeon is comfort food of the first order, as pleasing as takeout pizza or kung pao chicken.
lead_paragraph: There are at least three holidays in South Korea notionally dedicated to friendship and romance. The first comes from the West: Valentine’s Day, on Feb. 14, when girls give chocolate to boys. The second is a gendered response: White Day, on March 14, an invention of the candy industry, when boys offer girls marshmallows, white chocolate and other snowy confections.

headline: The Next Playwright to Know? Florian Zeller, From France to Broadway in a Big, Busy Leap
abstract: His play “The Father” comes to New York after successful runs in Paris and London.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An old man, André, is home in his apartment as people come and go. There’s his daughter, Anne, and her boyfriend. Or is it her first husband? And is she really moving to London? Laura, his new caregiver, the one he seems to like, keeps him company. So then why would she steal his watch?

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Segmented Sleep
abstract: It’s not insomnia if you stay up voluntarily.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, an edgy, blanked-­out feeling nestled in with me and wouldn’t leave. I’d find myself sitting at my desk, facing emails that I couldn’t remember sending and deeply wished to retract. How had my life been put in the hands of someone like me? I had no attention, no patience; whatever I did, I was bored 10 seconds later. I closed my eyes and saw browser tabs on the inside of my lids.

headline: The Invisible Catastrophe
keywords: ['Methane', 'Natural Gas', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Over the course of four months, 97,100 metric tons of methane quietly leaked out of a single well into California’s sky. Scientists and residents are still trying to figure out just how much damage was done.
lead_paragraph: ‘It just seems like a beautiful day in Southern California,” Bryan Caforio said.

headline: Why Mapplethorpe Still Matters
abstract: Because he’s become part of the canon, with auction prices to match, but there are still places — The New York Times is one — where his most sexually charged photographs are considered too transgressive for reproduction.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a midcareer self-portrait, Robert Mapplethorpe depicted himself as a devil, with a bullwhip for a tail. But he ended up on the side of the angels. In 1989, a traveling survey of his work, with pictures of extreme homosexual acts, pushed the American culture wars into high gear. Religious groups raged. An indignant Congress cut federal money to artists. The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, set to host the show, dropped it like a shot.

headline: An Island in the Bahamas Where Pigs Swim Free
abstract: On Big Major Cay, tourists and swine play together on the sand and in the water.
lead_paragraph: On Big Major Cay, tourists and swine play together on the sand and in the water.

headline: Running in Cuba
abstract: Big things are about to happen in Cuba, a place with a complex history, but I felt a bit removed from it all until I struck out in my running shoes.
lead_paragraph: The tap on my shoulder came about 20 minutes into my first run along the Malecón, Havana’s seawall. “Maratón? Maratón?” Was I training for a marathon? The question came from a runner in his early 20s, wearing shorts and a racing singlet.

headline: Imre Kertesz, Nobel Laureate Who Survived Holocaust, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: What set the Hungarian writer apart from others was his insistence on describing Auschwitz and Buchenwald without outrage, especially in his definitive work, “Fateless.”
lead_paragraph: Imre Kertesz, a Nobel laureate who was acclaimed for his semi-autobiographical novels on surviving the Holocaust and its aftermath, died on Thursday at his home in Budapest. He was 86.

headline: Top Female Players Accuse U.S. Soccer of Wage Discrimination
abstract: Carli Lloyd, Alex Morgan and Hope Solo are among those contending that they are the driving economic force for U.S. Soccer but are paid far less than men’s players.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer, the governing body for the sport in America, pays the members of the men’s and women’s national teams who represent the United States in international competitions. The men’s team has historically been mediocre. The women’s team has been a quadrennial phenomenon, winning world and Olympic championships and bringing much of the country to a standstill in the process.

headline: Q. and A.: Hyeonseo Lee on North Korean Defectors in China
abstract: Ms. Lee, who hid in China for a decade after defecting from North Korea, discusses her experiences and China’s relationship with North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Hyeonseo Lee, who lived in a North Korean town near the border with China, often wondered why there were so many more lights on the Chinese side. One winter night in 1997, when she was 17, she walked across the frozen Yalu River to see for herself. What began as an excursion to satisfy her curiosity turned into a decade of hiding in China. In 2008, Ms. Lee made her way to South Korea, where she was granted asylum.

lead_paragraph: Vetements, the upstart collective built on a combination of elevated grit and Martin Margiela antecedents that has become the darling of French fashion, has proved influential in any number of ways, inciting a renaissance in the industry’s fascination with street style and the exaggerated silhouette that culminated in one of its founders, Demna Gvasalia, being named artistic director of Balenciaga. Which means that Vetements’ recent reaction to a parody garment created by Davil Tran, a 22-year-old from Brooklyn, could be something of a turning point.

headline: Review: ‘No Home Movie,’ of Love and Melancholy
keywords: ['Movies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Chantal Akerman’s last feature, about her mother, makes the viewer wonder how any of us, in our unguarded intimacy, manage to survive.
lead_paragraph: The last time the filmmaker Chantal Akerman appears in “No Home Movie” she’s tying her shoelaces. Seated on a bed in a dark, sparsely furnished room with a single window, she doesn’t say anything. She just ties her shoes, draws the curtains and exits, letting the shot linger on the empty room. Her mother, Natalia, has been failing and Ms. Akerman’s melancholy hangs over the scene like funeral crepe. The first time I watched it, her heavy silence was painful to see; the second time, watching had turned into raw feeling because Ms. Akerman is now gone.

headline: Seoul Celebrates the Home of an American Hero

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For decades, squatters have lived inside a dilapidated red brick house on a hillside not far from the royal palace in Seoul.

headline: A Push to Rebuild a Modernist Gem by Mies
abstract: German architects and planners are seeking to rebuild Mies van der Rohe’s Wolf House, an important transitional design. But some experts oppose the idea.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For almost 20 years, the stern, cuboid forms of the German-American architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s Wolf House loomed over the town of Guben on the Neisse River in Germany. But in 1945, as the Soviet Army approached from the east, the owners of the house, the Wolf family, fled, and their home was destroyed in the chaos that ensued.

headline: Playing On Despite the Fear of Terrorism
abstract: An exhibition soccer match between Germany and England was a symbol of defiance after the attacks in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In years past it might have seemed a routine weekend — a trip to Germany, a soccer match between the home country and England. But after the terrorist attacks in Brussels, routine has become elusive, replaced by newer questions: How will Europeans respond to the jihadist onslaught from within their citadel, and how will they know who is winning?

headline: To Unify Europe, Face the Mideast as One

Cooperating more effectively on counterterrorism while tightening security at airports and train stations would be a start.

headline: Between Playboy’s Pages, a Peek at How a Future Donald Trump Would Campaign
abstract: In a 1990 interview, the mogul detailed a grievance-filled agenda and a denunciation of weak leadership, remarks strikingly similar to his 2016 campaign message.
lead_paragraph: Bookended by ads for Trojan condoms and Malibu Ultra Light cigarettes, the lengthy interview in Playboy magazine is a remarkably prophetic document. Twenty-six years ago this month, Donald J. Trump sat down with Glenn Plaskin, a celebrity columnist, and, over a glass of chilled Coke, offered a grievance-filled economic agenda, a searing denunciation of weak-kneed American leadership and a keen understanding of his appeal to blue-collar Americans that uncannily resembled the White House campaign he is waging today — without Twitter, which didn’t yet exist.

headline: Ukraine’s Unyielding Corruption
abstract: The overdue dismissal of Viktor Shokin will do nothing to prevent further abuses of power unless there is serious judicial reform.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Parliament finally voted to oust Ukraine’s odious prosecutor general, Viktor Shokin, on Tuesday. The United States and European countries that have provided aid to Ukraine had long pressed for his dismissal; in his year in office, Mr. Shokin became a symbol of Ukraine’s deeply ingrained culture of corruption, failing to prosecute a single member of the deposed Yanukovych regime or of the current government while blocking the efforts of reform-minded deputies. Alas, nothing is likely to change unless President Petro Poroshenko and Parliament agree to install some real corruption fighters and approve serious judicial reform.

headline: Argentina’s Senate Allows Payment to Bondholders

lead_paragraph: Argentina’s Senate has approved measures that will allow the government to pay billions of dollars to American hedge funds, a critical step toward settling a legal battle that is more than a decade old.

headline: 1966: Verwoerd Party Sets a Record

headline: A Young Design Duo’s Colorful Spirit
abstract: The husband and wife behind Raw-Edges Studio create whimsical things like collapsible light fixtures and a one-room house with movable walls.
lead_paragraph: As partners both personally and professionally, Shay Alkalay and Yael Mer, the Israeli couple behind the London-based Raw-Edges Studio, spend a lot of time together. “At home we talk about work,” Alkalay says, “and at the studio, we talk about our daughters.” The whimsical, curious spirit that informs their designs — a one-room house with movable walls; flower-shaped leather folding chairs — has struck a chord with clients like Louis Vuitton and Stella McCartney, and earned them a commission for this year’s Salone del Mobile design fair. There, the pair debuted a project that builds on, yet departs from, their popular Endgrain series (above left and center), for which they saturated wood blocks with colorful dye, then glued them together to create three-dimensionally patterned furniture. For Salone, they dipped wood in overlapping coats of pigment for a herringbone effect — a fittingly layered approach for a duo with plenty of history.

headline: 1941: France Faces Food Shortages
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: France faces food shortages in 1941.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Besides a drastic reduction in bread ration for occupied France, which, beginning April 1, will cut the average per capita consumption from 300 grams down to 200 (from 10.5 to 7.05 ounces), the French government has announced a number of stringent measures indicating that the country is fast reaching the bottom of its larder. Because 65 percent of the nation’s hog stock was lost as a result of the war, price rises ranging from 37 to 85 percent have been authorized to keep down consumption. The price of lard will be increased 89 percent. — New York Herald Tribune, April 1, 1941

headline: Zaha Hadid, Groundbreaking Architect, Dies at 65

lead_paragraph: Dame Zaha Hadid, the Iraqi-born British architect whose soaring structures left a mark on skylines and imaginations around the world and in the process reshaped architecture for the modern age, died in Miami on Thursday. She was 65.

lead_paragraph: In a political season that has seemed to feature a fresh outrage every day, the way Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey eats his M&M’s would not really seem to rank highly.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Miles Ahead’
abstract: Don Cheadle, the director and star of “Miles Ahead,” discusses a sequence from his film about Miles Davis.
lead_paragraph: Don Cheadle, the director and star of “Miles Ahead,” discusses a sequence from his film about Miles Davis.

headline: Donald Trump: The Art of the Address
abstract: We are met here on a great battlefield. Isn’t it great? It’s great, believe me.
lead_paragraph: FOURSCORE and seven years ago, our fathers — and also, our mothers. I love mothers, too, because we need our mothers — brought forth on this continent a huge nation, a great, amazing country dedicated to the proposition that we can beat any weak losers who are bad, bad guys and totally overrated, believe me.

headline: Don Cheadle Narrates a Scene From ‘Miles Ahead’
abstract: The director and actor discusses a sequence from his film about the jazz musician Miles Davis.
lead_paragraph: Don Cheadle takes on the role of the jazz trumpeter Miles Davis for an unconventional biopic “Miles Ahead,” which zeroes in on a period of the performer’s life in the late ’70s when he wasn’t actually performing. In a recent interview, Mr. Cheadle spoke about a scene from the film in which Miles meets with an opportunistic journalist, Dave Brill (Ewan McGregor). Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Improbable Rangers Win in 1970 Left Canada Out in the Cold
abstract: The shutout of Canadian teams from the N.H.L. playoffs this year evokes the 1969-70 season, the only other time it happened.
lead_paragraph: Late on the night of April 4, 1970, at an airport in Windsor, Ontario, Emile Francis, the Rangers’ coach at the time, bumped into Sid Abel, who was coaching the Detroit Red Wings. The two men had arrived with their teams for separate Air Canada charter flights to New York.

headline: A Look at Zaha Hadid’s Designs
abstract: Ms. Hadid, an Iraqi-British architect who left a mark on skylines around the world, died on Thursday at 65.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Hadid, an Iraqi-British architect who left a mark on skylines around the world, died on Thursday at 65.

headline: Ensuring That Educators Are Honest About Job Prospects
abstract: Disclosure about true job placement would be better than lawsuits and government relief.
lead_paragraph: Students deserve debt relief, but the truth should come first.

headline: Injured Yankees Relievers See Their Fortunes Turn, for Better and Worse
abstract: Andrew Miller will try to pitch despite a break to a “nonessential” wrist bone, but Bryan Mitchell will miss time with a broken foot bone.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Andrew Miller and Bryan Mitchell arrived on Thursday morning at their lockers, located next to each other, the pitchers were a dichotomy of the fickle nature of sports injuries. Miller sat in his chair, his right wrist wrapped to protect a chipped bone. Mitchell stood on crutches picking through his belongings.

headline: A Love of Drawing and Telling Stories: One Ceramist’s Perfect Formula
abstract: Katharine Morling, whose works are on view at Bergdorf Goodman beginning Thursday, let T into her London studio.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t guess from the luxurious parquet wood floor, but the South London studio of the British ceramist Katharine Morling sits in a former government building. “When I first moved here 12 years ago, I just had a strip of space,” says Morling, gesturing to the corner of her now roomy workshop at Cockpit Arts in Deptford, a thriving creative community that’s home to some 65 artists and designers. (She is sandwiched between a guitar-maker and a wood-turner.) There are shelves full of the unglazed, ink-drawn pieces for which Morling, who lives just 10 minutes away along the river in Greenwich, has become known and which will be on view beginning today at Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Inside the British Ceramist Katharine Morling’s Studio
abstract: The artist, whose work is now on view at Bergdorf Goodman, shares her process with T.
lead_paragraph: The artist, whose work is now on view at Bergdorf Goodman, shares her process with T.

headline: Smithsonian Says Museum Will Include Mention of Bill Cosby Sexual Assault Accusations
abstract: The National Museum of African American History and Culture, opening in September, will recognize his pioneering work in comedy and TV as well as his damaged legacy.
lead_paragraph: After days of questioning, the National Museum of African American History and Culture, which opens in Washington in September, said on Thursday that it would add a reference to accusations of sexual assault made against Bill Cosby in an exhibition that recognizes pioneering work in comedy and television.

headline: Endometriosis Tied to Increased Risk for Heart Disease
abstract: It may be especially important for women with endometriosis, especially those under 40, to follow a heart-healthy lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: Women with endometriosis, especially those under 40, are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease, a new study has found.

headline: Obamacare on Track
abstract: Uninsured right on the projections.
lead_paragraph: Largely as a note to myself.

headline: Beware of April Fools’ Day
abstract: We’re The New York Times, and we hate fun. Just kidding! But we are here to warn you not to fall for April Fool’s Day pranks. You’re welcome.
lead_paragraph: We’re The New York Times, and we hate fun. Just kidding! But we are here to warn you not to fall for April Fool’s Day pranks. You’re welcome.

headline: U.N. Peacekeeping Hit by New Allegations of ‘Sickening’ Sex Abuse
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The allegations, if confirmed, would expand the scope of the sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers deployed in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations is investigating a litany of “sickening” new allegations that peacekeepers from at least three countries sexually abused civilians in the Central African Republic, including more than 100 girls in one prefecture, the organization said on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘H.,’ a Fireball Sends Things Spinning Out of Control
abstract: This mysterious film, inspired by a Greek tragedy, depicts the parallel lives of two women named Helen in Troy, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A movie that raises more questions than it answers lends itself perfectly to a review that starts with a quiz:

headline: Pittsburgh TV Anchor Is Fired After Racial Facebook Post
abstract: After a shooting, Wendy Bell made comments about “young black men” that some felt relied on damaging stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks after a grisly shooting in a Pittsburgh suburb, Wendy Bell, a local news anchor for WTAE-TV, wrote a public Facebook post that focused in part on finding hope and offering kindness.

headline: Corporations No Longer Sit Idly By on Discrimination
abstract: Major employers in North Carolina have denounced a bill that overturned an ordinance in Charlotte that protected people from discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: When North Carolina voters were considering a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage in 2012, the silence from North Carolina companies was deafening.

headline: Gilles Laurent, a Filmmaker With an Eye for Sounds, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Mr. Laurent, 46, had such an intimate connection with the noises of everyday life that his collaborators say he “looked” at sounds as if observing an object.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gilles Laurent, 46, a Belgian sound engineer and documentary filmmaker, had such an intimate connection with the noises of everyday life that his collaborators say he “looked” at sounds as if observing an object, a color or a shape.

abstract: A reader praises the F.D.A.’s decision to ease access to the pill as based on science, not politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Two readers offer opposing views of the B.D.S. movement on college campuses.

abstract: A reader is stunned that anyone would consider it a good idea.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A doctor writes, “Research finds that genetic testing actually has the potential to be profoundly valuable.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Queasy About Flare-Ups in the South China Sea? Helene Cooper Can Relate.
abstract: Four days on tranquil waters was one thing; six days and monster-sized waves was quite another.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Helene Cooper, The Times’s Pentagon correspondent, reveals what unnerved her during a recent 6-day stint on a U.S. Navy cruiser in the South China Sea. Hint: It wasn’t the threat of Chinese torpedoes.

headline: Investigators Pursue Leads on Frenchman Accused of Terror Plot
abstract: Reda Kriket, 34, previously convicted of robbery and acts of violence, had amassed an arsenal of weapons and bombs, and on Wednesday he was charged with terrorist conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Soldiers, police officers and at least one bomb-sniffing dog descended on a wooded residential neighborhood in northwestern Belgium on Thursday morning as investigators dug into the activities of Reda Kriket, a Frenchman who has been charged with plotting an “imminent attack” in France.

headline: Cameron Rules Out Nationalization of Britain’s Struggling Steel Industry
keywords: ['Steel and Iron', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron spoke after Tata Steel, an Indian company, announced on Wednesday that it would seek to sell its British steel factories.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain emerged from an emergency cabinet meeting on Thursday to say that the government would do all it could to preserve the British steel industry but that nationalization was not an option.

headline: The Cities on the Sunny Side of the American Economy
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Relocation of Business', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: In places like Denver, Seattle and Atlanta, employers are hiring at a steady clip, housing prices are up and consumers are spending more avidly.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When the aerospace company Sierra Nevada Corporation moved into the Colorado Technology Center about eight years ago, employees on their lunch break could stroll by the alpaca farm next door.

abstract: Readers discusses the candidate’s remarks on abortion and his view of women.

headline: White House Assails Donald Trump Proposal to Let Asian Allies Get Nuclear Weapons
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A White House official said it would be “catastrophic” to adopt a proposal by Donald J. Trump that Japan and South Korea manufacture their own nuclear bombs to deter North Korea, upending decades of work to prevent proliferation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House official said on Thursday that it would be “catastrophic” to adopt a proposal by Donald J. Trump, the Republican front-runner, that Japan and South Korea manufacture their own nuclear bombs to deter North Korea.

headline: ‘Falsettos’ Revival Casts Its Leads: Christian Borle, Andrew Rannells and Stephanie J. Block
abstract: The Broadway revival of “Falsettos,” scheduled for the fall, announces its lead actors.
lead_paragraph: Marvin and Whizzer, meet Christian and Andrew.

headline: 36 Hours in Galway, Ireland
abstract: Welcoming and walkable and filled to the brim with old-fashioned pubs and excellent seafood restaurants, scenic Galway may be Ireland’s most charming city.
lead_paragraph: Welcoming and walkable and filled to the brim with old-fashioned pubs and excellent seafood restaurants, scenic Galway may be Ireland’s most charming city.

headline: Childhood Stress Is Linked to Hardening of the Arteries
abstract: The higher the childhood stress score in a study, the greater the risk for coronary artery calcification in adulthood.
lead_paragraph: Stress in childhood may be linked to hardening of the arteries in adulthood, new research suggests.

headline: Tips for Eagle Spotting, Both Virtually and in Real Life
abstract: If the National Arboretum eagles were not enough for you, here are some more opportunities for eagle watching on the Internet and in real life.
lead_paragraph: Mr. President and The First Lady, the two bald eagles nesting in a tulip poplar in Washington, D.C., made headlines earlier this month after millions of people watched them become parents on a live webcam in the National Arboretum. If you are one of those viewers who just couldn’t get enough, we offer some other cams and real life opportunities for eagle watching at different stages of their life cycles.

headline: How Much Less Are Female Soccer Players Paid?
abstract: Members of the United States women’s national soccer team includes several examples of wage discrimination in their complaint to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
lead_paragraph: Members of the United States women’s national soccer team includes several examples of wage discrimination in their complaint to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

headline: Suspensions Keep Falling in New York City’s Schools
abstract: The use of the punishment declined by 32 percent during the second half of 2015, in part because of curtailed suspensions for defying authority.
lead_paragraph: Suspensions at New York City public schools continued to decline last year, the Education Department announced on Thursday, a key measure of efforts to change school discipline practices.

headline: Baseball’s Enduring Oddities
abstract: You see something new in every baseball game, the saying goes, but we haven’t seen these things in quite a while.
lead_paragraph: Baseball has far more games than other sports, increasing the chances that over the course of time, some truly unusual things will happen. Here is a sampling, meant to both intrigue and amuse. The Hall of Famer Casey Stengel used to impishly proclaim, “You could look it up!” We did.

headline: Review: ‘Darling,’ a Horror Outing
abstract: A young woman accepts an assignment from a wealthy matron to mind an upscale Manhattan apartment, only to unravel, in Mickey Keating’s film.
lead_paragraph: Using the simplest of settings — and familiar genre devices — Mickey Keating’s horror outing “Darling” manages to conjure an effectively unsettling miasma. The story borrows from the Polanski playbook (particularly “Repulsion” and “The Tenant”): A young woman, Darling (Lauren Ashley Carter), accepts an assignment from a wealthy matron (Sean Young) to mind an upscale Manhattan apartment, only to unravel into a homicidal psychopath. A previous employee committed suicide while performing the same work, so perhaps the apartment itself exerts a malevolent force.

headline: Review: In ‘Marinoni,’ a Racing Champion Turned Bicycle Craftsman
abstract: This documentary follows Giuseppe Marinoni, 75, as he travels from his adopted home in Canada to Italy to compete for a speed record in his age group.
lead_paragraph: “Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame,” a documentary by Tony Girardin, opens with Giuseppe Marinoni bent over a bicycle he’s building, welding torch in hand, in his workshop near Montreal. He doesn’t enjoy having the camera around, and hates talking about himself: “The welds can feel the stress,” he complains.

headline: Review: In ‘The Girl in the Photographs,’ Ambitious Goals Slashed
abstract: This horror film, with Wes Craven credited as executive producer, has a hackneyed sleaziness.
lead_paragraph: “The Girl in the Photographs” is an unfortunate example of the expanse that can open between a movie’s ambitions and its execution. Notable only for the involvement of the genre pillar Wes Craven (who died last year and is credited as an executive producer), this sad slasher is as lacking in scares as in ideas.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City. For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Overhaul of Solitary Confinement Is Approved for New York’s Prisons
abstract: A federal judge signed off on a class-action settlement intended to alter the practice, but concerns remain about the state’s ability to carry out the deal.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday formally approved a class-action settlement intended to overhaul the way solitary confinement is used in New York State’s prisons.

lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: In ‘The Ranch,’ Ashton Kutcher and Danny Masterson Reunite as Cowboy Siblings
abstract: Mr. Kutcher is a prodigal son who heads home after a failed football career in this Netflix comedy western, which has flashes of raw emotion.
lead_paragraph: Each episode of “The Ranch” begins with a country song. (Its theme is a cover of “Mammas Don’t Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys,” performed by Shooter Jennings and Lukas Nelson, the sons of Waylon and Willie.) Each one ends with a different country song. But really this sitcom, whose first 10 episodes appear Friday on Netflix, is a country song all the way through.

headline: Review: ‘The Flight Fantastic’ Takes to the Air With the Flying Gaonas
abstract: This documentary, by Tom Moore, explores the career of Tito Gaona and his three siblings, Mexican trapeze artists who brought a new verve to the form.
lead_paragraph: If someone were to call and ask, “Wanna come over and watch our home movies?,” you’d probably think, “Ugh.” But that’s because you don’t know the Gaona family.

headline: Review: ‘Catching the Sun’ Profiles Solar Energy Entrepreneurs and Activists
abstract: This documentary spotlights international efforts to build a green economy through solar power.
lead_paragraph: One notion underlying Shalini Kantayya’s winning documentary, “Catching the Sun,” is that solar power is not only a cleaner alternative to fossil fuels but can also effectively curtail unemployment. The film begins in Northern California, which has experienced at least one refinery accident, and where clean-energy initiatives — Sungevity, Solar Richmond — are hiring and training area residents.

headline: Study Focuses on Repeated Hits, Not Concussions
abstract: Researchers found cumulative number of hits to be a better predictor of later life impairments than measures like concussions.
lead_paragraph: Some scientists studying the relationship between contact sports and memory or mood problems later in life argue that cumulative exposure to hits that cause a snap of the head — not an athlete’s number of concussions — is the most important risk factor. That possibility is particularly worrisome in football, in which frequent “subconcussive” blows are unavoidable.

lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area. Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘Kill Your Friends,’ Corporate Climbing Can Prove Deadly
abstract: The Britpop scene of the ‘90s takes it squarely on the chin in this blisteringly bleak yet richly satisfying poison-pen letter to the music industry.
lead_paragraph: The Britpop scene of the 1990s takes it squarely on the chin in the blisteringly bleak “Kill Your Friends,” a richly satisfying poison-pen letter to the music industry directed by Owen Harris. Written by John Niven, a former artists-and-repertoire man, adapting his own novel, the movie follows the Machiavellian destiny of Steven Stelfox (Nicholas Hoult of “Mad Max: Fury Road”), a ruthless corporate climber at the London record label Unigram.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City. Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘Afternoon,’ Two Men Open Up
abstract: This Tsai Ming-liang film features him and the actor Lee Kang-sheng discussing personal issues in a minimalist setting.
lead_paragraph: “Recently I’ve been getting this strong feeling that I may be dying soon.” The Taiwanese filmmaker Tsai Ming-liang, 58, makes this confession early on in his new picture, the sublimely simple, emotionally charged “Afternoon.” A little over two hours, it documents a fitful conversation between Mr. Tsai and the actor Lee Kang-sheng. About 10 years Mr. Tsai’s junior, Mr. Lee appears in nearly every film Mr. Tsai has made; many of these, including “Goodbye, Dragon Inn” and “What Time Is It There?,” are masterpieces of contemporary Asian cinema.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City. Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tapeworms and Other Parasites Can Make Good Guests
abstract: Some researchers argue that thinking of internal species as enemies, and eradicating them, is a potentially harmful mistake.
lead_paragraph: The kakapo, a large flightless parrot that can live 95 years and perhaps longer, is dangerously close to extinction. Once found throughout New Zealand, the population has dwindled to fewer than 150.

headline: Review: ‘1776,’ a Musical Portrait of Squabbling Politicians
abstract: This stately concert production at City Center, part of Encores!, underscores the agonizing labor that momentous change often involves.
lead_paragraph: Even in times of tumult, history moves at different paces. To see the hit Broadway musical “Hamilton” is to experience the American Revolution as a hotheaded, hotfooted affair, sped forward by impatient firebrands who act as fast they talk.

headline: Review: ‘Miles Ahead,’ an Impressionistic Take on Miles Davis
abstract: Don Cheadle stars in — and directed — this biopic about the jazz trumpeter, who was a sly chameleon, both in his life and in his music.
lead_paragraph: There’s a hopped-up scene in “Miles Ahead,” controlled yet frenzied, when you get why Don Cheadle decided to go for broke. He’s playing Miles Davis (he also directed) and the time is the late 1970s — although it’s also the 1960s. Time and space tend to blur in this movie and while the setting is a ’70s boxing match, a couple of figures from Miles’s past — his wife, his younger self — soon swing in to shake things up. She’s running scared and the 1970s Miles is running amok, but the younger Miles, well, there he is, too, playing it cool in the ring. Music is fighting, at least for this pugilist.
