lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area. Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Growing Mess of the Supreme Court’s Contraception Case
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: The court seems to be trying to find a way out of a case it should never have taken in the first place.
lead_paragraph: What, exactly, was the Supreme Court doing on Tuesday with its bizarre, lengthy, highly unusual order to the parties in a major case involving religious freedom and contraception?

headline: Around Town for April 1-7
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Hitoshi Fugo’s “Flying Frying Pan 1979-1994”
abstract: The photographer spent 15 years photographing a humble iron pan in a variety of abstract ways.
lead_paragraph: The photographer spent 15 years photographing a humble iron pan in a variety of abstract ways.

headline: One Frying Pan, Photographed Over 15 Years
abstract: The conceptual photographer Hitoshi Fugo’s series “Flying Frying Pan 1979-1994” involves many abstract, surprising variations on a single everyday object.
lead_paragraph: The conceptual photographer Hitoshi Fugo’s series “Flying Frying Pan 1979-1994” has a simple premise: a 15-year study of Fugo’s iron pan. He chose the pan as a subject because he thought it would free him from specifics — of time and place, and even of recognizable shape. It also has personal resonance for the artist: He used the pan to prepare many meals for his wife and daughter throughout her childhood.

headline: Rachid Koraichi, Making His Own Language
abstract: In “Love Side by Side With the Soul,” Mr. Koraichi’s first New York solo exhibition, at Aicon Gallery, words are a binder and calligraphy’s all about.
lead_paragraph: Rachid Koraichi, who has been widely exhibited internationally for decades, is only now having his first New York solo exhibition. Born in Algeria in 1947, he came from a family of Quranic scholars and copyists in a Sufi tradition. He trained as a calligrapher before studying painting and printmaking in Paris in the 1970s and has made the written word, as a conveyor of spiritual philosophy, poetry and politics, his primary medium. Just as language serves as a visual binder in many Islamic cultures, so it does in Mr. Koraichi’s formally diverse but completely of-a-piece show, “Love Side by Side With the Soul,” at Aicon Gallery.

headline: Rivers Cuomo of Weezer Taps His Inner Beach Boy
abstract: On his band’s 10th studio album, Mr. Cuomo conjures sun-dappled sounds with influences coming from the city where he lives: Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There aren’t many rock stars patrolling the Ballona Wetlands at 9:30 on a Saturday morning with hopes of training their binoculars on double-crested cormorants. So Rivers Cuomo, the lead singer and songwriter in the clever, hard-edge power-pop band Weezer, was, as he often is, an outlier here on a drizzly March weekend.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 1-7
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Review: ‘Francofonia,’ About World War II Foes Turned Allies, for the Sake of Art
abstract: Alexander Sokurov’s unsettling film examines efforts by the Louvre’s director and a Nazi conservator to protect the Louvre’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The Russian filmmaker Alexander Sokurov has a gift, perhaps unmatched among his international peers, for turning intellectual brooding into visually arresting cinema. He tackles big, capitalized themes — Power, Art, Virtue, Evil — but his films speak in whispers, murmurs and ruminative pauses. They often feel as intimate and inscrutable as diary entries, even when they deal with monstrous public figures like Hitler, Stalin and Hirohito. Mr. Sokurov forgoes sweeping pictorial gestures and period pageantry in favor of quiet lyricism and tight, sometimes claustrophobic compositions. He thinks a lot about history, and in his best work you can hear history thinking.

headline: A Day in the Life of Alaïa’s First Assistant, Illustrated
abstract: The artist and designer Hideki Seo draws his adventures around Paris and in the atelier.
lead_paragraph: For most people — fashion folk included — the house of Azzedine Alaïa is enigmatic. But not for Hideki Seo: the Hiroshima-born, Paris-based artist, who is also a designer in his own right, met Alaïa at Antwerp’s Royal Academy of Fine Arts in 2005, when the couturier reviewed thesis collections, Seo’s among them. Soon after, Alaïa hired him to research Japanese fabrics. Now — a decade later — Seo is Alaïa’s first assistant, responsible for sketching everything from silhouettes to inventive prints, as well as studying materials and their accouterments. Here, he draws a day in his life exclusively for T.

headline: Seven of Zaha Hadid’s Most Striking Designs
abstract: Ms. Hadid’s ambitious architecture spanned the globe. Here’s a look at some of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Hadid’s ambitious architecture spanned the globe. Here’s a look at some of the highlights.

headline: Sip Sake While You Shop at Tokyobike
abstract: Celebrate with Dr. Martens in Williamsburg, try buzzy new Gentle Monster eyewear at Opening Ceremony, and more.
lead_paragraph: You know what they say about April showers. On Thursday, Tokyobike will host a shopping event from 6 to 10 p.m. for the outerwear label the Arrivals, during which you can sip sake and try on a water-repellant bomber ($325) or a waterproof leather moto ($685) that should see you through the new month. At 1 Prince Street.

headline: Review: ‘The Dark Horse’ Dramatizes the Tale of a Chess Coach
abstract: “The Dark Horse,” a film inspired by a documentary, is about Gen Potini, a Maori speed-chess player who used his skill to help young players.
lead_paragraph: “The Dark Horse” rides on the impassioned performance of Cliff Curtis, the Maori actor who plays Genesis (a.k.a. Gen) Potini, a New Zealand chessmaster with bipolar disorder. With a partially shaved head and many extra pounds, Mr. Curtis is barely recognizable from his roles in “Whale Rider” and “Once Were Warriors.” The film, directed and written by James Napier Robertson, is inspired by Jim Marbrook’s 2003 documentary, “Dark Horse,” which focused on Mr. Potini, a speed-chess player who died in 2011.

headline: Review: In ‘Too Late,’ Imitation Is Sincere Flattery
abstract: Noir pays tribute to noir, with respect, in this film by Dennis Hauck, starring John Hawkes as a private investigator determined to avenge a murder.
lead_paragraph: If I were as cynical as the hard-boiled characters of “Too Late,” I might scoff that each scene is overstuffed with fawning references to classic film noir, Quentin Tarantino and pulp novels. Actually, I am that cynical. And yet I still couldn’t help loving almost every moment of the movie.

headline: Reptiles’ Retreat
abstract: When it comes to pets, Ron Peteroy doesn’t get much joy from a cat or a dog. He prefers his geckos — all thousand of them.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to pets, Ron Peteroy doesn’t get much joy from a cat or a dog. He prefers his geckos — all thousand of them.

headline: Lots to Love About a Gecko
abstract: Ron Peteroy says there is a lizard for everyone out there. He should know. He has about a thousand of them.
lead_paragraph: All was quiet in the reptile room of Ron Peteroy’s Staten Island home one recent Wednesday morning, save the soft chirp of a few doomed crickets. But in and around the hundreds of glass tanks and plastic tubs that lined the walls, bulgy-eyed creatures were stirring.

headline: Arrest Ordered for Twice-Convicted Ex-Congressman Mel Reynolds
abstract: The former Chicago-area lawmaker, previously convicted of bank fraud and a sexual relationship with an underage campaign volunteer, is refusing to return from South Africa.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ordered the arrest of Mel Reynolds, a scandal-scarred former congressman, on Thursday, after Mr. Reynolds defied a judge’s order to return to Chicago to face tax charges, saying that he would remain in South Africa for now with his ailing daughter.

headline: Review: From Ailey II, Youthful Promise Caught in a Juvenile Setting
abstract: The dancers, who spend two years with Ailey II before joining the main company, performed new works at the Ailey Citigroup Theater.
lead_paragraph: The dancers in Ailey II are spectacular beings, as proved in a program of new works offered as part of its two-week season at the Ailey Citigroup Theater. But there’s nothing like an evening spent with Ailey II, the younger version of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, to make you appreciate even the tepid, generic choreography sometimes offered by the main company.

headline: Uganda’s Supreme Court Rejects Challenge to Presidential Election
abstract: The challenge by the third-place finisher, Amama Mbabazi, argued that President Yoweri Museveni was not validly elected and that false results had been disseminated.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Uganda’s Supreme Court has rejected a challenge to the presidential election held in February, issuing a ruling on Thursday that secured President Yoweri Museveni a mandate for another five-year term. He has been in office since 1986.

headline: A Teenage Girl Searching for a New Normal
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Families and Family Life', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Gifts', 'Birthdays', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Also, a forgetful birthday pal, problems in a long-distance relationship, and a backdoor invitation.
lead_paragraph: I am a 16-year-old girl who was in a serious car crash. I had to have muscle grafts on my legs that are bulky and very noticeable. I am still trying to get used to the way I look. But I want to be body confident and don’t want to feel as if I have to cover them up in public. I’m nervous that people will ask questions or stare at me. What would be the right response if they do (which they probably will)?

headline: Review: ‘Standing Tall,’ a Boy’s Encounter With the Law
abstract: Emmanuelle Bercot’s film, with Rod Paradot as a violent boy, and Catherine Deneuve as a magistrate, examines France’s approach to juvenile justice.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t any such thing in the world as a bad boy.

headline: Starwood Bidding War Ends Abruptly, Yielding a Merger and a Puzzle
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A consortium led by the Anbang Insurance Group of China withdrew its $14 billion offer with no explanation, clearing the way for Marriott’s offer.
lead_paragraph: Ever since a group led by the acquisitive — and secretive — Chinese firm Anbang Insurance Group raised its bid for Starwood Hotels and Resorts, advisers to the American hotel company were a little wary that its new suitor might not be able to follow through.

headline: Kosher Kilts and Plaid Skullcaps: Scotland’s Jews Get a Tartan
abstract: Rabbi Mendel Jacobs has drawn a wave of attention for his “Jewish Tartan,” a combination of colors from the Scottish saltire flag and the Israeli one.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Jews of Scotland finally have a tartan to call their own. Or, disputatiously, they seem to have two of them.

headline: #OscarsSoWhite Makes a Court Appearance
abstract: A federal judge cites the diversity debate in a ruling involving a defamation suit filed by the music executive Jerry Heller.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The debate over race in Hollywood edged its way into the legal system by way of a judge’s order.

headline: Review: ‘Notfilm’ Tells How Beckett and Keaton Collaborated
abstract: This documentary about the making of the 1965 short movie “Film” features interviews and anecdotes about the two men.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Beckett and Buster Keaton surely possess two of the most photogenic faces of the 20th century, contrasting images of haplessness and stoicism. Beckett’s deeply lined visage, surmounted by a sweep of silver hair, is an emblem of late modernism, a quietly charismatic mask of weary resolve in the face of existential absurdity. Keaton’s smooth brow and melancholy deadpan, customarily shadowed by a porkpie hat, express an ingenious, innocent determination to surmount whatever obstacles the universe imposes.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Broadband Subsidy for Low-Income Households
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The move is aimed at bridging the digital divide at a time when one in five people don’t have broadband Internet access at home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved a $9.25 monthly broadband subsidy to help millions of low-income households connect to the Internet, in a move aimed at bridging the digital divide.

headline: High Lead Levels Found at More Newark Schools
abstract: Nearly a quarter of samples collected in school buildings in the district last week had concentrations above the federal threshold.
lead_paragraph: A new round of testing has found high levels of lead in water at more schools in Newark, including at least two charter schools, according to results the school district released on Thursday.

headline: Friday File: A Household of April Fool’s Jokes
abstract: In the 1890s, The New York Times noted, the number of jokes played “at home and among one’s friends” was a measure of the regard a man was held in.
lead_paragraph: A man who is not made a fool of is no man at all.

headline: ISIS Leader Is My Ex-Husband, Woman Says, but Doubts Remain
abstract: The woman, Saja al-Dulaimi, 28, told the Swedish newspaper Expressen that she married Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in 2008, but experts question her claims.
lead_paragraph: A woman who said she was the ex-wife of the leader of the Islamic State spoke to a Swedish newspaper about their marriage in an interview published on Thursday, but experts and officials expressed doubt that she was ever married to the self-styled caliph of the terror group.

headline: رسالة من مهاجرة سورية إلى الاتحاد الاوروبي
abstract: هربنا من الحرب طلبا للأمان مع عوائلنا. لماذا يجعل الاتحاد الأوروبي حياتنا أكثر بؤسا؟
lead_paragraph: هربنا من الحرب طلبا للأمان مع عوائلنا. لماذا يجعل الاتحاد الأوروبي حياتنا أكثر بؤسا؟

headline: A Syrian Refugee’s Message to the European Union
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Families and Family Life', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: We fled war to find safety with our families. Why is the E.U. making our lives more miserable?
lead_paragraph: IDOMENI, Greece — WHEN we first got here we had money to buy a little food. Now it’s gone. We stand in line for hours for a sandwich. My husband told a journalist recently: “People are fed up. Maybe tomorrow they will break down the gate and flood across the border.” The journalist said, “How many weapons do you have?” If we knew how to carry weapons or wanted to carry weapons we would not have fled Syria. We want peace. We are sick of killing.

headline: More Racist and Homophobic Texts by San Francisco Police Are Found
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Text Messaging', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The disclosure of the messages hit a police department that is already under federal investigation over complaints of bias.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco police officers sent dozens of racist and homophobic text messages in the past several months, even as another group of officers was being investigated by prosecutors for having traded similar messages, the city’s district attorney said Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Nuclear Security Summit, Donald Trump, Kolkata
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: This Week’s Movies | April 1, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Everybody Wants Some!!,” “No Home Movie” and “Miles Ahead.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Everybody Wants Some!!,” “No Home Movie” and “Miles Ahead.”

headline: John Doerr to Step Aside and Become Chairman at Kleiner Perkins
abstract: The move reflects a shift in prioritization of Mr. Doerr’s time from managing the firm to grooming its next generation of leaders.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — John Doerr, one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent venture capitalists, is stepping back from the day-to-day management of his firm, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, in a changing of the guard.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Art Once Hidden From Hitler, Now on View
abstract: The German photographer Elisabeth Hase’s works, including cinematic self-portraits that anticipate those by Cindy Sherman, are being shown in America for the first time.
lead_paragraph: A woman out shopping has fallen — splat! — onto her face on a stairway, hat still primly on head, stocking seams properly straight, purse and one shoe gone astray. She is armored for a foray in search of department store bounty but this photograph is not a decisive moment. It is a bit of role-playing, a self-portrait in disguise, by Elisabeth Hase, a German photographer (1905-1991) who wore shirts and sometimes ties rather than heels and hats and looked down on women trapped in such decorum.

headline: In Denver, Persuading Latino Immigrants to Trust the Tap Water
keywords: ['Water', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Soft Drinks', 'Lead']
abstract: For many Hispanics, drinking soda or bottled water is cultural and a hard habit to break, even if they come to live where the water is clean and healthy.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Maria Cruz stays away from the tap. So does Monserrat Trejo. And then there is Lucero González — also an immigrant from Mexico — who, on a recent afternoon, shoved a shopping cart across the parking lot at Mi Pueblo Market. Inside: Nothing but water. Ninety-six bottles of it.

headline: Isabel Lewis Offers an Immersive Experience at Dia Art Foundation
abstract: Also, Yorgo Alexopoulos combines nature and technology at the Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery and Lygia Pape gets a solo show at Hauser & Wirth in London.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to know what to call installations that you cannot only see, but also hear, feel, taste — even smell.

headline: 400 Million Streams Later, Kanye West’s ‘Pablo’ Gets a Wider Release
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: This rapper’s latest album, “The Life of Pablo,” has been available only on Tidal, and that streaming service has only now revealed numbers indicating its popularity.
lead_paragraph: What makes a successful album in 2016? A No. 1 debut on the Billboard chart? Steady play across streaming services? A hit radio single or a viral music video?

headline: A Swedish-Born Carver’s Celtic Knots and Norse Monsters
abstract: The American Swedish Historical Museum in Philadelphia is exhibiting highly ornamented furniture made a century ago for American industrialists by Karl von Rydingsvard.
lead_paragraph: A forgotten collection of oak furniture by the Swedish-born carver Karl von Rydingsvard goes on view Sunday at the American Swedish Historical Museum in Philadelphia, returning this craftsman to the public eye a century after he briefly rose to fame.

headline: View From Space Hints at a New Viking Site in North America
abstract: The site was identified last summer after satellite images showed possible man-made shapes under discolored vegetation on the Newfoundland coast.
lead_paragraph: A thousand years after the Vikings braved the icy seas from Greenland to the New World in search of timber and plunder, satellite technology has found intriguing evidence of a long-elusive prize in archaeology — a second Norse settlement in North America, further south than ever known.

headline: MoMA Offers Japanese Navigators in an Architectural Firmament
abstract: Subtitled “Toyo Ito, SANAA, and Beyond,” this show at the Museum of Modern Art examines a master architect and those in his aesthetic circle.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Pedro Gadanho, who was then curator of contemporary architecture at the Museum of Modern Art, met with one of Japan’s leading architects, Toyo Ito, about preparing an exhibition on his experimental and organic work and that of the architects in his orbit.

headline: Before the Brussels Attacks, Portents From a Film
abstract: The French director Philippe Faucon discusses his struggles to make his fictional 2012 movie “La Désintégration,” which turned out to be a prescient warning.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the celebrated French director Philippe Faucon was seeking funding for his 2012 film, “La Désintégration,” or “The Disintegration,” about a group of frustrated young French Muslim men who attack the NATO headquarters in Brussels, he kept meeting resistance from investors.

headline: High-End Works Toying With Politically Loaded Signifiers
abstract: An exhibition of gaudy, cartoonish and technically impressive works by the design team Studio Job.
lead_paragraph: In “Monkey Business,” a 2013 sculpture by the design team Studio Job, a life-size, long-tailed primate covered in a granular coat of tiny crystals and sporting a gold-tasseled red fez straddles a treasure chest. The mischievous creature is starting to lift its lid with the fingers of one hand, affording a glimpse of the golden glow within. It’s an Aesopian allegory, the monkey a symbol of greed, temptation and addiction — as in having a monkey on your back.

headline: ‘Her Love Is Still There’
abstract: Eddy Van Calster’s wife worked at Brussels Airport. After the terrorist attack there, Mr. Van Calster was told she had survived. Then the story changed.
lead_paragraph: Eddy Van Calster’s wife worked at Brussels Airport. After the terrorist attack there, Mr. Van Calster was told she had survived. Then the story changed.

headline: Despite Wall St. Wavering, Merger Market Is Largely Intact
abstract: The first quarter of 2016 was a fairly weak time for deal making, yet somehow the numbers came out all right.
lead_paragraph: By many measures, the markets should have made for a fairly weak quarter in deal making.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Beverly Cleary, Nearing 100, Is to Be Celebrated at Symphony Space
abstract: This event, a fund-raiser for Team First Book New York City, will feature actors, authors and artists reading from, and talking about, her books.
lead_paragraph: How do you interest a child in a centenarian’s birthday party? You can’t say that it has magic tricks. Or a video arcade. Or paintball.

headline: The Danger of a Runaway Antarctica
abstract: Despite environmental progress, the threat of rising seas must be countered by increased international cooperation and leadership from the United States.
lead_paragraph: Here are some disturbing things we have learned since December, when the nations of the world reached a landmark agreement in Paris to lower greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Bill Clinton Rallies Some of His Old New York Friends
abstract: An ex-president crisscrossed Manhattan hosting campaign events with union members and minority voters on behalf of Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: In the years since he left the White House, former President Bill Clinton has become a New Yorker. He has an office in Harlem, sits in courtside seats at Nets games and spends summers days in exclusive Hamptons enclaves.
